I get horrible shaving bumps in the summer, and this year they even came from waxing! I've tried every remedy of salicylic acid, glycolic acid, and witch hazel. I switched soaps and exfoliate and moisturize daily; doesn't matter, always bumps that get infected. This is the first thing that ACTUALLY worked, and I was so happy I could cry. Shaving or waxing, just cleanse the area after and apply this. I do a few spritzes, then rub it in really well with my fingers.Note: it smells rather terrible, but that's a small price to pay for something that finally provided relief. There is enough alcohol in this that it does burn, however not enough to dry out my sensitive skin with 2x daily use.It's like aftershave for girls, or for guys who want something more natural. THANK YOU so much for this product. I give it my most enthusiastic recommendation.

I'm really happy with this tumbler, as it lives up to the promises. The borosilicate glass allows strength without adding weight, and the double wall keeps hot coffee hot for about an hour, and it gets to lukewarm in about 2-3 hours depending on how full the cup is. I haven't timed it with cold drinks yet, though it does succeed in not forming condensation on the outside. It did form condensation within the double walls, which I did not expect, but I guess that's ok. The one thing I would change is to create a vacuum inside between the two glass layers.The silicone lid is a standard size, so if you have old lids from other to-go coffee mugs, they will fit this too, which is nice. I'm NOT a fan of the taste of silicone, so I use a narrow coffee straw. One more idea for the manufacturer would be to create a lid with a silicone seal where it connects, but borosilicate double-wall glass for the top where your lips touch to drink. That would be AMAZING.Considering the quality, utility, and the price, I'd say this tumbler is an excellent value, especially if you want something to double for both hot and cold use. Recommended.

These are made of thin material, so I'd be very gentle with washing so that they can last, but my goodness they are comfy. The lace isn't scratchy, the waistband is unobtrusive, and they fit perfectly according to measuring my hips and using a generic online sizing chart. The material feels like cotton but the softness of a rayon and the stretch of a spandex, and it's breathable and just lovely. Highly recommended!

These are comfortable, somewhat utilitarian panties for everyday if you prefer the hipster cut. It has a low rise, only moderate seat coverage, and the leg openings don't surge up super high on the sides like a bikini cut. Kind of like a cuter, younger non-granny-panty. Here's the thing. You can get the 6 pack of these for $9, so just be aware of that. I know these are the 8-pack, but it's kind of not worth it if you look at the per-panty price.

I absolutely adore this ring, but the title is highly misleading, claiming "comfort fit," when in fact, this is a traditional band, not a comfort-fit band. You'll need to order your normal size (not 1/2-1 size smaller as is needed for comfort fit), as this is a traditional pipe-cut band. So disappointed.

Not a comfort fit band on this ring at all. This is a traditional or pipe cut style band. Comfort fit rings are rounded on the inside where they touch your finger, and you have to get 1/2-1 size smaller. For this one, you would need to order your traditional size since, again, this is not a comfort fit band on this ring. Very misleading. Disappointed.

These are very decent silicone pads for the price. If anything, they are better as trivets because they are quite stiff. If you want a silicone mat to use as a potholder or jar opener, you'd be much better off with ones that are flexible. These are stiff as plastic.

These are fantastic little things. Use them before bed to wake up with literally glowing skin. They have a soft scent of exotic fruits and are gentle enough to use daily on my moderately sensitive skin. Here are some of the ways I've personally used these and found them to be effective:(1) Use as all over exfoliator at night(2) Use as targeted treatment for acne(3) Remove fine lines around eyes & mouth(4) Exfoliate cracked lips before bed(5) Apply to just-shaved skin (bikini area) to prevent razor bumps / razor rash(6) Apply to existing razor bumps(7) Apply several times daily to help release severely ingrown hairsIf you want a gentle yet effective everyday chemical exfoliant / almost a toner for sensituve skin, this is perfect.(Side note: I like to apply this first in the morning, followed with a spritz all over the face of Thayer Rose Witch Hazel also here on Amazon to mousturizing, exfoliate, and keep a matte finish without the use of makeup. They make an amazing combo.)

After going no shampoo for about 6 months (using Wen knockoffs), I got my very itchy dry scalp that comes a few times a year. I gave this a try, hoping that the minerals would be soothing, and it worked! This is by far and away the best "natural" way to clean my hair. No parabens, no sulfates. The best part is that because oils are removed with clay, I can still go 3 days between cleansing my hair, just like I did with the cleansing conditioner. (By the way, I used Hair One in Olive purchased here on Amazon as well.)

(1) There was NO decorative gift box as was promised in both the photo and product description. (2) They arrived with the bag torn, and the gummies all dried out and terrible.Yes, this is one of the world's best gummy brands, but this item was absolutely not worth it.

I wear size L pants, and this size L belt is very uncomfortable, in spite of the elastic. It's a decent belt otherwise, though the shiny faux patent leather does make it look a bit cheap compared to the photograph. In all fairness, this is a cheap belt, and you get what you pay for, but for the price, it's still a good value. Just be sure to order up a size from what you usually wear.

The scoby arrived healthy, active, ready to brew, and safely shipped in some starter tea. I also added 1/4 c distilled vinegar to the first brew to prevent mold. The flavor of kombucha achieved with this scoby made with green tea and honey was INCREDIBLE. Now I understand why people brew their own. The freshness and flavor are unbeatable, and this Jun has a lovely complex and well-rounded character.The scoby sent to me was the diameter of a quart mason jar, and ~1/2" thick, just right really. I was able to grow a very large baby from it in my first brew in less than 7 days, and this cultures seems quite vigorous.Absolutely love. Highly recommended.

The color on this is good, and it lasts reasonably for a gloss, but I can't stand the sticky. It also does nothing for moisturizing your lips, just makes an uncomfortable, sticky mess.If you like glosses in general, give it a try. But if you're looking for moisture and comfort, try a balm instead.
These are a great idea, but my chickens won't eat them! They are too lifeless and crunchy. Going to try rehydrating these in water to see if the hens like them better that way.

These are an okay substitute for the Beauty Blender. You can use the same techniques, and it does need to be wet first.Limitations:Not as soft and squishy as the BB.Texture not as smooth as BB.Harder to squeeze water out than BB.Absorbs more product than BB.So these are good if you're on a budget, but they are not close enough to the real Beauty Blender to call a perfect dupe.HOWEVER, these are great to learn on and practice with before investing in the real deal. Also, the real Beauty Blender is MUCH less expensive when purchased here on Amazon. Instead of $30 for one, sometimes there are pairs for $22-$25 on here. I recommend these for learning, but save up for a real BB, and save $ buying it here on Amazon.

I saw this in a movie of all places, and decided to try it. Now I use it every day and don't know how I ever lived without it! Because it is oil-free but non-drying, it is suitable for all skin types.Pros:Controls acne without drying the skin.Light scent of cucumber and green tea.Soothes redness.Really does prevent acne if used daily.Cons:If you don't like scent, you might not like it. However, the scent is VERY mild and comes from plants, so it is unlikely to cause an allergy. But those who prefer NO scent may wish to pass on this one.

I use this for highlighting cheekbones, above brow arch, and at the center of each eyelid. It works beautifully. I find it's best applied with two fingers, or a very soft blush brush. I'm a fan of fingers with this product for over foundation. If you want to get a glow all over without sparkles, try using a brush to apply this all over, but UNDER your foundation. It makes for a lovely, radiant effect.Shimmery and pearly without looking like glitter, goes on easily, and the pan lasts forever. Highly recommended.Good low price dupe alternative to Hourglass Ambient Light powders, IF you use this under your foundation, over moisturizer/primer and concealer.

This is the only lip liner I use. Experts recommend matching your liner to your natural lip color. I tried EVERYTHING and couldn't get a good match. This liner goes on clear, so it's a perfect match to any and all lipcolors! Plus with this, you can have just ONE lip liner no matter how many lipstick shades you own, saving you time, space, and money.

I love how this brush is protected inside a cap so it's safe to take in your purse! I like the way it applies color to the lips. Makes application on chapped, cracked, or dry lips a thousand times easier. Plus color lasts longer when applied with a brush. (I don't know why, I just notice that it does!)Just apply balm or conditioner to lips first, then apply lipcolor with this brush, blot, and repeat the color again.

My lips are constantly dry, chapped, and peeling during the frigid, dry winters where I live. As a result, even the creamiest lipsticks show off the horrible cracks in my lips.Colorburst Lip Butter to the rescue!I love this product and have collected nearly every shade. It acts like a balm, nourishing and hydrating the lips, but with color that doesn't catch on the cracks and dry areas! There's no smell or taste, except a hint of Shea butter. Also, if used over a Chapstick or other conditioner, the medium color lasts for several hours. You don't need a mirror to apply, and it doesn't get on my teeth or smear.I recommend going to the product website to see the color swatches and choose the shades you like, then coming back here to check the prices. This shade (sugar frosting) is MUCH less expensive here on Amazon.This is for the Sugar Frosting shade, but really it applies to all of them. I have almost every color! Other favorites: Gumdrop (for the lilac lip trend), The berry shades, the peachy shades, even the reds!Highly recommended.

This root booster was ok, but it made my hair too oily and heavy. I only tried it after seeing it featured in a "must have" article for products to help you wash your hair every other day. (Since daily washing is pretty damaging.) If you have really thick or curly hair, you might like this.If you have thin or straight hair, it might feel too oily. Instead, I recommend the John Frieda root booster in the pale blue bottle. That one I use every day. It gives volume and helps revive hair on non-wash days.

These are my new favorite winter socks, and I will be ordering more. Where I live, temperatures often drop to -10 to -20F, and it's hard to stay warm even indoors.I love these because they are soft and thick, and the little loops inside wick moisture away so your feet don't get sweaty in them. They are a little big for my feet (women's size 10, men's size 8.5), but I can live with that.If your feet are near the above range or larger, I HIGHLY recommend these fabulous socks!

I ordered 4 of these pencils through Amazon, and two of them arrived damaged during shipping, with all the color rubbed off the end. When I tried to see if they were salvageable by sharpening, I learned that they are impossible to sharpen, even though they are made for it. The wood peels away just like a pencil, but the colors are so creamy that they just jam up in the sharpener, leaving you with an empty top when you pull it out of the sharpener.Pros:Very pigmented color.Extremely creamy texture.Cons:Very fragile.Can't be sharpened due to creamy texture.I did also try Nyx's mechanical pencil (a twist up version) in Silky Cashmere, and it is phenomenal. Long lasting, waterproof, no irritation on the waterline.I love Nyx products, but the Slide On Pencil was an abject fail. Try the Mechanical Pencil instead. That is just as creamy, plus it's long wearing, comfortable, and waterproof.

This is a really nice, low-wattage, non-light heat lamp that conveniently fits into any standard light bulb fixture.I got this to warm our chicken coop when it drops below 0F here. We've tested it a lot, and it provides steady, gentle warmth, exactly as we needed. You're not supposed to heat the coop, but using this, it makes it as if there are just a few more warm bodies in there without risking messing up their metabolism for the cold.I have no idea if this really stimulates plant growth, but I suspect it would. It simulates gentle, natural heat like a rock that has been warmed in the sun.

These were the only socks from this line that I could find with mereno wool (here on Amazon anyway.) They do pill after the first wash, but they are VERY soft for wool, and are nice and padded on the bottom. Great for wearing with boots or other winter shoes.I'm hoping they'll add more color choices for the wool blend socks. The others in this line don't have wool, though they are cute colors.If you need the warmth of wool but don't like the scratchiness, these wool blend socks by Steve Madden are a great choice! They keep your feet warm without making them sweaty, have sturdy construction, and are thick on the bottom. I'd recommend them to anyone trying to keep toasty in the polar vortex!

These fingerless gloves are ok. I was disappointed because they are both small and thin. For taller customers, you'll probably want to find something bigger. They also do not protect the thumb at all, as seems to be the style of fingerless mitts these days.They are lighter weight made with a very fine yarn, making these appropriate for spring or fall. For winter, you'll want something warmer. (Unless you're in SoCal or Florida! Then these would be perfect for winter.)I would recommend this if you have slender hands and need something light and breathable.

These are actually really nice gloves, very cute. The problem is that they run VERY small. They are like children's size, which needs to be updated in the product description. Like they would fit a tween girl, but not a teen or adult.The fur is faux that's pulled off nicely. It's soft and looks real enough from a distance. The gloves themselves are average thickness for a fine-gauge knit glove. Not to thick, not too thin.Just be aware that these are TINY! They would fit women or girls who are 5' tall and smaller. If you are over 5' or 5'1", these are likely going to be too small.

After doing a great deal of research into what would be best to help my early fine lines around my eyes, I knew I needed hyaluronic acid, peptides, and retinol. I also knew I wanted NO parabens.I absolutely adore this product. It soaks into the skin quickly, and the best part is that the HA helps whatever product you use right after it to be pulled into the skin as well.I ordered this to use as a daytime treatment for around my eyes only, but now I use it morning and night on all of my face, and even on my hands! In the morning, it goes all over my face followed by a gel moisturizer by garnier. At night, it goes around my eyes, followed by Watts Beauty retinol serum, and on the backs of my hands, followed by a cocoa butter moisturizing cream.It's too early to tell how it will affect my eyes, but based on research and the ingredients, I'm certain the combination will help. On my hands, however, I noticed a difference within just a few days! Normal moisturizing with heavy emollients is not enough in our cold, dry Montana winters, but by using this HA serum followed by the emollient cream, my hands are happy and youthful again!Don't be afraid to later your products!! This can be used by itself, but it's excellent for pulling other products down I to deeper layers of the skin.Highly recommended.For the record, I purchased from Direct 2u Wholesale, and was very happy with their service. I will be ordering again.

This first college edition textbook for Intermediate Microeconomics is good, I give it that. It does a decent job in taking a topic that is mind-numbingly confusing and making it marginally understandable.However, it's only slightly better than Intermediate Microeconomics: A Modern Approach (Eighth Edition) by Hal R. Varian, who also does as good a job as can be expected of explaining the same mind-numbing material. This title only wins the "slightly better" endorsement because of the prettier graphics and more frequent side-notes. However, the concepts are EXACTLY the same, only slightly differing examples with fewer pictures in the Varian version.Considering the astronomical difference in price, this sparkly new title just isn't worth it. How are students supposed to afford this? Unless your professor makes this title absolutely mandatory, I say go with the Varian book instead. You will learn all the exact same things, and save yourself a lot of $$$.

Ok, let me start by saying this this IS going to be painful, especially the first time. However, it is very akin to waxing in terms of pain, only you have complete control and can kind of ease into it. The first pass is the worst; grit your teeth and get through it, and as you go, this skin becomes desensitized and it dulls to little tugging pricks.I found it most effective to go in the correct direction (as shown in the manual) first, but then come back and hold the device in the opposite direction to catch all the stubborn hairs that were lying too flat. This works because then the barrel is brushing the opposite direction, lifting the hairs and allowing them to snag and be pulled. I also found that the manual's claim that moving in small circles is more comfortable to be true.The device did not clog up with hairs, but you have to stop and brush the hairs off periodically, as it spits the pulled hairs out the back towards your feet as you move from ankle upward. I had no trouble with bikini area. It is supposed to hurt more, but maybe I had just gotten so used to it by the time I got that far up the leg.Finally, the ideal length of the hairs stated in the manual is true! You only need 0.5-2.0mm. I found that in the areas where I had shaved and were the correct length, the epilator was MUCH more effective, pulling most of the hairs in only one or two passes. The longer areas (1/2-3/4") were much more difficult. So for best results, I would recommend shaving 1 week prior to use, so that the hairs will all be the most ideal length.Overall, one of the best purchases I've ever made! For less than half the cost of a single waxing at a salon, you can do it at home, and do it over and over! If you hate shaving or struggle with ingrowns, this epilator is more than worth the investment! Like with waxing, it will be less painful each time. Yes, it hurts. Yes, it's SO worth it!!

I take these for what's in them, and I started them a month before my knee surgery where they had to saw off and bolt down a section of my shin. It's major bone breakage, and I had a hard time after getting the first one done, so wanted to be more nutritionally prepared this time around.I'm 1 month post-op, and my knee/leg is healing WAY ahead of schedule, and I was able to get off painkillers entirely after only two weeks. I feel the addition of this supplement really did help with my bone and other healing.The only drawback is that these are REALLY hard to take. They upset my stomach something terrible, causing an hour or more of nausea every time. I actually ended up vomiting every time I tried to take them on a light or empty stomach, or before eating. After taking them with my biggest meal of the day did not solve the problem, I have begun taking this right before bed. No noticing the nausea while I'm asleep!So, these can be very difficult to tolerate, but they are very much worth it if you can keep them down. I wish there were some way to buffer them to reduce the nausea. Any ideas?

My old boy is getting to be an old-man-cat, and since he hasn't been feeling well lately, I decided to look for some cat-vitamins for him.I actually decided to try these after seeing them elsewhere online, and was pleased to find them available here on Amazon.These did the trick! He loves the flavor and begs for these, and they put the pep back in his step! I wish I had started my cat on these years ago.Great investment to improve the quality of life for your senior cat! Thank you!!

I loved this book!  I wasn't sure what to expect, but since it was KU, decided to take a chance.  I am so glad I did!  This is a well written contemporary romance that drew me right it.  I am really looking forward to reading future books by this author.

This is a heartwarming book that made me smile.  If you are looking for a fun contemporary romance, you have found it in this book.  While it is an adult book, it is a clean romance and one that you can share with your teens.

This book is another winner that I loved.  If you like snarky humor, you will love this series - I laughed until I cried....literally.  I read this while waited for my car and kept getting strange looks from someone else in the waiting room.  There's just no easy way to explain this author's books.  I just love her sarcastic and snarky humor. This is a must read for fans of the genre.

Another winner in the series.  I literally laughed until I cried through most of the book.  If you're looking for a funny book that you will love, this is it.  The author is very witty, funny and full of sarcasm as this series perfectly showcases.  This is a must read for fans of the genre.

Wow.  Just, Wow....I loved this book - it picks up right where 34.5 left off and throws you into a whirlwind story that will have you flying through the pages as quickly as possible to see what happens next. The author made me feel like I was experiencing the tale along with the characters and feeling their emotions.  If you are a fan of the Rose Gardner series, you will love this book.  And if you're not, do yourself a favor and start the series with the first book  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0058UXHHK/ref=series_dp_rw_ca_1.  You will be glad you did.

I loved this book - it's another winner in the Beachcomber books and starts a new series by the same title. Shana and Dane are thrown into an investigation into threats against one of Dane's old friends. Shana gets on board, but is then forced to make a choice between working with Dane or Scotland Yard.Dane, Acer, Cap, and Shana begin a complex investigation that brings danger to their door. Along the way, Dane adopts a stray, Reggie. Reggie added an interesting dynamic and I'm hoping he continues in future books.This is a fast paced romantic suspense that fans of the genre will love. While it is part of a series, it is a stand alone novel.

I loved this book and was hooked from page one and stayed engaged until the very last page. It follows a woman, Nicole, who has hidden from her prior life for the past 15 years. Suddenly, it seems that she has been found. But who has found her? She struggles with trying to determine if she is in danger while also trying to figure out how to get off the island. While she realizes she should leave, she doesn't want to shed this life and give up her friends and the home she established. I loved the characters, especially Nicole. The author made me care about her and want her to be able to have what she wants. Additionally, the island played such an integral role, it was almost as though it was a character in its own right. This is a must read book and I loved it so much that I have added the author to my must read authors' list.

This is a great collection of short stories by some of my favorite authors. While the stories are short on length, they are long on entertainment. Each of the tales left me with a smile on my face. My favorite story in the collection is "Organized for Christmas Wishes". It will restore you faith in humanity and help you find the Christmas spirit.....if only it was a true story.If you are looking for a heartwarming collection that will make you smile, you have found it in this collection.

I really loved this book - very sexy romantic suspense. I really enjoyed the interplay between Blake and Hadley. Hadley is a country music star whose life is threatened. Blake is tasked, against his will, with keeping her safe. What follows leads to romance and a horrific crime. This book kept me engaged until the very last page. If you enjoy romantic suspense, you will love this book.Just a note for parents that this one is not for teens. Some of the language is course and the subject matter is very adult

I loved this book - it's a great addition to the series. In this novel, Maggie realizes that she needs someone to help her care for her niece when she is discharged from the hospital. Her aunts "help" her with this decision, which leads to lots of awkward and funny situations. As Maggie deals with this, she starts to examine her life choices while also dealing with her secret life as a hitwoman.This is a wonderful book that I highly recommend to fans of the genre. While it is a stand alone book, you will enjoy it so much more if you read them all.
I love this series!  Fun romantic suspense that will keep you hooked.

Wow, what a phenomenal series!  This is a trilogy that grabbed my attention from the very first page and kept it until the very last page of the last book.  It is a fast paced and well constructed romantic suspense/thriller that was so good that I was sorry when it ended.  Each book focuses on two people with supporting characters in common over the three books.  Each book is a stand alone novel, but you will appreciate it so much more if you read them as the author intended.This author was new to me, but I have added her to my must read authors' list.  She is a very talented writer and if you haven't yet read anything by her, you are missing out.

Wow, what a phenomenal series!  This is a trilogy that grabbed my attention from the very first page and kept it until the very last page of the last book.  It is a fast paced and well constructed romantic suspense/thriller that was so good that I was sorry when it ended.  Each book focuses on two people with supporting characters in common over the three books.  Each book is a stand alone novel, but you will appreciate it so much more if you read them as the author intended.This author was new to me, but I have added her to my must read authors' list.  She is a very talented writer and if you haven't yet read anything by her, you are missing out.

Wow, what a phenomenal series!  This is a trilogy that grabbed my attention from the very first page and kept it until the very last page of the last book.  It is a fast paced and well constructed romantic suspense/thriller that was so good that I was sorry when it ended.  Each book focuses on two people with supporting characters in common over the three books.  Each book is a stand alone novel, but you will appreciate it so much more if you read them as the author intended.This author was new to me, but I have added her to my must read authors' list.  She is a very talented writer and if you haven't yet read anything by her, you are missing out.

Wow, what a phenomenal series!  This is a trilogy that grabbed my attention from the very first page and kept it until the very last page of the last book.  It is a fast paced and well constructed romantic suspense/thriller that was so good that I was sorry when it ended.  Each book focuses on two people with supporting characters in common over the three books.  Each book is a stand alone novel, but you will appreciate it so much more if you read them as the author intended.This author was new to me, but I have added her to my must read authors' list.  She is a very talented writer and if you haven't yet read anything by her, you are missing out.

Once again, the author has outdone herself in this delightful historical romance. Hannah is learned woman in the Scotland of long ago, when women of the gentry were expected to be meek and mild and, most definitely not educated. Despite feeling very plain, she has numerous bids for her hand in marriage (and her dowry). Alexander is delighted when she accepts his bid, but is flummoxed by her behavior and insistence at being included in running the keep. These two strangers, though legally wed, must find a way to work together to stop an untenable horror from destroying all that they hold dear.The author has created characters with depth that you can't help but fall in love with. Add in a horrific problem and the author's masterful storytelling style, and you have an exceptional book. If you love historical romance, you will love this book. And if you don't, this book just might change your mind.
This is one of my favorite series - it's fun, funny, and plenty of mystery and suspense.  You can't go wrong with this series - I love it and it is one of the few series that I will pre-order.
Loved it!

I just love this series - it has it all - a mystery with lots of ghosts and a hint of romance. Add in a great story, and you've got a wonderful book. Verity can see ghosts, well, mostly one ghost, Frankie, but he helps her see other ghosts. Ellis, her former fiance's brother, can't see them, but believes her and has experienced a poltergeist with her. Ellis is also a cop and helps Verity try to solve a murder. If you love paranormal mystery with a touch of humor and romance, you will love this book. While it is the second book in the series, it is a stand alone book. I strongly recommend this to fans of the genre.

I loved this book so much that I was sorry when it ended. It grabbed me from the first page and kept me turning pages late into the night because I couldn't put it down.Mia is a quirky geek IT girl. While brilliant, she has a very limited ability to interact with other people, especially men. So when the new head of security, Jake, arrives, she is at a loss as to how to talk to him. Add security problems at her job that keeps him in her orbit, and many funny interactions follow. Throw a murder into the mix and Mia seems to be in over her head.This is a funny and smart chick lit mystery. I love having a heroine that is smart, especially when she is thrown together with a hot security chief. I am really looking forward to the next book in the series. More Mia and Jake, please...... I have added this author to my must read authors' list. If you are a fan of Julie Moffett's Lexi Carmicheal series, you will love this one. This is a must read.Thank you to Netgalley for providing a complementary ARC in exchange for an honest review.

First of all, let me say what a striking cover this is! It is one of the best covers I've seen in a while. As for the story, it is a bit of a departure from the team this series has focused on. David is undercover DEA but has some common ties to Hunter and the guys from books 1-3. This could definitely be read as a standalone though if you haven't read the other books.One main difference in this story, other than the length, is that it focuses on a married couple with children. Over the last few years, they have drifted apart as his job has increasingly monopolized David's time and Lori has gotten caught up in her resentment of it. Both of them have begun to notice the problems but don't know how to fix them. As is typical, they have been neglecting the intimate aspects of their marriage. David takes some time off work to remind Lori how he feels about her and how much he desires her. The problems occur when his work unexpectedly bleeds into his home and Lori's life could be the cost.I thought this was a very realistic representation of how couples can get after years of complacency. Their way of reconnecting was spicy and fun. I will be looking forward to the next offshoot novella. The preview was interesting.

This story is book two in the Men of Mercy series, and oh what men they are...whew! While this could definitely be read as a standalone, I highly recommend reading book one first. You will love it, so start there. Resurrection River focuses on Ranger, the brother of the hero from book one, Hunter. The relationship between Ranger and Amy started long before this book, but somewhere along the line it got messed up. That didn't stop the two from having feelings for each other, although Amy's marriage to Ranger's best friend does keep them from acting on those feelings...at least until he dies. Ranger had to deliver the news of his friend's death, and steps up to take care of Amy and her baby. Amy wants to be with Ranger, but feels guilt. The two clash frequently over Amy's doubts, but when dangerous things begin to happen surrounding her, Ranger is determined not to ever leave her side regardless of what she wants or who else wants her.I loved this story just as much as book one, maybe even more. Ranger was totally swoon worthy, and Amy was spunky and determined. When this couple gets hot and bothered, serious sparks fly. I love them and the other men from Ranger's team. I can't wait to see who gets the next story! I'm hoping it's Merc!I received an early copy for review from the author.

Having read and loved the first two books in this series, I didn't hesitate to jump when the author offered an ARC for this story. I'll start by saying that this book is very different from its predecessors. It focuses on the brothers, Jared and Hoyt who were raised mountain backwoods by a family of criminals. Jared is finally ready to try to take out his aunt's criminal operation even though he knows she and her people will kill him and Hoyt on sight. What he doesn't count on is encountering the one person worth saving in the whole mountain community, a girl who saved him first long ago, Sparrow. Sparrow feels trapped by her lack of education and money. She longs for a different life, and Jared convinces her to risk her life and escape with him. Unfortunately, circumstances cause him to mistrust her, and he then turns on Sparrow. Her existence becomes less desirable than what she already had. I have to say that Jared made made furious several times over his treatment of Sparrow. I wanted her to cut him off, but her kind nature and lack of worldview showed, and she was too quickly forgiving. In the end, Jared does get a big wake up call, and I was happy about that. I definitely like them as a couple because she gives his life the positive softer aspects it desperately lacks, and she has the forgiving spirit necessary for dealing with his quick temper.Now, as for Hoyt, he got a lot of page time in this story too, and his association (not quite a relationship yet) with Hayden progresses as well. Unfortunately, a lot happens to change Hoyt from his usual easygoing self. Overall, this story was emotionally tougher than the others in my opinion. I am definitely ready to read more about Hoyt. He needs a happily ever after more than anyone.

I was completely unfamiliar with Tess Diamond when I was offered an ARC for review, but the book description sounded interesting enough for me to give it a try. I actually had already downloaded another book to read first, but once I read the first couple of paragraphs in Dangerous Games, I was intrigued enough to keep reading.The story begins when Maggie Kincaid is recruited to help with the investigation into the kidnapping of a senator's teenage daughter. Maggie was formerly with the FBI but had wit a couple of years previously due to a negotiation that went wrong. She blamed herself, and after surviving a kidnapping as a child, she couldn't deal with her failure to bring a victim home. She never wanted to be involved in that type of situation again, but with medical issues making recovering the victim even more urgent, she wasn't able to refuse.Despite facing ridicule from former co-workers, stonewalling by the victim's father, and the cocky interference of Jake O'Connor, Maggie doggedly pursues answers. Without giving too much away, I will just say that I enjoyed the chemistry between Jake and Maggie, especially when he was trying to get a rise out of her. The story was well written and gave just enough details to draw you into the story but also keep you guessing. It did end with a pretty decent cliffhanger, but my understanding is that book two will follow close behind this one. I will definitely be keeping an eye out for it!

I have really enjoyed The Colton's of Oklahoma series. Throughout the series, little questions and suspicions kept popping up about Greta. Finding out about Greta's "evil twin" aft the end of the last book was a shocker as was who took a risk to get Greta out of trouble...her fiance's brother. Tyler was super sexy and completely blunt about his desire for Greta. His compete lack of pretense seemed to both catch Greta off guard and also turn her on. It doesn't take long for Tyler to find out what has been going on in Greta's family and discover why she is in danger. He is interested in her although not yet willing to determine how much. He decides to protect her as best he can and figure out the rest later. With Tyler and her brothers all looking out for her, Greta feels safe but discovers her twin can still get to her. The twin wants to steal her life, and Greta is not sure if anyone would even know the difference. It is up to Tyler to prove her wrong.I thought this was a great way to wrap up the stories of the Colton siblings. I was happy to see Greta ditch her fiance and find someone who was more of a match for her.I received an ARC from Net Galley for review.

This is the third book in this series, but while I think reading the previous two prior to reading this one would be helpful, it is definitely not necessary in order to enjoy this story.  While many of my favorite characters from books one and two made small appearances, this book primarily focused on Jake. After having lost his left foot and hand while serving in the Army, Jake has built up his own security and investigations company. A famous pro football player hires Jake to find out who is harassing his cousin, a young lady who is confined to her apartment by her overwhelming fears. Jake begins communicating with the young lady, Natalie, through text and quickly finds himself attracted to her quirky humor and angered by the events that have predicated her fear. He is determined to make things better for her in any way he can, and finds himself drawn closer and closer to her. Even though Natalie can't even bring herself to let Jake in her home at first, it doesn't keep this story from being extremely sexy. Let's just say they get really creative until they finally get together physically, that's when the sparks really begin to fly. Unfortunately, whoever is targeting Natalie is covering tracks very well. When the truth comes out and all the betrayals are revealed, it may be the ultimate setback which keeps Natalie locked away forever.I've enjoyed all three books in the series. I hope there are more to come, especially the story of Sabrina and Kaga!I received an ARC for review from Net Galley.

is was the twenty seventh book I've read by Allison Brennan, so I guess you could say I'm a huge fan. This particular series is absolutely my favorite. Just as a note, this is definitely not a standalone. It is book ten in the series, and each book builds on the previous one. Actually, in my opinion, you get the best reading experience by first reading the Evil trilogy and then the FBI trilogy. These two series help familiarize you with the Kincaid and Rogan families. They also take you through everything that happens to Lucy Kincaid, the events that shape who she is. Having this background information just makes the Lucy series ten times better.This story has Lucy and Sean tracking prison escapee Nicole Rollins, a murderer they helped apprehend in the previous book. Lucy and Sean are FINALLY engaged ( yes, I've been waiting for that for a long time), but there is no time to celebrate. DEA and FBI agents are being murdered, and all hands are on deck working around the clock to recapture Rollins. Sean and Lucy are pulled in different directions, but try to connect as much as possible. Unfortunately, things only get worse when Kane, Sean's brother, disappears in Mexico. Sean knows he has to go find Kane, but hates to leave knowing Lucy is likely a target for Rollin's violence. He enlists the help of a trusted colleague to watch over Lucy and sets out for Mexico.Lucy is working non-stop. Information is leaking from someone within the joint task force. The leak forces Lucy to question everyone she knows and works with. No one is above suspicion other than a couple of close friends. Lucy's brother, Jack, also arrives in town to help out.Personally, this was my favorite Lucy story to date. The action and suspense were continuous, the depth of the relationship between Lucy and Sean is beautifully depicted, and Jack and Kane ( two of my favorites) are front and center for much of the story.  I truly can't wait for Kane and Siobhan to get their own story.  I'm completely addicted to the Kincaids and the Rogans.I received an ARC for review from Net Galley.

Mary Burton has long been one of my favorite authors. I especially enjoyed the Senseless duo and the Texas Rangers Trilogy. Honestly, I thought the first two books in the Morgans series were okay, but much more procedural than previous novels. Happily, this story picked up the suspense. While there is a romantic element, the Morgan's are not exactly an emotional family, Alex least of all. Rather than out of control chemistry, this is a couple of fully closed off individuals who gradually find their way into each other's lives and eventually each other's arms.Leah was attacked several years ago by her ex husband who stabbed her repeatedly and left her for dead. Now, her friend is murdered in the same manner as she was attacked. When weird things begin happening in every area of Leah's life, she has to wonder if it is paranoia or if someone is stalking her. Alex made a point to get to know Leah as a way to further his investigation into her friend, but he finds himself drawn to her even as she is unwittingly drawn right into the middle of his investigation. The two slowly draw closer and closer as the danger escalates. Alex vows to protect Leah at all cost, but can he keep her safe when the past comes to call?I enjoyed the creepiness of this story and the twists and turns. Leah was a great character, and I loved how strong she became.I received an ARC for review from Net Galley.

This book is the first in a new series. Several characters ( the members of Hunter's task force team) are introduced right off the bat. They have a funny sense of humor and the team camaraderie reads very strong. After returning from a disastrous mission overseas, a connection is found in the U.S. linking back to the terrorist they had been tracking. Jake and his team are sent undercover back to his hometown where he is expected to get in with the suspect in any way possible. The only problem is that the suspect is Evie, Hunter's former lover. He has tried to convince himself over the years that he hates her, but if sleeping with her will get him the answers he needs, he has no problem with it. What Hunter doesn't know is that after he left her, Evie chose a man on the rebound and ended up in a sickly abusive relationship. She got out but still lives in terror of her ex. Now, her ex has leveraged her cooperation with something illegal, and she can't find a safe way out of it. When Hunter throws himself into the mix, things become just as dangerous as they are complicated. He quickly realizes Evie isn't the criminal he was led to believe, but will she still want him after she finds out why he sought her out in the first place?This book was wall to wall action. Once the danger hit, it never slowed down. I was actually late leaving my house this morning because there was no way I could stop reading at 95%. I absolutely had to know how it was going to end. A little blurb at the end of the epilogue caught me by surprise and made me very excited about the next book. Lindsay Cross is absolutely going on my favorite authors list.I received an ARC from Net Galley.

I love how this book starts off with Davis, the series twin, laughing. It was such a sweet cute scene between him and Jamie. More so than the previous books in this series, this book starts off with action and keeps the suspense and danger high throughout. Poor Davis, it seems like he has been injured in nearly every book, and this one is no exception. His injuries won't stop him from keeping Jamie safe though. He has wanted her from the first time he saw her and has placed himself in her path as much as he can. Now that she needs his help fending off a nightmare from her past, he will risk anything.This was such a great story. I can't wait to get Mac and Sullivan's stories!

I thought the author did a pretty good job of keeping the feeling of this story similar to the original series. I liked seeing Kade older and interacting with his son. Ellie was funny and a good fit for Kane. Though it was a novella, it read like a full length story and didn't rush things. Kathleen didn't really read true to character for me. I'd like to give an exact reason why, but she just felt off, maybe a bit too sweet and coddling. In any case, that's very subjective, so maybe it's just me. In any case, it was a nice story.

I have loved and completely adored this series. It has been so emotional, both good and bad. I was so happy to see the change in Demyan after he met Claire. He quickly became a favorite of mine, and I wanted to see him happy. No once could have been more perfect for him than Claire. The lengths they went to in order to be with each other were beyond belief. They loved and trusted so deeply. This story also reiterated the great love of Vine and Anton. I'm so glad I gave this series a chance. It has kept me deeply engrossed for days.

Though it was definitely not on par with Callaghan series, this was a sweet contemporary romance. I was hoping for a bit more adventure or even a touch of suspense, but the straight up romance was still nice. I liked learning a bit more about some of the cousins who popped up frequently in the Callaghan books. I liked the characters and really want to read more about Johnny and definitely Michael.

While this story was utterly and completely heartbreaking, I wouldn't have missed it for anything. I don't want to give away any of the plot, so details will not be forthcoming in this review. I will say don't skip this book even if, like me, you hate to read things that might make you emotional. The story was amazing and insightful, and it gave the reader a chance to get to know Anton and Vine's kids in a totally different way. I'm so ready to read the next book. I just hope everyone gets what they deserve, both good and bad.

This series just gets more emotional and more gut wrenching as it goes along. The stories stress me out, but I can't stop reading them. I just love the connection between Anton and Vine.  They are so passionate, but their soul deep connection is what pulls me in and makes me want to read more about them. Usually, it is Anton who has the secrets, but this time it is Vine who has to keep her actions hidden from Anton for a time. Everything she does is to save him, but while her sacrifice may save his freedom, it may cost her his love.

So much more is going on in this book than even in the first one! It appears that the danger for Vine and Anton is never going to go away. In fact, Vine apparently has a new enemy, or one of Anton's enemies is using her to get to him. Anton is concerned for his new little family, distracted by the pending death of his father, and suspicious of the people he should be able to trust the most. Vine is worried and feeling like an outsider to Anton's life. This book had even more passion and intrigue than the first book, and it ended in a way that leads me to believe book three will be a shocker. I already have it downloaded and can't wait to get started reading it!

I found the series on Kindle unlimited , but was unfamiliar with the author. Having read several mob style romantic suspense novels in the past, I decided I had a pretty good chance of enjoying this one. I'm really thrilled that I gave it a try, because I completely loved it. Though our hero in this book is definitely not one of three good guys, her is a good man, and here had been in love with Vine for years. She was promised to him through a mafia arranged marriage, and even though she believes the agreement died with her parents, Anton has no intention of letting her go...ever. At first, Vine is furious because she is ripped out of the life she loves and thrown into a situation she thought would never occur. As she gets to know her future husband, however, she comes to realize exactly how much he loves her and how much he has put into making sure she will be safe and happy. Vine decides she and Anton can truly be happy and melts almost seamlessly into his life. If he loved her before, he is nothing short of obsessed with her now. The passion between this couple is off the charts. They are perfect for each other, but not everyone is happy with their union, and Anton is hiding a secret which may rip everything apart if Vine can survive long enough to discover it.This was a great story, and I'm thrilled to have found a new series I love on Kindle Unlimited.

This book is part of a fairly large series called The Krewe of Hunters. I had read one of the books in this series a long time ago and really enjoyed it. I tend to read at least a book per day, so even though I planned to read more of this series, I had unfortunately forgotten the name of the series and the author by the time I remembered to check them out. Recently, I have tried a few other paranormal type series trying to find this one with no success. Thankfully, I spotted this book on Net Galley. As soon as I read the title, I knew this was what I'd been looking for and requested the book. I was so happy to get the ARC for review!The Krewe of Hunters is a special FBI division with lots of special funding and leeway to investigate crimes with a paranormal type element. Diego's best friend and partner in the FBI has just joined the Krewe and issued an invitation to Diego. He is wavering about the decision until his ex-wife (whom he is still in love with) calls desperate for his help. He makes a snap decision to join the Krewe hoping their resources will get him to Scarlet faster.In the meantime, Scarlet is seeing ghosts. They are even appearing on her camera making her the focus of a police murder investigation. Scarlet is terrified of the ghosts, but the when the Krewe arrives, they believe the ghosts may be trying to help. Working together with the ghosts might help the Krewe solve not only the recent murders but maybe even some decades old, however, can they help save Scarlet or will Diego have to continue learning to live without her?I enjoyed the story and the characters, especially Daniel the ghost. There were enough plot turns to keep me guessing and enough action and chemistry to keep me turning pages. I'm so glad I found this series again!

Oh my word, I loved this book!!!! Though I could have done without the whole "squirt" discussion ( you'll find it near the beginning of the story), I otherwise loved everything about it. I have already recommended it to my favorite book buddies and will keep recommending it. It was extremely sexy, had great characters, and was thoroughly suspenseful with plenty of action and hot chemistry. I hope the author writes more stories like this one.

I really enjoyed this story even though I am no closer to deciding exactly which guy I want to root for. I like them both. This book gives so much more insight into all three off the main characters, but instead of making the choice of who Sage should be with, it really only made it harder. The story was full of tons of kick butt action and suspense, and I didn't want to put it down. I can't even imagine how this is all going to play out, but I'm sure Tiffany Snow will come up with something completely unexpected. I can't wait.

Blood on Snow starts well, with a few twists and turns and a anti-hero protagonist who is just intriguing enough to not be an instant turn-off.Unfortunately the story lacked enough depth to keep my interest. At a mere novella length the story begins with tension and resolves somewhat blandly. It almost felt like Nesbo ran out of characters and plot to keep the story exciting  rather than the story actually resolving well.I'm usually a huge fan of Nesbo works, but I won't be pursuing the rest of this series.

The weird thing about this book, if this was just a complete rip-off of the Millennium Trilogy with derivative characters and style I would have probably given it 5 stars. As it is however, an average thriller using Larsson's characters, a sense of mediocre achievement and betrayal pervaded my reading of this novel.(SPOILER ALERTS ONGOING)There were some good action sequences, but overall the story was overwhelmed with sins that I couldn't look past. Too many minor characters, a very late and extremely contrived introduction of Lisbeth's sister as the big-bad. Attempts at conspiracy fell flat (There is a mole in the police!), especially compared to the deep corruption revealed in the original trilogy. Lisbeth was reduced to a tom-girl action-hero stereotype with very little page time.Where the original trilogy had a gloomy nihilistic tone, this novel read more like a B-grade crime thriller, but what hurt the most was how destructive the tale was to the original characters. Everything just felt like a try-hard attempt to replicate the power of the previous books. Why can't they leave good things alone?

Even if you have seen the movie, or like me had the plot of this story spoiled by reviews or analysis, this book is amazing. As easy to read as a cheap thriller, as deep as a literary novel, and as unsettling as a horror. Mystic River is probably going to stick with me for a while. Probably the best thing about it is, despite having the twists and turns of good fiction, one really feels like they are listening in on the three main characters lives as they bounce from tragedy to tragedy. Recommended.

Anyone following my reviews lately will be realizing that I'm basically catching up on books that have been on the 'to-read' shelf for too long. In the case of the exorcist, I've been a fan of the movie since I saw an anniversary special what must have been ~15 years ago.In my opinion the book it even better. Much is similar, the book taps into the imagination in a way that the movie simply cannot. (although there are some truly terrifying sections of the film don't get me wrong.)

For the longest time I honestly thought this story was some sort of 'orphan child coming of age' novel. Don't judge a book by its cover I guess. It wasn't until a quiz question identified the book as being about vampires that I realized I had it wrong.So was it a good vampire novel. Yes and No, hard no to be impressed by the epic scope of this piece. Possibly one of the most well written ends of the world I've read.On the other hand, some of the early scenes were cheesy as milk-mold, and personally I found it hard to care about the characters in the second half of the novel because I'd just become attached to the first lot dammit!The ending was a little underwhelming, I suppose because this is a trilogy, SPOILERS nonetheless it seemed a bit of a cop out to design this huge world-ending situation, and then conclude the novel by destroying, one group of the vampires only.

Not being a big fan of prequels or spin-offs, but a huge fan of the Song of Fire and Ice I thought a graphic novel was not a painful way to give Hedge Knight a go.Present is Grr Martin's chaotic violence and unique ability to weave a tale complete with twists and adventure and heroism, without somehow seeming far-fetched or cheesy fantasy fiction. The Hedge Knight is however a more traditional approach to fantasy, a story following a single hero rising from poverty to get mixed up with kings and 'dragons.' Also present was Martin's confusing and thorough approach to lineage and family, which will be familiar to readers attempting to keep up with Westeros' elaborate family trees.The story itself is strong but not awe inspiring, much like the artwork which while technically brilliant I felt simply did the job of telling the story nothing more (nothing less though so still 4 star)

This was a book I thought I was going to love, so the 3 star rating could be in part due to the disappointment of high expectations, but honestly the book was a let-down. Disease Proof had been sitting on my wishlist since I heard about it being an evidenced based health advice book and a viable alternative to fadish an alternative medicinal self-help type books.However in the end Disease Proof tells anyone half-educated little new, Eat your veges, exercise and avoid fatty and/or processed food, Sure perhaps I learnt a few more details about healthy living, but ultimately it was more a reminder than a healthy lesson. And like many books of this genre, I highly doubt anyone who doesn't know that keeping active and eating vegetables is good for you is going to pick up this book. There are several technique and practical advice pages that may help the small portion of people who pick up this book but need a practical boost to live better.I really liked the holistic section focused on sleep, stress, social relationships and chronic pain, but alas this was effectively the closing chapter and not nearly as much time was spent on these topics.This review may seem overly harsh, the book is accurate well researched and covers an important topic, its could have done with more writing pizzazz and perhaps more detail aspects of health living other than eating (I guess diet has a huge impact on health so it also had a huge portion of this book, but still) In summary, this book is worth a look it you are in the rare bracket where you want more technical knowledge about health living and have no-idea where to start.

I had been hearing about the Chowder Society and a classic novel called Ghost Story in 'horror fiction' topic for Quiz-up for ages (I'm best in NZ by the way), and finally saw a hard-cover at a sale and picked it up!My story aside, if you like Stephen King's older works and are a horror fan in general Ghost Story is worth a look. Even though its not technically that old (published 1979) the book has a nostalgic feel and a slow pace that is usually absent from modern horror. While the tale-spinning old men of the Chowder Society and Mr Wanderly aren't the most unique or sexy of protagonists the story redeems itself by its powerful images, crazy but ultimately sensical plotting and an ending that most authors would/should be jealous of.The slow and somewhat rambling pace may put some excitement-junkies off, and its hard to attach to the large cast of character presented in a symphony of chaos narratively, but the well-executed mythology and 'ghost' story was above par and I can see why this novel brought horror into the upper echelon of publishing.

An intriguing concept - The Finkler questions follows a protagonist who is not in fact Jewish, but almost pathologically jealous of his friend Finkler, who is. The story follows our main man around as he imitates, fakes, and almost makes himself jewish. The story is light-hearted a humorous, although I'm sure likely to offend some.Overall the tale was a relatively easy read and gave some food for thought, but honestly I ended up hating the protagonist and treating the tale as more cautionary than anything else.As a work The Finkler question was not bad, not amazing, but certainly unique.

I picked up this novel through a successful giveaway om IMGUR, the author being a lovely chap wants to get the book out there for free. The story is pretty stock epic fantasy, the main character is a relative nobody who quickly finds themselves caught up in a magical battle which includes stupid demons, an attractive rogue and a couple of mentors.The book is pretty fun and easy to process, great for kids, nothing particularly stood out to make me want to read more, and I would not have been happy if I'd paid for this piece.

So I've had somewhat of hiatus from Amazon reviewing - and WTF is with those questions about pacing and plot twists!!?!?But towards the book - since its been a while since reviewing I thought I would start with one of the most vivid reading experiences I've had. Deep North is a semi-biographical novel (by which I mean the story is strongly based on the life of the author's father + research with some dramatization to make the story more powerful and effective [don't panic history remains intact]) of the experience of WWII POWs in a Japanense prisoner of war camp building a railway to 'nowhere'The scenes are harrowing and violent to say the least, but Deep North is not just a festival of gruesome treatment of war prisoners, the depth of characterization is almost more haunting, especially the stories of the soldiers back home and trying to live their lives.I wouldn't recommend the story to those even remotely squeamish, in some respects reading the book was horrible, incredibly rewarding though.

So this book finally put me off this series (thank goodness fans yell, now we won't have to read your negative reviews no more.) The novel started with such promise - our main lady revealing that she was in fact addicting to cutting for prophecy. An intriguing move joining real life issues with fantasy fiction.But then the rest of the long story happened, endless conversations about human vs other politics which aside from being boring confused the crap out of me (cue fans of book accusing of stupidity.) The majority of the book wasn't from Meg's point of view (and she is the best honestly) and I knew the book was a dud as I approached the end I realized I had no idea what the climax would/could be.On the plus side - one less series to feel obligated to read.

Touch was an intriguing tale, built around the idea of a person (or entity) than can possess people indefinitely, and what might happen in such a person's life.The tale was well constructed, fascinating and the action well-crafted, bloody, and tense. I only had a couple of beefs. One was that similar to the body-switching of the narrator, the story zipped around between the characters origins, random anecdotes and the present day action. While it wasn't tough to follow it did weaken the drive of the plot. Second was the book was a bit too long for what it was - as a kick ass action story that touched on some deeper themes I found myself having to intentionally sit down and read this book through, because I fund myself getting bored with the 400+ pages.Nonetheless an interesting read

As per the headline, I read Blood Meridian on recommendation of a friend as I loved the Road.So what was Blood Meridian like? Personally I did not enjoy this as much as the Road as the narrative was less personal, more action focused than Road. If that sounds like your thing than BM is likely for you. The too stories have much in common: an examination of human beings and violence and the place of innocence in horrible worlds. BM is perhaps draws more from history and has more culture contains within (whereas Road was unifying in its bleakness.)I wasn't sad that I read Blood Meridian but it wasn't my slice of cake.

So Shannon's earlier book The Bone Season was somewhat of a let-down for me. My friends adored the thing so I thought I would give Mime Order a chance.To be frank for about 80% of the book I regretted the decision. After a melodramatic but pointless prologue the book begins immediately after the end of Bone Season, and quickly sees Paige return to London to deal with the supernatural politics of her unnatural creed. The weird thing is I wanted more London in Bone Season, but I wasn't happy with the world portrayed in Mime Order. Everything seemed too organised, I was thinking that if the unnaturals were a big like gangs then they surely would be somewhat informal (i.e. not having a set ruler.) The world of Mime Order felt more like try-hard Harry Potter which was a shame.Second problem in a similar Potter vein, was the shear weight of the terminology, Shannon seemed like a big linguistic show-off playing around with all these 'mancers' but the effect was one of making the book gimmicky and lacking substance. The plot meandered around endless meetings with various unmemorable characters (seriously I could only tell you about Paige, Warden and Jaxon if you asked me right now) except for some brief moments of interest when that certain someone showed up again (sorry spoiler (c'mon not really))The final redeeming feature was the climactic ending. In fact I suspect this book was written largely as filler to build to a well written ending, which was genuinely so good I almost added a star. Here is hoping that the rest of the series is ALL crafted so well because overall this book was a drag.

Ok so I was reading this book with the succinct recommendation that it was a "mind-f***" for the first 50 pages I felt more like the book was a just a drag, and the author couldn't get his head together to write a coherent story. After about page 75 and definitely after page 100 the book really started to take off. Every started to make sense, the tension build brilliantly on the premise and setting had me really cringing at the narrators plight.So if you've ever wondered what would happen if you crossed The Matrix, Memento and The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo (there is some weird stuff in there) then this is the book.

There were a few things that struck me about Reviver as I began reading, first, the prose is exceptionally well written. Tight, tense and clear it was a rare moment to not feel absorbed by the coherence of the story. Second however was the slight tropey plot. A forensic professional who speaks to the recently dead to build a court case, never seen that before.Nonetheless, the tale goes places unexpected, and most enjoyable is Patrick's ability to riff about the social consequences of 'revival' while keeping the story alive.I must confess the final confrontation and aftermath started to get a bit cheesy and cliche, but I don't regret reading this one for a second.

So definitely had to read the second installment of Maus after rereading the first. I must confess, while still strong and brilliant the second novel meanders a little. There is a heavier focus on the author this time round, with Spiegelman riffing on the pressures and difficulties of creating the follow-up.In saying that the history is during a much more brutal phase of the Holocaust, the father's experiencing much more violence and death (portrayed with significant harrow.) So it's hardly like the book is all about the author. The final few panels were expertly done and appropriately heart-wrenching. The strange juxtaposition of seeing Spiegelman's father deteriorate with old age while recounting his near-death experiences prompts a maelstrom of feelings. One feels an odd agreement with the ranting father when he says 'I survived for what, this?' referring to the difficulty and inevitable decline of old age. At the same time one gets the sense of a man living a full and complete life (which many did not obviously)In summary Maus portrays the holocaust in a unique and powerful way, personal without preaching, insightful without overblowing it. Once again finding a bizarre paradox of humanizing the tragic events by depicting people as animals.

This wasn't the first time I read Maus - so this review is more of a 'is this still good' and the answer is definitely yes. My initial reading was as a teenager, now as a (supposed) adult I found myself identifying with different aspects.The whole metaphor aspect has probably been overcooked over the years in review, but it is worth mentioning that the depiction of the Jews as mice and Polish as pigs creates a fascinating paradox in that the cartoonish perhaps even childish aspects both softens and hardens the brutality of the story. The most powerful effect however is the emphasis on 'race' and the plight of the mice.In terms of storyline Maus manages to cover both broad issues and personal through Spiegelman's father. When I first read the book I was struck by the direct persecution of the Jews, from an older perspective I was more intrigued by the relationship and family dynamics portrayed in the book, such as Spiegelman's family refusing to change their lifestyle in the face of poverty.Perhaps the strongest aspect of this piece, is created the strong desire to read the second part, much enjoyed even the second time.

I must confess a double feeling about this book - mostly on the positive; the book was compelling insightful, disturbing (as a Booker Prize winner should be.)At the same time I felt I didn't get this book, compelling as the story was I wasn't sure where it was intended to go, while there were many themes and messages I couldn't tell you (without reading some analysis online.)Very similar to Sense of an Ending Disgrace follows a man staring down old age thinking about relationships (Disgrace has more sex) a strong theme being the often insensitive perspective of men (sorry dudes)I wouldn't recommend this one for the squeamish, much debauch is contained within the pages and Coetzee has incredible skill making the action believable.

In regards to Behaviour Analysis 'The White Book' is probably the best general introduction you can find. Read as part of my future study requirements I found the book to be succinct useful and practical.My only worry was a few slips into unacademic writing, one chapter resorts to 'the science of common sense' another uses the word guesstimate (although according to chrome this is a real word, not the most scientific I believe [or am I the snob]) overall great.

Promise of the Wolves has much in common with the Clan of the Cave Bear Series (roughly set 14,000) years ago. In this case however we see the world from a wolf's eyes. Our main character a young wolf-pup caught in a strange conflict between humans and wolves, based on an ancient tradition/rule of a perfect harmony between the two species.Animalistic main characters is always a risk - how animal and how human does one make them? - Hearst pulls this off well. Balancing wolfy passtimes with an apocalyptic storyline this book flows quickly through its 300+ pages.My only worry is that this is an origin story for how people came to have dogs as pets - not that it isn't intriguing just feels a little unepic for 'wolf chronicles'

With On the Edge Ilona Andrew(s) offers a fairly succinct romance and magi heavy fantasy novel with a lonely desert feel much similar to Patrica Briggs Mercy Thompson series.There isn't too much wrong with this novel, although not much stand-out either, in general a decent read.

There were many draws to this book - a good title, a theme that involved one of my great loves (walking) encased in a relatively light book. However I found myself not really enjoying this book, the idea is that as the author wanders the meridian he recounts important historic and scientific progress around that point and topic. While this sounds good in theory it makes for a somewhat disjointed book, at one point discussing the cosmos, then Charles Darwin and the dinosaurs. It makes a lot more sense when the epilogue reminds us that the author has been pondering their own and mankind's significance in the universe (which explains the heavy content)In regards the quality of the information the knowledge imparted by this book is a little heavy and pretty formally presented without much flair or verve, for people already fascinated by the topics they probably wouldn't hear anything new and for those uninformed Raymo kinda jumps right into the complicated stuff (it involved trig)Overall by far not my favorite non-fiction. The book isn't bad by any stretch, just not great either. Mediocre.

Strikes is probably the best so far in this series, the mythology and plot are woven together coherently into a sort of mortal kombat for fantasy creatures, the overarching story-line advances nicely and there is even some brief kissey kissey moments for those who misinterpret the fantasy part of urban fantasy genre...

So I really liked the general setting of this book - I was cautious about the main tension though, a love story? Not usually my thing. Nonetheless I dived in and really enjoyed Everyday. The idea of a person existing as someone knew everyday could have been bigger than Ben Hurr, but Levithan skilfully focuses on a relatively simply plot which somehow worked. Rather than bogging down the story with all the possibilities Levithan uses deft writing to explore a few plot points well.

I really like the premise of this book - working in the service sector I have taken a while to come to terms with being in many respects 'the enemy' when it comes to people getting real support.Although when I began the book it felt more like a polemic rant than careful analysis. Many points were cunningly presented as hypothesis or theories, then repeated shortly after as fact (a genuine psyc tactic) Nonetheless I strongly agree with many of the points made - the overall thesis that often service systems hinder more than help is interesting especially since the focus is not a right-wing or anti-government rant but a genuine focus on people and community

There is some sorrow in working through an epic compendium like this - so much Lovecraft, and yet knowing that once finished that is essentially it (poetry and letters only remain.)Reading Lovecraft is like a study in influence of modern horror (and some sci-fi) his shorter earlier fiction shines brightest the longer novellas being hit and miss, some pieces such as the Dream Quest of Unknown Kadath were rambling distractions of terminology where The Case of Charles Dexter Ward possess intriguing characterisation along with signature supernatural elements.My new favourite is The Thing on the Doorstep, a short story with the strongest mythos (aside from Chu-Chu himself) and most memorable characters.The music of Erich Zann, The Rats in the Walls, are two stand-out stories, Mountains of Madness is a strong piece although bogged down in mythology.Obviously some of these pieces are getting dated, the blatant racism, mild sexism and elitism are surprisingly unjarring although quite noticeable.

I was asked to post a review of sample chapters by the author - to be honest I was not impressed by this tactic. The sample chapters were OK, if Briar had asked for anything more expensive than writing a review then I would have said no.There is a medium amount of intrigue in the intro chapters to this book - some missing friends, a conflict for the main character between returning to old ways or starting afresh. I look forward to reading the whole story and posting a more informed review

Its hard to imagine this book being anything but compelling with a hookline like this piece. The story is in a similar vein to 3 Cups of Tea, but in this instance from a genuine citizen of the Middle East caught in the conflict between Taliban and more moderate Muslims.The story is perfectly paced and well crafted to get the full impact of Malala's life and perspective without becoming preachy or overcooked.What a tale

I really love the idea here - mixing Lovecraft's unique prose with graphic work. At times the art worked really well supplementing the story, however I did feel at times the artwork let the story down, with boxy basic drawings of settings (such as the classic Miskatonic university.) Something really cool was the well balancing paneling, as the story pacing increased so did the intensity and size of the art panels.Apparently there are similar works out there, which I look forward to devouring. This sort of thing is highly recommended for anyone interested in HP but perhaps find the old timey prose a little clunky.

I'm always a fan of more classic dystopian settings. I must be getting old, but the recent fad for heroic young lass' saving the world from shallow and controlling governments seems a little too trite for my tastes.Where Children of Men gets it right is thorough social commentary seamlessly stirred in with a good story so that one never feels the world is fake or artificial, nor does one ever get bored with the lack of action.Relatively short The Children of Men is enjoyable and thought provoking, the only downside being that PD James did not write more books in this genre.

This book came to me by an unusual route - a friend from up north sent it to us thinking it was ours (the bookmark in it was a plane ticket with my wife's name on it) we had never heard of it.Nonetheless I gave the book a read, the premise seemed great and one of my goals is to read non-fiction outside of my usual (special) interests.Overall the book was lackluster. I found myself struggling a little with the physics, although at the same time I suspect someone well qualified in the area would probably have a better understanding that what was presented here. Thusly one questions who this book is for?The 2nd and 3rd sections were the strongest, the 1st felt like an endless repetition of the question: If there was a big bang why is the universe so consistent?

Few books successfully capture the experience of a child, fewer still manage to both capture the perspective of a child with a thorough comment on 'adult' issues. In Paddy Clarke Doyle comments on religion, politics, Ireland, family dynamics (and probably more stuff I didn't pick up on)The story is light-hearted in prose, but deep in content which creates a somewhat awkward but fulfilling story. A good length too, leaving one satiated without gagging for more (or bored throughout)

As all textbooks with chapter authors, the quality of these piece varies greatly depending on the individual chapters. Some I found to be highly interesting and applicable (14, 4, 6). Whereas other chapters (5 and 11) were heavy on jargon and statistics.Being a work related read the overall textbook was particularly helpful, in a few specific areas, namely restraint and risk management, but I felt at times lacked coherence, for example one chapter promoting punishment techniques whereas others promoting non-aversion. There was a sense of the book being a collection of authors general knowledge in each area, rather than a structured textbook (it does promise to be a handbook after all.)

So hesitant was I to pick up this book, as much as I can relate - sometimes epic fantasy seems to be epicly long just for the sake of it.
