Imagine it like Robocop with animals except if Robocop violently obliterated anyone who threatened him in a flurry of blood, eyeballs and shattered bones.This is one of the goriest most brutal books comics I have ever read but it doesnt feel gratuitous. It feels like the reality of what would happen if animals were trained to defend themselves at all costs by any means necessary and then given the tools to inflict massive bodily. One of the problems Morrison has had in the past (and up until today) is creating characters who feel real. Ironically the three animals, Bandit, Tinker and Pirate, are some of the most real characters Morrison has ever created. Despite being literal killing machines its damn near impossible not to feel tremendous sympathy for them and hope for a happy ending even as the animals inflict and receive horrific abuse.This is another brilliant collaboration of Grant Morrison and Frank Quitely and this is a collection by DC that mostly does their work justice.  With only three issues there really wasnt enough material here to sustain an Absolute or Omnibus Edition but what readers to get is a nice amount of sketches and background material. I heartily recommend this collection and unless you are squeamish about the violence I dont see a reason not to give it a chance. One last thing. Another deficiency Morrison has is his ability to give a story an ending that equals the buildup. WE3 has one of Morrisons best and most memorable endings. All and all its a great story with magnificent art.

There are probably a lot of people who would read Ultra Comic and give it one star and I wouldnt blame them. This is definitely a story that will resonate with some people and fall flat on its face with others. Grant Morrison has been experimenting with storytelling for his entire career with some brilliant successes (Flex Mentallo) and some spectacular failures (Final Crisis). Of course these are subjective and IGN ranked Final Crisis as the greatest DC crossover ever but suffice to say it cannot be disputed that Morrison polarizes readers and for some people like myself we find some stories amazing and some awful.Ultra Comics is Morrisons attempt to make a fully self-aware comic book. A comic that communicates directly with the reader. This is similar to what Morrison did with Flex Mentallo but here he has taken it to the nth degree. The main character is literally named Ultra Comics and was created on Earth Prime, the Earth which was originally intended to be OUR Earth in the DC multiverse. It was eradicated in Crisis on Infinite Earths but is apparently back again. Like a lot of Morrison stories it doesnt make a much sense. If Earth Prime is our Earth, an Earth with no super heroes and magic than how was Ultra Comics created and where does he go when he faces off against distorted parodies of the Justice League if Earth Prime has no super humans? A reader will simply have to strap in for the ride because things tend to happen without rhyme or reason because yknow, its Morrison.Ive really enjoyed Multiversity but more as a fascinating comic book experiment than as a tight coherent story. For straight storytelling its all over the place; more of a collection of fascinating ideas than an actual tale. The most lucid story in the series was Thunderworld Adventures. I would put Ultra Comics somewhere in the middle of the pack with Pax Americana and Thunderworld being my two favorites. The beauty of this series is that I can read each comic three and four times and discover something new each time. Thats not true with most writers. In fact the first day I bought Ultra Comics I read it twice and will probably read it several more times.I can envision a reader upon finishing Ultra Comics throwing it down in disgust as pretentious, self-indulgent garbage. My take was different. Im an older comic reader and Ive read a LOT of stories and when I see something different it attracts my attention. Morrisons experimentations dont always work but I respect him for taking risks. In my opinion the entire Multiversity effort gets a B+. Whether you love Ultra Comics or hate it you probably wont forget it and I hope that Morrison will continue to explore this idea of involving the reader in the comic. I encourage people to give this one a try.

The Tom Swift novels stick to a VERY tight formula. Tom Swift either acquires or creates a vehicle, the Swift family is menaced by a group of thugs (in the first three books its the same group) and he has frequent encounters with his nemesis the red headed bully Andy Folger. With the fourth book we finally get a slight break form the formula. This time its Toms father Barton who invents the titular submarine and we may finally be done with the Happy Harry Gang. The Swifts have an actual goal this time which is to use the submarine to find 300 grand in lost treasure lost at sea.If youre searching for great literature from the early 20th century keep looking. The Tom Swift books were cranked out at a blistering pace releasing 15 books in the first 3 years of publication. But that doesnt mean they arent enjoyable reads and a very interesting sociological glimpse into life in 1910. Thats not to say this is an entirely accurate representation but a readers get a general feel of a simpler time. The Tom Swift books are written for young adults and they feature very simple plots that are easy to follow.Although the plots are simple and aimed towards a younger audience they dont insult the readers intelligence. Reading this as an adult Im impressed with how airtight the plots tend to be. These stories are also intellectually inspirational as we read about the Swifts challenges in building a fully operational submarine. The writer even includes descriptions of the means of propulsion and yet the story never drags down with needless scientific chatter. When the Swifts are in development phase things never work correctly the first time and thats reality. In fact the initial test of the submarine is the closest the Swifts and friends have come to death.Having an inventor as a hero and being along for the ride as he invents might encourage a youngster to consider a career in science or at least increase respect for the scientific method. The only issue I might bring up is that the feasibility of the Swifts having the funds to produce a fully operational 100 foot long submarine seems entirely fanciful. This is no primitive cut rate sub. This is the real deal capable of sailing to the middle of the ocean and descending several miles under the ocean. Its even equipped with a defensive weapon that gets some usage but Im willing to accept it because the author integrates it all into an entertaining tale.With each entry in the series the stories are growing bigger and bigger. The first book had Tom Swift acquiring a motorbike. Whoop-de-doo. By the third story Tom had co-invented a hybrid plane/balloon which was somewhat cool and now hes on a treasure hunt with a submarine. Thus far this is my favorite book in the series. The villains are a bit more interesting and I enjoyed reading of their travels across the ocean including a stop at the classic desert island. This is a series that is aimed at young teens but it doesnt pander or insult intelligence so even older readers can enjoy it.

The original writer and creator of Justice League Dark was Peter Milligan. Writing was later taken over by Jeff Lemire and with this volume J.M. DeMatteis. I can officially say that each writer has been just about equally bland and forgettable. I will get into the specifics in a moment but let me mention that I have tried three New 52 series including Scott Snyders Swamp Thing, Suicide Squad and Justice League Dark and have found them all disappointing. There are other comics like Forever Evil and Multiversity that I enjoyed but overall it seems like the New 52 is just not for me and maybe its partly due to my age.Peter Milligan set the tone for the JLD and it was decidedly kid friendly. There was lots of emphasis on Justice League and not much on Dark. There were a few creepy moments but nothing a pre-teen couldnt handle. Lemire took it even further in the kid friendly direction with a long storyline dealing the JLD battling longtime JLA villain Felix Faust over the powerful Books of Magic. The story even included a character that I can only assume was intended to capitalize on the popularity of Harry Potter.So now DeMatteis has taken over writing duties and for a brief moment I thought he was taking the series in a new and improved direction. The back of the book shows Nightmare Nurse with a half demonic face garroting Zatanna. Now THAT would be interesting. A member of the team, revealed as evil, turning on her teammates. And her name IS Nightmare Nurse which is a somewhat frightening name. Halfway through the story DeMatteis does a U-Turn and takes the Tales from the Darkside story and gives it a Goosebumps ending and the team is back to being happy and friendly with Nightmare Nurse learning a good lesson in friendship.DeMatteis stories here just seem random and unfocussed. The team is floating around in the House of Mystery and challenges just pop up for them to deal with. Another issue I have is something I wrote in a previous review. John Constantine is constantly referred to as a bastard by the other members of the team despite no evidence to back it up (at least not in this series). Deadman refers to him exclusively as con-man even though he continually fights alongside the team and defends its members. Like the previous writers DeMatteis wants to have his cake and eat it too. He wants Constantine to be regarded as an anti-hero but never has him actually act like an anti-hero (because THAT would be interesting). At one point John Constantine suggests he will leave the rest of the team in peril and escape but is prevented from doing so. This way DeMatteis could point and say LOOK Constantine was going to do something terrible except he didnt and even when he said he would leave them chained up that was out of character for him based on his actions in the JLD.My suggestion in a review of a previous Justice League Dark volume was go read Swamp Thing by Alan Moore which are all available on Amazon. Then read Sandman by Neal Gaiman and if you can find it The Spectre by Joe Orlando. Then come back and read Justice League Dark and compare the two. I read Alan Moores Swamp Thing in the early 1980s and a distinctly remember many of the storylines over 30 years later. I barely remember JLD volumes 1 and 2 which I read just recently. DC has done some great, dark, arcane stories but the JLD is safe for kids and forgettable. Volume 5 is my last volume. Done.

The first two issues are by Peter Milligan with the Justice League Dark battling a hoard of vampires in Gotham City. When last we left off the JLD was finishing off their long fight with The Enchantress that occupied the entire book and it felt like the vampire storyline started up in mid-stream. Just as abruptly as the storyline starts it ends, seemingly with no conclusion and Peter Milligan writing stint comes to a close as Jeff Lemire takes over. After doing a little research it appears the vampire storyline was a crossover with the I, Vampire series so unless you read I, Vampire you are treated to two issues with no start and no conclusion. Real Nice DC.In my review of book one I wrote that the Justice League Dark had a ton of unrealized potential. Milligan made some attempts at character depth and he had some snappy dialogue but for a team of magical and occult based characters the story felt very benign. It wasnt creepy or gothic or even particularly intriguing or thoughtful. Milligan seemed to focus more on the Justice League and less on the Dark.Unfortunately Jeff Lemire has taken it even further in that direction. His entire storyline is an almost relentless battle with Felix Faust. As if they werent standing in the shadow of the Justice League enough now they spend a significant amount of time battling one of the JLAs classic villains. Many of the magic based heroes powers are either indistinguishable from super powers (Deadman) or so ill-defined that you have no idea WHAT they are capable of (Madame Xanadu). In the case of Zatanna her power are constantly conking out because her ability to do pretty much ANYTHING by speaking backwards makes totally overpowered. The JLD fight in classic superhero style, as a group each using their powers in battle but that exactly how an occult based team SHOULDNT fight. Instead of differentiating the JLD from other super hero teams Lemire goes with the same tired super team storyline. A more thoughtful story could have been highly rewarding but thats not where Lemire and Milligan decided to go.My last issue is with John Constantine. I just dont think Lemire has any idea what to do with him. Hes constantly referred to as a liar, a bastard and con artist and yet there is little evidence to back this up. He lies to Zatanna but even that seems like it was put in just to give SOME evidence that he was a liar and his lie wasnt really done for selfish reasons. Or was it? Who knows? There is an issue devoted to his backstory but all we learn is that hes obsessed with obtaining magic. For what ends? We dont know. The only thing he seems to do with magic is fight evil which flies in the face of his being a bastard. If Lemire wants to make him an anti-hero then do it. Instead Lemire plays it safe as he does with the entire storyline.Based on user reviews it seems as if people are really enjoying Justice League Dark. Here is my suggestion for fans, most of whom are probably quite a bit younger than I am. Go read Swamp Thing by Alan Moore which are all available on Amazon. Then read Sandman by Neal Gaiman and if you can find it The Spectre by Joe Orlando. The come back and read Justice League Dark and see if you still think its five star material.

Jules Verne has never been known to create deep and compelling characters or complex plots but Eight Hundred Leagues on the Amazon was one of his shallowest. The Wikipedia plot summary is a whopping four lines long which may be a record for the shortest description of any Verne story on Wikipedia. It really is little more than a story of a family travelling down the Amazon for a wedding. The twist is that they build an island sized raft with huts and even foliage and they bring along tons of workers. Not exactly roughing it.Most people who know the works of Jules Verne have not actually read his stories and those who have read his stories have probably not read his lesser known works. Here is the thing about Verne. His work is really dated. This is not Victor Hugo or Alexandre Dumas level storytelling. Vernes hook was that he would offer readers a literary tour of places they would or could never go, which was brilliant for 19th century reader but less so for a reader today. If you or I want to experience the Amazon we could watch a nature program or even fly to South America (not nearly as easy or affordable in 1881).Certainly a skilled writer could create a compelling story about a trip down the Amazon but that is not Vernes intention. The trip IS the story and so much of the book is like reading an encyclopedia full of facts. Its like a travelogue from Mutual of Omahas Wild Kingdom narrated by a deep voiced announcer. On paper it can be quite dull. About halfway through the book we FINALLY get a little bit of a plot. It seems that years ago the patriarch of the family was accused of a crime he didnt commit but escaped, changed his name and has lived in relative isolation on his large farm. The trip down the Amazon has inspired him to clear his name but a terrible series of circumstances lands him back in prison with a date of execution.The story continues to drag along as the mans son and future son-in-law desperately try to find the proof to free their dad and when they do its inexplicably encrypted. With Verne writing the story there is never any doubt the man will be freed so the long drawn out attempt at tension is just dull.130 years ago this story might have been fascinating to a reader with the descriptions of South America and the melodramatic story but I think youd be hard pressed to find a modern reader that will find it riveting which is probably why few people have heard of this book. This book sort of showcases the worst aspects of Jules Vernes writing and doesnt feature a cool hook like the Nemos Nautilus or Roburs Terror. Just a big floating pile drifting down the Amazon. If you want to read through the Jules Verne bibliography I would put this story very low on the list of stories to read.

Let me get one thing out of the way. Tarzan does NOT go to the Earths core. To say that Tarzan went to the Earths core would be like saying youve gotten to the apple core when you peel off the skin. What Burroughs has done is create a hollow Earth filled with dinosaurs, all sorts of primitive tribes and even a miniature son at the center of the Earth (the true core). Burroughs didnt invent the idea of the hollow Earth but simply used it in a series of books including this one that includes Tarzan. Its pretty clear to me that this was Burroughs the businessman trying to utilize his popular Tarzan character to bring more attention to his Pellucidar books.Here is my problem with Pellucidar. Tarzan is clearly a fantasy character but to me he has always maintained one foot in reality. Even the existence of Pal-ul-don with its own dinosaurs doesnt break any laws of physics but Pellucidar is absurd. The idea appears to be that gravity is within the crust of the Earth rather than the core since people can walk on both the inside and outside of the crust which is about 500 miles thick. A ship, for instance, could sail through one of the polar openings and arrive in Pellucidar unaware that they had moved from the exterior to the interior of the planet. But if gravity were spread out within the entire crust rather than at the true core people couldnt walk on the interior OR exterior. If the gravity came from the interior sun the people inside the Earth would get pulled right into the sun. There are just way too many absurdities for me to take the premise seriously but I guess the big question would be whether Burroughs was able to take this silly concept and create a compelling story.So is it a good story? Not really. Tarzan is recruited to lead an expedition into Pellucidar to rescue a gentleman named David Ennis from pirates called Korsars. This is just a pretense as Tarzan wanders off on his own and gets lost pretty immediately after entering Pellucidar and a group sent to rescue him likewise gets lost and the story dissolves into Tarzan and another character named Jason Gridley wandering around Pellicidar and David Ennis is forgotten about until the last few pages. This is far from the first time Burroughs has written a story where the plot is basically people running around doing stuff.Besides having a near vacuous plot At Earths Core also suffers from some other classic Burroughs writing idiosyncrasies. There are the unbelievable coincidences as characters just happen to run into each other repeatedly in this world of Pellicidar (which literally has more land mass than the external world). In previous Tarzan stories, Tarzan has a nearly supernatural ability to pick up foreign languages almost instantaneously. Its a cheap literary shortcut but I guess we can just assume Tarzan is freaky good at learning new languages except in this book Jason Gridley becomes fluent in the language of Pellicidar in a ridiculously short period of time. On the other hand I dont even know how much time this story is supposed to span. Is it days, weeks, months, years? If the time span is established I must have missed it.Tarzan at Earths Core leaves open plot points that will be resolved in Burroughs other Pellicidar books but thats the whole point. Burroughs was a businessman and here was his version of synergy. Its too bad the plot was so empty.

Mastermen is another brilliant addition to the Multiversity miniseries but it suffers from the same problem as the rest of the books in the series. The book is released as Mastermen #1 and it comes off as the first in an exciting new series except there is no scheduled issue 2. To put it simply there is no resolution to the story and this is quite common in the Multiversity stories.The story starts off reminiscent of Red Son except Ka-L lands in Germany and is adopted by Hitler instead of landing in Soviet Russia. He is raised as Overman and helps the Nazis win WW II. The natural assumption is always that if the Nazis win WW II they will simply continue to be the same bloodthirsty Nazis perpetually but to Morrisons credit he takes a different approach and after 60 years the Nazi ruled planet has stabilized and Earth-10s JLA seem like a fairly decent group who legitimately protect the Earth from danger. They are not the squeaky clean JLA we all know but by and large seem earnest in their battling of evil. Of the groups members only the seemingly immortal Overman was alive during the Nazis most heinous days and continues to bear the shame. As Leatherwing (Batman) says he wasnt even alive at the time and wont be held responsible.It is in this environment that Uncle Sam rises again and with the help of an unexpected ally creates the Freedom Fighters to end the Nazi rule. The battle is ON and then the story ends. We never actually see The Ray or Black Condor in action and we get one panel of Phantom Lady doing something. The Human Bomb easily gets those most panel time. If this were the first issue of a new series I would be totally stoked to get issue 2 but its not. Unless Multiversity #2 wraps up the story or DC actually does continue the series it remains an unresolved cliffhanger.Multiversity feels like an evolution with DC comics taking existing characters and placing them in alternative situations. Elsewhere stories is nothing new and even the idea that the elsewhere stories exist in different parallel universes has been done for decades but it feels like Morrison is trying to organize and evolve these ideas. DC might be responding favorably to this idea and will be following up Multiversity with Convergence which looks like a similar project to Multiversity. In fact Convergence is probably the most exciting DC crossover Ive seen (which means it will probably disappoint).Morrison tried to inspire seven new series with his Seven Soldiers of Victory experiment which to the best of my knowledge produced none and Multiversity will probably end the same way but there is some really good writing going on here and if DC were to continue these series Id definitely give them a chance. I would recommend all the Multiversity comics with Pax Americana being my favorite followed by Thunderworld but honestly there is yet to be a clunker in the batch.

Ive never really understood why Dark Horse chose to publish the Astro Boy comics out of chronological order. In volume 9 we start with The Secret of the Egyptian Conspirators published April to August 1969 followed by The Invisible Giant from May to July 1960 and then we go all the way back to June of 1954 for Cobalt.The Secret of the Egyptian Conspirators is a fairly typical Tezuka story involving the abuse and manipulation of robots. We get a rare appearance by Astro Boy creator Dr. Tenma who was originally shown to be a bastard but now occasionally pops up when Astro Boy is in real danger. The ending is also typical of Tezuka in that its a lot more hard hitting and real than one might expect from a comic with such whimsical art. This is the longest story in the book and probably the best with some pretty good robot fighting mixed with some emotional scenes as the robot Cleopatra is treated with disdain by her evil creator.The Invisible Giant was intended to be an homage to The Fly where a scientist created a teleporter and ends up having his own DNA mixed with that of a fly. In this story two scientists create a teleporter but when one of the scientists turns the machine off in mid teleportation, in order keep to the technology for himself, the other scientist essentially has his atoms scattered. The scattered scientist is able to somewhat reconstitute himself using 3D TVs and begins killing people not out of evil but seemingly from confusion. A villain tries to use the ghostly scientist for his own nefarious ends but Astro Boy arrives to try and stop the villain and save the poor scientist.The oldest story in this book is Cobalt. Astro Boy is sent out to find and disarm an H-Bomb but when they lose contact with him Professor Ochanomizu creates a near duplicate of Astro Boy named Cobalt. Cobalt is powerful but not as technically capable and doesnt have Astro Boys ability to disarm a bomb so his mission is to find Astro. This is the first story featuring Astro Boys little brother, Cobalt, and like a lot of early Tezuka stories the plot is a bit disjointed. All and all a decent book. Not my favorite volume but a worthy addition.

If you haven't upgraded to a SSD you won't believe this-  You can not get a better performance improvement for less cost.I installed this drive in an old Core2 Duo with 2gb RAM.  I installed WIN 7 from USB in 13 minutes.  Boot time to log-in is now 13 seconds. (It was over a minute)  Log-in to desktop is about 1 second.  Shut down is under 6 seconds.Applications launch faster than if I had a 16gb RAM upgrade.  Everything works faster, the battery lasts longer, the fan NEVER runs.I was blown away.
Works, as advertised, no problems.

Works great- better than great.  I've use this to clone dozens of drive images when I didn't have the ability to push the image over a network.  This would clone a 160 GB 3.5inch 7200 rpm drive in about 30 minutes, and 160 GB 2.5 inch 5400 rpm drives in an hour.It also works great to connect drives to a workstation for management or archival purposes.The only improvement I would recomend:  use 3 LEDs, maybe green, yellow, and red to indicate status.  As it is it uses one indicator that is blue when it is ready, blue/ teal pulsing while it is cloning, and teal when it is complete.  Sure, it works, it even looks kinda neat- but it isn't a clear delineation between status.

The only problem with this tool bag is that it is so perfect you will probably weigh it down and make it too heavy and hard to carry- but that is your fault, not the bag's- and the bag can take it.This bag has essentially become the home of all of my hand tools.  I work in different places and I found that when the tools were hung up nice on the peg-board in my shop I was constantly needing a tool somewhere else.

The instructions didn't work well for me.The instructions indicate the compression nuts go through the deflector.However, they didn't fit.Apparently they only gone into the hood.I attempted to drilled out the holes in the deflector to fit which worked- except I wasn't careful enough and the drill bit broke out one of the two holes.  Not happy about this, but I affected a repair and all is well.The instructions also specified to remove the rubber strip under the hood.1- This is not as easy to do as it is to say, I managed to get the first (of a dozen) plastic "rivet" out, destroying the rivet.I then opted to see if the deflector would fit without removing the rubber.2- the deflector fits just fine without removing the rubber.Normally I would have caught these discrepancies in the instructions, but I was in a bit of a rush trying to get the thing put on before work one morning, but my own haste got me this time.  In this case I think no instructions would have been better than the instructions that were included.

The wrench sizes are metric, which is sometimes annoying, but I have another similar tool and the wrench sizes are standard, and that too is sometimes annoying.  Because of the cool skull "head" it is just a bit longer than other tools, which is great for leverage and bad in the pocket.  The tip is very sharp, I've made razor perfect cuts in paper with this thing.
I love these shirts, they fit great, look great, and they are so soft- really can't say anything more than these are awesome.
Works great, but you have to follow the directions.

Absolutely fantastic compressor, it is so quiet it will stun and amaze-The unit arrived, however, with a faulty pressure switch- but C-A-T responded immediately, provided me instructions to adjust the pressure switch  to allow the compressor to be usable, and shipped me a new switch overnight.They actually called me directly in less than 24 hours of contacting them through their website.I made the adjustment, which allows the compressor to function normally but only allowed the pressure to get up to about 140.The replacement pressure switch works perfectly.Amazing product, great customer service, better than I could have expected.
Perfect for my armorers toolbox.

These are not Lego brand, which is not a big deal, except: The outside dimensions of the plate are just a tiny bit larger than a Lego plate.We bought these along with Lego brand to glue down to a play table to make one large Lego surface, we mixed up greens, grays, and blues to give a variety of environments.To make 3 of these 5"x5" plates align with a Lego 15"x15" we had to trim about a razors width off the outside edges of these plates, otherwise the dots would be out of alignment.Otherwise they worked great!

These are not Lego brand, which is not a big deal, except: The outside dimensions of the plate are just a tiny bit larger than a Lego plate.We bought these along with Lego brand to glue down to a play table to make one large Lego surface, we mixed up greens, grays, and blues to give a variety of environments.To make 3 of these 5"x5" plates align with a Lego 15"x15" we had to trim about a razors width off the outside edges of these plates, otherwise the dots would be out of alignment.Otherwise they worked great!

It took me a little bit to figure this thing out.  The switched circuits do not pull power from the power source connected to the board- you have to supply a hot lead to each circuit, this can be good, allowing the device to witch any voltage you want to apply allowing for devices of several different voltages being controlled by the box, but it makes the wiring a little messy and most likely wont all fit in the enclosure.

Video quality is poor.  We bought this to use with an infrared golf simulator.  It works for that.Keystone adjustment is minor and very course.  Text on screen is very difficult to read unless it is very large.Any angle will cause distortion at the far edges.

The large latch works great, it makes it easier to isolate mechanical manipulations to the non-shooting hand, this is especially usefull on a CQB gun and on a bi-pod mounted mid range shooter with a big optic.I also recommend the troy ambi mag release as a companion to this charge handle.

It shreds, shreds, shreds.  The confetti this thing puts out might not be as fine as the paper slivers that military office shredders produce, but it is fine enough that what you shred will stay shredded.The credit card shredder slot does not cut cards into nearly as small bits, but it does an adequate job.It is very quiet for what it does, and although it will choke on junk mail envelopes fed into it straight out of the mail box, it will eagerly devour several pages at a time.If you are concerned with the amount of personal information you might be disclosing by throwing anything in the garbage, this shredder is a worthwhile investment- don't waste money buying a little shredder, get something that will do the job, so that you will actually use it.The bin is large enough that it doesn't feel like a daily chore emptying it.It is tall enough to sit on its own on the floor and you don't feel like you are exercising to bend over and feed it.The finger sensing safety function is cool, if you have little curious people with little curious fingers in your house, or even that occasionally visit your house, you need this feature.

For such a small part the price is a little steep, but this is an outstanding upgrade for specialty AR15s.This is ideal on a CQB gun- allowing a right handed shooter to grip-and-rip the mag with the left hand and not have to manipulate anything with the right hand.This also works well on a AR set up with a long range optic and a bi-pod, again allowing the non-shooting hand to do all of the manipulations  (as long as you are using short magazines).I also recommend a badger latch charge handle for both of these special purpose AR15 builds.That covers those two special purpose built AR15s.  I wouldn't install this on a standard "general purpose" AR15/ M16.  It works so well that I think it would be too easy to inadvertently drop a magazine at an inopportune time.We don't want that happening, do we?

Fits AR15s superbly, regardless of add-ons.The main cargo compartment is a top loader, or through a side zipper opening.  It makes a sort of sense that if the rifle is in the pack it can't be set on the packs bottom really isn't the bottom, so it would be sitting on the ground on the packs left side.  Do to the design of the pack, as a top loader it is very deep. So I wish the pack had a little better accessibility with a full opening back.

I really wanted to love it, I really really did.  I tried to, but it just isn't happening.  The wifi router functionality is just bad.  Everything else seems to work as advertised.  It is a little challenging to set up some of the apps and such, there is a lot of geek jedi going on in this thing.  So far it does one thing well, and that is to connect my IP camera to the web, which due to my ISP has been a challenge.I think that the Vera products are fine, but if you are looking for one device to handle your network and your home automation- don't.  Spend less and go with the Veralite and stick to a quality router for your network.Shipping was great, the product is very plain, the packaging was also very plain, which is okay.  The support documentation that comes in the package seemed out of date, and one of the links in the documentation is no longer valid.  This wasn't a major issue, it just took a few extra minutes banging around on the website.Sorry.

I was expecting something that produces a variable (4.5-8 pounds) trigger pressure followed by a simulated hammer fall, followed by a simulated sear reset.  In other words- a dry fire trigger.  Apparently it doesn't exist.What I got was a bore light, that cleverly enough activates by pressing the trigger.  But there is no hammer fall or reset.  What it does provide is a trigger that I can work that does have a some resistance.As a dry fire training aid the laser is pointless, which means it is added cost to the system that I could be done without.In an AR,  the line-of-sights are so high above the line-of-bore that the laser strike is hidden behind the front sight post at anything less than 10 meters (and that requires the rear elevation to be maxed out)That, and of course the shooters visual focus should be on the sights and not the target area, so looking for a laser strike is bad training.I will keep it, but I do not recommend the device as a dry fire training aid.  I might recommend the device as an engagement skills trainer, especially if it is used in a training scenario with observer-controllers who can watch for the laser strikes on targets, or it might be fun to set up a "shoot house" if you can afford to buy a bunch of the laser targets.Build quality is not impressive.  Mine has a split on one side following what looks like an injection mold seam.  The battery contact is a little odd (a washer soldered to the end of a piece of wire that makes the negative contact)Sadly I probably could have built this device using an old bore guide and a laser pointer, but I give them credit for getting the thing manufactured and marketed-  Maybe they can work on the simulated trigger- give it a break and a reset, and make something that replicates the feel of a live trigger.  That might actually be worth this price.

In fact, I never do hesitate to order from this seller, which means I've got quite a few patches from them.This patch lives on a tan condor cap, It's my hat of choice when I'm in an extra NRA-ee mood. I am a bit of a gear geek, and yes I own a lot of 5.11 gear.  Among several, I have an orange 5.11 cap, and subdued red, white and blue really looks kinda orangish, which means this patch just looks great on that cap.

This thing should be oh so cool, but-1. With no front camera to sense when the camera is up to your face it has been coded so the phone app locks the screen as soon as a call is in progress.  If you are dialing into anything requiring key presses- like your voicemail- you will have to unlock the screen every few seconds.2.  There is no update available from LG, there is no rom mod available from cyanogen, there is nothing you can do to update the OS (without risking bricking it by installing a ROM built for another model)  I have tried several no-lock apps, and not one can over ride the coding for the screen lock.3.  Regardless of the screen lock and display timeout settings applied in Security or Display settings the phone screen locks right about 30 seconds of inactivity.  Again, there seems to be no way around that.4. The LG App Adviser wont connect over wifi- and there is no updated app available from LG or in the Play store.The screen is small.  I'm not saying that as a complaint, just be forewarned.Form factor is not bad, it is a little fat, as to be expected for a phone with a physical keyboard, but otherwise it is all around small.The slide out keyboard is actually quite good.It makes voice calls with about the same reception as any other phone, and it's not bad for text.  If you evaluate it as an Android based message phone it is not awful, I just wish I could disable the auto screen lock during calls.

Captivating and extremely suspenseful, Pretty Girls is the kind of book one doesn't want to put down until the last page is read and the book closed. Even after I finished reading this novel, the characters and scenarios remained in my thoughts for a couple of days.An abducted girl and a very deceptive man's obsession with her sisters lead to the almost utter destruction of a family. Fortunately Claire and Lydia are determined to find the sick individuals who did this and bring them to justice.As usual Karin Slaughter created a cast of totally realistic and thoroughly flawed characters to populate this story. Fortunately, helpless rich wife, Claire, is forced to become much more self-sufficient during the massive drama that hits her and her family. In helping her sister and almost endangering her own daughter, Lydia obtains peace of mind and the justice she had been wanting for more than twenty years.A true page-turner, this book hardly gives the reader a chance to breathe as one suspenseful and horrific scene follows another. Every page read is a step of discovery of corruption in government, law enforcement and those nearest and dearest to the main characters.Thrilling, suspenseful and utterly satisfying, Pretty Girls is an absolute must-read. (Ellen Fritz)

What an extraordinary adventure! Neil Gaiman is undoubtedly a master at his craft. It takes a literary genius to knit such an inventive tale with such amazing characters. This story reminded me very much of the sort of books I grew up with as a child. I think Ill listen to this on audio as well just to experience it all over again.

Way, WAAAYYYY before the final page, I knew I was going to give this novel a resounding five stars. It more than deserves it. In my wildest dreams I never thought I would love this book as much as I have.This Song Will Save Your Life breaks out of the YA mold with fists swinging. I liked every single character in this story; even the less than stellar ones. Mostly I could relate to Elise and I loved, loved, LOVED the strong voice the author gave her.Every aspect of this story gels together to create a winning formula. The characters are excellent, the music is tasteful, and I lived myself into the nightlife setting at Start. I could hear the music, feel the excitement and joy of every dancer, experience the crackling atmosphere, and I smiled like a lunatic while dancing to the music in mind that Char and Elise were playing. My heart went out to Elise and her struggles, and I so appreciated her sincerity and brutal honesty.I loved Elises story  plain and simple as that. She isnt unique, but she is one hundred percent authentic and relatable. The author nailed it with this character. I appreciated the close relationship between Elise and her parents and Im so happy that I got to know her parents and siblings as well. I loved how Elise made mistakes but also how she learned through each of her mistakes and had to deal with the consequences of her actions.Another reason why Im saying that this story breaks out of the YA mold is because the romance is so different. I can only applaud Leila Sales for writing a romance that is so different from what Im used to getting in YA. I wish more authors would be this brave. I dont want to say more about it, or I might spoil it for those who havent read it yet.Can you tell by now how much I LOVED this book? Honestly, I cant wait to read more by this author who has such an incredible talent of bringing her characters to life. I dont think Ive even scratched the surface of all the things I LOVED about this book, but Im sure youve by now added it to your to-read list, and thats all that matters to me. Read this book. Now.

Hate List is a captivating novel with a great deal of depth. Blamed for conspiring with her boyfriend, Nick Levil, Valerie Leftman has to suffer through a senior year of hatred, accusations and guilt; all this because of a seemingly innocent list of names of people that she and Nick disliked.As all excellent books should, Hate List starts with a scene that instantly grabs the attention of the reader. Though the book remains quite gripping throughout, there are parts that are a bit lengthy thus hindering the forward motion of the story.The magic of this novel lies in the development and growth of Valerie's character. Not only does she have to move past her grief over her boyfriend's suicide, she also has to face her own guilt over the death and injury done to several people at her school by said boyfriend.When the school year starts, she must face not only her own guilt, but also the accusations and often the hatred of the other kids and even the teachers. This book is all about her psychological journey to healing and the forming of new friendships.The other characters are realistic and all the family scenarios are natural and not exaggerated. For a relaxing read with some depth, I think Hate List is a very worthwhile read. (Ellen Fritz)

In short, this book is mostly much aboutwell, nothing. The first 85% is just your average teenage characters doing typical teenage stuff. Lots of making out, hanging out with da boys, crushing on said boys, the Spring Queen dance, buying dresses for the dance, and getting ready for the aforementioned dance. The last 15% of the book is when the story actually kicks in, but because its the last few pages, expect a massive amount of info dump.Admittedly, the story starts of intriguing and with the discovery of the pyxis box some mystery can be expected. But then the pacing slows down to a crawl and not much of anything happens almost until the end. If youre not put off by the usual grammar errors which are rife in self-pub books, this makes for good afternoon reading to lull you into an afternoon nap.

A superb blend of reinvented history and steampunk set in an alternate reality, this novel turned out to be an excellent and well-imagined read. The story gripped me right from the start and I was awed and mesmerized by the fantastic and frightening inventions of Charlottes world. I wasnt very interested in the romance once it turned into a love-triangle (oh, do I despise those!), but the varied cast of characters, nefarious secrets, mysteries, and brutal tyranny of the empire kept me glued to the pages. All in all this was an exciting novel that set my imagination alight!

I would never have guessed at the start of this story that I would end up giving it less than a four-star rating. The first half of the book flowed well and I was completely onboard with the romance between Becca and Nikolai. Sadly, a little after halfway, everything started falling flat when  after knowing each other for less than a week  these two MCs became so lovesick and obsessed with each other, and their romance so sappy, it put me off completely. Clearly Stanton has not yet received the memo that insta-love has become a big no-no and a thing of the past. Both these characters are eighteen and therefore I expected a certain level of maturity and clear-headedness, especially from the one who is a royal.Prince Nikolai isnt exactly princely. He only seems to be one in name, but does not behave like, or talk like, a royal. He comes across as a very ordinary teenager and I feel the author couldve done a lot more to make him more like a prince. To me it didnt feel like a prince fell in love with Becca; more like just a boy falling in love with just a girl. Why then bother to make Nikolais character a prince at all?The upside of this book was that I got to travel to a lot of places with Nikolai and Becca. The author either travels a lot, or did her research incredibly well, because she got the different settings down pat, and it was effortless to imagine the places she described.I would consider reading more of Angie Stantons future novels. But for that to happen she will definitely have to get her A-game on where romance is concerned, as well as doing away with the immaturity of her characters. She has potential and this book was centered on a fantastic idea, its just a pity the ending was so predictable and left me disappointed.

The Appearance of Annie Van Sinderen is a relaxing, sometimes thoroughly scary and slightly longwinded read. Wes and Tyler have film study projects to complete. Will the sudden appearance of Annie Van Sinderen benefit the project or threaten to derail, at least, Wes's effort?I had to read almost half of this novel before I was convinced that I wanted to actually finish it. A worthwhile read in the end, I found, especially the first part of this book overly descriptive and unnecessarily drawn out with lots of superfluous detail.The characters are fleshed out and extremely realistic. The young men, Wes and Tyler, are typical and rather irritating nineteen-year-olds. Wes, with his very obvious self image problem, complicates his own life with his insecurities about approaching women.Annie is very realistically portrayed in both her ghostly as well as her nineteenth century New York girl persona. Maddie is probably the most intriguing and likable character in this book.The final third of this story, however, makes reading The Appearance of Annie Van Sinderen a reasonably exciting and pleasurable experience.Those who love tales of hauntings with a hint of time travel may find this book a truly pleasant read. (Ellen Fritz)

What a cute and memorable novella! Accident-prone Bonnie, the main character, is your typical rom-com heroine who is just plain unlucky. Of course, her ideal man is right under her nose, but she has to go through some stuff before she actually realizes this. The humor is straight from a string of well-known romantic comedy movies, but Bonnie is such an adorable character, it doesnt really matter what inspired her antics in this story.I was adequately impressed with Liz Appels writing (considering shes a self-pub), and I enjoyed every minute of this lighthearted romance novella. I will most certainly read more of her books and stories.

This book is my first Jennifer E. Smith experience, and will most certainly not be the last. I actually enjoyed this story a lot more than I initially thought I would, you know, seeing as its a romance and all. But what a beautiful romance it was! It was balanced perfectly and did not overshadow the development of this lovely cast of characters.I loved how the author didnt describe any of the characters  or had them think of each other  as cute or hot. Those are two words in the YA and romance genres that time and again make me gag. I mean, with a little creative effort on any authors part, there are so many imaginative and alternative ways to describe a love-interest. Jennifer E. Smith proves my point with her inventive ways of sketching these two main characters and how they perceive each other.Also, this romance doesnt follow the usual plot formula. It ends in such a way where anything can still happen for Lucy and Owen. I think the reason I enjoyed this story so much is because I didnt know how it was going to end for them, and also because, through Lucy and Owens travels, I got to visit parts of the U.S. Europe, Scotland and London.Overall, this was a delightful read and I was wholly enveloped in this poignant romance that took me places and allowed me to get to know two striking characters. I was also impressed that unlike most YA novels, this one didnt get anywhere near a high school, and just goes to show that love can happen outside of the confines of a classroom. I wish more YA authors would be this creative with their setting.

Set in the mid nineteenth century during the California gold-rush, Walk on Earth a Stranger is a captivating and often touching read. After her parents' brutal murder, Leah Westfall is forced to leave her hometown of Dahlonega, Georgia, to escape her uncle, Hiram. Hoping to meet up with her longtime friend, Jefferson McCauly, she heads west with thousands of gold seekers and pioneers with only her horse, Peony, for company.A true page-turner, Walk on Earth a Stranger is definitely among my favorite five books for this year. This book gripped me from the very first page where it is revealed that the main character, Lee, has an unusual supernatural gift. From there on I simply immersed myself in the adventures of Leah, her horse, and her best friend, Jefferson.The characters in this book are realistic, endearing and definitely the kind of people one wants to continue reading about. Leah is tough and gutsy, yet, deep down she is still the lady her mother wanted her to be.Jefferson is a bit more of an enigma. With his Native American heritage, he is often bitter about other people's attitudes regarding his ethnicity. He and Leah make a wonderful team when they are working for the Joiner family. Together, and knowing each other's ways, they perform several rescues during the hard journey to California.What struck me was the staggering amount of research the author must have put into this book. Vivid descriptions of life in a travelling wagon train put me right there with the families as they journeyed across prairie, desert and mountains. Romance is only hinted at throughout most of this story.For a stimulating, gripping and deeply touching read, I recommend Walk on Earth a Stranger as an absolute must-read. (Ellen Fritz)

Full of dark twists and even more twisted characters, Horns is a captivating and sometimes scary read. When Ignatius Perrish wakes up with horns growing out of his temples, he knows that he must have done something really bad the previous night. When, subsequently, he starts getting confessions of terrible thoughts and sins from everybody he meets, he knows that the devil must have a hand in his change.From the captivating start to the very realistic and satisfying end of this book, it kept me enthralled all the time. Despite the fine detail, numerous back stories and lengthy visits to Ignatius's mind, I never found my attention straying.The main character, Ignatius, or Iggy, as we get to know him, is a truly good person with a couple of realistic personality flaws; a good guy who really tries to combat the torrent of evil that grips hold of him once the horns have appeared. Even then, and despite the evil thoughts and confessions he picks up from the various people he encounters, he still tries to do the right thing.This book really makes one think about the dual nature of most human beings. Through Iggy's eyes we get to see the hatred lurking in the minds of his own family, the sinful thoughts of the local priest and the tormented insanity in the mind of a good friend. We walk the past with Iggy while he hunts through the minds and thoughts of others as well as his own, seeking the truth behind the murder of his beloved Merrin.For a thrilling, often frightening read that will make you think deeply about the secrets and motives of others, I recommend Horns as a very, very worthwhile read. (Ellen Fritz)

Deeply touching and most certainly one of the best books I've read so far this year, Still Alice brought me to whole new insights about Alzheimer's. Alice Howland, with her teaching position at Harvard and her PHD in cognitive Psychology, is diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's at the age of 50. Apart from her husband and three children having to deal with this, most importantly, she must deal with it.At the start of this book the reader is given a look into the still healthy mind of the main character, Alice. She is a busy, widely traveling professor with a busy social life and a passion for running.Once the Alzheimer's symptoms begin to show, the reader is already familiar with the person and the psyche of Alice. This makes Alice's journey into the confusion of Alzheimer's just so much more gripping and poignant.The medical detail of Alice's treatment, the tests she has to endure and even the hope given by drug testing on her brings a wonderful realism to this story. What really touched me is when Alice wished that she could have rather contracted cancer as in that case she would have a fighting chance. She sees cancer victims as heroes while Alzheimer's victims are simply insane people best locked away and forgotten by society.For a touching and, in many ways, an eye-opening read, I recommend Still Alice as a must-read. (Ellen Fritz)

Bordering on horror, The Boy Who Drew Monsters, is a gripping and often scary read. While Jack Peter Keenan draws Monsters with an almost manic urgency, his parents, as well as his friend, Nick, is drawn into the nightmare depicted by said pictures.Despite the wonderfully clever plot, the vivid descriptions of both nature and the monsters and the lifelike characters, I found this book somewhat depressing. All the characters seem to be stuck in their past, their regrets, or the world of Jack Peter's imagination. There is absolutely no humor to break the dire atmosphere of this story.The characters, though lifelike and fleshed out, are difficult to identify with. Jack Peter's apparent instability is masterfully depicted while leaving the reader with numerous questions as to whether he is truly insane, extremely intelligent, or perhaps supernaturally gifted. I actually found myself slightly afraid of this enigmatic main character.The final pages of this book hold a clever surprise. Its a surprise that gives the tale an oddly satisfying end. The descriptions of nature and, especially, that of winter in a winter bound coastal town in Maine, are richly vivid, placing the reader right there in the middle of the drama surrounding the Keenan family.A suspenseful and often frightening tale, I recommend The Boy Who Drew Monsters as a worthwhile read. (Ellen Fritz)

The Weight Of Blood is another book that will most certainly make it onto my best reads for 2015 list. After her best friend, Cheri, had been gruesomely murdered, Lucy is determined to find the killer as well as the secret behind her own mother's strange disappearance when Lucy was just a baby.This is undoubtedly one of the best books I've read in a long time. The story gripped me from the word go and kept me captivated throughout. As it is told from alternating points of view it gives the reader a thorough picture of what was truly happening in and around the little Ozark town of Henbane.The true magic of this book, however, lies in the characters. Not only are they well fleshed out, they are real people; people with strengths and weaknesses. Even the worst villain in this tale has a couple of redeeming qualities.The main character, Lucy, is a normal teenage girl who has to live with a difficult, somewhat alcoholic father. Though she is determined to find out what happened to her friend, Cheri, she isn't all tough and all successful like so many unrealistic heroines.The background against which this book is set is realistic and, in itself, a captivating world of small town politics, family secrets, under the table deals, and poor but warmhearted people.For a deeply touching and often suspenseful read with a healthy dose of romance, I recommend The Weight Of Blood as a must-read. (Ellen Fritz)

Set in Paris, France, Die for Me, with its unique take on the undead, is a captivating tale of heroism and love. Having tragically lost her parents, Kate immerses herself in books and art. That is, until she meets Vincent and her life changes from the aforementioned passive world to one of adventure and romance.Though truly a comfortably paced and relaxing read, this book held my attention all the way. The paranormal theme of undead revenants is skillfully worked into everyday life as we know it, thus making it just so much more believable.Kate is a realistic and well fleshed out main character. She is tough and capable when necessary, yet feminine enough to stir the protective instinct of, not only Vincent, but also that of others, including her elder sister, Georgia.The male main character, Vincent, is a lifelike and believable character with an old-world charm. Despite his long life, rather sad back-story, and dangerous and extraordinary calling, he is a sensitive and thoughtful person; very much any young girl's dream.Filled with heroic deeds, suspense and a healthy dose of romance, I consider Die for Me a very worthwhile read. (Ellen Fritz)

Though lengthy, The Wise Man's Fear grips the reader's imagination all the way. Continuing his tale begun in The Name of the Wind, Kvothe takes us back to The University, to the court of the Maer Alveron, to the fighting school of the Adem and through numerous bandit hunting and roadside adventures.Having read and enjoyed The Name of the Wind, I looked forward to reading The Wise Man's Fear. I was slightly disappointed. This book, though written in beautiful prose and with wonderfully imaginative descriptions, is extremely long. Even though I read it over a period of time, at times I just wished the story would get a move on.Probably because of the finer detail in this story, as well as the length, one gets to know Kvothe very well. A well fleshed out character, Kvothe is a sensitive, romantic soul and certainly a hero, with several glaring personality flaws; making him a lovable and realistic main character.The world building in this book is even better and more brilliantly inventive than in the previous book. Here one can truly lose oneself in the fantasy realms and Kvothe's adventures.If you read The Wise Man's Fear at leisure, it has a treasure trove of adventure, romance and lots of magic to offer. (Ellen Fritz)

Im curious: is this the same Sarah Lotz who wrote the unforgettable novel, The Three? It sure doesnt read as though it was written by the same author. I am shocked at the terrible, stilted, and unnatural dialogue between the characters! And whats up with psychic, Celine Del Ray, starting every second sentence with, Know this.? Good grief it was annoying!Overall, I think this book had a great ending. Much like Lotzs previous novel, the excellently written and well plotted, The Three, but still different. I liked the idea on which this story was built, and I enjoyed being part of the panic the passengers felt while being stranded in the ocean with the cruise ship falling apart around them. I really got into all of it and felt the fear and desperation of the characters. I also enjoyed the different points of view of the many voices that tells the story, and I felt the Suicide Sisters were a unique addition to this story.Day Four most certainly has its strong points and its weak points. However, for me it didnt hold a candle to The Three. It just wasnt what I got from the fitting cover and synopsis. So by the way, although reference is made to the aforementioned book, this one can still be read as a stand-alone. I have mixed feelings about Day Four, but it certainly wont deter me from reading another of Lotzs future books.

Having read and thoroughly enjoyed The Kiss of Deception, I really looked forward to reading The Heart of Betrayal. I wasn't disappointed at all! In fact, I honestly think The Heart of Betrayal is an even better book than The Kiss of Deception.Having always believed the Vendans to be barbarians, captives, Lia and Rafe are in for a few interesting surprises. While Rafe plans an escape and Lia hopes to be saved against all odds, both prisoners must play their respective roles to gain the advantage of time and avoid being killed.A page-turner in the true sense of the word, I simply couldn't put this book down. The excellent world building combined with extremely lifelike and colorful characters, makes reading The Heart of Betrayal a feast.As Vendan politicians, the Komizar and his Rahtan hover, ready to pounce at the slightest wrong or traitorous move from our two main characters, the suspense builds to nail biting proportions. The last part of this book is fast moving and filled with scenes that will have you holding your breath.Although she is a princess, Lia is tough, intelligent and capable enough to hold her own in dangerous situations. She is an excellent actress, cleverly deceiving the Komizar into believing her a willing captive.Rafe, our other main character and truly a prince at heart, has an equally difficult role to fulfill. The third key character, Caden, though a little more in the background in this book, has to deal with inner turmoil, division of loyalties and a heart that wants to go its own way.Despite my aversion to love triangles, the triangle in this book keeps a low profile. At least Lia knows to whom her heart belongs.I highly recommend The Heart of Betrayal as a thrilling and captivating reading experience. (Ellen Fritz)

The first thought I had after finishing this book: Please tell me theres a third on the way! Then I discovered that there will indeed be a third book, and I gave a sigh of relief.You know, it very seldom happens that I give the sequel to a much-loved first book in a series, five stars. Nine out of ten times I find that the second book hardly ever lives up to my expectations. I am so incredibly relieved that it wasnt the same for this book. I had high expectations for The Invasion of the Tearling after I finished the first book, and my expectations were met in spades!Unlike with The Queen of the Tearling, the sequel moves from YA into New Adult territory. If it had followed the expected and typical NA plot formula, this magnificent novel wouldve probably left me disappointed. Johansen cleverly steers away from the overused NA plot formula and gives the reader something fresh and different, with only a few elements of the aforementioned genre, such as profanity and adult themes, but without it becoming crude and distasteful. It worked perfectly well for me, and actually it was the next natural step to move into this genre, as Kelseas character grows in leaps and bounds.From countless glowing reviews on the blogs I follow, I wasnt sure whether I was going to enjoy Lilys story. Surprisingly I did, and found that it is as much an integral part of the Tearlings history as Kelseas character is to the survival or destruction of the Tearling.Overall, this was a glorious read and even though it took me nearly five days to work my way through it, it was well worth every minute of reading time. I would love to shake Johansens hand and thank her from the bottom of my heart for steering clear of the romance backbone countless authors cant seem to do without for their novels. It takes a truly talented writer with one heck of an imagination to create a story of such epic proportions, and Johansens got it down pat!

In short, this book is about many things. Every reader, I believe, will take something different away from it. Im not going to go on my usual spiel about the characters, plot, world-building, etc. Brutal Youth is not just about the students, but also about their parents and the teachers at St. Michaels. The two points that stood out for me the most were that the good guys dont always win, and that the best revenge you can get is making people see the worst parts of themselves.Overall, this is a great read and if youve read Some Girls Are by Courtney Summers, Id also recommend this novel, proving that its not just girls who have it hard at school.Hopefully Breznican wont make us wait long for his next offering!

I love books featuring strong, butt-kicking protagonists, and thats just what this book is. Apparently this is also supposed to be an epic romance novel, but fortunately for me, the romance didnt overshadow the story and pretty much remained in the background. Even though the romance plays a small part in this story, it took me by surprise and was not predictable in any way.The majority of the characters in this story is strong and performs their parts with passion. However, the winning formula that makes this book a hit is the political intrigue and royal court conspiracies. That is ultimately what kept me reading. Grave Mercy might be specifically for a YA audience, but I would also recommend it to older readers who enjoy historical fiction.

Landline did, most unfortunately, not live up to my expectations. When I read about communicating in the past, I thought, WOW! Sadly the book didn't deliver.Georgie has to stay in LA while Neal and the girls visit his mother in Omaha. A similar separation happened years ago. Suddenly, when Georgie uses the old landline rotary phone to call Neal, the past and the present become entwined.The idea of a specific kind of phone and phone call taking the characters into the past, is very inventive and imaginative. That, however, is where my fascination with this book stopped.Throughout the story the reader is immersed in Georgie's doubts, self doubts, fears and uncertainties. She seems, quite understandably, thrown into turmoil by suddenly encountering the Neal of their youth. It takes her rather long to start making positive decisions about said development.The two positive points in favor of this book is: the clever plot and the truly excellent dialogue. The end is unpredictable and thus urges the reader to continue turning the pages.For those who like books about relationships with lots of dialogue, Landline may be a very worthwhile and relaxing read. (Ellen Fritz)

I recently finished Some Girls Are by this same author, and if I have to compare this novel against that one, I think Some Girls Are is much better. Or at least, I enjoyed it more. Cracked Up To Be has much going for it and also features a strong protagonist, but the massive amount of angst was just too much for me. I did like how it featured friends who cared for our leading girl and parents who were worried about their daughter, as well as educators and a principal who did their best to accommodate her wish to graduate. Also, the romance takes a backseat and is surprisingly unpredictable, and that always scores a lot of points with me. Overall, a good read.

Im convinced a staggering amount of research went into writing this story. Im seriously impressed. Mark Watney is a phenomenal character, not only for surviving on Mars, but mostly because during all that time at deaths door and with the odds stacked against his survival, he remains optimistic and does so with an incredible sense of humor. Needless to say, even though sci-fi isnt one of my preferred genres, Im really happy I read this book and I wholeheartedly agree with every glowing review it receives. Well done, Andy Weir!

A very relaxing, yet highly exciting read, The Burning Sky, with surprises round every corner, is the kind of book you won't be able to put down. Young Prince Titus must protect the greatest elemental mage of his time, no matter the cost. If that means making a girl pose as a school boy during Victorian times and in Victorian England, so be it.I very almost didn't read this book. When it started with fire magic and elixirs, I thought, 'oh no, not another one'. Fortunately I persevered and was pleasantly surprised!The world building in this book is absolutely stunning. On the one hand we get the highly inventive mage realms and Atlantis, and on the other the perfectly normal Victorian England. The mage realms, especially, is incredibly well described and imaginative. The historically accurate descriptions of Victorian England balance the abundance of magic and paranormal phenomena in the mage realms.The characters, though not anything extraordinary, are well fleshed out and lifelike. However, this book is first and foremost a romance novel in a fantasy setting. The romance is skillfully and tastefully written, with the hero and heroine as the perfect romantic couple.Still, for me the true magic of this book lay in the imaginative world building and the numerous surprises said world holds for the reader. The Burning Sky, with its flying chariots, magical beasts, princes riding to the rescue and its very ordinary cricket,  is most certainly an enjoyable and worthwhile read for both romance and fantasy readers. (Ellen Fritz)

Ive read the controversy on some of the blogs I follow about the parent who made a fuss about this book being on her daughters recommended reading list by her school and then got the school to remove it from the list and replace it with another book. Being naturally curious, I wanted to know whats in this book that could upset a parent so much as to do something that drastic. Now after finishing Some Girls Are, I can see what that mother might be distressed about, but I still dont think its fair to make that decision for every student and their parents.Some Girls Are is definitely not an easy read. Ive read countless YA novels in which the protagonist is a bully or is being bullied, but never has it been anything as disturbing as whats happening in this story. This is more real, more raw, and unbelievably terrifying. Mostly so, because this is really happening to our kids in our schools. Whether we want to know it or not, this story tells it like it is and the author isnt sugarcoating it.There is no solution being offered in this story and wont enlighten teens who are being tormented by their peers on how to deal with it. That is not the point of this novel. The point here is just that it happens and this is how far kids will go without considering the consequences. I like Regina. I like that she fought back. At first I thought it is just a story about a bully being bullied and her getting what she deserves. But it really is more than that, and at times I had to sit back and take a few deep breaths before continuing reading because the tormenting and revenge also took an emotional toll on me as reader.Overall, I think this is a good book to be on a high school recommended reading list, and even better for parents to read as well and to discuss the realities of bullying and being bullied with their child.

I cant say Im particularly a fan of Shania Twain, but Ive heard her music playing on the radio over the years, and I especially enjoy one of her songs, Ka-ching. The only reason I picked up her memoir is because I always enjoy a good rags to riches story, and this one did not disappoint.In fact, Shania Twains autobiography gave me a deeper insight into what its like for children who are neglected by parents who selfishly had more children than they could afford. It just cemented my opinion that most of the worlds poverty can be attributed to people irresponsibly having more children than they can care for. Sad to see is how she justifies the neglect by her mother and the domestic abuse by her father. I guess no matter what, most of us refuse to see our parents through anything other than rose tinted glasses.After finishing From This Moment On, I feel that Shania Twain deserves all the good things that come her way. Having grown up the way she did, making all the sacrifices she did, and working her behind off for her dream and achieving all that she has, she is more than deserving of the good life she is living. Im not saying this as a fan (because Im still not), but as someone who made the journey through Shanias life story by way of her memoir, and as a wife and a mother who has also suffered betrayal and divorce.Although much of this autobiography is Eilleen reflecting on her life and writing this book as a way to heal, beyond her sad childhood and painful divorce, there isnt much else in here that havent been publicized in the media over the years. True Shania Twain fans wont find much new in here, but others, like me, would come to know both Eilleen and Shania Twain.

When I read the blurb of Evidence of Things Not Seen, I was quite excited. Disappearances, particle physics and parallel universes are themes bound to attract my attention, but, sadly, I was quite disappointed. Tommy Smith disappears, maybe into one of the alternate dimensions he believed in, and a whole lot of people confess that, yes, he was weird but likable.Firstly, I don't even see this as a novel but rather a collection of short stories centered round a specific setting and basic plot. Because all the characters make one or, if you're lucky, two appearances, I simply couldn't identify with anybody.The theme of rape and abuse, especially aimed at women, seems to repeat itself over and over until I felt like this book was only reflecting the negative side of life.Fortunately, the individual stories - some in first person and some in third - were told in an entertaining and often captivating way. The characters in each section are adequately developed and descriptions are vivid and lifelike.The end is more or less satisfying.This is a worthwhile read if you're into really sad and often violent personal accounts of rape, drug abuse, ruined marriages and general unhappiness. Do not expect much in the way of paranormal. (Ellen Fritz)

At first, I wasnt sure whether I was going to enjoy this fast read; even after seeing many glowing reviews for it on the many blogs I follow. Now, after finishing it and having read the first three books in this series, I can see how Fairest is a necessary add-on to the Lunar Chronicles, as it preludes the next book in the series, as well as the first.Levanas back-story, as well as that of Princess Selene, her mother queen Channary, and Princess Winter, all add up to the overall build-up of what I expect is going to be a fiery conclusion in the final book of the Lunar Chronicles.Overall, if youre a fan of this magnificent series and havent read Fairest yet, please do. It is well-deserving of every positive review and all the praise it has garnered thus far.

As Ive mentioned countless times before, Im not really into the whole anthology thing. But, I was pleasantly surprised by this collection of short stories and found myself captivated and enthralled by this authors dark imagination.I enjoyed every story and dont have any particular favorites. However, two stories that stood out for me above the rest are Popcorn (because I love cats and can easily believe that they can be manipulative and evil), and also Crown Vic (because of the twisted humor found in the way it is written, as well as the narrative itself).Each story offers something new and chilling, and I wouldnt hesitate to recommend this compilation of horror novellas to anyone looking for a read that is worth every cent!
Ghost College, with its own brand of sardonic humor, is a quick, well-written read that is sure to give any reader new to the horror genre, the chills.

The Movie of Me and Earl and the Dying Girl would hopefully and most likely be better than the book. As I wasn't too impressed with a few things in the book, I would very much like to see said movie. Greg Gaines unwillingly supports his very sick childhood friend, Rachel, and changes his status at school from mainly unnoticed to unpopular.This book actually starts off with a few chapters of wonderfully witty humor and Greg's insights regarding the various social groups and hierarchy within the school. Unfortunately, his attitude towards Rachel, who is suffering from cancer, started putting me off. Add to that the constant use of four letter words and, one third into the book, I couldn't wait for it to just be over.As a main character, Greg Gaines is a disappointment. His rebellious attitude combined with his constant crude thoughts and dialogue was extremely off-putting. I most certainly wouldn't want him to be a role model for my kids. His irritation with Rachel and her illness further alienated me.His friend, Earl, is even worse with regards to crudeness, but, Earl's attitude, at least, redeemed him. Unlike Greg, Earl is sympathetic towards Rachel and genuinely tries to make her last weeks a pleasant experience for her.Having now completed my rant about all the negative points of this book, I can add that the style in which it is written is unique and kept me turning the pages. Despite the crude language, the humor is clean and truly tasteful.I hope I'll be more impressed once I get to watch the movie of Me and Earl and the Dying Girl. If you want to read it, at least the humor and the alternating writing styles of lively prose and movie script makes it worth the read. (Ellen Fritz)

I cant explain why, but Im not a fan of anthologies. No particular reason; Im just not. I picked up this anthology of short tales only because the proceeds for the sale of this book go towards a charity I feel strongly about.In short, all these stories are well-written and have depth. Every novella is identifiable by each authors unique voice and writing style, telling a story based on some or other superstitious belief. My two favorites are without a doubt The Gift of the Were-Magi by Mari Mancusi and Bloody Mary by Dianne K. Salerni. Unfortunately, The Road Home by Stephanie Kuenhert and The Silverfoot Heretic by Pab Sungenis had me stifling yawns.Overall this anthology is a quick read with stories that are well worth the time spent reading it.

This story is snort-through-your-nose hilarious! Jane is most certainly a character of another color with her outrageous scheme to fake a nine-month pregnancy with reasons only she can justify and accept. As can be expected, her impulsive plan snowballs out of control and hilarity ensues as she stacks one jaw-dropping lie on top of the other.Though the ending disappointed me so much I actually reconsidered my intended five-star rating, I noticed from the synopsis of Crossing the Line  the next Jane Taylor novel  that the conclusion is not where this story ends. Naturally, I now want to read the next book to discover what happened after the point where the story left off.The writing is superb and the characters have enough depth not to be stale. I would recommend The Thin Pink Line to fans of Sophie Kinsella and Eileen Cook.
