Set in the harsh world of social workers, child abuse, and irresponsible parenting, Little Mercies is a captivating and touching story. As a social worker, Ellen Moore changed many lives; rescuing both children and parents and often annoying said parents. When she slips up and makes a near fatal mistake, the world is out to lynch her. Yet, even while she is in the depth of trouble as well as despair, she still can't resist saving a street wise girl named Jenny.This absolutely realistic novel looks into the world of poverty, child abuse, neglect, alcohol and drug abuse and mothers who simply do not care enough about a child to make the wise move to leave the aggressive husband or boyfriend.The two point of view characters, Ellen and Jenny, are lifelike and fleshed out. However, I thought Jenny had the more developed and outstanding character of the two. She is cynical and almost hard for her ten years and she is a really smart kid. She faces betrayal and disappointment several times, yet, except for a few tears on one occasion, she moves on with her next plan of action.The change in POV, often at crucial times, certainly encouraged me to keep reading. This is truly a never-a-dull-moment read with some nail-biting suspense towards the end.A touching and often enlightening tale, I certainly recommend Little Mercies as a very worthwhile read. (Ellen Fritz)

I have watched the movie that was based on this book a thousand moons ago, and I still cant remember a thing that happened in the movie. So once I started this book, I started it on a clean slate and couldnt compare it to the movie. Of course, the book is usually better anyway (although I have come across exceptions).I love the concept of this story, and also the slow-burning romance. The ending was unexpected and I shouldve seen it coming, but I didnt. The ending also brought tears to my eyes. Overall a great, feel-good story that inspired me to do more for others.

Auracle is one of the best YA novels I've read in a good long while and will definitely be going on my favorite reads for 2015 list. Astral travel is cool, handy and exciting, yet, Anna finds out how it can also be extremely dangerous, especially with dead enemies in the vicinity.A truly good story should hook the reader from the start and this is what Auracle did for me. Anna popping out of her body and over to an erupting volcano most certainly got my attention right away. From that point on there was simply no let up as one exciting, suspenseful and often touching incident followed another.The characters are the kind of young people most teen readers would be able to relate to. Anna, the main character, dreams of going to the places to where she astral travels. Yet, in her daily life, and especially in a crisis, she is level headed and can think on her feet.Rei Ellis, the other main character, is the kind of guy of whom most young girls would dream. Loyal, physically active and attractive and, on top of all that, a gifted guitarist and singer, he most certainly has the attention of all the girls.Unfortunately, Anna and Rei's troubled friend, Seth Murphy, has to suffer the attention of equally troubled but beautiful Taylor Gleason. Taylor, the selfish, yet deeply unhappy, antagonist in this story, does inspire some sympathy from the reader.With its excellent plot and brilliantly alive and solid characters, Auracle is a stimulating and often suspenseful read. Although the romance is limited, it is tender and tastefully written. Auracle is most certainly a must-read suitable for young adults, but, can definitely also be enjoyed by older readers as well. (Ellen Fritz)

Ive read Gone Girl and seen the movie, so I was eager to read Dark Places. I almost gave up on Gone Girl, but Im glad I didnt. Dark Places hooked me right from the start. I didnt much like the main character, Libby, but I honestly think the reader isnt meant to like her. About 25% into the book I realized it doesnt matter whether I liked Libby or not, the storyline kept me captivated and I found it very difficult to put this book down. The entire time I was reading, I couldnt decide whether Ben is guilty or not. Sometimes it seemed that he was without a doubt the one who murdered his family, but then there were a whole lot of chapters in which it looked as though he couldnt possibly be the killer. In the end things come together nicely, but I felt the tone of the rest of the story wasnt captured in the conclusion. Overall, this is an addictive and suspense-laden read that was plotted expertly!

This short romantic comedy took me about fifteen minutes to finish. It felt like I was watching an episode of one of my favorite sitcoms. Its a delightful and sweet little novella that made me smile and brought on the warm and fuzzies. I would definitely read more of this authors books!

I have some mixed feelings about Lost and Found, and as I dont even know where to begin Im going to jump right in and share my likes and dislikes about this mystery adventure.The story didnt hook me straightaway. That only happened around 67% into the book. Some of the main issues I had were that the characters were rather bland. I didnt like that Blake is a hotheaded character. It wouldve made sense maybe if I knew why he was always being short-tempered. It felt as if from the minute we meet him, hes angry and his outbursts unpredictable. Julia is a much better character than Blake, but even so, I struggled to find a connection with her or any of the other characters. I did, however, like that Julia is one of Laferneys better female characters than, say, the one in his previous novel, Jumper.  Julia seemed more the type of girl I would like to have as a friend.Blakes grandfathers dementia constantly threw me off balance and by the time he disappears, it was more a relief than a sad occurrence. You know, coming to think of it, I recently finished a book by Ransom Riggs, titled Miss Peregrines Home for Peculiar Children, where the grandfather in that story also has dementia. The difference is that that character was far more believable and likable because he didnt resort to below-the-belt or toilet humor to bring the point home to the reader that he suffers from dementia. After reading that book, it was unfortunately a lot harder to sympathize or connect with Blakes grandfather.It seemed that every character that wasnt in the protagonists corner, were portrayed as immature and dumb. In my opinion, thats no way to portray your antagonists. Its like saying to your readers theyre not bright enough to figure out by themselves who the bad guys are. Thats probably not what the author intended, but thats sure how it made me feel. Take for instance schoolyard bully, Kevin. Ive seen this type of bully/antagonist in Laferneys previous novels. The same can be said for all the bad guys in this story who are older than Kevin. They all seem to have the behavior of a mentally challenged ten-year-old. Because of this and the fact that a lot of focus was placed on Kevin and his fathers behavior in the early chapters, it was easy to spot from early on who the culprits were going to be in the end, and thus it came as no surprise (except for one, but by then it no longer mattered).There arent many surprises in this story, even though there are a ton of clues leading up to the eventual find  which turns out to also not be surprising or revealing much. The one treasure Blake and Julia uncovers is so unlikely, it wasnt even believable, and more so because it is never explained how it came to be in Blakes familys possession.What I enjoyed about this book was the fast pace. That also means there was a ton of info dump with few to no breathers in between. For many avid mystery readers this would not be a problem, though some, like me, prefer our mysteries to be uncovered gradually and with little breaks spaced in to get to know our characters and their surroundings better.What was a huge plus for me was the sweet and subtle romance between Blake and Julia which I think the author timed perfectly well. I also enjoyed reading the Authors Note at the end which gave me insight into his research and which parts of the story are fictional and which were based on facts/truth. The dialogue in the beginning of the story is a little stunted, but towards the middle it smoothes out and adds depth to the protagonists voices.Overall I feel this is a clever YA mystery with lots to offer its most curious readers. The topic and setting has clearly been well researched and the clues  as confusing as it might be at times  serve their purpose to bring the characters to their intended destination. The writing is typical Laferney and the author sticks to the style he is known for best, which means if youve read any of his previous novels, youll feel right at home settling into Lost and Found.

High fantasy with a liberal helping of Roman empire, An Ember in the Ashes is going to the top of my list of favorite books read so far this year. Although they come from completely different backgrounds and have different missions and goals, Laia and Elias keep crossing paths. In the end Laia is placed before a choice. Can her choice help both people she needs to save?Where can I start my rave about this book. Firstly, the world building is absolutely brilliant and highly believable. Although the fictional empire is based on the Roman empire, it is still unique enough to stand as a universe in its own right.The characters are fleshed out and often very realistically flawed. As the female main character, Laia, is a girl after my own heart. Courageous and tough, yet sometimes naturally swayed by emotion, at seventeen she is already proving that she could become what her mother was, The Lioness.Elias, except for his very normal moments of wanting to jump ship, is the ultimate hero. Even when certain death awaits him, he refuses to cross certain lines or sacrifice his personal values.Other wonderfully crafted characters like Helen, Cook, and Izzi, make this an  unforgettable reading experience.The author is a master at creating the kind of situations that put me, for one, on an emotional roller coaster. The hints at romance in this story are kept low key. Although magic and the paranormal feature strongly, it is incorporated in natural and believable ways.For a read that will thrill as well as touch you deeply, I recommend An Ember in the Ashes as an absolute must-read. (Ellen Fritz)

I can see why this book is being made into a movie. It is going to be EPIC! What a wonderful and imaginative story this is; completely different and just what I needed. Filled with mystery, fantastically unique characters and intense, bloodcurdling action, this is through and through a ten-star read!

The ending of this story left me elated and satisfied, but the journey I had to undergo with Reece, Cathy, her family, and other key role players to get to this wonderful finale was harrowing and painful.  I thought I had heard and read enough to understand the extent abusive parents will go to to damage their own flesh and blood, but this book made me realize that I had no clue.I could almost not fathom a mother such as Tracey and for a while there thought the author was exaggerating about how terrifying and massively disturbed Tracey is, but once all the distressing details came together to form a bigger picture of Reeces home life before he was removed from his mother, I had to accept that the world is filled with such monsters.The sadder truth is that there are parents doing even worse things to their children than Tracey has done to Reece and his siblings. All I can say is that Im grateful for foster parents such as Cathy who take these children into their homes with love, patience, understanding and compassion, and give them a fresh start to a new life. I have a seven-year-old son and it pained me to read this book, knowing I would never in a million years do to my kids what Tracey did to hers.Thank you, Cathy, for sharing this story with us.

Wow, I can almost not believe this book was edited and published by a leading publishing house.Confessions of a Teen Nanny is really easy to sum up: shallow girls, party, make-up, party, hair, party, kissing, party, clothes shopping, party, makeover, party, hormonal boys, party, underage drinking, party, more underage drinking, party, nude poolside party, drug abuse, party, boy drama, party, party, and...oh yes, party.And then there were also several inconsistencies and unlikely scenarios, plus the real biggie where an eight-year-old is soundly asleep while a whopper of a party is raging outside her bedroom door. The book should have been more accurately titled, Nannies Needing Nannies, because these atrociously forgettable characters spent an entire novel living it up and fighting about boys, and very little of what they were getting paid to do.Let me put it this way: if youre expecting another Nanny Diaries, youre going to be severely disappointed. At least it is a short and quick read, for which youll be thankful you havent wasted a lot of time on.

After much thought, I think the reason I enjoyed this book a tiny bit less than I did the previous one, is because I went into These Broken Stars with low expectations (and was pleasantly surprised), and I expected far too much from This Shattered World. Dont get me wrong. This was a really fantastic story, but it missed a lot of the wow that blew me away with These Broken Stars.Jubilee and Flynn are two magnificent characters, yet there interactions and eventual romance didnt interest me as much as Lilac and Tarvers did. The story only hooked in the last sixty or so pages. The world building, though, is what got me through to the end. It wasnt as intriguing or mysterious as the planet Lilac and Tarver got stuck on, but Avon is a dark, dreary and swampy place  the perfect setting for madness and the whispers to flourish.The ending was heartwarming and the perfect conclusion to a story that couldve gone the other way. Overall, a wonderful read.

Thrilling and often frightening, Through A Mirror Darkly is one of the  most memorable books I've read so far this year.  Although the four  novellas that make up this book, can be read as stand alone stories, the  combination of all four tell of a town, Clifton Heights, the strange  things that happen there and its supernatural connection to a legendary  world; the world of Carcosa.While the first three stories are definitely written in the supernatural thriller genre, the last story falls solidly inside the horror genre. The incorporation of the King in Yellow, Carcosa and Lake Hyades brings a hint of legend and mythology into the book.The characters, some of whom are mentioned in more than one of the  stories, are fleshed out and highly realistic. In every story the main  character has to face a trial, real or psychological. Where the MC in the  first story has to confront real demons, the MC in the final deals with  demons of the psyche and imagination.Through A Mirror Darkly presents the reader with hours of  never-a-dull-moment reading, some depth and enough horror to cause a few  nightmares. (Ellen Fritz)

The first thought that came to my mind the minute I finished this book was that the book summary sounds much more intriguing than the book really is. As you continue through the chapters, layers and layers of secrets and deceit are uncovered. It all seems like an elaborate set-up for a good mystery, and at the speed the suspense keeps building, one would naturally expect a big twist with a couple of surprise reveals. But no, what you see is what you get and the conclusion doesnt offer anything you havent suspected along the way.Also, Tom is the sort of character reminiscent of the leading investigator in a Michael Robotham novel. The only difference is that Robothams main characters are so much better and more believable. I also didnt think much of Olivia towards the end, but she really proved how infuriatingly dumb she is in the last few chapters. She had an opportunity to get away from Robert and run for help, but instead she stands there waiting for him to complete his search of the house for their children. She turns out to be THAT character in movies where the woman tries to be the hero and does the opposite of what the authorities, who are trying to help her, tells her to do.Robert isnt much better and doesnt stand out in any way besides being an underdeveloped antagonist who apparently doesnt have one shred of humanity. Even the worst obsessed psychopath or serial killer can at least be charming, or friendly, or loves puppies  but not Robert. Hes just all teeth and claws and angry revenge and blah blah blah. Im sorry to say, but he was a really boooooring character to read.This is the first book of Abbotts Ive read, and as its not the first in this series, I didnt feel Ive missed out on not reading the previous books. Sleep Tight does well as a stand-alone. Though I wasnt particularly impressed with this book, I will someday give one of her other novels a last try.

Ive promised myself I will never start a review with Oh my gosh!. Im totally breaking that promise. OH MY GOSH!!! This book changed my life! No wait, dont look away, let me explain! It seriously did. It made me realize that there are others in the world, who are JUST. LIKE. ME! That might not seem like much of a revelation to you, but if you could understand how hard Ive been trying all my life to be normal and just fit the hell in, youd understand what an incredibly amazing eye-opener this has been for me. This is so my kind of humor and it makes complete sense to me because, in reality (okay, more in my head than in reality), Im just as kickass crazy, socially awkward, and not accepted universally by those who consider themselves sane.I mean this in a good way.No, seriously, dont call the cops.I can basically describe this memoir as one long running thought process with no end in sight, except when you get to the end of the book and you grudgingly realize it had to end sometime. At least theres another book coming out soon and I cant wait to get my grubby little paws on it!

Despite its daunting length, The Name of the Wind is a gripping novel that absolutely held my full attention right up to the last word. Kvothe, a legendary wizard who poses as an inn keeper, tells his tale to a professional story writer, Chronicler. This tale takes the reader on the road with a performing troupe, into the dangerous back streets of a more or less medieval city, and on to a university for wizards.Although this book is comfortably paced and written in beautifully descriptive prose, it is never boring. Where action, intrigue and suspense leaves off, brilliant characterization takes over.With his failures as abundant as his successes, unlike the perfect wizards - think Gandalf and Merlin - Kvothe has numerous flaws in both his character as well as his judgment. Naturally, as a young boy he makes mistakes; yet, as an older and more experienced man and wizard, he still has moments of doubt.All the other characters are fleshed out and realistic. At first Kvothe's nemesis, Ambrose, comes across as not such a bad fellow. Unfortunately, our first few encounters with said nemesis are extremely deceptive.From a dragon who is addicted to a drug, to creepy supernatural spiders, this book is filled with interesting and thrilling paranormal phenomena and lots of awe inspiring magic. The bit of romance that surfaces here and there in Kvothe's tale is rather poignant.If you're looking for a story that will completely take you out of your daily life into a world of old-fashioned living and magic, The Name of the Wind is the book I would recommend. (Ellen Fritz)

Five years after facing off against the dark sorcerer Arcannen, Paxon Leah, sworn protector of the druids and now known as the High Druid's Blade, faces his greatest challenge.Aphenglow Elessedil, Ard Rhys of the druid order, has passed away.  But Paxon has no time to mourn, for in a distant corner of the Four Lands, the magic of the wishsong has been detected.  Now, Paxon and his druid companion Avelene have set off to find the source of the magic.The source turns out to be Reyn Frosch, a young traveling minstrel who plays music in taverns and inns.  One evening, a stranger happens to hear Reyn's music.  The stranger is none other but Arcannen.  He promises Reyn that he will help him control the wishsong.  Enlisting the help of Lariana, a young, attractive and persuasive girl, they set to the task of training Reyn.But the training is just a cover for a much larger scheme that will involve many others.  And by now, Paxon and Avelene have discovered that Reyn is the source of the magic and are coming for him as well.  What is about to ensue is a dramatic showdown where many will fight and die.I'm a big fan of Terry Brooks, and I've read all of his books.  I especially liked this one.  The story of the wishsong has appeared in many of his other books, and it serves as a good backdrop for this story.  The character development is very good and the story slowly builds throughout until the final battle at the end.  If you enjoy epic fantasy, then make sure to read this newest installment from the master of the genre.  Highly recommended.

On December 21, 1943, Leon Crane and the rest of the crew of his B-24 bomber took off from Ladd field in Alaska.  The purpose of their mission was to run tests on the propellers of the plane.  The mission ended in disaster; the plane crashed and Crane was the only survivor.  In this book, author Brian Murphy describes the flight, crash, and Crane's struggle to survive.Crane managed to bail out of the stricken bomber, but he was not nearly prepared for what he was about to endure.  He had forgotten his cold-weather mittens, and all he had of consequence with him were 40 matches and a boy scout pocket knife.  For the next 81 days, Crane somehow managed to survive in Alaska's harsh wilderness.  He used his parachute to sleep in and carefully rationed his matches for making fires.  Fortunately, he stumbled upon an abandoned cabin which contained food and other useful items.  It wasn't until much later that he came upon a person living in the wilderness who was able to help him get back to his base."81 Days Below Zero" is a harrowing tale of endurance and survival.  The book not only tells Crane's story, but also that of crash investigators that searched over the plane years later.  These investigators were also able to discover other human remains within the wreckage and have them positively identified.  This book serves as a testament to Crane's struggle to survive, endure the unendurable, and emerge healthy and strong.  Highly recommended.

Peter Orullian has written a masterful sequel to his first novel, "The Unremembered".  In "Trial of Intentions", the story continues at a rapid pace, and the characters are facing new challenges.  Convocation has been called in Recityv, but instead, civil war breaks out among factions loyal to Helaina, Regent of Recityv, and Roth Staned, leader and Ascendant of the League of Civility.Tahn has been sent to Aubade Grove to find a way of strengthening the Veil.  He believes that Resonance will work, but he must convince the colleges in the Grove that he is right.Wendra has continued her studies in learning to sing Suffering, but her talents are needed elsewhere, and Sutter and Mira have found themselves in the midst of a conflict in a far away kingdom.The Vault of Heaven series has quickly become one of my favorites.  The story keeps getting better, and the reader can truly relate with the many well-developed characters.  "Trial of Intentions" starts off quick, and the action never lets up.  Each of the characters has their own set of tasks, and the story builds throughout.  I can't wait for the next entry in this fine series.  Highly, highly recommended.

In early May, 1942, the American and Japanese fleets met in the first carrier battle of the Pacific war in the Coral Sea.  The oiler USS Neosho was part of the American task force.  It was her job to provide oil for the ships as well as aviation gas for the carrier planes.  After topping off the American ships, Admiral Frank Jack Fletcher ordered the Neosho and escort destroyer USS Sims to sail out of harm's way away from the coming battle.  What happened next can only be considered pure bad luck, for the Japanese planes, in their search for the American carriers, stumbled upon the two American ships.For most of the day, the Neosho and Sims were attacked by scores of Japanese planes; the pilots who mistook the Neosho and Sims to be an aircraft carrier and cruiser.  The Sims sank shortly after being attacked, while the Neosho remained on the surface for four more days.  Many men jumped overboard after claiming to have heard the order to abandon ship.  This order was never given.  The actual order was to prepare to abandon ship.  Nevertheless, scores of men jumped overboard into the oily, flaming sea.  After four days, rescue finally arrived, but not before many men perished in the sea.Author Don Keith has done a very good job of telling the story of the Neosho and Sims.  The Neosho, survivor of the attack on Pearl Harbor, was truly a ship that wouldn't die, as evidenced by her remaining afloat for four days.  She finally succumbed to shell fire from a rescuing destroyer.  This book tells a harrowing tale of survival on the high seas and the heroic efforts of the U.S. Navy to locate the survivors.  Highly recommended.

Juan Cabrillo and the crew of the Oregon return in another fast-paced adventure.In 1902, a German scientist is killed when the ship he is on is destroyed in the eruption of Mt. Pelee.  Claiming to have found Oz, the scientist was on the verge of a dramatic breakthrough.Fast-forward to over a century later.  Cabrillo and his crew become entangled with a Venezuelan admiral intent on sinking their ship.  The female  admiral is in possession of stolen American technology known as Piranha; a small undersea craft which can drill perfect holes in the hull of a ship.  The admiral received her technology from a traitorous American weapons designer.  To make matters even worse, this same person seems to have also completed the work started over a century earlier by the German scientist killed in the volcanic eruption.  Now, this person has the ability to see practically anywhere at any time.Intent on taking control of the U.S. government, the designer's next target has become Air Force 2; the private plane of the vice-president of the United States.Meanwhile, Cabrillo has faked the sinking of the Oregon to throw the weapons designer and his accomplices off their trail, but will Juan and his team be able to stop this madman before it's too late?I found "Piranha" to be a great read.  I miss Jack Du Brul's writing style, but I feel that Boyd Morrison did an excellent job telling this story.  The characters are as lively as ever, and the story is well-conceived and full of action, adventure, and surprises.  Highly recommended.

Author Taylor Anderson has written another fine story in the "Destroyermen" series.In the West, Captain Matthew Reddy and the crew of the USS Walker have defeated the Grik and their Celestial Mother.  But the Grik are far from finished, for a force larger than any other is prepared to strike back against Reddy and the others at Grik City.In the East, General Tomatsu Shinya and his Allied Expeditionary Force has constructed Fort Defiance; an immense, pentagon-shaped stronghold.  But Don Hernan, commander of the "Army of God" of the Holy Dominion has massed to attack the fort and drive Shinya and his forces away.To make matters worse, a new threat, known as the League of Tripoli, has joined in the fight against the Allies.  Will Reddy and his forces be able to fight on such a large front, or will the Grik, Doms, and the remaining Japanese under the command of General of the Sea Kurokawa finally be able to defeat the Allies?I've read each of the books in this series, and I have enjoyed each one.  The story is full of action, and the characters are well-developed.  Highly recommended.

Several years after the events of "Revenge of the Sith" Darth Vader and Emperor Palpatine find themselves in the middle of an uprising led by Twi'lek freedom fighters.  On the planet Ryloth, valuable to the Empire as a source of slave labor and a drug known as "spice", a rebellion, led by Cham Syndulla has been born.  Determined to see both Vader and the Emperor dead, Cham and his female Twi'lek fighter Isval, have set a trap.Vader and Palpatine's Star Destroyer is ambushed by the freedom fighters.  Soon, the Star Destroyer is nothing but a smoking wreck, and Vader and Palpatine barely escape.  Their only chance is to head for Ryloth.  Once there, the duo is determined to wipe out the uprising once and for all.  But there are other forces at work.  The terrain is inhospitable and the freedom fighters are stronger than first thought.  Plus, the relationship between Vader and Palpatine is in question.  Traditionally, a Sith apprentice has killed his master in a bid for power.  Vader is still having remembrances of his earlier life as Anakin Skywalker.  Will he strike out against Palpatine?  What will happen to them on Ryloth?I'm a big fan of the Star Wars novels, and "Lords of the Sith" is very good.  Author Paul S. Kemp has written an interesting story that is loaded with action and adventure.  He has done a good job of developing the relationship between Vader and Palpatine, while at the same time planting a seed of doubt about how things will eventually turn out between them.  The development of the other characters, especially Cham and Isval, is very good, too.  Don't miss this very good addition to the Star Wars series.

On April 16th, 1945, the crew of the destroyer USS Laffey were informed that their ship was being moved to radar picket station #1, north of Okinawa.  This station was the closest picket station to Japan and, therefore, the first station that Japanese kamikazes would see on their flight to Okinawa.  Over the preceding days, several American ships had been sunk or severely damaged while serving at station #1.  The men of the Laffey knew what they were sailing into; an inferno of steel and pilots willing to dive their planes into American ships.  For eighty minutes on that fateful April morning, the crew of the USS Laffey faced over twenty individual kamikaze attacks.  "Hell From The Heavens" is their testimony.Before that April morning, the USS Laffey had served with distinction in the U.S Navy.  Commissioned in February, 1944, the Laffey fought in her initial battle off of Normandy during the D-Day landings.  She provided fire support and anti-submarine protection.  Next, the Laffey moved through the Panama Canal to the Pacific, where she served in the Philippine campaign and as a carrier escort for raids on the Japanese homeland.  Led by Commander F. Julian Becton, the Laffey had become a well-seasoned veteran.Becton and the crew took their assignment to radar picket station #1 as they had in the past; they were prepared to do their best in the task assigned to them.  But nothing could have prepared them for the onslaught they were about to face.  Over the course of eighty minutes, the crew shot down several attacking Japanese planes, but several got through to crash into the ship.  Aside from the kamikaze attacks, the Laffey also sustained bomb hits as well.  Over thirty sailors were killed and many others were injured, but the ship would not sink.  Despite being hit by no fewer than six of the attackers, Becton and his heroic crew would save their ship and ultimately return to the United States as heroes.Author John Wukovits has written a wonderful book about one of the most famous ships in the U.S. Navy.  He starts with the commissioning of the Laffey and continues describing the other campaigns she fought in.  The sections devoted to the kamikaze attacks are loaded with stories of individual heroism as the men struggled to save their ship.  Included throughout Wukovits' narrative are numerous quotes and remembrances from the Laffey's crew members.I give this book my highest recommendation.  John Wukovits has written a fine tribute to one of the U.S. Navy's most memorable ships and her fine crew.

On December 7th, 1941, the Japanese attacked the American Pacific fleet at Pearl Harbor.  In the aftermath of this attack, President Roosevelt wanted to strike back at the Japanese.  Nuisance raids were being carried out by American forces in the central Pacific, but Roosevelt wanted more; namely, a strike against Japan itself.  In "Target Tokyo", author James M. Scott takes the reader on that fateful and historic mission.In the early months of 1942, eighty American volunteers, led by Col. Jimmy Doolittle, began training for a spectacular raid; they were going to fly B-25 medium bombers off the deck of an aircraft carrier that had steamed to within 300-400 miles of Japan.  After the attack, the planes were to fly to China and land on Chinese airfields.  As history has shown, it didn't work that way.The task force was discovered by Japanese picket boats while still some 700 miles from Japan.  Doolittle wasted no time and launched immediately.  The bombers arrived over Japan and bombed targets in Tokyo and surrounding cities.  Actual physical damage was slight, but the psychological impact on the Japanese was tremendous.  Now the pilots and crew faced the dangerous task of flying to China with little fuel.  But thanks to a 25 mph tailwind, the planes made landfall, except one which diverted to Russia.  However, the planes were unable to land so the crews were forced to bail out.  This began an odyssey of evasion and survival for the fliers as they attempted to make their way to Chungking and freedom."Target Tokyo" is destined to become the definitive account on the Doolittle raid.  Masterfully written, this book takes the reader from the attack on Pearl Harbor through the planning and execution of the raid on Tokyo.  But the story doesn't end with the raid.  Author James M. Scott also discusses the capture of two of the B-25 crews by the Japanese along with the saga of the crew who landed in Russia.  Also, Scott  describes the terrible revenge attacks unleashed on the Chinese by the Japanese, which included the destruction of entire towns and villages along with over 250,000 civilian deaths.I give this book my highest recommendation.  "Target Tokyo" is a fine book about America's first strike against Japan

During the early days of the Pacific War, the Japanese captured many American civilian workers.  These people had been employed as nurses or with the Pan American Clipper seaplane service, among other positions.  Now, with Manila in the hands of the Japanese, these civilians were rounded up and placed in camps.  For the next 3-plus years, these civilian workers would face the wrath of the Japanese.Civilians were supposed to be protected prisoners under the international rules of war, but this meant little to the Japanese.  In places such as Cabanatuan and other camps throughout the Philippines, the Japanese began a plan of starvation and intimidation upon the prisoners.  The American civilians interred at Los Banos faced similar repercussions, not to mention that the population at Los Banos also included women and children.General Douglas MacArthur personally authorized a rescue mission to be carried out by the 11th Airborne division to free the prisoners held in Los Banos.  These men, with the aid of Filipino guerrillas, launched a three-pronged attack from air, land, and sea.  They succeeded in freeing over two thousand civilians.I found "Rescue At Los Banos" to be an informative and interesting book.  I've read books about the raid on Cabanatuan, so I was somewhat familiar with this topic before.  However, I was unaware that Los Banos contained civilian POWs.  I was shocked at the conditions these men, women, and children were forced to live under.  If not for the 11th's attack, many of these people would have starved to death or been killed outright by the Japanese.I give this book a high recommendation.  General Colin Powell has referenced the rescue at Los Banos as a perfect attack.  Author Bruce Henderson brings that attack to life.

On May 1st, 1915, the luxury liner Lusitania left New York bound for England.  On board were hundreds of passengers, including many women and children.  Despite warnings placed in the New York newspapers by the German government, the Lusitania set sail. Germany had declared the waters around Great Britain to be a war zone and promised to sink any vessel entering them.  Less than a week later, the Lusitania would be on the bottom of the ocean, and over 1000 passengers would be dead.  In "Dead Wake", author Erik Larson not only describes the terrible sinking, but also gives the reader a view of the world 100 years ago.In 1915, the United States was still neutral; unwilling to become involved in the European war.  Great Britain longed for the assistance of the Americans.  The American President, Woodrow Wilson, had just lost his first wife.  But soon thereafter, he had found companionship with Edith Galt, who would later become his 2nd wife.  In Germany, Capt. Walther Schwieger prepared to take his submarine U-20 to sea in hunt of enemy shipping.The Lusitania sailed on, oblivious to the knowledge the British in their "Room 40" had acquired about German submarine activity along their planned route.  It was a recipe for disaster, for on May 7th, 1915, the U-20 fired a single torpedo which struck the Lusitania.  In just eighteen minutes, the ship sank, taking over 1,000 passengers with her.  Many others died from exposure or injuries suffered in the attack.  U-20 made good her escape."Dead Wake" is a well-written account of one of the great maritime disasters of all-time.  Author Erik Larson does a fine job of informing the reader about the sequence of events leading up to the sinking, including the German warnings, the information gained by the British about German submarine activity that wasn't shared with the captain of the Lusitania, and the terrible aftermath of the sinking, including the infamous Zimmerman note.  Written with a style that alternates from hunter to hunted, this book does a fine job of describing the tragic loss of a great ship.  Highly recommended.

At the turn of the 20th century, oil was king.  Led by such men as John D. Rockefeller, oil became a commodity that men fought and killed over.  Rockefeller, head of the Standard Oil monopoly, is being investigated by Isaac Bell of the Van Dorn detective agency.  What begins as an investigation turns to murder when a hired assassin starts targeting opponents of Standard Oil, many of them independents hoping to break Standard's grip on the oil industry.Isaac and the others from the Van Dorn agency are soon looking for the assassin.  Their pursuit will lead them to Kansas, Texas, and across the Atlantic Ocean to Russia.  Meanwhile, the assassin is still at large.  Having had his best witness killed by the assassin, it is up to Isaac and his fellow detectives to solve the mystery before the assassin destroys Standard Oil and John D. Rockefeller himself.I'm a big fan of the Isaac Bell series by Clive Cussler, and "The Assassin" in a fine new entry to the series.  As with the earlier books in the series, Cussler concentrates his story during an actual time frame in American history.  The story is exciting, and the characters are well-developed.  There are many twists and turns along the way, and the reader must pay close attention to the story.I highly recommend this fine book.  Fans of Isaac Bell will surely enjoy "The Assassin".

Luke Skywalker has destroyed the Death Star.  Now, the fledgling rebel alliance must find a new base of operations.  But first, young Skywalker is given a mission of vital importance to the rebellion.  A brilliant alien cryptographer renowned for her ability to tap into Imperial codes is being detained by Imperial agents.  In exchange for being reunited with her family, she will share her secrets with the rebellion.  Luke, along with his faithful companion R2-D2 are soon dispatched.Before setting off, Luke acquires a cool ship called the Desert Jewel.  Owned by Fayet Kelen of Kelen Biolabs, the Desert Jewel is one of the fastest ships around.  Piloted by Fayet's beautiful daughter Nakari, Luke sets off to free the cryptographer.Along the way, Luke and Nakari run into several skirmishes, including Imperial star destroyers, bounty hunters, and mysterious alien parasites. Also, he discovers that he has feelings for Nakari.  Will they succeed in finding the cryptographer, or will the Imperials discover their intentions first?I'm a big fan of the Star Wars novels, and "Heir to the Jedi" adds an interesting twist to the series.  Told in Luke's voice throughout, the story focuses on Luke's development as a Jedi along with his deepening feelings for Nakari.  There is a good amount of action throughout, and I felt that the character development, especially that of Nakari and Drusil, is very good.  This is a good book worthy of a place with the previous Star Wars novels.  Recommended.

Eric Albright has ventured through a door that has led to the alternate world known as Levaal.  Inhabited by war mages, dragons, and invia, Eric and his band of friends have set off to a castle to find Vous.  Lord Vous is a madman who is in the process of turning himself into a god.  Eric and his friends Siel and Loup must reach the castle before its too late.  Complicating matters further is the presence of Shadow; a mysterious being who looks remarkably like Eric but seems to have no purpose. But may have an effect on Vous.  Finally, the great wall at world's end has been brought down and the very survival of Levaal is in doubt.  Will Eric and his friends reach the castle, or will Vous finish his transformation into a god?I've found the first two books of the Pendulum Trilogy to be very good.  Following in the footsteps of such authors as Terry Brooks and Robert Jordan, Will Elliott has created an epic fantasy loaded with action, adventure, and well-developed characters.  I'm eagerly anticipating reading the final installment of this very good series.  Highly recommended.

By January, 1945, the powerful Russian army was making its way across Poland and into Germany.  During this time, the Nazi prison camps located in Poland were discovered and liberated by the advancing Russians.  The stipulations of the agreement at Yalta that was signed by the Russians and the United States stated that all liberated POWs must be treated humanely.  The Americans followed the rules while, by and large, the Russians did not.  The Russians viewed POWs as cowards, and many were left to survive on their own.  In "Beyond The Call", one American airman does what he can to help these forgotten men.Captain Robert Trimble was a pilot in the Eighth Air Force.  He had just finished his thirty-fifth and final mission when he was offered a new position.  On the surface, he was given the task of locating American aircraft forced to land in Poland, making necessary repairs, and flying them back to American lines.  But the mission turned out to be much more than that, for Captain Trimble soon found himself helping POWs find their way to freedom under the noses of the Russians.For several months, Robert worked to help as many prisoners as possible.  Ultimately, he would help hundreds of men and women, both POWs and refugees, find safety while at the same time staying one step ahead of the Russians."Beyond The Call" is a good book.  I've read many books about the air war over Europe, and the added element of espionage makes this book even more compelling.  I was unaware of the POW situation in Poland before reading this book, and I find it appalling that the Russians treated their allied POWs in such a disgraceful manner.  It took men like Captain Trimble to risk their lives to go in and free these prisoners and refugees."Beyond The Call" does a good job of describing one of the lesser-known elements of the war in Europe.  Highly recommended.

Louis Zamperini is an American icon.  From Olympic athlete to prisoner of war to born-again Christian, Louis has inspired people with his straight-forward attitude towards life and others.Louis was a self-proclaimed rebel as a child.  He would steal and otherwise cause problems wherever he went.  But thanks to the encouragement of his older brother, Louis fell in love with running and soon became a world-class athlete.  He went on to compete in the 1936 Olympics.  When World War II broke out, Louis became a crew member on a B-24 bomber in the Pacific theater.  His plane was shot down by the Japanese, and Louis survived over forty days adrift in a raft.  Picked up by the Japanese, Louis was interred for two-and-a-half years in a Japanese POW camp, enduring physical beatings from the guards.After surviving his time as a POW, Louis returned to the U.S. and got married.  Shortly thereafter, while attending a Billy Graham sermon, Louis gave his life to Jesus.  For the rest of his life, Louis lived his life for Jesus.  He also carried the Olympic torch on five separate occasions.  But perhaps the most remarkable of all: he forgave all of the guards who mistreated him."Don't Give Up, Don't Give In" is not just a biography.  Rather, it is a blueprint for living a productive, happy life.  Louis is remembered as a happy, resilient person.  Much of his successful living can be attributed to his salvation, but he also lived life with a purpose; to help others and glorify God in everything he did.  He succeeded.I highly recommend this fine book.  Louis Zamperini is a shining example of what God can do in a person's life, and Louis' love and zeal made a large impression on others, too.

In this excellent second installment of the "Red Rising" trilogy, Darrow has continued his infiltration of the Golds.  No longer content with mere infiltration, Darrow and his followers have started a civil war between the Gold houses of Augustus and Bellona.  Throughout this fast-paced story, alliances will change, friendships will be tested, and relationships will be broken.  Darrow, seeing the destructiveness of some of his decisions, must steel himself to continue his quest, even though friends will die and his search for the love of Mustang will be put in question.Quite simply, "Golden Son" is an excellent book.  Although I felt that the first quarter of the book was somewhat slow, the story definitely picks up speed.  The characters are well-developed and the plot is loaded with twists and turns, not to mention the cliffhanger ending.I give this great book my highest recommendation.  If you enjoy great science fiction, then don't miss the "Red Rising" series.  I'm eagerly anticipating book three.

In the near future, a terrifying world-wide pandemic is taking place.  Millions of people are being infected with a deadly disease called "the Gets".  It starts out slowly; people forget minor things, but as the disease progresses, the disease grips the people more tightly.  People begin to forget how to function completely.  There is no cure: or is there?Miles below the surface of the Pacific ocean, in the deepest part known as the Marianas Trench, a possible cure may have been located.  Ambrosia is the name, and a massive underwater lab has been built to harvest it.  Luke Nelson has been summoned to fly to Guam and catch a boat to aid his brother Clayton, who is already below in the lab.  Riding to the station with Lt. Alice Sykes in a sophisticated mini-sub, they hope to harvest the ambrosia and bring it to the surface.  Luke is suffering from recurring flashbacks to the abduction of his young son Zach as well as the terrible treatment he and his brother suffered at the hands of their mother.Upon reaching the station, Luke and Alice discover that things are not as they should be.  As time passes, it becomes clear that there is something else under the eight miles of ocean; a presence so evil that any living thing will be lucky to escape alive.  It's a race to see if Alice and Luke will ever make it off the ocean floor and back to the surface.I read Nick Cutter's previous book, "The Troop", and I found it to be pretty good.  "The Deep" is not on the same level.  The book is loaded with flashbacks and journal entries that take away from the flow of the story.  Plus, the character development is somewhat lacking, and the ending is predictable.  That said, there are some truly scary passages, and the reader does get a sense of what it would be like to be trapped underwater with no communication ability with the surface.  This book isn't bad, I just wish there would have been more scary parts and less flashbacks.

In 1942, the United States began preparations for the creation of the Eighth Air Force.  Over the course of the next three years, the Eighth would grow from relative obscurity into one of the largest fighting forces of the war.  Employing thousands of men and aircraft, the Eighth developed the premise of daylight precision bombing as opposed to the British doctrine of night time area bombing.  One of the groups in the Eighth was the 303rd bomb group, and "Hell's Angels"  tells the story of the group's formation until their last mission in April, 1945.The 303rd consisted of a cross-section of members from across the country.  Some were farmers, some were laborers, and many were still in their teens.  As the war progressed, these young boys honed their skills and became one of the most successful bomb groups in the Eighth.Author Jay A. Stoudt has done a masterful job in describing the 303rd bomb group.  Loaded with first-person accounts from the members themselves, the reader gets a true sense of what it was like to fly a B-17 or to fight off attacks from German fighters.  He describes what it was like to be crammed inside the ball turret and what it was like to be shot down and captured.  Not only does Stoudt discuss the actual missions flown by the 303rd, he also discusses the human element of war, such as the loss of a bomber on their 35th and last mission, or the horrific sight of two B-17s colliding in midair.I've read many books about the air war over Germany, and "Hell's Angels" is one of the best I've read.  Loaded with eyewitness accounts of the actual flights to Berlin, Cologne, and other cities, Jay Stoudt gives the reader a true look into the air war over Germany.  Highly, highly recommended.

Marine doctor Joe Rush is headed to the Arctic.  The high-powered nuclear submarine USS Montana is afire and adrift.  Many of the crew have already died, and the survivors are encamped on the ice near the submarine.  Now, Joe and  2 squads of Marines are headed to board the only American ice breaker in the Arctic in hopes of reaching the stricken submarine.Upon arriving, Joe learns that there's much more to the Montana; not just the fire, but something else.  Something has caused the surviving crew members to become violently ill, and the source is on the submarine.  Joe not only has to deal with a stricken submarine, but a potential lethal medical outbreak.  And, to make matters even worse, a Chinese submarine has surfaced and is poised to blow the Montana out of the water.  Joe and his crew must find a way to not only save the Montana, but to prevent a possible pandemic of global proportions.I'm a fan of Tom Clancy and Clive Cussler, so I was interested in reading "White Plague".  Overall, I thought the story and character development was good.  Joe Rush is a Marine who has his own demons to fight while at the same time maintaining control in order to save the crew of the Montana.  Other characters, such as Joe's sidekick Eddie and assistant deputy secretary Andrew Sachs play important roles throughout the book.  The action starts immediately and doesn't stop until the end of the book.  I'm looking forward to more books in the Joe Rush series.

Most people who were alive in November, 1963 can remember where they were and what they were doing when it was announced that President Kennedy had been shot.  For those of us like myself who were not alive in 1963, Bill O'Reilly's book "Killing Kennedy" does a good job of describing the events of that tragic day.Not limiting themselves to Kennedy's assassination, O'Reilly and co-author Martin Dugard describe Kennedy's time aboard PT-109 during World War II and how he managed to save his crew members after the boat was sunk by a Japanese destroyer.While serving as President, Kennedy faced many challenges, including the Bay of Pigs disaster, the Cuban Missile Crisis, the escalation of the Vietnam War, and the birth of the Civil Rights movement.  These events are detailed throughout the course of the book.Paralleling Kennedy's time as President is the story of Lee Harvey Oswald, an American citizen who has immigrated to the Soviet Union.  Throughout the course of the book, O'Reilly paints a collision course between Kennedy and Oswald that will reach its tragic conclusion in Dallas on November 22nd, 1963.I found "Killing Kennedy" to be an informative and interesting read.  I was not alive in 1963, so I've had to rely on books for information about the Kennedy assassination, and this book does a good job of providing information about the events leading up to and the assassination itself.  Highly recommended

The story of the Chaos Born continues in this exciting second book.The Danaan have left their ruined city in pursuit of Jerrod, Keenan, Norr, Scythe, and Vaaler. Led by Valeer's mother, the queen, the Danaan are determined to regain possession of the Ring.  Plus, one of Daemron's minions has joined with the Danaan.  Corrupting the mind of the queen, the minion hopes to retrieve the Ring for himself.  Pursued across the frozen grounds of the east, the Chaos Born link up with members of the Clans, one of whom happens to be Norr's wife.  But their badly outnumbered members must face the Danaan in battle.  To make matters even worse, the Danaan have a giant ogre on their side.Cassandra has found her way to the cave of the Guardian.  Cassandra, in possession of the Crown, has come looking for protection from the Guardian, who is in possession of the Sword.  But Cassandra is tracked by another of Daemron's minions, and now both Cassandra and the Guardian must flee.Death and destruction reign as the story goes on and many will die.  Will the Children of Fire succeed in their quest to acquire all three talismans to contain Daemron behind the legacy, or is it too late?"The Children of Fire" series has quickly become one of my favorites.  Author Drew Karpyshyn has written a masterful epic fantasy that keeps the reader hooked throughout.  The characters are well-developed, and the story is loaded with action and adventure. New characters are introduced that blend in nicely with the story.  I've read many other fantasy authors, including Terry Brooks and Robert Jordan, and the Children of Fire series ranks right up with Shannara and The Wheel of Time.  I'm eagerly anticipating book 3 in this fine series.  Highly recommended

On December 9, 1945, the car that U.S. General George Patton was riding in collided with an American truck.  Patton was left paralyzed.  Twelve days later, Patton died.  Over the years, theories have emerged as to what really happened to Patton.  In "Killing Patton", authors Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard attempt to explain the truth behind Patton's death.Not limiting themselves to the circumstances behind Patton's death, O'Reilly and Dugard explain the war in Eurpoe from the autumn of 1944 to the German surrender, focusing on Patton's famed Third Army.  From the rescue of the 101st Airborne at Bastogne to the crossing of the Rhine, the Third Army established themselves as the tip of the American spear.  It is believed that the Third Army could have raced straight into Berlin, but Eisenhower put Patton on the defensive.  Still, Patton and his men distinguished themselves over and over again.The authors point out that there were strange instances leading up to Patton's death.  For example, a Spitfire tried to shoot down a plane Patton was flying in.  Then, there are reports out that the Russians wanted Patton killed.  Finally, the tragic car accident ended up taking Patton's life, but was it really an accident?I found "Killing Patton" to be an informative and interesting book.  I enjoyed reading about Patton's heroics on the battlefield, and it was sobering reading about the General's untimely death.  Was Patton killed or was he simply involved in a tragic accident?I highly recommend this fine book.  Patton was one of America's finest fighting Generals, and "Killing Patton" describes his heroic actions on the battlefield as well as his tragic death.

"A New Dawn" takes place between the events of Episode III and A New Hope.  Order 66 has been executed, and most of the remaining Jedi knights have been killed.  Kanan Jarrus has managed to survive; not by using the Force, but by staying one step ahead of everyone else.The planet Gorse and its companion moon Cynda contain large quantities of an element needed by the Empire to run its star fleet.  Enter Count Vidian, an Imperial supposedly acting on orders from the Emperor.  Vidian believes that the best way to secure the needed resources from Cynda is to destroy the moon and harvest the remnants from space.  But is this true?  Others, including Captain Sloane of the star destroyer Ultimatum, believe that Vidian might be wrong in his assessment.  Throw in a beautiful female Twi'lek, an unscrupulous mineral miner, and a tech-savvy Sullustan and Vidian will soon have all the problems he can handle.  Will Vidian succeed in destroying Cynda, or will the small band of misfits stop him before it's too late?I'm a big fan of the Star Wars novels, and "A New Dawn" is a good addition to the series.  The characters are well-developed, and the story keeps the reader interested.  It will be fun to see where this new series goes.

Sam and Remi Fargo return in this newest installment of the Fargo series.In 1085, a Viking ship runs aground in a fjord in Canada.  Fast forward to the present day.  Sam and Remi are off the coast of Spain working on a sunken ship treasure when British archeologist Janus Benedict comes upon the same wreck.  Janus tries making off with the treasure , but the Fargos foil the plot.  This is just the beginning of an ongoing confrontation between Sam, Remi, and Janus that will traverse the globe from Spain to Canada to Laos and Mexico.Upon discovering the perfectly preserved Viking ship sitting in ice in Canada, Sam and Remi discover that some of the treasures on board contain inscriptions suggesting they came from the pre-Columbian period.  Learning that these treasures could have been from the Toltecs, Sam and Remi deduce that the Vikings were trading with the Toltecs.  This discovery leads the Fargos on a quest to find the "Eye of Heaven"; a large emerald crafted in honor of the Toltec leader.  But the Fargos aren't the only ones on the trail; Janus and his scheming brother Reginald are hot on their tail.  Will the Fargos succeed, or will Janus and Reginald foil their efforts?I'm a big fan of Cussler's Fargo series, and "The Eye of Heaven" is a thrilling addition.  The story is fast-paced and packed full of interesting history.  The characters are well-developed, especially Sam's former professor Lazlo and the Benedicts.  I'm sure we'll see more of Janus Benedict in a future Fargo adventure.If you're a fan of good action/adventure stories, make sure to read "The Eye of Heaven".  Highly recommended.

Well-known sci-fi/fantasy author Drew Karpyshyn has written a very good epic fantasy loaded with interesting characters and a thrilling plot line.Daemron, chosen by the gods to stand against the demonic spawn of Chaos, has been corrupted by the power of the magical talismans given to him by the gods.  As a result of this corruption, Daemron challenged the gods themselves.  But in the end, Daemron was defeated and secured behind the Legacy, a magical barrier designed to keep him hidden away from the mortal world.Now, the Legacy grows weak.  At the same time, four children are born under a burning moon.  These children are destined to become a wizard, a warrior, a prophet, and a king; the children of Chaos. Sharing a connection stronger than blood, it will become their mission to keep Daemron locked safely behind the Legacy.  Will their quest succeed, or will Daemron unleash his wrath on the mortal world?I found "Children of Fire" to be a very good read.  I've been a fan of fantasy fiction for years, and I really enjoyed this story.  The characters are well-developed, and the story, although somewhat slow in the beginning, really picks up its pace.  I'm eagerly awaiting reading the next book after this one.  Highly recommended.

By July, 1945, Japan was on the brink of collapse.  Her navy was at the bottom of the Pacific, her air force was nowhere to be found, and an American blockade stopped virtually all shipments of goods.  However, Japan refused to surrender. In this book, author Paul Ham contends that the Japanese would have eventually surrendered without the use of the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.This question is open to debate.  It is true that Japan was on life support by the summer of 1945.  However, The Japanese vowed to fight on.  Any talk of surrender by the Japanese had conditions attached (no occupation, Japan would try her own war criminals, retention of Emperor).  The Allies at Potsdam insisted upon unconditional surrender.  It is true, as the situation worsened, that Japan sent out peace feelers to the Russians, hoping they would mediate a negotiated surrender with the Americans.  Hopes of this were dashed when Russia declared war on Japan on August 8, 1945; two days after the Hiroshima bombing.This book does a good job of describing the use of the atomic bombs vs surrender by blockade and conventional air strikes.  Ham believes that Japan would have surrendered by December 1945 due to the acute lack of food.  It is difficult to say.  Granted, the atomic bombs killed thousands of civilians, but they gave the Japanese a way to surrender while "saving face".Ham's book definitely will stir up debate as to whether the bombs were necessary to end the war.

During the American bombing campaign against Germany in World War II, the Eighth Air Force, or the "Mighty Eighth" was the glamor outfit that garnered much of the attention.  However, there was another American bomb group stationed in Italy as well.  This group was the Fifteenth Air Force.  It didn't grab headlines like the larger 8th did, but this group made an important contribution to the defeat of Germany.Stationed in Foggia, Italy, the Fifteenth flew missions against Europe's "soft underbelly".  Oil refineries were the primary target of the Fifteenth, and these airmen made several trips to such flak-infested areas as Ploesti with the goal of knocking out Germany's synthetic oil production capabilities.It fell upon the Fifteenth to carry out these missions, for the Eighth aircraft could not reach them from their bases in England.Besides hitting oil targets, the Fifteenth also participated in raids on Germany as well as targets in the Balkans.  Often living in the shadows of the larger Eighth, the men of the Fifteenth nonetheless proved to be a vital element in the defeat of Germany."Forgotten Fifteenth" is a fine book about one of America's lesser-known bomber groups.  These brave men distinguished themselves time and again, flying dangerous missions over flak and fighter infested targets.  This group produced many fighter aces as well as famous bomber pilots such as George McGovern and Lloyd Bentsen.  The men of the Fifteenth never received the recognition like their brothers in the Eighth did, but their efforts proved monumental in the defeat of Germany.Author Barrett Tillman has done a fine job of describing the formation of the Fifteenth, along with the missions flown.  He describes in vivid detail how these brave flyers struck at the heart of such targets as Ploesti and Vienna.  He also describes some of the more obscure aspects of the Fifteenth, from weather recon flights to efforts to bring Allied POWs safely home.  I've read other books by Tillman, and "Forgotten Fifteenth" is just as good as his earlier works.  Readers of the air war in Europe will definitely want to read this book.  Highly Recommended.

On an autumn weekend, five boys and their scoutmaster head to Falstaff island for a camping trip.  Leading the group is scoutmaster Tim Riggs, who works as a general practitioner doctor.  The boys are friends from school; Ephriham, Max, Kent, Newt, and Shelley.  The agenda includes camping out in a cabin and going on long hikes, but unfortunately for the group, that's all about to change.On the first night, an unexpected visitor arrives at camp.  Wild-eyed and voraciously hungry, this man is about to unleash a horror so terrifying that it will render the group spellbound and fighting for survival; for inside this man is a bioengineered nightmare that will spread fear and terror throughout the camp.  Plus, there is other involvement as well from other sources, including the military, who has gotten word of the goings-on on Falstaff island.  Now, the boys must fight for survival against an unseen enemy that its threatening to take over their bodies and minds.  Will any survive?It took me a while to really get into this book, but the story does pick up eventually.  I thought the premise and background for the story was well-conceived, but the character development is somewhat lacking.  The five boys are stereotypical teenagers: the jock, the nerd, the outcast, and the "best friends forever".  Even scoutmaster Tim's character is pretty predictable in his actions.  This being said, I did like the bioengineering aspect to the story, as well as the involvement of the military in isolating the island.This book has some definite scary parts, but there are lulls, too.  I do think fans of horror fiction would enjoy this book, though.

Ben Bova has written an excellent collection of short stories in "New Frontiers".  From a golf course on the moon to a rescue mission to save the sun from exploding, Bova covers a wide range of topics.  Sticking with his usual knack for developing interesting stories and characters, these tales provide action and intrigue throughout.I've been a fan of Ben Bova's works for many years, and I thoroughly enjoyed reading these stories.  Rather than having to follow characters throughout an entire novel, the reader is introduced to new characters and situations in each story.I highly recommend this fine collection of short stories.  Each one deals with a new adventure, and they are all loaded with Bova's typical blend of science fact and fiction.  Bova readers will definitely enjoy this fine collection.

Om May 16, 1943, a force of 19 specially-modified Lancaster bombers took off from their base in England.  The target was the German dams located in the industrial Ruhr valley.  Carrying specially-designed 4-ton bombs that were designed to skip across the water, the goal of the mission was to destroy the Mohne, Eder, and Sorpe dams.Conceived by Barnes Wallis, the idea was to destroy the dams.  The resultant flooding would overwhelm the surrounding countryside, which included power plants, industries, and homes.  Originally shot down by the higher-ups, Wallis persisted in his arguments.  Eventually, his plan was approved and work started on the special bombs, which were code-named Upkeep.Guy Gibson was selected to form the special squadron which would carry out the raid.  A veteran of many missions over Germany, Gibson was the perfect selection to head up the attack.  Soon, the squadron was selected and training begun.Over the course of several weeks, the squadron grew together into a well-formed fighting unit.I found "Dam Busters" to be an interesting and informative read.  Having read little on this particular raid, I was impressed by author James Holland's thoroughness in covering every aspect of the attack.  Included in Holland's work is the early discussions about the feasibility of such an attack, Wallis' belief in the bouncing bomb, the construction and testing of the bomb itself, and finally, the discussion of the raid.  Each area is fully explored, and the reader gets a true feel of not only the raid itself, but everything that led up to it.I give "Dam Busters" a very high recommendation.  James Holland has taken one of the great surprise raids in the war and brought it to life.

On September 1, 1944, an American B-24 bomber was shot down over the Palau islands in the Pacific.  Three men managed to bail out before the plane crashed.  The others perished in the crash.  In "Vanished", author Wil S. Hylton tells a remarkable tale of one man's journey to discover the remains of the plane and the men entombed within.Pat Scannon is the name of the man responsible for the search.  Over a period of many years, Scannon and his crew of scuba divers, sonar experts, and scientists made several visits to the Palau islands in search of the missing B-24.  Each time Scannon and his crew went to search for the plane, obstacles kept appearing.  But Scannon didn't let these obstacles deter him from his ultimate goal of providing closure for the families of the crew members.  In a story that reads like a novel, Hylton describes each of Scannon's visits and the results obtained.Not just focusing on the search for the missing plane, Hylton also vividly describes the brutal action that took place during the time of the B-24's disappearance.  The Palau islands were viewed as a potential staging area for attacks by the Japanese against MacArthur's drive to retake the Philippines.  This point is hotly debated, as many saw the Palaus as an unnecessary operation.  The battles fought here, especially on Peleliu, were some of the bloodiest of the war.  Bombing missions were ordered to neutralize the islands.  The missing B-24 was shot down on a mission over these islands.I found "Vanished" to be an excellent read.  The story of Scannon's search for the missing bomber is riveting, and each trip Scannon made is described in great detail.  The discussion about the Palaus campaign is told in frightening terms relating to tremendous casualties suffered on both sides.I recommend this book to readers of World War II history and to those who enjoy books about searching for missing relics.  The story is gripping and the end result is uplifting.

Everyone knows that, on December 7th, 1941, the Japanese Navy attacked the American base at Pearl Harbor.  Numerous ships were sunk or damaged, scores of planes destroyed, and over 2,000 people were killed.  But what led Japan to take such a drastic step to start a war that they had no hope of winning?  Eri Hotta attempts to answer this question in "Japan 1941".One could argue that World War II began when Japan invaded China in 1931.  From that point forward, Japan was under scrutiny from the rest of the world, including the United States.  By 1941, Japan was suffering from sanctions, including an embargo on oil and scrap metal from the United States.  War with the United States was a distinct possibility.But what of the preparations for this war?  Hotta argues, rightly so, that the Japanese were unprepared to fight a successful war against the United States.  The industrial might of the United States would overwhelm Japan.  Japan, in the words of Winston Churchill, would be ground into dust.Despite the vast difference in industrial might, many Japanese felt that war was the only answer.  Others believed that success could be achieved through negotiation.  It was this constant bickering and interservice rivalry that ultimately doomed Japan.  Hotta states that none of Japan's top leaders had sufficient will, desire, or courage to stop the momentum for war.  The attack on Pearl Harbor can be viewed loosely as a tactical success for the Japanese.  But the result was a strategic nightmare, for only 6 months later, the Japanese advance was stopped at Midway.I found this book to be an informative narrative about Japan's preparations for war in 1941.  The narrative encompasses all major aspects of what the diplomatic and military situation was like for Japan from the time of the invasion of China up to the attack on Pearl Harbor.  Although somewhat difficult to read due to all of the names, the book nonetheless contains a wealth of information about Japan's preparations for war.

2013 marks the 50th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy.  "Parkland" explores the chaotic four days in Dallas through the eyes of the hospital workers who worked to revive JFK and later Lee Harvey Oswald, the Secret Service workers who were charged with protecting the President, and family members, including Oswald's brother Robert and his mother, who were forced to live with the repercussions of the actions of others.The film begins with Kennedy's motorcade proceeding through the streets of Dallas.  Kennedy is shot, and the Presidential limo speeds toward Parkland, where the only doctor initially on duty is a resident (Zac Efron).  The staff members of parkland fight heroically to save Kennedy, but to no avail.  Next, the movie proceeds to the events concerning the Secret Service, including the seizure of the Zapruder film and the struggle to have Kennedy's body released for the flight back to Washington, D.C.  The viewer also gets a look at the brother and mother of Lee Harvey Oswald."Parkland" is one of the best movies I've seen.  The historical timeline is accurate, and the scenes in the Parkland operating room, while most definitely graphic, are historically correct.  The acting is top-notch, and Billy Bob Thornton, James Badge Dale, and Zac Efron all give first-rate performances.  "Parkland" is destined to become one of the definitive movies about the Kennedy assassination.  Highly, highly recommended.

One morning, Ingatius (Ig) Perrish wakes up from a night of drinking and "doing terrible things".  But waking up with a hangover is only the beginning, for Ig soon discovers that he has grown, of all things, horns!  At first, Ig believes he is imagining the horns.  But he soon realizes they are real.Ig has been wallowing in grief since the death of Merrin Williams, his girlfriend.  Merrin was beaten, raped, and left for dead.  Everyone in town believes that Ig is responsible and the only reason he's not in jail is his family's wealth and influence.But the horns have powers far beyond anything Ig could have imagined.  Just by touching someone, he can learn their innermost secrets, fantasies, desires, and wrongdoings.  Ig hopes to use this power to find out who really killed his beloved Merrin.This is a wonderfully developed story that is packed with terror, humor, and a true, down-to-earth love story.  The reader will truly experience all of these emotions during the course of the book.  It's easy to sympathize with Ig; the grieving soul left behind after the unsolved death of his girlfriend.  On the other hand, as the story progresses, Ig transforms into something truly scary.  But, even during his transformation, his goal remains to find who killed Merrin.I've become a fan of Joe Hill's work, and "Horns" is a cleverly-developed story that is exciting throughout.  The character development is good, and the story definitely keeps the reader's interest.  Highly recommended.

Joe Hill has written a scary and terrifying book about vivid imaginations and pure evil."NOS4A2" is the story of Victoria McQueen.  During the course of the story, Vic goes from a young eight-year-old to a grown-up woman.  But one thing remains constant throughout: her connection with Charles Talent Manx.  Charles rides around in a 1938 Rolls Royce Wraith.  Through his imaginations, he transports children who are unhappy or hurt to a magical place called Christmasland, where it's always Christmas.  But Manx is not the nice person he seems to be.  In reality he is a cold-blooded killer and kidnapper.Vic herself is kidnapped by Manx, but she managed to escape.  Now it's her twelve-year-old son Wayne who has fallen into Manx's clutches.  The only way Vic can save Wayne is to use her own imagination and retrieve Wayne from Christmasland before it's too late.This is the first book I've read from Joe Hill.  I was immediately drawn in to this great story.  The story is excellent, and the character development is perfect.  There are a lot of characters introduced throughout, but Joe Hill manages to develop each one in a unique, descriptive manner.As for the story itself, it is loaded with suspense, horror, and even a little humor.  I was somewhat nervous at the end, because I thought the ending was going to be disappointing, but I was wrong.  Everything is tied up very neatly.I recommend "NOS4A2" very highly.  If you like suspenseful, scary stories, then don't miss this one.

The Death Star has been destroyed.  Now, Princess Leia and her band of Rebel comrades have begun construction of a new secret outpost known as Echo Base on the remote ice world of Hoth.  But the base needs supplies for construction, so Leia and Han Solo have set up a rendezvous to acquire them. But her ship comes out of hyperspace right into the arms of a waiting Imperial corvette.  Was she betrayed?  If so, by whom?  Leia's damaged ship managed to escape from the Imperial corvette, but what she comes across after exiting hyperspace is even more disturbing; a gunship is attacking a merchant freighter.Disturbed by the actions of the gunship, Leia learns that it is in fact crewed by survivors from Alderaan.  Being Alderaanean herself, Leia is determined to find out why this gunship would be attacking a merchant vessel.  What she finds is a ship crewed by pirates.  Now, Leia's job has become one of not only acquiring supplies for Echo Base, but finding a way to help the crew members of the gunship.  The Alderaaneans are in debt to a mysterious pirate leader, and Leia has set her mind to helping them while possibly recruiting them to the Rebel alliance.  Will she succeed?I'm a big fan of "Star Wars" novels, and I found "Razor's Edge" to be a good book.  I enjoyed watching the development of Princess Leia from a diplomat to a very capable fighter.  Of course, having Han Solo and Chewbacca around means that there will always be plenty of action.  I felt the story was well-conceived, and I enjoyed the actions of Han and Leia vs. the pirates and Imperials.  I hope the next book in the series is as good as this one.

R.L Stine has been scaring children for years with his "Goosebumps" series of books.  Now, it's the adults turn to be scared, and "Red Rain" does a masterful job of doing just that.Lea Sutter is a travel writer who writes a blog about interesting places to visit.  Her current destination is the island of Le Chat Noir.  While on the island, a devastating hurricane strikes, killing dozens and destroying numerous buildings.  Lea herself is injured, but it's the two twin boys who emerge from the rubble that catch Lea's attention.  Lea had always wanted more children than the two she and her husband Mark have, so she makes the impulsive decision to adopt the boys and raise them as her own.Needless to say, her husband is not enthusiastic about welcoming two new children into his family.
