Plus, he's unsure about how his children Ira and Elena will react. Mark is struggling with bad press about his new book and does not need another distraction in his life.  At the beginning, the twins seem to fit in.  Appearances can be deceiving, for soon after their arrival, the twins begin stealing items from the home and doing other nasty deeds.  But these are only a prelude, for as the story goes along, it is revealed that the boys are definitely not the little angels Lea thought they were.I found "Red Rain" to be an excellent book.  The story is definitely loaded with terror and suspense, and the characters are well-developed.  Stine also displays a sense of humor in the book with the constant banter back and forth between the two police officer characters.  The ending has a twist as well.I've never read R.L. Stine before, but I will again.  Hopefully, he'll have another new adult novel out soon.  Highly recommended.

Sam and Remi Fargo are vacationing in Mexico when a violent earthquake rocks the region.  The Fargos remain in the area, providing medical assistance to the injured.  While there, they come across a volcano; but it's what's inside the volcano that is truly amazing; for inside the volcano is an ancient building containing the remains of a mummified man.  But even more amazing is the discovery of a Mayan codex.  Soon, Sam and Remi have shipped the codex back to the United States and are on their way home.Upon returning, they are approached by Sarah Allersby, a wealthy English heiress who has an interest in the codex.  Rebuffed by the Fargos when she expresses a desire to purchase the codex, Sarah leaves, but this initial encounter is only the beginning, for Sarah soon becomes obsessed at possessing the codex and will do everything in ther power to acquire it, including murder.  Will Sam and Remi survive?  Who will end up with the codex?I've become a fan of Cussler's Fargo series, and I thoroughly enjoyed reading "The Mayan Secrets".  The story is good, and Sam and Remi always keep the action moving.  The other characters introduced in this book are very good, too, especially Sarah Allersby and the two thugs who work for her.  The ending is a bit of a surprise, too.I highly recommend "The Mayan Secrets".  It is a worthy addition to the Fargo series.

Obi-Wan Kenobi has come to the desert planet Tatooine as an exile.  After Emperor Palpatine's Order 66 to exterminate the remaining Jedi was issued, Obi-Wan, Yoda, and the remaining Jedi who weren't killed went into hiding.  Kenobi chose Tatooine to oversee Anakin Skywalker's (now Darth Vader) son Luke.  He hopes to remain isolated in his efforts, but things have a way of changing.The Oasis is a small general store and livery located in the sands of Tatooine.  Run by Annileen Calwell and her children, the Oasis serves people who need supplies, animals, or alcohol.  Orrin Gault, a moisture farmer, frequents the Oasis.  He is also the head of the local militia which protects paying customers from the dangerous Tuskens.  One day, Obi-Wan, now known as Ben, rescues Annileen's daughter from an encounter with the Tuskens.  In the days and weeks that follow, Ben's desire to remain hidden is tested, as he becomes close to Annileen.  But danger lurks as well, not only from the dangerous Tuskens, but from a secret that Orrin is hiding which could jeopardize not only his mission to protect Luke, but to the other locals as well.  Not willing to stand by and watch innocents harmed, Ben must rely on his Force training in his never-ending fight for justice.I'm a big fan of the Star Wars novels, and "Kenobi" is one of the best I've read.  From the very beginning, the story explodes and keeps the reader interested throughout.  Author John Jackson Miller has done a fine job of developing Ben's character as he struggles to contain his ever-growing feelings for Annileen.  Orrin's betrayal is also a highlight of the story.I give "Kenobi" my highest recommendation.  Full of action from beginning to end, this book is the perfect addition to the Star Wars novels.

Jessye Norman.....What can I say that has not already been said about this truly fascinating and vocal treasure...one of the greatest to ever grace the operatic stages of the world, and also, naturally, of the recording studioLong have I followed this amazing woman from what seems an explosive appearance into super-stardom and her long ride at the crest of the waves throughout these many years of her career.I have long loved this great super-talented and gracious truly beautiful lady and the many great excursions she has taken me on through her recordings and videos of both operatic productions/recordings, and also for her solo recital work.....simply one of the best (but I bet you already knew that, right?).The history and history-lesson(s) she presents to us here in this book are so truly needed today and to be re-viewed and re-minded for us, and for those who were not around when Jessye's (and my) formative years and beyond were happening. Wonderful indeed, to reflect on just "how things were" back then, and how she came through it all, etc., got her education, and made the absolutely-correct choices in moving forward, and along the way became the very great lady that she is....truly she stands with Marian Anderson (her hero) and Leontyne Price as the three greatest Black Operatic Singers from the USA to grace the stages of the world! This is a great biographical book and a must-read for any opera lover.If I were to say anything in the somewhat negative of this book I would have to say that I at more than a few points felt like she was presenting points sort of like "I did this" and "Then I did that", etc. Now, please bear in mind that I read the pre-publication galleys and things may have been corrected for the final print version (so I'm just saying) but I still would highly recommend it to you whole-heartedly....a "must read" from a very gracious honest and lovely lady who just grows and grows more gracious and lovely every day!

What a truly moving and fabulous book about the military, it's men, their love and comradeship for and between one another, and those who far down the line still feel and revere from members lost so many years ago, and the lengths one may go to "do the right thing" and display the love for a brother/friend/family member, etc.I loved this book and was deeply touched at many points within this multi-branched story, leading to one truly filling heart-felt conclusion.If you read only one historical/semi-biographical book this year, I urge you to make it this book by Bryan Bender....you will be so happy that you did read it as I was. Truly a lovely patriotic love-story to/for those lost but not forgotten men from previous conflicts. It gets my vote for best book that I've read in a very long time!

Such a wonderful light-hearted story, with more than enough serious advice of what, why, and how you should choose what you do with your life and the results from the correct choice.I fell in love with this story on so very many levels. I'm sure you will also, and I most highly recommend it to you. David Michie has become a favorite writer to me and I have been reading his other books in this Dali Lama's Cat series.....again, as I said above, Purely and Simply Delightful!

I LOVE this book! Sherri Gragg has the gift of being able to put this all together with such loving and tender and enlightening touch, words and expression! This lovely book has remained on my nightstand now for many months, and frequently before "putting out the light" I spend some time reading/re-reading Gragg's "Call to Linger in the Savior's Presence" before sleep. Sometimes because I "need to" for one reason or another as in the case of a bad or stressful day, and other times "just because" before ending my day...good news is indeed good news after all!Presented as a short piece of scripture followed by a recommendation to read a particular passage from the Gospels and then Gragg's thoughts/interpretations/expressions, this is a warm and very gentle and personal view into the Life, Deeds, Teachings and Thoughts of Jesus. I find it one of my favorite books after the New Testament (and the rest of the Bible) and some of my other volumes regarding scripture and historical writings and documentation(s), etc.  As I said earlier, it is, indeed, a very lovely and moving, touching, greatly uplifting and comforting book (for me) to have on my nightstand to close out my day with these wonderful entries assembled and written here by Sherri Gragg. I highly recommend it to you and am positive that you will also find it becomes one of your favorite daily pleasures to read from.~operabruin

An especially enlightening and enjoyable little book (under 220 pages) about "walking" and its "purpose" or usefulness in the creative lives of famous philosophers, thinkers, teachers, poets, etc. throughout our relatively recent and not so recent past.First, I cannot believe how many people have "torn this book up" with their reviews! My honest hope is that you will overlook these and read some of the 4 and 5 star ones....they are the folks who have understood and relate to the author's intentions! I cannot imagine that the average perspective reader will not come away from this truly wonderful educational/enlightening experience laid out for you by Mr. Gros and not think themselves the better for having read/experienced this lovely book!Walking....it's pace, the determination put into it, the steep rugged terrain walk, the easy lazy stroll, etc., on and on are gone into here with interesting, informative and delightful examples of what each meant to famous men during their creative productive lives in our past.Others have written much, so I will keep this review rather brief, but urge you to read this really enjoyable book. Nietzsche, Rimbaud, Rousseau, Thoreau, and Travelers-By-Foot to Santiago de Compostela all would recommend you read it, as well as many Strollers in the Public Gardens of the 1890's would also! Do read this book....I'm betting you will really love it and be glad you did so!~operabruin

In these times today, it is hardly likely that there is another book so vitally important to (1) Parents (2) Students and (3) Teachers and the people that will influence the school kids "here and now".....  Let's not kid ourselves, these times are indeed hard for all involved with these young people and how/what to do with them (as things currently exist) in their close personal/educational surroundings. Someone needs to stop the crazy merry-go-round that our young people are caught up on from the pushing/pressure of their parents, the same from their peers, and certainly sometimes from the very "wise" educators that supposedly should be "inspiring" and "stretching" them and their minds.What I find truly amazing is just how many people here have given this book a thumbs down... It seems the parents themselves (today) were also caught up on this same merry-go-round and for some reason could not/cannot separate the "necessary" from the "not" that David McCullough, Jr. here was/is trying to point out/instruct them on about what is wrong with their children's "lives" that they are directly responsible for!Education...and the resultant ability/knowledge to go on about and direct one's life and future in the world (both business-wise and other-wise) is what should be most important during these 12 years of formal education, but most particularly the last 4, above everything else. Correct mind-set, learned ability to continue pushing themselves to know and do more "work-wise" sets them right upon the path to continue with this very drive and desire to excel, push through and succeed. This is necessary during these last 4 years...it sets them up for furthering their learning in advanced education beyond high school, and for these very brief 4 years it certainly must take precedent over nearly most other things in the student's life.But....what do we get generally now-days?....Pressure from the parents for extra outside interests like sports....one of the most intense competitive activities that exists today......pressure and added stresses, etc., placed on their children to "be sports stars" or "heroes" etc., and to the point that "every-one's" lives that are directly involved with the student are caught up (again) on this "M-G-R".....  Further, parents today more than tend to direct every aspect of the student's life and activities (as if it were Their Lives instead of their child's) to the point that the child literally is short-changed on education and over-loaded with "other stuff" that simply is not "all that important"....  Johnny will soon learn that his Baseball or Football Letter is one hell of a lot less important that developing his ability to continue "thinking through" and "pressing forward" when it comes to a particularly challenging problem or aspect of his job when perhaps that particular problem might be putting his future on the line....I have read many many of these reviews here, and frankly I find the "whiners" with their "I got bored" or "I couldn't figure out what he was trying to point out", or "whatever".......obviously they were not concentrating on and/or trying to absorb what Mr. McCullough, Jr. was (quite) clearly presenting to them! Honestly, as I said earlier, this is perhaps the most important book today that should be read by parents, students, and their teachers......and, Even Better, would be for them to read it and discuss it in a group surrounding (perhaps one night a week until they are finished with reading it and then a final "summing-up" meeting......  Truthfully, this sort of solution/answer is perhaps the best thing that "Johnny" could have happen to him before it comes to his High School Graduation.....Now, the "Brilliant" that I lead my heading off with....  The commencement address that Mr. McCullough, Jr. gave in 2012 at his school's graduation ceremony is just that....Brilliant!  I have read these 8 pages at the end of the book numerous times and unfailingly marvel at the true brilliance of McCullough's words and can only wonder just what the effect of them must have had on that audience, and how the very air in that hall or space must have been charged/changed by the time he had finished speaking! I cannot imagine ANY parent not wishing and hoping for the author to be their son or daughter's teacher/mentor in high school (or somebody comparatively like him). This point was particularly touching for me as I was a near-failing student at 9th grade, but for an excellent English teacher and a very astute math "genius-type" instructor who both saw me and understood my problem and took to me and coached/guided me, pushed me if you will, to become a high-honors graduate at the end of those 3 years....forever am I grateful and thankful for these special people who watched out and over me and taught me to drive onward and be productive, astute, and successful throughout this remainder of my life, even today, forever pushing onward, striving to "know" and "do" more these 50 years later!This is what this book is about (amongst other things also) and important it is! Parents....read this book, disentangle yourselves with your own "personal" interest(s) that you place on your children, stop orchestrating and organizing every aspect of their lives! Allow Johnny or Jill to stumble some...they will learn SO much more by/from doing so. Their "glory" in the athletic/sports/or whatever else activities that deeply cut into their learning time is SO short lived, SO superficial even just a few months after graduating, versus the importance of their preparation learning while in class and developing these skills that they will need/use every day of the rest of their lives simply makes no sense. David McCullough, Jr. is one of the most respected educators in the country and his long successful career and brilliance at what he does is no accident....believe me! He worked for that, he pushed, he studied and learned just how/what to be/do to become the superlative educator and public citizen of Wellesley, Massachusetts and I guarantee you that every "teacher" that has read this book "wishes" that he/she had written and delivered the commencement address that David McCullough, Jr. did that day to the graduating students of the Wellesley High School where he taught! (Imagine, for a moment, what effect "their teacher" must have had on them that day as he stood before them and delivered his "benediction" to them)!One last thing in wrapping up.....do not be put off by the "so called negative" reviews here. The issue is your child and his readiness and preparedness for "life beyond the popularity of high school".....this is no laughing matter and is indeed very serious. Read this book for yourself, urge your child/children to read it, and inquire if perhaps their teacher(s) might have also read it and talk openly, discuss, the point and purpose of this amazing book. It is Important. It is Relevant! It is Worthy of your time, your child's time, etc. You may never read a more helpful eye-opening book that may/will affect your or your child's life and future!~operabruin

I had these two albums back in the 60's/70's and while I do not currently have this cd, I can verify that the Glaser Brothers were one of the greatest groups of that era and after, nobody ever harmonized better! Thus, the 5-stars at the heading here.While this is not technically a "review" as such, the reason for writing this is to post on here the contents of this cd as Amazon does not list them, and I think most folks would like to know what is on the disk.....Track Listings:1. What Is A Woman What Is A Man2. Help Me Make It Through The Night3. A Girl I Used To Know4. Bye Bye Love5. Me And Bobby McGee6. Snowbird7. That's When I Love You The Most8. Stand Beside Me9. I See His Love All Over You10. A Simple Thing As Love11. Faded Love12. Rings13. Lovin' You Again14. Delta Lost15. The Days When You Were Still In Love With Me16. Leave That For Memories17. Sweet Love Me Good Woman18. Blue Ridge Mountains19. Back In Each Other's Arms Again20. You're In Carolina21. Phoney World22. Pretty EyesI hope that this helps the prospective buyer!~operabruin

The folks at Integrated Marketing do the cook/chef/food lover a great service with the trilogy of this guide andFresh Produce Guide (2012) and The Art of Selecting & Serving Cheese (2011) (The Art of Selecting & Serving Cheese (2011)).All three of these books, taken together, make a great cornerstone/helping hand in one's kitchen.This meat and seafood guide presents more than 120 cuts of Beef, Veal, Pork, and Lamb, plus Chicken. Also contained within its pages are guides on Seafoods from the 20 most common Fishes plus seven varieties of Clams, Dungeness and Snow Crabs, three varieties of Lobster, Oysters, Bay and Sea Scallops, and Shrimp. Nutritional content, etc., and how to prepare all these and know when they are done, etc.Beautiful photographs and illustrations of all the cuts of meats and chicken are here for you to see and get to know what they are and what to look for, etc. I bet (if you're like me) you will probably refer to these 3 books more frequently than your cookbooks! They really are indispensable in your kitchen!Each of them easily earns 5 Stars on many points, including their ease of use because the spiral bindings allow them to "lie flat" when you're using them. For the beautiful and clear photos and illustrations of each of their contents they are describing, etc., and for the sheer Wealth of Knowledge that they present to the average cook/homemaker....after all, we are not all a Garden/Vegetable/Orchard aficionado, nor a Meat Cutter or a Fromagere!Enjoy this book, as well as its two companions I have linked to here....they are Wonderful!~operabruin

Here is the second of three highly recommended  "kitchen" type references from Integrated Marketing. I bet you'll be telling friends and relatives about it and its companions also once you've seen them yourself!It covers: Fresh/Unripened Cheeses, Soft Cheeses, Semi-Soft Cheeses, Pasta Filata Cheeses, Hard/Firm Cheeses, Washed-Rind Cheeses, Blue Cheeses, the Specialty Cheeses, and also Olives. Ninety-two pages of beautiful clear photos of cheese(s) and knowledge about each one, and at the end of the book, information and photos of 28 varieties of olives.Like its two companions, it is a work of high-quality (printing, etc.) and spiral-bound so that it is much easier to handle/use in the kitchen as it will lay absolutely flat. It is ruggedly assembled meaning that it will be with you for a long time. It's a jam-packed little book that you will treasure if you love cheese (and olives)!Its companion volumes are: Fresh Produce Guide (2012) and Meat & Seafood Guide (2012) (Meat & Seafood Guide (2012)) and you will find them also very useful and handy when you reference them! All three are truly "Five Star" volumes!~operabruin

As other reviewers here before me have stated, I also first saw this book in an older edition at my local grocers and inquired of the manager if he could order me a copy of it and I pay for it. He checked and got back to me and told me that he had found it here on Amazon, and in a newer edition. I immediately ordered myself a copy.This book along with its companion volumes (see below) are Kitchen/Cook/Nutritionist references of great value to anybody involved with food, whether you be the chef or just one of the many who simply enjoy food and care to know more about the things you either eat or are perhaps inquisitive about adding to your diet.The edition at my grocery was loose leaf and had much larger photos and printed matter, which makes sense considering the use that it serves in the produce department where folks can quickly locate and read about whatever it is they are checking upon or about while they are in the process of shopping. This edition is updated and although the information is presented with the smaller photos and typeface, for home use it is much more usable because of its size and the presentation is just fine for your frequent checking upon of items in your more relaxed environment where you can spend more time researching. It is lighter which is great for frequent handling and also fits on a shelf much better than the grocer's edition would. Also, it is spiral bound rather than loose-leaf so it is much more rugged in its construction giving it a longer life-span than the 3-hole punch would offer.This informative book is definitely a "Five-Star" reference work that you will be very glad you chose to add to your shelves! If you check the photos of the listing above you can get a really clear idea of what this book contains and how it is presented, etc. As a life-long publishing/printing master, I can assure you that this is an A+ volume of "knowledge" & "information" that will be of great use to anyone wishing to know more about the fresh fruit and vegetables that you "already know" and also the range of items that you may not know about, or are "curious" about that are readily available for you to try at the grocery.As a further bit of information for you to consider, the following are two further items that you should seriously consider adding to your order.....The Art of Selecting & Serving Cheese (2011) (The Art of Selecting & Serving Cheese (2011)) and Meat & Seafood Guide (2012) (Meat & Seafood Guide (2012)) are both very highly recommended for your referencing over 100 cheeses (and also olives) from all over the world, and also for information on over 120 cuts of meat(s) and also poultry and seafood.Trust me, you (as I do) will find this Fresh Produce Guide one of the best investments you will ever make for a reference on food items, along with the two further companion volumes I suggest.  ENJOY!~operabruin

One of the finest discoveries so far this year!At the beginning of the 19th century, the guitar began to be taken more seriously as an instrument and pieces written for it began showing up....luckily for us!The only one who's work I was familiar with here, naturally, is Diabelli. Thus, when one "takes a chance" (I loved the cover art at first sighting), and an album "comes up with" such delightful pieces/music as this one it is very special even from the first listen and through repeated visitations!All three pieces are true, pure, delights to listen to. First, the sound on this cd is beyond reproach, crisp, clearly captured and projecting "presence" with excellent dimension. All three instruments are carefully miked so that we clearly hear the "air" around the flute (beautifully played by Stephanie Hamburger), the "bite" on the strings of the bow on Christian Euler's violin, and the rich quality and ring of the strings on Maximilian Mangold's guitar. I would almost declare this as a "Great Demonstration Disk", but will refrain from doing so, although recommending highly for sound and great musicianship on the part of the three players.All three pieces here were previously unheard by me, and I came away from them with "pure delight" in my heart and in my brain. All three works are bright and for lack of another word, perky! They are light and easy-to-listen-to, almost "demanding" to be played again and again! This disk has rarely been out of my player since I received it and I recommend it highly to chamber music lovers, especially small trio pieces. It is always so wonderful when you make a new discovery like this!It is sad there are no sound-bites here for you to listen to. I wish Amazon would provide them for all recordings.In closing, this is truly an album to enjoy....again and again, and I guarantee that it will be a favorite of yours as it has become one of mine....enjoy it!~operabruin

I had previously never heard of Xue-Wei, and I came upon this recording through a discussion group here on Amazon from a post by another listener/member. What a lucky spot of coincidence that I caught that post!I had to buy a used copy as it is (sadly) now out-of-print.The recommended piece here was the "Serenade Melancolique, Op. 26", a very rarely performed piece of Tchaikovsky's first performed in 1876 in Moscow, featuring Brodsky, and dedicated to Auer. What a shame this piece seems "lost" as it does. Probably it's short duration is the biggest thing against it, sadly.The Violin Concerto is very beautifully executed by Xue-Wei, rivaling any other's efforts that I have ever heard, and I have listened to dozens of recordings over the years. I will stay away from giving a "best" to this recording, as I will stay away from throwing a "best" out to any other performer's efforts also. What I will say is that this is a beautiful, warm, excellent performance by Xue-Wei, rating with any "top favorites". I would now NOT want to be without this recording, if that helps your making a decision about this recording.The Serenade is a pure delight, like some wonderfully rich exotic chocolate treat, or a truly fine rare wine, seldom experienced by many and perhaps for some a "never heard it" which needs to be remedied. There are a few other recordings available by other players, I know that Heifitz recorded it with Ormandy, and also, I believe that Itzak Perlman recorded it also, perhaps a few others also.The sound on this recording is just beautiful, warm, rich, clear, very well captured. I would not give a downgraded opinion as to the mastering or re-mastering for this disk.As I rated this "treasure" above, easily deserving 5-Stars without question at all!Now, the sad part.....out of print at the moment, very hard to find copies of. My suggestion to you, however, is even if you have to fore-go purchasing some other recordings that you have been wanting, it is worth seeking out and paying a "reasonable" used price for...as I said, I would not wish to be without this recording, it is indeed very special and worth having in one's collection.I do know, though, that ASV has a 2-disc set of Xue-Wei playing violin concertos Great Violin Concertos which I am sure is excellent (I might even acquire it for the other works on it) but it does not include the Serenade Op 26, Valse-Scherzo Op 34, or the Melodie Op 42 here on this disk.Easily Recommended, but hard to find, and of course at "collector's prices".~operabruin

This two-for of Wagner Overtures/Preludes holds a rather high spot in the pantheon of Wagner records, and I wish to draw your attention here as I only stumbled upon it by accident.Wagner lovers, this is the ONLY place, other than the Big Anniversary Boxed "Ring" (Solti/Decca, released last year as a limited edition) where you will find a copy of "Kinderkatechismus", nearly unknown even to Wagner enthusiasts! This very short 2'24 piece played by members of the Vienna Philharmonic is (to me) a wonderful "gift" from Decca/Elequence to those who deign to purchase this set. The piece is charming, and interesting naturally, as it is a "personal piece" written NOT for public performance, but for his family. The title  in English: "A Children's Catechism for Kosel's Birthday".....Kosel is the nickname Wagner had for his wife Cosima. In it's original form, it was performed by Wagner's children, accompanied by piano, on Christmas Day 1873. Later Wagner scored it for a very small orchestra and added an instrumental postlude taken from the very end of the recently completed "Gotterdammerung".  The Album is Worth it's price, alone, for this piece, and as I have never seen this anywhere before, I would suggest you obtain a copy asap if you're a curious or completest collector!Another "Surprise" bonus is the recording of Wagner's "Faust Overture", also rather unknown. Here we are presented Edo de Waart's recording with the San Francisco Symphony and it is very good.This album is sort of a "smorgasbord" of recordings by Zubin Mehta, Edo de Waart, and Sir Georg Solti, and it is easily recommendable for the two rarities contained within it.For a Wagner-lover, this album is a no-brainer!~operabruin

This is really one scary story (written by Allison Littlewood, whom I am not familiar with) that will surely push you through what you may consider your "comfort level" to shattering new heights of terror.Cass and her young son, Ben are journeying towards a new place, a new life, after her husband Pete has been killed in Afganistan in a battle. Distraught herself, and little Ben now bereft and lost--sunk into harrowing solitude--she has decided to go back to the little village of Darnshaw where she spent part of her youth.Caught in a driving, and blinding, snow-and-ice storm as they cross the moorland heavy with fog, they are presented with eerie events that bring an uncomfortable itchiness to Cass and a moody short-tempered reaction in Ben. Out of seemingly nowhere a figure appears, knocking at the car-window...it is an odd-acting woman named Sally who has broken down a ways back. They pick her up as she also is headed for Darnshaw and give her a ride back into town.They locate the old mill that has been recently converted to apartments, where she has contracted through an agent to rent one of the units. The place is deserted except for Cass and Ben, even though she was told by the agent it was full-up and this unit was the last available. It is late, they are tired, unnerved by the drive through the storm and the strange circumstance of Sally (Cass had not seen any broken-down, abandoned vehicle along the road she has come to realize), and the total oddness with things at the mill. Now, she is unable to sleep for a strange scritchey-scratching she feels is coming from the wall of her room.Take it from me, things can only get worse!In the coming days Cass and Ben meet a few towns-folk, all remotely strange, the teachers and principle of the school that Ben attends, the snow, meanwhile piling up deeper and deeper....no-one plowing, things getting stranger, like a tension-set screw is being silently turned, ever tighter and tighter. Communication, in or out of Darnshaw, has been cut off now...no cell or phone service, roads unpassable, no mail, and no internet connection...everything with the outside, now shutdown! Ben has become an abrasive, unruly, thoroughly changed foul-mouthed brat...and we see that Cass is incapable of handling the situation. Through it all, the towns-folk just seem to carry on, everything normal, as expected here in Darnshaw.Things begin to unravel, and we find that Cass was not Cass when she lived here previously, that something unpleasant and misunderstood happened...but what exactly went on? She cannot remember exactly, it seems. Family stuff, her father, something strangely wrong, the church...it was in the church...I will stop here with descriptive "tweaks" to you, not wishing to deliver up any kind of spoiler. (I do not believe in spoiling a prospective reader's full enjoyment of a good book or movie).This story begins right on page one with an uneasy scratching, an itching, under your collar (so to speak), and continues at a harrowing, breakneck speed, building to breath-taking unbelievable terror. Unrelenting terror like you cannot imagine snuck upon us here, by Littlewood, and thrust into our faces!I recommend this book to you highly if you are a horror-book fan of Steven King, Koontz, Peter Straub, and others like them. Several passages here literally left me "dumbstruck" with the level of uneasiness, fear, chilling revelations, relentlessly sweeping me along to it's conclusion. What a scary thrill-ride this was!Two reservations...1) This book is Definitely Not For Children...they are definately not equipped to deal with descriptions and events presented here!2) Although one gets to the point where you "just can't take any more", there are a few more pages presented by Litlewood that do not live up to what has happened before. This is unfortunate for it feels like a let-down, not exactly anti-climactic, but like perhaps extraneous to this book--better saved, perhaps, as an intro or foreward to a sequel.However, enjoy this...it is one scary journey here in Darnshaw!~operabruin

Before I get too far here with this review, I need first do a test featuring footage of the baryton so you may see and hear what a beautiful instrument it is (even if it is now quite unknown). If this link is not removed, then, you will see and hear the instrument...[...]Well, as I thought, amazon has removed the link. So, try this, then...copy and paste this in search window at head of pageRoland Hutchinson and the barytonWhen listings come up look for youtube and click that. Hutchinson gives a wonderfully informative overview of this beautiful instrument.This is an enormous set of 21 cds of the trios that Haydn wrote for Esterhazy, who loved the instrument and played as an amateur for personal enjoyment with his friends and to entertain guests. His skills were nowhere capable of realizing full use of the instrument, and Haydn (who it seems, with all honesty), was simply incapable of writing anything that was not wonderful, brilliant, or perfectly fitting for its intended venue and musicians. By Haydn's other works (for professional public performance by highly skilled musicians), then, at first, one would expect these small pieces to be shallow or two-dimensional. They are not such, but rather display incredible breadth and variation. They are anything but boring or flat.The Esterhazy Trio (I will return shortly and augment here) are captured in a delightfully warm environ, and very cleanly and crisply recorded. I would expect at first hearing many will find the baryton strange, which is perfectly natural...it is, of course "unheard for over two centuries" more or less. However, the ear quickly finds unusual beauty and sonority in this instrument's tone and the spread derived from the vibration of the strings under the board, occasionally plucked, and thoroughly enjoyable.That having been said, though, 120+ trios, to sit down and play one's way through would not be suitable at all...it's just too much, and, indeed, these pieces were intended to be played perhaps one or two in an evening as diversion or light entertainment from the events of the evening's setting in Esterhazy's day. At this writing I have listened to the first 4 disks completely and spot-checked several others and come away thus far with great interest, pleasant surprise and truly have enjoyed everything I have heard. This is though, for me, quiet-time, restful reflective-time music...best enjoyed with the lights low, a glass of light wine or a small brandy, with no diversion, that one may be "sung to" by this amazing lost instrument. I would say perhaps they would present several weeks or a couple of month's listening enjoyment by the finish-up, and would honestly expect if listened to at that rate two complete play-throughs plus occasional single disk plays a year will give any Haydn fan well more than this box's cost returned many times over. This is great music by one of the greatest composers and it should be heard and enjoyed. And, so, I hope that I have made a case here for your enjoyment into another exploration that will bring great satisfaction to you.~operabruin

Way to go, Dennis McFarland!I am a staunch Civil War fan, and for good reason, really. It was an evolutionary necessity for this country. It is the only war fought on our soil as "The United States", even though at the time "United" is a misnomer. For sheer terror and horribleness it was shocking in it's brutality and the sobering numbers killed. It is single-handedly this country's greatest piece of history.With "Nostalgia", McFarland has given us, perhaps, the finest novel of the Civil War since Steven Crane's "The Red Badge of Courage". This book is so very finely crafted, and thoughtfully written, that it will stand out with you both while reading it and afterward, as you think back on it, savoring it's human richness, both for the characters and also for the "photographic brilliance" that the author creates (of) the Virginia Wilderness on those early days of May 1946, and also (of) what it was like to have been there (on the 4th, 5th and 6th) fighting and coming under fire, ball and shot literally peppering tree-trunks and whizzing overhead as a sideways "rainstorm" literally stripping those trees of leaves and branches...not to mention the mowing down of so very many men and boys, commanders, and horses...so much fire that the forest would actually catch afire and blaze uncontrolled burning soldiers to death if trapped in it.Summerfield Hayes has joined up in the Union Forces. He is 19 and untried at anything that could prepare him for what is now to come. He has led a life of leisure in Brooklyn with his older sister since they were orphaned, living in the family home with the staff who have stayed on in their capacity as when their parents were alive. Summerfield's great love in life is baseball...and he is good a the game.In Army training during downtimes Summerfield and his buddies play for sport and to relieve the tension of "waiting" for orders. comradery develops to fondness and love for each other of course, and it's a bad recipe for walking into the brutality that awaits them. This is an extreme, and painful, journey that Summerfield is on and acceptance, action, terrifying horror, shock, and fear place him on a knife's edge. We are with him witnessing the trial of those battles, but more, afterward, as he struggles to survive, alone and left for dead seeking help and safety. Then we watch the true aftermath, something new and misunderstood (as it still was up until recently), ptsd, crippling and preventing communication, cognitive thoughts, even "reality" itself.One of the absolutely crowning pieces of brilliance in this story is the inclusion of Walt Whitman in the capacity he served in the field hospitals around DC. Further, one is truthfully presented with "just how things really were in these dirty ramshackle, amateur staffed "death-houses" where questionable treatments hourly added to the death toll.The characters here are beautiful, breathing people that one comes to feel deeply for as men and also for their situation(s) , for there is more than just "recovering" (if one actually did), questions regarding one's status and its consequences. For Summerfield it is a terrifying trial and ordeal.And afterward, the true aftermath, Summerfield's further recovery to re-adapt, and the final moment (for me) of a most brilliant touch that will surely hit you in the heart (especially guys) and perhaps even move you to tears. What a truly wonderful book this is from McFarland, a book that I would consider "required reading" in that if you miss this you have missed a truly fine reading experience...and a truly presented slice of the Civil War and how it affected many, unconsidered until recently just "what the matter was with them" and why recovery was at best questionable."The New York Times" has designated this wonderful book as one of the 50 best books of 2013 and I Agree Completely!-operabruin

I am an avid reader, and my interests are all over the entire list of genres. Further, James Rollins has been a favorite of mine for a great many years. Thus, I was eager to receive and read this book. Rebecca Cantrell I am totally unfamiliar with, but see that she was a student of Rollins previously.With that being said, I first was a little disappointed before starting the book that it is part of a series, and while I am not one to "jump into something like this (not from the very beginning of the tale(s))", I did so as I have an obligation to review here.What I did like about the book:Very fast-paced and edge of your seat thrilling as all of Rollins' books are, so I was pleased from that aspect of it. Further, there are many aspects that really held my attention, as in the creation of the creatures that the villain (sorry, not into spoilers, so will leave the name out here) devises and constructs to protect himself and also threaten or kill his adversaries with. I found this very captivating and thoroughly chilling....a Very Nice Touch, for sure. There is a scene in Stockholm that takes place in the night in a fascinating Ice Sculpture Garden-Maze-Castle that captivated me also (throwbacks I guess to a Sherlock Holmes story not by Doyle, and also reminiscent of "The Shining", and in a different medium in one of the Harry Potter stories). This "set-up" or "foil" always grabs me and fuels my imagination...every time. Something back from my childhood or something maybe?What I did not care for here:First, I have been an early "Christian" religion enthusiast for a great many years. While I am not interested in "organized" religion as such, and seem to have or desire no affiliation to any modern church per se, I am always eager and hunger for more knowledge of Jesus's time itself, when he was here on Earth, and that of his direct followers before they were put to death by the powers from Rome because they would not profess as the Romans did and demanded they do (enough said, ok?). So, with the coming of Constantine, all interest in this subject simply "stops" for me.Ok, having given you this much information and how I feel about that, I now come to this book, and as I said (while I find much of it very interesting, fast paced, etc., I cannot bear to see Fantasy/Horror/etc. mixed up into a soup such as this one is here. Vampiric characters and ancient Seers, phantasmagoric happenings with animals, etc., is not a mix or combination that appeals to me at all....somehow I feel that religion and these dark creatures and beings from the night or depths just don't gel. I hated that aspect of the book and many times almost threw it across the room in anger. However, my obligation was to read and review it, so here I am doing my job.The two star rating:Because of the great parts of the book, I cannot give it any less than 2 stars, and in fact those parts actually rate higher award. But, because I was so totally thrown off (repulsed?) by the mixture of religion with the evil elements present here I cannot fairly give three as that is a rating of "I Like It" (and I didn't).I never deliver up spoilers (do NOT believe in destroying a potential reader's ability to enjoy something by doing that) and so I hope that I have not given away anything that will take away from someone's enjoyment. Also, though, I do hope that I have made a clear enough statement that clearly explains my dissatisfaction with this book.My views of course are just that, how I saw this book. You should perhaps also read other reviews here as most seem to think it is excellent...then you will probably be better able to make a decision as to whether or not you wish to read this. There are SO many other, truly great books out there to enjoy that this one seems unworthy in comparison.~operabruin

I wasn't sure when I picked this knife out, but having experience with Coast's flashlights (excellent, indeed), I took a chance on it. When it arrived and I opened the (deluxe presentation-type box) and saw it I thought "it's too big". Not really. Although I have very small hands for a man, this seems to fit perfectly in my grip. It also is quite light, and I like that, too. The action is smooth and easy, again great for a small hand (a 66-year old one, too) and I have no problem with it fitting in my pocket (not sure which pockets others are complaining about here). The balance is great, so it feels right, and natural, in my hand.While I no longer do anything much in the woods and forests, I still have uses that this knife will be handy and just right for here around home, whether in the workshop or working with my craft projects.Others here talk about durability factors, but I see no reason this knife will not serve me just fine for many years. I bet the average user would agree with my assessment of it. It's a Good Quality knife, at a reasonable price...check it out!~operabruin

Well, it is true. I did just shave my beard! Now that may not sound startling to you, but (this time) it has been in place since 2006.I was curious you see, when this product was offered for me to try, so I ordered it.After waiting a week, "thinking about it", you know, I just "clippered" it off (except the moustache), spent a few minutes as I looked at it asking "why"?, and then lathered up this Nivea product, and "shaved".First word...."wow". It lathered up wonderfully rich, was nicely slippery so my razor glided smoothly, felt wonderful on my face (the Chamomile and Witch Hazel, I am sure), and has left me smooth, soft, and not "uncomfortable" as I usually feel when I shave off long-standing beard hair. My skin feels invigorated, and I like that!I have used Nivea products for various reasons over the years, but this Shave Cream is just great. I like it, really I do! Now I have a problem, though.... Do I let my beard grow back out again or continue to shave? I can't decide. I love myself with a beard, but this feels so good! Maybe I'll come back later and let you know what I finally decided!Give this a try, guys, it's great!~operabruin

Suave has been around "forever" of course, and for good reason.I must say that I am "death" on any product that smells like perfume or "flowers"......I don't know if most other guys feel this way or not, but I assume they probably might. Colognes, etc., anything with a "fragrance" turns me off for two reasons, one is that I am sensitive to these smells, and the second is that I just do not want to smell like I am "prepared" or whatever you want to call it.I wear NO scents at all, ever. I keep myself clean, naturally, but no longer feel a need to "deodorize" myself. Thus, when I find a product with a light, clean, next to nothing scent, I like it! This is one of those products.My hair responds well to it, sparkling white and clean, stays in place nicely without anything to hold it, and best of all, there is no "perfume residue" wafting from me after showering, etc. Further, my beard likes it too! Fluffy, again, sparkling white, shiny, staying in place with just a simple combing, and again, no breathing "perfume residue" all day either.It lathers really nicely, rinses out completely to a really nice "squeak", and it also comes in the "landmark" Suave "easy for a man to hold" container.Give it a try yourself, I bet you're happy with it too!~operabruin

I have sported "fur" on my face for the better part of the last 50 years. Mutton-chops, gottee, van dyke, full beard, moustache, stubble, etc., I have exhibited them all.Throughout all this I have naturally had to struggle with taming what manner of fur I was sporting at any given time. From brushes, combs, etc., and I must admit, some strange "control" products also (yuck). I also on a few occasions have owned a Beard Comb, although I have not used one in later years when my beard was halfway to my belt. Recently I decided to "clean myself up" so to speak, and shaved most of it off, beginning with stubble again, and now sport a carefully groomed short beard and moustache. When Vine offered this Baxter Beard Comb, I quickly ordered one.This, hands down, is the finest comb of any sort that I have owned in my entire life. I kid you not. It is heavyweight. Every tooth is polished to a smooth tip for comfort. I'm delighted.What can I say next? Well, I am about to order myself a whole collection of Baxter of California combs in various sizes!Good Product!~operabruin

Loving tuna as I do, I was quick to order this product when I saw it on offer here.Recently I had seen another brand similar to this in my local grocery and had tried that (although packed in water) but was eager when I saw this one to try one that was packed in olive oil.This has got to be the best can of tunafish that I have had in a very long while. (Remember when tuna was a "solid" round "plug" of sturdy meat?) Well, here you go, again, baby! Solid, clear tuna, in healthy-for-you olive oil, versus "salt" water....ugh! In these days of now living and trying to eat more healthily I eagerly come back to tuna in oil as it used to be in my childhood, before we were begun being fed a regular "salt" diet from food processors, etc.Flavorful! I tried a bit right out of the can first just to see just how good it might be. And It Was Good! So good, in fact, that I skipped mayonnaise altogether and just added chopped onion and celery and a dash of pepper. I even skipped making it into a sandwich and simply ate it right out of the bowl with some whole-wheat toast....spectacular. As plain as that!So, do I recommend you try this yourself? What do you think? Do you see the 5 stars above!?Another "plus" for this product also....13-cents from every can sold goes to support the World Wildlife Fund. It is Sustainably harvested, and supports marine conservation and improvement projects. How can one not feel good about that?!If I am unable to find this product in my local grocers, then I will just have to start a new thing for me, ordering staples from Amazon...I don't want to go back to that other tuna!~operabruin

How many "scary" books have we all read, huh? One person's "scary" is not necessarily anthers! But that said.....This is One Scary, heart-thumping, piece of work, from first time out Elizabeth Heiter! I am most eagerly awaiting her next book.Like myself, I bet you will not be able to put it down, and that you just may find yourself getting back up in the night in order to read further into this terrifying story.Evelyn Baine, like others before her, knows how to think like a serial killer, enabling her to get "into the head" of a stalker and killer. We are introduced to the "Bakersville Burier", killer of young women, who murders, rapes, horribly bruises (through some unknown process), carves them up, and then buries them in the woods up to their neck, leaving their heads and faces exposed...."why"?Evelyn has become a profiler for the FBI because of an incident from her childhood, an incident that has seemingly "forever" marked her, unable to recover. She has been assigned to this case, to figure out who this killer is and why and what he does to the victims, all young women. Carefully working the case, as she approaches her auto one evening, she feels a sting, becomes overtaken and blacks out, waking up to a scary situation, deadly situation, with terror like she has never even dreamed about before.Heiter leads us through a maze of eerie, breath-holding tension(s), attacks, further murders, past murders, leads and dead-ends until she brings us right up to that one last night, the night that we have known was coming all along since the beginning. Here we are, seemingly in the same space as Evelyn and this unknown person, capable of the most unspeakable acts and abuses imaginable. He's here, you can hear his breath, feel his presence...That's it, I will not deliver up a spoiler ever. I do not believe in that sort of thing. Why would anybody steal these scintillating terrifying moments from a prospective reader?As you can see, I highly recommend this truly scary book to you. It is just "the best"....do get it and read it for yourself....if you dare!~operabruin

From one who is really not too "religious", although I do consider myself Very Deeply Spiritual, and a believer in the Man Jesus.First, praises to Jay Parini for writing this most excellent text....it is so wonderful. I cannot imagine anybody not being engaged and moved by this beautiful 152 page dissertation regarding Jesus.Before I really begin, let me tell you that there will be further books from Parini in this "Icons" series covering, I believe, the Apostles, etc. Surely this series will become a great measuring-stick during our times, opening up the biographies of these men.After my statement above about not being religious, I mean, of course, "steeped in dogma, etc., and rigid belief without question". That does not make me a "non-believer" in Jesus himself, Jesus the Man. For those who wander outside church rigidity to read the words of the Buddha, Confucius, and others, one finds that the teachings of Jesus and these others follow nearly identically to a remarkable degree. I look at Jesus as a very great teacher, educator, and through his teachings, the world came out from the dark days of "an eye for an eye" etc, "slay your enemies", etc. to "Love Everybody" "Treat them as you yourself wish to be done by", etc.Parini presents Jesus to us without all the trappings that have been hung on him down through the ages, and shows us the human Jesus, what he said, what he stood for, how he lived by his words, and urged us to do so also. He also knew of course that his time was short (perhaps even much shorter than the Bible would have us believe) and he definitely knew that he would be put to death because of his teachings, teachings that would create great ripples through the traditional Jewish faith who controlled everything in his times, for fear of, and willingness to "play it safe" to the Roman authorities.He gives us logical, believable, explanations of events and things, enabling us to look "under" the "magic" or "mumbo-jumbo" if you will (I do not mean this in a mean-spirited way, folks, just as an expression). Everything, presumably, was perhaps pre-calculated by Jesus beforehand, or perhaps just as it was happening, and it all makes sense. The kind of sense that a brilliant teacher, educator, friend, etc., who wanted to take us and show us how to escape the many "terrors" (if you will) that humanity was under during those times. To free us up, to show us that we were worthy, we were honorable, etc. He taught us to be humble, honest, non-judgmental, and even to the point that we all do indeed bear our own cross in life until we are set free (in death) yet with unfailing belief.My words here may not be what you personally need to get you to pick up and read this book. Please, then, do not be put off by them. Read another's review here, maybe that will spur you. No matter. Whatever. But do, please, read this book. You will look at Jesus, again, with a new(er) set of eyes, see him perhaps in a slightly different light, but in a beautiful new way.Then, you, like I, will eagerly await the next volume in this wonderful new series.Thank you, Jay Parini, you have done all of us a great deed in presenting "Jesus: The Human Face of God" to us for our enlightenment and enjoyment.~operabruin

Neil Swidey in this documentation of tragedy in the Deer Island Sewage Outfall Tunnel under Boston Harbor on July 12, 1999, takes rightful place in literary excellence giving us the bare-bones, unadorned story of this horrendous accident 9.5 miles out deep under Boston Harbor.His "forward" introductory tells us the situation that day as DJ, Tap, Hoss, Billy, and Tim worked out at the end of this completely black unlit hole under the harbor, with no fresh air, only their backup oxygen apparatuses and that ominous length of hose snaking from the Humvee back there in the dark leading to them. It was a recipe for tragedy and of course it Happened.We are "hooked" here at this point, 11 pages in.Flashing back six years, we are then presented with "back-story" on these men and how they came to be here in this situation under Boston Harbor that day. We (or at least I) have great interest and feeling for these men once we understand who they are, what they do, and the level of dedication and sheer mental-physical determination that it surely must take to do this sort of job for a living....I cannot imagine it, period! God Bless the Boys who do these jobs (like firemen, etc.) because the majority of us cannot even think about doing this....these guys? They get the job(s) done.We discover, as always, that "powers that be" through arrogance, willfulness, lack of concern perhaps, create horrendously grave circumstances through this "negligence" (shall we say), and repeated notations of problems make no difference and create no changes in approach to more safely getting the job done more safely. And so, "Mr Everyday Average Guy" becomes the victim of the errors that those in charge are responsible for.July 10th 1999, things go terribly unwell down in this ominously scary column so very far out and so deep under the Harbor. Nobody listens to their concerns, their fears. Tuesday, the 11th, things become even more scary to these brave men, but again no addressing the issues from the guys in charge. Wednesday, the 12th, back under again, hopelessly trying to get the plugs removed that will allow access between the tunnel and the volume of the Harbor so the waste can disperse out to sea, we get the final tragedy that now takes the lives of two experienced, brave deep sea divers, nearly claims the other three (less than seconds before it would have been to late, saved only by a "chance" happening), and the horrifying experience of desperately trying to get to help before it is too late. As always with this type of story, it IS to save two lives, and also to SAVE three others from debilitating injuries that they desperately struggle with. Three great added tragedies played out in the days and years after this "Perfect Storm" re-imagined and re-lived, but this time Under the Sea.I cannot recommend and urge you to read this wonderful book enough. It is a story that needed to be told. Needs to be read. Needs to be remembered as do these brave men (and those others who had died on the job on the tunnel before them, in the beginning stages of the tunnel).It is painful (tears frequently were running down my cheeks while reading), it is graphic (as was the tragedy that day for these men, I am sure), but it needed to be told, and Swidey has done a remarkable job in doing it. Generously annotated and full of information to clarify things for us (the average every-day person not familiar with this kind of work project, etc.), it is for me, one of the finest, interesting, and moving books that I have read in months.You are recommended to put this on your "to read" list!

In its third incarnation, Rose Myers' "Graphic Designer's Guide to Portfolio Design" gets better so I award it 4 stars.The very toughest thing that I ever had to do while in Computer Graphics Courses from 1997-98 and (advanced) 2001-2004 was attempting to create a portfolio of my work. There is no simple way to do this, and as every artist or designers style and output is different, so too I feel the portfolio should also beone size does not fit all which I believe you understand.There is much covered here in this 300 pages of text, studded with photos, illustrations, tips, advice, and comments from professional designers. It presents a great overall view of creating a gathering and ordering of ones work suitably for presentation to get professional results. Therein, to me, lies the largest part of the problemgetting through all this on your own. Not easy for a newbie, manageable for a designer of some experience. I honestly have not seen any perfect text for this that many can easily get through the first or second time around at it. (As I said above, personally, I found it the most difficult of jobs).Ideally, I would say that this book is good enough to be a textbook that would be the support of a physical course in portfolio design. Under the physical presentation of a skilled professor or graphic technician, this book becomes a strong support in learning to create the vehicle for presentation of your work.Chapters include:1, The Portfolio Process2, Planning Your Portfolio3, Traditional Portfolio: Resume, Cover Letter, and Business Card4, Traditional Portfolio: Design & Art Projects5, Digital Portfolio: CD-ROMs, DVDs, and Web Site(s)6, Digital Portfolio: Technical Elements7, Design Phase8, Working With Type9, Maneuvering Around Your Site: Navigation10, Web-Based Portfolio: Web Page Design11, Web-Based Portfolio: Technical Elements12, Multimedia & Your Interface13, Designer Checklists14, Using Social Media to Land a Great Job15, Taking Interviews & Presenting Your PortfolioAfter reading this TOC list, just try to imagine fitting all this onto 300 pages in a manner that the majority of folks could manage to get through easily and clearly understood. This is the Crux of my notations abovea go-between (professor or tutor) helps immeasurably for the majority of folks trying to weather their way through this in a manner that is easily understood and that they can maneuver through with a sense of confidence.Rose Myers has great knowledge, and gives much advice, showing numerous examples through illustrationsbut, as I said, I do not personally or professionally feel that one text can completely present this process. I recommend this book, but further I recommend or urge the prospective Portfolio Designer locate a class or a tutor to make this process bearable to get through without pulling out all your hair or chewing your nails down into the quick!Lastly, as with all Wiley publications that I have ever had exposure to, this volume is of excellent quality, from the dull-coated paper used for the text (no glare, important for someone staring for hours at printed pages), excellent solid perfect binding, and a durably heavy coated cover make this a text that should last the user a long time through use.

Personal thoughts regarding seasonal music....Holiday albums, or Christmas music, however one chooses to refer to this seasonal genre is a strange piece of the musical spectrum. This music holds a very specific emotional, even familial, tie to the greater part of folks. The "old" songs seem to always hold sway over anything new that comes along. So, the old carols, chants, ancient-leaning instrumented, the Bing Crosby, Sinatra, Nat King Cole, Perry Como, Peggy Lee, etc., on and on recordings always trump newer efforts.Yet, it seems that every 8-10 years there is a new piece or song that strikes like a lightening-bolt and wakes us all up and grabs us by our heart, ears, and/or other pleasure-sensing organs, and we take this new piece into our collective "loved" seasonal music, sort of like binding a new chapter into a treasured old book of love.Silver Bells, Do You Hear What I Hear?, Christmas in Dixie, Little Drummer Boy, are examples of this. Occasionally, a real out-there entry takes hold also, like Feliz Navidad, or (lord help us all) Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer sidles in and takes a place amongst all the old treasures. Most, though, just get one season or less of airplay and then are lost to the great majority...they just cannot hold up to our favorites from years gone by. I attribute this mostly to the fact that the Holidays are so emotionally charged that the older always bring fond memories of loved ones now gone or still with us. The new has no connection to us like the old ones have.Review:I got a text from a cousin to go to the link she sent, taking me to youtube. What I was seeing and hearing literally sat me down with amazement. Great musicianship and talent will always get my undivided attention, but what I was not only witnessing that, but tremendous creativity, ingenuitive thinking, and an amazingly creative team effort, together to create and deliver up something so different, original, marvelous to see and listen to that I was nothing short of transfixed by it. This was what is the opening track on this album, a mind-boggling rendition of Angels We Have Heard on High. The ingenuity and creative talent to execute this amazingly complicated "arrangement" is breathtaking to watch. Ribbons of horsehair from a cello bow, pieces of paper, tapping with fingers and little hammers, etc., all need to be witnessed to appreciate what these 4 men are doing...hearing is wonderful, seeing it is mesmerizing. I will send you to witness this later here.The contents on the cd in this special cd/dvd set are:  1. Angels We Have Heard on High  2. O Come, O Come, Emmanuel  3. Good King Wenceslas  4. Carol of the Bells/God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen  5. Where Are You Christmas  6. Let It Snow/Winter Wonderland  7. Still, Still, Still  8. We Three Kings  9. Away in a Manger10. Christmas Morning11. Winter Wind12. Silent NightThe DVD:1. O Come, Emmanuel2. Carol of the Bells/God Rest You Merry Gentlemen3. Where Are You Christmas (featuring Sarah Schmidt, Jon Schmidt's daughter)4. We Three Kings5. Rudolph6. A Family Christmas Yule Log EditionThis was produced and directed by the musicians themselves....More Creativity from these amazingly talented guys!5 Stars for Talent!5 Stars for Musical Execution/Musicianship!5 Stars for Creativity!5 Stars for Production and Direction by Themselves!5 Stars for Excellent Natural Sound and Fidelity!(25 Stars? -- You decide for yourself!)I have had this cd in my player now for two weeks, and so far, two or three times a day I give it another spin! What does this tell you? Either I am stupid and don't know "good" when I hear it, or this album is simply astounding, worthy of my time to keep listening to it. I think it is the latter, and I most heartily recommend it to you. And, with that, I send you here to witness for yourself! [...]*  I cannot imagine anyone not totally loving this most special album from these exceptionally talented men.*amazon removed my link that I inserted here for you, so copy and paste the last line below in a youtube search to see and hear this amazing piece.Angels We Have Heard on High (Christmas w/ 32 fingers and 8 thumbs)

(First, an overview regarding these reviews here.)I am always amazed when a product receives review ratings all throughout the spectrum. In the case of Frances Mayes' memoir it certainly divides these numerous readers into clearly defined blocks.Some complain that it does not follow the movie! This, to me, is a thoroughly invalid point as the movie was made from the book and came much later, and is the item at fault for not following the book!Others state what a boring piece of crap this book is. Obviously they have never been involved with restoring a very old house (so cannot begin to understand what Mayes is relating) and especially the problems that must be overcome when that particular old house is halfway around the world, and further, the fact that one would be dealing with workmen who speak another language!In the case of one reviewer here, the reader believes she read a novel, so perhaps she thought what she was reading should have been exciting, glamorous, etc. Well, a memoir, by its very nature of course, is seldom those.*****My review,I had purchased this book some time ago and as is sometimes the case one thing leads to or away from intentions. In a recent move this past summer I un-buried this forgotten little book from "someplace" in unpacking and sat it on a stand near my bathtub. As I suffer from back problems and take warm soaks frequently, it was natural to spend those times with this book.First I would urge you to not be too much put off from reading this lovely book by those reviews that the reader found boring, artificial, etc. Of course, if you know nothing about restoration and renovation, etc., then you may not find this book as entertaining as someone who does. This book is Mayes' memoir of those years that she and her husband spent shuffling from their California home during semester and summer breaks from teaching at UCLA and the high hills of Tuscany to oversee and work on the historic old home they bought there and all the shared details of those efforts. Interspersed with these events and memories are those little excursions throughout the countryside and surrounding towns and villages and what they experienced and the people they acquainted there. (Many here I guess found this boring, sadly missing the point.) Coming from an earlier time, with different values perhaps, I found this book simply lovely, very fulfilling, and especially so for the little memories it pricked from back across my own past and experience. In many ways, I guess, it just happens that the things she relates here touched me personally which naturally created a richer experience for me in reading her efforts.Her prose is lovely, descriptive to the point that you can see and smell the dust, the foods as she walks past or perhaps into local restaurants or taverns. Or clearly allowing you to see or smell the flora and fauna of the surrounding hills and countryside, or literally "putting you there" with her and her husband as they snoop through antique shops or boutiques in search of furnishings, etc. Simply stated, this is an especially wonderful documentation of the times and efforts that Mayes, her husband and family and friends and new Italian acquaintances spent there on the hill renovating and putting their magnificent "ancient" Tuscan home back into it's former shape.The book is lovely, just lovely. I highly recommend it to you...it is very special and totally worth your time.You will also find many recipes enclosed within it's chapters, and not for nothing, food does, indeed create further interest and her sharing these points in time give you a sort of bit of personal time with her in that enormous old high-walled space she called kitchen!

Without doubt, this is the single greatest addition to my large music collection that I have added in the last year (maybe longer).For some reason I am not remembering owning any Steinberg recordings years ago on LPs, yet knowing his reputation, I find that hard to believe. Yet, coming to this set, and listening for the past couple weeks or so, I do not recollect hearing these before either, so I come to write this review with totally "new" eyes and ears, if you will.Impressed? Yes, indeed, So! As I said to a friend regarding the Beethoven symphonies enclosed here, it was like hearing Beethoven (again) for the first time! Is this really possible? I do not rightly know, but I DO know that I return over and over again to listen to these pieces and am thoroughly struck and captivated by them under Steinberg's hand.Every entry on these 20 discs is thoroughly enjoyable and a special satisfying pleasure to listen to and I most heartily recommend that you add this set to your collection as these recordings stand out against nearly all others and give you a great look into this great interpreter of our musical giants that further enhances your enjoyment of their works, and also will bring you to love this man's genius for interpretation and insight, and make you "wish for more"!Surely one of the finest additions you could wish to add to your collection. These are, of course, old recordings, yet they come up with stellar sound and fidelity for their age, and are "must haves" for most classical music lovers, trust me!

Normally, I go through the day with "average" or "every-day" items and find them usually satisfactory....it is just how I am and how I keep on my budget, so to speak.I selected this Baxter Badger Brush through the Vine program, and am SO pleased that I did!Over my many years I have used many shaving items from many genres, be they blades, electric, aerisol lather,  soaps, etc., and brushes. I have used many!What a beautiful item this brush is! It is sleek, neatly designed and shaped, and well balanced for holding and working with in your fingers. The bristles are soft, smooth, and flexible with just enough "spring" in them to create a great lather and work it over our face comfortably and smoothly. Luxurious? Yes, Indeed, it is, and it is wonderful to wake up in the morning and start the day with this beautiful luxurious shave brush...I leave my bath with a happy smile versus my previous "sigh" or somewhat underwhelmed and "not closely enough cut" feel of my face, knowing by noon I will look like I did not shave this morning. Not with this brush! It retains enough moisture to evenly spread and work the lather in and that helps a great deal, guys, as you know if you use a brush...nothing works like one, and this one is really fine, indeed. You will not be disappointed in the least, it is a totally well-worth-it investment--an investment in your face and how well you look every day.I would urge you to invest, additionally, in a truly good first-class soap to create your lather, and of course a brush/razor stand so that you leave your brush hanging vertically, extending its shape and useful life, and also its beauty. As I said, waking up and getting to use a luxury item first thing in the morning is wonderful and Does guarantee a smile on your face to begin your day with.As you can see here, I am not the only guy granting 5 *s to this fabulous shaving brush....order and enjoy! (You and your face deserve it!).

The ratings here don't lie, of course!Crystal Gayle....what to say! Hasn't it all already been said by many over and over throughout the music world? Talented, Beautiful Beyond Words, and, best of all, Low-Key....no razzle-dazzle "big deal" showmanship for her...truly a real class act for this woman!Just for the record, this is what wikipedia says about her: "Crystal Gayle (born Brenda Gail Webb on January 9, 1951) is an American country music singer best known for her 1977 country-pop hit, "Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue". An award-winning singer, she accumulated 20 number one country hit songs during the 1970s and 1980s (18 No. 1's on Billboard and 2 on Cashbox). Also famous for her nearly floor-length hair, she was voted one of the 50 most beautiful people in the world by People Magazine in 1983. She is the youngest sister (by 19 years) of singer Loretta Lynn and a distant cousin of singer Patty Loveless. Crystal Gayle has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, near Loretta Lynn's star."Here we have Crystal's Christmas Album, "A Crystal Christmas", and as many others before me have stated, it is surely one of the very finest Seasonal Albums to come along in a Very Long Time.Also, as others before me have said, this is a Laserlight reissue of the original album (which I believe is now out of print), and it is far less expensive than "collector's prices", sounds just as good as the original release, just a minor re-arrangement of the song layout on the disc and the substitution of "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" for "Christmas In America" which I would guess may involve copyright stuff. None-the-less, this album as it stands here is a pure winner, attested to by all the other reviewers!Crystal wins again, here, with these lovely Christmas Season treasures, sung in her distinct silvery-toned voice that has won the world over again and again with her hit songs and albums of conventional country-pop music. Ten timeless delights, here for your enjoyment at Christmastime or anytime you wish!This is a Real Stand-Out Album, recommended for Everyone who likes Crystal Gayle or Christmas Music....or BOTH!Enjoy!~operabruin

For those of you who are my age, or near it, you undoubtedly must remember the DixieBelles for their fun, raucous, thoroughly enjoyable toe-tapping songs full of humor.The 1960's were truly great years for memorable tunes, singers, and also groups that will carry on into the millennium ahead of us. For me, the 60's were where I discovered Bobby Darin, Johnny Cash, Bob Dylan, Buck Owens, Brenda Lee, Connie Francis, The Supremes, Peggy Lee, Dean Martin, Joan Baez, The Beach Boys, Beatles, Kinks, Rolling Stones, etc., on and on with so very many more great artists and songs. The 70's, 80's, 90's, etc., of course, each had their "new" discoveries, etc., but somehow the 60's hold pride of place as my musical "sweet-spot-in-time".The Dixie Belles were an American girl group briefly popular in the early 1960s. Their best-known single, "(Down At) Papa Joe's", hit #9 on the Billboard Hot 100 late in 1963, and the follow-up, "Southtown U.S.A.", hit #15 early in 1964. Both these songs were produced by Bill Justis, and released on Sound Stage 7 Records, a division of Monument Records under the directorship of Fred Foster (no relation, btw).On record (at least for their first single, "(Down At) Papa Joe's"), The Dixie Belles were in fact all members of the all-white Anita Kerr Singers. However, an all-black touring group was assembled for publicity, promotion and live dates; this touring group may also have sung on some of the later recordings credited to the Dixie Belles.Based in Memphis, Tennessee, the Dixie Belles touring group had all previously sung backup in various capacities. Several members had been in The Tonettes, who recorded one single for the Stax Records subsidiary Volt in 1962.A full-length Dixie Belles album was released, but a third single ("New York Town") failed to hit the Hot 100, peaking at just #119 on Billboard's "Bubbling Under" chart. Shortly thereafter, their contract with Sound Stage 7 ended and they never released another single.Several members of the touring group later turned up in The Charmels, a group that recorded four non-hit singles for Stax between 1966 and 1968.If you are "hungry" for some down-and-out rollicking FUN music, then by all means, take my advice and order yourself up a dose of the DixieBelles....you won't regret it!~operabruin

Right off the bat, I am a Devoted Coffee Drinker, probably I could be considered an addict!I just love it when Vine offers a product like this for us to try. Surely this is the finest and best way to get a good item like this great coffee the circulation and attention that it deserves, so that we may then "safely" order it and know we will be enjoying it.My personal favorite coffees are usually Sumatran, Kenyan, Ethiopian, Somalian, Nicaraguan, Guatemalan, and Indonesian-Javanese grown beans. Occasionally, there is Kona, sometimes a Yukon blend.
