As most coffee lovers know, each of these are truly unique unto themselves, and each is always a welcome change that will bring a satisfied smile to your face...every time!This coffee is sure to please even the most demanding drinker. It is dark and rich, full-bodied with a mellow overtone to it. Smooth certainly would describe it also. It ranks right up there with the finest imported brands of beans.I grant it 5-stars easily--as it is that good. Would I order it regularly? You Bet! (and I will be ordering it frequently here....there is always something truly special when you get your mail, and it contains a pleasurable treat like this.)If you are a coffee drinker, I highly recommend this truly great Ethiopian to you.....you'll surely enjoy it!~operabruin

***First, (some personal thoughts and recollections) that day....November 22, 1963. It was one of those rare days that (unfortunately) get imprinted onto our cogitative memory like 9-11-2001, or myriad other things that for one reason or another we always remember. I have never forgotten that day, nor that moment, (having just returned from lunch with my high school sophomore classmates to Miss Curtis' homeroom and waiting to go to the first afternoon's class) when our principal, John Abbott, came over the intercom with the news from Dallas.  I do not believe that any of us actually thought what we were hearing was true. We were young, untouched by any kind of tragedy in our lives, and thus, it had some kind of unreality; difficult for us to absorb. I was left simply not knowing how to act, or react, to this news, and still remember that all I could muster was a smile (to my horror), but truthfully, I did not know how to act or react, nor what I really was feeling at that moment, trying to process something unimaginable to my young self. Much later I would learn that usually response to this sort of thing is either tears or a smile (or something like it) is quite normal. This was the United States, this just couldn't happen here. We were dismissed and I remember the walk home from school, through town, seeing people everywhere, all asking or declaring what had happened, or how, in Texas, so many, many, miles away, just an hour ago. And, then, of course, the uninterrupted broadcasts of never-ending coverage from the saddest possible news and images to scenes of unbelievably and outrage that were still playing out there in Dallas, Texas, throughout that sad weekend.Time, of course moves on, and with that time, things settle out, become sifted to their proper level of importance or memory to the times. It takes this time for history to sort itself out.***"Killing Kennedy" review:Last year I bought "Killing Lincoln" as I have had a life-long interest in both the man and the Civil War and it's times. Of course, with a lifetime of prior readings and studies, I knew the story inside out (I thought). Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard certainly had to have done their homework very well and have produced one of the finest books I have ever had the pleasure to read about Lincoln and his times. It is a magnificent achievement, and if you have not read it, I heartily recommend it to you for your enlightenment. It moves in real-time and is so clearly written and articulated that you literally feel that you are "there"....which I have never experienced before. That book can be found by clicking this link: Killing Lincoln: The Shocking Assassination that Changed America ForeverAs I was finishing up "Killing Lincoln", I saw the announcement for "Killing Kennedy", and thus since it was relevant to my or "our" time, I pre-ordered it here and awaited its publication and release. Other life obligations prevented my reading it until about two weeks ago, but I must say it, also, is one of the finest-told (presented), in "real-time" again, "endings of Camelot" that I have read, and as with Lincoln/Civil War, I have read many about Kennedy, Cuban Invasion, Missile Crisis, Cold War, etc.Again, O'Reilly and Dugard have done incredible homework and worked diligently to piece together this riveting account, hour-by-hour, of the assassination there at Dealey Plaza that "last" sunny autumn day of the Kennedy presidency, and the shattering destruction of "Camelot" as we were just coming to know it. The back story is clear and concise, seemingly not too long, but neither short-ended with its presentation of relevant facts, etc. I was quite fascinated by revelations of JFK and Jackie's "private life" in the White House vs. their "public life" that we of course always knew about.Of course, we all know the story, (again, it seems), intimately from the "over-and-over" of all the intervening years and the countless "theories" that have come about. I greatly admired O'Reilly's avoidance of these theories, directly, in this presentation of this sad and tragic piece of American history. Mention of all those who have been accused over the years of having had a hand in this brutal killing, but O'Reilly leaves that information "just there", which I was pleased and impressed by.Details, yes, there are myriad details concerning many things that have not been exactly presented in the "full light of day" so to speak, and they speak much here in this fascinating account of Jack, Jackie, Bobby, even the rise of Teddy, and more; --revealing and personal insights into their lives, personal and public, shining new light onto and into their situation during JFK's "reign" as this country's chief executive.You will get insights into the introductory chapter(s) of the Viet Nam Conflict, the Mafia, Marilyn Monroe, the Lawford's, Onassis (and how he first came into the picture), Sinatra, Bing Crosby, Greta Garbo, Lyndon Baines Johnson, Adlai Stevenson, Lee Harvey and Marina Oswald, FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover, the CIA, the Secret Service, and the police force there in Dallas that day. And, of course, the last character in this story, the strip-joint operator, Jack Ruby. There also are wonderful "afterwards" to all concerned characters here in this "Saddest of Stories".This, of course, has always been one of the biggest and so-called best stories of the past century, and O'Reilly and Dugard have magnificently re-told it here, enhanced greatly by details and information that we have not previously been exposed to before. Because of the news-coverage and the immediacy of the electronic age that was just coming into being, the notoriety and instantaneous presentation of events, both tragic, horrifying, and ceaselessly amazing to us, the people who either were there that day in person or were there because of television, it will long remain in the memory of the history of the citizens of the `60s and too, the history of this country and of it's leaders and the movement just out of sight of us as ordinary citizens.This surely is a "must read" book for every person in this country who lived during those days or who is interested in this country's history, both in and of itself, and also of it's leadership over the years. I cannot recommend Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard's magnificent presentation to us of "The End of Camelot" (as we knew it) highly enough. You are SURE to love this book!~operabruin

A thoroughly enjoyable book for "wanna-be" writers and also just for the memoirs between Kidder & Todd over all their years together as writer & editor.I was taken in immediately with the winning description of "The Atlantic's" offices in 1972's Boston, and delightedly swept along through the friendship and working relationship between Tracy Kidder and Richard Todd through the intervening years. Educational and enlightening, solidly helpful to those seeking to perhaps become non-fiction writers (or fiction writers also, for that matter, as they offer good solid advice and examples), or just for the warm and fuzzy relationship of these two guys working together.A thoroughly enjoyable and very special book! I highly recommend it to anyone seeking writing advice, or those just looking for a warm remembrance between two friends.

Many here reviewing this chair mention how difficult it is to assemble...I had absolutely no problem with this, but I have assembled many pieces of furniture, and I guess one gets the hang of this sort of thing, like any "learned experience" so to speak. However, as with most of these items, I quickly switched to my own tools vs the wrench supplied to my advantage...you may wish to do likewise.Also questions regarding the durability of the "leather"...this seems to have become the norm for this type chair. Have no fear, it is durable and I cannot imagine that it would not hold up through normal use. As for the strength of the plastic parts, I am 245# and have spent some time sitting, rolling, raising and lowering, etc., and I cannot imagine that even someone approaching 300# would have reason to worry.Over the years I have "gone through" several of these type chairs (and stools) and can honestly say that 4 out of five have been great...one with padded arms had them split from my resting my arms and elbows on them. All of the others served me well, usually 4-5 years of 8-10 hours a day. My last one is now 8 years old and is still solid, but the inner padding of the seat has finally gotten tired, and so I ordered this item as a replacement.This one is very comfortable, fits to and supports my back very well, rolls smoothly and just seems to fit my body better than most chairs that I have owned.I would easily recommend this chair to anyone for its comfort level, and its stability, my perceived sense of its lasting durability, and for its really good looks. I would have no fear ordering this chair.~operabruin

I love it when someone can re-tell a piece of history that we all have lived with for 50 years and leave you thinking "I wonder....." "What if....."When was the last time you were drawn in completely and carried along by a story?.....Particularly an old story, endlessly investigated, theorized, wondered about, argued over, covered up, interfered with, etc., to the point where you come to not really believe anything is the truth. Stephen Hunter succeeds here with this book, and when it's all over, you get left to mull "Hmmm, I wonder..."When this happens, the author has succeeded at his job and Hunter scores a big one, again, with this fascinating, incredible re-telling of the assassination that imprinted November 22, 1963 in all our minds the way 9/11 would mark us 38 years later. Well constructed, certainly researched and with enough "believability" to keep you glued to this story as Bob Lee Swagger struggles to figure it all out. "What really happened at Dealy Plaza that day, and who was behind it"....the very same thing we all are still asking ourselves after all these years. We probably may never really know, but will forever keep asking ourselves.Stephen Hunter is a truly great storyteller. He and Dennis Lehane have entertained me a great many times with their exceptional works. Unless you just can't stand to hear or read another word about the JFK assassination, I highly recommend this book for your reading pleasure...it's fascinating, it's exciting, it's gonna make you go "I wonder..."~operabruin

Norma Deloris Egstrom.... from Jamestown, North Dakota...What a ride this great artist and lady had from destitution, abuse, neglect, etc., finally through association with Benny Goodman, emerging as Peggy Lee, and the world of music sat up and was changed forever.No matter what song, or genre, she dabbled in, she got right into the heart and soul of her subject and literally, completely, made the song her own. She was also a songwriter as well as an artist when she wasn't lighting up the stages or recording studios. Immortalized, surely, for her work on Disney's "Lady & the Tramp", unforgettable as the voices of the Siamese cats.Her lengthy time at Capitol, then Decca for a time, and back to Capitol, produced a seemingly endless stream of lovely truly "hit" albums. She was at the top of her game, always, teasing depth and meaning from everything she sang.In 1972, she decided to tackle "pop" if you will, a fair step away from her jazz, blues, swing, and torch-song norm. The result was this album, sadly under appreciated at the time of release, receiving little airplay, etc. It is, today, arguably her very finest album, and I agree with that rating. When it was released I fell completely under her spell all over again, and literally played my first lp to death.Sadly, it would be her last work with Capitol Records and her contract was ended, as so many others had happen to them (particularly Connie Francis), out of nowhere "ka-boom", you're all through, "Goodbye". She never regained her momentum, although she still recorded several really good albums for various labels, and of course she still toured and appeared frequently to the delight of her millions of devoted fans. Age, Time, and Illness finally prevented her from working which was a very sad thing, and then, God Bless her, she was gone from us, a great light gone out. The last time I felt that sad at the passing of a singer was when Nat King Cole passed away.Fortunately she was such an avid and active recording artist, and we are left with the hundreds (seemingly) of her beautiful albums...what a gift to us and all the world to enjoy!When Capitol was releasing their "Two For" cd issues, "Norma Deloris.........." was paired with her "I'm a Woman" album. I knew ahead of time by a year or so and eagerly awaited it's long desired release. Imagine my shock and unhappiness when I played it and found out that it "Was Not" the original album! Tracks that were out-takes or alternatives were substituted, leaving myself (and I am certain) all her fans heartbroken at this error. I have dearly wished for this misfortune to be corrected, and At Last, fortunately, it has happened with this corrected, completely remastered MP3 release here. I am not a "download" type guy, preferring to be able to physically hold, see, and read cd releases, and can only hope that Capitol will release this as such. It certainly will give me reason to re-purchase this album "one-more-time" because it is so very special, and so very wonderful.I hope I have not lost you with this lengthy review and narrative history. What I wish to say is that I am literally completely blown away by this "restored" reissue! I have never heard a remastering of any recording that has come up so chrystal-clear, so immediate, so very "fresh" that you would swear you were hearing Peggy Lee live, truly! I am not sure what has been done to the sound from the original masters, but this issue is, TRULY, a MUST-HAVE for anyone's collection.If you are not familiar with this album, order and download it, you will not be disappointed, in fact, you will hear Ms Lee as you have never heard her before! Those who are familiar with this album need to also order and download it...you, too, will be completely won over once again, and in beautifully remastered fidelity.Peggy Lee, Norma Deloris Egstrom, from Jamestown, North Dakota, her finest album, reconstructed, for us to once again enjoy...thank you, Capitol Records.~operabruin

This album (origionally two seperate lp releases) houses my "first" Petrouchka and my "second" Le Sacre Du Printemps recordings.At the time of his Petrouchka, Boulez was setting New Yorkers back in their seats (when they weren't angrily dissing him) and afterwards here, he showed us just what the Cleveland could do under his direction. From the early to late '70's, just approaching his middle age in years and his coming of age in composition, he was the "Bad Boy" of classical both on the page and on the podium. New Yorkers eventually drove him away (what a shameful loss to themselves and music in general).Today, he has mellowed and tempered his interpretive delivery, and has slowed his concertizing and is concentrating again on composition. Some will probably say "Oh God!" while many will be saying "At last!" i am of the latter...but this extraneous material to this review, though relevant and informative.I was totally mesmerized and put under the spell of Stravinsky with this recording of Petrouchka, totally and endlessly fascinated with it. I have never heard another recording that can dull it or acceed to greater heights, as to "replace it" so to speak (and I have many on my shelves). Remastered, this edition reflects the dynamics of the original lp and is one of the greatest Stravinsky recording efforts ever done. Columbia's technicians and engineers were doing their best work here. Everything about this recording simply sparkles, dazzles, and crashes to display and reveal the greatness of Stravinsky to the fullest level.Le Sacre, again, knocked everything before it back a few notches. That said, I came to appreciate the work only after a great many listenings and years of trying(s) with many recordings. Eventually, Boulez and the Clevelanders finally clawed their way to the light and this work became epitomized with/by this recording. Again, the fidelity of this remaster surpasses the first cd release and is truer to how I remember the lp release.As another side note, I find Boulez's later DG recording of these works very interesting to listen to, showing us his later, truly mature thoughts about them very enlightening indeed. However, these earlier Columbia efforts are the ones you want "first"!My most urgent recommendation to anyone, either looking to become acquainted with these works, or seeking great readings of them, would be to not hesitate...they are both stellar and uniquely, unforgettably, top-drawer all the way around. They belong in every Stravinsky fan's collection, too good to miss!What could be better? Well...one could wish for a SACD remastering of them, couldn't he or she. Let's hope it happens!~operabruin

Written words here for you to read cannot begin to cover the truly wonderful pleasure and experience of listening to this beautiful album. The by-line on the reverse of the case reads "Spiritual & Traditional Christmas Celebrations from the Famous Mountain Regions in Austria" these few words alone should be tweaking your desire to hear for yourself, I would think!Twenty-four of the most delightfully played seasonal pieces are captured here for one's listening pleasure, each like a sparkling diamond lying on snow, as so often seen by us when the sun shines on last night's new flakes. From simple harpsichord, small string numbers, flutes and whistles, accordians, solo or small-group vocals accompanied by simple instruments, etc., one truly feels the delightful simple pleasure that citizens from this beautiful area deliver and also receive in the pleasure of playing these lovely gems. I have never known anyone who does not receive the greatest pleasure and enjoyment from small intimately delivered secular tunes and melodies.The entirety of this album is filled with richly fulfilling music that will become not only a "seasonal delight", but for many, I bet, a frequently-played album throughout the year.Others here before me feel the same way as I do, eagerly urging you to add this delightful collection of songs and tunes to your personal library.~operabruin

These were a necessary upgrade from my previous +1.50 that looked similar; these were the closest looking ones I could find to my old pair.  My previous glasses has a greyish tinted lens, these, more of a rose color, IMO.  As soon as I put them on, I noticed a difference, for the better.  They helped cut down on the harsh fluorescent light right above my desk.  Very happy; purchasing another pair for a backup.

I've been a huge fan of these shut-off valves.  Most of the hose nozzles I use tend to use leak after time, probably from all the dropping and dragging of the hose.  With this nozzle, it helps eliminate wasting water and money.  Hopefully I'll get a few years out of it, as compared to those made entirely of plastic or even just the plastic shut-off piece.  I'll be keeping a few extras in the shed as well.The one problem I have experienced is that it interferes with my nozzle attachment; so the valve does not open fully, taking away from the water stream/pressure.

I have been using my GoPro as a dash cam and have it mounted using one of the adhesive pads.  With the original buckle mount that came with my GoPro Hero3+, I didn't experience any annoying rattling.  With this replacement, there is, unfortunately.  At first, I thought I didn't tighten the nut good enough, but apparently that's not the case.

Upon receipt, I wasn't particularly thrilled with the cheap plastic tray.  I never expected it to be such a flimsy product, especially since I'm big on using Perky Pet Hummingbird feeders.  I'm going to go out on a limb here and say that it's not going to last too long.  The clips from the chain were pretty difficult to snap on, I didn't think the plastic would survive the snap, but all 3 did.I waited until the Orioles showed up and immediately put this feeder out.  That was 2 weeks ago.  I filled the container half way, to test the waters, and hung the feeder from a shady tree.  I have plenty of birds in my yard; woodpeckers, cardinals, titmouse, nuthatches, chickadees, sparrows, robins, orioles, hummingbirds, starlings, goldfinches, mockingbirds, on a daily basis.  I have a suet feeder on a pole, that I now fill with seed cakes, that is the current favorite by all above mentioned birds.  For 2 weeks, I sporadically checked this feeder.  I had never seen one bird visit.  I had noticed the jelly dropping from the 3 drain holes in the orange plastic tray.  The ants were thankful for that.  I went out on the deck last night and heard unusual noise; sure enough, the local gimpy raccoon (has a bum leg) was tossing & turning the feeder.  I didn't even bother to shoo it away or spray it with the hose.  I figured I'd let him enjoy it.  He licked it clean, and for that, I'm kind of grateful.  I'm unsure if I'll even bother putting it back out.

This power center is a great item.  It's perfect for those clunky power adapters (laptops, older non-usb devices) along with many usb  devices (mp3, phone, tablet).  I admit, I had gotten this to use in our conference room at work, but changed my mind when I thought about how many devices get plugged in at home every night.  I keep DH's FD pager (clunky adapter), DH's Bearcat FD scanner (clunky adapter), and via USB,  an LG phone, 2 iPhones, a Kindle Fire,  & a wireless bluetooth speaker.  I will also be bringing this item with us when we go away; it'll replace all of clunky adapters I bring that would have to be scattered around the hotel room, just for the USB devices alone.

I've done so much damage to my skin, since I was young & stupid in the 80s, not caring at the time about using sunscreen, just wanting that fast color.  Now that I've learned my lesson, and have the pale skin to prove it, I really wanted that little hint of color, without doing further damage.  This lotion is really a good product.  I'm sensitive to smells, and this Suave doesn't bother me like lots of other self tanners and/or lotions.  I used it sparingly for a few days, and noticed a gradual hint of color.  No streaking, no Jersey Shore cast orange, just a nice, subtle glow.  As gardening season is upon us, I'll definitely be using this to enhance any color I might get from being outside.  This product doesn't contain sunscreen.

We figured this bag would be the perfect amount for the front of the house, but we actually had some left over and did some of the back yard.  I have to say, our lawn greened up fast, and even though the amount of rainfall we've had so far in NJ could have had lots to do with that happening; I'll never know.  Despite this, I have never seen the lawn come in so green & lush over the last 16 years.  I'm extremely happy with the results, and will continue to use.

I'm not a big chip person, but love a good spicy treat.  Sometimes chips are greasy, and/or sometimes they have a nasty aftertaste.  These chips have neither.  Nice crunch, great taste, no lingering unwanted aftertaste, and even better, you can actually taste the potato.  DH loves spicy as well, but not too much, and these chips were a hit for him.  DD loves very spicy, so  would've preferred a bit more spice, but she really likes these regardless.These chips are awesome, period, but we'll purchase them sparingly, unless they can do something about the high caloric & fat content, without removing the taste.1 2oz bag:290 calories160 calories from fat18g of fat:2g of saturated fat0g trans fat2g polyunsaturated fat14g monounsaturated fat

Belkin, in the past, was a name I could trust and have faith in, for the most part.  I have purchased many cables for iPod4, iPod5, iPhone4, and iPhone5, and practically everyone of them fails soon after, and this one is no exception.  Bad enough Apple can't make a decent cable for their own devices, apparently nobody else can either.  Any i-device cables are disposable with their limited life spans, and it's too bad their prices don't reflect that.

It's a stunning design on a hard plastic outer cover.  I wish it were more flexible and/or rubberized, which would make it much easier to put on and take off.  I haven't had much luck with the last 2 Speck cases (both broke in the same spot, undoubtedly from constantly changing cases), so if this case does manage to crack, I will post back.  So far, so good though.

That isn't available from what I can tell.  When searching the app store, the app doesn't even appear.  Googling shows it in Amazon, but isn't available in the U.S. for download.  HUH?  Can no longer even play the current version 3.7.2  Lame.EDIT:Kindle users:  remove this app from your device, go to 1mobile and download the android version of Crime City, which will work on the Kindle.  You must allow non-Amazon apps to be installed on your Kindle; the default is set to "no", so go into your app settings to change it.  I don't know all that much about the game, since dh is the one who downloaded it onto my Kindle in the first place, but all the game data remained.  But, from what I've seen online in some forums is that you can't buy gold, which doesn't matter to me or dh since we won't pay for game add-ons/add-ins.

Like others have stated, this app will only play when flat.  Tilting the fire ever so slightly and the game flips.  And when you tilt it to attempt play will cause it to flip again,  and so ok on, into a never ending flip-a-thon.  Frustrating.

I removed my original antenna to put a tarp over the Escape before a snow storm. I threw the antenna on the ground with the intention of picking it up, but forgot, and now it's been shoveled and probably sitting at the bottom of a big snow pile.  Not having the patience to wait until it thaws, I ordered this replacement, and it fits fine.  I listen to satellite radio and don't really listen to local stations so I haven't noticed any issues with static.  I really wanted this for cosmetic purposes and didn't want anything to clog or happen to the mount area before I'm able to find the original, but when I finally find the original, I'll put it away as the backup antenna, if I ever need it.March14:  Found the original antenna; shredded up when it went thru the snowblower.  This antenna has been working fine.  My favorite radio station, which is iffy on a good day, is still iffy on a good day with this antenna.  No noticable interference with any other local stations.

I'm torn about this Flantern.  As compared to my Rayovac Sportsman LED Lantern (SE3DLN), the weight alone makes it more desirable.  I'm not a fan of LED lighting in general, I'm going to use the Rayovac, which is easier on my eyes.  It's been especially useful as a flashlight lately, since I'm using it to look out on the deck at night for a stray cat that's been visiting.  The range is much nicer than some of my current flashlights, and very bright.  I'm not fond of the position of the on/off button when using the flashlight; it's annoying to have to find the button.  On a regular flashlight, it's generally right there for your thumb to find, not on this.  It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out how to use and charge the flashlight, but an insert of some sort describing the product, would have been nice.It's a nice device to have handy in case of a brief power outage.  Even during longer periods, as long as you use this one sparingly, it should last long enough to give you a few hours a day of needed light.
On Kindle Fire HDX, works fine with Optimum.  As of 02.18.14, providers are:AT&T U-versebright houseDirect TVGrande CommunicationsOptimumTime Warner CableVerizon FiOS

My damaged hair, from many years of home coloring and blow drying, was in need of some help.  I've tried leave in conditioners, which left my hair feeling heavy & dirty.  I've tried hot oil, which would be a quick fix.  I eventually switched back to using just one brand of home color, which helped, but not fully.  I had tried another spray oil and it left my hair feeling dirty, greasy & heavy.This was the perfect opportunity to try before I buy (Vine), and I'm sold.  Normally, I hate anything scented, due to a heightened sense of smell, but this has a nice pleasant smell.  My daughter got a whiff of it and now she's using it as well.  I only use a couple of sprays on my shoulder length hair, in the back.  My hair has gotten that shine and manageability back that's been missing for years; and that over-processed frizz is gone.  A little goes a long way; don't over-spray.

Having been a fan of T-fal (cookware) for about 20 years, I was anxious to try this popper.The stainless finish is attractive.  The popper itself is rather low, much lower than my Presto 04820 PopLite Hot Air Popper, White.  I did like that this T-fal has an on/off switch, which the Presto PopLite doesn't.  The measuring cup is "built in" to the top of the domed lid.  The one thing I didn't like about this popper is that while it's popping, it shoots rather fast/hard into the bowl.  Many popped & unpopped kernels ended up bouncing out of the bowl and onto the kitchen counter.  I never had this happen with the Presto.Once done, there were only a few unpopped kernels left in the unit itself, but way to many in the bowl, along with the bunch that were launched out of the bowl during popping.  The removable dome was ridiculously hot, even after a few minutes, but this works extremely well for the melted butter, much better then the Presto PopLite.Combined, Presto's height & popping capabilities along with T-fal's look & on/off switch would make one heck of a popper.

I couldn't wait to get this on my new Kindle Fire 8.9 HDX, since the device itself it so thin and fragile.  I inspected the case, only to find out that I had no idea on how to open it.  The instructions that came with the Otterbox are a waste of paper.  Thankfully, there's a online instructional video on Otterbox, probably because of all the complaints.[...]  (((My link to the OtterBox instructional video on the OtterBox website was removed by Amazon, so you'll have to search yourself, sigh.)))Once viewed, it was a breeze to open, insert the Kindle, and get it all closed up.  Everything snapped in place nicely.The case itself is rather heavy, imo.  But, it adds a sense of durable protection.  The on/off button on the back of the Kindle is a rather odd place to put the button, but Otterbox seems to handle that obstacle pretty well.  Sometimes the depressed button will not turn the Kindle on or off, and it takes a bit more exertion to get it to work. The screen protector plastic works fine with the touch screen and hasn't been the least bit quirky.  Both my Kindle screen and Otterbox protector plastic were prefectly dry & clean when assembled, but when the screen is dark, I see a few swirls here and there, but not enough of a bother to make me disassemble it. The Kindle charges fine with the case on; there is no interference with the cable and the case, unlike other devices.I applaud Amazon for making the Kindle so thin, but I like a device with some bulk to it, so I that I don't think it's so fragile.With this case on, it feels sturdy and protected.

I ordered the red socks but received black!  Regardless, I think dd will be happier with the black socks anyway.They're very soft.  Cardboard attachment has NBA logo, made in Korea.  Size says MD, which fits US womens 6-11 / US mens 5-10, according to the cardboard attachment.  Tag also says plastic, nylon, latex, rubber.  Latex is not stated in the item description, which would be an issue with those having a latex allergy!

I've been taking Vitafusion Vitamin D3 gummies as well as the CVS store brand gummies for quite some time now.  Both I like, but prefer the CVS brand, taste wise and cost wise (they're frequently BOGOF).  These Sundown Naturals taste okay, the yellow appears to be a banana flavor, which I'm not fond of, and they have a chalkier texture as compared to other gummies.  I really like the taste of the orange ones (kind of orangy peachy) and the red (berry/cherry?) are just alright. A definite plus is that it is stated that they have 'no artificial flavor, no preservatives, no milk, no lactose, no soy, no gluten, no wheat, no yeast, no fish, while my other gummies are made in a facility that creates products with most of those ingredients.  Not really an issue for me though.  The rest of my family prefers the CVS gummies, but if these Sundowns were on sale locally, I'd probably grab a bottle or two for my own consumption.

I generally in between 9 & 9.5, so I played it safe and ordered the 9.5.  They fit well and have a little room to spare in the toe area, which is perfect if I'm wearing thicker socks.  I wear them with bootcut jeans 5 days a week.  They're relatively comfortable, although some arch support would've been nice.  Very happy with purchase.

I own another pair of size 9 Bearpaws, the Ugg look-alikes, that fit me great.  I tried these on, with a thinner than normal pair of socks, and had a hard time getting into them to begin with.  Once I loosened up the back laces, my foot slid in but they were simply too tight.  I would've ordered a 9.5 had they been available, and those probably would've been perfect.  10's never work for me, which is a shame, since these are really cute.

I'm not going to blow out any windows with this speaker, but as far as compact speakers sound, this one is pretty good.Right out of the box, I plugged it into the wall adapter via the supplied USB cable.  I turned the speaker on and a tiny blue light flickered.  I was able to pair my lousy LG Extravert phone up to it without any problems.  I was able to play whatever music I had on my SD card.  It sounded okay, better than some other compact speakers I had tried in the past.  I brought it outside to see how it would work while I'm out and about in the yard.  Placing the speaker on my deck, I began to walk away.  After about 30 feet, it started cutting out and getting choppy and continued throughout my brief walk to about 60 feet, where it got so choppy that I turned to walk back to it.  I placed my phone 40' away (yes, I measured it with the tape measure), then went over to the speaker and dialed my phone from the landline.  The music indeed stopped and gave a series of chimes that alerted me the phone was ringing.  Although the product booklet states that I would hear my phone's ringtone, I did not. I was able to answer my phone from the speaker by hitting the Play/Pause button.  There was an annoying echo, but that could've been because I had the phones & speaker so close to each other.I let my daughter borrow it while her & a friend were goofing around on the laptop, since they were listening to their music.  The music sounded substantially better through this speaker, using the supplied 3.5mm jack.I went back outside and attached it to my Sansa Clip MP3 player, using the 3.5mm jack, and it sounded great.  Same music that was on my phone, but sounded MUCH better coming from the MP3 player.  It's going to work out well when I'm out and about in the yard, running around between the front & back of the house.EDIT:  Just used it outdoors during a snowstorm, in a hot tub.  Put it into a ziplock baggie, Bluetooth'd it with an Ipod Touch.  Sounded great.

I jumped at the chance to try and test this smaller camera bag.  It's a little bigger than I expected.I'm not particularly thrilled with the odd angles of the zippered side compartments.  If something small, like an SD card or battery gets into the lower corner away from the zipper, you really need to dig & push to get down there.  A half zipper going from left to right instead of bottom to top might be more functional, but that's my personal preference.My first choice for this camera bag is for my GoPro and it's accessories.  One side pouch contains quick-clip and an additional mount.  The other has an extra battery and car charger.  The main compartment contains the camera (in it's housing & mount), the battery charger, and the usb cord.  There's still room to spare.  I could easily fit the few other clips & mounts that I have for it.Another older camera I have is a Fuji Finepix 3800.  I put my Sanyo Eneloop battery charger at the bottom and the camera on top of it, and extra batteries in both side pouches.  Perfect fit.2 more of my larger cameras fit into this bag, the Kodak Easyshare Z5010 and the Sony DSC-H200, both with room to spare.  The bag is way to large for the smaller cameras, like the Sony DSC-HX30V, or any pocket cams, although it would fit quite a few pocket cams.The reason I gave this 3 stars instead of 4 was because of the lack of padding, on all sides, especially the bottom.  With the snug fit of the Fuji and charger, I think it would be safe to assume that a fall from just a few feet onto concrete might produce some damage.

The item itself is okay, but didn't fit in my 2014 Ford Escape, due to a dashboard obstruction (the player is located at the top of the dashboard and has a ledge just below it). The bottom of this holder wouldn't let it sit properly.  It did however fit in my old 2001 Ford Escape, which dh is now using, and it fits fine.  The seller had an issue with delaying shipping which they informed me about soon after the order was placed.  They kept me informed of the status, as well as my options to keep the order or cancel it.  Their customer service is outstanding.

0:46 MinsI jumped at the chance to try this camera via the Vine Program, to use for snow sports (skiing, snowmobiling).  Since it's not the season yet, I am testing it as a dash cam.  I initially mounted the first flat adhesive mount onto my dashboard, directly in front of the steering wheel.  Considering this camera is a wide screen, it just didn't work as planned.  After a few days, I used a hair dryer, I heated the mount, and after a few minutes, it easily removed from the dashboard without leaving any marks, stains, or residues.  I mounted another just in front of my cd drive, which is centered and at the top of the dashboard (2014 Ford Escape), and it does not interfere with putting in or removing a cd.  Much better; I now get almost the entire windshield view, but unfortunately, part of the dashboard as well.  Tilting the camera upright helps a bit, but makes for an odd video.  I tried to eliminate that by purchasing the GoPro Helmet Front Mount, but the video was extremely shaky & noisy, moreso than with using the standard mount that came with the camera.The menu is kind of confusing for a newbie, but after time, it's easy enough to figure out.  The still shots I did manage to take while driving, were pretty clear and nothing seemed out of focus.  But although I pressed the button quite a bit, it only managed to take a few shots, much less than I thought I took.  At one point, I kept pressing the button, only to have one jpg show up on the card.  The housing itself it kind of hard to open; I managed to break a few nails, but with time, I got the hang of it, even managing to snap it off, but eventually got it back on.  The seal seems tight, after about 20 openings/closings of the case.  I tested it the hot tub, and it was indeed watertight.  The daylight video itself was surprisingly grainy, something definitely not expected.Right off the bat, I installed at 16gb SD card, but that quickly filled up, after what seemed to be only a small amount of time.  So I purchased SanDisk Ultra 32 GB MicroSDHC C10/UHS1 Memory Card with Adapter (SDSDQU-032G-AFFP-A), and haven't had it fill up, but then again, I'm pretty good about offloading & freeing up space.  A long trip would require multiple cards for sure.I also purchased Wasabi Power Battery (2-Pack) and Charger for GoPro HD HERO3, HERO3+ and GoPro AHDBT-201, AHDBT-301, AHDBT-302, since the battery definitely needs recharging after a few hours.  The original battery that came with the camera didn't initially fit, but after some shoving, it fit & charged.  The replacement battery fits inside the camera perfectly.The one major issue I have is that I wish it had a LCD viewer on the back of the camera.  Whether using it as a dash cam or snorkeling, I'd like to see that I'm at least pointing it in the right direction, and not too high or too low or at an off centered angle.It takes a nice video and the coloring is beautiful, but I look forward to testing it out on the slopes.  I'm not sure what type of mount I will go with, most likely a chest harness, since I don't wear a helmet.EDIT:  Another small thing that bothers me is why it doesn't have a tripod mount built directly into the bottom of the camera?  Yes, I know there's an additional mount (GoPro Tripod Mount) that can be purchased that can be used when using the case, but what if you just want to use the standalone camera without the case?  It certainly couldn't have hurt to put one on the camera itself.

I'm not a big water drinker, so I jumped at the chance to try this additive.  I've been a fan of the Mio Fruit Punch (the only flavor from the line that I can tolerate) for quite some time now, but it's still not enough to get me to drink more.  I had high hopes for this, upon opening the envelope (it smelled sweet & fruity), but it kind of reminds me of Alka Seltzer.  It's rather foamy/fizzy while shaking, but did seem to dissolve rather quickly.  Adding it to 12oz of water (as instructed), I simply couldn't drink it.  It has a nasty initial taste, almost like that uncoated aspirin that sticks at the back of your throat.  I added another 4oz back to the bottle (it was initially a 16.9oz), but it is still undrinkable.

I'm just a regular user looking for a good bud.  As long as it sounds good enough to my liking, I'm a happy camper. I generally get whatever cheapies I can find, even better if I pull them out of the clearance bin at Office Depot or find an online daily deal.  People say I have an earbud fetish, which I'm guessing, they're right.  I jumped at the chance to try these out.This is my first pair of Moshi buds.  They fit perfect fit out of the box, as most do for me (with the "medium" cushions).  The sound is good, the perfect amount of bass.  I've been using these with my Kindle Fire and at work on the PC.  When I keep the volume low enough, I can hear if someone is trying to get my attention.  I can also keep it at a lower volume which enables me to block out the various noises that come out of my coworker.  I'm very happy with these.

Like a few other posters, I purchased this to raise Black Swallowtail caterpillars/butterflies.  I have a large deck railing planter that I filled with parsley.  Towards the end of the growing season, I had a butterfly leave me a bunch of eggs.  Having an excessive parasite problem this year in my current screened in butterfly cage (to many holes/gaps), I needed something large & enclosed in a pinch.  This fit the bill perfectly.  I laid the hamper on its side and slid the planter(s) in, and it's PERFECT.  I ordered 3 in all, so that next year, I have a few habitats handy, which may just replace my cage.  I might just need a few more ;)EDIT:  I now have 6 of these hampers, and they're perfect if you have the space and area outside to use them to rear caterpillars/butterflies.  I keep swapping out the spent parsley plants with new plants that contain eggs and/or caterpillars.
I love this case.  It's pretty, larger than most, and fits my reading glasses just fine.  I'm tempted to order one or two more as a backup, in case I break or lose it.

This reminds me a little of putting a protective screen on a smart phone.  The instructions for putting this up look simple enough, but the challenge is executing the instructions.  And just like with a smart phone, one must have patience to get rid of dust/lint as well as to get rid of bubbles.  But unlike a smart phone, a little lint won't stand out like a sore thumb.I have the light shade which as other reviewers noted seems darker until it is up.  Still, with the light color you do get a lot of the UV rays blocked which can protect furniture and other items in the house.All in all, this is a nice solution for those who don't want to hire a professional.

As a side sleeper, I prefer a softer mattress, but the memory foam and the cooling action gel in this mattress definitely helps.  The cooling action gel foam makes it sound as if the mattress will be cool to the touch, but that is not the case.  Rather, there is a less of a heat build up as your body lays in one spot.  You can test this out by lying in one spot for several minutes and then move off the spot so that you can feel the how hot heat signature is left behind.  In the case of this mattress, it was very slight.  This reduction of a hot spot is one of the five key points of being an official NSF mattress.  Read the Amazon product description for all five of the key points.  Another NSF key point worth mentioning is for the mattress to minimizes impact from partner movement, and I can confirm that this feature is implemented very well in the Northlight mattress.The mattress is constructed with high quality although I had a lot of loose threads on mine.  No biggie but it did surprise me for this price point.  The mattress also has some really nice side handles that are more firmly secure than traditional mattresses.  Backed by a 10 year warranty and the official mattress of NSF, this mattress should do you well if you take care of it.

This is probably the lightest and most compact air pad I've ever used.  As a side sleeper, I was skeptical at first that there would be enough padding.  When fully inflated, however, I felt comfortable.  Rocks and uneven ground might be a little more noticeable compared to a thicker pad, so scout out a good camping spot.  I am also considering taking this bag to the office for power naps and since I can easily lock it in a cabinet.The material seems very strong but I've had other air pads leak over time -- even indoor air pads.  These general occur at the seams.  Conveniently included in the carrying bag is a repair kit.  The sleeping bag and repair kit do not come with paper instructions but most people will be able to figure it out.  For this price, I expect no leaks under normal use assuming nothing has punctured it.  I'll update the review if I start to get leaks.

Light but pleasant smell.  No skin irritation thus far even when applying after shaving.  Protects from sun rays.It does leave a slight oily layer on the skin but you get used to it.  Pump can be annoying as I have had a few time where it reverts back to its shipping state.  Maybe I didnt turn it hard enough initially.

Phyto-peel has a gentle, pleasant smell -- it reminds me of a cross between cocoa butter and mint.  And one you wash it off, the odor is barely present.  In the lotion are little dark brown specs about the size of grains of sand that act as the abrasive.  I've been using this facial on just one side of my face for two weeks.  Thus far, there is no visible difference but I will update this review as I go.  After using the product, my skin tingles a little likely due to working the abrasive bits into my skin.As for the price, if it works well, people will gladly pay for it.

Pretty much everything you could ask for in skewers:+ Dual prong to prevent food spinning+ Easy push-off slider to keep hands clean+ Slider designed to not slide off skewers so you won't lose parts+ No wood parts so you can put the entire skewer on the grill+ Easy to clean+ Fair priceI'll also not that the skewers are not overly sharp so there is less likely a chance that they will stab a person by accident.  They are still sharp enough though to easily penetrate meat and veggies.Finally, these are not dishwasher safe but that's okay -- I prefer to manually wash as my grill tools.

Nice glove that works as advertised.  The concept is the same as the Ove Glove Oven Mitt, and use can use this glove for the oven too.  Keep in mind that although this glove does reduce the heat, it does not eliminate it.  So for a really hot grill, such as running on high heat, you may be able to keep your hand there for 10-15 seconds instead of say 2-4 seconds.  Where the glove excels is more at normal cooking temperatures.I'm 6'3 and this gloves fits me fine, note, so it may be a little big for someone with very small hands.  I also think that the black color is a good idea as it hides normal grilling grime.  Anyone that has a white Ove Glove knows how quickly it can show grime.Finally, I want to mention price.  If you look at one of the top competitors, the Pitt Mitt, it runs about $5 cheaper and is slightly longer protecting more of your wrist area.  In my own informal heat test, both the Pitt Mitt and the Grill Gauntlet performed the same in terms of heat resistance.  Since I recommend getting two gloves, one for each hand, at this time I'd recommend the Pitt Mitt instead since it is more affordable.

All of my family members thinks this is a great idea for kids.  In fact, some in the family half jokingly said that they thought it might work for adults too.  We are trying this out on our four-year old right now.  He is intrigued by the idea but it is too early to tell if this doll has long term effects for reducing his worries.  He worries about people dying, for example.  He can't spell this out so we have him draw pictures about it just like the instructions said to.The doll itself is made of quality materials and the threading is well done.  The zipper is also high quality and has yet to snag.  I don't like the two tags on the doll as they stick out a bit so we might cut those off.  Also, the price is rather high for how simple this doll is.  All in all, though, this doll has potential to comfort a kid who worries too much.

Setup was straight forward.  I was able to get this going using their quick installation guide as you would hope.  I was coming from 300Mbps so the extra boost to 433Mbps helps.  I didn't notice any change in speed but the speed tests sites that show the metrics did see the increase.Most features for this router/modem are what you would expect such as a guest network.  There are also parental controls and something TP-LINK calls Beamforming Technology that supposedly boosts Wi-Fi strength over longer distances.The box has a sticker on it that reads, "AT&T Verizon FairPoint CenturyLink WindStream".  There is also a 2 year warranty and 24/7 unlimited technical support.  Box also says this modem/router is compatible with Windows 8.1.I've had great luck with TP-LINK routers, and rarely do I have to reboot the router.  This is another fine product from them.

A book full of award-winning recipes with most having a gorgeous picture next to them.  Most if not all of these recipes use ingredients you can find at your local grocery store, thankfully.Only about 20 pages of this 192 page book focus on grilling techniques and tips.  However there are a few tips also in some of the recipes.  I was hoping for more tips and tricks to be honest.  A good example is that the author goes into detail about the Minion method, but a few pictures could have helped out a lot.  Another small gripe is the the book uses a too small of a font.  On the plus side, the book uses study paper and the binding seems solid.  I don't anticipate this book falling apart in the kitchen or around the grill.Although I wish this book had more secrets and tips, the recipes seem to make up for this.  Anyone BBQ lover who flipped through this book in a book store would probably end up buying the book.  I'm looking forward to trying more in the coming weeks.

This is my first juice if you don't count my hand held citrus press I bought for $10.  Obviously this item is for someone who is going to process a lot such as someone who has a citrus/apple tree or who makes a lot of french fries.  Sadly, instead of doing any one task excellent, it simply does all three average.  For citrus, it doesn't get as much juice as it should.  For apples and potatoes, it struggles with larger variants.  And with potatoes, it struggles to slice through easily.  No matter how you use product, you are going to build up some muscles in the end.  Personally, I need more exercise so I actually like manual kitchen appliances.  Having said that, I want all my appliances to do a great job.  This item has potential, but it needs to go back to the drawing board and do better than average.

Quality product here.  All the plastic parts are strong, thick molding including the belt clip.  The belt clip does seem to rotate but it takes a lot of torque to do so.Operation is simple -- slide your thumb or finger under the flap and push.  Some sprays make you rotate a lever or do some intermediate step, but this Sabre professional sized model is really a one-step operation.  This is important because when you are under stress, you can't always operate something slightly complicated.I tested this outdoors.  Indeed, the orange liquid shot to 15 feet.  Another reviewer claimed 20ft but for me that would have required arching it higher.  By time the liquid hits 15 feet, it is well spread out.  Upon smelling the liquid up close, it wasn't strong at all to my senses.  I've seen cases where someone accidentally deployed mace, and in those cases, I could definitely smell a strong odor.  Maybe it is a plus that it doesn't emit a strong odor but rather does the pain upon direct contact?  For this test, I didn't apply it to directly to my body.  My furry animals though could definitely smell the liquid and backed away when I put them near it.  I'll trust other reviewers who claim this burns on humans rather painfully upon contact.This review is for the professional size.  This size is not really intended for pockets or keychains.  Sabre does offer a smaller model.  The negative of the smaller model is that it holds less liquid, shoots only up to 12 feet, and has a slightly more complex operation (but if you dry-fire practice, you'll get good at it in no time).  It'll probably come down to personal style.  Do you like items fasten to your belt/pants/shorts or do you prefer stuff in pockets/key chains?  Both sizes get the job done.Also, the product says not to use on humans.  For me personally, as a backup, if a human is physically threatening me or putting me in an uncomfortable position, I have every right to use this product to defend myself.  If I am wrong, then we'll let the courts settle the matter (if it gets that far) later in a more calm environment.

I use ear plugs/filters to reduce noise at the office as well as when I go shooting so I've tried various brands and solutions over the years.  (And just to be clear, these are not recommended for shooting although they might be an option for .22 caliber that produces about 130 decibels.)These ear filters advertise a 12 decibel reduction which may not sound like a lot, but it actually is when you consider that the decibel scale uses a logarithmic unit.  In other words, 90dB is 10 times louder than 80dB rather than just +10 louder.  So you are getting at least a 10x reduction in audio with these DUBS filters.These filters pop right into my ear with little fuss unlike foam ear plugs.  Of course, everyone has slightly different shaped ears so the fit might slightly vary but based on the numerous reviews here, this fits the vast majority very well.  After wearing these for more than an hour, you might notice slight discomfort but this is really true with every in-the-ear item I've ever worn.  The DUBS filter has some of the least discomfort I've felt in such products so that is good news.  Eventually you just get used to these being in your ear and somewhat forget they are there.Although these can be used at concerts, if you are an audiophile, you may be disappointed in how they do strip away some of the richness of the music.  It's a slight muffling or distortion however vocal are still very crisp and you can still easily have a conversation with these.  I should note that I'd rather have some slight muffling then to having ringing in my ear after the concert.For the record, I tested these with my audio system blasting various genres of tunes (concert simulator).  I also tested this in conversations, with an extremely loud alarm system, and just every day life.PROs=====+ Easily slide into ear with snug fit+ Comfortable+ Vocal audio still clear and crisp+ Nice carrying box+ Doesn't require a batteryCONs=====+ Strips the richness out of musicOverall, I highly recommend these for anywhere you want a general noise reduction but still want to communicate with people or hear various sounds.  To be clear, they won't do magic like selectively eliminating barking dogs or deliver perfectly volume-reduced concert music.  But they will lower the general volume around you with only slight muffling (i.e., not sounding like you are in a tin can).

I don't see many Black & Decker coffee makers these days despite all the sales they do on Amazon, but I do remember several years ago of having an excellent coffee maker from them.  Across the board, their coffee makers are averaging 4+ stars on Amazon.  It's nice to be reminded that they are indeed a force in the coffee maker market.This unit uses a basket style filter (not a cone), and has many of the features you expect for this price range.  Namely, brew strength selector, water window, digital controls, programmable, and auto shut off.  Some notable features it has that you may not find on many other makers is 1-4 cup brew option, even stream shower head, wide-mouth carafe (for easy cleaning), and a display for the amount of time since the coffee was brewed.  Most importantly, though, is the included carafe.  We really like to keep our coffee hot, and with traditional glass coffee pots, we ultimately ended up having to pour the coffee into a carafe anyway.  Now, we can skip that step.The coffee maker has excellent usability, intuitive icons, and easy to use.  The display does not light up however but there is a nice light when the program is set.  The Sneak-A-Cup feature is also very slick as you can pour yourself a cup during brewing.This coffee maker is perfect for those who want less clutter in their kitchen by not needing an extra carafe.  It is also perfect for those who like to keep it simple.  One downside though of the carafe is that you can't brew another pot until you finish the existing pot.  By having an extra carafe, you can pour the pot out and then start another one.  So for households with multiple people that drink a lot of coffee, this maker may not be the best choice unless you buy a separate carafe.  Finally, the maker comes with a 2 year limited warranty.

Offered in three different colors, the Allen Sports JTX-1 is an excellent child jogger or trailer.  The shocks and smooth tires make for a pleasant ride.  The product description says this is a 2-in-1, but I haven't tried the trailer option (no do I plan to).  I only have interest in the jogging option or the stroller option.  Note that there is an option for a front two wheel stroller accessory but I find the front one-wheel included feature perfect for my needs.There are a lot of conveniences as well with the JTX-1: foot brake, front wheel lock (so that it doesn't swivel), push button rear wheel release, three season cover, padded handle, etc.  It would be nice if the cover offered UV protection or if there was a netted version for warmer weather.  For some southern states, our morning temps can get warm quick (but still safe for the baby) so it would be nice to have air and sun protection.I would have like to have seen more storage space for when in stroller mode.  You've seen how big baby bags can be, so it would be nice to be able to hold as much as that.  I know this is primary for jogging, but I love dual purpose items especially for an expensive item like this.Finally, this product is so new that you won't find a product video or manual on the Allen web page.  If interested, keep checking back as I imagine they'll have more info posted soon.

This mouse is highly configurable but in a very easy way as it comes with very intuitive software.On the hardware side, it is very light weight and feels great in the hand.  The cable is a braid, soft material that bends easier than your typical mouse cable and is very resistant to tangles.  Some velcro is included to bundle up the cord when transporting.  The multiple lights on the mouse look slick, and each can be configured to a different color.As for configuring/programming the mouse, the amount of options is staggering.  For starters, you can create different profiles that can easily be switched to and from.  You can also setup macros that it will save.  The macros can include all sorts of traits such as delays, keystrokes, clicks, light color changes, application launches, etc.The DPI is adjustable of course.  And there is a slick option known as "sniper" mode where you can toggle less sensitivity for those sniper moments.If all of this sounds complicated, it's not.  That's a credit to Corsair with their software.  To see the software in action, check out the tutorials on their web site or YouTube by Googling the following keywords: Corsair Gaming SABREAnd although this mouse is designed for gaming, if you run non-gaming software that involves repetitive key/mouse actions, consider this mouse an option to make your life easier.Finally, this doesn't work well with Mac and Linux.  It's a Windows mouse -- but maybe someday they'll expand support

Simple and affordable, this is a budget level food processor.  The container is made of plastic, and it does feel a bit cheap in construction but will likely give you a few years if you take good care of it.  Contains a course/chopping blade plus another dual purpose blade that does grating and slicing.  The dual purpose blade requires you to flip it to alternate between its two modes.Instruction manual is very clear and simple.  It also have a nice trouble shooting section.  I'm new to food processors, so the tips on refrigerating cheese and water-heavy vegetables for 30 minutes beforehand to stiffen them up for the processor was appreciated.  For soft cheeses, it recommends putting them in the freezer for 30 minutes.  Simple tips that I may have not thought of on my own.We are still playing with our processor.  We had a few times where we had to stop the unit and move some of the food around to get it to chop right.  We'll experiment a little more to figure out what we are doing wrong.  Overall though it has done a very good job on many of the recipes we've tried.  We'll update this review as we use it more.

For my taste buds, almost all top brand coconut water tastes good to me.  I did try a side by side taste test with C2O vs Zico (bought from Costco).  The C2O has a slightly sweeter taste, and thus is was no surprise that C2O has 12g of sugar per serving (8oz) compared to Zico's 9g per serving (8oz).  But this can vary -- looking at the Zico on Amazon, it has a serving size of 11.2 ounces with 14g.  Doing that math, that means Amazon's Zico has 10g per serving (8oz).  The amount different is so small that I don't really think about it.  I just buy a reputable brand that is on sale or the cheapest.  If you want a slightly sweeter taste, get C2O over Zico.I do recommend the pure coconut versions over any that have a mixture of fruit in it (i.e., pineapple + coconut). The other fruits overpower the light coconut flavor in my opinion. I also prefer cans over the paper cartons as I like that sturdy feel. I took a star off this review since I think the current price is a tad high.Also, the shipping box used for these was packaged incredibly well.  Thick cardboard separated each can protecting it from dents.

Most badminton sets are "portable" if you do not mind setting up the stakes and have soft ground available.  Setting up a conventional badminton set at the park can take about 5-7 minutes with stakes.  The Zume set can be setup in two minutes -- so just a little time saved.  So really, this Zume set is more convenient for playing on hard surfaces or for cases where no adults are available to setup the net.  And the down side is a less stable net and a less official net.The plastic poles feel cheap and susceptible to bending the first time someone crashes into them.  The racquets also feel cheap and likely to bend/break if accidentally striking the ground or concrete.  Still, the cleverness of the set is impressive.  It is recommended to put a heavy item, perhaps a rock, into the base to weigh it down a little.  Overall the set feels more like it should be priced at $40 rather than $60 at the time of this review.Some of the reviewers have complained that the net is not wide enough.  When setup, it measures roughly 138 inches wide or 11'6".  Regulation is 20 ft for comparison.  This net is for casual fun and not for a official badminton tournament so don't get caught up too much on regulation width.So, buy this set if you don't have soft ground, want children to be able to set it up, playing in compact areas, or only play badminton casually.  I DO NOT recommend this set if you have competitive boys who crash into things as they will likely accidentally destroy this net and the racquets.  There are more rugged options out there -- and yes, they will involved stakes.  Plus a more traditional net is taller reducing the chances that someone will debate you whether the birdie went over or under the net.

This is a bare bones digital scale that gets the job done.  If you don't need all those other measurements such as BMI, body fat, bone mass, etc., then this Taylor scale should be considered.Just stand on the scale and it automatically comes on.  That sounds obvious but a few years ago several digital scales required you to tap the scale first before standing on it which I found annoying.  Once you step off the scale, after a few seconds the scale with automatically shut off meaning it is likely going to be a few years before you have to replace the batteries.Speaking of batteries, the product description on Amazon states that a lithium battery will be included.  Actually, two AAA batteries will be included so I suspect that is a mistake in the description.The scale has a nice clear display, increments in 0.2 intervals, handles up to 400 lbs, and has a 5 year warranty.  Take a look at Amazon's top 20 selling digital scales and then compare it to this one in price, longevity, and features.  Since the digital scale market is very competitive, you'll come away with a great scale one way or another.

I don't know if I am doing something wrong, but I am not getting any extra shine when using this product.  I tried it on laminate flooring as well as ceramic tile.  For comparison, I applied the product to an area next to an area that I cleaned with only water.  After letting the product dry, I could not tell any difference in shine between the Mop&Glo area versus the area cleaned with plain water.  I even tried shining a flashlight at different angles over the Mop&Glo area but still didn't notice any difference.Also, despite having 20/20 vision, reading the back label was very difficult due to the very small font.  There is plenty more space on the back side of the bottle so I am not sure why this company printed such a small label.After reading some of the horror stories here on Amazon about how difficult it can be for people to remove the wax build up, I have to wonder if such a product is worth the trouble.  Combing in my own brief experience with the product with no noticeable shine, I cannot recommend this product.

This is the perfect racket for the table tennis enthusiast as it is priced reasonably yet still offers great features. The level of control from the soft and lightly sticky pad is amazing. And the nice, deep thud the ball makes upon contact contributes to the level of control. Construction is high quality and very solid. Grip is very good although I find the handle a bit small, but consider that I am 6'3" tall. However, every racquet I've tried thus far has a "small" handle.No instructions provided on how to clean the racquet which I find strange. Sure, I can Google for generic cleaning instructions, but I want that info directly from the manufacture. I think I might try water and dish soap. Please comment to this review if that is really a bad idea or if you have a better idea. STIGA sells a rubber wiper but, again, there is no mention of this on the packaging.Finally, note that the back of the packaging warns that this product contains a chemical known to cause cancer in the State of California. I imagine this warning is talking about formaldehyde. The note says to wash your hands after using, but there is a sticker above the warning reading, "California 93120 Compliant formaldeyde" so take that for whatever it is worth. The warning is a bit concerning so I play it safe and wash my hands afterwards.No carrying case provided to my surprise but STIGA sells a nice $6 case separately.

For the price, these are solid training gloves.  They also fit very well for my size -- I'm 205lbs and 6'3 in height. The stitching and workmanship all seem very solid, but let's see what they look like in six months.  The gloves are easy for me to put on and pull off, and the strap is designed in such a way that I can unfasten them while wearing the other glove.  The strap also has a wide and long band of velcro on it -- these are not going to come loose.Immediately after opening, I examined the gloves for loose threads or other manufacturing defects.  None detected.  I did notice that the tip of the thumb has a piece of leather connecting it to the glove I assume to restrict movement so the thumb doesn't get bent backwards.  On another pair of gloves I have, that strap is much further down the glove allowing the thumb to move a little more than this pair.  I'm not sure which is better but I wanted to point that out since none of the pictures on the product page show this.I've tested these gloves on a punch bag and they felt excellent by dampening the blow.  However, I am not an aspiring boxer (or a boxer, period) so I am just giving the average Joe opinion here.  I use the gloves to do basic self defense training and to get a workout.  The only minor complaint I have is that my hands started getting warm when wearing the gloves.  In other words, there isn't much ventilation that I could find but this could be normal.I look forward to seeing if these gloves can hold up.  If I notice some premature wear and tear, I'll be sure to update this review.

I open the product, and the setup was rather intuitive and simple.  To my surprise, no instruction pamphlet or page was included.  Instead, instructions are briefly printed on the side of the box.  The full instructions are on the web (http://us.focusrite.com/get-started/itrack-pocket).  For quick instructions, though, I found the instructions on the box rather lacking.  For example, my friend and I debated for a few minutes as to the purpose of the red light.  We thought it was indicating good audio rather than clipping.  A better solution would be a label next to the light reading "Clip" or mentioning this on the quick instructions would have been helpful.  The good news is that the full instructions and the introduction video online are done very well.For some of our initial recordings, we were getting a small amount of background static.  This went away when we picked some different amps, but according to the online troubleshooting (aka Answerbase), we should have been in airplane mode to reduce interference from Bluetooth and perhaps Wi-Fi.  The four amp options, by the way, are "none", V-AC, Brit, and Twin.The iTrack software is slick and pretty straightforward as well.  Our biggest complaint is that some of the fonts are really small and the buttons could also be larger.  We also had trouble turning the virtual knobs (e.g., reverb).  If anyone knows the secret to consistently getting those controls past the midway point, please provide a comment to this review.  Also, be warned that if your iPhone has a case it will likely not fit on the iTrack stand until you remove the case.  But know that you do not have to necessarily put your phone on the iTrack so that shouldn't be a deal breaker.Overall, this product does what is says it does -- and it does it pretty well.  Guitar recording is very clean and vocal recording is adequate for a quick tune.  If you are on the fence, check out the video at the link I posted near the top of my review as it has a seven minute video that goes over the product in better detail than the video on this Amazon product page.  You can also read the manual at that same site in multiple languages and/or play with the free app from the iTunes store (search for "Focusrite by iTrack") if you are curious about some of the more advanced features.

Up front, at this price range (roughly $40), you can find other hand crank radios on Amazon that include solar power, weather radio, and cell phone charging options.  Furthermore, other hand crank radios have digital tuner which makes tuning easier and more accurate.On the plus side, this guy is small and has a loud speaker for its size.  The speaker though becomes distorted at half way up on the volume.  Controls are intuitive and ergonomics are good.  With one minute of cranking, you get up to 10 min of radio and up to 30 minutes of flashlight.  The light is not that bright, and it does not cast a well distributed light.  Hand crank is similar to other hand crank radios -- somewhat cheap and could be broken by a child cranking too hard.  Included instructions are very well written and clearly explain each feature.Skip this radio.  At this price range and for emergency situations you need more features and better features.  I value this radio at $10.

This is my first premium racquet, and I can now see why the more skilled players have these.  The level of control from the soft and lightly stick pad is amazing.  And the nice, deep thud the ball makes upon contact contributes to the level of control. Construction is high quality and very solid.  Grip is very good although I find the handle a bit small, but consider I am 6'3" tall.  Every racquet I've tried thus far has a "small" handle.No instructions provided on how to clean the racquet which I find very strange.  Sure, I can Google for generic cleaning instructions, but I want that info directly from the manufacture.  I think I might try water and dish soap.  Please comment to this review if that is really a bad idea or if you have a better idea.  STIGA sells a rubber wiper but, again, there is no mention of this on the Pro Carbon packaging.The back of the packaging warns that this product contains a chemical known to cause cancer in the State of California.  I imagine this warning is talking about formaldehyde.  The note says to wash your hands after using, but there is a sticker above the warning reading, "California 93120 Compliant formaldeyde" so take that for whatever it is worth.No carrying case provided to my surprise but STIGA sells a nice $6 case separately.

I've now owned an Oral-B tooth brush for two years, and there is no going back to regular toothbrushes. The thoroughness of how these clean and how smooth your teeth feel afterwards will convince you after using it the first time.Using this toothbrush is intuitive and easy. You set the mode you want and guide the head to the targeted area. You brush each area for about two minutes, and then the toothbrush buzzes to signal that you should move to the next area. When you are done, you rinse the toothbrush and place it back on the stand. And you can share the toothbrush by giving family members each their own head. Oral-B provides colored bands for each head so you can tell the heads apart.Charging this device is very easy and kid friendly due to it using inductive (wireless) charging. You can easily go a few days before needing to charge again, but for simplicity, I just put it back on the stand after every brush.Now, about the new feature. We are now getting to the point where more and more products are trying to integrate with the web or smart phone. In this case, I'm not so sure it is worth it. I see my dentist every six months, and they tell me already where I need to do a better job. This toothbrush isn't smart enough to compete with my dentist and my dental hygienist -- at least not yet. If this toothbrush told me that tartar was building up in certain sports or could clearly tell me which spots I was missing, then it would be much more useful. The best use I can think of for the smartphone feature is if you wanted to monitor your children to see how well they were doing. Other than that, it is kind of a fluff feature.If Oral-B were to make any improvements, I'd like to see a version of the toothbrush that doesn't allow for gunk to get inside it which then runs down the body of the brush. I have to clean my toothbrush about every 1-3 months. To reduce the amount of gunk, I've learned that if I keep the toothbrush running while holding it under running water helps. Further, don't just clean the head -- clean the entire tip otherwise gunk runs down past the brush head. I'd also like to see a better solution for cleaning a person's tongue. The small head struggles in that department so I keep a traditional style toothbrush around for that job.In the end, I love Oral-B toothbrushes, and I have even have bought some for other people as gifts. If I had to start all over, I would simply just get the Oral-B PRO 3000 and put the extra money into more heads. However, if you have people in your house that have sensitive gums or if you want to monitor how often and for how long children are brushing, then the 5000 is a very good choice.

Note this product never mentions if it is specifically for women, so this test is being done on a male's face (that's me). Further, I've never used a mask on my face before so I am coming into this test fresh.In the short time I've been testing this, I've been only applying it to the left half of my face. After about three applications, I've noticed no difference between the left and the right side of my face. This includes monitoring my pores, skin tone, wrinkles, etc. I'll keep testing and report back.The clay smells slightly minty (even though mint isn't present) combined with smells similar to lotion products. I find the smell pleasant. The texture does feel clay like and it quickly dries on your face after applying it. I don't plan on getting it on my clothes but the manufacture states it can stain clothing.
