And there is a slight tingle sensation shortly after applying the mask.Removing the mask is slightly more tedious than I thought it would be. It takes me several rinses to get all the gray residue off. But I can live with this if the product works.The manufacture also states you should avoid the sun while using this product and for a week afterwards. This is due to the product containing alpha hydroxy acid (AHA). I've been wearing sun screen to counter this affect.For now, the jury is still out so I'm giving this four stars for now. If I do not start seeing results soon, I'll drop the rating.

We are a big video gaming family, and it seems our boys are frequently on an X-box 360, smartphone, our tablet playing away.  However rarely are they playing educational games so I was happy to see this Leap Frog system.  The challenge though is how to make educational games fun so the kids stayed engaged.Setup was pretty straight forward even for non-technical people.  Thus far I have only used the quick setup guide but there is another more in-depth manual I'll be looking at here soon.  The hardest part is with lighting as other reviewers have noted.  The camera requires a lot more light than say an Xbox Kinnect.  We had to turn on all the lights at night time plus bring a floor lamp over to the area to help out.Navigation on the screen is a breeze and intuitive for children and adults.  They also use large fonts and, often, use instructional voice prompts to assist.  Although our kids followed a lot of the instructions well, they couldn't always figure things out so having a parent around initially will certainly help.  Case in point is getting the child to position himself in front of the camera so that his body fills the calibration silhouette.  Our four-year old bent his body down instead of moving backwards to get the video setup phase to pass.The controller is easy to operate on has less buttons than a standard video game controller.  This is perfect for keeping it simple for kids.  The controller, though, feels a little flimsy so I'm hoping it can withstand abuse from kids.  Thankfully the controls are cheaper than most video game controllers.Game play is designed to get kids in motion which is great for the over-weight epidemic in the USA.  Many games integrate the kids on the TV which really gets kids exited and laughing.  The Xbox Kinect has games that do this as well but the Leap Frog system is designed from ground up to be for kids and to be educational.LeapFrog supports Internet connection which can then report statistics back to the company.  From there, after you register at their site, you'll get some reports about how your child is doing.  This feature looks promising.We'll report back here shortly on how our kids are doing.  We also might order the Spiderman game so they have a "cool" but still educational game to play.

Diono does a great job on the Amazon page here describing all the features so I'm just going to append to that my own observations.I was pleased to see all the padding and the memory foam seat as we are the kind of family that often makes six-hour drives. Our kids don't regularly complain about the other car seats but it is nice to see Diono trying to make the seat as comfortable as possible.Even though Diono advertises this seat as having a thinner profile, just know that it still is rather heavy likely due to the steal frame. And as you can see from some of the negative reviews, people with different vehicles have had different results with this seat. That's just a reminder to be prepared to keep the packing box in good shape in case you need to return it.In hindsight, I think I am leaning more towards having two car seats for a child as they grow up instead of this style of the Diono Rainier. So one seat for the infant phase and then one for the non-infant phase. Why? Because I think I prefer the type of car seat that acts as a carrier as well and/or can be plopped into a stroller. It just seems easier especially for when an infant is already sleeping when you are ready to pull the baby out of the vehicle. Although eventually buying two car seats might be more expensive, at least you don't have the costs of buying a separate carrier. I prefer convenience and space saving over this all-phase Diono Rainier.Still, the Diono Rainier is a great car seat if you don't mind having an extra carrier on board for infants.

Finally a good screen protector for the Edge Plus! We tried a few of them (some generic, as well as the  Skinomi TechSkin ) and even tempered glass ones, but the amFilm is the way to go. It is perfectly cut, and it installs without any bubbles (not even one!) The Edge Plus screen is fantastic, and this protector does not change that one bit. Highly recommended!

The intent was to use this receiver with some older speakers. What attracted me to this particular one was the decent price and the micro-usb power source (my receiver has a power usb out and hence it could also turn on/off the bluetooth receiver).The receiver is very compact, and it paired rather easily. The problem is very, very poor range.  Music would be very choppy between 4ft and 8ft, and it would completely cut out at about 8ft or so. Also, even if within the OK range, just siting in front of the phone (the source) would render the sound very choppy.I tried my older Amazon Basics Receiver and that one had no such issues. As such, this receiver is not working as intended, and a $2 cable could replace it if the working range is less than 4ft. So 1 star it is then...

We were very active in our kitchen before and eat very healthy, but we were still purchasing a few of processed items (healthy, but processed nonetheless). Since switching to Paleo we completely eliminated processed foods, and this has opened new opportunities for us. One of these is making our own chocolate and other cacao treats. So we purchased Navitas Naturals Cacao Butter and Certified Organic Raw Cacao Powder and made our own chocolate, nutella, avocado chocolate mousse, Paleo bars, etc. But it seems as they needed a bit of pizzazz...Enter the Viva Labs Cacao Nibs! These things are great! The crunch! The taste! The flavor! Outstanding! And no, I have not received them for free in exchange for a review. Nope. This is how good they are! And just for a bit forget about how healthy these things are for you; all I am saying is: pizzazz, welcome!We have since used them in all the above mentioned treats, we added them to hot chocolate, to the kids' "cereals", and to other beverages. We have used regular cacao powder in the past, but these nibs just give them that "je new sais quoi". And they are even good the way they are, so we just sneak a teaspoon once in a while...This past weekend my kids wanted a quick chocolate fix, so I made them my version of Mexican chocolate: a few cacao nibs, a touch of raw honey, just enough cacao butter, and a hint of cinnamon, all crushed for about a minute in my mortar - I had to make another one of course! And then another one, but this time I skipped the cinnamon and added a couple of roasted hazelnuts for my lovely wife: oh boy! Let's call it rustic nutella, or whatever you want, but it was definitely delicious. And of course I had to make another one... Note to self: next time double the quantities...Needless to say, highly recommended for their taste, crunchiness, flavor, and value.

I have purchased this coconut oil for its price. This oil was at the time of my purchase a very good value at less than 40 cents per ounce, or 50 bucks for the 128 ounces container. After reading all the reviews I was expecting a very good oil in a pretty hard to open container. I found the exact opposite...The container is extremely easy to open. After receiving it I was expecting to have to cut the entire lid. Before I started doing so I just took a flat screwdriver and I was able to pry the rid right off. I put the lid back on and then took a few pictures, this time with cutting a bit from the lid as instructed on the lid - see all the pictures I posted. After taking the bag out, I just cut the bottom and the entire content just slid into the container effortlessly. A bit of oil remained in the bag, but that was pretty insignificant and I was able to warm it up a bit and squeezed it in the container. I maybe lost a few pesky drops that didn't want to come out of that bag.The problem that I have is the taste. This oil is not very good. Maybe we have been spoiled by extremely good oils - we tried a few and settled on the Nature's Way Extra Virgin Organic Coconut Oil which is about 55 cents per ounce. The Nature's Way is creamy (at same ambient temperature) and the taste is just perfect, as it smells like fresh coconuts. This one, the Native Forest, has a different texture, almost glassy (it doe not scoop as nicely as the other one) and it smells too toasty, almost rubbery or plasticky... While I can easily take a spoonful of the Nature's Way the way it is, I cannot do so with the Native Forest...I wish I could have tried a smaller quantity before committing to such a big container. But it is what it is now, and we use this one as moisturizer, hair treatment, etc. and reserve the honors for ingesting to the Nature's Way. For the price it was a pretty good value, but now that the price is up I probably won't buy it again.

When in need of organic spices, we always look at Frontier first. This one does not disappoint at all. On the contrary, this cinnamon is very very good, with a nice taste and rich flavor. To top it all off, it is organic, non irradiated, and without coumarin. Highly recommended.

I recently rewired my entire house. I needed a few connectors, and I thought that a trip to the local HD would solve that. Imagine my surprise when I saw that they charge 10 bucks for 25 connectors! I actually placed the order on Amazon right from the store: 100 connectors for less than 5 bucks! Great value for a pretty good product.
I recently rewired my entire house, and had to lengthen some wires in the process. This was a very inexpensive way to achieve that.

This is a good can opener. We bought it about 2 months ago and has performed very well during this period. It works pretty easy and it leaves a pretty smooth edge. No rust yet.Two things I am no so happy with: the cutting wheel developed a small dent, and the handle (probably hollow) has a dent as well (we keep it in a drawer with other utensils and tools).

A friend recommended this for our kids a while back, and we got it from iHerb. While it might be good, we avoided giving it to our kid, as it contains 3 ingredients that I would avoid:- xanthan gum. While deemed somewhat safe, there are some worries with feeding it to infants, and they seem to relate to the development of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in infants.- potassium sorbate. It is a skin, eye and respiratory irritant, but the worst is that it is deemed to be toxic to human DNA, basically causing damage in DNA.- sodium benzoate. This is pretty nasty. It seems to deprives cells of oxygen at DNA cellular level. The biggest issue is that when combined with vitamin C (also found in this vitamin) it produces benzene! It might produce levels below those considered dangerous for consumption, but I did not want to risk it with my kid.I am no chemist or scientist, but these put enough doubt in my mind not to use it.
I am impressed. We used to have some headphones that came with a couple of older phones (HTC) and they were OK, but these headphones blows them out of the water! Very inexpensive, but very good.

I really like Simple Mills mixes. Their concoctions are very good, and we always get good results. This is no different. The bread is pretty decent, and the focaccia as well. Maybe a bit too sweet. Whoever is expecting this to be EXACTLY like regular bread or focaccia should reconsider their expectations.As always, Paleo mixes are expensive, and this one is no exception. They are not extremely hard to reproduce (and there are plenty of recipes online), and lately we have been experimenting with our own organic ingredients with great success.

We used to get Bob's Mill tapioca, but when I found this organic one I jumped on it. We use it for our Paleo baking mostly, as it adds a bit of elasticity to certain doughs.Recently though we have been making Kabalagala (plantain or banana fritters) - mix the tapioca starch with smashed plantain and fry it in coconut oil. I used to love fried dough, and this is very close - very good, but different :) Recipe from Michelle Tam's Nom Nom Paleo
I am using this splitter to be able to use my Amazon bluetooth receiver for listening to Pandora and split the signal between my Creative Roar and my older Cambridge Soundworks PortaPack.
This was an inexpensive way to provide Bluetooth capabilities for my older desktop. The adapter has been working without any issues for the past few months now. I hope it will last...

My wife is a professor, and she received a smaller Dell laptop from the university that has only a mini display port. This adapter was an inexpensive way to provide her with the ability to use some newer projectors (with HDMI) for her presentations. The adapter has been working well for about a semester now. I hope it last...

This is a good splitter and a very good value. I got it when needing to provide power to a new PCI USB3 card. The splitter is a bit short, so I got this Extension Cable as well. The combo worked great for me.
This is a good cable and very good value. I installed a new PCI USB3 card and the power splitter they provided was too short. This one solved my problem.

This is very good. We started using this years ago (we used to get it from iHerb. Amazon has now the best price) when we decided we need to say goodby to those chemical spills they call detergent. Absolutely no regrets. And we have two young boys (7.5 and 5.5 years old)...

We have been using this for about 5 years now - this is one of the best. I personally prefer the MIU solid turner. If I have to choose which turner/spatula to use, that is the one that I would get. This one is very good too, but it is not without issues: the handle will melt easily, so it would have been much better with wooden handles.For outdoor cooking activities, get the Winco TN48 = a versatile beast.

I have been using this for about 5 years now - this is the one. If I have to choose which turner/spatula to use, this is the one that I would get. But it is not without issues: the handle will melt easily, so it would have been much better with wooden handles. For the price I paid (under 7 bucks) this is a great value.For outdoor cooking activities, get the Winco TN48 = a versatile beast.

I have been using this spatula for about 3 years now. It is great. This is a rigid spatula, and very sturdy, so I use it for burgers, steak, fish, getting pizza out of the oven, pancakes, slap something, I don't know, anything. Handle has been solid, but I always wash it by hand (we decided to take the dishwasher out and use that space for something else, so I AM the dishwasher anyway). I even use it to scrape my stainless griddle I have on one of my grills - perfect.I also have a couple of the flexible spatulas, but this on is the one that I always reach for. So I recently just bought another one. It is so versatile, that if I would have to choose between all my spatulas, this one will probably win (although for indoor cooking the MIU solid spatula almost perfection...Happy cooking!

I am using this puppy with a Plugable USB 3.0 to 10/100/1000 Gigabit Adapter, two Plugable USB 3.0 to VGA / DVI / HDMI, a keyboard and a mouse as a "docking station" for my wife's laptop for when she is working home. It works great and haven't had any issues for months now. Hope it will last, because as we know: "happy wife = happy life", and I like my happy life...
No noticeable difference in range or signal power for my Asus RT-N66U. I missed the return window, so now I can use them as swords and fight with my kids...

This adapter works very good. I paired it with the Amazon USB3 hub and two Plugable USB 3.0 to VGA / DVI / HDMI and created a "docking station" for my wife's tiny laptop so she can work when home. It has been working fine for the past few months, but it doesn't see a lot of use though. Hope it will last.

These are very good. After converting to a Paleo lifestyle we started using dates in our baking. We tried a few brands and got these ones because they were organic and pitted. They are very sweet - maybe a little bit too sweet, as a couple of our recipes came out very sweet, so we might need to use less.We got them for about 17 bucks which makes them a great value (they are identical with these ones. When I bought them I accidentally had in my cart the Sincerely Nuts Medjool Dates, and those were about 13 bucks. When I received the Sincerely Nuts ones I saw they were not even organic, and we realized that if subtract the weight of the pits they would probably be double in price when compared to these (those came moldy too - we just threw them away).BTW, a recipe we found and came to love: search for "Grain Free Pecan Sticky Date Cake" by Peachy Palate - out of this world!

I use this for my griddle (I have a large stainless one that I put on my grill whenever we feel like eating, well, good stuff). This scraper is perfect for cleaning the griddle of all the gooey-sticky-burnt stuff that's left after cooking on it.I got two of them actually to replace the two I had for about 2 years - replace them not because they are bad, but because they are so good I used them during my basement remodeling for spackling, or for cleaning thinset from the tiles, and many more...

Decent bag, still looks good after a few months of daily use. I got it for my wife's 13" laptop, and she loves it, especially the fact that she can load it with more stuff in those front pockets (it seems her bag is not enough for the lifting weights she carries with her). But what do I know... maybe only that "happy wife = happy life", and I like my happy life...

Last year we started looking to get a portable speaker. So we have tried: JBL Charge 2, Sony SRSX3, Oontz XL, Creative Sound Blaster Roar, Bose SoundLink III, and Sharkk BoomBox. Each have their pluses and minuses. We bought the Sony first, and when we decided we didn't really like it, we got the Roar. We ended up keeping the Roar. I wish I tried UE boom and Bose SoundLink Mini as well, but I got tired of searching for a better one... We also got a pretty good deal on the Roar (a little over 120 bucks), so we might be sticking with it for a while...I never had all these speakers at once in my house, as we ended up returning them after comparing them individually to the one we had in the house - the Roar. So I cannot really comment on how they all compare, just how they compare against the Roar mostly.I am not too sold on this Sharkk. In fact it was not that good. I believe it was much weaker than the others we tried, but definitely much worse than the Roar. The sound is not impressive at all, actually is not even decent. It is loud, if that's what you are looking for, but it has very, very hollow with very limited range. For the price it might be the best option (although it is my understanding that they started at about 40 bucks or so and kept raising the price since (look on camelcamelcamel for price history). At $40 I would say it would be a great value, but at the price I paid (70) I was not impressed. I cannot even comment on the battery life - the sound it created was so disappointing when compared to the Roar that I just packed it back in the box and sent it back...

2 of these puppies plugged in the Amazon USB3 hub and voila: dual 24" monitors for my lovely wife's free-work-provided-miniature-crappy-no-hdmi-port  Dell laptop. Or, three monitors for my free-work-provided-huge-still-crappy-still-no-hdmi-port Dell laptop.They have been working perfectly for the past few months, but not on a continuous basis. I hope they last, because these puppies are expensive!

This is pretty good tahini. We used to get the Achva Tahini. The Kevala seems a bit runnier, which makes it easier to work with. Flavor is very good, but I cannot really decide between the two, maybe the Achva was a bit more intense, while the Kevala a bit more subtle.We use it exclusively for our Paleo cauliflower hummus, and it is delicious. I love traditional hummus, while my wife was crazy about the Eat Well Enjoy Life yellow lentil hummus. Since I adopted a Paleo lifestyle I started making the cauliflower hummus. My wife, the naysayer, hated the idea, but after trying it she is a convert too, and her Enjoy Life hummus pretty much enjoyed a slow and moldy death in the fridge...

Since we got them, I was able to smell the roses, the sky, the grass, the monsters, the Angry birds, Steve from minecraft, and many, many other. They all smell very good (Steve surprised me a bit). They all smell a bit expensive, but good nonetheless. For an inexpensive but equally flavorful fragrance experience we also got Mr Sketch

Frontier is the first brand I look for when searching for spices etc. and this one does not disappoint. It does not have the subtlety of Hungarian paprika (it is not Hungarian after all) but this is extremely good, all natural, it is fresh with tons of flavor and superb smokiness. It would have been nice to be organic. We also use a lot of Frontier organic paprika which is highly recommended too.It is very, very good value as well.

We initially got a Hobart 500521R 125 EZ - a very good simple to use welder. But when realized that we will also weld stainless we got this one instead. This is a very good welder. I use it around the house every time I have the chance, and never skipped a bit. I actually got a refurbished one from Hobart for a little under 250 bucks - a great value for a welder that looks, feels and acts as new.Highly recommended

It came in a pretty bit up box, but the unit was pristine and looked as new. This welder is pretty easy to use, with very limited controls (just material thickness selector). The welding was very good, maybe just once or so a bit inconsistent, but it might have been the wire... We ended up getting a Handler 125 MIG Ready to be able to use it for stainless as well.

My kids (7.5 and 5.5) are into these books, so we got them the entire series. They get a kick out of them every time they read them, and they reach for them pretty often.It is hard to rank which one is the best - I think they all provide some good jokes/facts, and some not so good.

My kids (7.5 and 5.5) are into these books, so we got them the entire series.It is hard to rank which one is the best - I think they all provide some good jokes/facts, and some not so good. But the kids get a kick out of them every time they read them, and they reach for them pretty often.

My kids (7.5 and 5.5) are into these books. We got them the entire series. It is hard to rank which one is the best - I think they all provide some good jokes/facts, and some not so good. But the kids get a kick out of them every time they read them, and they reach for them pretty often.

Good inexpensive stripper. I wired my entire house with Cat5e and this stripper along with Cat connectors and a TRENDnet tool was all I needed. I also made my own custom length wires. It will probably not be in a pro's bag, but it is perfect for my occasional needs.

Fits very well the G pad 8.3. Very good access to ports. It also provides the wake-up feature if desired. This is for the kids' G pads, and those have seen their share of abuse and drops. The cover protects them pretty well. The only complain they have is that this case does not allow them to play Angry Birds Telepods. Well, tough luck...
Works great 5 months later. I got it with an Inateck PCI card to have a couple of front USB3. The combo provides good read-write speeds.For the price (less than 10 bucks) this is a great value too.

The card works very well, at good speeds. I installed the Anker front panel hub as well (ASIN: B00J4EZE4U), and that one connects to this card and works without any issues.The included power cables (needed) were useless thought as they are too short. Nonetheless, this is an inexpensive way of adding a bunch of USB3 ports. Hope it will last too...

We believe this mix is almost spot on. The pancakes are really good. Mix it with egg and some oil (we use either coconut or ghee) and you are good to go. The taste is great for a Paleo product. It is NOT however the regular pancake taste, as the coconut is pretty easily identifiable. Mouth feel is a bit different too, as they will have a bit of a grainy texture. But, my kids (8 and 6) are now demanding I make them these pancakes instead of the regular ones, so "On The Go Paleo" hits the right spot. And we were not expecting them to be exactly like the regular pancakes either.But it is bit on the expensive side. You need 1/3 cup of the mix, 1 egg, 1/2TBS oil and 3 TBS milk to make three 4" pancakes, or at least that's what they promise. I always double the quantity and I get 4 pancakes (maybe just a tad over 4"), so the entire package should yield 28 pancakes. But when I put 1/3 cup of mix on my trusted scale, it told me it is a little over 40g, not 34g as specified. So the package has in fact almost 12 servings x 2 pancakes = 24 pancakes. But this is nitpicking...Still, I have to recommend this mix as one of the better ones. But as always, we are trying to make our own mix now (for a fraction of the cost).

These ottomans are pretty good quality compared to others in the price range (and I tried a few). They arrive completely assembled. The little ones fit inside the large ottoman, and do not have any storage themselves. This is a bit of bad design for two reasons: it would have provided additional storage even if they are fairly small; it would have provided some additional rigidity as they are the weakest link in this set - when I put my 185lbs on one of them it almost caved in (if you read the reviews for other colors you'll find out that they break pretty fast.) Also from those reviews I found out that the lid handles from the large one will eventually come out or break, and some people even cut them from the beginning to eliminate those floppy things...So while they have very good stitching, they seem well constructed and the materials used seem pretty good in quality, we ended up returning them. Why? Because the color is completely off! We bought two of them and both were the same purplish gray, almost with brown tones. Very strange color. We liked them and wanted to keep them and stop this searching madness, but the color is not the gray pictured.

I bought this fan about 3 years ago. It has been working great for me. My original review went under the VenTech IF6 fan, but this is the one that I received (Amazon either recycled the ASIN or something else happened...)I made the mistake of building my own kitchen island, and our cooktop is on it. I have vaulted ceiling so I thought the best option is to route my exhaust through the floor. Now, I could have bought a downdraft unit, but noooo, I had to build my own... (well, to my defense, the island design would have made that downdraft installation almost impossible, as it is a two-level island). So I bought this puppy and ducted my own exhaust with the Speedi-Products EX-WCHD 06 wall cap (ASIN: B0085KZOQW, btw, a great wall cap - I just glued a washer to the damper to stay closed better.)Take note that this fan can get loud as it gets busy at sucking the food out of the pan when I'm cooking something... So I tried slowing it down a bit. Amazon's matchdotcom engine mates this with SE Electronic Stepless Speed Controller, but I don't know about you, but I don't really like that thing hanging on my newly remodeled kitchen's glass-tile-with-natural-stone-and-sweat-and-tears-and-a-piece-of-my-finger-backsplash. I also tried a regular Home Depot-purchased ceiling fan controller (this fan is not drawing a lot of amperage), but there it was, the unavoidable hum. I tried another type (forgot what type) and it worked just as an on-off switch. Then I tried it with the Leviton 6637-PW (ASIN: B000U3HXF2) and it works perfectly! Excellent speed control rated for 5-Amps too (much more than the fan's 1A)! Designed for this type of motors! Fully adjustable (the top and bottom of the slide action)! It can work as a 3-way fan control as well! It looks excellent! It integrates perfectly with our other Decora (or something-something) switches! It can cook diner! It can wash and put the kids to bed! BUT IT IS BLOODY EXPENSIVE!!!But I digress... this is an excellent fan, and if you can slow it down a bit, it is golden. It has been working for 3 years now, and it is so efficient at removing the food odors out of the house, that I have the neighbors complaining about my mouth-watering cooking odors now... Oh well, you can't win...The mounting bracket can be a pain, as it is very short and provides no access from the fan side to screw or bolts you might use. So I needed to have this fan bolted to a 1.5"x1.5"x16" piece of wood and screwed that one into a joist in my crawlspace. Well, of course it vibrated. So I put some foam (2 pieces I cut from one of those interlocking mats) between the bracket and the piece of wood, and between the piece of wood and the joist. Better, but still some vibration can be felt through the floor upstairs. So I replaced about 1 foot of the solid duct for both inlet and outlet with flexible aluminum duct (the more rigid one) and I cut two 6" pieces of strap from an old ratchet tie-down, screwed the ends of the side of the joist, and screwed the piece of wood to the middle of it, so basically with the fan left dangling about 1/2" from  the joist. VOILA! No vibration!Anyway, I have installed a filter that fit perfectly my two-level kitchen island - do a search for Broan filter 97015843 or Broan RMDD4804 (this is the hood that uses this filter) and look at the pictures in the search results (they were about $100 for a pair, but I used only one and kept the other one for when I (if ever) selling the house). I installed tile on that small backsplash and used the Kerdi corners around the tile, which are almost identical to the filter's edge material. At full force the air movement through filter is very loud!Now, the downdraft is not as efficient (in general, not this particular one), and I noticed that when used at high RPM, it "tilts" or sucks the fire a bit (I have gas stovetop) towards the intake. So, the plan include now moving this fan into the attic with a new glass or stainless intake mounted on the cathedral ceiling (basically an island hood with all the "guts" removed and cut to install flush with the ceiling, or built from scratch to look like a Best Cirrus CC34E6SB, or a Gaggenau Vario AC402, or a Futuro Futuro Skylight IS54SKYLIGHT, or my own design) = yet another project!

This is a great shower head. Very inexpensive, but very good quality.Things I like:The quality is very good. The chrome is spotless (and I got two of them, both work and look perfect.) It also looks very good. In fact, I have in my bathroom all Hansgrohe and Grohe fixtures and in all honesty this is very much up there (I have tried a Hansgrohe shower head and I actually like this one better.)It is very light (this is all plastic) and easy to maneuver because of this. There are positive stops for the function selector which will click when in each position. The selector works very good and there are no leaks from the nozzles that are not used.The chrome finish cleans pretty easily, easier than my old shower head, and I believe easier than my Hansgrohe and Grohe fixtures (my bath is finished about 3 months ago, so all my fixtures are new - age cannot be a factor here.)For me is not that important, but they came in a very nice black box with good padding and protection.OK, so it looks good and it came in a nice box, but does it work well? YES. We like it! We used to have one shower head that would concentrate all water in just a few very fine nozzles and would spray in a pretty narrow pattern. Because of it, the skin would hurt, and instead of a shower I would feel like I was at an acupuncture session! I could actually hear my skin cry! This Lordear is so much gentler and wider, without sacrificing pressure. It has 54 nozzles used for the shower function, and probably because of it it feels more like a rain shower. The other shower head it replaced had less nozzles but probably with a bigger diameter so it always felt like the water pressure was never good enough. The Lordear is feels much better in this case as well, and even though this shower head is gentler I do not have the feeling that it is underpowered, making pretty good use of my fairly low water pressure (about 40psi or less.) In both installations I removed the pressure regulator / filter (the orange piece in the picture - very easy to remove), but I did not notice a drastic difference in water flow with it installed.Things I don't like:OK, so it looks good, it came in a nice box, and it works well. But is it perfect then? Not really. For starters this is a pretty large shower head (not the whole thing, just the spraying part), and pretty flat. As such, it feels a bit awkward when using it. Maybe I was too used to the old one, and it is just a matter of getting used to this one now. But, I cannot detract any stars here as I it is advertised as a 4inch shower head, and it is very light and pretty maneuverable as such. And the spray pattern is nice and wide.Also, I know maybe it's just me, but it would have been nice to have the middle function as the rain shower. We never use the massage function (which is in fact not the best, as it doesn't pulsate - it just concentrate the water in the middle 10 nozzles), so we have to keep the selector at all times all the way to the left (and it goes about 40 degrees or so). We knew about this from one of the product images (and product construction required probably to have the middle function as the one that combines the other two), but in my opinion it would have been nicer. To be honest, we would have liked this shower head with just one function - the rain shower - and as such, no selector.Finally, more nitpicking - the handle is very square. It is easier to hold the shower head at a desired angle because of it, but it would have been nicer to have the handle maybe tapered and more rounded towards the hose connection. It would have looked much better and more cohesive with our shower bar, or any shower holders as I have not seen a lot of then square.  But again, I know about it from the picture so I cannot take any stars here as well.Nonetheless, none of these detract from the fact that this is a great shower head, and a very good value (we paid about 15 bucks for each.) Highly recommended!

Very good. My wife uses it to take soup for lunch. We don't even prep it with hot water before filling it, as she said the soup is still too hot at lunch, and she needs to either leave it for 20 minutes or so in it to let it cool or dump it in a different bowl to cool it faster. The lid with the spoon from the 16oz one fits perfectly. We also got the RSVP Endurance 18/8 Stainless Steel Canning Funnel (ASIN: B0000DE4FN) to fill it without a mess.The only thing we don't like is the internal cap, which is still plastic, and will touch the food is not held completely upright.

This is indeed a very quiet fan. Even at full 150CFM. This quietness is a great feature, but can be a detriment too: my lovely wife had to make me aware that certain noises are now easier to hear from outside of the bathroom now! Well, I guess you can't have it all...Anyway, there are a few issues that you need to be aware of:#1First of all, the picture on Amazon's website is not the correct one (see the picture I uploaded). They show the FV-05-11VKSL1 model that has a 4 inch or 6 inch connection. The FV-11-15VKL1 model has only a 6 inch connection, so if you have a 4 inch duct you need to get a 6 to 4 inch reduction. You might get into some issues with a reduction, as explained below under #3.#2Installation wise - the instruction manual has a pretty good number of pages on explaining how to to install this fan in a new construction. And then just a page on how to do a retrofit. It is lacking here some information that I believe it is of importance - the fact that the housing splits in two parts. This is actually useful info to know even when you have access from above.If you use this in a new construction, just follow the instructions in the manual (easy to install before the drywall is up). However, in a retrofit things are a bit different for one major reason: you cannot insert this fan through the hole in the ceiling (the electrical junction box as well as the exhaust connection protrude significantly.) This fan can be fully installed from below IF (I repeat), only IF you can take the old fan out from below. Makes sense, but in my case I was out of luck, as the wise guys that built my house 30 years ago never thought that maybe, just maybe, one might need to replace that junk they put up there...Also, this fan is a little larger, so you might need to cut a bit of the drywall. After the hole is prepared, the support system can be installed from underneath through the hole (it bends in such way that you can get it up easily). It needs to have the two supporting brackets at the edge of the hole (placed directly on the drywall), as the fan will have to be bolted onto it. There is another issue here: if you have strapping on your ceiling (like I had) you will not be able to screw this system into the joists as instructed, as the screw holes will be too low. But there are other holes that you can use (not ideal, as the ones they recommend would have provided more rigidity to the entire support system).As mentioned above, the housing splits in two sections (the galvanized part with the electrical box and duct connection slides up and separates from the housing) - see the picture I uploaded. These are held together by one machine screw inside the fan housing. There are also 2 electrical connections between this two sections that need to be disconnected. After splitting, you can do the electrical and connect the duct much easier, as this section is very light. Once this is done, place this section up inside the hole in the proper position (flush with one side of the hole), then slide the black fan housing into it into the hole and into the galvanized section. There are 4 screws that will screw this housing into the supporting brackets. Replace the machine screw that joints the two sections together, and reconnect the 2 wires between them. Then install the LED bulbs and place the grill. DONE!#3This is a bit irritating. I bought this fan for its 150CFM capacity. In my case, I cannot use it! It might be my duct, but nonetheless, I wanted to share this, as it is a function of the fan involved here.I installed this during the winter. So even though I wanted to use the Speedi-Products EX-WCHD 06 (ASIN: B0085KZOQW) as a wall cap I couldn't as I cannot climb on the house right now. So I though I will re-purpose my old gas boiled vent stack (not used as I have an on-demand unit now). So I used a Fantech RSK-6 damper (the one on the fan is pretty bad) (ASIN: B000VMHYH4) and connected it to the vent stack. Well, when I put the fan on 150CFM, it will work a bit, stop, then start again, then stop again, and so on. I thought I have a defective one. But now I believe this is a "function" of the fan, as it's "SmartFlow" technology senses resistance in the duct and it tries to adjust the air flow... So I had to reduce the speed to 110CFM and it works properly. Now I have to wait until I install the wall cap in the spring to see if this is an issue with the fan or my stupid vent stack (probably not able to discharge properly that much air).So, to get back to that #1 issue with the picture, if you need to reduce the duct from 6 to 4 inch you might run into some problems with this "SmartFlow" (assuming this is the problem in my case, and not my fan being defective)...Other thoughts on this fan:- The LED bulbs are very nice, but I would have liked a light a bit cooler (it is more towards warm) and a bit brighter, so I might look in the future at some adapters and some corn LEDs;- For how much I paid for this thing, the grill could have been nicer - it is OK looking, but just OK, as it does not have a premium feel to it;- I did not use any additional sensors, as I have this installed with a Lutron Maestro MS-OPS6M-DV-WH (ASIN: B004P2C73M); They might be useful, and certainly this is a nice feature of this fan.- Finally, this thing has a slow start, so slow that when I turned it on after installing it I though it is not working!All of the above considering, this is a very nice fan, very quiet and very efficient. Would I buy it again: I am on the fence, as this thing is very good, but very expensive. The ducted 120CFM (Panasonic FV-10NLF1 ASIN B000EDOHBQ) which I have in my downstairs bathroom is less than half the price (it would involve finding alternatives for the light though).Hope that helps. Good luck.

Great fan! I recently built a new bathroom and used this for the exhaust. It has been working flawlessly for the past 4 months or so. The bathroom does not have windows, so this is the only way to eliminate moisture - it is quiet and efficient!I paired it with a Lutron Maestro MS-OPS6M-DV-WH, a Fantech PBV4 intake (I cannot see myself paying that much for the Panasonic one), a Fantech RSK-4 damper and a Speedi-Products EX-WCHD 04 wall cap. It works perfectly! Not a spec of moisture on the mirror ( I forgot to turn it on one time and it fogged up instantly), and takes care of the nasty fumes immediately (I have 2 young kids, not that what I do smells like roses...)I did not use the brackets they included as they wouldn't have worked in my case (see pictures on how I installed it.) I also installed a connection box and run conduit from the fan to that box. I used aluminum solid duct and this thing sings! On mute!Highly recommended!

This spout is very nice quality. It is very solid, with a nice chrome finish. I installed it about 4 months ago and no issues since.The main issue with this is installation: it is very finicky about how deep your drop-ear is. Within 1/8"! Of course that in my case I needed a 1.75" nip....le (Amazon will take down this review if I use the appropriate term for that short pipe), which is impossible to find (at least to my knowledge. So I had to make my own with two 1/2" to 3/8" reducers and one 3/8" nip...le. That did not decrease the flow at all (the inside diameter of the spout is the same as the 3/8" nip...le anyway), and it allowed me to have the flange perfectly flush with the wall.BTW, it looks great next to my Hansgrohe 04353000 valve, the Hansgrohe 04354000 diverter, and the Artos F902-7CH shower outlet (highly recommend this one - great quality, cheap, and it looks very, very close to the Grohe spout, which is the main reason I bought them). Also looks very close design wise to the Hansgrohe 28631000 Unica shower bar, as well as the Gatco Channel items.So highly recommended, but installation is problematic, so 1 star deducted for that.

This is by far one the best shower outlets I tried, and I tried a few of them. It is a solid chunk of brass (not like the plastic-fantastic Grohe or Hansgrohe shower outlets), with very good quality chrome finish. The flange is also solid, and stays perfectly close to the wall. I installed it about 4 months ago and no issues.It comes with a brass pipe nip...le (Amazon will take down this review if I use the appropriate term for that short pipe) already installed but it was a bit short for me, so I used another one (btw, it is a pain to get it out, as I thing they used some thread sealant that pretty much glued them together, but since it is all brass, I was able to use a bit of force and get it out).More, when compared to other fixtures (such as the Grohe tub spout I installed) the installation design is much better and easier, as the flange has about 1 inch of space where it could be positioned, so it is not so finicky about how deep is your drop-ear.It looks great next to my Hansgrohe 04353000 valve, the Hansgrohe 04354000 diverter, and the Grohe 13274 Concetto tub spout (actually, this one looks very, very close to the Artos, which is the main reason I bought the Artos). Also looks very close design wise to the Hansgrohe 28631000 Unica shower bar, as well as the Gatco Channel items.For the price I paid (less than 25 bucks) there is no other better value, and it has a much better quality than other ones at least double in price, even from big brand names. So highly recommended if it fits in your design!

I am slowly working my way through the entire Sidestreets series and, for the most part, I find all of the books pertinent and spot on.Love Hurts is no exception - yes, the entire story is very quickly told and settled, but that is the business model on which these books are based.What I liked very much about this story is that the main character does not take forever to realize what kind of situation she is in.  Granted, she does a "bonehead" move towards the end of the book which causes a chain reaction, but overall, I thought the story and the main character were portrayed realistically.Another great book in the series.  A must read.

I love Isabelle Lafleche's books. I discovered them, by sheer fluke, a few years ago and as soon as I started reading J'Adore New York, I was hooked.J'adore Montral is the newest member of the family, unfortunately, it is, at this point, a short story, but nonetheless, I was thrilled that a) Isabelle was offering us something new in the series and b) the setting is my hometown.Catherine is back and so is Rikash (I love him, although I always think his name is Rishkah) and they are spending some time in Montral, enjoying a Dior event at one of the classiest places in town. Of course, Catherine cannot stay out of trouble and soon finds herself caught up in a situation that made for some entertaining and fun reading.Even though this is a short story, Catherine`s style, class and intelligence still find their way into the story, I loved that Isabelle kept Catherine honest and true to herself. Of course Rikash was as always, funny and scary - every time I read a passage involving him, I feel like I am looking at a speeding train that may or may not stop in time - its wonderful and adds a little bit more spice to the story.Let`s face it - Catherine and Rikash are great together and THEY are the story - oh let`s not forget the glamorous Dior - never far from being a central character and in this story, beautiful Montral is front and center.Isabelle is a Montrealer - which makes her Montral based story authentic. Her descriptions of the stores, of the food and of the 'style' of Montral are spot on. Making this an even more entertaining read for me.I need this to come out as a full book.

I hate, hate the laces that came with my sneakers.  They are way too long and I step on them and untie them all the time.  Also, they tend to come undone for no reason!  I have been looking for laces that are easy to "install" and that will be the right size and actually stay tied.These laces did the job.  The pair I have are navy blue and they are quite dark - but do have a tinge of dark grey in them.  They are waxed and I thought this would be a problem keeping the shoes tied, but this has not been the case.Putting the laces on was easy and now, they look great with my shoes and guess what - i don't keep tripping over them anymore.

When you order these, you actually get 4 separate air fresheners and the idea of basing their scent on the seasons is genius.  The fall or autumn one is my favorite followed by the winter one.  It so happens that I also love those two seasons and both the air fresheners reminded me of that particular season as soon as I opened it.I know people seem to be using them for their car, but I actually used mine in my house - one closet and three rooms and I love the scent - not too strong.  Its always a bit of a mystery when you are trying a new product similar to this as to whether you will end up with some cheesy, overly strong freshener, but not the case here.Once the freshener starts to fade - I plan on using these for my drawers.Love this product.

I am a huge fan of this series - I find the books brave, timely and honest.Skank takes a look at how quickly things can unravel, especially if you are a young adult going to high school.While I did not hate this book, I felt nothing for the main character, which is not a good thing for me.  It means there is something about the character that feels under developed or that the story was simply not "arced" properly for me.I had mixed feelings about the relationship between Ariel and her mom.  Its nice to read a YA novel where the daughter is not at war with her mother - or that the parents are simply a nuisance within the story.  However, in this book, the mother is more like a friend than a mother - which, at times, left me screaming "helllloooo mommmm can you pick up on your daughter's cries for help?".Overall, it was an okay read.

This book started out really well for me, the story was engaging and I was all in. It kind of started falling apart once "the main event" happens.I could see the entire scenario playing itself out and yet, even at the height of the "problem" the author never portrays her main character as being that much in turmoil - as a matter of fact, nobody around her really seems to be all that surprised or mad or anything really at the end result.  Sure, the Highley throws in a "desperate act" - but to me, the whole thing felt too forced to be all that intriguing.I do like the author's writing style though and I would have gladly read this story without all the "detours" that were not necessary.  This story would have made excellent reading without all the forced drama.

I have never been a huge fan of Laverne and Shirley but I have always enjoyed Cindy Williams, which is why this book look so inviting to me.Having said that, I can honestly say that I enjoyed this book..  Did I love it?  No and the reason for this is that I found this book incredibly vanilla.I am not sure if this a trend these days as I have read a few others in this "genre"  for which I have the exact same comment.This book was fun to read because Williams has some funny anecdotes about some of the biggest tv celebrities., including Andy Kaufman.  She has a fun way of writing that makes you feel as though you are actually living the whole event right with her and....she is funny.  However, my beef with this book is that she just does not go into enough details about most of the things in her life.  For example, she talks about Laverne and Shirley and then, poof in less than two sentences, she tells us "by now I have married...:  Really?  Two paragraphs ago you were telling us about Laverne and Shirley and now you are married?  Not one mention of her even having a boyfriend up until this point and never again after that.It felt as though she skipped over some huge points - mainly in her personal life and that is simply not acceptable if you are writing a memoir.  If all you wanted to talk about was your career then that book should have been written and NOT called a memoir.Additionally, after I read the entire book, I had absolutely no idea how Cindy felt about Laverne and Shirley, Penny Marshall or almost everybody else she mentioned - except Ed Begley Jr.  She does not write, at any point in time, about ANY of her feelings and emotions.  She is never mad, sad or thrilled.I didn't hate this book, but wow, was it lacking as a "memoir:.

I enjoy YA and what attracted me to this book was the rehab/recovery aspect, which is why I was a little bit freaked out when i first starting reading this. I was worried about the way the author was incorporating the recovery aspect of the storyline, however, as I kept reading, I found a delightful, funny and at times, a little bit "out there" type of read.I guess you would expect that from an author who "infiltrates" her main character into a rehab, all in the name of "the guy".Ultimately, though, what this story is about and what Lola discovers - life lessons about growing up and finding out a little bit more about who you are and what you mean to the world.Very well written, engaging and entertaining - a little out of the box, but it works here.

I truly enjoy reading this author's works. She writes realistic stories that are both sad and uplifting without going over the top silly.The Truth About Us is basically a story about two young adults from very different worlds who want to come together despite everything. This book touched on a lot of emotions for me, at times, I found myself rooting for the characters and at the same time, I kind of saw why they could not be together. Its always a good sign for me when a storyline tears me in two - challenges me to think about a situation and question "what would I do if it were me?".Very well written - I love that Gurtler uses day to day dialogue and does not fall victim to the "high prose" that many authors tend to do - if you have dialogue or a scene to discribe - don't take 10 pages to do it in.I also enjoyed how none of the adult characters were particularly nice or were being portrayed as "knowing everything" - especially the moms of both of these characters and I won't even get into how much I disliked the dad in this one.Excellent reading and excellent writing. I loved it.

I am such a huge tea lover and I admit, I have been researching, for some time, what the cerremonial tea process is all about.The history of tea is fascinating to me and I am so happy that tea has really found a place in our "modern" world, yet, I have been dying to try reproducing, to the best of my ability, the process, thoughts, traditions and of course the tea used in ceremonial tea, which is why this matcha came at a perfect time.I admit, I was a bit intimidated at first, but i went ahead and purchased the bowl, whisk and after reading everything carefully, I prepared my tea and it was perfect. The whole process made me feel as though I was truly exploring the traditions linked to matcha tea and I the end result was delicious.This tea is flavourful without being over powering, which is something I admit I was afraid of - no worries. It is pretty high octane so I would not suggest it for any before bed sipping, but I have actually made it throughout the day and it tastes great at any time.I loved this tea - and everything associated with it.

I have always loved white gold stud earrings, however thanks to the Orrous & Co Legacy Collection's reasonable prices and large variety of models, I decided to try some "new" for me styles - including this pair of drop down earrings.  My weakness is white gold so when I received these I was blown away by how shiny and expensive looking they look.I actually wore these with a pair of jeans to add contrast (and try some new looks) and I got so many compliments - people actually think I spent wayyyyy more on these than the actual cost.They are also incredibly easy to put on and stay in place even with a nice of dancing.  I love these so much.

For some reason I have always felt intimidated with drop down pearl earrings until I saw how beautiful these look.  The yellow gold gives this pair of earrings a reason to stand out from the crowd and the shell pearl is dainty yet large enough that your earrings can be seen whether you have long or short hair.While my first choice is not always yellow gold, I am glad that I did as they are just beautiful.

White gold is my favorite  and combined with a stud pattern (which by the way goes beautifully with another piece of jewellery I own) made me feel dressed up and elegant without appearing to wear "costume jewellery".  Let's face it, its so easy to look fake when wearing some costume jewellery but these cubic zirconia glitter and are a perfect size on my ear.I even got caught in the rain with them and they remained shiny and most importantly, in place and safe on my ear.I like the versatility of these earrings from day to night - they are a perfect match for all of my moods.

I love, love these earrings.  Although I would love to spend thousands on earrings, I just don't have the funds to do so, which is why I am so thrilled with the Orrous & Co collection, they let me purchase quality jewellery at very reasonable prices, while offering me variety and quality merchancise that doesn't look cheap.These earrings are so cute.  They are dainty and so feminine looking that I decided to pair them up with my business suit because I wanted to add a splash of class to the outfit and they did the trick.  I love pearls and this is the right size for the gold plated "shell" from which the pearl hangs.So classy.

I would have loved to give this book amazing reviews, unfortunately, I just could not get into the storyline at all.I was intrigued by this book because it sounded like a creepy whodunnit especially since the story unfolds in a tiny, remote town. However, this book felt like it was a plot line with nowhere to go.I think part of the problem was the author's determination in giving the story twists, which only bogged down the story.This book is not intriguing, creepy or particularly interesting.

I just received my quilt. I am rating it 3 stars because it is a pretty color and the red is nice and bright. Having said that, as soon as I pulled it out of the bag and put it on the bed, I noticed that some of the treads were coming off the flower designs - on both sides of the quilt.Secondly THIS IS DEFINITELY A SUMMER QUILT. It is extremely flimsy and to be honest is on my bed more as a "decoration" than as a useful blanket.

This wallet case is so nice.  I was surprised to see how classy this is and it is such a good deal for the price.  It works well with my IPHONE and I love that there are four card slots which are perfect for my most important (and more often pulled out cards).  It fits nicely in my purse's slot for my phone and it is easy to open and close.Its well made and as mentioned looks more expensive than the price listed.This was a great buy.

These 18k White Gold Plated White Shell Pearl earrings are beautiful.  I am always weary of ordering something online because they can often look very different on a photo.  Fortunately, that is not the case here.They are dainty but large enough to be easily seen on my ear.  The white gold plated around the pearl looks very sparkly and rich and the pearl is nice an large which sits beautifully on my earlobe.  I received quite a few compliments on my earrings and at this price, they are a wonderful deal.Perfect to wear at work and then to a nice dinner out - I love, loved these earrings.  What a gem (no pun intented LOL).

We entertain quite a lot and nothing is more annoying than going back and forth to the fridge with the wine bottle because you don't want to keep the wine because it gets warm. I have tried other types of wine chiller before and they have been such a pain (or simply didn't work) that I almost gave up...almost, until I discovered the Vinomio Wine Chiller.Firstly, it is incredibly easy to use (which is great because I am horrible at inserting part A into Part B, etc. The instructions, which are included in the box (which looks very pretty actually) are simple to follow, as I soon discovered during out last dinner party.I have a fear of opening wine bottles because I always make a mess of the cork, but once my boyfriend tackled that job, I took the wine chiller out (as per the instructions) inserted into the bottle and wow! worked like a charm. The bottle(s) stayed on the table, my guests served themselves easily and happily and the wine chiller did a perfect job of keeping the liquid at a perfect temperature, despite being on the table for hours.The Vinomio Wine Chiller was also a joy to clean - no fuss and no muss and I even keep it in its original box for safekeeping.I am so happy with this product and I have bragged about it to my friends. A wonderful addition to our dinner parties.

** spoiler alert ** I have read all of Patterson's Alex Cross books and, for the most part, have truly loved them. I just love Alex Cross, which is why I was so happy to read this one. I consider my once a year Alex Cross books as a huge treat.Unfortunately, this one left me "meh". While its not horrible, its fairly boring focusing solely on Cross trying to save his family (left off from the previous book).What works, for me, when it comes to Alex Cross is that he can be incredibly analytical and its a treat to read his exploits as he follows the clues and tracks his prey - they never stand a chance. Except that in this one, Cross is reduced to reacting instead of planning and using his intelligence. I don't like that Alex Cross.Additionally, this book pushes a little too much when it comes to certain things - at times, its just not credible, especially the scene when he has to "rescue" himself. There is almost no mention or presence from Sampson and everything is about his family, which I find tedious even when the story is great (which it is not here).Finally and this is MY BIGGEST beef with this one - Patterson uses silly ploys to lure his readers and then, chooses to PLAY IT VERY, VERY SAFE. This book could have had a saving grace - the author could have taken a chance and really done something daring which would have moved the story forward greatly for this book and for the others which will follow - except he went and played it safe - what a bore and a total let down.

I, like many people, heard about this through Dr. Oz.I am ALWAYS on the lookout for products that are safe and touted as helping with weight loss.  So I really wanted to try this product.Some people have commented on the negative taste. I LOVED it.  I had 3 teaspoons each day (I altered the requirements to suit me) and I actually took it straight up!I was very interested to see what reaction my body would have to this and I am happy to report that it worked just wonderfully.  In fact, I have been using this for close to three weeks now and I have lost 2 lbs without changing anything in my diet.I find it easy to use, tasty and it actually seems to be working for me - miracle of miracles.  I also love the fact that its organic and pure.If you have been hesitating about this product, I suggest you give it a try, you will be happy with the results.

I have neck problems and when I travel I can really feel the pain.  I have been searching for a neck pillow that will both offer comfort and relief and this pillow is the answer.Firstly, it looks comfy and classy. Some pillows i have looked at have given me the impression that they will rip apart as soon as I use it more than once.  NOT the case here - its sturdy, flexible and cosy looking.Secondly, it vibrates!!! and it even has various settings, depending on what you are looking for.  For me, I always put it on full vibration massage to soothe my neck.I have used the pillow at home (watching tv) and while I am travelling and it works perfectly for any circumstances.I love that it only uses two batteries, which means no plugs or expensive charging issues.Overall, this is a wonderful product and I am thrilled to have it.

I enjoy reading novels that act out some of the "real" life situations that I would have liked to have happen to me.Granted, I am not a kickboxer (not even close) but I have always wanted to know what it would be like to somehow get thrown into the world of celebrity, without actually having to act, sing or anything like that and this book does a fantastic job of showing us just how an ordinary girl can find herself wrap up into a world that is overwhelming and so obviously not real.Author Hantz portrays her main character as a down to earth girl who reluctantly finds herself the "double" for the it actress of the moment.  Although she doesn't want to be in that place, she quickly gets engulfed and this is where the story line turns very interesting to me.Becoming a diva, pushing away friends Liv and Matt and starting to buy your own press, these are the steps that Abi suddenly goes through, without even really noticing it (in the beginning) until she realizes just what she is doing and just how much the world she is now in is sucking the life out of her.I admit, there is no new ground covered here, but the story is quick, fun and engaging which made this book a great read.

If I had to write a very short review of this book it would be "wow".  I absolutely loved this book.  I am a huge fan of  "stranded in a disaster/mother nature goes nuts" type of read (yes, I know its not an actual genre, but I just made it up LOL).Pandemic is THE perfect read for anyone who is looking for that creepy yet hopeful plot line where you know that everything written on the page is VERY plausible, while, at the same time, hoping (praying) that it never actually happens to you and just basically stays on the written page.Author Ventresca does a terrific job of introducing her characters and setting up the premise before throwing the reader into a catastrophe that is all too real.  Unlike many dystopian type books - there are no zombies, undead or walking corpses and this was such a relief.  Rather, this book is a story about what happens if we are hit with the next powerful plague, something as seemingly insignificant as the flu.The book pulls no punches and nobody is sacred, in fact, I felt for the main character Lil who will have to go through so much and may not in fact survive it all (no spoilers sorry!).Written extremely well without being gross or too detailed, this book kept me reading page after page, in fact, I found I could not put it down, especially once people start to get infected.I love the resilience of the main characters, even when they are asked to make some very tough choices and this book made me do some serious thinking about what kind of person I would be in this type of emergency.  I also like how Lil learns some very important lessons throughout the storyline.The only two things that were a bit of an irritant to me where the Mr. B. plot line which may have worked well in the beginning of the book, but dragged the story down a bit after that, especially when Lil keeps the whole situation a secret, way past when it should have been.  Also, the whole "relationships"  thing with two of the characters was not necessary to the story as I kept asking myself "really, that's important at a time like this?".Otherwise, the author hit it right out of the field with this one and I was so mad when I kept seeing the % on my Kindle inch its way up and up - it meant the end of an absolutely terrifying but brilliant book.

I discovered Ayurveda a few years ago and I have gotten very interested in it.  Unfortunately, there are not many good DVD's on the subject, but this one by the wonderful GAIAM company is informative and produced for the beginners (like me).No long winded boring stories about Ayurveda, but rather, something that is aimed at people who want to start at the beginning to improve their lives with Ayurveda.Sections on food (my favorite), exercises as well as massages and just every day ayurveda practices.  Its wonderful

I bought this bracelet in the hope that it would not look "cheesy" and I was thrilled when I opened this package.The bracelet is beautiful, looks classy and is sturdy and dainty at the same time.The wording is very visible and it fits beautifully.This was a wonderful purchase.

I took a chance and selected this sampler as I thought it would be a great way to discover new brands of coffee. My favorite is Green Mountain but they have so few choices, I wanted to branch out.I am very happy with this sampler. Some yummy flavors (I love flavored coffees) to discover and a nice selection of teas as well (Herbal was prominent which I am very happy with).A few Green Mountain sprinkled in for good measure.Loving this sampler.

I love, love this brand of coffee. You can really taste the Butter Toffee and you can smell it as soon as you brew it (or in this case pour it in your cup because it was a K cup).The price is right too, I just wish they made other flavors although I do plan on trying mudslide next.

It took me a long time to convert to a Kindle, but a few years ago, I did.  Unfortunately, the initial wire that came with it wasn't very good, in fact after less than a year of (medium) usage, the wire simply broke.  When I looked more closely, I saw that the problem was actually all the tiny wires inside the wire - basically bending this wire is a very bad idea.So, I ordered this one, which is much longer than the original which is a plus, but, once again, I have to be extremely careful not to bend this wire because the same thing will happen.I am not sure why they can't invent a wire that is a little more resistant to every day usage.

In this day and age, all of us have to do anything and everything to use quality products that work, but that can also protect and this Argan Oil is the perfect answer.I am a huge fan of this company, as mentioned in previous posts, I love all their products and this one wins me over because of its ease of use.  A fee seconds and you are giving your hair a treat loaded with vitamins.  But what I also love is the fact that this product protects against UV rays,  How great is that?There is no downside to using this product and as a huge plus, my hair is looking healthier and bouncier.A win-win on all sides.

Having read a shred about Ronald Knox's becoming Catholic, I wanted to read more. Looking through Amazon, I found this book. I ignored the title "as apologist", and the subtitle, which seemed to unnecessarily alienate potential readers. I was drawn to it by it's being on a trusted publisher (Ignatius Press), and by the quote from Thomas Howard saying that you'd have to read a shelfful of books by and about Knox to find what you can find here. Howard hit the nail on the head. That's exactly right. Having said that, what about the subtitle and title?The subtitle comes from a four line poem, reprinted in the frontspiece of the book, uncredited. Inside you find out it's a poem by Chesterton titled "Namesake", which explains everything. If they'd said that at the outset, one wouldn't wonder about the "Popish Creed". On the back it says that Father Walsh did his dissertation on Knox. This book reads like that dissertation. It's very well researched, and very intellectual, like a dissertation. Thomas Howard likes it because while his own apologetics are like those of Knox, very homey, his writing style in some books is above many readers' heads. An English major like me finds Howards' "On Being Catholic" dazzling, but a friend preferred his "If Your Mind Wanders at Mass" because it was much simpler (and almost makes the same points). As C. S. Lewis points out in his book about reading, "An Experiment in Criticism", there are various kinds of readers. What Walsh really does in this book is offer the reader a sort of map of how to get around in Knox. I'm trying in this review to offer a way to get around in Walsh, so a different sort of reader (a more casual one) can discover Knox.Someone may say, "the more casual reader can just go find a more casual book to read", but I don't agree. Here's why. You have the same problem with any prolific author, say G.K. Chesterton or C.S. Lewis. No one knows where to start or what to read. A well-researched book like this one can help one find the trail. This is an apt metaphor, as Walsh titles a chapter "Seeking the Treasure". The casual reader can use this book as a map by simply noting the layout of the book. The casual reader will enjoy the first parts, because they are arranged by "Before Conversion" and "After Conversion". This is the same way that Newman laid out his autobiographical "Apologia Pro Vita Sua", and makes for delightful reading (we'll get to Newman in a minute).The other thing to note is the "Contents" page which begins the book Why? Because Walsh reprints the text of some rare "Conferences" given by Knox on pages 132, 148, 185, 202, and 235. However, nothing tells you you're reading a "Conference" when you get to these pages in the book, except for these bits in the "Contents". The treasure is buried in the book. On page 15, however, Walsh provides a very helpful list of abbreviations for Knox's various books cited in the text. This will prove helpful to the reader who may decide to read more by Knox, and also indicates the dates of publication. This is very helpful with the "Conferences", talks given earlier to students at Oxford and elsewhere, but only published later.If the "apologist" in the title is throwing anyone off, that comes from a line from St. Paul, "Be ready to make a defense (or apologia) for the hope that is in you." It's sometimes translated "answer", since it doesn't mean to apologize as if you're sorry, and there's nothing defensive about it.  Walsh makes the point that Knox didn't only pile up intellectual arguments, but rather gave homey metaphors drawn from English life. As most readers know, C.S. Lewis also did this, and some of Lewis' best-known "apologetics" came from Knox. Walsh has another book about the two authors' friendship. Thomas Howard's books also strike this friendly, homey note, but for US readers.Now for Newman. I had stayed away from reading Newman, because even though I had first year Latin, "Apologia Pro Vita Sua" is a forbidding title. However, it simply means "Apology for My Life", and turns out to be written in English, some of the best written and easiest to read English I've ever encountered. Reading the Knox quotes here, Knox seems to be the same way. But Father Walsh's book is not written that way. It's written, as I've noted, as a dissertation. People interested in "Knox's apologetics" (which I'm not), may find plenty of brain food here. I simply find the two writing styles clashing. Walsh writes in the chapter called "Experience, Reason, and Authority" "The wave of experience dashes us up against the rock of authority; the system or creed that emerges dashes us back on the waves of praxis." What? Fortunately he then quotes Knox, who simply says "Don't be the kind of Catholic who slinks off to Mass".I don't know if I've rescued Knox for the general reader. My main impression on reading this book is that I wish Ignatius would simply reprint all the Sheed and Ward published titles by Knox (they have begun to bring some back into print). Although Father Walsh's style here is more scholarly than popular, that may be what he was hoping for all along. Thomas Howard is right. You don't have to be interested in either apologetics or "the Popish Creed" to meet Knox here, and that is a treasure worth digging for.

My title might seem a bit odd. Having joined the Knights of Columbus, a Catholic fraternal men's service organization, I was interested in this documentary about its founder. I had read the book Parish Priest about Father Michael McGivney, but that doesn't mention Knights until 200 pages in, and I thought this DVD might be a bit more to the point. But in a certain sense it's not, because Father McGivney did so much more than that, and most of it before founding Knights. This documentary runs almost an hour, but it seems a lot longer, having no commercials. Other than that, it's like a History Channel TV show. There's running narration, and brief interview bits, but most of it is a dramatic reconstruction of 19th century life, with a huge cast. For this reason, it's quite engaging and gripping.This video dates from 2008, although the packaging of this edition is from 2014. I bought it in a Catholic book store for the same price Amazon has it for, as I write. Amazon may lower it at some point, of course. It seems like it was shown on TV because it starts with a teaser about Father McGivney's cause for Sainthood (which won't interest non-Catholics), and the narrator does a lot of foreshadowing as if approaching a commercial break. But on the video, the story is seamless. You could watch this as an interesting documentary about the plight of immigrants in the 19th century, particularly Irish immigrants, or about the related topic of the state of the Catholic Church in New England at that time. Or as a history of the Knights. There are no extras on the DVD, but you can select between four languages: English, Spanish, French, and Polish.About a million immigrants fled the potato famine in Ireland, mostly to the eastern US. This got them even more hated than they already were, and Catholics viewed with even more suspicion. Two things happened around then in the 19th century in the US. A lot of religious movements were started, and a lot of secret societies began. Sometimes the two were related. It's no accident that nearly all of the US presidents were Masons, and sometimes you had to join a society like that to get a good job. Immigrants, especially Irish ones, worked at hard, dangerous jobs, and the breadwinning father often died young. There was no universally available insurance. Masons, for example, were also an insurance, known as a death benefits, group, for their members. Knights was started for two main reasons. First, to provide an organization that was not a secret society for men that would affirm Catholic values, and second, to provide for widows and children. Thus it is that Knights still offers insurance today.Knights sometimes gets a bad rap today as a drinking club, or an organization with its own agenda that doesn't support the priest or pope. Every stereotype might be true in some cases, but where Knights councils follow their founder's vision, the members can provide greatly needed support and assistance to the priest, the pope, the parish, the wider Church, and the community. If anything would make a man want to join the Knights, it's this video, which shows how he takes his place in a great legacy, and why Knights are proud to regard Father McGivney as the Father of us all. Only one thing about it is misleading. For a man said to be always laughing and smiling, in his portraits he looks somber and sad. This is because of the 19th century view that you ought to look dignified in a portrait. It's the same way with Chesterton's portraits from the same time.  (Note: parents should watch this video first before showing it to their kids, as it shows a man being hanged).

When I got the AquaSpa, I found the instructions confusing. However, it's actually very intuitive, both to install and to operate. Someone handier than I am won't need to read this, but I'll give  step by step operation, and installation, as well as answer a couple comments.I replaced a massaging showerhead that was supposed to make low water pressure seem higher. This new showerhead (the large head), has a built in flow restrictor to save water (the instructions say how to remove it if you have low water pressure). I left it in, although I thought I'd have to go back and take it out to get more pressure. But I didn't have to, because even on the lowest setting, this showerhead has more pressure than the one I had before.As for installation, you don't need any tools, as you simply hand tighten the pieces in place.
