First, you unscrew the old showerhead. Then you slip the plastic lock nut on the pipe, slip in the thick rubber washer, and screw on the new piece that looks sort of like a sausage. What's the lock nut for? You screw this down on the sausage piece. Plumber's tape is supplied, but you don't need it unless this fitting leaks. Then you simply screw in the large showerhead. Now you test it. Turn the lever on the left side of the water diverter (the thing that looks like a sausage) to the left so it points down. Turn on the shower and you can test it for leaks. It probably won't leak. If it does leak, unscrew the diverter, wrap plumber's tape around the threads on the pipe coming out of the wall, and screw it back on. You probably have a normal pipe with about an inch of thread showing on the end, sticking out of the wall. But if, for some reason, you had just a few threads showing on the end of the pipe, you simply leave off the lock nut, and there's an included thin rubber washer you can use to make it fit better. That's it for the large showerhead. Right there you've got a great, six position adjustable showerhead.What about the handheld shower? Two small rubber washers are tied to the flexible, metal hose. You slip one washer in each end of the hose, then screw one end into the sausage thing, and the other into the base of the handheld shower. That's it. The right side of the sausage thing holds the handheld shower. If for some reason this slips (mine didn't), you tighten it with a screwdriver. Turning the lever on the left side of the sausage to point to the front selects the handheld shower. On the base of the handheld shower (by the hose) is a lever which selects the inner or outer ring. Why? You can shower with either one, but if you snap one of the two brushes into the handheld showerhead, and select the outer ring, the water will spin the brush. You start it rotating by turning the lever on the back top of the brush. The purple brush has rounded massaging nubs. The green brush has softer brush ends. I never thought I'd figure it all out, but one shower and I did.The water has to be flowing through the outer ring of the handheld shower to rotate the brush. If you pull the brush too hard, and it separates from the brush holder, it easily stretches back on (you can also clean it this way). You can also turn a dial on the face of the handheld shower to switch from power spray to pulsating massage. All of the controls are easy to operate because they click into position. For instance, the large showerhead has a lever which clicks between six positions. The rightmost is economy rain, which is stronger than my previous shower head. Next is a mist setting, which can simulate a steam room. The other settings include massage, rainfall, and various combinations.The reason to only hand tighten is because the pieces are made of chrome-plated PVC pipe. They don't look like metal, although I find the entire AquaSpa attractive. The entire assembly is very light, so it doesn't stress the connecting pipe. With the handheld shower in place, it looms up high over the pipe, which is not a problem, but a bracket is available to mount it down by the tub, and you could use either the handheld or the large showerhead by themseleves. I found the rotating brushes good for rinsing my short haircut after shampooing, and the mist setting warms up your face for shaving. With my former showerhead, I always regretted that the water pressure was so low. With AquaSpa, I look forward to a shower.

After reading the cavils against this Bible in reviews here, I determined to see it before I bought it. I did see it at the Alleluia Catholic Book Store in Mill Creek WA yesterday, and then I bought it. Here's why. I had the Ignatius Study Bible New Testament, which I cannot recommend too highly, but due to all the introductions and notes (which are excellent), Ignatius Catholic Study Bible: New Testament it's as big as a phone book. I wanted to get the entire Bible as well, mostly to read the seven books in the Old Testament which are no longer in Protestant (non-Catholic) Bibles. Protestants call them the Apocrypha, although for no good reason, as I'll explain below.But back to this Bible. Physically it's only about 3/4 inch thick, and an attractive 9 X 6 inch paperback. I skipped over it in the Book Store, thinking it must be a study Bible with only Psalms in it, since it's so thin. The cover matches the New Testament study Bible, except that it's sort of deep wine red rather than dark brown/ black, but both are far more attractive than they look in the photos. Someone complained that the paper is too thin and you can see right through it. Lots of Bibles use what is called Bible paper, which is very thin. It's possible this is a bit thinner, and yes, you can see partly through it. I don't find it distracting, but no, you don't want to highlight or even underline in it. Wait until the Study Bible includes the New Testament (or it's published separately) for that. But for careful reading, I think this Bible is excellent. I have a Harper RSV study Bible which is very large, but this fits easily into my pack. Someone said Esther and other books were missing in their copy. That must have been a mistake. They are fine in mine. I'm very pleased with this Bible. In the back, it has the same sixteen pages of color maps that are in the Ignatius New Testament study Bible. It's a very easy Bible to read, as the pages are in two columns. The only "helps" are the standard RSV-style footnotes.The RSV (Revised Standard Version) is the best "modern" translation. This Ignatius edition is based on the RSV-CE (Catholic Edition), which was British and dates from 1966. However, it takes into account all later Bible study and second edition means some of the archaic language has been changed from the O.T. In short, the perfect Bible. On the Protestant side, the ESV is also based on the RSV, and therefore I'd say it's the best Protestant Bible. Greek Translator Richmond Lattimore did his own New Testament without verse numbers, so it reads like a book The New Testament . It's also based on the RSV. What about the seven books? Did Catholics add them? No. The apostles read the Greek version of the Old Testament, called the Septuagint, which included these seven books. They are even quoted some of these seven books in the New Testament. Also, they were originally included in the King James (Authorized Version) Bible of 1611. In the preface of a Protestant King James Bible, it claims to be from 1611, but the seven books were only taken out of the edition of 1625. Interesting Bible trivia. Is this what people mean by the "Apocrypha"? Yes and no. Sometimes they mean any ancient books that were left out of the Protestant Bible. Only the seven "extra" books included in the Catholic Bible are considered by Catholics to be the "canon" of Scripture, regardless of whatever other books may have been floating around at the time.By the way, this is an officially approved Catholic Bible, and the one used in the Catechism of the Catholic Church. The New American Bible is still used in the Mass, but I wish it were replaced by the RSV. Also, for Protestants who read the NKJV (New King James), I dare you to read this RSV and compare the two for understandability and readability. The RSV is also beautiful for flow. St. Paul's letters really read like letters. To my mind, this is also everything Protestants are looking for in a Bible. Someone might want a pricier or fancier edition, and these are available. It would be wonderful to see it made into a big family Bible/ coffee table edition with beautiful color art prints as well. It's very expensive for a publisher to make a Bible translation, and they have to change 15 per cent of it to copyright it. Ignatius did not copyright this one. The copyright is still held by the National Council of the Churches of Christ. Ignatius put all the work in, but they don't get the money back. The reason is they don't want to arbitrarily change wording just to get a copyright. They have done excellent work from, to my mind, the best translation, the RSV. This is, I would say, a Bible for everyone.

I had just read Father Charles Connor's "Classic Catholic Converts" Classic Catholic Converts, when I  came upon this book. How do they compare? Father Connor is an historian, and provides fewer but longer portraits. This book, "A Century of Catholic Converts" covers more stories, but some are as short as a page and a half. Given that people like to read at different levels, in different ways, and all that, I still have qualms with this book. The format of it seems ridiculous.Why? Each section or chapter starts with a very brief summary of the decade, which is so brief as to be misleading, and to sometimes give a slanted view. It seems like a collection of cut and pasted headlines. This allows the author to refer to these events in the converts' stories. But, as Chesterton said, "anyone can believe anything in any era". The decade has nothing to do with it. Also, some of it is so one-sided as to be wrong. The author mentions the Progressive movement, but surely the spirit of the entire century is Modernism. The book gives tacit assent to this by the cover picture of New York, showing Modernism's triumph in the skyscraper, and the dazzling, deco Chrysler Building.The second bothersome thing is that each convert's story starts, for no discernible reason, with a summing up paragraph. Why not just start the story? Thankfully, the stories themselves are not written in this breezy journalistic style. Not surprisingly, perhaps, the two books draw from some of the same sources, so there is some overlap. Both books focus on well-known people, which of course is one of the big draws for readers. However, everyone has a story, and I find those just as fascinating as these better-known ones. Marcus Grodi, host of "The Journey Home" on EWTN, has gathered these in a fascinating volume called Journeys Home Journeys Home, while Grodi's own story is included in A Century of Catholic Converts.

Father Charles Connor is my favorite television personality to watch. He's an avid reader, well-informed, and a fount of knowledge. But more than that, he's so excited that he gets ahead of himself. So I wondered what his writing style would be like in this book. This book dates from 2001, and on the back it says he had a show on EWTN called "Historic Catholic Converts". I've not seen that show (or maybe it's a series), but I wonder if this book is made from transcripts of the shows. One reason is the order of the chapters, which I'll go into later. Also, I actually would rate this book 4.5 stars were that available, simply because some of the writing is not too clear-- I'd say Father Connor gets ahead of himself, as in the parts on Newman, which covers two chapters, and because sometimes it seems like a show transcript. However, this is one book that would be delightful to read on a Kindle, and I did read the first chapter that way. There is at least one minor error, a misprint of the title of Chesterton's novel, "The Ball and the Cross". Those tiny cavils are more than made up for by Father Connor's excitement, evident on every page. If you think history is dry as dust, you haven't read (or heard, or watched) Father Charles Connor.One great thing about this book, as opposed to a TV show, is the bibliography and footnotes, which beckon to avid readers thirsting to explore further. More on the Newman part. These two chapters cover, first, the Oxford Movement, also known as the Tractarian Movement, of which Newman was a part, and then Newman himself. One reason these chapters are not quite clear is that the author doesn't tell the story smoothly, start to finish, as he tends to with the other converts. This is because he's an expert on Newman, and can't quite make it simple enough for a Novice reader. This is because you have to know about the English Church to understand the situation and significance of Newman's becoming Roman Catholic. However, I found Newman's own account in Apologia Pro Vita Sua to be lucid and enlightening Apologia Pro Vita Sua (A Defense of One's Life) (Dover Giant Thrift Editions).The chapters are as follows:1. Elizabeth Ann Seton2. The Oxford Movement3. John Henry Newman4. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop5. Ignatius Spencer6. Orestes Brownson and Isaac Hecker7. Robert Hugh Benson and C.C. Martindale8. Edith Stein9. G.K. Chesterton10. Jaques Maritain11. Karl Stern12. British and French Literary Converts, including: Maurice Baring, Sir Arnold Lunn, Evelyn Waugh, Graham Greene, Leon Bloy, and Paul Claudel13. Ronald Knox14. Dorothy Day15. Converts of Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, including: Horace Mann, Bella Dodd, Louis Budenz, Fritz Kreisler, Heywood Broun,  and Clare Boothe Luce.16. Malcolm MuggeridgeSome Other European and American Converts of Note. Very brief sketches, including: Christopher Dawson, Carlton J. H. Hayes, Shane Leslie, Christopher Hollis, Fulton Oursler, Sigrid Undset, Helen Fowler, Alexis Carrel, A.J. Cronin, and Alphonse Ratisbone.

I'm not completely sure what the point of this book is supposed to be. It's from American Atheist press. "Atheist" merely means "non-theist" and theist is already a vague word. In this case, it might better be called "Angry Atheist press", and who wouldn't be angry, defining themselves in terms of what they don't believe? If the point of this book is to expose the "God of War" of the Old Testament as a pretender and an also ran, in this the author succeeds admirably. What is the slaughter of 70,000 compared to the massacres  wrought by atheists in the last century, who at a stroke slew millions? Hitler, Stalin, and Mao come to mind, for starters, and they were mere humans. Then again, if you think the universe is really a meaningless accident, you have no basis for ethics or morality, so who's to say they were wrong?Paul's own story is also curious. He says he started, as we all do as an atheist, then he was a Catholic, then a  "born again" Christian and then an atheist again. This is like saying a frog starts out as a tadpole, but then grows to a frog. The author seems to be saying it's better to remain a tadpole, or return to being one. Perhaps he grew very fast and is on his second childhood, or has been "born again" as an atheist. No wonder he seems angry, watching the other frogs hop away, who seem to have no desire to join him.If I detect in this book a mocking tone, it's also not surprising. It must be annoying to think there's no meaning in the universe when everyone else thinks there is. Like everyone else, atheists sometimes feel a sense of wonder and gratitude, and the worst thing, as a former non-theist, G.K. Chesterton said, is that there's no one to thank. And it must be annoying watching the other frogs hop away, who consider the tadpole stage not the end, but the beginning of their journey.

I am here reviewing the Dover Giant Thrift paperback edition, which I highly recommend. I note this as this review may show up under some other edition. The Dover paperback is priced at $5 US on the back, and is over 300 pages. It's a very clean reprint of the 1908 Longmans and Green British edition, and includes numerous notes and letters in the back, as well as Kingsley's attack on Newman, which prompted his apology.I became curious about Newman because so many people mention him on "The Journey Home", a show on EWTN, as being instrumental in their spiritual journeys. Also, there's a video of Malcolm Muggeridge in which he and his wife, Kitty, are reading Newman aloud MALCOLM MUGGERIDGE Also, the Newman centers for Catholic students at universities are named for Newman (although it conveniently sounds like New Man).What I did not think is that this book would be easy reading, as most works from 170 years ago are not. The back cover remarks of Newman's "flowing prose and conversational style", and believe it or not, it's true. This is one of the most delightful books I've read in a long time. I knew very little about the Anglican controversies mentioned, but Newman reveals more about them as the book goes on. Also, the names and places are all unfamiliar, but they also are in a fantasy novel. It will sound odd, but this book reads like science fiction, not in the sense of unfolding a plot or story, but because of the imaginative way in which Newman writes, and his felicitous turns of phrase. For that reason, when he drops in a slogan of his day which his contemporary readers would understand, those are so dated that it rarely makes his point clearer now.There are a few brief Latin quotes, not translated into English, but other than that, it's quite smooth going. Every now and then he lifts into amazing prose like this idea of the Catholic Church as "a vast assemblage of human beings with wilful intellects and wild passions, brought together into one by the beauty and Majesty of a Superhuman Power-- into what may be called a large reformatory or training school, for the melting, refining and moulding, by an incessant, noisy process, of the raw material of human nature, so excellent, so dangerous, so capable of divine purposes."This book makes Newman's views very clear. Why he became Catholic (and resisted doing so for so long); his attempts to chart a Via Media (Middle Way) in the Anglican Church, and how, in his view, he failed; his part in the Tractarian Movement, and the resulting controversies. The irony is that he didn't want to be followed or imitated, but after he converted to Rome, a great many Brits followed him into the Catholic Church.

This mid- '80s series is often dismissed as an "Undersea Smurfs", but it's not. Both Smurfs and Snorks have this in common, however, like Tintin, they were both Belgian comics. Snorks starts with an odd, heavy backstory about Captain Ortega's ship being attacked by pirates. A sailor finds his journal in a monastery, in which the captain tells of tiny undersea creatures, the Snorks. The rest of the show is much lighter, but it continues among other oddities. Realistic-looking fish swim by the cartoon characters, and sometimes attack them. In the last of the 13  episodes in this set, a whale is mistakenly called a "killer whale", slang for an Orca, but they might mean simply that the whale is a killer, since it attacks another whale. Each episode consists of two cartoons. The set includes two one-sided discs, with no extras. Another oddity is that the Snorks sometimes glimpse humans, or vice versa.Their own world is very well realized, with a full cast of characters. They can be jet-propelled using the snork on their heads, in the manner of a squid. Allstar, the main character, has a faithful doglike pet octopus, Occy, voiced by Frank Welker, who also voices Tooter, a character who communicates by means of sounds, in the manner of Gerald McBoing Boing. The full cast is rounded out, somewhat like the Flintstones, and played against dazzling, bright undersea backdrops. The characters are well-drawn, well-developed and likable, with the exception of Junior, the mayor's son, who is sort of like Reggie in Archie comics. His schemes are foiled in ways that arise naturally in the stories, and the good nature of the other characters wins the day. All in all, this is a delightful series, far above most cartoons of its time.

The BBC need not wait for Father Brown to consign it to hell. I'll do it now. They've ruined everything innocent they've touched. Blandings, a travesty of Wodehouse, the new Dr. Who with all it's trickier than thou tired ulterior motives and not so hidden agendas, and now trashing Chesterton's sleuth, Father Brown, with unwatchable, unthinkable, unimaginable rubbish like "The Hammer of God". Chesterton wrote plenty of stories. It's not necessary for the worst writers of today to write others, nor the worst directors to dirty them up, nor stick in their trashy anti-male biases. Nor is it in any way an advance that they have found their way behind a camera instead of on a shrink's couch or at a confessional where they belong.One had hoped that the BBC might at least make an attempt at this series. ITV/ Granada managed to make out a decent two seasons sometime back. But then they don't have endless post-modern axes to grind, and they may know what the present BBC staff does not, that decadence makes bad art. As the real Chesterton said, "Art, like morality, consists of drawing the line somewhere," a bit of wisdom apparently lost on the BBC. Malcolm Muggeridge long ago forecasted the direction they would take in Christ and the Media Christ and the Media, but they seem determined to far outrun him over the Gadarene slope. Despite the fact that I love watching Top Gear, I'd never watch BBC America, because like so many American channels, its directors seem incapable of drawing the line somewhere. Fortunately, anyone literate can simply read the real Father Brown stories (and the many novels and mysteries not featuring Father Brown) by Chesterton, and avoid the BBC's failed versions altogether. Father Brown:The Complete Collection, The Complete Father Brown Stories.

Why did I name this review 'Thank You Jeeves'? Because I imagine that lifesaver bringing self this book on a salver, somewhere near the end of an imaginary novel in which I've had the ghastly task of wading through numerous Wodehouse bios by critics who don't "get it". Jeeves pulls yours truly from the muligatawny by bringing in this work by Mr. Green. "Thank you Jeeves," I remark, cleverly providing the book title, "you are a lifesaver".Critics are forever attempting to dissect Wodehouse like some museum piece, claiming to unearth endless mysteries. But to anyone who's read and keeps reading Wodehouse, which is to say, likes reading him, the biggest mystery is how the critics seem to just not get it. The best example is the McCrum bio, of which it may be said that the tone is nothing like a Wodehouse book, and its author seems to be always looking over his shoulder at his other little playmate critics in the schoolyard, which alone accounts for such a blinkered bio. Wodehouse would more charitably say that with a Scottish name, McCrum probably got his disposition from wrestling with the harsh realities of St. Andrews and his times of testing on the links. But back to B.G..I wondered what earned the subtitle "A Literary Biography", and it is simply this. This is a book for those who already have read, or rather immersed themselves in Wodehouse. Mr. Green feels free to drop names constantly, but the lineage of these names lies in the novels. Or short stories. Or musicals. Or somewhere.That already will stave off those who are saying "Wodehouse who?" but there's a bit more. Mr. Green is, I surmise, British, and his book uses British spellings, which will fascinate Wodehouse readers who track down the British editions. But where other biographers try to simplify their endless arguments and discoveries into facts, facts, and more facts, Mr. Green goes the other way. He has a great many unknown facts at his fingertips, but he uses them to effortlessly springboard into the novels, there to find parallels with bits in Plum's life, but far more often to exult with the reader in what he finds there. I really thought I had read all that could be said about the Berlin Broadcasts, but no, I found more here. Green somehow manages to quote and cite far more interesting critics with far more interesting quotes that have escaped the other biographers I've read.That said, I ought to give a word of warning, that this book is harder to read than a Wodehouse book, even though at times it almost seems to be one, so lyrical is its prose. In its favor, I merely note that it is well worth reading. The Epilogue closes with a quote from Frank Swinnerton, which seems a decent summing up of Wodehouse in his era (and continuing into ours) "in a period when laughter has been difficult, he has made men laugh without shame."Not that I think everything else on Wodehouse is bad. I don't at all. Donaldson's is a very decent biography, and one of the first P.G.Wodehouse: The Authorised Biography, also the brief one by Connolly P.G.Wodehouse: An Illustrated Biography, and Jasen P.G. Wodehouse: Portrait of a Master. Malcolm Muggeridge has written of him in numerous places, including "The Wodehouse Affair" The Most of Malcolm Muggeridge. A decent short introduction (under 90 pages) is given by Warren Wind The World of P.G. Wodehouse, not to mention the not-to-be-missed guide by Usborne Plum Sauce: A  P. G. Wodehouse Companion.

I never thought I'd be awarding this sort of movie five stars, but this is five stars. The characters are not cardboard cut-outs. The various stories intertwine as in a novel, the photography is excellent. There's even a bit of cinema verite, with the band Newsboys playing themselves. I thought the philosophy part would be a bit hackneyed, or at least simplified, but it's really not. I've read the books mentioned, and the film's writer did a good job representing those philosophies. Before I read Richard Dawkins' The God Delusion, I assumed there were some rather good arguments against the existence of God. Reading it convinced me there weren't any, or if there are, Dawkins is unaware of them.The striking similarity of the Genesis creation story and the Big Bang has been previously pointed out by astronomer Robert Jastrow in God and the Astronomers God and the Astronomers (New and Expanded Edition). Philosopher Richard Purtill, author of Reason to Believe Reason to Believe: Why Faith Makes Sense thought it was a good film, and pointed out that if Steven Hawking is an atheist, it might be noted that in occupying the chair of Sir Isaac Newton, he is occupying the chair of a theist (Newton believed in God). The film also alludes to the fact that if agnostics were earnest in the last century, in this century, atheism is often adopted out of convenience or as a default position (as when students signed the statement in the philosophy class in the film.As for the extras on the DVD, they include two excellent music videos, and a bit on students' right to religious freedom on university campuses, something also addressed in the earlier documentary with Ben Stein, Expelled Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed. While it's not a point by point rebuttal, David Berlinski's book The Devil's Delusion The Devil's Delusion: Atheism and its Scientific Pretensions is an engaging discussion of some of these questions, and plays off of Dawkins' title. Philosopher Peter Kreeft has written numerous books, but a few are highly readable explorations of basic philosophical questions, such as The Best Things in Life The Best Things in Life. An extremely readable book dealing with some of the science surrounding the Big Bang in relation to the existence of God and similar questions is The New Story of Science The New Story of Science.Mortimer Adler, editor of the Great Books, offered a proof of the existence of God in How to Prove There Is a God: Mortimer J. Adler's Writings and Thoughts About God, but admitted that once you've done that, it's still only a philosophical proof. Philosopher Anthony Flew, the last century's most celebrated atheist, one the other hand, gives a readable and engrossing account of his conversion in There is a God There Is a God: How the World's Most Notorious Atheist Changed His Mind, and finds in this realization, as do characters in the film, a cause for celebration.

I don't know who this book is for. Post-literates (people who don't choose to read) won't read it. There are some thought-provoking questions at the end of the brief chapters, but Turner rightly realizes that they need some back story. The problem with media criticism is one encounters media in the middle (which is what it means), immediately and now, when to get any grip on it one needs to go back to its beginnings. A Canadian Catholic named Marshall McLuhan already said all that in the '60s, but he did so in a way that was sometimes confusing and complex. Unpacking his short, pithy quips leads to much longer studies like this one.But it's not really a study. Turner is at his best relating his personal stories (which he could do forever as he knows everyone), as he does in his best books like The Gospel According to the Beatles The Gospel According to the Beatles and Imagine Imagine: A Vision for Christians in the Arts. He can't simply do that here because it's an InterVarsity Press book. Therefore it has to be about some mix of culture and faith. The chapter on "popular culture" in the Bible seems to interrupt the book, although it's actually quite good. The Bible doesn't say a lot about what we now consider popular culture, he says, the reason being because it's only existed since the dawn of what McLuhan calls "the electric environment".I would consider this book an impossible one to write, especially the way Turner breaks it out into different media-- movies, advertising, fashion (which I would not think of including), when it seems to me certain forms of pop culture have more in common than not. He's certainly right to warn the innocent of ulterior motives of writers, hidden agendas in movies, that music is made for money, and the rest of the dark side of being on the receiving end of pop culture. Perhaps for that reason I preferred his book Imagine, about being on the giving side of pop culture. But there's something else here. It seems to me that since the writing of that book and this book, Turner has become untethered. He continually refers to his church, but it doesn't seem to make any difference. I would call him a post-Anglican, except that's just a stereotype I may have since he is British. He may have never been Anglican. But, as many others of us have done, he seems to run up against the problem of being your own pope.He quotes the right people, like Malcolm Muggeridge, but fails to mention MM's book, Christ and the Media Christ and the Media as a brief but incisive (and shocking, because unexpected) exploration of the same topic. He asks about "good and bad" in relation to pop culture, but knows full well that has been simply explored by Francis Schaeffer in his booklet, Art and the Bible (InterVarsity Press) Art and the Bible (IVP Classics). Visual art has been explored by Turner's friend and fellow Brit, musician and poet Steve Scott, in Crying for a Vision Crying for a Vision and Other Essays: The Collected Steve Scott Vol. One. The websites to explore seem to be almost randomly cut and pasted from the Internet, and the entire book has a rushed feel to it. I wondered why Turner would use one of the worst Bible translations, the NRSV, when the RSV is one of the best, but one finds out as one reads along. The RSV is not lost in the modern world, however. It is the foundation of the ESV, and the Ignatius Catholic Study Bible is based on the British RSV.I don't know if other readers will consider this book rambling. It sort of is, but that's the part I like. It's somewhat Steve thinking out loud. Although he confesses his diffidence and misgivings in the introduction, he pretty much opts to charge in, full speed ahead. This produces chapters that seem too telegraphic, sprinkled with anecdotes which seem too few, with overarching conclusions that seem too broad. But there's almost no way to start media criticism except with a question. There's no way to climb a mountain except with a first step. And part of the illusion of media is to seem so massive and all-encompassing, so impenetrable that it becomes synonymous with reality. Turner helps us at least notice the man behind the curtain. And that's a start.

Why did I give the first Alice Faye box set four stars and this one five? No real reason. Maybe because there were four films in that set and five in this one (which seems like a better deal), or maybe because I like these somewhat better. Maybe they could both average out to four and a half. Once again, I give Leonard Maltin's views from his Classic Movie Guide (this is the edition I actually read, but there is a later, expanded edition) Leonard Maltin's Classic Movie Guide, followed by my own impressions.Rose of Washington Square. B&W, 1939. LM says, "so-so musical", and gives it two and a half stars. I sort of agree and sort of don't. LM has watched lots of musicals, but I never tire of them. This is a musical within a musical (as so many of these films tend to be), this one set in the '20s during Prohibition. Alice Faye is fantastic with Tyrone Power, and it's great to see William Frawley from I Love Lucy in this film.Hollywood Cavalcade. B&W and color, 1939. "Colorful film starts out fun", says LM, giving it two and a half stars. Why B&W and color? Because the setting this time is 1913, the beginning of slapstick comedy (and the end of it). LM thinks the slapstick was well done. I didn't really, but then there's so much great stuff from Buster Keaton, Harold Lloyd and others of the silent era that can likely not be bettered.The Great American Broadcast. B&W, 1941. LM says, "Entertaining...bright cast", giving it two and a half stars. My own view is that John Payne is fantastic, while Jack Oakie falls somewhat flat. But there are plenty of other acts that more than make up for it. Alice is the bombshell at the birth of radio, or rather of radio as a means of entertainment, but it's a very visual film.Hello Frisco Hello. Color, 1943. LM did not like this film, calling it "a hackneyed musicomedy...a big comedown from earlier musicals for this trio," and gave it two stars. Perhaps so, but I liked it immensely. John Payne and Alice Faye are once again amazing together. What more do you need? The setting this time is the gold rush, and it does sort of seem like a comic western. Similar ground was worked later by Disney in The Happiest Millionaire Disney 4-Movie Collection: Classics (Gnome-Mobile / Darby O'gill & Little People / One & Only Genuine Family / Happiest Millionaire).Four Jills in a Jeep. B&W, 1944. LM gives it two and a half stars and says, "some good musical moments". Phil Silvers for some reason overacts, unlike when he later played almost the same role in Sgt Bilko (the Phil Silvers Show) Sgt. Bilko: The Phil Silvers Show-50th Anniversary Edition. This film introduces Dick Haymes, who would go on to star in such xlnt films as St. Benny the Dip Classic Comedy Triple Feature, Vol. 2 - St. Benny the Dip / Behave Yourself / Topper Returns, and her plays a singing soldier. In this film about the first female USO performers, both Carmen Miranda and Alice Faye reprise their best songs from the other films.This box set holds five one-sided discs in snap cases, with one booklet for all five films.

Having come upon this set in the manner of one watching Turner Classic Movies, having no idea of who Alice Faye was, but hoping for some light entertainment, I can say I was not disappointed. I cannot add any bio. or tech. detail about the actress or these films, so I merely note Leonard Maltin's reviews in his Classic Movie Guide Leonard Maltin's Classic Movie Guide and give my own brief impression.Lilian Russell. LM calls this a "strained bio." and gives it two stars. It's in black and white, from 1940, and carries a disclaimer that this is the best print they could find. It's the only one of these films that seems chopped up and the only one I didn't watch all the way through.On the Avenue. B&W, 1937. LM calls this a "tasteful, intelligent musical" and gives it three stars (the highest rating of the four films in this set). I'm inclined to agree. It's also full of catchy Irving Berlin tunes. Many reviewers say Alice Faye has an amazing voice, and I'm inclined to agree. Her singing style seems effortless and unforced, with her staring straight ahead. It's very compelling and refreshing after so much overdone singing in so many musicals.That Night in Rio. Technicolor, 1941. LM calls it a "Standard Fox musical of mistaken identities," awarding two and a half stars. Perhaps so, but I found it rather decent and amusing. After all, aren't all of Wodehouse's novels the same story? Yet the endless variations are endlessly compelling. And Carmen Miranda is a ball of fire. Don Ameche plays his two roles rather well as well.The Gang's All Here. Color, 1943. LM calls this a "visually dazzling wartime musical", and gives it two and a half stars.Well-packaged with four one-sided discs in individual snap cases in a box set, with individual four page booklets on each film, and extras (most of which I didn't watch). There's also a second box set, this one with five Alice Faye films (see my review) Alice Faye Collection 2 (Rose of Washington Square/Hollywood Cavalcade/The Great American Broadcast/Hello, Frisco, Hello/Four Jills in a Jeep) (Full Chk Gift)

How can it possibly be that a collection of the most intriguing British writer of the 20th century could rate less than five stars? Merely due to, as another reviewer has already noted, the lack of attribution, which means where something is from. The reason the Internet is largely a random rumor mill is due to lack of attribution. Without knowing where something comes from you can't track it down, and whoever wrote or said it can't be held accountable. That probably seems neither here nor there, but this book provides a very concrete example of why it matters.It is simply this. The form or layout or style of this book varies slightly entry to entry (day to day), but for the most part it runs something like this: A Bible verse, then a tiny shred (from Chesterton),  followed by a larger shred from Chesterton. The Bible verse, we are told, comes from the King James (Authorized) version of the Bible (probably from 1611 or 1625). However, the interesting front note advises us that verses marked NKJV are from the New King James Version, the copyright for which happens to belong to Thomas Nelson publishers, who also published this book. That's a very convenient thing to do, and is often done, and it's not a problem. We are told where in the Bible each verse comes from, in other words, its attribution. You can look it up yourself, if so inclined (and you might be, because the Shakespearean language of the KJV is very beautiful, and the NKJV brings it a bit up to date by dropping out the "Thees" and "Thous").So you'd think or hope that the Chesterton quotes would likewise be traceable and can be tracked down. Alas and alack, no such luck. The tiny quotes under the Bible verses don't even say they're from GKC (I read about a dozen before I realized they were). The larger shred says what it's from, but not when. Unlike the Bible quote, the GKC shred doesn't cite chapter and verse. In short, you can't track it down. And the effect of a book like this is to make you want to track it down.If you're an absolute beginner regarding Chesterton (which is how we all start), this might be OK. But a great many readers drawn to this book would not be. Someone who has never spent a day or an hour with Chesterton probably would not want to spend a year with him, although he does have a way of drawing one in. Chesterton was so prolific, no one can read all of Chesterton. At least that's the view of the man who tried to do so, Dale Ahlquist, who writes and hosts a TV series on EWTN about Chesterton called "The Apostle of Common Sense", of which about four seasons are out. I have the same complaint with that show, that tantalizing nuggets are dropped right and left, with no way to pick them up as we are swept by on a whirlwind tour that leaves the viewer dazzled and dazed.Realizing this, Alquist wrote a book with the same title which considers some of Chesterton's 100 or so books so that the reader has a place to start G. K. Chesterton:  Apostle of Common Sense. He wrote another one full of brief quotes considering Chesterton's ideas Common Sense 101: Lessons from Chesterton, and then a third one looking at various aspects of his thinking The Complete Thinker: The Marvelous Mind of G.K. Chesterton. In each of these he provides a framework around the quotes and relates them to his own journey.Is that the only way to start? No, not at all. Ignatius Press has set itself the possibly impossible task of publishing all the Chesterton in collected volumes, and they have quite a few out. Shoot for the moon, as they say, and if you miss, you may fall among the stars (which you wouldn't because stars are further out than the moon, but you get the idea). I discovered GKC in college in a book of non-fiction essays, of which his was the most intriguing, and which I never forgot. It was called "On Lying in Bed", and there are numerous collections of his essays, like this recent one, In Defense of Sanity: The Best Essays of G.K. Chesterton.However, almost no one would pick up an essay collection by an unknown writer right out of the box. A great many people (I know one) likely come upon GKC through his novels and short stories, particularly the Father Brown mysteries, which were made into British TV shows in the mid-seventies, and have been so recently again by the BBC. I can't even begin to link to all of them. Arguably, if you did come across a particularly engaging, enticing or challenging quote in this volume during your year with Chesterton, the longer bits have at least the name of the book or article at the bottom. And if the downside of the Internet is its lack of attribution, the upside is that it will probably put you, as in a Father Brown mystery, on the trail.

I saw Roy Schoeman on "Journey Home", a TV program on the EWTN network. Many guests have interesting stories about their spiritual journeys, but few are as articulate, literate, and at ease telling them. Especially since the second half of the show has viewers call in or e-mail questions which, I should think, would be somewhat unnerving. But Schoeman also turned out to be the author of a book called Salvation is From the Jews which I had just read, with the intriguing subtitle: "The role of Judaism in salvation history from Abraham to the second coming" Salvation Is from the Jews. That sounds like a long period of time. Does he skip over the ghastly anti-semitism of some places and times? No, he does not. There is a chapter on the roots of Nazism for example, also documented in this book by another Jewish author The Myth of Hitler's Pope: Pope Pius XII And His Secret War Against Nazi Germany.So I was very excited to find Honey from the Rock, and to hear about more people's journeys, but it wasn't what I expected. The first two accounts are from the 19th century, and the first one, that of Alphonse Ratisbonne, Schoeman himself translated from the French. Both of them are painful to read due to incidents of anti-semitism. But both are also amazingly supernatural. Over half of the writers in this collection are from the current era. When I had nearly finished the book, I saw one of the authors on the Journey Home TV show, which could date from some time back, as EWTN re-airs shows from the past as the program is so popular. The host, Marcus Grodi, also has compiled some of the stories in a book, Journeys Home Journeys Home.I would say this book is directed toward Catholics due to the subtitle: "Sixteen Jews find the sweetness of Christ". And they may find it eye-opening, as I did. However, it could just as well say "the sweetness of the Messiah", because "Christ" isn't Jesus' last name, it's the Greek word for Messiah, and both words mean "anointed one". If the name "Jesus" is a stumbling block, it could be Joshua, as it's the same name, or in Hebrew, Yeshua. That's one thing I learned in this book. Nearly all of the members of the early church (which means assembly) led by St. Peter (the first pope) were Jewish. Mary and Joseph, both Jewish, were both descendants of King David, so their son, Yeshua, was in that lineage. I could go on all day about the numerous fulfilled prophecies, but the sixteen authors in this book put it so much better.

The "hard choices" of the present era are those forced on Americans by H. Clinton. She is not making them, we are. All of the bad ideas the current president has put into place are actually hers. His first day in office he put into action her agenda, which had been fought down, voted down and turned down many times before. Her vastly unpopular FOCA bill which, for instance, every Catholic congregation wrote against to their representatives and congresspersons, was systematically put through in pieces as riders on other bills, beginning with the children's health act.She is also behind the HHS Mandate. Mandate, mind you, as in mandatory. Not voluntary. Not voted in. Mandated in the fashion of a totalitarian government. Never mind that it's anti-conscience, anti-life, anti-choice, anti-freedom. If H. Clinton can force through a bill, as she has been doing ever since the Clinton's law practice in Arkansas, she will. If she can blackmail world leaders in an official capacity, she will. If she can send up a smoke screen to cover it all in this book, she will. Don't make it worse by giving her money for her book. She doesn't need it. She's already found numerous ways to take your money from you. The current president merely obliged.When Planned Parenthood gave her its Margaret Sanger award, she perhaps didn't know that the founder of PP was anti-Jew, anti-Black, and anti-Catholic. Maybe they didn't know. Maybe they don't care. Maybe it means nothing to them that Sanger traveled to Germany and gave her approval of the eugenics program that led to the Final Solution, and which PP carries on today. If that seems entirely in conflict with her supposed Methodist faith, maybe again H. Clinton simply doesn't care. After all, Nancy Pelosi doesn't seem to know what it means to be a Catholic, or not the sort that listen to the pope.The saddest part of it may be that she pretends to represent women, despite the great number who see through her machinations, and expects them to support her. Certainly the vocal ones in the media seem to, but then reporters are seldom mistaken for deep thinkers. It seems like a million years ago when Bill Clinton was in office. At that time the leading atheist of the day was so anti-Clinton that Christopher Hitchens wrote an expose of them No One Left To Lie To Publisher: Verso. Apparently there are plenty of people left to lie to. For some reason, although she's managed to do everything up 'till now without a popular vote and by simply forcing her way through, she can't seem to just take over the country. So there's talk of her trying to run for president. That's one bad idea the people will have a chance to veto for reasons you won't find in this book. And it's an easy choice.

Chesterton wrote the first Father Brown story in 1911. It was the first thing he wrote that clicked with the British public. The amazing thing is that 100 years later, it's still clicking. This series aired on PBS Mystery! in the states forty years ago. Just now have the two series been collected by Acorn Media into one four disc DVD set. Unlike a great many shows from the '70s, this one is still eminently watchable. One reason is that it was set in the 'tens and 'twenties, and thus has a period look. Another reason is that Chesterton is his own animal. This series tantalizingly draws one in, and makes one want to read the stories. Penguin released its five individual Father Brown paperbacks in a box set in 1982, featuring Kenneth More from this series as Father Brown on the covers. These four one-sided discs are the same ones that appeared in the two disc individual sets for season one (purple) and season two (green).My favorite episodes in this series are those with Flambeau, because I think he and Father Brown make good sidekicks. But I confess to being very taken with Chesterton's short stories  that don't feature Father Brown. These include Four Faultless Felons Four Faultless Felons, The Club of Queer Trades (which may not actually be mysteries in the strict sense) The Club of Queer Trades, The Poet and the Lunatics The Poet and the Lunatics: Episodes in the Life of Gabriel Gale (Dover Books on Literature & Drama), and The Paradoxes of Mr. Pond The Paradoxes of Mr. Pond (Dover Books on Literature & Drama). Of his novels, my favorite is The Ball and the Cross The Ball and the Cross. Second probably The Flying Inn The Flying Inn. Orthodoxy, which reads like a novel, is, in my view, one of the best non-fiction books ever written Orthodoxy.There aren't many other authors from a century ago one can easily read, or who move so seamlessly to television. As of this writing, I've not seen the new BBC Father Brown shows, and cannot vouch for them, but this shows that in these 13 episodes from forty years ago, which only covered about one fourth of the Father Brown stories, Kenneth More has whetted viewers appetites for more.

I almost called this review "After Alwyn", as Red Alert came out after Malcolm and Alwyn had gone their separate ways, both continuing to make amazing music and follow their callings. First, about M and A. Their two records were truly amazing. Fool's Wisdom is an eternal gem from the Jesus Music/ Calvary Chapel era that I and about a million other people will always love Fool's Wisdom Wildwall. The next album, Wildwall, isn't overall as strong, but it has a couple amazing songs, first and foremost, the anthemic ballad, "England Goodbye", which is almost like Barry McGuire's hit "Eve of Destruction" written by P.F. Sloan. Larry Norman produced an album of Alwyn Wall Band, and in the little-known double Myrrh sampler album, Jubilation, there's a Norman song called "Dear Malcolm, Dear Alwyn". See how witty that Wildwall title was, combining the names of Malcom Wild and Alwyn Wall, with the refrain, "the writing's on the Wildwall"?But I digress. Maranatha (or some associated label imprint like A&S) released a stellar sampler album called "Back to the Rock", certainly rockier than the series of also good Marantha! albums, which introduced Malcolm and the Mirrors, along with other artists such as the Altar Boys and Undercover and Leslie Phillips (AKA Sam Phillips) to the wider world beyond Southern California (thank you from the other 49 states). Another album that did that was "What's Shakin'" a new wave sort of sampler on the MRC (Ministry Resource Center) label released in the mid-80s. That said, the subject matter of this disc is still unique. The title song is about Cheyenne Mountain, the failsafe missile base set up as a US defensive during the cold war. My favorite song on this disc is "She's Going to Go Through Changes". This is one of those Maranatha discs that seem to be different on side A and B, and some people may think the new wave on the flip side is too subtle and restrained. But so was most of the early new wave introduced on "Night Tracks" on Ted Turner's Superstation, and on fledgling MTV.Anyway, this is, to my mind, another great album lost in time, and one which I greatly wish was on CD (a slightly later technology than records). If the world ever gets tired of decadence and glitz and overproduction, it might for some reason enter some post-apocalyptic phase where it longs for something innocent, and in that empty space can hear again simple, creative artists in a fresh and new way. Or, if you don't want to wait that long, you could hear it now.

This hardback is really an 82 page essay (93 counting the index). This is the only reason it gets four stars. But that's not a fault. "Lightly" is the style of PGW, and the right style for a bio of him, not, in my view, like McCrum's, which is anything but light, and in my view again, completely misses the Wodehouse sensibility. If you miss that, you've missed it all, and I'm quite certain that's why we read him. If you like reading brief books anyway, if you love the form of the essay, if you want a well-written book you can read in one sitting, or a couple if you like to lounge with a libation, Wodehouse style, as you read, here you go. Don't pay too much for this book, but if it's the sort of book you like, don't miss it either.Well, are there any other good, and a bit longer bios with the Wodehouse sensibility? Luckily, there are. Donaldson's, Jansen's, and Connolly's are all highly recommended. My edition of The World of Wodehouse, published by Hutchinson in 1981 (reprinted from 1971) has a red cover with a black and white picture of PGW in one of the cars he crashed (he drove no better than some of the characters in his novels). The red cover looks rather better than the one shown here. Since Wodehouse's own stories and novels kept being collected in volumes with titles like "The World of Jeeves", this book is easy to miss in the plethora of similarly-titled collections. Here are some links for some of the above-mentioned books, not that I'm suggesting paying a ridiculous price merely because they may be out of print. P G WODEHOUSE - A Biography; P.G. Wodehouse: Portrait of a Master, Wodehouse (Life & Times Series). There's also a quite decent piece by Malcolm Muggeridge on the Berlin Broadcasts, which everyone wonders about, called "The Wodehouse Affair" The Most of Malcolm Muggeridge.

There are three ways to view this 350 page, hardback, color-drenched, oversize coffee table book. One is as a dazzlingly attractive, endlessly fascinating art book, all the better because so much of it will be familiar to anyone who's ever had the good fortune to see Rocky and Bullwinkle, George of the Jungle, or even Quisp or Captain Crunch on TV, which is at least a million of us. The second is to read the captions under all the pictures, which will make you wonder about the amazing talents that produced this amazing art. The third is to read the book, which I might term "The Writing About the Art of Jay Ward Productions. Coffee table books are usually quickly-produced, cut and paste productions, you note. Yes, but as anyone who had the good fortune to read his book "Mister Magoo's Christmas Carol" knows, not when the author is DVC.DVC is a one-man Wikipedia. He doesn't just edit these books, he writes a compendium of tributes to the unsung heroes behind the scenes, and sings them in an ecstatic, enthralling way. Not only animators, but designers, layout persons, directors, and artists. He also explains the difference between theatrical animation and TV cartoons, and the difference it made and makes. The only other book I've read that deals with the exigencies of TV cartoons this well is Joe Murray's Creating Animated Cartoons With Character. See also my Amazon Guide, which I'll write after this review, because this new, stripped down way to write reviews on Amazon doesn't seem to let you link to other products, like Joe Murray's book. I think I'll call it a guide to Darrell Van Citters, although I don't pretend it will be exhaustive, as his work is everywhere I look.I merely note that since the Magoo book, published only last year, is already being scalped for ridiculous amounts on Amazon, it's time to republish it at a reasonable price. So, you cartoon buffs, get this book now at Amazon's great price, which will enable Oxberry Press to republish the other book. Win, win. And here's a third win. At a time when major publishers insist they need to make their coffee table books in China, Oxberry managed to create this one in the Great White North, aka Canada (Dover Press even manages to make their books in Canada's southern neighbor, the USA). And I bet your first act upon closing "The Art of Jay Ward Productions" and the writing of DVC will be to track down the cartoons of Moose and Squirrel.

In his excellent book about reading, An Experiment in Criticism An Experiment in Criticism (Canto), C.S. Lewis made an argument that there are different kinds of readers. Whether you view this as three or five stars will depend on what sort of reader you are. This is the Lewis for those who read The Discarded Image The Discarded Image: An Introduction to Medieval and Renaissance Literature (Canto Classics) and his volume on sixteenth century literature English Literature in the Sixteenth Century. Lewis was chair of Mediaeval and Renaissance Literature at Cambridge, and in a certain sense, these reviews center around classical and English literature, but at one remove, with Lewis reviewing someone's book on an Arthurian tale. What's interesting about this is it puts you in Lewis' own milieu, interacting with the authors and ideas, through books, of his day. It's also interesting to note who published these reviews. Many were in the Oxford Magazine or "Theology". The new essay here was written for T.S. Eliot, editor of "The New Criterion".This essay makes some interesting points, and seems to me to go with The Abolition of Man The Abolition of Man. although I found it more readable than that book, which always seemed to me to be an answer to a controversy I know nothing about. Fortunately, Cambridge Press/ Canto has enabled the "Look Inside" feature, so a prospective reader can scan the contents. I was interested to read reviews of authors I've read other books by, but I'd have liked Lewis to have reviewed other books by them, such as George Steiner's "In Bluebeard's Castle" and Denis de Rougemont's "Love Declared". General readers may enjoy the four reviews of his friend, Tolkien's, books, and some, like me, the reviews of Charles Williams' poetry. The best writing on that, however is the preface from "Essays Presented to Charles Williams", the entire book being well-worth reading Essays Presented to Charles Williams.So now we come to more likely readers for this collection. Those who are reading Milton, or the same person writing about Milton whom Lewis here reviews. Or Spenser, or The Odyssey. Almost everywhere Lewis lets drop a brief, perceptive comment that readers will find invaluable. Another invaluable thing is the nearly forty pages of notes in the back. These would be more helpful as footnotes (and less likely to be missed), but they add immeasurably to the reviews. I have trod softly in this review, my only goal being to dissuade a certain sort of reader who reads Lewis for the stories or apologetics, and to persuade another sort of reader who favors the academic side. As an example of the second sort, a philosophy professor, on hearing I had obtained this volume, immediately asked to borrow it.

In a novel by P.G. Wodehouse, Bertie Wooster refers to "hymns, ancient and modern". This reminds me of when Larry Norman said that the musicians of his time may be writing the hymns of tomorrow. His prediction has certainly come true in non-denominational churches which feature a worship band or team, and in Catholic youth Masses, not the sort from the '60s, but new ones called Lifeteen. However, most "Jesus Music" was not really that. What it was was very individual, finely crafted rock music, at least as varied and expressive as anything now, much less overproduced, overarranged, and overeyerythinged than is pop music today, whether it passes as country or rock.I still have this record, but I just played the CD in my car, because it's much easier to do. It's only new listeners who have revived the sensibilities of records (and more power to them!). I gave this a five, but anyone may disagree, because this music is so personal (not private but, individual), so, to my mind, artistic, and creative. When records existed, I only owned, and then played a few, and played them every day. This is another album that reminds me that the hippie lifestyle was about seeking. Almost everything was good about it, despite the fact that it is denounced today as hopelessly naive. I learn from the notes in the CD liner that Mike Johnson was involved with InterVarsity, a sort of college fellowship group attracting thinking people, with an emphasis on missions, and which still provides books through InterVarsity Press. Back to the CD. Let me say why for me it's a five.What it instantly reminds me of is one of the best albums of that era, White Horse, by Michael O'Martian White Horse, who was himself involved with another college outreach group, Campus Crusade. Both these groups predate the hippie/ Jesus Movement time, and had, if anything, a harder sell, to the ridiculous Esquire/ frat/ Playboy/ sexual revolution culture, the heirs of which run TV and most other media today (which is probably why most of it is so boring, uncreative, corporate, and a waste of time compared to the freshness of this music and this era. Like so many other groups and bands of the time, Mike Johnson was an original, and this is his best CD, in my opinion. It has two elements almost missing from music today-- he's an intellectual and the music is seeped in jazz. There's also the sort of loose, joyful playing that has been beaten out of anything tagged with the cookie cutter label ccm, which is why so many would dismiss this CD out of hand (guilt by association). The CD ends with an extremely decent instrumental jazz bit which I used to play everyday.This last cut puts it in the camp of the amazing creative mavericks who refused to play the ccm game, at least early on, like James Vincent, whose first album (the name escapes me) is a stellar example of this sort of creativity. Another name is Jeff Johnson, in his vocal albums, beginning with The Face of the Deep, continuing through Pilgrimage and the like. I also think of that unheard benchmark of amazing psychedelia, "Awaiting Your Reply" by Resurrection Band Awaiting Your Reply / Resurrection Band One song reminds me of Country Joe and the Fish (without the Fish cheer that begins their Woodstock set), leaning a bit toward Canned Heat and, yes, some Dylan.The other early releases on Born Twice Records show how incredibly varied this era of music was. They include three albums I had records of: Amaziah (formerly released on Tunesmith Records) Straight Talker; Daniel Amos' "Shotgun Angel" Shotgun Angel  which came out of the Calvary Chapel cornucopia of music, bands and creativity, the like of which has never been seen again; and Bill Mason Band's "No Sham" No Sham , an original British punk rock band/ album, the songs of which even how I could sing (as much as one can sing punk songs). If I had my druthers, I'd wish for someone to release even more obscure music, my favorite being Malcom and the Mirrors' "Red Alert" Red Alert, which also came from the Calvary Chapel renaissance. Will you be disappointed by this Mike Johnson CD? You might, for the simple reason that it doesn't sound like everything else. Some of us think that's a good thing. Anyone interested in the rest of the story might consider Mark Powell's excellent volume (great writing, bad publisher-forced title) Encyclopedia of Contemporary Christian Music [With CDROM] (Recent Releases).

When Walt Disney saw Mr. Magoo's Christmas Carol, the first animated Christmas special, airing in 1962, he called up Lee Mishkin to tell him how wonderful he thought it was, and to say it would endure from generation to generation, to be watched with his grandkids and ever after. It's been over fifty years, and Walt's been proved right. The only thing that could improve this special would be to remaster it so the colors were as sharp and bright as half a century ago, and to provide interviews with voice actors and commentary by Darrell Van Citters, author of the definitive and delightful coffee table book that goes behind the making of the special. Done and done.This 2011 rerelease DVD edition, while very reasonably priced, includes all that and more. Darrell's book provides a marvelous addition, as two of the bonus features on the disc feature storyboards, along with the completed art from the show. Unfortunately, people are scalping the book on Amazon, at such a ridiculous price I can't even print it. One may have better luck with Van Citters' book on Jay Ward Studio art, which is just being released at the end of 2013. All I can say, is get it while you can The Art of Jay Ward Productions.

A great many reviewers have given this collection four or five stars. I was skeptical, but now I heartily share their views. Leonard Maltin, in his indispensable Classic Movie Guide Leonard Maltin's Classic Movie Guide gives all six of these films 2.5 or 3 stars, well in the realm of an LM thumbs up. He and these other perceptive Amazon patrons have more than covered these films, so I will just make a few comments based on my own viewing.These films are part Vaudeville, part stand-up, part radio merging into TV, part sitcom, part play, part musical, and most of all,  vehicles for singing stars like Bing, and comic entertainers of the day such as George and Gracie, of whom I can never get enough. Here's my down and dirty shooting from the hip review. First of all, it's almost a no-brainer to get this collection, since here are six films, well-packaged, for less than the usual cost of one DVD. And little-seen films. But, I promised, and here goes. "College Humor" I didn't find very funny, but "We're Not Dressing" I did. "Here is My Heart" sparkles with Roland Young, not as comic relief, but an integral part of the ensemble. Bing, it seems to me, generally plays himself, as in the "Road" pictures, but in "Mississippi," he doesn't. In fact, no one does in that film, made from a book, and in which the actors try to adhere to a story line, and which features, unfortunate roles for Black performers, including kids. "Sing You Sinners" is a quite decent little film, with Fred MacMurray and Bing as brothers, and Bing the slacker of the two. In "Welcome Stranger," Bing adheres to the role of a doctor, but seems to still play himself. A good story in the "It's a Wonderful Life" vein, with some great songs like "Smile Right Back at the Sun."It's an understatement to say they don't make movies like this anymore, but why don't they? Because these are seen as too underbudget, unpolished, impromptu and naive. But I far prefer them over bloated big-budget blockbusters with a special effects budget in the stratosphere. These are also all-family movies. Finally, a reason to own a DVD player. Keep em' coming, Universal. Thank you, Bing.

This series is at once grand and a disappointment. Despite wonderful and unforgettable characters, particularly Beach the Butler, played by Mark Williams, and Freddie, played by Jack Farthing, and Lord Emsworth, played by Timothy Spall; and despite a seemingly unlimited repertoire of witty remarks, the one thing that can be said without fear of contradiction is that Wodehouse would not have written these scripts. What he did write were a series of light, winsome, innocent novels, and it would be sad if viewers of this series who were new to Wodehouse thought the show accurately reflected his Blandings series.For here you get the some bits of the novels, but what is missing is the light, winsome, and innocent, adjectives always applicable to the books. So, instead of getting humorous viewing for all the family, you get here the sort of thing that makes BBC America so unwatchable, and for all I know, the real version in the UK is somewhat worse. This is the main reason for buying a series like this on DVD in the first place-- to avoid the tiresome excesses of ill-advised programming on such channels. This series could be saved by a judicious censor, or by inserting a bar of soap in the mouths of certain characters at certain places in the shows, but barring that, I would give this series a miss.Unimaginable as it seems, for the second time, the British Empire, or the Commonwealth, or whatever it goes by these days, has proven that it doesn't get Wodehouse's brand of gentle slapstick at all. The first time was the ghastly affair of the Berlin broadcasts. The second was and is producing such travesties as this series. Particularly the sixth and last episode in this two disc set is virtually unwatchable and unlistenable. The good news is that there is nothing in the books with this sort of language anywhere. I merely note that, as Wodehouse has outlived many other bad writers, he will outlive these at the BBC or wherever they are who are writing, as Bertie Wooster would say, "such bilge." It merely remains to be said, as readers of Wodehouse already know, and which hopefully viewers of these shows will discover, but of which writers of this series are apparently unawares, that to enter the timeless world of Wodehouse's innocent slapstick, one need merely open the books.

French comics are readily available in German or Spanish, but few have been translated into English. Why? Certainly the enthusiastic reception of Tintin in English-reading countries bodes well for other European comics as well. Here is a case in point. This is one of a handful of Spirou and Fantasio comics to appear in an English edition, and only the second one by Franquin, so far as I know. The previous comic, "Z is for Zorglub" published in the US in 1995 by Fantasy Flight Publishing is sufficient, by itself, to establish his reputation as a brilliant artist and comics writer, and is now regarded as a collector's item.Spirou and Fantasio introduced the unique and lovable Marsupilami, a cartoon featuring whom made it to American shores in a much-changed Disney version as part of the short-lived Raw Toonage show. Twenty-two artists and authors have worked on Spirou and Fantasio, we are told in the back matter of The Marsupilami Thieves, and the characters have been reinterpreted as often as Mickey Mouse. Nevertheless, it's the Belgian artist Franquin who, for two decades drew and developed this trio, as in the present volume, published by Dupuis in French in 1954. I applaud UK publisher Cinebook for making it available in English, as they have other European comics, and hope they will extend their publishing venture to the entirety of Franquin's creative endeavors, including Gaston and his other characters. As for quality, The Marsupilami Thieves (Spirou and Fantasio No. 5), showcases Franquin's art in an oversized color paperback, with an engrossing story that will enthrall lovers of Tintin and other European comics. Thank you Cinebook for bringing Franquin to our notice and our shores.

In recent years, books on the muscle-era Mopars have proliferated, in large part due to the return of cars with the Charger, Challenger, and most recently Dart nameplates. With all the lavish, color coffee table books featuring these beautiful cars, why would you want this 200 page, 12" X 8.5" black and white paperback? Merely because, as the publisher notes in the 2009 671 Press edition, those books are written today, looking backward. This book collects articles from the '60s and '70s when the cars were new, looking forward.Author Martyn L. Schorr was formerly editor for Hi Performance CARS magazine, from which these bits were taken, along with SPEED, SUPERSTOCK, and SUPERCAR publications. That's about eighty articles, ranging from test drives to racing to performance packages to wing car stats. So while this book won't win a photo contest, it does provide a unique "you are there" sense which not only recaptures the cars, but the eras they were born in.

Last Gasp Press saved Michael Farr's Tintin: The Complete Companion, Tintin: the Complete Companion by reprinting it. Now they've done likewise with Farr's Tintin and Co. The 2007 UK edition from Egmont Press is a 130 page, 12" X 9", red-jacketed hardback, which matches Egmont's English language Tintin books. Every page has black and white photographs and color frames from Tintin adventures. One reviewer complained that probably everything in this book is in the Companion. Perhaps so. But they are not the same book at all.The Companion is arranged by the 23 Tintin adventures (and one unfinished one). This book profiles a dozen characters: Tintin, Snowy, and ten more. It must be obvious that someone reading all the Tintin adventures would next reach for the Companion. But to find out when General Alcazar made his first appearance, or Rastapopoulos his last, one need only consult Tintin and Co. Somewhat easier than leafing through 24 Tintin books.Someone who likes to dive deep can delve into one of the biographies of Herge. A more casual reader may prefer the Companion. But anyone who has seen the Tintin movie or one of the animated episodes will be fascinated by this volume, which serves as a graphic invitation to the books. Lay this book on the coffee table, and I defy your guests not to pick it up. As I write, a calendar of Herge's wonderful art graces the wall above my desk. This book overflows with such perfectly composed  still shots. Enjoyment of Tintin crosses the generations, and the many families who read his adventures together will also enjoy brushing up on the backstories and inspirations of Herge's famous creation.

This thin, stainless steel door sill guard for the 2013 Dart is an easy addition. You get a set of two, one for each front door, and they install easily, thanks to self-stick tape on the back. They provide protection for the door sills and add a custom, classy look. The background is satin finish, with horizontal stripes and the word "Dart" in shiny letters to match the "Dart" logo by the taillights. Genuine Mopar part, designed for the 2013 Dart, for an easy, classy upgrade.

These black and white shows, dating mostly from the early '50s, rank among the most delightful TV I've seen in a long time. The price right now is nearly free for 38 episodes on 4 discs. Mill Creek has packaged the discs safely and economically in little paper sleeves that stack in the DVD case. The writing is simply wonderful. Witty, low-key, never snarkey. Devoid in every way of the elements that writers today feel are required in a sitcom, and which this show shows are not. Don DeFore is Oz's next door neighbor in the earlier shows, and he's a ball of fire. Many know about Rick Nelson's singing career, but David holds his own in the show quite well, and Harriet gets a lot of good lines and deadpan refrains. Since Ozzie was a bandleader, there's lots of music worked into the shows. Why not five stars? It could be five stars, simply based on entertainment value and enjoyment quotient, but these discs have not been remastered. Most shows are quite watchable, with only a few print problems. Shows also include commercials. The worst are for Listerine. The best are for Kodak (the later shows on disc four). Anyone who ever saw an episode will enjoy having this set, and some younger viewers may find themselves also drawn to the convivial Nelsons and the inviting Land of Oz.

This claims to be an expose of a secret Jewish conspiracy to undermine civilization, but it was actually written in 1897 as an anti-Jewish tract, and is a hoax. No Jewish elders had anything to do with it. But, like the anti-Catholic novels of the same period, which inevitably featured Jesuits kidnapping Protestant children, it greatly influenced the popular imagination of the time. When it was exposed, not everyone got the word. Henry Ford used his fortune to print anti-Jewish tracts which were reprinted by Hitler. The Arab Radio and Television Network produced a 41 part TV series on the Protocols. But then, in 1999, Hitler's Mein Kampf (My Plan) ranked sixth on the bestseller list of Palestinian Arabs.It may be extremely tempting to conspiracy theorists like Texe Marrs to see in the Protocols some sort of prophetic warning about Soviet Russia, but if so, some questions arise. Why was the actual text originally a satire about Napoleon III? Why were Jews made the villains when it was changed by Pyotor Ivanovich Rachovsky of the Russian secret police? Marrs' view of the Soviet Union as a Jewish dictatorship also doesn't square with history, because the Soviets were highly anti-Semitic. Rather than ending the pogroms against the Jews before the revolution, the secret police continued them, as well as blaming all the problems in the new utopia on the Jews.Jews who were downtrodden in the previous Russian regime naturally looked for better conditions to prevail after the Russian revolution. Therefore, many became communists or socialists. But they were not alone in that. Walter Duranty filled the New York Times with false stories of how the Soviet utopia had brought peace and plenty, even while forced collectivization brought famine. The only journalist to tell the true story, and that for a left wing paper, was Malcolm Muggeridge. See his autobiography Chronicles of Wasted Time. The Soviet Union of that time was not definitively exposed until Solzhenitsyn's The Gulag Archipelago The Gulag Archipelago.Chesterton apparently also believed the Protocols, although he was more concerned with Britain selling titles, making wealthy landowners nobility. However, once he saw through the propaganda, he became the first opponent of Hitler and a defender of the Jews, and used his journalistic column to urge Britain to fight Hitler, instead of giving up countries to him as a peace offering. See his autobiography from 1936 The Autobiography of G. K. Chesterton. In his book Orthodoxy Orthodoxy, Chesterton notes the contradictory arguments advanced against Christianity in his day. "It began to seem that any stick was good enough to beat Christianity with," he writes. The alarms against the Jews of his time were similarly contradictory. On one hand, the Jews were capitalists in a worldwide conspiracy. On the other, they were the socialists undermining the capitalists. You can't have it both ways. At any rate, demonizing them in a fairy tale doesn't help anyone.What actually happened during the time Marrs speaks of, and the actual conspiracy behind the writing of the Protocols hoax is, however, far more exciting and convoluted than the so-called Protocols conspiracy could ever be. That story is told in numerous places. Two of the best books that deal with it are Salvation Is from the Jews and The Myth of Hitler's Pope: Pope Pius XII And His Secret War Against Nazi Germany.

I've got the bottom model 2013 Dart, the SE, and I thought this was an upgrade I could live without. But after I saw how the Mopar rubber slush mats protected the inside (and how dirty they've since gotten), I started thinking about this mat. I didn't think for long, and ordered it that night from Steve White Motors through Amazon. It covers the entire trunk area (what Brits call the Boot), and it's exactly what it says it is-- thick, knobby black rubber with the "Dart" logo in raised letters. I didn't expect it to fit well, but it fits like a glove, and comes exactly to the edge of the trunk. The grippy back holds it in place. And it matches the floor slush mats 2012 2013 DODGE DART WEATHER RUBBER SLUSH MATS 4PCS GENUINE FACTORY MOPAR BLACK. Now the whole Dart is protected. It looks like a factory mat because it is. Genuine Mopar, the real deal, custom designed for the 2013 Dart.

If you live in a two-plate state, as I do, you need a license plate in front as well as back. This black metal license plate frame perfectly complements the recent line of Dodge cars with black grilles and the double red hash mark accent. The only color accent on my silver 2013 Dart is the red hash mark next to the front "Dodge" chrome logo. So these plates blend into the black grille and echo the tiny red accent. I considered a "Mopar" plate, but the Mopar M is blue. Would look great on a Mopar 13 or blue-striped Dodge, but for my silver car, I went for the Dodge red accent.What about the back? One could put a chrome plate on a silver car, but I think it tends to clash more, since both the plate and car are shiny and reflective, but not the same shade.
