Just a 3 out of 5. Sorry, but it really leaves you wanting for more.

My wife and I are both big fans of Ahava products. I use Ahava exclusively for shave and after-shave, and she's tried hand creams, foot creams, body creams, eye creams and loves the feel and scent.This is a review for the AHAVA Dead Sea Water Mineral Hand Cream 1.3 fl. oz. tube specifically. As with all Ahava products, it feels smooth and gentle going on, and it never leaves a greasy feel. It soothes the skin. My wife uses this hand cream especially in the winter, to keep her skin from drying out and to keep the skin on her hands from painful cracking. Sometimes she'll even go with the much more expensive "Dermud" version from Ahava, which she finds especially effective.Although the 3.4 fl. oz. tube is sized specifically to meet the TSA's 3.4 oz. limit for carry-ons, this smaller tube may be enough for you--and at this price it's a pretty good buy as Ahava products go. Yes, Ahava products are expensive. I use the tiniest amount I can get away with, and a little bit of Ahava does go a long way. As the commercials say, a little dab'll do ya! Oh, wait, that's Brylcreem, from decades long past.Last item: This particular product has a gender-neutral scent and package-design, so all of us macho guys can use it without fear of derision.

As long as your expectations are set correctly, you'll like this DII shower curtain! It's very lacy and has a pretty flower-blossom pattern throughout (or a lattice pattern, depending on which "flavor" you choose here).As for expectations, please be advised that this requires a shower liner. It's decorative but won't keep the water in your tub. It's very light and frilly and oh so delicate looking!My wife is more of a perfectionist than I am. She didn't like that the edges are frayed all around, apparently because of the way the underlying lace pattern would leave frayed threads when cut to shape. But it's polyester--not a natural fabric--so I guess they were able to heat or otherwise seal up the edges so that whatever is there will stay there and not fray and fall apart.The top edge is tape-reinforced to last awhile, and the buttonholes take shower curtain rings pretty easily.It's quite inexpensive, but you should get a year or two out of it and then you'll be able to get something else to freshen up the look of your bathroom!

Our little pink hooded towel arrived just this weekend, and I'd have to say the photos and descriptions here on the Amazon page are pretty faithful to the actual product. It's soft, yet not velvety soft; I think if it were too soft, it would be prone to pilling and matting plus it wouldn't be as absorbent. And, as always, for maximum absorbency in towels and washcloths, avoid using fabric softeners. That holds true for large, high-priced bath sheets as well as cute little baby towels like this one.I'm taking one star off a perfect 5 because our towel arrived with some pulled and/or loose threads. All the seams are tightly stitched, which seems great for long wear after multiple washings. Nevertheless, we were surprised to see a couple of pulls straight out of manufacturing and quality control, but the loose threads don't seem to compromise the structure at all. It's a good buy, though, as these were very minor imperfections in a very attractive and useful baby gift or accessory.The towel is large enough to wrap fully around baby and keep him or her warm and eventually dry, and the shape allows for easy wrapping or swaddling of baby as you get the diaper and clothes ready.

The TP-LINK AC1200 dual band router has worked very well for me. Setup was fairly easy. One thing I did was to disconnect my old router first as well as the range extender I've been using, to make sure my devices weren't picking up any signals that would confuse them or me. After reading other reviews here, I did make sure to run software/firmware updates repeatedly until everything was up to date. I'm a chronic updater anyway, so I would have gotten to that eventually regardless of other user input.I set up my MacBook, iPad, and iPhone easily enough. I made sure to put my Roku on the faster, 5 GHz channel, especially now that we're streaming HD more often. My Mac is on the faster band, too. I set up my wife's ASUS PC as well as her iPad and iPhone on the regular (2.4 GHz) band, because she does mostly emails, social networking, and low-res video (YouTube, cooking videos, etc.). We've both been satisfied with the speed. Signal strength hasn't been an issue, except in one extreme corner of our house, where the signal drops occasionally. Then again, that corner is where one of the bathrooms is, and no one in their right minds would ever bring their iPad or their iPhone into the bathroom, would they?? (heh).The unit has 3 external antennas for the higher-speed band and 3 internal antennas for the "slower" band. That helps provide a strong signal and may be the reason I haven't felt compelled to try me range extender yet. Just take your time going through the setup, think about which devices you want on which band, and do all the updates and you may have the same positive experience I had. I've learned that everyone's situation is different regarding wifi usage. We stayed with friends recently in a big-city high-rise apartment building, and when I tried to log into their wifi router I saw more networks pop up on the list than there are homes in my entire community--many with the same signal strength as their own network! That's a lot of radio waves glomming onto your device antennas! They even needed to add a range extender just to get around the corners of their small apartment in that steel-enforced building--not a problem we have here with wood frame construction. One solution certainly does not work for all circumstances, so you may have to try a few different routers before finding the one that makes itself at home in your home. Be patient.

I know the most important thing for most Amazon customers is the overall star rating of a product, so I really regret that I have to give this pretty good shower caddy only 3 stars. Here are the reasons I downgraded it:1. As others have mentioned, the shower caddy slips down over the shower arm and comes to rest against the binding nut of our shower head. That means the top of the caddy sits about an inch or so further out than the bottom of the caddy, thus the shower caddy is sloped all the time.2. The suction cups provided might have solved the problem by pulling the whole unit tight to the wall, but they simply do not stick to my Fiberglas shower enclosure.3. The wires are spaced a bit too far apart on the lowest shelf, which I would like to use for bar soap. Once the soap gets down to about 3/8 inch thickness (still plenty of soap left), the soap tends to slip down through the wire shelf and fall to the shower floor.4. Because the shower caddy slips down to rest against the tightening nut of my shower head, the upper part of it falls within the water flow from the shower head. Not ideal.Nevertheless, this is one of the best-built shower caddies I've come across. It feels substantial in both the frame and the shelves--not like a lot of the flimsy caddies you see in department stores. Also, it's great that it won't rust. That's the biggest problem we have in keeping clean-looking shower accessories like curtain rings, rods, etc.So, if you have a fairly long shower arm, one that comes out at least six inches or so horizontally from the wall, you may fare better with this than we did. The suction cups also may stick better to real tile than to the wall of our bathtub enclosure. It's worth a try if you're looking for a shower caddy that feels like it will last a long time.

The Dorman Hardware Peggable Wire Baskets are better than I even imagined! If you have a pegboard in your garage, laundry area, or other workspace, you'll find this set of three baskets to be an amazing addition. You get 3 sizes in the pack:Large: 12" x 6" x 5" and holds up to 20 lbsMedium: 8" x 5" x 4" and holds up to 10 lbsSmall: 6" x 4" x 3" and holds up to 5 lbsThat's a total of up to 35 lbs in just these 3 compact baskets! Just make sure your pegboard is securely mounted, and you're set.There's nothing about these baskets that has a cheap feel to it. They're made of heavy gauge, sturdy steel wire. The hooks anchor perfectly into my standard pegboard. Highly recommended.

The Aqua Optima Evolve filter works well as a replacement for the Mavea-brand filters in my Mavea Elemaris 9-cup pitcher. The Elemaris is the one with the curved top that has a usage meter at the top that supposedly doesn't just count down the time to replace your filter, as the simple technology in a Brita device does. The Mavea Elemaris claims to measure replacement time by tracking how much water flows into the pitcher and by measuring the hardness of your water as a factor in filter lifetime. So, if that's really true, then rarely will you find 2 people who have the same filter lifetime. Different people use vastly different amounts of filtered water (think a family of 5 with a few pets in a house with very hard water vs. a single or couple who spend little time in a home or apartment with "soft" water, for example). Given that reality, I don't know how anyone can state a general fact of how much it costs per month to use a Mavea filter.So I'm not going to comment on price.Also, if the Aqua Optima gives you a straightforward "60 Day" usage guideline, how does that account for how much filtered water your household uses, what your water hardness is, and whatever other factors may cause your filter's lifetime to vary (bacteria? chlorine levels? other chemical and microorganism levels?).So, again--at least, to me--calculating price is very confusing. To use the Mavea pitcher with the Aqua Optima filters, you have to ignore the filter countdown gauge on the pitcher and just replace the filter every 60 days. Well, I can do that with my Mavea filters, too, and that would run me maybe $4.50 to $5.00 every 60 days. So, I'm not saying whether this whole issue is a positive or a negative. I'm just sayin'...think about it...and maybe a water technician or scientist out there can elaborate on this.As to whether this replacement filter works, it does. You just pull out your old Mavea filter and put in the new Aqua Optima Evolve filter after just a little prep. They say to dip the filter into a pitcher full of water to soak it all around, then hold the filter under your running faucet for 1 minute, then place the filter in the filter cutout space in your pitcher, and you're good to go.I didn't time it, but my impression was that the water runs through this filter faster than it does through the Mavea filter, because there's one extra hole in this one. From purely a filtration standpoint, I don't know if it's good or bad that the water runs through more quickly. But it does, and you've got a full pitcher before you know it.I saved a cold glass of water that ran through my Mavea filter, and I did a taste test with the first run of water through my Aqua Optima filter. There was no discernible difference in taste. I can't even begin to analyze how effectively the respective filters worked in removing microparticles. I'll leave that for others.As far as the 60-day timer app goes, for iPhone and Android devices, this was my experience: I scanned the QR code that appears on the filter wrap, and my iPhone went through a couple of redirects to a page where I could choose Install. I did that, and it took me to the Apple App Store but led me to an app for a VPN (virtual private network) service. I scratched my head, wondering why I'd have to download a VPN app for this. So I backed out and scanned the QR code again, it took me to an Aqua Optima page that had an install button, and I pressed install again. This time it took me to some financial app in the App Store. I tried it one more time, and this time it took me to the Aqua Optima Timer app. I downloaded it, booted it up, the app asked for access to my calendar, which I allowed, and it was easy to set today's date and choose whether I wanted the 30-, 60-, or 90-day reminder. I chose 60 and that was it. After 60 days, I guess it will alert me to change the filter.But will the filter still be effective in 60 days, based on my own usage? I don't know. Would it last yet another 30 days? I don't know--your guess, or Aqua Optima's guess, is as good as mine.

I ordered the AR Blue Clean AR383S pressure washer to replace a McCulloch 1400 PSI unit here at home. The Blue Clean worked well, so I'm going to bring the McCulloch to our summer home where all I need it for is deck and siding, and it has plenty enough power for those after 6 years of light to moderate use.Out of the box, the Blue Clean was extremely easy to set up. All you really have to do is snap on a hard plastic bracket to the side of the unit, screw in the input hose adapter, and you're pretty much set for typical use. On the other end, you have to set up whatever you'd set up each time you use the machine: Screw in the output hose (I suppose you could leave it attached if you want), attach the preferred power wand (they supply 2 different ones) to the spray grip, attach your water source using the snap-on hose adapter, plug the unit into a GFCI protected outlet, set the reset button on the electrical plug, and you're ready to "rip."When you're done with your task, detach everything in reverse order, and easily stow the various pieces in the very convenient holster, reel, and rack they provide on the unit for the gun, spray hose, power wands, and power cord. It's really pretty cool and very, very easy to keep together all the pieces you'll need for your next use.I felt the power in this unit soon after I turned it on. As I said, I was used to the 1400 PSI washer I have; this one is rated up to 1800 PSI, which they say is up to 40 times the pressure from a typical garden hose. You take that pressure and drive it through a narrow power wand, and you're talking some pretty strong water flow. Be careful!Job #1: cutting through caked-on dirt on the concrete walkwayIt took me a few minutes of practice to get control over the jet spray coming from the Blue Clean. There are a lot of variables: water pressure at the spigot source; length of garden hose and whether or not it has any kinks in it; choice of power wand (more on that later); width and height of spray (for flat sprays); composition of the surface material you're washing; stubbornness of the dirt or stain or covering you're trying to remove; the angle of spray, and probably more I'm leaving out. I experimented a bit on the concrete, got a feel for the wands and the flow, and then went to work. Using a concentrated flat spray (and quickly realizing this walkway was really, really dirty, with years of caked-on silt, ice-melt/salt, lawn chemicals, and whatnot), I worked my way up and down one square of walkway. I started to reveal the real surface of the material and saw how bright, clean, and white it was under all that grit. The Blue Clean worked amazingly well. Then, it being Christmas week here in the unseasonably warm Northeast, some of my grown kids started watching, so I showed off a bit by switching to pinpoint power and wrote my name on the walkway! It shone through as almost a bright white, with no damage to the rock-hard surface. And that was without putting any kind of detergent into the detergent tank.Warning: don't try this on your deck or siding unless you want your name permanently etched into the surface. Plus, my wife didn't like the idea of having my name etched through the dirt (said it heightened awareness of just how dirty it was!).The two wands they include are the pretty standard adjustable wand, and a "turbo nozzle" for concentrated, high-pressure spray. Both worked very well and were easy to attach, detach, and control.The spray gun handle is comfortable to use, and it has a convenient lock to prevent unwanted sprays during setup, teardown, or when you're just taking a rest.AR did a great job on this Blue Clean pressure washer. It feels sturdy, and even the plastic pieces are on the heavyweight side. We'll see how well it stands up over the next few years. I expect it to do very well.

Dance & Learn is a game module from LeapFrog for use on the LeapTV console. I see that LeapFrog has just launched its LeapTV app store, so you can order this game and lots of others as a digital download, too.Dance & Learn is lots of fun for young children. It's rated for ages 4-7, but I think it can be used by a precocious 3-year-old, too, with some help from an adult or older sibling. There are many learning games to choose from in Dance & Learn, some requiring the LeapTV hand-operated controller and others using the system's camera to bring your child right onscreen into the action to interact with the graphics by choosing answers or following the graphics to lead the child through fun actions like dancing or swiping at stars or popping balloons!As with all LeapTV games that use the camera, it's really important to set up the play area with the correct lighting: the child should be well lit from the front, and there should be no glare on the camera and TV screen.Some of the Dance & Learn games focus on: making compound words; recognizing rhyming words; understanding adjectives; and blending sounds into words. The games integrate learning with fun actions like dancing, jumping, twirling, waving arms--almost all with screen-based interactivity that allows your child to make things happen and actually see themselves as part of the action onscreen. It's fun while learning!There's a lot of versatility in play, too. You can set the games for one child to play, or for up to four children to take turns playing. You can set up individual profiles on the LeapFrog website so that your children get activities appropriate for their age or grade level. You can track your child's progress and usage online, too, if you take the trouble to set up a LeapFrog account and monitor it.The list price is pretty high, but it looks like you can get a pretty decent discount here on Amazon. It looks like everything is list price on the LeapFrog app store, but some of their other games are listed there for as little as $10.This is a good active-learning game for a young child who has the LeapTV system. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

I ordered this as a Vine selection for my wife (born in the 1950s is all she wants to share about that!), and here's her review:I was surprised that this was offered as a dual-purpose oil spray: for skin and for hair. I never even thought of using the same spray for both purposes, but I decided to give this a try.For hair, I spray a small amount on my hand, rub my hands together, and then apply to my hair before drying. It dries really well and gives my hair a nice gentle texture and clean feel. I hadn't even noticed the scent till I read other reviews here. I asked my husband (that's me, the guy who's typing this!) to give it the smell test, and he couldn't smell anything till he put his nose right up against my hair. That's when he said, whoa, that other person is right! It does remind me of that beauty parlor smell my mother's hair had! But I can't smell it at all, and he says he really only smells it when his nose is right in the middle of it. So, it passes the "stink test" for both of us! My advice is: use it sparingly, just a spray in one hand, then rub it through your hair and blow-dry. No problem, nice feel! (And the typist here agrees.)I've always used things for my skin all year-round, but especially during the cold, dry winters here in the inland northeast. I applied the L'Occitane Shea Butter oil, also sparingly, to my skin after showering, and it works well while leaving no noticeable scent at all. Also, I really like that it doesn't leave my face feeling greasy, like some other oils do.So, yes, it is perfumed in some way, but if you can control your button finger and use just a teeny bit of it on hair and skin, I think you're going to like it.

The Taylor 7209 scale is sleek and shiny and would fit well with the decor of most bathrooms. The surface is a thick sheet of clear glass. The great thing about that is that it's easy to keep clean, using the same spray cleanser you'd clean your bathroom mirrors with.Be aware that the scale comes with a thin piece of plastic film that keeps the battery fresh between the time the scale leaves the factory and when it eventually gets to you. The film protrudes from the battery compartment on the bottom of the scale, but I found it difficult to just pull it out as the instructions describe. I had to open the battery compartment, which requires unscrewing two small Phillips screws. You'll need one of those mini screwdrivers to open it.Also, be aware that with this type of scale, you have to recalibrate it to zero the first time you use it and then every time you move it or even jostle it from its position on your bathroom floor. It's easy to recalibrate it. Just step on it briefly, even with one foot, and let it set to a zero display. The next time you get on it, it will display your accurate weight.We found the scale varies about 0.4 lbs. from the measurement on another digital bathroom scale we have. I think that's reasonable. You'll always have small variations between scales, unless you're working with highly calibrated, scientific devices. It's relative weight you'll want to be most concerned with here. We found that if one scale says one of us gained 0.2 lbs from the previous day, the other scale also shows a gain of 0.2 lbs, so it's consistent.One improvement we'd like to see is a lighted display. Our other scale has that, and it's a helpful feature. The weight readout is a pretty good size, though, and there's really no problem seeing it unless you want to weigh yourself in the dark!Additional features include BMI measurement, and memories to track stats for up to 4 different people.

Belkin was one of the first companies that made accessories for Apple products, going back well before Apple became the huge mass-market success it is now. So Belkin has been doing this for a long time and knows how to get it right.The product photo shows you exactly what you get: a one-port wall charger, a cigarette lighter adapter for the car, and a USB-to-Lightning cord.The shape and solid feel of the wall charger tells me that, structurally, the charger is likely to last a long time. My experience with Belkin tells me the electronics will last, too. And it's rated for 100-240V, which means you should be set for international usage as long as you bring along the necessary plug converter.2.1 Amp charging means much faster charging of iPads, and you should find faster charging of iPhones, as well.The lighter adapter is also rated at 2.1 Amps, so you'll get that fast charging the car, too.I also like that the USB/Lightning cord has a pretty sturdy feel to it. Add to all this the fact that it's Apple MFi certified, and we have a winner here!

Out of the package, these curtain rings are great. They were shiny chrome, easy to install, and slide very smoothly across our shower curtain rod. Time will tell just how rustproof they are, or how durable.

Unless and until Crayola improves this product, it's not even worth a buck. The markers color so lightly that you can barely see them. The colors are duller than dull, way muter than pastel. I can't imagine that any child would find them stimulating and enjoyable to use. The only thing that worked well was the eraser. You push the eraser head down firmly over and over again on the drawing board, over and over and over again, until it draws enough moisture from the handle to erase the barely visible markings drawn on the board. That works well. The markings come right off the board.In the Amazon description is says something like Choking Hazard!! Contains small pieces. Not for use by children under the age of 3, or something like that. So keep that in mind. The small sheet of instructions that comes with it is strewn with warnings:The marking surface is "NOT FOR USE WITH ANY OTHER CRAYOLA MARKERS." And this is not only in all caps, but boldface, too."Doodle Magic colors may affect the appearance of some surfaces. Wipe household surfaces IMMEDIATELY. Avoid using Doodle Magic near any surfaces that cannot be laundered."Wow. And "IMMEDIATELY" is also in boldface.Cleanup instructions include:"Wash hands with soap and water after use""Rinse clothing or hard surfaces with cool water. If color reappears, wash with mild soap and water."If necessary, clean outer surfaces of Lap Desk with mild soap and water. DO NOT IMMERSE."And there's more, in tiny type on the back, including:"Keep away from wallpaper, painted walls, finished and unfinished wood, vinyl, carpeting and other materials that cannot be laundered."And all this for markers that you can barely see.Fail.

The Adonit Jot Touch 4 feels like a solid, sturdy writing instrument in your hand. It's comfortable to the grip and allows for good pen control on my iPad mini.Setup was extremely easy, but with one hitch that I overcame. Instructions tell you to go to the Adonit website, where you can see the list of currently pairable apps and link over to the iTunes store to buy an app. I chose GoodNotes. I've been needing a basic handwriting and drawing app, and this looked like a GoodChoice! I couldn't find any free apps that were compatible, just to try it out, but GoodNotes was reasonably priced and it had a lot of good reviews so I went ahead with the purchase.Instructions for pairing with apps are available through the Adonit support site. Instructions basically linked you over to their YouTube channel. Here was the hitch, which I hope is short-term: When I clicked on the link to YouTube, a shadowbox opened on the Adonit page, ostensibly to allow you to view the YouTube video within the Adonit site, but the link was dead. It went nowhere, so I was left with a blank box. I tried this on my MacBook using Firefox, Safari, and Chrome, all with the same results. So I just copied the YouTube link (right-click on hyperlink and select Copy Link Location, then paste that address into your browser command line). It took me over to the Adonit channel on YouTube and I picked the video to pair up with GoodNotes. It was really, really simple, and the video was as clear as could be about how to do it. The stylus was paired up within a minute or two, no more than that, and the app responded to the stylus perfectly the first time I tried it.The app's option bar allows various pen thicknesses and colors, highlighting in various colors, drawing of perfect boxes and circles/ovals, fill-in colors. It's really a good set of features.The box includes a USB-powered charger. The charger contains a very strong magnet that holds the base of the stylus firmly and steadily during recharge. They say it takes 45 minutes, on average, to charge up, and the charge can hold for months when not in use. There is a simple green LED indicator that tells you when it's charged and when it's successfully paired. A red LED lets you know when it's not paired or not charged. There's a simple on/off switch which seems solid and works fine. The give you a screw-on cap to protect the stylus point, and they also give you an extra point. I don't know what the life expectancy of the point is.Seems pretty good so far, and they promise more apps to come soon.

The Moenflo XL Single Function Showerhead has a lean, attractive look and provides an even, steady flow. Installation was a breeze, as it's just a simple round thing you screw on over some fresh Teflon tape. At first attempt, it provided a tight seal when I turned the water on--no dripping from the seal, no reworks needed.It does tilt/swivel in all directions, so you can customize the reach and direction as you like it. "Single function," of course, means there's just one choice of flow: no water jets, no mist or spray, no pulsing. If that's okay with you--if you're just looking for a basic showerhead with a clean look, this could be the one for you.

This review is about the Bergamot and Pear "flavor" of Baxter of California's Invigorating Body Wash. As you may know, bergamot essential oil is the flavoring used in Earl Grey tea. Bergamot is a type of orange (citrus fruit), and you'd think its rind would have a tangy/citrus-y bite; but it has only a mild hint of citrus, and that's what's made Earl Grey tea such a favorite over the years.Most of us know a pear when we see one and smell one. It's one of the mildest fruity tastes and scents ever "invented"! I love a sweet, juicy pear--especially one that's ripened on the vine and freshly picked, an experience no one should miss.So it only makes sense that if Baxter put bergamot and pear together, you'd get a mild scent. And that's what you get. In fact, it's so mild that I can barely smell it. I've used it for a couple of weeks, and sometimes I start to wonder whether there's really any bergamot and pear essence in the formulation. Other times I just barely get a hint of pear.As for applying it, I still like to use my hands to apply things in the shower, whether hard soap or liquid body wash. (Now, how would that work if I didn't use my hands to soap myself up? I'm thinking about it and will update this if I come up with something.) I found that applying the wash by hand brought up no lather at all. Something about being a guy in a shower makes me want and expect that I'm going to get soap lather all over me, and I won't feel clean unless I do. The experience was more like applying a lotion and then rinsing it off. And because of that, I didn't feel like it really cleaned me. Probably just a perception thing, but there nevertheless.Next time I tried applying it with a terry washcloth. Barely a bubble. Still more like a lotion.The next day my wife tossed me an exfoliating sponge and said, here, try this. Just a few more bubbles.Next morning my wife threw a pouf at me and said, here, soapy boy, maybe this will work.And, voila, it did! Three pumps in that pouf (hmm...does that sound weird?) and I worked up a nice gentle lather all over. It rinsed off cleanly, with no lingering oily or lotion feel, and it was all good. Just as good was the fact that it didn't make the shower floor slippery--something I've experienced in testing other body washes. That's really dangerous, certainly nothing to play around with.I guess I'm just used to the deodorant soap bars with strong scents, lots of lather, and the squeaky clean skin it leaves behind. I just have to be careful to rinse the bar soap gunk off very thoroughly and then apply lotion to the areas that tend to get irritated. The Baxter wash probably leaves some good oils on your skin, and it's probably better for your skin. But I'm just guessing.Finally, the price of the Baxter wash is a bit too high for my wallet. Summary: I'd like a slightly stronger scent, I don't like having to use the pouf, it's too expensive for me, but I think it's a good product.

The product description says, "Applying pomade to dry hair helps achieve a more matte finish, while applying to wet hair will give you more of a semi-wet look." I like what they call a "matte" finish for everyday use, and I prefer the "semi-wet" look for dress-up occasions.So far I've applied Baxter of California's Soft Water Pomade very lightly to medium-short hair while it's around 2/3 of the way toward naturally dry, after I've finished my shower and shave. I apply just a little and run it through my hair with just one sweep across the front/top with my right hand and one little streak down the parted side with my left hand. Then I just shape my hair with my fingers and it sits just right, just the way I like it!As my hair has gotten increasingly (almost completely) gray, it's gotten a little more brittle, with plenty of strays and stand-ups. Baxter's keeps it in place all day long without the hard/sticky feel of gel. And, yes, it does give it a natural, matte finish, exactly the way I like it.

The first thing we did with the Bunnery Breakfast Sampler was go through all 4 varieties of their granola. My wife and I loved every one of them. The granola has a great consistency--that lightly cooked crunch that we like. It's not overly sweetened and not overly baked, so the granola forms either very small clumps or just individual oatmeal flakes. All the flavorings--fruits, nuts, seasonings, etc.--taste fresh and natural. And as an added bonus, the granola holds up well when sprinkled over a bowl of yogurt and mixed with fresh fruit.The oatmeal with sunflower seeds has a wonderful flavor and fully absorbs the milk or water we prepare it with for a full-bodied, natural taste.The pancake mix has some extra graininess built in. It cooks up nice and light, though, but with good body that lets you know there's fiber and healthy ingredients in there.The price is a little high for regular use at home, but it could make a great gift for natural breakfast lovers out there! Enjoy!

I tried the Lifeproof iPhone 5 case and found it to be a little too bulky for regular use. But, then again, it's not really intended for regular use. It's a "special occasion" cover, when you think it might be exposed to water, sand, mud, etc.It's impossible to place the phone with cover on the 30-pin to Lightning adapter to charge or play your phone off a speaker dock.After reading some of the reviews here that described water damage incurred during regular use, I decided not to give it a water test at all. The risks are too great. So I can't vouch for water safety.Also, the plastic screen cover doesn't lie flat and smooth enough to be used as effectively as I would like to control the touch screen. And the sound from the phone's speakers is muffled slightly by the cover. The sound from the iPhone 5 is usually great, but this just sounds garbled and muted.It may be good for someone who really needs to subject their phone to risky situations, but I'm just not willing to try that with this cover. I'll keep my phone out of the water and off the beach.

The Belkin Grip Cash for my iPhone 5 has a very good design in all respects but one. It's snug so the phone won't jiggle around inside the grip, keeping it safe from vibrations, abrasion, etc. The texture of the Grip case itself is great for keeping the phone steady in your hand. Some people live and work in hot or humid climates and their hands can get a little sweaty. The grip is rubbery and textured enough so that the phone won't slip from your hand easily at all. Push controls are placed perfectly, meaning that you can control your volume up/down buttons by pressing on the case covering them (marked + and -) and the contact is perfect. The on/off switch fits perfectly into its cutout, as does the photo lens and the mute switch.As with many of these cases, the going gets a little rocky when you get to the plug-in area at the bottom of the device. The simple, thin Apple earplug jack fits nicely into the external jack, but I've seen other connectors that might not fit. The cutouts for the 2 speakers are well placed. No problem there. It's the Lightning plug jack that's the killer. The simple charging cord fits in there nicely, but the 30-pin to 9-pin adapter does not fit into the jack with the Belkin cover on. That means I can't charge my device or listen to my music on all the various speaker docks I have around the house. And for me, that's a killer.So, if you don't use the adapter, you should be good to go. If you use the square 30-pin-to-Lightning (9-pin) adapter, forget it.

OK, dumb title for a review, but as I started writing this, I was listening to "I've Got the World on a String," by Frank Sinatra. It's a rousing, feel-good song, and it was the first song I started playing when I wanted to test the Jabra Speak 510 as a Bluetooth speaker for my MacBook Pro.Let's start from the beginning, though. The speaker comes with a USB cable wrapped conveniently around its base. The unit is powered by USB, but it can also double as a USB-connected external speaker as well as a Bluetooth speaker. You just choose which way you want to go by using the Jabra Suite, which you download from the Jabra website. On the Mac, it comes up as a control panel under System Preferences.To start up, you plug the Jabra speaker into a USB port on your laptop or PC and just do a quick Bluetooth-device connection routine. You can then pair up your speaker with your phone or other Bluetooth-enabled device.The controls on the speaker are touch-sensitive and are located around the surface edge surrounding the speaker itself. You can see what I'm talking about in the product photos. The controls are surprisingly precise for touch-sensitive switches. The switches are: power on/off, phone pickup, phone hangup, + and - volume controls (which are nicely complemented by an array of little LED lights that circle the device--the higher the volume, the more dots are lit up around the device clockwise; then there's the Bluetooth switch (with blue LED when successfully paired); mute on/off; and power/charging light: red while it's charging up, and I guess I'll find out eventually what color it changes to when it's fully powered (green, I hope).The sound quality is pretty good for a little speaker. By testing it with music right now (still Sinatra), I can tell how well it's reproducing the sound. It's much harder to judge speaker quality with a cellphone connection because of all the variables of connection quality, background noise, how loudly the person is speaking, how far they are from the mic, etc. The small speaker has very decent quality. I have to say the stereo speakers built into the MacBook Pro (recent build) are quite good, and stereo, too, but this allows me to play music while I'm working without having the music coming out right in front of my face--in case my landline rings, etc. Also, I can turn the volume up and down using the keyboard volume controls. Interesting, though, that I can't mute the speaker by hitting the mute key on my Mac. The play/pause button works, though, so all is good.I also did a phone test. It required just a simple Bluetooth pairing and all was set to go. The sound is fine, a little better than the quite good built-in speaker on my iPhone 5 that's used when in speakerphone mode. The mic is great--picks up anyone speaking in my office, and with good sound, I'm told on the other end.Good job, Jabra!

English Girl in New York by Scarlet Wilson All alone in New York after quite possibly the worst year one can imagine Carrie McKenzie doesnt know if she can handle one more thing. Then it happens a snow storm that cripples New York happens on her way home. Finally making it home, after stocking up on comfort food and putting on comfort clothes, Carrie thinks she hears a cat at the door. Opening it she finds something that shocks her and sets her on her heels yet again, there is a baby on the doorstep.Dan Cooper has his own knife to grind with babies and more importantly with parents, moms especially, who arent able to care for their own children. However he has a great heart and is a cop who is trained and has friends to help so when Carrie comes pounding on his door for help with a baby she found on a doorstop he knows he has to keep calm and take control of the situation.What will happen when these two almost anti baby people are cooped up in the big city for days with a baby? Can they work through their baggage? Can they learn to trust one another with their secrets? Then when the weather finally lets up will they be able to face the real world?I wasnt sure what to expect with the title of this book, but what I found wasnt it. I found myself wishing I knew more about Dans past and Carries as well. Though overall it was a wonderful story and then ending did make me tear I cant help but think that something was missing. I would definitely pick it up though because even though the romance was secondary the story was top shelf.

In For the Sake of Their Son (The Alpha Brotherhood #4) by Catherine Mann, Formula One race car driver Elliot Starc discovers he has a son from his best friend Lucy Ann when he is kidnapped from his best friends bachelor party. He has not talked to Lucy for eleven months after misunderstandings drove them apart and now he has discovered he has an infant son from the single night of passion they shared.Elliot wants a second chance. The chance to become the father he never had. The chance for best friends to become something more. But can Lucy Ann forgive the mistakes he's made and trust that he wants more than a marriage for the sake of their son?For the Sake of Their Son by Catherine Mann is definitely one of Catherine' Mann's best novel because of great writing and lots of drama. Right from the start the way Elliot gets to know about his son to the finish, the story had enough interesting turns to keep me hooked. The chemistry between the characters was so amazing and the fact that they were childhood best friends made their love story more believable..Though I did not like Elliot in the beginning for abandoning Lucy after their night together, I warmed up to him eventually because he was willing to undo the mistakes he made with Lucy for the sake of their son, Lucy too was a perfect match for Elliot because she stood up to him and was an amazing mother.Overall, For the Sake of Their Son by Catherine Mann is captivating read that keeps you hooked to the end. Recommend for Catherine Mann fans and for anyone who loves the friends to lovers trope.

Hard to Hold (The U.S. Marshals) by Karen Foley:  Madeline Howe loves her younger brother Jamie with all her heart. He is the only family she has left in this world, so when he is kidnapped and threatened with death unless his gambling debt is paid, Maddie hops on a bus to Reno to save him. She doesn't have the $50,000 ransom needed to set him free, but she is working on it. Her mind is a mad mess of worry, as she contemplates robbing a diner in order to get some cash. Instead, she uses a toy gun to take a hostage, who just happens to be Colton Black, a rugged, U.S. Deputy Marshall.Colton was onto Madeline the minute she walked into the diner. He knew something was up, but had no idea how truly desperate she was. After spending some time with her, under toy gunpoint, he gets her to confide in him a little bit, and that is when he realizes that he has to help her. There is something about Maddie that calls to Colton. In addition, he believes that the organization threatening and holding her brother is part of a huge crime syndicate, that the U.S. government has been trying to infiltrate for over a year.Madeline is a spunky little CPA. In spite of growing up without a mother, a father that committed suicide and an alcoholic grandfather, she turned out okay. Unfortunately, her brother inherited the addiction to gambling gene, associated with the Howe men, and on more than one occasion has gotten himself into trouble. Madeline basically raised Jamie, and did whatever was necessary to keep some food on the table while they were growing up. Although Jamie is 20, she continues to feel an obligation to him.Even with all of Madeline's baggage, Colton is falling for her and she is beginning to feel the same way. Madeline and Colton have instant chemistry and once they learn to trust each other, Jamie can be saved and they can begin to explore a future together.Hard to Hold is a well-written book and the story flows effortlessly from beginning to end. The characters are well described and their feelings are palpable. The sex scenes between Madeline and Colton are steamy and Colton's alpha male persona is hot.However, I found the plot to be utterly ridiculous, which made it difficult for me to get through the story.

In Marrying the Cowboy by Trish Milburn, Elissa Mason has been dodging her aunt Veronas matchmaking by throwing everyone she can in her way. She even managed to put her best friends in the way before her aunt could set her sights on her. But now Verona is determined that it is time for Elissa to be married and have her own happiness. But Elissa considers herself wedded to the family nursery and its success is all she cares about.Until one unfortunate night a devastating tornado hits her hometown. When she awoke in the middle of the night all she wanted was to get to the shed with her aunt Verona before the tornado hit, but once she realized that they would not have enough time to get there, they went to hide inside a closet and tried to protect themselves. Now that the tornado has passed, they were lucky that only an uprooted tree was embedded through the window in their living room. Unlike her best friend and neighbor, Sheriff Pete Kayne whos house was completely taken by the tornado.Nothing could describe the fear that Elissa felt when she saw the house was gone and afraid that Pete may not have made it, until she heard him trapped in the shed, which was being covered by his old washing machine. Not only that, his patrol car was upside down on her lawn.Pete has had a lot of losses in his life, his entire family is gone and now every memory he had of them is also gone. He plans to do his job and help as much as he can, but when its time to go home, he has no home to go to now. So when Verona offers him their guest room, he is a little reluctant to accept, but she can certainly be persistent.Now Pete and Elissa will be roommates, separated by only a wall. And the friendship they always shared is about to change. For living under the same roof and sharing so much time together will bring out feeling that are deeper than either of them may be willing to share, especially Elissa.But unless Elissa can make up her mind and prove to Pete that she loves him, their love may be lost due to her indecision and her dreams of independency. For Pete may be willing to do many thing for her, but he will not force himself on her if she does not want him.This was a really fun and entertaining read. I loved that Verona was the same as always, tricky but with the best heart and intentions underneath it all. Friends-to-lovers is one of my favorite tropes, and the way that these best friends feelings grew and became more was just great. I also loved how the community banded together to help those that were the most affected by the tornado and hurt for the few that were lost. I hope that there will be more of Blue Falls, Texas series, and more of Veronas matchmaking, but if not, I can honestly say that I am happy with all the books in this series.If you like a sweet and heartwarming read, dont miss Marrying the Cowboy by Trish Milburn.

In Her Miracle Twins by Margaret Barker, Dr. Chantal Winstone longs to become a mother but after a failed relationship and pregnancy, she has lost all hopes of ever being one. So when her aloof boss Dr. Michel Devine coolly proposes that they have a baby together Chantal is shocked--maybe his emotions really did die with his beloved wife....The chemistry between them is undeniable, and after only one unexpected passionate night Chantal finds herself pregnant with twins! Can the miracle of giving life to two tiny babies heal their damaged hearts.In Her Miracle Twins by Margaret Barker is a well written story about two individuals whose relationship start with a pregnancy of convenience but slowly becomes much more intimate and serious. Both Chantal and Michel had lost someone important in the past and were hurt emotionally due to the same. The story was about how they both find true love in each other through their twin babies.This was a good story overall with enough medical details but it was lacking in emotion at times. The characters shared amazing chemistry at times but then there were also some "cold" moments between them where I just couldn't feel their passion. I haven't read many romances where the relationship starts with a pregnancy of convenience so this story was different in its theme to me.Overall Her Miracle Twins by Margaret Barker is a well written medical romance with a nice theme and story. It has some good moments but I just wanted more emotions from the characters.

In Jades Treasure by Ana Krista Johnson, Jade Sawyer wants to manage the familys mountain resort and design her jewelry in peace. Of course not to mention that she wants to remain man free for as long as she can. But things will go downhill when the newest guest arrives.Matthew Riley McLaughlin needs time alone away from everyone to write and research about an old legend of a buried treasure for his next book. So he booked his stay at a mountain resort under an alias he uses when he wants to be left alone, otherwise he has women flocking to him just for his fame and money. But when he arrives and finds the lovely Jade chopping wood, he may just be in for an adventure he had not planned but definitely wants.Soon Matthew convinces Jade to help him look for the treasure and tell him about the legend. Since her father investigated and wrote about it she is one of the few people who knows the most about it, but no matter how many have searched, so far none have found the treasure that the letters and legend tell came from the true love of an Indian girl and a city boy.As Jade and Matthew spend more time together they will begin to grow closer together, but because of her past Jade is afraid of leaving her comfortable and safe life. And once she learns the truth about Matthews identity and his real reason for being there, her fears may become too much for her to try and take the happiness that he has brought to her life. Now it will be up to Matthew to prove to her that she can fit into his world and that his love for her is true. And maybe, just maybe the legend of the hidden treasure will help them see how true their love is.For a sweet and entertaining read, dont miss Jades Treasure by Ana Krista Johnson.

In A SEAL's Salvation (Uniformly Hot!) by Tawny Weber, hot good girl Genna Reilly was dared by her best friends to kiss sexy bad boy Brody Lane. Genna never, ever, reneged on a dare and in this particular case, looked forward to fulfilling it. She always lusted after Brody, but he was totally off limits to her. You see, Genna is the sheriff's daughter and Brody is from the wrong side of the tracks. Even Joe, Brody's good friend and Genna's older brother, had warned her to stay away from him.Brody always found Genna to be attractive but unattainable. Being raised by a heavy-handed father who was usually drunk, only contributed to his bad boy persona. Brody was forever in out of trouble with the law, and knew Genna's father on an intimate basis. When their amazing kiss was leading to more, the sheriff discovered them together. Consequently, within a few days, Brody was forced out of town and into the navy. Needless to say, Brody hates and despises his home town of Bedford.Now it is ten years later and due to an injury, Brody returns home. Due to his gramma's urging and his own guilt, Brody agrees to recuperate in her small guesthouse. Brody is a navy SEAL, a hero, and a medal recipient. He returns to Bedford with honor and respect, although he does not see himself that way. The mayor is so proud he is planning a parade in his honor. Wow, what a far cry from his loser life over a decade ago.Genna works for the mayor's office and leads a life of pure boredom. Although she owns her own place and has a good job, she still puts up with her overbearing and intrusive parents managing her life. As a result, she has stopped dreaming about a future filled with happiness, family and love. However, once Brody returns to town, the jig is up.I always look forward to reading books by Ms. Weber because they are sharp, interesting and sexy. In A SEAL's Salvation, Ms. Weber makes a reference to a book she wrote recently, which I found totally awesome because I read it as well and really liked it, Genna says:Im just waiting for the latest Cosmo. I heard there are some great book recommendations in there. Books. In Cosmo? Macy shook her head and went back to sewing tiny roses on an array of tulle circles. I can just imagine what kind of stories those are. Naughty, right? Very naughty. Red-hot, in fact, I read one last month called Fearless. Very hot.Genna and Brody are great together and their sexual appetites are extremely hot. I loved how Genna used baking sweets and treats to soothe her nerves. With Genna and Brody finally being able to support each other, their future together is extremely bright. Overall, a good, solid read.

In Rancher at Risk by Barbara White Daille, Ryan Malloy has been having a tough time since he loss of his wife and son. After he took things too far one last time his boss has decided to send him to Flagman's Folly, New Mexico. Unfortunately, his bad attitude lands him in hot water as soon as he arrives in town with one of the locals.Lianne Ward has been deaf since birth, but she has not let her disability define her. Now she is back in her hometown to rebuild her life and prove to her ex that she can definitely make it on her own. When her niece runs into the street chasing after her dog and is almost run over by a car, Lianne has to explain to her why she should not run into the street again. What she cannot stand is the attitude of the cowboy who decides to start judging them and calls her a drunk.Things will only get more interesting when they find out that they are both going to be living under the same roof on the ranch as Ryan is the foreman and Lianne will be the ranch manager. They will have to learn to compromise and to trust each other enough to get their own jobs done and to meet their own goals. But Ryans tendency to try and control every last thing and Liannes independency to prove herself will complicate things.The chemistry and attraction between Ryan and Lianne is pretty immediate, but Ryan may not be completely ready to let go of his past and Lianne needs to heal from hers as well. Add a couple of the towns busybodies and matchmakers and you just know that things are not going to be simple for either of them.I just loved that Rancher at Risk had an easy flow to it. Lianne had a hard life between the world of the deaf and the world of the hearing, since she could speak and read lips she didnt fully belong with the deaf, but since she could not hear she didnt fit in with the hearing. Something that not many could understand, and something that Ryan will learn when he finds out that she is deaf. While Lianne will help Ryan heal from his own wounds and guilt and help him learn that he cannot control everything to make sure that everything will work exactly as he wants.If you want a sweet, fun and slightly different read, dont miss Rancher at Risk by Barbara White Daille.

In Desperately Seeking Firemen (The Bachelor Firemen of San Gabriel #4.5) by Jennifer Bernard, In the three years since Fire Captain Jeb Stone first met Nita Moreno at a wedding, his life has changed considerably. He finds himself now in a position to pursue their attraction when fate throws them together on Santa Lucia Island. But between the pregnant friend hes there to watch over and Nitas job cleaning up the latest scandal her boss is embroiled in, Jeb has to make their limited time count. He opts for straight-forward honesty and it just may be crazy enough to work some magic on the dark-haired beauty.Press secretary Nita Moreno feels like shes been to hell and back over the past few years. Now the senator, her crazy boss, is expecting her to smooth over his latest debacle with the press while hiding out on Santa Lucia Island. Nita is happy to see her reporter friend Melissa who will get the exclusive interview, but didnt expect gorgeous Jeb Stone to be tagging along with her. Surprisingly he remembers Nita from their brief meeting years earlier and the strong spark is still there. Unsure if she should follow her attraction and let herself get caught up in the moment, Nita has to decide if an island fling will be enough of the hunky fireman for her or if she actually wants forever with him.Desperately Seeking Fireman and is quirky and oh so charming romance novella from Jennifer Bernard. I havent read any of the previous books in The Bachelor Firemen of San Gabriel series, but I didnt need to as this can be read as a standalone very easily. But after reading about yummy Fire Captain Jeb, I will definitely be checking out the other firemen, I mean, books.This novella follows our protagonists intermittently for about three years or so and we get to see the changes they endure in their personal lives. I really enjoyed Jennifers writing style. It was fun, super sexy with lots of flirting and banter going on, but there was still a lot of emotion to each scene. I thought the way she wrote the characters responses to different situations was raw and pretty realistic, which only made the story that much better to me. They may not have always made the right decisions or have known what to do, but they did the best they could and ended up balancing each other out in the end.I easily got the sense of sadness Nita was dealing with and how it changed not only her outlook but even her physical appearance to a certain extent. But Jeb brought out the spark in her that she had been missing. I loved how he could make her laugh and finally relax after all she had been through. Not that Jeb hadnt been through some big changes himself. Their burgeoning relationship was so cute and had some very, very sexy moments mixed in with all the drama.I hope you get a chance to read this endearing, steamy novella. If youre a fan of quirky characters, fun dialogue and passionate romance, Desperately Seeking Fireman is for you.

In Rome (Marked Men #3) by Jay Crownover, Leaving the army and getting used to civilian life hasn't been an easy transition for Rome Archer. He was the go-to guy in his job with the military, as well as for his family before he left home. Now he just doesn't seem to fit in anywhere and it's put him in a funk that doesn't want to let go.Drowning his sorrows in vodka isn't getting Rome anywhere. And it takes a feisty little pint-sized woman to point this out and get him moving along the right track. Cora Lewis is a force to be reckoned with and takes over his life by storm. With Cora, Rome feels like he's finally home and like he might be able to put his demons to rest. If he just can get her to understand how perfect they really are together, he could be content for the rest of his life.Cora Lewis learned young, thanks to her ex-fiance Jimmy, that handing your heart over to someone can completely break you. Now she's on the lookout for Mr. Perfect and she won't settle for less. The friends she calls her family mean everything to her so when Rome Archer comes home all brooding and full of attitude, she takes offense to it.Never one to keep her feelings in check, Cora sets out to take him down a peg or two, only to feel her traitorous body (and heart) warm up to the giant soldier. It's obvious he's hurting and could use some help but Cora is scared to get too involved. Rome is so far removed from what she's looking for in a man that she shouldn't even think twice about him. Yet she can't let it go. Is she too damaged to let herself fall in love again or can Rome help heal her as well?Rome is the fantastic third book in the Marked Men new adult romance series by Jay Crownover. I would suggest probably reading these books in order just to get the full effect of how the story builds as it goes along. Plus there will be spoilers galore if you go back to read the previous novels, but honestly, it would be worth it.Cora and Rome's story is filled with so much drama and passion it should be illegal! I fell for both of them pretty much right away, especially for Rome and his tortured soul. I loved Cora in the previous book, Jet, as she was always so willing to give great advice and took care of everyone around her. It was nice to get her full story and see her finally get to be happy (eventually) herself with sexy badass Rome.Rome had been to hell and back more than once in his life, both in the army and with the loss of his brother. I thought his struggle was a rather realistic one that a lot of people may have dealt with in their lives and loved that it was Cora who helped him dig himself out of his dark place. I found it so interesting that they were such opposites on the outside: Rome was a huge intense guy with dark hair and no tattoos or piercings, and Cora was a petite spitfire who was full of life with vividly colored tattoos/piercings. But they connected perfectly on a profound level that was nothing short of amazing.I thought Jay had an intelligent writing style that drew me in to the story. Everything moved along at a nice pace and I felt all of the characters were well thought out and that the plot kept me interested until the very end. One of my favorite things about this story is getting to watch Cora's definition of the word "perfect" change drastically...for the better. Rome and Cora go through a LOT in their story, sorry I can't got into details without giving everything away, but suffice it to say they earn their HEA! And based on the ending of this one, it looks like Nash will be up next in book four. Can't wait!!

In Revenge in Rio by Samantha Darling, Luca Vencancio returns to Rio for his brothers funeral. But thats not the only reason, he also wants to seduce Daniella, his fiance at one time, and have his revenge on her for leaving him without an explanation to replace him with his younger brother Miguel.In order to protect Luca, Daniella gave in to Miguels blackmail and became his wife, his verbal and physical punching bag. Now that Miguel is gone, she is finally free. But at least there was one good thing that came out of such a horrible five years, an innocent baby that she loves and will protect.Luca didnt realize that seeking revenge on her would be this hard. But even though he wants to hurt her, he just cant. There is something that just doesnt add up, and he needs to know the truth.The chemistry between Luca and Daniella is still there, and they will start burning up the sheets real fast. But unless the truth comes out and they can put the past behind, there will always be the ghost of Miguel to intrude in their happiness.Kudos to Samantha Darling for such a great debut, I cant wait to read more. For a hot, emotional read that will leave you wanting more, dont miss Revenge in Rio by Samantha Darling

The Tycoon's Delicious Distraction by Maggie Cox: Hal Treverne is confined to a wheelchair after an unfortunate skiing accident. He is not happy in being so helpless and constantly dependent on others due to his physical condition. He hires Kit as a temporary companion to help him with all things practical while he recuperates but he does not take into the attraction he starts feeling for his feisty new assistant. Forced to rely on her, there's no escape from her intoxicating presence and soon he catches a glimpse of the simmering desire she conceals beneath her ever-so-professional facade. Unleashing Kit's passion is a challenge this arrogant tycoon will relish!The Tycoon's Delicious Distraction by Maggie Cox is a pleasant read written in the author's usual pleasant style. Kit was a feisty heroine who stood her ground every time and Hal was too bad tempered throughout the book. I understood his physical incapability made him grumpy but sometimes I just wish he would snap out of it and realize that it was a temporary disability not a permanent one.There was an epilogue in the end which wrapped up the book well and was kinda sweet. I had a problem with the blurb of the story which states Kit was a physio when she was clearly his temporary assistant and there is a good difference between physio and assistant. Kit and Hal were likable characters but their chemistry was really low on pretty much every level.Overall The Tycoon's Delicious Distraction by Maggie Cox is a pleasant enough read altogether. It has its moments but a grumpy hero and non existent chemistry between the characters might put you off a little. Maggie Cox is a great author but this one is sadly not her best.

In Her Hard to Resist Husband by Tina Beckett, Dr. Tracy Hinton needs unrivaled medical expertise when disaster hits a small community with potentially catastrophic consequences. After running out of every possible options for cure, she turns unwillingly to the man she walked out on four years ago--her husband Dr.Ben Almeida.Ben has never forgiven Tracy for choosing her work over him and walking out of his life four years ago. Now she is here and is asking him for help but can they keep their personal problems away and keep things strictly professional..??Working against the clock means they can temporarily put aside their differences. Yet there's no denying their sizzling attraction--and Ben has always been so hard to resist...Nothing. Im just surprised you havent found a woman whod be thrilled to stick close to the house and give you all those kids you said you wanted.That would be impossible, given the circumstances.Oh? Her brows arched. And why is that?Grabbing her left hand, he held it up, forcing her eyes to the outline of the plain gold band visible beneath her latex glove.For the same reason youre wearing this. He stared into her face.Have you forgotten, Mrs. Almeida? You may not go by your married name any more, but in the eyes of the lawwere still husband and wife.Her Hard to Resist Husband is not a straightforward romance and that's what I loved about it. Ben and Tracy have big problems which are based on misunderstandings and mistrust. This is a story of dealing with problems and giving their relationship a second chance. There was no shortage of medical details and the whole story was kind of based or standing on the medical aspects which is why I think this was a medical romance in every sense. The romance is there but its not that rosy because of the misunderstandings. Sparks do fly and sometimes I did wanted to yell at the leads to just do it already but I think it was worth the wait in the end. I loved Ben and I can't explain why because there are so many reasons the author gives you to love him.Overall Her Hard to Resist Husband is a realistic medical romance about second chances. If you want something different then go for this one.

In Foolish Games by Tracy Solheim, Will, an NHL linebacker and the national spokesperson against deadbeat Dads, doesn't do one night stands. And he always uses protection... "He's borne the shame of being the consequence of a one night stand all his life.", and he is adamant no child of his will ever be subject to that. But one hot night and one hot woman a year ago is about to change all that..."...a sensual encounter the night of his best friend's wedding." with a woman who never told him his name and who disappeared before he woke up, is about to change Will's life. Julianna is a wedding dress designer, living in Italy, when she returns to the US for a friend's wedding. A migraine, a storm, and some potent medication soon had her in the company of Will, and in his bed. A broken condom and nine months later though, Julianna now has a son - Owen. Julianna has no intention of telling Will about Owen, or having him in their lives - until it becomes a life and death decision.Will is furious when he finds out about the secret Julianna has been hiding from everyone. Determined to do right by his child, he guilts Julianna into a marriage of convenience. Both of them vow that's all it will be, and it won't be forever. But forced to live together and care for Owen together soon have Julianna and Will cautiously forging a relationship together...and given their history and chemistry, it is bound to heat up.But Will has secrets of his own that can affect not only his relationship wtih Julianna, but his career. He carries a lot of weight on his shoulders along with misguided perceptions of how others view him. Misunderstandings, secrets and a lack of communication might rattle the already shaky relationship they are establishing. Can Will put his trust in Julianna? Or with everything else in the way is theirs a relationship doomed to failure, with Owen being the only bond between them?Foolish Games by Tracy Solheim is much more than the romance of Will and Julianna! Tracy will draw you in with an intricate plot and some fascinating secondary characters. I will admit that it took me a while to warm up to Julianna...no matter her past or reasoning, I really did not like her for not telling Will about her pregnancy. Julianna has a lot of unresolved issues in her life, some of them I still don't understand, and I felt like as successful as she was, she still had a lot of growing up to do. Having said that, Julianna was a strong heroine and she did manage to gain my respect and admiration. Above all, she was willing to do anything for her son. She also proved to have more depth to her than she initially appeared, she understood Will, and I found myself really wanting Will to trust her, confide in her, and give her a chance.Through most of Foolish Games, my perception of Will was that he had a lot more to give if only he wasn't so angry about past and present events. He doesn't let anyone get close to him, but Julianna is certainly managing to wiggle her way closer and closer to his heart. He loves Owen unconditionally, and it is fun to see him lighten up a bit with his baby boy. There is a lot going on in Will's life right now, and as much as he struggles with the bad, some good can come of it if he'll open himself up to it if it's not too late.I loved the secondary romance of Will's very young mother and his manager Hank! I loved watching his mother finally blossom! Hank and his daughter were fun and came across as honest, don't hold anything back people. This part of Foolish Games had me just as intrigued as the relationship between Will and Julianna. There were also some friends of Will's that I really hope to read about in a future book.Tracy kept me far more intrigued than I thought I'd be in Foolish Games. There was a lot going on, but she writes smoothly and manages to separate the sub plots enough that there is no confusion, only a reader wanting to get deeper into the story. I have not read the first book in this series, and would definitely say Foolish Games can be read alone. I will be looking forward to another book in this series though! I'd love to read Brody's story!I highly recommend Foolish Games by Tracy Solheim to a romance reader looking for a plot that just keeps getting better as the story progresses, and strong, memorable characters.

One Texas Night...by Sara Orwig: Six years ago, Texas billionaire Jared Weston and antiques appraiser Allison Tyler shared one passionate night together that they vowed never to repeat. Now, Jared has hired Allison's company to appraise the value of some antiques he has inherited and wishes to sell. Allison is content to let things stay all business between them. There's just one problem: the attraction between her and Jared is still sizzling, an attraction Jared is more interested in indulging than fighting.Jared knows that behind her businesslike faade, Allison is just as hot for him as he is for her. The fact that his thrill seeking ways and disdain for settling down are in direct opposition to what Allison says she wants is more of a challenge than a turn off. He enjoys trying to get Allison to loosen up and give in to the passionate attraction between them.But is Jared willing to give up his high risk, non-committal ways once he realizes he has deeper feelings for Allison? Can Allison love a man who's always putting his life at risk for fun? And there's always the tiny issue of Allison's brother and Jared's best friend, Sloan...One Texas Night... by Sara Orwig pulled me in from the first chapter with the recounting of what happened six years ago. I loved Allison and Jared together when they were both young and a little wild. The dialogue was snappy and the attraction sizzled on the page. It was so easy to get caught up in their attraction that you lost sight of what was stopping them from being together. Normally, this would be a great thing, but for some reason, it didn't work for me as well in One Texas Night.I liked Allison, Jared, and even Sloan, worrier that he was. I felt that the conflict between wanting to be with Jared and not being able to handle his high risk lifestyle in light of the tragedy in her past gave Allison's character depth. I also thought that Ms. Orwig did a great job with giving Jared an actual reason why he felt that not settling down and continuing his risky behaviors was the right decision for him to make. It's just that so much time is spent on the less pressing reasons they can't be together that you only glimpse these real impediments. I also felt like the character of Phillip got a bit of a raw deal. I didn't believe what he was in the story to do was even remotely possible for him to do, which was sad because I'm sure he was a more interesting character than he got credit for in the story.I can't say that I was disappointed in One Texas Night; it's a solid read. It's just that Ms. Orwig does such an outstanding job of painting Allison and Jared's first encounter that I was expecting more. I loved the way that the love scenes were done because they took me back to that earlier scene with the writing. Allison's black moment when she realizes Jared's lifestyle is a serious impediment to their relationship was also gripping. There were moments in One Texas Night that I was completely lost in the story and loving it. It's just that I didn't feel that way throughout.I would recommend One Texas Night to readers who love a couple with boatloads of sexual attraction and tension, a flirty girl who becomes a pragmatic woman, and the high risk taking man who tempts her to let her naughty side out to play.

A Promise for the Baby by Jennifer Lohmann: Vivian Yip's life is complicated. It was complicated even before she decided to have a drink at a bar in the hotel for which she worked as a Vegas Dealer. She happens to sit next to a very handsome and fairly drunk man, and they end up getting to know each other while drowning their respective sorrows.Karl Milek wasn't playing to his character that night in Vegas. His real life is controlled and disciplined. He never veers from that path - until he realizes his life isn't going to plan. When he takes refuge with a glass of scotch, he doesn't expect Vivian. Nor does he expect that they'll drink enough to shed inhibitions and have a night to remember.When the morning comes, Viv and Karl have spent the night in each other's arms as husband and wife. Definitely consummated. Neither of them remember everything, but Karl says some things that rock Vivian to her core. Accusations of manipulation and deceit which were never intended - mostly because Vivian had no idea about his life in Chicago. She reluctantly lets him go and agrees to a divorce.But things veer off course again when she shows up at Karl's place in Chicago with nothing but a rattletrap car and a baby on the way. Again, Karl is cruel and demands a paternity test, but decides he can't throw her out on the street in her condition. Viv has noplace to go and nobody to lean on, so Karl is her only hope.After a few weeks living under his thumb, Vivian decides she should do things on her own. However, when she makes a stop on her way out of town, she's drawn even further into the Milek family - and Karl's not sure how to feel about that. Is she insinuating herself so she can get more out of their already tenuous bond? He knows things about her - things that definitely don't put her life in a good light, but is she more than she seems?I like the premise of this book very much, and I found myself rooting for Vivian through the whole story. Karl is a different animal however. I just couldn't connect with him. I still have no idea why Vivian is attracted to him in the least, but I think she would definitely take to his family if this story were real life. Really, Karl was the only character I had a hard time believing - and he's the only reason I knocked my rating down to three stars.The story is solid and all of the secondary characters were lovely and full of life. Vivian's backstory was heartbreaking and I loved seeing her rise above it to stand on her own two feet. The plot was well-paced and well-written - I just couldn't get behind Karl and his issues.

In Tango Love by Nicole Flockton, Melinda Jones has been in love with her housemate James Brady since the day they met. It has killed her to hear him when he brings other women into the apartment and to hear them together. It has taken all she has not to scratch their eyes out. But she doesnt want to risk their friendship on what may not be a reciprocated love.One night when she is at a club with her friends and she meets James at the bar, when she hears his pickup line, she believes that he is only using her to practice as usual. Until she is sending signals to a guy she likes enough to sleep with, then James steps in and ruins it for her. As she is about to get on his case about that, a tango starts to play, Melinda loves tango but she has not found anyone to dance with. Well this time James asks her to dance with him, and the dance becomes more like foreplay than a simple dance.So much so, that they finally give in to their instincts and finally sleep together. But what seems like a dream comes true the night becomes Melinda's worst nightmare when she wakes up alone and without even a note from James. Melinda is not the only afraid of what will happen to their relationship, for James is also afraid of loosing her. And unless they are both honest about their feelings, they may just end up loosing the one true love they have both been waiting for.For a sweet, hot and sexy short read, dont miss Tango Love by Nicole Flockton.

In Sweetest Mistake (Sweet, Texas #2) by Candis Terry, Ex-Marine Jackson Wilder is a firefighter who is used to jumping in first and asking questions later. He has no problem defending his country or running into a burning building. But admitting to his feelings is a whole 'nother ballgame, doubly so when it comes to his former best friend Abby Morgan.When Abby left Sweet, Texas just after Jackson enlisted, he sadly thought he would never see her again. Five years later, Abby waltzes back into town and into his life giving him a chance to find out what went wrong. Jackson's emotions once again go haywire when she's near, causing him to do and say stupid things. He wants desperately to convince Abby to stay so he can confess his love for her, but could it destroy the friendship he's come to rely on once again?Abby Morgan left Sweet, Texas once she realized that even though she had loved her best friend Jackson for years, he would never feel the same for her. Moving to Houston didn't turn out as she had hoped either. As a newly divorced woman, Abby's back in Sweet to put her parent's house up for sale and hopefully find some closure. However, the sparks fly immediately when she sees Jackson again. More confused than ever with where her life is going, Abby wonders if it's foolish to hope things could possibly work out between her and Jackson this time around.Sweetest Mistake is the second sexy offering in the Sweet, Texas series by Candis Terry.
