Centering around one of the youngest Wilder brothers and his estranged best friend, this is a story of second chances that will make you laugh but still pull at your heartstrings.There is just so much to love about this book! All of the characters are larger than life...I mean, it is set in Texas, so you can't expect otherwise. From Jackson's meddling but loving family to the local residents, everyone adds their own personal touch to the story. I loved that even though there is such a strong sense of togetherness in Sweet, there are still realistic touches like gossipy neighbors and grumpy octogenarians. Things weren't happy happy all the time. There were conflicts and personal issues.I'll admit that even though Jackson made some boneheaded moves, I still kind of fell in love with him. He's a hero who loves his family, he's a hands-on dad who isn't afraid to be silly to make his daughter happy, and he's genuine. I can see why Abby would fall in love with him! And she's not too shabby herself. She's such a caring person. Abby took care of her younger sister while her parents were MIA and was basically raised herself by the Wilder family. She also has a special place in her heart (just like I do) for animals in need, which plays into the plot a bit.If you love rugged alpha males and a well written friends-to-lovers trope, Sweetest Mistake is the romance for you!

Mr. (Not Quite) Perfect by Jessica Hart: Max is still a little stunned by the abrupt way his ex dumped him. They were perfect for each other, but apparently she needed to be swept off her feet. She didn't cheat on him, but definitely got 'swept away' from their relationship. So he retreats to his sisters place to recoup. She's away on business, so he'll be bunking in with their long-time friend, Allegra.Glitz magazine has finally given Allegra an assignment she can make her own. After a round of 'why can't we find the perfect guy', her boss is swayed by her pitch to make an ordinary joe into the perfect man. Now she just needs to find a guy to be her subject. When Max lands (literally) on her doorstep, she realizes he is ready-made for this job. He's not what she'd call "hunky", but there's potential there. As long as he'll agree to let them give him a makeover and tutor him in the ways of dating, maybe he can get his ex back.Max doesn't want to agree to be Allegra's guinea pig, but since she's helping him to get an assignment he's been aiming for, he can hardly say no. In fact, she doesn't give him any choice whatsoever. It doesn't hurt that he'll be fake-dating a famous model for the story - although she's not really the kind of woman he'd choose to date under normal circumstances.As long as they've known each other, Allegra has never thought of Max as anything other than a brother type, but now that he's spruced up a bit, she's seeing an entirely different man - and she's surprised at how much she likes the new him. On the other hand, Max already has a preconceived notion about who Allegra is, but under the messiness and chaotic wardrobe, there's a surprisingly deep woman. When their curiosity leads to a steamy night they vow to forget, their lives become more complicated than they've ever imagined.I was not sure what to think when I started reading this book. Usually, when a guy is kinda geeky, the woman is already slightly attracted to him, but "wakes up" once he's seen in a new light. However, Allegra *truly* doesn't see Max in any kind of romantic or sexual way in the beginning. She even thinks that he's not really attractive, and quite stuffy.Max doesn't feel much for her either, especially since he's constantly frustrated by her superficiality and unkempt living habits. Her issues stem from an inner conflict, whereas his are mostly outward changes. Max's sister, Libby - is only mentioned briefly in the book. She's Allegra's real roommate, and I was expecting her to make an appearance at some point, but she doesn't. The twist in Allegra's backstory was truly out of left field, but things click into place when we find out her mother's secret.I really despised Allegra's mother, in fact, even after things get explained, she's still not exactly warm and cuddly. It was nice that the reveal allowed Allegra to decide what to do with her life, and that she should live it for herself, not to impress anybody else.I loved how Max came back to Allegra - so romantic. Totally swoon-worthy. I think you'll enjoy it too.

In Midnight Surrender by Donna Grant, Rennie lives a life of relative isolation on property on the Isle of Coll left to her by her aunt. Every time she thinks of selling the property and moving on, something stops her. She's not sure why she hasn't left, but she feels something is holding her there. Now it is getting close to Christmas, and Rennie wants a wish for Christmas instead of a present. She is feeling lonely and wishes for someone to spend the rest of her life with. But even with this wish she thinks "It was better that she was alone. Then she didn't have to explain the odd things she could do just by thinking of them." Or the visions people got after touching her. Rennie is a Druid. But Rennie has no idea how powerful she can be or the extent of her legacy.Dale, a Warrior, has followed the feel of magic to Coll. Although Dale believes his past and future will make him forever not good enough for someone like Rennie, he is still drawn to her. Soon Rennie and Dale fine each other impossible to resist and they both fall hard and fast. But with who they are can they even have a future together? What can become of a Druid and an immortal Warrior?With danger close by, they are confronted by evil and Rennie threatened. Will either of them have a future at all let alone together? Will Rennie have a chance to realize her legacy before it's too late?In the short time I came to know her, Rennie came across as a strong, independent woman who I really liked. She has not moved on from Coll and seems to know the reason will come to her soon. She is cautious, but when she meets Dale she feels something for him...even after she knows who and what he is. She has taken the lessons learned from her aunt to heart. Dale is a strong Warrior who would like nothing more than to have the god within him bound so that he can be mortal again...but that can never happen, can it? Because of what he's done, what he's had to do, Dale doesn't think he deserves happiness or Rennie. Even if he can't resist her.Midnight Surrender was a well paced novella that is a quick but not rushed, intriguing read. It can be read as a stand alone outside of the Dark Warriors series (I have not read any of the other books in this series), but I think I would have had a better feel and appreciation of the novella if I had read the other books. Donna gives you some characters that you will love as well as fast paced action and suspense with entrancing descriptiveness in Midnight Surrender.I'd recommend this to any paranormal romance reader looking for a quick, fulfilling read...especially if you've read other books in this series.

I have purchased jewelry from this company before and been extremely pleased with the quality and appearance.  These earrings just aren't my cup of tea, though.  One thing I've always loved is their packaging -- black boxes with bright teal interior.  Both the outer box and the jewelry box in which these arrived had peeling paper on the outside.  I'm glad I wasn't intending to give this as a gift!  Inside, the post on one earring was bent; I'm guessing it was from inserting the earring into the cardboard display piece, which tells you a little about the sturdiness of the post.  It was easily bent back into shape.Otherwise, I'll just say that the photo is very true, especially the very pink tint to the center stone.  I was hoping for elegant,  but these earrings remind me a bit more of something your young daughter would wear with her princess costume, or your pre-teen to a Dad/daughter dance.

These little packets are SO handy!  My dogs love coconut oil on their kibble but I have to take a jar and spoon with me when we travel.  Now I just toss a few of these packets in the bag and voila!  No stress, no mess, and a perfect individual serving, and the dogs loved the taste.  These also came in handy when I forgot my conditioner; I just used a packet of coconut oil instead!  And the dab that was left, I smoothed on my lower legs, the part that showed below the capris, to make it look like I actually attend to personal grooming at times.I have NO hand strength, but managed to open the packets easily, yet they withstood the wear and tear of being loose in the bag with the metal dog dishes, the kibble and scoop and the box of treats and none were punctured or otherwise broken open.  If you were to stomp down on one, I'm sure you'd have a blowout mess, just like you would with an individual serving of sour cream, which is kind of what the container reminds me of, as there is a slight gusset on one end and then the tear-off tab "cap" on the other end.I'll be honest; I got these to use for travel, but they are so handy that I find I'm using them "everyday," as well.  Terrific idea and terrific product!

I love the treats.  More importantly, my dogs love the treats.  They are nicely soft, so they are consumed quickly.  Here's the thing... I mostly want treats to be used for training, and I have to break these into 4 to 6 smaller pieces to use as reasonably-sized training treats with my 55-65 pound dogs.  A competing manufacturer that makes a popular treat that sounds a lot like "pepperoni" has come up with tiny nuggets of their product, about the size of a hamster pellet, and I really wish Wellness would do the same.  Because I think these treats are better for my dogs, and my dogs do prefer these treats in a side-by-side taste test.Wellness is and has been my food of choice for many, many years, and I am glad that they make terrific treats to complement the food (which, let's face it, I also use as training treats...!)

Since a (terrific) business incubator popped up in town, the community college where I work has been holding occasional Agile Project management workshops, including Scrum training.  I've desperately wanted to go but never could, and hoped that this book could teach me enough about Scrum that I could then train students in my business management classes.I don't think it is at all a weakness of this book, because it doesn't claim to teach about Agile, the why and wherefore of these innovative project management approaches.  However, someone like me, who doesn't grok Agile in fullness is at a bit of a disadvantage.  Possibly reading "Agile Project Management for Dummies" (which does exist!) would have been a good first step; I would strongly recommend that this book NOT be your introduction to Agile Project Management.Otherwise, this book provides all the detail one might require and then some.  This isn't a simplified version, as the name might imply... it's really very in-depth.  That can be a little intimidating, but the examples of each step as applied to different industries are excellent and help a lot with making this seem do-able.My husband, the software engineer, was a little astonished to find Scrum being applied to things other than programming, although, since I'd seen it at the business incubator being used to coordinate every level of business development, it hadn't occurred to me that it wouldn't be.  So I do think that the diversity of examples in this book is a great strength.  There is even a chapter on Scrum for Life Goals, including financial security, weight loss, life balance, planning vacations and (my new secret weapon) success as a student.  The section on achieving in college is really terrific; as an instructor, I find myself considering the semester as one week long "sprints."  I think Scrum for Curriculum Development would be a very interesting read!

If you haven't read at least the Farseer Trilogy, the Tawny Man trilogy and the previous book in this trilogy, Fool's Assassin, you really should; this book will mean so much more!  This book comes 10 years after the publication of the last book in the Tawny Man trilogy, and picks up action 15 years into the future of the characters (and if you're just reading the whole series now, lucky you to not have had to wait!)In this second book in the new trilogy, Fitz and the Fool are together again for the first time in 15 years, but the cost of that meeting is great.  The Fool has been kept captive and tortured for most of those years, and now he has led his captors to Fitz's home, where they seize Fitz's daughter, Bee.  Much of the book is given to action at Buckkeep Castle, catching up with the Fool's intervening years as well as his slow recovery from the torture that has blinded him.  Once Fitz learns of Bee's abduction, he, of course, is determined to go after her, but her captors use magic to cloak their movements and take much time to be found.  In the meantime, we are able to reconnect with the many characters at Buckkeep.I have to admit something: I don't know why, but I find Hobb's books to be 1000 times more suspenseful than I do any 'suspense' or 'thriller' novel I've ever read.  I think that's the reason people compare the series to Martin's "Song of Ice and Fire," because of the tremendous suspense...  there are layers and layers of peril and just because one layer may be suspended for a moment, the reader is never entirely "off the hook."  I also think that's the reason many reviewers complain of "slowness" in this book: it seems that what you really WANT to happen, for Fitz and the Fool to go after Bee, is never going to actually happen.The only other thing I think I can mention without spoilers is that this is an absolutely enormous book.  My copy weighs well over two pounds; while I love that it includes all those wonderful words, this is one time, where, for me, the book would have been much easier to enjoy in electronic format on a light-weight and easily-portable Kindle!

The biggest surprise we had with these shorts was that they are plaid.  My husband's mother was apparently frightened by loud clothing patterns when she was carrying him, as he is ultra conservative when it comes to both colors, patterns and styles.  Thus, the plaid was a bit of a shock.  Although labeled "slate," the color is actually more of an olive drab with thin gray stripes to make the plaid.  They are not what I'd call 'loud' by any means and look great with a charcoal or ash shirt.They are also pretty long.  On my long-legged 6'2" husband, they came to just below the kneecap.  He said he didn't find that uncomfortable, but it's not what he's used to.The thing that impressed him most about the shorts was that they are light.  Really light.  He said it's a little alarming to feel like you have nothing on, but that it's easy to get used to.  In 100 degree heat and 90% humidity, they didn't cling or become wet, even when he was using the riding mower.I thought the shorts washed beautifully, and they dried very quickly.  These would be terrific to pack for vacation and would be a great option for those "I don't really want to wear swim trunks but am probably going to get wet" events like rafting.

Bottom line: if you've ever wondered what it's like to work in a Veterinary clinic; if you love your pets and would like to better understand the challenges in their medical care; and, most of all, if you think perhaps you'd like to become a Veterinarian, this is a great book for you to read.Non-fiction books about dogs generally end in one way.  This book, which includes the lives of three dogs, includes three such events.  You have now been warned.  Yes, you should definitely still read the book but if you start to get into that part of the book (you'll know), you may want to consider your surroundings before continuing.  Fellow train-riders and lunch-counter diners tend to look askance at the person blubbing all over his or her book.I knew the rule, but, having read a brief excerpt of the book in Dr. Andy Roark's blog, I wanted to read it, anyway.  It really is a good book -- an easy read, with plenty of humor and lots of appealing honesty.  The book details the life, thus far, of Dr. Jessica Vogelsang.  Some elements are slightly fictionalized to protect the... original party.  But the stories ring very true.In a very interesting and funny narrative, Dr. Vogelsang conveys a great many truths about the world of the Veterinary clinic.  Dr. Vogelsang is very honest about her rather nerdy and introverted childhood, about how academic achievement was quite easy for her, and how she explored many other careers, including research and human medicine, before deciding on Vet school.  She was admitted to and attended the University of California at Davis, definitely one of the premier Veterinary colleges in the world.  Upon graduation, she went to work at a "chain" clinic, what many in the industry disdain as "Corporate Medicine," but the experience she describes sounds an awful lot like most any other clinic to me.In addition to talking about the three dogs who shared her life during various parts of this journey, Dr. Vogelsang talks about her marriage as well as about her two children, Zoe and Zach.  Following the birth of her daughter, Dr. Vogelsang experienced crippling post partum depression; even as a medical professional, it took her quite a while to realize something was wrong and to ask for help.  A mother of a one-day-old infant recently walked away from her home near mine and was found dead; I hope that everyone reading this book will take this message, in particular, to heart, understanding that a mother with post partum depression is not weak nor foolish, but under the influence of some of the most powerful drugs in the universe -- hormones -- and they are making her mind play tricks on her.Dr. Vogelsang uses humor and detail to gently illuminate the lamentable fact that many members of the public have no idea how many years of school is required to become a Veterinarian (or a Technician, Hospital Manager or Assistant), nor that these professionals usually make less than half the wage of their similarly-educated counterparts in human medicine.  She talks about the challenge of dealing with patients who cannot speak to describe their symptoms while pointing out that anybody who thinks they'll go into Veterinary medicine because they don't have to deal with people is sadly mistaken.  (Vogelsang credits her own growth in interpersonal communication to a summer spent as a research assistant, recording the experience of patients during the trial of a little blue pill that was intended to help cardiac symptoms but which had other, more noteworthy effects)And Dr. Vogelsang talks about loss and grief -- her own and that of her clients.  Her discussion is straightforward, poignant but without drama and bathos.  She does a very nice job.If you love pets, I think you will enjoy this book.  I also think it will make a terrific gift for other pet lovers you may know.

My dogs can be picky eaters.  I give them a high-quality kibble, on which they thrive, but they aren't always willing to eat regularly.  Thus, I resort to what we call "kibble sweeteners," something to make the food more appealing.  This dehydrated raw mixer fits the bill perfectly.  My picky eaters found the product to be extremely palatable and have been eating their mixed kibble with gusto.My 50 pound dogs get 1/4 cup mixed in with each meal.  The nuggets have been freeze dried and so can be easily crumbled into a dehydrated powder to sprinkle over the kibble, so the dogs don't "cherry pick."  While I sometimes add a little warm water to the kibble, I wouldn't say that these mixers rehydrate, exactly.  However, I do think it's really important to make sure the dog has access to lots of fresh water when feeding any sort of dehydrated food.  The bag also notes that this is intended to be a treat or supplement and is not a balanced diet, intended to be fed by itself; there is an Instinct Rawboost Kibble that is intended to be a balanced diet.I do think these nuggets also make a nice training treat.  Although they crumble, which is not ideal, they don't really require chewing and can easily and safely be gulped on the fly.  The bag is very careful to report that 1/4 cup has 52 calories, and notes that the dog's food should be reduced by a similar amount.  The product nuggets aren't all the same size, but I seem to get an average of about 25 per 1/4 cup, so each nugget is about 2 calories (the bag says 1.6 kcal apiece).  Unless you have a dog on a very strict diet, the calorie counting probably is a relatively minimal issue; however, 2 calories per training treat can get substantial in a hurry.  (Nature's Variety does make training treats, but I have not tried them.)The bag indicates that six ounces will provide 24 1/8 cup (or 12 1/4 cup) servings.  The bag is resealable, which is important... if you let the product absorb moisture over time, the nuggets will disintegrate and you'll just be dealing with powder.The product is "manufactured in US facilities."  I don't see anything about the sourcing of Nature's Variety ingredients, although most dog food rating sites are very complimentary about the company's products.  I certainly don't have any trouble giving them to my own rather spoiled but highly valued dogs!

Like Alex Delaware, the protagonist of this suspense novel is also a psychologist.  And, while I have enjoyed the Delaware series for the most part, I have to say that the heroine of this book, Dr. Grace Blades, makes him look a bit stodgy.When one of Blades' clients is murdered, the only clue to his identity is her business card in his shoe.  Blades soon determines, though, that she and the man knew one another as children, and that she is now in danger, as well.  The story alternates between present day and a detailing of Blades' growing up as a neglected baby, an orphan and foster child.  Extremely intelligent, Blades came to be both an extremely effective psychologist, but also has been scarred by her childhood.  She has no friends, is an extremely autonomous and self-sufficient woman, and something of a thrill-seeker.  Thus, rather than seeking help from authorities, Blades undertakes to find and deal with the murderer, herself.Author Kellerman, himself a psychologist whose work emphasized pediatric patients, uses this opportunity to turn a light on the impact of violent crime on children, and the terrifying randomness and implacability of the social services designed to protect and care for them.  The points are quietly introduced as plot elements, though, and not at all preachy.Frankly, Blades is a compelling character, reminiscent of some of the "forged-by-trauma" superheroes of comic books and movies.  I really hope that this is an introduction and not her only outing.

These earrings are lightweight, very attractive, and suitable for both casual and dressy wear.  What's not to love?But I also want to acknowledge the presentation, because I think these would be a terrific gift, and the packaging really supports that.The earrings come in an attractive black box that is about twice as large as a velvet earring box from a jeweler.  The inside of the box lid is lined with dark teal paper and the 'velvet' insert that holds the earrings has a teal tab that allows easy removal from the box.  This is the second item I've received recently with this 'surprise' dash of color in a black box and I have to say that I think it is very striking and classy.The velvet insert covers the bottom of the box then curves over itself, so the earrings and their backs can be viewed without removing the insert from the box.  I think this is a lot nicer than removing the velvet insert to get to the earring backs, where one often sees the brown cardboard "guts" of the packaging.  There are no brown guts to be had here, even with the insert taken out.  One thing that is a tiny bit odd is that the earring backs are "enforced" by the little plastic "corks" that you often see on fish-hook style earrings.  I suppose they make doubly sure that the earring backs stay in place during shipping, but I think I would remove them before giving the earrings to someone if I had the chance.The earrings, themselves, have terrific sparkle.  They do not look cheap or plastic and, for me, the only thing that really gives them away as CZ is the mounting, which isn't one that would probably be used for a diamond.  The rhodium around the outside is very pretty, and, in a touch that is hard to spot in the item photos, there are tiny CZs set around the outside, providing additional sparkle.  The earring design is very classic and would look great with a little black dress or with capris, sandals and a t-shirt on the boardwalk.  These aren't "in your face with rhinestones!" bling but they aren't so small as to be unnoticed, either.  The rhodium kind of "blends in" to the sparkle of the CZ, and, as a result, these earrings don't look especially "silver."  I wouldn't hesitate to wear them with a gold necklace, for example, which is nice, especially if you are traveling and don't want to have to haul a lot of "matching" pieces around.The earring backs are the traditional metal butterfly.

Warning: this is NOT a Joe Pickett novel.  I assumed that it was, simply because I'm more used to the Pickett novels.This is a sequel to The Highway, which was listed as NS (non series) but, apparently, is not.SPOILERS HERE IF YOU HAVEN'T READ "THE HIGHWAY"If you'd asked me before I read this, I would have said a sequel was a bad thing.  I thought The Highway was a good story but it was WAY too creepy for my tastes, the kind of thing that gives you nightmares.  And, while this book does pick up with Cassie Dewell being called upon to identify the Lizard King, the villain from that previous book, the remainder of the story takes a completely new turn, with Cassie taking a job in a North Dakota oil boomtown.  Investigating what appear to be related murders, the sheriff in Cassie's new department suspects corruption in his ranks, and hires Cassie to come in to resolve both situations.Box has evidently done extensive homework on the bizarre environment of the North Dakota fracking oil production, where landowners routinely go from broke the millionaire and where the building can't keep up with the need to house and feed the workers, who also earn extremely well in their dangerous and mind-numbing jobs.Box also does a really fantastic job with his female protagonist.  She seems like a real, normal person, something that many authors, and especially male authors, struggle with.Lastly, Box manages to weave in an extensive storyline about a genetically-disadvantaged young man who sees everything that is happening, but who is largely invisible to the players in the story.This book gave me time to get to know Cassie better, and I will definitely read future stories featuring her, even though I know that means the Lizard King will be back.  Yuck.

Disclaimer:  I have REALLY fine, REALLY straight hair, so straight that heated rollers or iron give it a slight wave for about 5 minutes, less if it is humid.  If your hair has more texture/body than that, I think your results might differ dramatically.I used this product per directions, applying following towel-drying and without any other post-shower product.  It went on very lightly and I had high hopes, but, following the blow dry, my hair was just as flat and limp as usual, despite every blow dry trick I know to try to give it some lift.  When using my straightening iron, I could HEAR the sound of something on my hair, an added friction.  However, may hair didn't look any different, and the one good thing about my hair, the silky, cold feel when you slip your hand through it, was gone.  So this did nothing for me, but I think if you had something to work with, it might.
This is a handy pocket blacklight.  I've dropped it once already and it is holding up well, unlike some I have whose lenses drop out at the slightest bump.  Great value!

I would love this massage device if I could use it on my neck, which is what I believe it's intended to treat.  However, I like it A LOT as for foot massage; without the massage, the heat setting is great for just warming cold feet.  The vibrate feature doesn't seem to do much except make the dog come look at it funny.The massage "balls" are very hard and are barely covered by a fine, netlike material.  The maker recommends folding a towel over the massager if you find the massage to be too firm, but that adds thickness and I couldn't ever figure out a position that would allow my neck to relax onto the massager with a towel on it that was comfortable for the rest of my back.  I think it might be possible to by building an incline of some but that's kind of a lot of work for a device that's supposed to be relaxing.However, using a towel for the foot massage is a good idea, because of that firmness... when the balls come together, it can really compress your foot if it's down between them.  For the heat, however, I prefer to not have the towel in place, at least not initially.The flush-mount press controls are easy to manipulate with your feet, too.  Having a foot massage has become a much-looked-forward-to part of my evening routine.

I cried through a lot of this book.  If you, like me, have lost people you love to death, you might cry, too.  Re-reading portions of it, I haven't cried any less, either.  I suppose that could be hormones or stress, but, to me, it feels like truth.For someone like my office mate, someone my age who has yet to lose anyone close to him, I think death is a lot more abstract.  It's not that you just feel sad about those you lost, but you also wonder how you're going to face it when it is your turn.  And this book gives you lots of options -- lots of stories and lots of things to think about.I still don't know whether I can summon grace when the time comes, but I do think things I learned from this book will help.

I used these cards to make 'disposable' evidence marker tents for a classroom crime scene.  Although they aren't the standard 'upright' format for such cards, we liked these better because they had more of a horizontal edge; printed with a scale across it, these made nice scales as well as numbered markers.The cards printed beautifully on the laser jet printer, very crisp (important for the scale), and the numbers showed up well in our "crime scene" photographs.  Even more importantly, when printing 25 sheets of them, they tore apart very evenly.  I did fold on the scores, but had no problems with errant tears that would have given me distracting or unstable edges.  Lastly, when folding, they stayed folded and stayed folded.

I wish there was a rating between "It's okay" and "I like it" for this book.  It is the standard Steve Berry formula for Cotton Malone, an adventurous quest to save the United States from the devastation that would occur if some centuries-old document becomes public.  In this case, Malone is tracking down documents that might prove the 16th amendment -- and income tax -- to have been improperly ratified and thus be illegal.  An American fugitive has the documents and wishes to meet with other like-minded ex-patriots but a North Korean playboy and his killing machine daughter want the documents in order to bring down the US government and secure their own places as saviors in North Korea.Malone is moping about having parted ways with his fellow-operative girlfriend, Cassiopeia Witt, in the last novel, and Stephanie Nelle, head of the Magellan Billet for which Malone is taking on an after-retirement mission (haven't all of his chronicled adventures been post-retirement?) is still looking forward to exploring a personal relationship with Danny Daniels, presently married and, incidentally, the US President.Action takes place on a Mediterranean cruise ship, then Croatia, as well as in Washington D.C. and backstory historical figures include Andrew Mellon, FDR, and pretty much all the North Korean dictators.If you've ever wondered what the "income taxes are illegal" folks are going on about, this is probably a fairly painless way to get the general idea, and you get a nice grounding in modern North Korean history, too.  This is also the third mystery I've read in recent months that celebrates the beauty and tragedy of Croatia.  But the quotes from real and purported documents are long and dry, and the action very Clive Cussler over-the-top, and I just didn't really *care* very much about how it all turned out.

While appearing as a guest on "The Tonight Show" one evening, famed hotelier Conrad Hilton was asked by his host (Johnny Carson) whether he had a "message" for the American people.  With great gravity, Hilton paused momentarily before turning to the camera. "Please," he pleaded, "put the shower curtain inside the tub!"  Critical advice, of course, and the reason that some people ignore it is that they hate having the shower curtain 'stick' to them during their shower.  As a result, many hotels have curved shower rods these days, providing more 'elbow room' inside the tub, and it  only makes sense to bring this innovation home.While some of the motel installations are a bit rinky-dink, this rod has a satin finish and is quite sturdy, with a "quality" feel.  The rod is not pressure-mount the way many of the straight rods are, so you *must* drill holes and put mounting brackets on the walls.  Except for the drill, the tape measure and the pencil used to mark the installation spot, all the tools are included in the package.  Our installation took about 20 minutes.We installed this shower curtain rod on a 60-inch shower/tub combination.  We followed the instructions explicitly, placing the ends of the rods 5" in from the outside edge of the enclosure, and 65" above the tub ledge.  The instructions say to put the ends 8" in on a 72" long tub.  There are 'leveling' screws in the mounting bracket to level and secure the rod, and they do a nice job.  The metal covers that go over the brackets were less impressive, however.  The holes that the screws go into, holding them in place, were not completely machined so needed to be drilled out a bit.  Once on, the covers protect the bracket from water and from viewing inside the shower, but show the "guts" of the bracket from the outside.  This was probably our biggest disappointment, as it makes the cover look like it's installed wrong and we feel it requires us to keep the shower curtain closed to obscure the big hole in the side of the cover.In retrospect, I think we should have put the bracket closer to the outside edge, i.e. not the full 5" in.  There is some added space, but, really, not that much.  It is an attractive rod, other than the cover issue, and it *looks* like we made an effort to upgrade the comfort in this guest bathroom, but, in practice, it doesn't feel like it makes much of a difference to the person inside the shower.

I enjoyed the heck out of this book.  It is extremely suspenseful.  The author 'plays by the rules,' giving the reader all the information to figure out the mystery BUT it is done so deftly and enough red herrings skillfully inserted that it wasn't until the denouement that I was able to go back and smack my head and say "I can't believe I missed it!"  Those are the best mysteries, in my book.In addition to great suspense and pacing, Talty has created a compelling heroine.  Detective Abbie Kearney is the best kind of protagonist, one that appeals to the best within the reader.  She is good at her job because she uses her brain; her happiness doesn't depend upon having a romantic relationship and it is a relationship built on mutual respect and not a one-sided worship of some sort.  Abbie's is a product of her history but won't let it define her future, and her flaws come from making the kind of decisions that I think most of us would make if someone's life was in the balance.  Also, Talty manages to include Irish cops without descending into cliche' -- the characters are somehow *more* real because of everything you know about Irish immigrants and communities with strong Irish sub-culture, rather than being predictable and stereotypical.  Subtly amazing writing!Talty is now firmly on place in my FictFact alerts and I will look forward to more books by him!PS Also, he dedicated this book "to the late John D. MacDonald, still unequaled."  While this book bears really no resemblance to MacDonald's stories, Abbie is, like Travis, a white knight -- not a noble and pure Galahad, but the best-intentioned but sometimes human sort like omer and Buffy Summers.  And now I'm gonna go subside in some kind of fangirl puddle until I can pull myself back together.  Read the book!

There is such responsibility in carrying on the work of a deceased author and an even bigger onus on those who would continue with iconic characters like Nero Wolfe and Archie Goodwin.  The work has to succeed on one of two levels.  The first is to be a good read for someone completely unfamiliar with the original work, and the second, of course, is to satisfy the fans.  I haven't seen too many (anyone?) hit that second mark and was really hoping that this author, with the approval of the author's estate and an encyclopedic knowledge of the oeuvre, would get the brass ring.While I'm not a huge devotee of Rex Stout's work, I've read and enjoyed some of his books.  Neither Wolfe nor Archie resonated with me, but Stout's writing was excellent -- his pacing, his deft characterization and his ineffable sense of time and place.I'll be honest -- I couldn't finish this book.  As a Nero Wolfe story, even for someone as casually acquainted with them as I am, it falls far short.  The characters, who have such backstory and fanbase that they practically stand on their own, seem flat and hackneyed.  Stout's dialog always seemed more authentic because of period dialog, but, here, Archie's slang seems inserted for effect and doesn't ring true.  Instead of a thrilling transport to another time, I kept finding myself thinking of PI parodies, like Firesign Theater's Nick Danger and Stone in the musical 'City of Angels.'It makes me very sad; I wanted this to work because there are so many characters that I miss and whom I wish could be returned to us through approved authors.  I'm just not sure it can be done, though.  :-(

This is absolutely excellent primer.  It is actually perfectly named.  It takes hardly any at all to smooth over my face before I put on foundation and it makes all the difference between the foundation lasting either 6 hours or until I sweat, whichever comes first, or until I remove the makeup with soap and water and washcloth.  My skin, which gets blotchy and breaks out at the slightest insult, has been more clear and less winter-dry-and-flaky since I started using it. I also love that there is a BOTTLE full of the stuff, instead of a thin straw worth of product that is artistically twirled inside a bigger empty bottle, like some of the other products I've used.

This was a really fun read.  I was unfamiliar with the author, who has written a lot, apparently mostly in the romantic suspense and paranormal romance categories, which, admittedly, are not my genre.  The writing is very, very good: the prose is tight, the dialogue sounds very natural and the characters develop nicely even throughout a story like this one set during a short timeframe.  The premise for the heroine is even very fun -- a self-help author who writes platitudes in which she doesn't believe, except they seem to really help her masses of fans, so could it possibly be that her glib recommendations really do constitute good advice?I am only removing the one star because the plot was not up to the standard of the rest of the book.  If you're going to write suspense, the reader needs to have at least some doubts about "who dunnit."  Unfortunately, it was patently obvious from about the 3rd plot point who our villain was.The only other thing that I found a bit odd was the author's choice to have the heroine be someone who "swears like a sailor."  While swearing works fine in an Elmore Leonard novel, for example, it was distracting in this book.  I think it might be because the heroine was the only one swearing, often in her internal dialog.  I'd be interested to know what others thought.

A single dimension in 'star' rating isn't enough for this book.  It's got some great elements to it, and some that I didn't like as much, so 3 stars is more of a "mean" than a true rating!Things I liked:The book is well-written, with prose that flows very nicely, good dialogue, and some great word choices.  The descriptions of scenes were evocative, and the costumes and illusions in the magic show are extremely deft.  The author explains what you need to know about how the tricks work with just a few, well-chosen words when I'm sure some would have slogged on for pages.The timing of the book is fun, at the end of the 19th century and just across into the 20th.  Settings include Biltmore, the newly-built New York Public Library and the theatres of the various Vaudeville circuits, as well as the private train cars of the magic show and it's clear that the author has done a great deal of research to capture the look and feel of such places at that point in time.Things I didn't like:The story is described as "Water for Elephants" meets "The Night Circus," but I thought it was more like "Flowers in the Attic" meets "The Burning Bed."  Stripped of the glamour of the magic show, it's a disturbing story without much actual plot.There isn't any character development to speak of.  The characters grow older and change physically, but, by and large, they continue to act the same way and do the same things all their lives.  There was not much depth to any of them, even the Magician, whom we hear about the most.  Her costumes and her stage routine seemed more real than she did as a person.While the dialog sounds "natural," it doesn't feel right for the period, nor do many of the character interactions.  It is a very difficult period to capture, no question, but the truth is that women were still extremely restricted in terms of dress, relationship and movement.  The author sometimes gives brief nods to the conventions of the time, but never really points up the contrast when her characters flout them.  The whole story feels much too contemporary.Lastly, I think it's a bad title.  I'm really not even sure just what it references.

I bought this to cover a small fountain, and am extremely happy with the material.  Although we strapped it to the fountain, I thought the material, which feels a little papery, might quickly disintegrate in the face of any Iowa winter.  And I have to admit that I really didn't believe the claim to being waterproof.  The cover has stayed in place, has remained completely intact and totally sheds water.  I will definitely buy Duck Covers for other outdoor items in the future.

I should start by saying that I really, really like Neutrogena products.  I am on the downhill side of 50 and wear contact lenses and low-shedding, hypo-allergenic make-up and toiletries are essential to making it through the day without eye irritation.  I'd never been particularly impressed with Neutrogena eye shadow palettes, however, so I was excited to see these colors.  I tried the mink brown, which includes three browns, from a dark walnut to a mild cocoa and a warm vanilla as a highlight; cocoa mauve which has what looks like the same four colors but with a slight purplish tint; and smokey steel, with a dark charcoal, a dark gray, a dark silver and a very cool off-white.  I have to say I love the colors in the cocoa mauve, especially; while it sounds a little awful, it has GREAT colors, not purple and not brown.  I'd like to try the cool plum, also.The shadow goes on smoothly.  It is definitely a powder, not a cream, but it is, as advertised, very moist.  As a result, it blends almost too easily.  You're not going to create the definition described on the package ("put this color here and that color there and the other color in the crease and the last color along the lash line") because the colors are going to blend as you apply them, especially with the little sponge applicator included.  It is possible to get better definition using real tools, such a thin, firm brush for the lash-line outline, but they still blend together quite a bit.  If you're okay with subtle, as I am, that's fine, but if you're looking for high-def drama, this probably isn't the best choice.I can't give the product five stars because its main claim to fame is being LONG WEAR (it's in all caps on the package), and I just didn't find that to be the case.  I applied it a little before 10 in the morning and, when I went to wash my face at a little before 6 that evening, my remover cloth found very little color left.  Although the product indicates it includes primer, I tried it the next day with a separate eye shadow primer underneath, but had the same result.The good news there was that the color didn't seem to settle into creases or get blotchy looking... it seemed to fade away gradually, so that's a blessing.I will definitely use the eye shadow and, as I said, probably purchase a few other colors, because I do like the moisture-rich formula, the colors, and the lack of irritation.  However, if I need the color to last longer, I'll take the shadow with me and plan to re-apply.

It seems like a crime not to love a product like this, not least of all because it is REALLY good chocolate, and I love chocolate!  However, I think that, as a "how to pair wine and chocolate" tasting guide, this falls a bit short, and, since that's the purpose of the product, I'm going to only give it 3 stars.  If it was just "a collection of great chocolate," I would give it 5 stars.The little canister of chocolates comes with 55 squares of chocolate, divided between semi-sweet, bittersweet and extra dark chocolate.  Each candy is about an inch square and maybe an eighth of an inch thick, so these are not chintzy little pieces.  They are individually wrapped.The canister also includes two booklets.  One is about the origin of the chocolates, which are crafted into candy beginning with the cocoa beans under the label of a man who, when he found he only had about a decade left to live, decided to devote his remaining time to his love of good food and good wine, and ended up creating these lovely chocolates.The second booklet describes the process to use to pair wines with chocolates.  Our local grocery has had regular displays for the last few months of wine and chocolate for the wine.  I will readily admit that I am a culture-free bumpkin and am completely unfamiliar with the idea of chocolate and wine together up until encountering these grocery displays, which is one of the reasons I chose this package -- I wanted to learn more about this.  However, while the booklet suggests getting a bunch of wines and inviting 6-8 people for the tasting, and instructs that you include buckets for folks to dispose of wine they don't wish to drink, it falls down terribly with regard to selecting the wines to use.  A single label and vintage is suggested for each variety of chocolate, "or something similar."  The basic idea presented is to use sweeter wines with the sweeter chocolate and dryer wines with the dark chocolate, but there are a LOT of wines out there.During the tasting, you are then to take a bite of the chocolate and savor it, then a sip of wine, then repeat.  There's a little... meditation, I guess I would call it, included to encourage you to better relish the experience.  The booklet encouraged me to read this meditation aloud to my fellow tasters, but I'm afraid that the experience... devolved a bit at that point and we never really got around to the association of the included list of potential adjectives with the tastes of the wine and chocolate.We liked the chocolates.  We liked the wine.  We just didn't like them together.  We ended up getting out the cheese to go with the wine, and pairing the chocolates with coffee, instead.So maybe we are just bumpkins with no palate.  Or maybe I chose wines poorly, although, again, I don't feel like I was given much direction.  But, as a tasting experience, the kit didn't work for us.We did like the chocolate, though!

I should start by saying that none of the dart players here over the holidays have played darts much in a long time; we've been more happenstance spectators at the occasional pub game.  But we were eager to try out this electronic board, sure our skills would quickly be remembered.Finding a place to mount the board was a little bit trickier than we had thought.  It is a bit heavy and needs to be well-anchored to the wall, and also within reach of a power outlet.  The dart assembly was a little tricky because two of the darts came with the tail already on the wrong end of the shaft.  The tail is bigger than the tip, so when the tip was put into the shaft, it fell out.  Realizing the problem, we switched the tail to the correct side of the shaft but, when it had been shoved into the shaft before shipping, it enlarged that receiving end of the shaft and we ended up needing to put a drop of superglue into one tip to get it to stay on the shaft.The machine plays a rather ridiculous fanfare upon powering up; one then selects either the game or the number of players.  You can record the names of the players, which works fine and the machine will then announce the name of the next player to throw, but it's a step that we quickly decided was a bit hokey and stopped using.  The volume can be muted and the display used to track play, also.The scorekeeping worked extremely well.  If a dart bounces off the board, there is a button to push to update the score, easy to do while scooping up the fallen dart.  Another button lets you acknowledge a miss, advancing the play without score, again easy to do when getting the fallen dart.  The only quibble we had here was that all the buttons for game selection, number of players, bounce out dart, everything except a miss and game restart are exactly alike with hard-to-read legends. Just making them different colors or numbering them would have made them easier to use.Darts are a bit hard to get out of the board; again, making sure the board is very securely anchored to the wall is important.  The darts to us seemed to be heavier but smaller than the traditional ones in the past, and the tails definitely seemed smaller and more fragile, although they have not broken or been damaged thus far.The automatic scorekeeping handles a LOT of different games, many more than we'd ever heard of. The enclosed instructions concisely provide the rules for them.  There were a few times we thought the board was malfunctioning, but they all turned out to be situations where we had misunderstood rules for games with which we weren't familiar (which was most of them).We are all techies and thought we'd be all advanced with the electronic features.  Perversely, we found ourselves missing the heft of the "old" big darts and especially the sound of them hitting a cork board.  This, of course, is not the fault of this game, but there it is, nonetheless.Despite all the things the board does well, we found ourselves turning off features like the recorded voice and the voice at all.  We wished the board were more portable, but also decided that, if the board is going to be electronic, why not have portions of the board light up to indicate targets or hits?I give the board 4 stars because it seemed to generally operate as advertised, and because we did appreciate the electronic scoring.  I withhold the 5th star simply because we didn't love it; that, however, may have been us and not the game.

A loose-leaf tea that is described by the company as "strong," I expected this tea to be, well, strong -- the proverbial "stand your spoon up in it" stew.  It's not that at all, and that's the only reason I knocked it from 5 stars to 4.  If the company were to describe it as moderate, I'd agree wholeheartedly and give it the 5th star.  It is quite a nice tea; I just think it is a better choice for a lovely breakfast that precedes a day in the garden or a ramble in the woods than for the hearty meal you bolt prior to ice fishing or baling hay.These are real tea leaves, not the minced up stuff one often gets.  My little infuser was completely inadequate for the 1-2 teaspoons of tea called for in a cup (amount of water isn't specified; I used 8 ounces).  I think I will get this infuser for the future FORLIFE Brew-in-Mug Extra-Fine Tea Infuser with Lid.  The water is to be 192 degrees, according to Tattle Tea, or boiling, so I brought the water to a boil and then poured over the loose tea in the cup.  The package says to steep 1-2 minutes.  I then strained the tea to drink, although one could always just drink carefully and then try a little tea leaf reading (Google it -- lots of directions on the web!).I found the tea to be quite dark in color, but subtle and nuanced in taste.  It is not at all acidic or bitter, but has what is almost a floral note.  For me, this tea gives a barely perceptible English Breakfast nod in the direction of Twinings' Lady Grey tea, the lighter and more restrained mate of musky Earl Grey.  That surprised me; from the company's description, I was expecting something more along the lines of Irish breakfast tea.  Thinking I might not have made it strong enough, I brewed a second cup with 3 teaspoons of tea this time, and a 3 1/2 minute steeping time, but the tea tasted the same.  It's rather remarkable, I think, for it not to get bitter or sludgy, and I'm pleasantly surprised to find that, even without the pre-measured convenience of a teabag, I get consistently good tea.  I do use cream and sweetener, and the tea holds up well to both, as English breakfast tea should, although I think I will use a bit less in the Tattle Tea than I do in some of the other English Tea blends, simply because I'm not contending with any bitterness.Now, I think I'm going to go brew a pot of Tattle Tea and then read some tea leaves to see what the New Year will bring!

One of the problems with evaluating photo editing software is that you don't know what you need until you need it...  so I'm not going to be able to say I've really put this package through its paces yet.  I also have Adobe Photoshop Elements 13, an application that I found amazingly unintuitive and difficult to use, especially considering that I've had every version since 9.  My hope was that Cyberlink PhotoDirector 6 Ultra would be more user friendly.  I found parts of PhotoDirector to be more user friendly, while other parts were less so, and I'm having less luck finding help and YouTube tutorials for those than I did for Elements.I liked it a lot that you don't have to make an either/or choice between editing and organizing; both functions exist on the same menu set.  I did have a real time trying to get PhotoDirector to import all the photos on a hard disk, which were divided between many directories.  I ended up copying them to an external hard drive, a backup that needed to happen, but I still don't understand why it seemed to hang up (or just take forever?) while seeking photos to import.  Some apps, like Picasa, you can't get to QUIT looking for photos and importing everything each time you open the application, but I essentially had to put all the pictures in a pile and tell PhotoDirector 6 to go look in that pile in order to get all the pictures imported.Once I was editing, the basics -- color, density, brightness, etc. -- were all easy to adjust.  I am still having a tough time with the fancier edits.  I am really disappointed in the eye color adjustment, but I have the same complaint about Elements.  A long time ago, there were packages that would do animal eye adjustment.  Now, you have to adjust animal eyes by painting and patch repairing, and it is really hard to easily get a good result.The panorama feature is nice and worked really well even though I didn't originally take photos thinking that I would try to "stitch" them.  There is enough offset in the original images that, if you know where to look, you can see the merge spots, but it's a nice effect at a "distance," when the whole image is resized small enough to see it all at once; you'd probably need to be quite a bit pickier if you're making a wall mural.I do think the app is giving me generally better results than I was getting with Elements, possibly because this app has a little less depth to it, i.e. the amateur doesn't have as much rope with which to get into trouble.And If anybody knows an app that handles animal eye repair well, though, I'd love to know about it!

My one-pound bag of truffles contained 50 truffles.  The outer clear bag is a very crackly plastic -- these are not stealth chocolates!  It also has a label that shows the wrapper color for each of the 14 (FOURTEEN!) flavors of truffles, and the bow is attractive, equally suitable for a male or female recipient.My bag had 3 or 4 of each flavor.  The foil-lined paper wrapper is labelled in addition to being color-coded.  The colors are really lovely, slightly iridescent, and make the truffles seem quite elegant.These truffles are rectangular rather than the large, ball-shaped candies I'm more used to.  At first, I thought this was a bad thing, because More Chocolate is Better.  However, these candies won me over because they are so much easier to eat.  You can easily bite them in half, which makes them a much nicer option for public consumption.The real proof, of course, is in the truffle.  The chocolate in these truffles is absolutely first-rate.  They melt in your mouth.  Each distinct flavor is rich.  If I had to pick a favorite, it would be the mint, with the raspberry a close second, but they are all delectable.This variety bag would, indeed, make a terrific gift, but it's also nice to empty into a pretty bowl to set out during a party or family gathering.  Or you could just keep it for yourself...

This is a romantic comedy which delivers reasonable- if not memorable- light entertainment.It reminded me of "Date Night". I suspect this movie would best be viewed by a couple with children, who are taking the time out to have a relaxing evening together watching a movie.The story is a simple one: with a view to reigniting the spark in their relationship, a married couple make a loving private video. They lose it in the internet cloud, then they try to recover it and stop it being seen by the world.That premise gets the story going, and the humor stems from their efforts to regain their privacy.I thought this was an adequately entertaining movie, but I doubt you would give it a second viewing.Revised: August 2, 2014

This is a gentle story, sensitively presented and rewarding to watch.Note: the majority of the dialogue is in Hindi; there are English subtitles.The story is set in Mumbai, where an extraordinarily efficient daily lunch delivery service operates to send hot meals from people's homes to the workplaces of their loved ones.The delivery service is the device that gets the story going. Through an unlikely error in the delivery of a lunchbox, two unlikely people meet and a relationship develops between them, as they write daily notes to each other- delivered through Mumbai's lunch delivery service.We see their relationship develop at the same time as we are taken into the daily lives of the two main characters: one a widower contemplating retirement, the other the mother of a young child who is contemplating the future of her marriage. All this is set against the backdrop of bustling Mumbai.The story sensitively explores their lives, while the sensitive direction, superb cinematography and nuanced performances from the excellent cast deliver a rewarding experience.This is an excellent example of cinematic storytelling- well worth experiencing.

This is a murder mystery thriller, set in 1962, with a gorgeous look and sound, thanks to the glamorous and exotic settings in Greece and Turkey, and a somewhat "Hitchcockesque" orchestral score.It's based on a Patricia Highsmith novel. Previous film adaptations of Ms Highsmith's novels have included Strangers on a Train and The Talented Mr Ripley- both excellent films.Sadly, I did not consider this movie to be in the same caliber as those great films. It lacks the richness of characterisation and quality of engagement which are hallmarks of both of those movies.Whilst it was adequately entertaining, these days we see television movies and episodes of serial television dramas which present more sophisticated, suspenseful and - frankly - entertaining tales.Although it is technically well made, it had a rather dated feel about it, like a B film from the 1950s.It's not a bad movie- rather, I suspect that audiences have become more demanding and discerning and this movie does not deliver a mystery/ suspense entertainment experience which accords with contemporary expectations.

This is the movie based on the international hit musical show.It's an entertaining and engaging biopic, telling the story of the Four Seasons musical group, and its members.The focus of the movie is on telling the story of the band, rather than performance of the music. Nonetheless, several of the Four Seasons hits are presented as part of the story.Translating a musical from the stage to the screen can be a difficult process. The translation of Jersey Boys has involved a refocussing on the narrative story, rather than the music. I suspect the film is best viewed on its own merits as a biopic, rather than a stage show adapted to the screen. The structure of the story telling has been changed significantly from the stage show (which tells the group's story from the perspective of each member).I thought the direction by Clint Eastwood was masterful- telling the story in a matter of fact fashion, effectively blending drama, emotion and humor. The interactions between the members of the band - in particular their tensions - are portrayed realistically.It is an entertaining and well crafted film, which I suspect will satisfy most viewers. The finale is particularly entertaining, featuring all the characters performing together- as in the finale to a stage production.Incidentally, watch out for Clint Eastwood appearing on a television screen as Rowdy Yates from Rawhide.

Essentially, this movie is about the world fighting against an implacable alien invader, and the protagonist's use of his ability to rewind time to carry on the seemingly futile fight.Put that way, it sounds a relatively simple story- it is cleverly and convincingly told, with good performances from the major actors.Tom Cruise plays against type, in a charming and engaging way, with a good dose of humor. Emily Blunt delivers a good performance as a no-nonsense heroine.If you enjoyed movies in the science fiction/ time travel genre such as Starship Troopers, Inception or Looper, I suspect you will enjoy this movie. The time rewind premise reminded me of Groundhog Day. And, the reincarnation concept reminded me of The Prestige.It has a good blend of engaging story, good acting performances and convincing special effects.For fans of the genre, this is a well crafted entertainment, convincingly made by an experienced action director: Doug (The Bourne Identity, Mr & Mrs Smith) Liman.Is it a great movie? No, but it is an engaging entertainment, with a sufficiently compelling premise to keep you watching.Reflecting upon the movie, I considered whether it had a message? Yes it does: maintain persistence in a struggle against adversity.Revised: June 26, 2014

This movie is not for everyone. It demands patience and concentration. For the director, it is a work which involved 10 years in the making. As you watch this film, it becomes evident that each scene has been the subject of much thought and consideration.For those who enjoy this genre of film, it is an extraordinary and rewarding experience. Others would find it a chore to sit through this complex allegorical tale for 108 minutes.Jonathan Glazer has crafted a remarkable work of original motion picture art, with the collaboration of Scarlett Johansson, who delivers a stunning performance in a complex role as an alien whose mission is to kidnap men for consumption by her race. Her role was made additionally challenging as several scenes involved improvisation, with Ms Johansson engaging numerous unwitting persons to become participants in the movie.The music by Mica Levi is atmospheric, haunting and disturbing.Daniel Landin's cinematography is excellent- whether it is capturing the beauty of Scarlett Johansson and the Scottish countryside, filming from a point of view perspective or meeting the challenge of filming covertly. The cinematography effectively conveys the mesmerising ambience and the emotion of the story.The story is told in a mesmerising fashion- the jigsaw pieces of the tale are disclosed one by one until the full picture is revealed.Interestingly, part of the filming of the movie involved the unknowing participation of men who were propositioned by Scarlett Johansson as she was driving a van. Covert cameras in the van captured their reaction to being approached by a beautiful and mysterious woman. The unwitting participants were told about the filming afterwards.In much the same way, the audience is taken on a journey where the multiple layers of the story are lifted one by one, until the final denouement. Johansson's (unnamed) character develops during the film, evolving from being a dispassionate hunter through to learning and experiencing human compassion, desire and vulnerability, acceptance by and assimilation with humanity, then ultimately metamorphosing (like the insects she finds fascinating) from being the hunter to prey and on to being a victim of cruelty and ignorance.There are fine observations and explorations of the nature of humanity- both good and bad - including compassion, vulnerability, mercy, pity, altruism, survival, desire, lust, cruelty and ignorance. And, the director makes some pointed observations about "skin" - society's fascination with the outer envelope of physical appearance.I have read that others have compared this movie to the works of Kubrick- I thought that there are some comparisons to be made with "2001- A Space Odyssey". As I was watching it, some scenes vaguely reminded me of Tony Scott's "The Hunger"- however, the stories are quite different. At times, I could see parallels with Nicholas Roeg's "The Man who fell to Earth". And, I thought the sympathetic killer theme was reminiscent of Hitchcock's "Psycho"*. Luc Besson's "Nikita" also came to mind.**Nonetheless, this is an original artistic work, which stands on its own creative merits, and which I suspect will become the subject of critical analysis by film students.This is a quite remarkable movie- very rewarding and worthwhile for aficionados of this artistic genre.*An unusual coincidence: Scarlett Johansson's character is a sympathetic killer; in "Hitchcock", she portrayed the actor who played the victim of one of the screen's best known sympathetic killers- Norman Bates in "Psycho".**Another coincidence: Ms Johansson is starring in M. Besson's "Lucy".Revised: 1. June 12, 2014; 2. June 15, 2014; 3. June 16, 2014; 4. June 17, 2014; 5. June 23, 2014

Chef is a straightforward story, which is told in an engaging and appealing way.The star- Jon Favreau- also wrote and directed the movie. His character- a celebrity chef who falls from grace, then rebuilds his life- is appealing, sympathetic, believable, and most importantly: genuinely funny.The story comprises several themes:1. Confrontation between the artistic creative chef (Jon Favreau) and his conservative employer about whether to serve adventurous or conservative cuisine2. A verbal "pie fight" between the chef and a fussy food critic3. A father disconnected from his son4. A road trip, where the chef rediscovers his creative roots and reconnects with his son5. The chef discovers reinvigorated creativityFrom these ingredients, Mr Favreau cooks up an entertaining feel good light comedy.There are good cameo appearances from Dustin Hoffman, Scarlett Johansson and Robert Downey Jr.Sofia Vergara appeals as the chef's ex wife.While the story is simple and straightforward, it is told in an engaging and charming fashion, with a good dose of light humor.The food scenes are gorgeous: apparently Mr Favreau did his own cooking after training from road truck chef Roy Choi - watch the closing credits!Also, look out for the animated Twitter tweets- an interesting story telling technique.This is an entertaining movie with broad appeal- well worth a look!Revised: June 14, 2014

I highly recommend this movie.It's a sensitive adaptation of the best selling young adult novel.What is it about? It's a love story- two star crossed lovers who find each other through their fight with a common enemy: cancer.Shailene Woodley is perfectly cast, as Hazel Grace Lancaster, a normal teenage girl coping with all of the agonies of growing up, with the additional challenge of battling cancer.The story explores her battle with cancer, as well as her first romance and the frustrations of growing up.Laura Dern stands out as Hazel's loving mother, who portrays all the love and angst of the parent of a terminally ill child.There's a subplot involving Hazel visiting a famous author in Amsterdam (a cantankerous Willam Defoe), and a poignant visit to the home of Anne Frank.This type of story is difficult to bring to the screen successfully- the artistic talents involved have done that, creating a beautiful and moving cinematic experience, which is well worthwhile.Revised June 9, 2014

At times it's rude, profane and violent. Also, some scenes involve sexual references and toilet humor.Nonetheless, I thought this was a clever and entertaining movie- a send up Western, in the tradition of "Blazing Saddles" and "Evil Roy Slade".The opening is terrific: a great Western score, and beautiful cinematography capturing the natural beauty of Monument Valley in Utah.The story is a simple one- but if you like this kind of humor, it's done well.The cast is uniformly excellent- Seth MacFarlane shows a deft comic touch as star, writer and director, as well as contributing his talent to songs in the movie- the dance hall scene with the band performing "If you've only got a moustache" is a show stopper.Charlie Theron shows another side as a comic talent, and the remainder of the cast are experienced comedy players. Liam Neeson is a suitably nasty gunslinger.There are some surprise cameo appearances which add to the enjoyment of this carefully contrived amusement.On the whole, this a well made light comedy entertainment. The music is great and the cinematography is gorgeous.Be sure to watch the credits all the way to the end:)Well worth seeing, unless you find this genre of humor offensive or in poor taste.

This is a comedy based upon the rivalry between a young couple with a new baby, and their new neighbors - a university frat house.The cast is good for this type of movie: Seth Rogan and Zac Efron play their protagonist roles convincingly, and Rose Byrne is a good foil as Rogan's wife.All of the cast are quite charming in their roles.Liza Kudrow makes a welcome cameo appearance as the dean of the university.It's a comedy based upon the simple premise of the friction between the family wishing to enjoy a peaceful suburban life and their garden partying neighbors.One thing you need to know is that is at times rude, and the characters use colorful language. Indeed, in one scene, Rogan comments to Byrne about his concern that their daughter's first word may be a profanity!If you enjoy this simple and somewhat  raunchy humor, you will like this movie. If not, I suspect you will find this tiresome.

This is an excellent movie.I suspect it is not for everyone: essentially, it's the tale of a morally bankrupt corporation which will stop at nothing to cover up its misdeeds. There's a battle between good and evil, and a full spectrum of characters: including decent people who are innocent victims, an anti-hero good guy, and people whose humanity has seemingly disappeared. The interplay of these characters, and the layering of story lines and subplots is handled masterfully.What makes it a good movie?First, the excellent performances from the cast. George Clooney is entirely believable as an attorney who is his firm's "fixer". Tilda Swinton delivers a superb performance as a corporate executive who will do anything- legal or not- to protect her employer. The supporting cast is uniformly excellent.Then, there's the screenplay and direction by Tony (Bourne Legacy) Gilroy. He sweeps you up into the story, and the devious twists and turns of the plot, as well as taking you into the lives of the characters.While this is a fictional story, there is an aura of authenticity which creates the impression the events depicted could happen in reality. It's a cautionary tale of what can happen when corporate greed overwhelms moral judgment. But, it is entertaining, and the moral message never overwhelms that entertainment value.Well worth watching for a compelling tale.

This is a 75 minute CD, with 26 tracks. All of the tracks are from the movie except track 26, which was an alternative recording for a scene. The original soundtrack CD had 10 tracks, so there is substantially more material on this CD.It features all of the orchestral music from the movie. It doesn't include the nightclub scene dance music - notwithstanding that this scene is depicted on the cover of the CD!For anyone who enjoys the music from the movie, this is a worthwhile purchase, as it has some 30 minutes of additional music, compared with the original soundtrack CD.The recording is of high quality.The CD is accompanied by an interesting booklet, which comprises commentary on the music and the movie.I highly recommend this CD for anyone who wishes to have a soundtrack of the movie, or who has an interest in the music of Jerry Goldsmith.

This is an excellent and engaging book.It is the companion to a television series which appeared on PBS and BBC.While written 20 years ago, it remains fresh and engaging, with wry observations on the nature of fame and self promotion.The last two decades only confirm James' observations on the cults of "fame" and "celebrity".The writer has a witty style, and a dry sense of humor, combined with a keen sense of observation.At the Amazon price, this is a good buy for an entertaining and thoughtful read.

This is an excellent cookbook.The writer is well known in the USA, as the food writer for the New York Times.It is a comprehensive book, with hundreds of interesting recipes, as well as practical tips.One of the most important things about the book is that the recipes actually work! Try the souffl recipe- I have found it to be literally foolproof!Highly recommended, and a great gift.Non-US readers should note this is a US book, so it refers to US measures and names for certain foods.

Vellux is a longstanding and dependable blanket, and an American innovation in fabrics.The Vellux material is a lightweight yet sturdy fabric, with a soft and cosy velour feel. While lightweight, it is warm. It maintains its attractive neat appearance, and it does not "pill" or shed fibers.One thing you need to note is the special laundering instructions, including the need to launder the blanket at least every 6 months to maintain moisture in the blanket. (The Australian distributor recommends laundering every 3 months). If they are not laundered, then the backing can disintegrate. The synthetic material is easy to launder - you can machine wash, and the material does not crease or wrinkle.The sizing of the blanket is generous, so there's plenty of material for tucking in.While traveling, I have found that several hotels- including 5 star- have Vellux blankets, which must represent an endorsement of their quality, durability and comfort.And, at the Amazon price, this is good value!

This is a highly entertaining movie, and a most successful adaptation of a theatrical musical.The acting, direction, music and visualisation are superb.Anyone who has seen movie versions of stage productions has witnessed how difficult it can be to make the transition from theater to cinema. Rob Marshall has made that transformation in a most imaginative and original way- having the movie glide from the gritty reality of 1920s era Chicago to a fantasy world- then back again.The singing and dancing is excellent.This is a textbook example of how to film a musical- and it stands a second viewing.Highly recommended

Vellux is a longstanding and dependable blanket.The Vellux material is a lightweight yet sturdy fabric, with a soft velour feel. While lightweight, it is a warm blanket. It maintains its attractive neat appearance, and it does not "pill" or shed fibers.One thing you need to note is the special laundering instructions, including the need to launder the blanket at least every 6 months to maintain moisture in the blanket. (The Australian distributor recommends laundering every 3 months). If they are not laundered, then the backing can disintegrate. The synthetic material is easy to launder - you can machine wash, and the material does not crease or wrinkle.The sizing of the blanket is generous, so there's plenty of material for tucking in.While traveling, I have found that several hotels- including 5 star- have Vellux blankets.At the Amazon price, this is good value!

This is the OEM cargo area tray.It has the following attributes:- attractive and good quality custom OEM appearance- incorporating the stylised "500" logo- hence it looks like an integral part of your car- the dimensions fit the floor of your car's cargo area perfectly- adding to the "integral part of the car" look- it is made from a durable and waterproof material, so it is practical and easy to clean- the tray has raised edges, so that spills are contained- the surface of the tray has ridges which help to stop items sliding around- the tray appears to be manufactured to a high quality standardAs far as I can see, there are no particular problems or disadvantages with this attractive looking and practical cargo tray.It is a practical storage enhancement as well as protecting the appearance of the trunk of your car.

I have used these blister bandages several times over the years, particularly when I have developed blisters on the soles of my feet after walking long distances, while traveling overseas on vacation.In my experience, they are invaluable, for these reasons:- they relieve the pain of a blister, by providing a cushion- they seal the area and accelerate the healing process, as well as inhibiting the ingress of germs. Note that the bandage is intended to stay on until the blister heals- they minimize the risk of the blister bursting- when you're traveling, they help you to stay on your feet and carry on with your journey!- they let you enjoy your vacationThe cost is extraordinarily modest for the benefits they deliver.Highly recommended, particularly for travelers and anyone who needs to stay on their feet!

This movie focuses on the interactions between the members of a (fictional) string quartet.The driver for the movie is the impending retirement of the leader of the quartet, due to diagnosis of an illness which will preclude him from performing.
