I used an iPhone 6+ which was also inside a battery charging half-clam case, so I tested the limits of how much this selfie stick could handle weight and size wise. It held up well (as it should), so no points deducted there.Where I really fell in "serious like" with it was the ease of bluetooth connectivity. I didn't "rtfm" and so I had no idea what the button was supposed to do. I thought it was a remote to move the camera around. It turns out that whatever you have your phone set for it will act like a remote. For example: I charged up the selfie stick by plugging it into the computer for a bit. Later I came back and pushed the button and looked at the settings on my iPhone. It shows up as "Winnersun" on your phone by the way. I hit the button on the selfie stick and some music on myPhone started to play. I hit the button again and the music stopped. This made me think, so I turned on the camera app and hit the selfie stick button again. It snapped a picture. I switched to video and hit the selfie stick button. It started recording. I hit the selfie stick button again and it stopped. This made sense.The device is pretty stupid (non-intuitive - not "it is bad"), but that is okay. You just have to be 2% smarter than the tool you are using. As long as you set up your phone to be ready to snap a picture or start recording, this selfie stick will do its job perfectly. As a bonus, you can use it as a remote for your phone for a number of things (like playing music it turns out). So, all in all, yes, it will hold your phone in place, it does fit in your pocket (if you have baggy pants - it was weird trying to walk around with this in my jeans pocket, although I did get some nice compliments). For the price it is a good value. The plastic grip on it is durable and easy to clean, and the hand loop (not shown in product shots) is nice to make sure you don't drop it - and your phone. What makes this is the bluetooth remote. I was given the black topped model and I have to say it looks pretty cool. This will be going in my gig bag. You don't have to just shoot selfies with it. Think of it as a 3' extension of your arm that you can use to film hard to get spots. THAT is why I give it 4 stars.

When ZVOLTZ contacted me and said "Hey! Do you want to review this?" I thought to myself "I just reviewed an identical product that cost twice as much. This has to be crap. There is no way they can sell the same exact thing for half the price." But I said yes anyway (I really wanted to compare these). So here's the poop:It is ridiculously inexpensive for what it does. So that is nice. But I did some comparisons to other, even cheaper, options and saw the tiny differences, like no LED lights and a less user-friendly composition. This thing is spot-on exact to the more expensive brand name models. I seriously believe the manufacturer makes them and simply silk screens each company's name on the back. The LEDs on the back are bright and easy to see, and they light up as it charges. If you want to see how much battery power is in your ZVOLTZ "external battery/charger" you simply quick press the button on the back. That is the same button you press to turn it on to charge your iPhone.Mind you, if you do NOT push the power button after snapping your iPhone into this thing it won't charge "automatically." You have to press the button, and then it will charge until your iPhone is completely charged, and then it shuts off automatically. If you want to charge your iPhone more (after using it for a while ) you press the button. It's pretty simple in that respect.Here is a HUGE ISSUE you must know: This works with an iPhone, so it has a built in lightning plug, but to charge your ZVOLTZ (battery/charger) you have to have a micro USB cable (which is PC or Chrome - and NOT Mac). This thing does come with a cable (USB 2 on one end, micro USB on the other), but if you misplace or forget it and think "iPhone, right? I can just use my lightning plug to charge my ZVOLTZ" you will bee angry, frustrated, and disappointed. You need to remember this because it is counter-intuitive and may cause problems.So, how long does it last? This charges my iPhone 1.25 times from dead, and if I charge my iPhone through my ZVOLTZ (so they are both charged 100%) I can squeeze about 250% of my iPhone's normal duration, or 1 normal iPhone charge and an extra 1.5 charge delivered from the ZVOLTZ.. This means that for the hassle of charging once you get a LOT more "in the field" iPhone usage. This makes a huge difference with the crappy iPhone batteries.The downside if that you really need to keep your phone in this thing at all times. It is not that large really.It makes your iPhone thicker and larger, but that is the point of a protective case. This is really Otterbox or Ballistic (premium brands) level protection "plus you get an extra battery." If you have an iPhone 6+ you know how much bigger it is than a 4 or a 5, so an extra cm or two should not matter much. But if you are a priss like me an love your TwelveSouth "BookBook" leather case that makes your iPhone look like an old leather book then you have some serious choices to make. Style or battery. This thing rates a 5 on style (compared to a solid 8 for the BookBook) so there is that. I make a big deal ot of this as I have found out the hard way what happens when you try to swap cases too much with this style of battery pack (no matter what brand you buy). The top or front part of the case snaps off (this is no easy task by the way) and you have to SLIDE your iPhone out, not LIFT it out, or the built-in lightning plug will snap off and you just wasted money on a battery case. Prognosis: if you get this thing leave it plugged in at all times.Is it waterproof? Meh. More than NOT having your iPhone in it, but I would not drop it in the toilet to find out. The speaker holes are "okay," but they point up (at you) instead of down the bottom of the iPhone so they give the illusion of a slightly fuller, richer sound and tiny increase in volume. All in all I really like this thing. It feels good in your hands and is relatively non-slip. Just make sure you like it, because you won't want to take your iPhone out of it: that is a hassle.

This is a solid cable, but it does have dome drawbacks. Disclaimer: I like Mediabridge products, because of all of the money I have spent on them, none has ever disappointed me. Coincidentally I was offered to test this for free, and I did. I am a bit disappointed, but not horribly so.So, we have a ten foot cable. That right there is worth 5 stars. Apple will NEVER make a ten foot cable. You would never think you need one until you get tired of jerking the tiny ones out of your Mac/i(Thing)/wall adapter. This is really handy when you need to run some cable a ways and you don't to have to use generic USB extenders (3' male to female extension cables). It is twice as thick as the ones Apple makes, which I like for durability, but according to the specs, this allows you to run a lot more wattage (means you can charge more - longer; the cable won't fry or melt).So basic usage: It has a standard USB (2) to lightning plug design. "Meh." They could have gone USB3 as long as they have a lightning plug and a thicker wire core, right? That would have allowed more "speed" of data transfer. Oh well, it is an inexpensive plug. I am disappointed, but not mortified. Next we have the color. I have to address this. Not to be a snob, but if you buy a Macbook, and/or an iPhone and/or an iPad and/or an iPod (omg! I just realized I might have too many Apple products!) you expect your cables to be white. It is an Apple thing. Apple = white cables. maybe someday they will come in cool rainbow colors, but until that day white cables screams out "Mac cool." The ones they sent me to test and review are battleship gray. Yes, gray like the Death Star, or like an average day in Seattle. It's kind of depressing really. I know this does not affect the function of the cables, but you have to be seen in public with these. If they offer these in white be sure to specify. The ones in the product picture are black.Now we get to what is seriously wrong with this cable. Sorry Mediabridge: "I love you man," but that lightning plug end is purposefully fattened up (for extra strength?) and that makes it completely useless when you are trying to charge your Apple product and your i(thing) is in a case you bought to protect it. This may seem like a small inconvenience until you have to deal with it and the only fix is to go on Amazon and buy a NEW cable, wait 2-5 days and then resume normal operation, or get in your car and drive around looking for a long cable that has an Apple-standard connector.

I have a few Bluetooth speakers. I think I was the last person on the planet to see the value of a Bluetooth speaker, but i have quickly become a connoisseur of these little devices. I prefer ones that are mid-range in price, and on the higher end of the quality (for price) spectrum. The idea of spending several hundred dollars (or more) for a tiny speaker I can take everywhere with me is just stupid. So, when I was asked to do a review of this I looked it over and said, "why not?" I have a feel for these now, after having bought several. I know what I like and what I like is ease of use, great sound, and a long battery life. Waterproof or water resistant properties are a bonus. So, why this speaker - and is it worth paying for?To be fair, I compared this particular speaker to my iHome speakers (two popular models) and one a friend sent me that looks like an octopus, as well as a rather large one the size of a football. This one outperformed them all. I have never heard of this company, and the fact that the big promo on Amazon is "Bluetooth" and not a brand name makes me think of my 42" Hisense computer monitor. I bought that at Walmart for half the price of any name brand. It works, but for the price I would not cry if it didn't. The same thing applies here. This is a GOOD LOOKING speaker. The blue ring does not light up by the way - it just looks like it does in the picture. I have added my own "real life" pix below.So, the sound is great, but what is really cool is that you don't drain your iPhone's (or Android phone's) battery whilst blasting your music. It draws from the speaker, so your phone lasts a LOT longer.All you are sending from your phone is the standard wireless ("Bluetooth") signal, so it is a low, steady draw of power. The battery (in the speaker) does all of the hard work. Not shown in the Amazon product pic is the GIGANTIC suction cup. At first this really pissed me off. I thought the suction cup looked dopey and cheesy. Well, then I tried using it and that thing is made of superglue. A tiny bit of moisture on a smooth surface (like tile, or glass, or your car) and that suction cup will hold up in a hurricane. It is a PitA to get it off of whatever you stick it to - which is the point of a good suction cup.The buttons are easy enough to figure out, and it is kind of cool to be able to raise and lower volume, pause, stop, fast forward and reverse, all without having to grab your phone. The speaker is great but the voice recognition of the unit is about 70% of where it should be: it will never replace your phone's microphone.Prognosis? This is a keeper. For the price I would put this as top of class. It charges quickly and is easy to use and remarkably water resistant (do not soak it). Great for rainy days, boats, bathrooms, or kitchens, as an external speaker. It is no Bose, but it is perfect as an additional speaker. You can always use it as an extra "hidden speaker" to complete your sound system as well. Anyway, thanks for reading - hope this helps.

Grr!!Stupid Windows!I swear, I have been through this twice now. I "think" this is working, but the Bluetooth technology can't be seen by Windows (8.1 i7 Quad core). I look online for help and get nothing. I am DONE with this. The tiny blue light works, so I know this thing is on, and "occasionally" I can get one of my Bluetooth headsets to work when this is plugged in. But other than that it is pretty useless. Until this comes with a manual I will say "stay away from it entirely." I don't care how well-made it is if it won't work with Windows (and 90% of the time it won't - and this is after hours of fighting with this on several occasions).

I have read some of the other reviews about this product so I will try to avoid repeating the same old information you will find elsewhere. I got this to try out free from Amazon in exchange for a review. What Amazon didn't know was that i would ask this product to do the impossible (and why not?)I bought a 100 year old set of (leather) saddlebags on eBay. It sounded like a good idea at the time. Well, they arrived and they were stiffer than old shoe leather. I had made a huge mistake and needed a "miracle cure" to bring the leather back to life. I had read all about mink oil (the yeses and the no's on whether to trust it or not), and I have some Leather Honey(tm) on hand. I decided I would give THIS product a try and even called the company.So, points for them answering the phone and helping me. I told them what I was attempting and asked them specifically for detailed instructions to get the best results. Sadly, after several treatments, and a LOT of soaking the bags in this stuff in ideal conditions I saw almost no change at all. Here is what happened. First, the smell is pretty strange - but the company is "The Chemical Guys" so that should not be a surprise. They are trying to invent a leather miracle-worker in a lab; of course it is going to smell like the inside of a plastic factory. To me, that was an acceptable nuisance if it did what I needed it to. The first coat soaked right into the leather within 15 minutes. Other than that I noticed no difference (except the smell).I coated the leather a few more times over a few weeks (which is why this review is so late) and if I used my imagination I could pretend I was seeing results. This product will NOT restore old dried out leather (note: this leather was slightly flexible and not brittle, flaky, or falling apart - just very very dry). I did try it out on my Docs though and it seemed to help a little (they are not dried out and 100 years old). Compared to other leather products I have used in the past I can't say this one is any better or worse. I don't care if you gave me a lifetime supply of this. I just don't see how it can help (or hurt). I would give it two stars, but the customer service is above top notch. I didn't talk to some shared customer service drone in a call-center. I spoke to someone who knew he product inside and out (maybe it was one of the Chemical Guys!) but I never asked what he did there. It pains me to write such a scathing review seeing how eager he was to help me succeed, but the stuff just doesn't seem to do a whole lot more than any quality oil or leather treatment would.I want to know what results other people are getting and how they can prove it. I should have seen SOME difference, some noticeable effect, but after weeks of trying all I ended up with was a smelly leather bag that was just as dry as when I got it from eBay. My Docs - well they are new and stiff (like Docs are) and this stuff did not soften them up much at all - if at all. I will keep trying this stuff (as I still have half of a bottle - this stuff does seem to go a long way). If I end up succeeding with an amazing breakthrough I will certainly amend my review. As for now, I just cannot recommend this particular product. The company? Yes. Thanks for reading. I hope your experiences are better than mine have been to date.

This is a great light-weight yoga mat bag with adjustable strap because it really thoughtfully addresses the needs of the practitioner. Here is what really stands out:(1)  Side loading zippered bag so it is easy to pull out and put the yoga mat especially when I am in a rush;(2)  Tabbed zipper makes it easy to open/close the bag when I am in a rush;(3)  The bag is sufficiently wide enough for the thick and longer Manduka mat;(4)  Vents in the bag are great to minimize a smelly mat;(5)  I like the lined interior so I can wipe it down if necessary;(6)  Two extra storage from the zipped interior and exterior pockets;The zipped interior webbed pocket is great for keys, wallet, and cell phoneThe zipped exterior pocket is great for frequently reached objects, such as yoga gloves, skidless towel, or yoga strapBut . . . to improve on an already awesome bag, recommendations:(1)  replace the strap connector to the bag from plastic to metal for higher durability;(2)  make the exterior material waterproof or line the interior of the exterior pocket to minimize the water intrusion when carrying the bag in the rain;(3)  confirm if the bag is machine washable; and(4)  have two zippers because in my experience a long zipper invariably breaks then I can no longer close the bag.All in all it is a great bag for the price. Thanks for reading. Hope this helps you make your decision.

I was asked to review this, along with the company's other creations. I got them free, but I like complaining, so they don't get any special treatment from me. That said, these are GREAT - but only if you have an actual use for them (see below). Otherwise they are a waste of money.You can make anything in these: jello, jello shots, ice, candy, chocolate chunks, square cakes, ice cream, sorbet, and pretty much anything else you need to freeze or bake in a mold. What makes this special is how easy it makes to create square blocks, which are extremely useful for creating artistic shapes (ice cream cakes, cake castles, Jello pyramids, etc). This is more a tool for the professional food artist than something you would have hanging around the house. Oven, microwave, and freezer safe (within responsible parameters), this is just a cool thing to have if you like creating with food.

Yea yeah, I got these free . . . so, how do they work?Well, before I address that I have to say that the reviews for this product are hilarious. The vendor does have to set the price, but they seem to still be in testing phase. Okay, yes there is a (gentle) learning curve to these. First, use good water. Forget that stuff from the tap. Purify your water or use distilled. Also, watch the temperature you use, and the temperature of the molds while you are pouring, and even the temperature of your freezer. All of these factor into how quickly your particular ice cubes will freeze, which in turns creates various amounts of cloudiness or bubbles. No, you CAN'T see the fill line, but if you use a measuring cup you will never make a mistake, so that problem is easily solved.For best results, use Kool-Aid, or similar colored punch flavored creations.

Yes! It does make anything (jello, jello shots, ice, candy, chocolate chunks, square cakes, ice cream, sorbet, and pretty much anything else you need to freeze or bake in a mold. What makes this special is how easy it makes to create square blocks, which are extremely useful for creating artistic shapes (ice cream cakes, cake castles, Jello pyramids, etc). This is more a tool for the professional food artist than something you would have hanging around the house. Oven, microwave, and freezer safe (within responsible parameters), this is just a cool thing to have if you like creating with food.

Well, I like it. But there are some caveats. The lines on this thing don't etch very deep into your ice, candy, or chocolate, so it is more of a special occasion thing to be combined with other obviously Star Wars themed items, than something fun and exciting on its own. I got this free to review. As I said, I like it, but I don't "love" it. Silicone molds for ice cubes are a PitA. I know this, as I have years of silicone mold experience making soaps, candies, and candles professionally. After reading other reviews I see what they did wrong. First, never run hot water over a cold silicone mold. You run the risk of damaging your mold and its contents. For best results you really need to use cola or tea, ice coffee, or some other dark liquid (hmmm... like chocolate) to really get the best results. Also, don't remove the mold from the freezer (or refrigerator) depending on your technique and what you are making, until you are ready to serve. If you are working with ice I strongly recommend that you pull this out from the freezer several minutes before, and then popping it in the fridge to defrost in a more controlled environment. You want the mold to warm up, not the contents inside. Silicone molds require patience - there is no substitute for that. When you take that into account, this is a pretty cool one. Thanks for reading. Hope this helps.

I had a chance to review these. They didn't have to ask me twice. These are super cool. They are silicone cups (well duh . . .) and they are easy to use and even easier to clean. The fun colors mean that you can pour the batter in them, toss them in the oven, and serve them. Why? Save money, save time, and make it fun to grab your creations. I am not sure what else I can add, as there are already so many reviews, but even though I got these free for examination, I really like them. They are dishwasher safe, or you can soak them a bit before hand-washing them. I don't see a downside to these except people you serve these to throwing them away afterwards by mistake.

Yes! Great paper. I choked on the cost, but it is really good paper. I like the smooth glossy feel, the strength of it: it is thick for a "normal sheet of paper." It is in fact super bright - white, not grayish or yellowish white. For 11x17 usage, this is the only paper I will be using from now on in my printer. Try to find it on sale if you can.

i bought a refurbished laptop off the dell refurb site for a really great deal. i knew the battery was going to be junk, and i was right. so i hopped over here to find something aftermarket that would pick up the slack, and this agptek appeared to be the best option. i didn't realize that the battery was going to stick out the backside, but that's what you get if you want that additional capacity.i get a full 5-6 hours use on each charge with this battery, which is what dell offered with it's oem batteries when this computer was new. it fits perfectly in my m4500, and it shipped quickly with no troubles. i'm very happy with this purchase!

this shirt is very comfortable. there's no loose strings, no tags to irritate your neck, and no frills or silly graphics or gimmicks going on here. it's a simple v-neck in white, that fits perfectly and is pretty lightweight. for under $5 with free shipping, this is a great deal.

this device does exactly what it is intended to do, and that is to convert hdmi signal into vga format with an analog audio output. my only issue with the device is that the vga adapter doesn't fasten securely into the adapter (the little hand-screws have nowhere to screw into) and the adapter has wiggled loose on me a couple times already.other than that one issue, i'm very pleased. picture quality is great, and the size of this adapter makes it easy to squeeze it in behind a tv or some other inconspicuous place. for the price, you can't beat it.

i received this product as a sample, for testing and review purposes.the sound quality is actually pretty impressive from this little bluetooth speaker. sure, it's a little bit harsh and not bassy at all, but what do you expect? it's not pretending to be a bose-quality sound system, and it definitely has more volume and a greater frequency response than most every phone's speakers. it paired with every device i tried it on, and it also controlled playback, without issue. my wife has used it in the shower several times, and she liked it enough that she even took it into the kitchen with her. the unit is constructed of not-flimsy but not-super-rigid plastic, which doesn't really give you the feeling of a heavy-duty piece of hardware. but it did stand up to water and general moisture in the shower, which is about all you can expect from a $25 bluetooth speaker.i can't fully comment on the battery life yet, but on first charge we have actually had well over 3 hours of playback. i haven't yet tried the call feature, because my phone hasn't rang while using it. however, i'm quite impressed with this device for its price point. i bought a $120 (at the time) waterproof bluetooth speaker from grace digital a couple years ago, that sounds better and is definitely more rugged. but it also cost 5x more. this device is a great deal if you're looking for a low-cost water-resistant bluetooth speaker.

i used this dye to change the color of a cotton robe from tan to a light purple-ish. it took less than half the bottle, and the effect was exactly what i was looking for. i just mixed 5 gallons of hot water, a half cup of salt, and the dye together in a large container, and then sloshed the robe around in that mixture for about 10 minutes. the robe absorbed almost all the dye from the water, and the container didn't suffer any stains. into the washer with the robe, and it was done. perfect!i think you can find this dye for less in the local big box stores, but i'm not making a special trip to one of them to save a buck or two. good purchase!

this remote appears to be new. there are absolutely no blemishes or scratches on it, and all the buttons are in perfect condition. i was of the impression that these were used? at any rate, you'll need to provide your own pair of AAA batteries. otherwise, it works right out of the gate with my dell 1410X projector very well.

this kit seems to work pretty well. some of the accessories are decent, while others are lacking. the wrench is far from ideal for accessing the faucet nut when you're working around multiple faucets. you'll want to buy a different wrench if this is the case. also, the cleaning line is attached to the jug and not the pump handle, so you'll have to either disconnect the cleaning line to refill the jug or refill it with another container.i never used the powder cleaner because i prefer national chemical "blc" in the quart containers. the brush works well and the ball lift does what it needs to do. for the price, this is a good kit if you're not pressed for time. cleaning multiple lines takes longer than it should, but if you're only cleaning one line, i would recommend it.

i like these wipes for the boy's bottom, because they don't leave a horrid scent behind and they do a pretty good job of cleaning up any messes he creates in, around, or even outside his diaper. this bulk packaging provides a larger amount of wipes than any size i see in the store. each box comes with one of those pop-lid containers and three individually-sealed bags of wipes. combine these wipes with a warmer, and i almost want to use them on my own bottom...i have had a couple problems with these wipes tearing mid-wipe, which often results in needing an extra wipe and a trip to the restroom to clean up your hands before continuing on. but hey, they're not made of burlap. an occasional tear is a good trade-off for the softness of these wipes. as an extra "good job you frugal old man" boost to the ego, you can also get an extra discount if you add these to the subscribe & save.you really can't go wrong with these wipes. we've never had any issues with allergic reactions, and they have always shipped in great condition with no dried-out packages. buy in bulk and subscribe for the best savings possible!

this is an extremely lightweight med kit! there's enough room inside the outer pouch to add a couple extra items. i added a clotting sponge and hemostatic gauze without adding hardly any extra weight or bulk to the pack. it fits nicely inside one of the outer pouches on my large alice pack. there are also sealed inner bags that offer extra water protection, if the outer bag were to fail from being punctured or smashed.i hope we don't ever need to use this medical kit. but if the need arises, i'm confident this kit will prove its excellence again.

i have this clipped to one of my pack straps for a handsfree light while moving around at night. the clip is very sturdy, and the case feels tough enough to handle abuse without any trouble. i have managed to knock the charging cover off by accident a couple times, and i'm concerned that i'll lose the cover entirely when this thing goes out on a hiking trip with me this summer.light is plenty bright for my needs. you tap the button to cycle between low, high, and off, and long-press to change from white light to red, or vice versa. i've yet to run it dead from its initial charge with several hours of low-beam use, so i think the battery will easily last for a multi-day hike. once i get this out in the real world and give it some actual use, i'll come back and update the review. for now though, i'm happy enough with this clip light that i would recommend it for outdoor use.

I ordered the 7 headband pack. They arrived quickly from overseas and I am thrilled with them. They are not made from flimsy plastic; instead the headband is a metal arch which is wrapped in colorful thread and beaded. While the headbands are all different colored, all of them have a gold threading on it. Great price for 7 beautiful headbands. They fit comfortably on my head as well as my 8 year old daughter's head too.If you found my review helpful, please let me know.

Love this stuff!  I saw that after my gastric sleevectomy that I could no longer tolerate sucralose.  Stevia always gave me a terrible aftertaste.  Enter:  Monk fruit.  I love the taste and I carry this convenient bottle everywhere.  I go through the bottles so quickly though and I have a hard time finding this in stores consistently.  Wish Amazon carried it at a more reasonable price.

I bought this b/c all the sauces I made from roux came out gritty and saw online that it was bc the cheese proteins would curdle if I was heating it too quickly or unevenly.  Great, so cheese sauce is out of my reach unless I use Velveeta?  (Not an option for us, since Velveeta is not kosher.)  But wait, what's this?  A cheat?  A cheese sauce hack?  Sodium citrate?Wow, I cannot believe how magically it works!  Added 2 teaspoons of this stuff to a cup of skim milk (which makes the milk turn clear, very interesting), bring to a simmer, mix in 4 cups of cheese slowly (I used an immersion blender to break it up quickly), and TA DA!  the most amazing cheese sauce and mac and cheese you will ever taste.  It tastes so intensely cheesy, so smooth and creamy, I cannot believe it took me so long to find this stuff.  I'm gonna put this stuff all over steamed veggies, baked potatoes, nachos.  It's AMAZING.  Love love love.  And so easy!If you found this review helpful, please let me know.
Our seeds failed to grow, despite following directions and optimal growing conditions.  Bummer, since I have a hard time finding sweet woodruff in the garden stores.

I don't know how he did it, but I looked out the window to see a squirrel sitting on top of this baffle, taking his sweet time to empty our bird feeder.  The feeder is nowhere near other shrubs or anything the squirrel could jump from, so I can only imagine that he is climbing the pole and somehow still able to climb around the baffle and get on top of it.  Argh.

I'm a huge fan of the Dr. Brown's glass bottles.  It's the only brand of glass baby bottle that I've been able to find commonly in stores.  We started out with about 10 of the 4oz glass bottles, but are now down to only 3 after about a year's use, thanks to slippery fingers during washing.  I came back to purchase 3 more of the 8 oz. bottles and have found that they've held up really well, despite being larger in size and therefore more susceptible to breakage when dropping them.  We've had a few roll off the desk and hit the floor, but no breaks or cracks so far.  These are awesome for us b/c our son will only drink milk very warm (yep, we couldn't break him of that habit).  So, I felt much better heating up glass bottles in a thermos full of hot water rather than plastic, even the BPA free ones.My only criticism is that I wish that the nipples on the 8 oz bottles were level 3 or 4.  Instead, they came with level 1 nipples and I had to purchase Level 4 separately.  If a baby is ready to drink from an 8 oz bottle, it seems likely to me that they've graduated beyond the level 1 or 2 bottle nipples.
We still have some people who ignore the sign, but it has reduced the volume of unwanted visitors dramatically.  I think placement is probably key.

We bought the "AB Gold" colored one for the irridescent rainbow stones.  It looks so much like the tiara from the Disney movie Tangled, which is why I was purchasing for my daughter.  I was very surprised by how small it was when it came.  It's not going to fit across your entire head like a typical headpiece, but designed more to fit into a top knot or top bun type hairstyle.  My daughter still loved it and the bonus was that its size makes it similar to Elsa's crown in Disney's Frozen movie, so she's using it for dual princess purposes.  :)I was a bit disappointed when I saw one of the larger stones come loose and get knocked out of place with only gentle play.  I was able to re-affix it by bending the prongs back into place, but I would have preferred something more durable for the price.Please let me know if you have any questions or if you found this review helpful.

We have a big age gap between the kids, so it's really nice to see Apples to Apples introduce a version of their game that allows the younger set who cannot reliably read every card to participate as well.  Apples to Apples has always been such a family friendly game and this edition makes it completely accessible for everyone.  I'm so happy to have this version to add to our collection.  Given that we take this game out with the younger kids around, I'd like to see them make the box and cards a bit more durable to little fingers.

Ever since having a baby, sunscreens have had to go through the Environmental Working Group (EWG) rating system before I will put it on my kid.  Given that every sunburn that a child has increases the chances of skin cancer later in life (five sunburns during your entire lifetime will double the chances at melanoma per the Skin Cancer Foundation), a well working sunscreen is a must.  But if you have a baby, you know that you also want something that rubs on quickly and smoothly for those squirmy bodies who don't sit still and something that doesn't have a lot of unhealthy added ingredients.MelanSol rubs on without leaving a thick white film on the skin surface, something that I've had difficulty finding in the sunscreens that the EWG rates highly.  The EWG actually rates this as a 2 (Low Hazard) on a scale of 1-10 and recommends the sunscreen.  It is BPA, phthalate, gluten, and paraben free.  It provides broad spectrum protection (UVA and UVB).  At the time of this writing, though, it is snowing in April (boo!) and I haven't had opportunity to truly test the product to see whether my fair-skinned son will redden under harsh conditions.My biggest beef with the product is the price.  At around twenty bucks, it's pretty comparable to my previous go-to for the kids, KINeSYS Spray-On Sunscreen.  But I prefer a cream to a spray for when we will be exposed to the sun all day at the pool or beach.  The spray works awesome for every day, quick coverage.

I have an 8 year old who still has a bit of chubby baby belly so I ordered this jacket in a size 10/12.  Although the sleeves are, as expected, long for her, the trench fits just snugly around her waist.  So, I wouldn't recommend this if you have a husky child.  But I'm still very pleased with the quality of the material, especially since the price was such a bargain.  The trench is lined, so it provides some protection from cool weather on spring or fall days.  And I was surprised when the trench came that the fabric is actually quite waterproof.  The hood is detachable and the bottom of the trench hits my daughter just above mid-thigh.  I would recommend it for most girls.If you found this review helpful or have any questions, please let me know.

I bought the white bolero jacket.  The fabric feels like a mix between felt and fleece.  I was hoping for something my daughter could use to make some of her strappy dresses more modest.  I really like the design; I'd like to see it made in a knitted fabric.  It might look a little less tacky.  Bought this on the word of another reviewer who said it made any dress red-carpet ready.  I could not disagree with that assessment more.  I feel like the material is more appropriate for wearing outside to provide a little coverage from the elements and not as part of your attire once indoors.

I actually already own the Perky-Pet 2-in-1 Wild Bird Feeder which didn't fare the elements too well last year as the copper finish not only began to tarnish quickly, but one of the ports actually corroded completely away during storage in our shed over the winter.So, when this Perky-Pet Seed Bunker feeder showed up, I was very pleased to see that for only a slightly elevated cost, the material on this feeder is of much sturdier quality.  This means that the feeder is pretty heavy and the metal is extraordinarily durable.  In fact, a number of the hoods and perches came knocked out of place during shipping.  (Amazon's usually amazing service for some reason did a lousy job with packing this item for shipment.)  But the perches and hoods were not damaged or bent despite what was probably a turbulent journey and they were easily snapped back into place.  I've only had it for a month, but my guess is that the quality material will probably fare a lot better and longer than my other bird feeder which is mostly made of thin plastic.For what it is primarily designed to do, it does it just fine.  It's easy to fill with bird seed and it attracted a variety of beautiful birds the very first day.However, it is not squirrel proof.I actually filled both feeders and suspended this one from a tree using a metal hook and the other from a shepherd's hook.  I noticed the very first day that half the seed was gone, very quickly.  Suspicious that a squirrel was getting into them, I swapped the two feeders, thinking that perhaps the lack of a plate on the bottom of this Seed Bunker feeder would make it harder for the squirrel to get a grip onto the feeder from the shepherd's hook.  A few hours later, I saw that much of the seed was gone already.  And then an hour after that, I caught the culprit in the act.  The squirrel was able to climb right up the shepherd's crook and then held himself upside down while raiding the Seed Bunker.  It did the exact same thing with the other bird feeder by climbing the tree and scooting himself upside down the metal hook.  At this point, I'm pretty convinced that very little will deter squirrels from the bird feeders, not even those fancy ones which have the collapsible perches (designed to collapse at the heavy weight of a squirrel, but not a bird) since the squirrel made no use of the perches at all when he was lowering himself onto the feeders from above.It should be noted that Perky Pet does market a number of wild bird feeders that are specifically targeted for problem squirrels here, here, and here among several others, but even those are of limited effectiveness against a determined squirrel.  (Which is what we've got.  Those little buggers have completely chewed through several thick plastic trash can lids of ours.)  Squirrels can chew through plastic parts of so-called squirrel-proof bird feeders.  And even if the feeder is completely made of metal (which this Seed Bunker feeder is not, as the viewing windows are very thin plastic), the squirrels can learn to shake the feeder and spill the seed onto the ground.  There are a few feeders that seem to fare better at warding off squirrels than the ones from Perky-Pet, but they tend to be in the next price range up and still not 100% effective for everyone.Our current hope, since we don't contemplate spending more money on bird feeders, is that greasing the pole and hook with ample amounts of vaseline will keep the squirrels away and perhaps make for some funny videos if we see them slipping off.  We will see if that does the trick and I'll come back here and update.  I guess, meanwhile, the silver lining in all this is that now that the squirrels have all this bird seed, they're sorta leaving my trash cans alone.  The other silver lining is that my kids have a good reason to scream "Those Darn Squirrels!" whenever they see the thieves raiding the feeders.If you found this review helpful or if you have any questions, please let me know.  If you have any solution suggestions for my pesky "friends", please comment!

My son suffers from chronic eczema and dry skin.  We've tried a lot of combinations and for spot treatment, this product works incredibly well.  There was a short time awhile back that following an allergic reaction, he was left with patches of eczema, so we tried to rub some baby oil on it.  Turns out he was allergic to the baby oil (who knew?) and his skin turned into a full flared attack of scaly dragon skin.  It took weeks to go away.  We tried this Eucerin Baby Eczema Relief Instant Therapy on it alone, and it helped moisturize the area, but didn't seem to make a major dent by morning.  Eventually, we figured out that rubbing him all over with Aveeno Baby Eczema lotion after a bath and then sealing it in with a petroleum base like Vaseline or Aquaphor did the best at eliminating the scales and covering him with footed PJs.  But this system wouldn't work on exposed areas, like his face or hands, where we didn't want the petroleum to be smeared all over the bedsheets or the furniture.  This is where the Eucerin Instant Therapy ended up being a blessing.  It is as lightweight as a lotion, spread easily, had no smell, and was easy to apply to a squirmy baby.  This was important since it took more frequent applications to help eliminate the dry skin.  We applied twice a day and it took a few days, but cleared up nicely.  We hadn't had such nice results using Aquaphor, baby lotion, or even the expensive Stelatopia alone.  We did get similar results, however, when we used Triple Cream.Something else that we've seen work for the absolute worst cases of eczema are bleach baths taken once or twice a week.  Add one half cup of chlorine bleach to a whole bathtub of warm water.  Watch out that the water doesn't get into child's eyes or mouth.  It seems to help with eliminating some of the bacteria or microbes on the skin that can cause inflammation.  All in all, I'd say this is a good product and worth a try in your arsenal for eczema treatment.  All babies/children seem to react differently; the skin is actually the largest organ in our bodies and an integral part to the immune system, so what works for one child may not necessarily work for another.Good luck.  Please let me know if you found my review helpful or if you have any questions.

At this point in my parenting career, I am seasoned enough to know what I want out of a stroller.  I've owned a lot of other strollers and tried out a few of my friends.  I started with the close to high end Valco Baby Tri-Mode when my friends were pushing their expensive Bugaboos.  I used a Britax Chaperone for awhile before deciding it was way too bulky to pull in and out of the car and had wheels that constantly fell off.  I tried going the minimalist route with the Contours Lite Stroller but it was so light, it kept falling over when I weighed it down with my diaper bag, purse, or shopping bags.But I'm excited about the Graco FastAction Fold Sport stroller.  It combines a lot of what I like about the other strollers:  maneuvers easily even with a heavy child; cup holders and storage aplenty, and easy to move in and out of the car.  It's not a perfect system, nothing ever is, but it hits that sweet spot of portability with user-friendliness so well that I'm getting rid of the other strollers.Specs:  Stroller weighs 21.47 lbs; is 42" high; and 24.5" wide at the widest (back wheels).  It is convertible to a 3 or 5 point harness and will hold a child up to 50 lbs.  (However, I had my 8 year old who is pushing 70 lbs sit in it, and I could still push it easily around the house.)Pros:1.  Value/Affordability -- Given the wide range of price-points for strollers out there, the Graco FastAction Fold Sport comes in on the lower end, without dropping into the cheapie umbrella stroller prices.2.  This stroller enables you to just snap a carseat into it to connect a carseat.  There are two flaps that can be unsnapped and opened to give the carseat a resting mount.  This feature allows parents to replace the SnugRider or Snap-N-Go.  (Though I think that if you can afford it, it's still worthwhile to hold onto a snugrider type stroller frame since it is so lightweight and much easier to use for infants still in carseats.)3.  One handed fold and lock.  That's the whole schtick behind the stroller, right?  You just pull a little strap hidden in the seat, pull, and the entire stroller folds and locks into place.  It's actually the exact same system used in my more expensive Britax Chaperone stroller.4.  There's a very simple system of locking for the swivel wheel, brakes, and the food tray.  Some may say it's pretty primitive.  But I've seen with my other strollers is that the complex locking mechanism or reclines, pneumatic wheel systems, and press button tray removals end up catching or failing somewhere.  And then, you've got a more complicated problem to fix than when a primitive system breaks.5.  There's a simple drawstring method for adjusting the seat back to recline, with a drawstring stay to keep it in place.  The strings don't adjust as smoothly as I'd like for my light sleeper not to notice, but I suspect it will become smoother over time as the strings are used.  I also don't like the flimsy feel of the plastic drawstring stay, but most people don't a the wrecking ball of a toddler like I do.6.  The canopy is arched and provide ample shade for even the tallest of children.  There's a zippered hood for extra coverage when the sun is coming in at the child horizontally or you want to cover them up while they're sleeping.  There's also a mesh viewing window to look in and provide ventilation while the canopy is closed.7.  The storage basket is ample and you can open up the velcro to reveal a second, smaller compartment separated from the other by a mesh.  This allows you to put stuff, like a sippy cup, keys, or some other item that you wouldn't want to rolling around and become lost among the coats, bags, and other mess of the larger compartment.8.  Two cup holders each for both baby and adult.  Love this.  I have an older child who also wants her water bottle in easy access when I go on walks with them and she hates the strollers that only have one cupholder.9.  Most importantly, the stroller has great maneuverability, turns on a dime and glides over the floor.  It does really well on the sidewalks of our Baltimore neighborhood which is full of cracks and uneven cement (thanks, Baltimore City government).  The back axle and basket are pretty low to the ground (trade off for more storage space), which makes pushing the stroller down stairs a bit tricky, but still very doable.  The sport stroller is a lot easier to push than the regular four wheeled Graco travel systems and is a good alternative for people who do a lot of walking with the stroller.10.  The assembly was quick and easy and I was able to do it in 10 minutes out of the box.Cons:1.  It's not quite as compact or light as an umbrella stroller.  You shouldn't expect it to be; it *is* a sport stroller.  But then again, it's not a jogging stroller and doesn't have huge wheels, so it's not going to do rough terrain that well either.  But for most users, it will meet their needs just fine.  It should be noted that Graco does have a FastAction Fold Jogging Stroller that has the air-filled tires for those who really want a jogger and it's similarly priced as this stroller.  But, mind you, it also is a good 9 lbs heavier than this sport stroller.2.  There's no easy way to remove and wash the padding or straps.  Most strollers don't really have an easy way to do this, but the Graco FastAction Fold Sport also has lots of holes and crevices (not to mention that folding strap hidden away in a pocket in the seat) that allows for cereal, snacks, and gunk to get caught in it.  Not to mention that if you've ever had a child vomit or explode out of a diaper in a stroller, the fewer slots to clean, the better.  At least the stroller has an easy to wipe down fabric.3.  The folding mechanism of the stroller is internal and not easily fixable if it goes bad.  I found that out with the Britax Chaperone, which as I said previously, has the same folding mechanism.  It started catching more and more frequently and just had difficulty in folding.  Then, after awhile, I had to only use the stroller while it was open and no longer had the option of folding it any longer.4.  Once the stroller is in the folded and locked position, it's not quite as compact as the photo would have you believe.  One you set it on the ground, it opens a little bit more (maybe another 1-2 cm).  Also, there's no easy way to push it once it's in the folded position.  (My Britax stroller would still allow you to push the stroller on its wheels towards the trunk of your car.  The Valco and the Bugaboo, once folded, couldn't be pushed either and had to be lifted into place.)  This Graco stroller could theoretically be pushed on its wheels, but the handlebar drags on the ground.  If the handlebar was slightly shorter or adjustable, it could have removed this issue entirely (are you listening, Graco?).  An adjustable handlebar would have also been a boon for those who are not average height.5.  The stroller really could have used an extra pocket or storage compartment on the seat back or hood.  More storage is better.6.  My biggest beef with the stroller is that it requires two hands to open stroller.  One hand must pull the release strap (the same as the fold and lock strap) and the other hand must reach down and grab the handlebar and straighten the stroller at the same time.  So, while you're doing this on the walkway bridge right out of the airplane with a ton of passengers piling up behind you and your carry-on luggage, who's going to hold the baby who is cranky and crying after the flight?  A much better system would have been some sort of release button or strap that would have let you open the stroller with one hand.Please let me know if my review was helpful or if you have any questions.

Initial assumptions and caveats:1) We run Macs in our household, so our setup and user experience is Mac-based.2) We plan on using this product exclusively either as a repeater (i.e., wireless extender) or client (i.e., a device to receive a wireless signal and convert it to ethernet), and my review is targeted at this experience and this experience only.  I cannot and will not comment in this review on how good this product is as a base wireless router either at home or on the road.Within these parameters, I am very satisfied with this.  It was easy to set up and will make our home wifi that much more robust.  Here are some observations gleaned as I set up the device.A) The instruction manual, or rather, poster, is quite thorough and well-documented.  It's very small, however.  At this point I'm north of 40 and my eyes don't read small print that well.  Also - mini-CDs (like the one included with this product) don't work either for us Mac users, or for anyone with a slot-loading optical drive.B) When you set up the device for repeater or client and run a survey of networks to extend, your network will show up once for your main base station and *once in addition for each repeater or other base station on your wireless network.*  The only distinction will be something called a BSSID, which may or may not be the same as the wireless device's MAC ID.  I couldn't easily locate my Airport Express' MAC ID, so the only way I knew for sure which BSSID corresponded to my base and not my existing repeater was simply to unplug the repeater in use before setting up the TPLink.  In retrospect, since the survey lists access points by decreasing signal strength, the best thing to do would have been to set up the TPLink in very close proximity to the main base station.C) By the way, for you Windows users out there, on the odd chance you've gotten this far in a review that is clearly not intended for you, this device doesn't do Wifi Protected Setup (aka the sort of instant magic that attaches printers to networks with a single button) with Windows either.  Folks, please correct me if I'm wrong.Finally, D) this device comes with a USB port which can ostensibly be used to attach a drive to the network as a volume server via SAMBA. Well, it works, but I wouldn't try to use it as a full fledged NAS backup access point, i.e. as a poor-man's Time Capsule.  On a lark I decided to see how long it would take to send a 6 GB DVD iso rip over to a USB key through the net - it would have taken an hour for just those 6 GB if I hadn't lost patience first.  If I were writing that file via FireWire, it would have taken no more than 30 seconds.  Note - if you're running OSX, SAMBA drives do *not* plug and play automatically - you have to connect to the server formally.  Open the finder, open the "GO" menu, at the bottom there's an option to "Connect to Server" - the server is "smb://tplinklogin.net" - use the same account info you use to access the TPLink itself for login.  Alternatively, I used my OSX administrator account and that worked fine too.I hope you find my observations helpful.  This is a very inexpensive and versatile wifi device, and it would be a shame if unnecessary exasperation got in the way of enjoying it.  Thumbs up!P.S. One last weird observation:  I don't know how easy it would be to use more than one of these within the same network, especially if you plan on using the USB input for volume or file serving.  Most likely, these devices are all accessed via "tplinklogin.net" whether for http or smb access.  So if you've got more than one of them, how will you - or for that matter the rest of the network - know which TPLink device you're trying to access?  Inquiring minds want to know.

As a parent of a child on the spectrum, I naturally found this book interesting.  Temple Grandin obviously doesn't need any introduction, but I gather the other author, Richard Panek, is well known as a science writer.  I haven't read much of Dr. Grandin's other works but this one is clearly written well.My primary interest at first reading were chapters two and three, in which the authors summarize current theories on the neuroscience and genetics of spectrum disorders. I'm not a scientist, but what they authors write here seems intuitively correct: the spectrum disorders are to a great extent manifestations of neurophysical and neuroanatomical phenomena (and interestingly enough, Dr. Grandin suggests later that maybe her motor function difficulties result from a reduced cerebellum), and that those phenomena themselves result from certain seemingly minor but crucial de novo genetic mutations.Oh, and she discusses the vaccine debate with an interesting perspective - I don't think she buys the vaccine theory that much yet.  One, she suggests that a great number of severe 18-month regressions actually result from mitochondrial disease, which in turn often results from the fact that the genetic integrity of male sperm deteriorates markedly as men get older.  Two, she hasn't seen the controlled study trying to connect regression with vaccines that she believes would set the record straight.

Having applied and played with this product, I can agree with the assessments of other reviewers here:1) It works best when you hold the phone in vertical ("portrait") orientation.  There's almost no privacy from sideways eyes when you're holding it in landscape, though.2) It reduces glare, but it also reduces ease of reading.Caveat emptor.

Screen protectors are increasingly commodified - most iPhone screen protectors are adequate for most iPhone users and have the same degree of ease or difficulty during their application.  That being said, this product is nice for a couple of reasons:1) The holes are aligned very precisely.  If you don't misalign during the application process, it's a really good, snug fit.2) The protector, once applied properly, stays on quite nicely, is easy to wipe off, and has thus far proven very abrasion-resistant. I like it.Kudos also to the other reviewer who pointed out that AT&T stores will apply something like this for free.  I didn't take advantage of this and I was able to apply my protector properly - I think - but I can see why someone else would benefit greatly from such a service.

Bless the folks at Avery - first their DIY labels in formats galore, and now these ticket sheets.  It really is a great concept - customized printer paper along with downloadable word processor templates.That being said, have some reasonable expectations for this particular product, which is squarely designed for amateurs making small batches:1) It's not glossy or anything resembling photo paper.  You're printing tickets on cardboard stock.2) If you want to print color tickets and you have an inkjet, remember that retail color inkjet ink is expensive.  If you're printing these on a color laser, more power to you, but if you plan on investing in a color laser to print tickets like these, maybe you're looking for a more wholesale quantity of ticket sheets.3) Speaking of wholesale, there's a reason why this package only comes with ten sheets totaling 100 tickets - more than that and a targeted user ought to begin considering whether printing the tickets is best outsourced to a professional shop.In sum, a great idea for what it's intended to do.

This really isn't so bad - I haven't used that many steam cleaners, but I was satisfied under the circumstances with what this product was able to accomplish.First - I didn't find it that difficult to set up.  The only confusion I had with the setup instructions was a picture step describing the attachment of an optional part not included with this particular model.Second - it actually cleaned a tough stain quite well.  We tested this after our daughter conveniently vomited some half-digested pizza on our upstairs carpet.  In fact, we didn't end up cleaning the vomit with this product until the morning after, 12 hours later at least, in part because we hadn't assembled the cleaner, and in part because this happened at night and all of us were a little under the weather and just needed to go to sleep.  So how did it do?  Using the sample cleaning fluid, the cleaner handled the stain quite well.  It didn't remove the smell completely though, but it left little enough that the smell faded on its own within a few days.  I assume the cleaner would have tackled the stain better if we had cleaned the vomit immediately.Third - I've seen some complaints about the single chamber water system as being messy when pouring out.  I didn't find this to be the case when I brought it to the sink.  Don't know how environmentally friendly Bissell's cleaning fluids are, however.All told, it's not bad.  I'm assuming that this cleaner is marketed as pet-specific because it's going to be most useful to pet owners, especially those with dogs prone either to anxiety or intestinal issues.  However, if you have neither pets nor children (i.e., you're not going to be staining carpets that much), you may want to consider whether you need something like this, especially at $250.

Each year, as part of our pre-Passover cleaning and preparation, we "kasher" our granite countertops and steel sinks, a process which involves systematically pouring boiling water over every square inch of said counters and sinks.  We've evolved a system where we boil the water in big pots and pour it after transferring to two smaller pots which we alternate.  (I'm not going to bore you ad nauseam with the intricacies and the reasons for this system.)The only problem is that neither of said smaller pots has a spout, so the pouring was very imprecise.  Rather than buy a new pot or saucier with a proper spout, we decided to try this.Big mistake.  To begin with, we never felt confident about the seal, and it always seemed like there was water leaking around the edges.  And then, after switching a few times between the two smaller pots we used for the actual pouring - and mind you, the pots were not the same size at all, i.e. 1 qt vs 2.5 qts - this thing got so bent out of shape that it basically couldn't seal at all, and the pouring was even more imprecise than it used to be when we didn't use this piece of plastic junk in the first place.A *total* waste of the money.

First - this is not a Matzah in any normal sense, and the box says this clearly.Having gotten that out of the way, here's a review of the product on its own merits.The good news (besides the obvious benefit of it being gluten-, soy-, and dairy-free - i.e., kosher for Passover) is that it's crispy, and I personally think it's tasty - kind of like a Pringle but a lot lighter and less aggressive, flavor-wise, which isn't always such a bad thing.  The bad news (besides the price) is that it breaks very easily; I'm not kidding.  Also, it can get stale pretty quickly and lose all of its merits in the process.Our daughter used to be on a much stricter gluten- and dairy-free diet, and these came in handy at the time - she liked them slathered with mayo and sliced smoked turkey.  But now that her diet has broadened, there are other starch and carbo sources she likes more, and we no longer have quite the need to shell out the expense for these.  But it's nice to have a box or two around for the occasional lark.

Look - you'll pay less for a trash bag without a drawstring, but frankly, they're a pain in the tush to tie up, especially if you're like me and you wait until the bin is really full before changing the bag.My only wish is that these bags were more puncture-resistant, but honestly, I can't think of another bag I've used that handled the same level of abuse any better.

How do I like this?  Let me count the ways:1) Laughably easy to set up, and equally easy to change the settings as needed.2) Excellent wireless range.3) Works flawlessly.4) Plays nicely with my repeater.5) Compact and unobtrusive.So it doesn't work with WPS (wifi-protected setup) so you can't connect your printers and repeaters that way.  Big deal - that's something I've been perfectly happy to live without.As usual, you get what you pay for - Apple products are more expensive, but usually worth the extra expense, and the AirPort Express is no exception.

When we switched to Comcast for our internet recently,  At first we rented a unified wireless gateway from them, but that was frankly not a good solution.  We looked into setting up our own modem and router instead - especially since we're convinced we're going to be with Comcast for quite some time since we can't get any faster wire-based internet connection in our area.  I looked at the list of recommended DOCSIS 3.0 modems on Comcast's website, and this seemed to be the best combination of inexpensive, no-nonsense, and highly rated.  And we've been quite pleased.Two issues, though:First - switching the cable modem you use for your Comcast connection is not so brainless.  You have to call them up, read them a bunch of MAC codes and serial numbers, and then you have to go through an uncomfortable few minutes when your old modem's been deauthorized and your new modem is unresponsive because it's just getting started with the connection process, and you have to switch your ethernet cable from the old modem to the new at some point in the middle of this juggling act.  There's a reason why this is the sort of thing usually handled by comcast techies, and I can't really fault the product for this.Second - the modem is locked down, as in you can't replace its firmware with a more flexible open-source variety to fit your needs or if you're otherwise adventurous.  When you access the router's IP either through wireless or an ethernet cable, all you get is a status page without any links or other form of input.  Firmware changes, if any, are pushed from Comcast alone.  I think I can live with that for now, though.All told, I'm almost completely satisfied with this.

We've been using a Honeywell 50250-S 99.97% Pure HEPA Round Air Purifier for the last three years and we've benefited greatly, particularly by getting sick a lot less often during the winter.  The main drawback about the purifier we've been using is that it is *really* loud, even at its lowest setting.  So loud, in fact, that our filter's been doing double duty as a white noise machine helping keep our kids asleep.  We won't be able to do the white noise thing with the AirGenius5, though.  Too quiet, even at its highest setting.That's not to say it isn't effective.  I set it up in the middle of a sunbeam in my living room at the middle setting, and watched all the flickering dust decrease markedly over the next hour.  The set up was really easy - the device was ready to go practically out of the box.  It really didn't take very long for the AirGenius to clear a fairly large room.  Not to mention the fact that the filter mechanism is really easy to access, and the default filters are actually washable!  (Ours also came with a sample odor-catching filter, which is not washable, but which we haven't tried yet.)My one minor gripe:  the instructions say you need to give the AirGenius three feet of space around it.  Well - we've got a toddler, and something like this isn't going to be safe for very long if it's not backed inconspicuously into a corner.  In a perfect world, Honeywell would have packed an optional and easily assembled pedestal base to stick the AirGenius into for just this purpose.  But really, you can just run it at night when the kids are asleep if you have to.  And note that I'm still giving this product five stars.Note:  unlike the purifier we've been using, this is *not* a HEPA air purifier, and if your allergies need filtration that effective, then this product is not for you.  Luckily, no one in my house has dust, pollen, or dander allergies as far as we know, so I don't think we need a fully-HEPA air filtration system in our living room.

After I ordered this product, I saw a fair amount of internet noise about how Apple routers didn't play nicely with other companies' repeaters.  To paraphrase at least one comment I saw in response to someone else who tried to use a D-link product to extend an AirPort Express' wireless reach, "apples play with apples, and you've got a banana," or something to that effect.  So I resigned myself and figured I'd try as best I could before giving up.Lo and behold, the setup was so easy I was worried I was missing something.  Granted, Apple routers don't do WPS (wifi protected setup), so it's not the totally effortless one-button setup I'd have had with any other base router.  On the other hand, this product comes with very clear instructions as to how to do a manual setup, and it took me less than five minutes to get my extender up and running.  And I know it's working - I have a monitor and a keyboard in my library room which I sometimes attach my laptop to, but which was beyond my router's wireless range.  That is, until now.  Also, I've been extending my wireless network for almost an hour now, and it has yet to drop a connection or cause any other hiccup in my wireless transmission, as far as I can tell.All told, I am surprised and gratified about this product.  Seriously - if you've got an AirPort Express and you need a little more range in your home, do not be afraid of this little guy's manual setup.Now if only I can figure out a way to keep my toddler from pulling this thing out on a regular basis...

This is a good printer - it produces quality pages, fast, and it was easy to set up with my network.  I never thought an inkjet could replace my laser printer, but this one just did.  (Granted, my old printer was an 11-year old Samsung ML-1430 which was totally incompatible with printing by WIFi; besides, said printer's ink cartridge was about to run dry and I was reluctant to shell out $80 for a new one.)That being said, I have three gripes with this product, of increasing severity.1) The nitpicky:  the instructions say that when you install the ink cartridge, you have to push down until it clicks.  Well, it really has to click - in my first attempt at setting the printer up, I thought it had clicked but I didn't push hard enough, and the printer went on priming forever without telling me that there was just no cartridge installed properly.  Just remember to push firmer than you might think you need to.2)  The obnoxious:  the starter ink cartridge is apparently just that, with only enough ink for 200 pages of normal use.  Of course Epson sells a  2400 page "XL" cartridge, but that'll set you back $50.  Come on, Epson, don't be so cheap.  Just price the printer a little higher and include the XL cartridge.  This by itself would have made me rate this with four stars, but then there's . . .3)  The seriously bad:  this is the second Epson printer I've installed on OSX where I couldn't get it to work without going to their support website first, the other being the XP-400 whose installation CD lacked a Mountain Lion compatible driver.  And this one was a real honest to God pain in the tush because the installation kept failing until, as per the not-so-easy-to-find instructions on Epson's site, I reset my printer preferences and printer list altogether.  In other words, I frankly don't know how anyone without at least moderate tech savvy could have succeeded in installing this on OSX without either calling Epson support or throwing their hands up in angry despair.  GET YOUR ACT TOGETHER, EPSON - THIS IS A SERIOUSLY BAD TREND.  There is no excuse in this day and age for allowing home printer installations to be anything but brainless.  None.  And this is why I'm only giving this product three stars.  For what it's worth, this printer doesn't do AirPlay either.There you have it.  I like this thing now that I've installed it, but I wish I hadn't gone through the aggravation.  It's a shame too, because Epson really should not be driving willing consumers away from an otherwise great product.I hope this is informative - and please, if you're an OSX user having trouble with your install, feel free to send me a message and I'll try to help.

The good news is that this thing was very easy to install - just interpose it between your TV's coaxial input and your antenna cord. (This assumes that your antenna, like mine, has a coaxial tail.)  Oh, and you'll need an extra two prong plug because this thing isn't self-powered, but I imaging most people who set up their TVs or home theater systems assume they're going to need extra available plugs.  Once I had this device hooked up and running, the channels I was already receiving came through clearer.However, not only did I not get any new channels, but for those channels where my reception was already iffy at best, this device basically killed their signal altogether.  The rich get richer and the poor get poorer.  Perhaps if I had a better antenna or better antenna placement, or if I just lived in an area with more available signals, maybe this product would work as advertised.I give this product three stars based on my own experience, but maybe other people have had better results.  Y(our) M(ileage) M(ay) V(ary), I suppose.

My husband actually majored in History of Science as an undergrad.  That's why he wanted to get this book.  However, he said that while the material should have been interesting, he couldn't get more than half-way through the book.  Don't know whether it's because of lack of sleep, or because the book itself was not written in the most sparkling of fashions.

Believe me - I'm a chronic procrastinator.  This is what drew me to the book in the first place. And from what I can recall (it's been almost two years since I actually read this), the author's explanations are not only well grounded in rigorous science and psychology, they also felt intuitively correct.  The shock of recognition is alone worth the read.The irony here - inevitable, really - is that I received this book almost two years ago, and I'm only reviewing it right now.  I'm not blaming the author for bad advice, though.A belated thumbs up!
From my husband:  "It was installed over a year ago, and it's worked with nary a hiccup since.  Its nice not to have to worry at all about surges when dealing with delicate electronics."

My husband would be the first to tell you I'm not a techie.  But I found this printer to be painless to install and a real joy to use.1)  Before we discuss the actual device, I first want to praise the packaging of all things.  Frankly, I was shocked at how small the box was when the printer came in the mail.  This is a model of how printers ought to be packaged.2)  The quick installation sheet that came with the printer was easy to understand and follow.  Like I said, painless.  The one caveat here is that I just updated to OSX Mountain Lion, and the installer that came on the enclosed CD said it was incompatible with my operating system.  I knew that the next thing to do was to go to Epson's web site and download an updated, Mountain Lion-friendly driver, and sure enough, Epson's website almost intuited that this was what I was looking for.  I only wish, for the sake of others perhaps less experienced in this sort of thing, that Epson had taken the time to add "Please visit our website for appropriate installation software" or something to that effect to the "incompatible with your system" dialog on the original install program.3)  The LED control panel is incredible.  It's easy to read and very easy to use, even with just four arrows and an "OK" key.  Really that's all you need.  The fact that I could actually key in my lower-case wireless router password is a big plus over the last wireless printer I installed and I mean BIG PLUS.4)  Oh and this printer also has an SD slot for printing photos straight off memory media, again unlike the last wireless printer I installed.5)  The printer works really well with OSX's built-in Image Capture program, which is smart on Epson's part as other printer manufacturers would just have tried to craft their own substitute which would not have been nearly as good.  Why reinvent wheels unnecessarily?6)  My only real gripe with this device (other than the fact that I had to figure out on my own to download my installation software directly from Epson and which I don't think is really a gripe given how recently Mountain Lion was released) is that it doesn't have a document feeder for the copier / scanner as far as I can tell.  This has the potential to be a real nuisance for anyone who needs to copy or scan more than three pages at a time.  In my case, however, I can just use my other wireless printer which does have a document feeder for its copier / scanner, but I'm under no real illusions that most people have spare copiers lying around at home.But, as I said, this is a great buy for its price point, and recommended.Please let me know if this review was helpful.

Don't get me wrong.  My daughter loves this.  Loves it!  It helps that we already had and my daughter already loved the mobile home, and now we have the "people" who were actually meant for the mobile home.  Assembly was easy too.  The item comes in a really huge white box, but it's pretty light, so I could carry it on my own.This dollhouse is massive.  You probably already know that.  There are three floors above ground - four if you count the secret attic of a pop-up "play room?"  You gotta make sure you have the space to store all that.  I suspect that's probably part of the strategy.  The bigger the house you have, the more rooms you have, the more doll furniture you gotta buy to fill that space, right?  (Just like in real life houses, LOL.)  The house is probably so huge that you should buy the Loving Family African American Family and turn the whole building into a hotel or bed and breakfast.Definitely a load of fun if you've got the room for it.

My daughter started using these at age 4.  She LOVES eating chinese noodles with them and adores having pho (traditional vietnamese noodle soup) with chopsticks just like the grownups.  They've made it really easy to use, especially for my kid who has significant fine motor issues.  These broke after only a couple months of use.  One "leg" snapped right below the round axle part.  My daughter is very gentle, so I can imagine that it would break more easily with a kid who is more rough with them.  Still, they're not so expensive, so I can't say I mind that much.The other thing I don't love about them is that they're plastic.  I'm asian, so I am just partial to wooden chopsticks.

I have a screen protector on my iPhone, and I've replaced them several times.  It's not that hard, probably because they're small enough that there's less room for screw-ups.Apparently, putting a screen protector on an iPad is something else entirely.  Primarily, the screen is a lot bigger (duh) so there's a lot more possibility of something going wrong, and in my case, plenty of things did, partly because I didn't do the process right due to the unclear instructions, and partly because the kit's components were, to put it charitably, not up to spec.1)  First of all, they tried to put the instructions on the packaging itself rather than a fold-out poster.  Really dumb idea, because I found the instructions almost incomprehensible in the absence of lots of large, detailed pictures.  There were pictures, yes, but they are small (at most 1 x 1.5 inches) and there weren't enough of them.2)  Second of all, the screen installation is not very intuitive.  By way of example, the hard peelable shell on which the screen rests in the packaging comes with a little tab on the side that says "place this on top" - which is fine except that the words on the tab are right-side up when the shell is on the bottom.  This is dumb, and it made my installation a lot more complicated.3)  This thing comes with an "alignment strip" which is supposed to anchor the screen in place to the iPad at one of the edges during the placement process, except mine wouldn't stick to my iPad.  Absolutely useless, and I had to undo and redo my placement process several times before it was aligned properly.4)  Like iPhone screen protector kits, this came with an applicator designed to smooth the screen down during placement and help smooth out bubbles afterwards.  Only the applicator in this kit is made out of flimsy cardboard as opposed to plastic. Utterly lame.  Frankly, given the amount of pressure needed to push the bubbles to the side, I ended up blunting the cardboard before I got rid of that many bubbles. I ended up using a credit card, and even then I couldn't get them all.  What's the use of the vaunted fingerprint disappearing tech when there are perma-bubbles below the screen protector which make the thing unclear anyway.
