All three lead actors play their roles to perfection; its clear they are having great fun.Did you know that the original casting had Martin and Caines roles reversed?  What could they possibly have been thinking?  One would think that Ruprecht was created with Steve Martin in mind! Steve had a Golden Globe nomination for best performance by an actor in a comedy/musical.  Apparently, as soon as the cast did a couple of scenes, they and the director set things straight.Like other reviewers, I waited a long time for this movie to be available online.  Steve Martin has said that this is his favorite role.  It is my favorite comedy, an all-time classic that I like to go back to again and again.

First of all, this is a 5-star product.  My problem is that I bought two of these and they were obviously taken out and repackaged.  One of them actually had the inner case inserted backwards in the outer box!  They both had some dust on them.  One had rattled around inside the inner case enough that the case window showed the effects of an opacity on all but an inner circle that the filter could not rub against. There was dust on both. One actually had a splinter of debris inside the inner case!  I had to clean both with a blower AND a Zeiss lens-cleaning wipe.  I'm not the first Amazon reviewer to have this problem.  Amazon's price is good on these, but is it because they are seconds?  The outer boxes were sealed with the standard tape, but I absolutely believe this is not a B+W quality-control issue.  I've bought a lot of their filters over the past 7 years and never found one  that wasn't pristine until now.  Something else is going on here.Now for the good news.  When cleaned, these filters show no problems at all: no blemishes on glass or metal.  I'm a true believer in B+W.  I use filters primarily for two reasons:  to protect the lens and for polarization effects.  Back in the film days I had all sorts of special-effects filters, but now it's about those two purposes, and these were obviously for protection only.  What do we want from a protective filter?  (1) Do no harm.  (2) Protect.  (Not necessarily in that order.)  I've used all of the high-end filter brands, and the very best do very little harm besides lens flare under extreme conditions.  I've not been able to identify any image degradation (except flare) with the very best UV filters.  So why B+W?  Because B+W filters are so easy to clean.  For me, that means they do a better job of requirement number 2:  they protect.  I've had so many filters that would have blotchy reflectivity after wet cleaning.  Not B+W.  Water won't hurt them, not even rain water.  So far nothing has, and I have 20 that I've subjected to all sorts of elements.  I always use B+W, and I always buy their top-of-the-line for a given functional type.  I even have 4 of their signature series.As an aside, many years ago I did careful tests of not-so-good filters.  I found that some of those filters degraded images more than the difference between a Nikon AI prime lens and a Hoya 70-210 zoom.  Point is, filter quality does matter.  I don't believe that super high numbers of coatings are relevant; there is a law of diminishing returns for numbers of coatings, and B+W has enough to get the job done.

OMOTRON sells the exact same keyboard without the stand for about half the price.  Is the stand worth the extra money?  The stand is very lightweight and it does work.  It collapses flat.  It has very cheap, deformable plastic hinges, which probably won't last long with regular use.  The only functional complaint about the stand is that in upright, portrait orientation there is no room at the bottom to plug in a charger.  Some apps will work in landscape orientation, and a few will work upside down, either of which solves the problem.  The stand is plenty strong enough for an iPhone 6+.As far as quality, the keyboard feels like it cost about 12-14 bucks.  I've had no problem with keys sticking or not working.  It is definitely better for me than typing on a touch screen.  Also, as others have said, it can work with laptops -- a good thing if you have one of those that won't let you turn off the touchpad.Good luck with your decision!

"Florida" is the first and one of the best of the 23-volume Freddy series.  The books are very educational.  They are suitable for reading to kindergarten-age kids and reading by older kids up to as high as age 14.  Brooks is a master at character development.  If you child is lucky enough to get hooked, he will discover a comfortable, fun world with magnetic personalities entangled in beguiling plots.When reading to very young children, expect to have to explain a lot of vocabulary -- not a bad thing at all.  Many years ago, I read these to my son and recorded them on cassette tapes.  He played them over many, many times, especially when traveling.  He developed a love of books that led him to read 54 Hardy Boys volumes while only a third-grader.This book originally had the innocuous title, "To and Again."  Like Howard R. Garris (Uncle Wiggly), Brooks didn't settle on his central character in his first books.One good way to get into these is via Kindle.  A Kindle app on larger phone or tablet is a great option.  Kindle is currently the ONLY way to get all of the series.  There is a website dedicated to Friends of Freddy that is worth looking up.BTW, the New York Times speculated that Orwell drew his inspiration for "Animal Farm" from the Freddy series.My grandson, son, daughter, and I have all enjoyed the Freddy books.  I can't recommend them highly enough.Another good choice is the Oz series, which consists of 15 volumes, beginning with the Wizard of Oz.  Those books are for similar ages, but probably no younger than 7.  Of course, when the kids are old enough, nothing beats Harry Potter.

At the time I'm writing this, there are two other reviews, both of which are unfavorable.  Much of the problem seems to stem from the earlier lack of a clear statement that you have to turn the switch on manually.  The listing now makes that clear, at least to me.  If you take the time to watch the video, it should remove any further doubt.  It appears that the earlier reviews had the effect of improving the listing -- we owe thanks to the earlier reviewers for that.  The other concern is that, in a 3-way application, you  need a special remote.  That is true; the remote needed is the Leviton VPOSR-10.What do I mean by "almost"?  If you reenter the area very shortly after the switch automatically turns off, it will turn itself back on!!  My two both do, anyway.  It's as though they are saying, "Oops, I must have turned off too quickly -- you're still here."  Go figure.  I'm not making this up.I just installed two of these, both in single-pole configuration.  They are working fine.  I turn on a switch manually; the switch stays on until the sensor determines that the area is vacant; then, after a variable delay, the switch turns off.  There are two adjustable screw settings on each switch:  one for sensor sensitivity and one for turn-off time delay.  The time delay is variable in discrete jumps from 30 seconds to 30 minutes.  The sensitivity is reducible by 50 % from the max value.  I set mine for max sensitivity since I'm often at a fairly wide angle from the switch.So far, it's working as advertised in my application.  I have a home theater that has 11 Z-wave switches and dimmers distributed around in it.  I've had manual switches in the equipment area that I tend to forget to turn off.  These new switches are perfect for me -- they are a better solution than adding more Z-wave switches.  Problem solved.

Summary:  This is a beautifully made, distinctive-looking watch that has grown on me over the month that I've had it.  As another reviewer said, pictures don't do it justice.  It's accuracy so far is superlative, drifting less than a second a month (for much better news:  see update below).Around the time that Citizen bought Bulova, they patented a new quartz movement, which, without the benefit of temperature regulation, is supposed to beat the accuracy of conventional quartz watches by a factor of 18 when installed in very large watch cases.  The movements, all of which are made in Japan, use a three-pronged quartz tuning fork that rotates rather than vibrates (i.e., torsional motion).  The frequency of the torsional motion is much higher and claimed to be much less sensitive to temperature than the conventional, two-pronged quartz vibrational mode.The first watches to get the new movement were dubbed the Bulova Precisionist.  The first Precisionists were huge things -- kind of a clock on your wrist.  Bulova has now released a second generation Precisionist that is a bit smaller, but still big (e.g., 46mm x 0.5 in).  Other manufacturers (e.g., Omega) who had made extremely accurate watches by applying costly, sophisticated temperature regulation to conventional quartz, had gotten out of the super-accuracy lane when radio control came along (so-called atomic time and GPS time).  Radio control worked well and was much less expensive.  The original Accutron was the first all-electric watch and set a new standard for maintenance-free, high accuracy performance.  Now Bulova decided to play the accuracy card again by introducing the Accutron II.  Accutron II is a smaller incarnation of the Precisionist movement, and I've read claims that the smaller size sacrificed a lot of the accuracy advantage.  Accutron II watches definitely look more expensive to my eye than Precisionists.Here's what I've found so far:  the Accutron has been more accurate than the Precisionist.  The Precisionist movement is claimed to be as good as 10 seconds drift per year, which is better than a second a month.  I've found slightly under two seconds a month drift, which is still far better than conventional quartz, which is generally rated at 15 seconds a month unregulated.  Meanwhile, this Accutron II has been good to within a second a month!  Did I get lucky with the Accutron II?  Did I get unlucky with the Precisionist?  I have no idea, I'm just reporting the results.**** Update **** after five months, the Accutron II has gained one second!  After six months, the Precisionist has gained 10 seconds -- about double the advertised drift but superb by any other standard.  Even though I have several radio-regulated watches, the Accutron II is my reference when I don't have time to make sure the radio watches are updated or go do the NIST thing on a computer.  This is fantastic accuracy for any free-running clock:  about 0.08 parts per million (ppm).Other reviewers have done an admirable job of reporting on the Space View heritage of this watch.  I'll just add that this watch is Beautifully made.  Everything about the case exudes quality.  To me, it looks far more expensive than its price.  The only thing I wish it had is a sapphire crystal, but that would certainly increase the price some.  The crystal is domed in a way that is very pleasing to the eye.  One good thing about so-called mineral crystals is that small scratches can be buffed out.I'll be surprised if this watch gets many negative reviews.  There just isn't much here to fault, and there's a whole lot to love.

First, the standard review stuff:This product works very well.  Logitech considers the remote supplied to be bare-bones, but I'll take a reliable bare-bones remote that can control a wide range of esoteric electronics any day.  The remote is sleek and compact, partly because it uses a button cell.  This thing is now handling relatively rare components from Mark Levinson and Bryston with aplomb.  Bryston charges $300 for their remote, which doesn't come with the equipment!  Mark Levinson charges $500 for a replacement!  Thanks to Logitech, I can now teach any learning remote to "speak Bryston."  (The Levinson preamp will actually teach a remote itself.)  The range of coverage of the IR blaster, hub or extension, is excellent, and I've been using blasters for 10 years.  My controlled equipment can pick it up after one bounce from just about any object in the room.  I have about five URC blasters strategically placed in my home theater today.  The Smart Control offers me another option beyond the URC 30, which is no longer supported by URC.  You may have noticed that a lot of reviewers are not using their cell phones as remotes.  I'm using both, and I'm happy with both approaches.  One advantage of the WiFi connectivity is that you can control from anywhere that your WiFi network reaches.  Walls and other obstacles simply don't matter.  Of course, direct-RF-linked alternatives will typically penetrate one or two layers of walls.I'm trying to determine whether I can add more Smart Control hubs to a single network and then add more networks for other systems.  I'm pretty sure the answer to the second question is "yes."  If it turns out to be true I'll expand this review to explain in detail.***Update***  You can have multiple hubs in one house on one wifi network.  You give them different names, and they work independently with their assigned remotes.  I haven't done it yet, but Logitech told me it is doable.  You cannot have more than one hub in one subnet, working together; in other words, there is no slave mode for a hub.  This limits extensibility, because a single remote can only transmit through a single hub and its blaster.  Each hub has a second blaster jack.  Logitech sent me one for free; I'm not sure how to buy one otherwise.  Some other systems allow you to plug in additional blasters anywhere that is in range.  URC Powerblasters are an example of that, but they cost almost as much as a Smart Control Hub with remote and blaster.  I'm going to try some other mix-and-match combinations after I get my next hub.  Now back to the original review.Let me explain the title of this review.I had a problem with this product that led me to write a one-star review yesterday.  I promised to upgrade the review if Logitech solved the problem which they did in VERY short order.  I had an audio component that Logitech apparently had incorrectly represented  in their IR code database.  The result was that I couldn't control the component, and it was the primary component controlling this particular system.  I e-mailed Logitech on Sunday, and, when I got home from work on Monday, they had fixed the problem in the database and sent me instructions on how to reload the device (see below).  The process worked, and now the Smart Control setup is exceeding my original expectations.  The main body of this review provides my Sunday message to them and their Monday response.  The respondent actually gave me his direct e-mail address, which I have removed out of respect for his privacy.  You may find it interesting reading.  I draw some conclusions at the end.  I'll begin the story with my original review.ORIGINAL REVIEWThe Logitech online database is very impressive when it comes to including codes for even the most obscure components.  I was very pleased to find I could set up my Bryston music server and DAC as well as my Mark Levinson 326S -- or so the website led me to believe.  All my components were in the database and were easily loaded along with several activities onto my hub.  Now for the bad news.  While the hub controls the Bryston components just fine and the hub/blaster exceeded expectation in area/volume coverage, there was no control of the Mark Levinson preamp.  The hub wouldn't turn it on, and when I turned it on manually, the hub wouldn't control the volume.  In other words it's useless to me (other than I can use it to teach "Bryston" to other IR remotes).The following is my communication to Logitech:"The hub cannot control my Mark Levinson No. 326S preamp.  The hub is at least turning on and off other components.  I've placed both the hub and the blaster directly in front of the preamp to no avail.  I've put them next to the preamp's own remote, and the preamp's remote will operate the preamp but the hub and/or blaster will not. They will not turn it on out of standby, and, if it is already on, they will not adjust volume."I've been using the Harmony remote.  I note that my iPhone 5 does not even show a volume control on-screen.  Could this be because the preamp was not loaded properly into the hub so that the hub has no knowledge of a volume control in the system?  I did the setup on a Windows 8 machine, not on the iPhone.  Then I downloaded the iOS app and set the iPhone up with the hub via wifi."It wouldn't be surprising if you hadn't had much feedback on the Mark Levinson 326S.  It is a high-end, line-level preamp, and only a small percentage of hardcore audiophiles will know the model exists."The Smart Control is potentially a terrific product, and control by cell phone is coming fast to all things electronic.  I hope this problem can be resolved."I followed this quote in the original review with the following:  Stay tuned.  I'll follow this up as I hear from Logitech.  If Logitech can't resolve the problem, I'll try it somewhere else with more mainstream components.  Based on the reviews of others, I expect my chances are good.  Meanwhile, since the product has totally failed to work well enough to be useful, I have no choice but to give it one star.  I'll certainly upgrade the rating if I can justify it.TimMONDAY MESSAGE FROM LOGITECHHi Tim - I am the Director of Product Management for Logitech's Harmony division.  I wanted to first apologize for the experience you have had, but I promise we will make it right.The team and I have looked into your issue and believe we have identified and resolved the issue.  We have corrected some of the data associated with the Mark Levinson device you have.If we could ask you to follow the below steps this should address your issue:Sign into your account on MyHarmony.comSelect the Device tab on the leftSelect your Mark Levinson deviceSelect Delete this devicePress the blue Add Device button and re-enter your device (Mark Levinson) and model number (NO. 326s) and click AddSelect the Activities tab on your left and select one of the activities that contains this device and click Change your settings to add the new device. Please repeat this for each activity.If you could confirm that this has fully addressed your issue we would greatly appreciate it.Please don't hesitate to reach out to me personally in the future with any questions you may have.Again, I apologize for your initial experience.  Thank you for your business.Chad ThompsonLogitech - HarmonyGlobal Product Management & MarketingThanks,ChadSo what have we learned from all this?  We've learned that Logitech places top priority on keeping their database blemish-free.  We've also learned that they don't want unhappy customers.  In the immortal words of Bo Bice, "It's all good."I'm not going to go overboard here.  I've had some problems with Logitech software in the past:  bugs, bugs, and more bugs.  As far as software goes, on this go-round, the software has worked flawlessly.  I'm planning to do a lot of experimenting with the Smart Control setup, and if it works out, I'm hoping to be able to use it in two more applications in the same house.  It's sad how few multi-function remotes there are out there with good Amazon review ratings.  That was what led me here in the first place.  I'm now another member of the fan club.All the best,Tim

If you have to conform to the standards laid out in this book, you obviously have to buy it.  If you are looking for a really good style manual, there are better ... and there are also worse.  A style manual normally includes coverage of grammar and then goes beyond that with recommendations on how to apply it.  It provides rules for the "gray" areas in which pure grammar leave a lot of lattitude.  One goal of a style manual is to help you learn to make your writing "scan well," that is, make it smooth and easy to follow so that a reader gets the meaning on the first pass.  A style manual will also help with formatting.The ultimate style manual is The Chicago Manual of Style, which is the standard at most of the major publishing houses.  It has roughly twice the useful content of the USGPO manual.Are you familiar with the difference in usage of "that" and "which"?  It has to do with restrictive versus non-restrictive clauses, and it is a rule that is observed formally in America but not in the U.K.  It's an example of a rule that Chicago covers but the USGPO does not.  Proper usage will definitely make your prose scan better (even if you're British).You may wonder why I called this manual "mediocre," yet I gave it four stars.  I wish I could give it three and a half, but it is enough better for me than some others (e.g., the AP Stylebook), that I decided on four.

This book is on a level somewhere between undergrad and graduate level mechanics.  It will be VERY useful to students in either capacity.  It is an absolute tragedy that Schaum has stopped publishing it.  Engineering students of dynamics will equally profit from this book.  It would also be great for reviewing for prelim's/qualifiers.I'm a huge fan of Murray Spiegel's writing.  He has a way of cutting through to the heart of the matter and then explaining and demonstrating applications.  It's not that I'm against theory; it's just that I don't feel comfortable until I've solved real problems with real-world numbers and units. This book gets you to that level quickly.  Of course, you learn more when you have to figure out more for yourself, but sometimes time is of the essence.When I took a course out of Goldstein's Classical Mechanics, the professor used problems out of this book by Speigel to illustrate points.  (He didn't admit that; we just figured out what was going on.)BTW, an intermediate undergrad book that also tends to make this subject easy is Becker's book.  That book being out of print is yet another tragedy.Since you're looking for books on mechanics, I have to mention one more classic: Symon's Mechanics.  That book, however, is the direct opposite of a Schaum's Outline.  It has an exceptionally lucid explanation of principles, but it requires a huge leap to actually solve the problems at the end chapters beyond Chapter 3.  Many students have had to "grow up" as physicists to be able to solve the harder problems in that book.  It is, to undergrads, what Jackson's Classical Electrodynamics is to graduate students.  (It took me 18 pages to work one of Jackson's problems, and, when I finished, I felt like I should publish it!)  Symon's book isn't that tough, but attaining the required proficiency to solve the tougher problems is a worthy rite of passage.  I worry that problem solutions on the internet and greater reliance on computer-based solution are robbing the next generation of physicists of analytical skill.The fact is, classical mechanics has had no significant discoveries in the last 80 years.  Related diciplines, such as quantum mechanics, have influenced the way that classical mechanics is taught in only minor ways.  But educators seem to have a need to be trendy.  Physics types are probably the least trend-oriented, but it's inexplicable to me that books like this one and Becker have fallen by the wayside.  Profs should be recommending these books even if they don't use them as texts.  At least Goldstein and Symon have stood the test of time pretty well.Bottom line:  If you're studying mechanics/dynamics or if you just want a handy reference for review, you owe it to yourself to have this book.

This book is a very good desk reference on mathematical functions.  You can browse it right here on the Amazon website, so I won't go into a lot of detail on contents.  A more modern book, NIST Handbook of Mathematical Functions, is based on this classic and should be considered by any modern buyer.  I gave the book five stars because it offers a broad set of basic functions at a very low price -- lower than the NIST edition.  The print in this Dover edition is small.  The original, Handbook of Mathematical Functions with Formulas, Graphs, and Mathematical Tables, National Bureau of Standards, Applied Mathematics Series, was a big, thick book with pretty large type.  You can follow the link and buy one on Amazon cheap.  I've been using that edition since just a few years after it was released by the NBS in 1964.  The old book, amusingly, had tables that appeared to have been produced, not through type-setting, but by typing on a mechanical typewriter!  My guess is they wanted to save money and avoid possible errors in typesetting.  Some have said that the tables are no longer useful.  If I convert the functions to computational algorithms, the tables can be extremely handy for checking.Other reviewers have stated that this book does not provide computational algorithms.  That's true some of the time, but not all of the time.  I once lifted two recursive formulas for the error function from this book that I programmed directly into a hand calculator. (No, I'm not a masochist; this was a long time ago before PCs.)  Fact is, an awful lot of functions are now included in programming language libraries, not to mention MatLab, etc.Today, I happen to be using the formulas for solution of the cubic equation, which I lifted from this book.  Did I have to do a little work to make them computationally practical? Yes.  This book wasn't the only source I had, but it gave me the best starting point that I could find.  I couldn't find a directly implementable computational algorithm anywhere.This book was THE standard among physicists beginning pretty much when it was published and lasting for a good twenty years.  For me, it's still the first place I look.

I had been using the LaCie with two Macs.  The Thunderbolt port stopped working with both Macs.  Neither of the Macs has a USB 3.0 port, so I'm stuck as far as the Macs are concerned.  When I plug the Thunderbolt cable into either Mac, the light on the drive flashes continuously at a very high rate, but neither Mac detects the drive.When you set up the LaCie, you can define two partitions, a Share partition formatted for both Mac and PC and a partition formatted for Mac only.  Neither of the partitions will now register through the Thunderbolt port.  Both will register through the USB 2.0 ports on the Macs.  Oddly, on one of the Macs, even the USB 2.0 port is crippled; I've not been able to salvage a single file from the LaCie with that Mac.  Files that were copied were corrupted.  Currently only the folders are visible and not the files.  Fortunately, USB 2.0 works on the other Mac, and I've been able to salvage the files.  Both of the Macs are recent models running Mountain Lion.  There were no software updates made to the Macs that could have triggered the problem.I did not make this purchase on Amazon.  I bought it new and in its unopened original packaging on eBay.  I haven't determined how LaCie will treat me on this.  Was the LaCie I purchased on eBaY only sold there because it was known to be defective?  It's unlikely, but not impossible.  I'm telling you the whole story.One thing I noticed was that when it was working, the drive stayed very warm when plugged into a computer via the Thunderbolt port, even when idle and even after it had been ejected on the Mac.  I've read similar comments from other users, so that's not just my unit.  As you'd expect, it sped up the drain on my MacBook Air.  If the LaCie hadn't stopped working simultaneously on both computers, I'd worry that it had damaged the computers.Bottom line:  this expensive drive has reliability that is highly suspect.  I wish I knew of a better alternative to recommend.  If anyone knows of one, please add a comment.  Also, if anyone has one of these that doesn't run very warm, please offer a comment.  If that were the case, users could buy from Amazon and return the ones that ran warm.Later addition:  I now see that 2 people took the trouble to say that they found this review helpful, while 10 went to the trouble to say that it was not helpful.  This is a hazard of writing negative reviews:  you get a lot of "unhelpful" hits.  Amazon keeps score on "helpful" versus "unhelpful" responses, and the "unhelpfuls" hurt the reviewer's rating.  Of course, if a review appears to be dishonest or misleading we should indicate that it is unhelpful.  If it doesn't provide a highly positive evaluation, some may  think it hasn't helped them find an answer since it didn't say "buy this."  Some people who have good luck with a product, or just WANT to like it, will go down the line and hit the "unhelpful" button for every one-star and two-star review.  I personally value positive and negative reviews equally when they are based on real-world, hands-on experience with a product that I can't test for myself.  In the case of this review, I went out of my way to warn people of what happened to me.  In the past, I've gone back and deleted honest, but negative, reviews because of the "unhelpful" scores they generated.  I'm not going to do that on this one yet, but if the "unhelpful" hits keep coming, I'll have no choice.  Deleting the review is, in a sense, dishonest, so I'm going to hang tough for a while.  BTW, my reviews are about 10-to-1 positive.  Also, if I solve early problems, I go back and increase my score and explain why I did.

This spreader will cover more ground, faster, with less hassle, for less money than anything I've tried.  I've been using spreaders for 40 years.I've used several of the kinds that roll on the ground and broadcast.  They're slow because they're low to the ground and the seed (or fertilizer) hits the ground before it can go very far.  Also, you can't vary the spin rate independently of your walking rate (as I explain later).I've used rolling drop spreaders, and while they are very precise, they are even slower than rolling broadcasters because they cover such a narrow path.  I do use them for seed to cover areas close to beds so that I can avoid growing grass in the beds.Until I got this spreader, the fastest things I'd used were the old hand-carried, wood-and-metal-and-canvas broadcast spreaders.  They had two problems.  When you filled them you had to have help because the canvas top would bend, and the whole thing would flop over and spill.  If you used fertilizer in them they would last one season before they corroded so badly, they were useless.  They were cheap, and they were very fast, and a lot of pros used them for seed and even fertilizer.  I used them because they were fast, but lately I haven't seen them in the stores, probably because people kept beating up the retailers over the corrosion problem.Then, from Amazon, I got a very expensive, hand-carried broadcast spreader call the Solo.  Terrible choice.  It didn't fall over, and it didn't corrode, but it was slow as molasses in the winter and didn't spread evenly.  It was also very hard to use without catching your finger in the mechanism.  It didn't hold a lot either.  I hated it.My neighbor had a huge, heavy, pro-grade handheld broadcaster that worked pretty well, didn't fall over, and didn't corrode.  I used it once.  I lift weights, but this thing was terribly unwieldly.  I actually tried several times to find one at the Farmer's Supply where he said he got it, and I never could.  Now I'm glad I didn't.I've used the little one-handed scoop-shaped spreaders you find a Home Depot et al.  They are fine for sprinkling seed on spots, but they're too small for full yards.  You'd do better spreading by hand out of a bag.And then along comes the Earthway 2750.  It does everything the old hand-carried, wood-and-metal-and-canvas broadcast spreaders would do, only better in terms of smooth cranking and speed variability.  It won't corrode (although I do worry about one little screw).  It doesn't flop over for two reasons:  (1) it has vertical plastic pieces you install in the front and back of the bag to hold it up;  (2) it has a wide, very stable base to keep the whole thing from tipping over.  The zipper on top is a nice touch to ensure that it doesn't spill when you're hoisting it onto your shoulder.  It costs a lot less than the Solo and will cover a yard more evenly in about 20 percent of the time.Now, let me manage expectations.  If you've never used a hand-held broadcast spreader before, don't fill it all the way up the first time.  You especially don't want to fill it all the way up with heavy fertilizer.  Once it's loaded, start out gingerly.  Prop it against your stomach to get it out in front of you.  You vary the width of the path that you sow by how fast you turn the crank (which slings the seed out).  The amount that you put down per square yard depends on three things:  (1) how far back you pull the left-hand lever; (2) how fast you walk; and (3) how fast you crank (because that varies the width).  It is not like learning to ride a bicycle, but it does take getting used to.  Once you get the hang of it (punny) you'll find it gives you wonderful control -- far more than any rolling spreader.Okay, I read the review from the person who said she got the fertilizer all over her.  I just walked in from using it, and I don't have a particle of fertilizer on me, but I certainly understand how it can happen.  Before you fill it up the first time, hold it in position and walk while turning the crank.  Pull back the left (valve or throttle) lever and look down to see what the valve in the bottom is doing.  Get comfortable doing that much first.  Next, fill it about 1/4 full.  Start walking and cranking BEFORE you open the valve.  Open it slowly.  If you do this, I predict you'll be totally successful the first time out and not waste a bit of seed or fertilizer.I also read the review from the guy who broke his spreader.  I was concerned by that.  The only way I can see that happening would be if you tried to  strong-arm the crank.  Just spin it up gently before you open the valve.  If you try to spin it up fast when it's clogged with fertilizer, you could stress the mechanism.  If you are using pelletized fertilizer, you're going to need to break up any clumps.  Follow these suggestions, and I'll be very surprised if you break it.***Update***  I've now been using this spreader for over a year, and I'm still sold on it.  It still works like new.Good luck!Tim

At the time of this writing, there is one other review, which gives the product one star.  The review says there are no instructions.  My clock came with good instructions, a two-sided sheet inside the sealed box.  The sheet was folded up very small and could easily be overlooked.  (I'm not saying the other reviewer's clock had instructions that he overlooked -- please take what I say at face value.)  Now, on to the review.The clock performs mostly as advertised.  The time readout is tall enough to be easily read from 10 feet away in decent light.  The day, date, and temperature readouts are much smaller.The one problem with performance is that the temperature measurement is about 4 degrees high.  It seems that most digital travel alarms now have temperature measurement.  They probably all use the same electronic module, and I expect that all of them are similarly unreliable.  Of course, mine may be much worse than typical.  I didn't want temperature measurement.  It can't help battery life.  Temperature measurement is only useful to me if it is about somewhere else;  I can tell well enough for myself how my motel room is doing.  Also note that the temperature measurement is very slow, at least an hour, to respond to, say 5 degrees change in temperature.  Even if your clock is better calibrated, don't expect it to tell you your motel room temperature if you have just taken it out of your suitcase.The clock is very lightweight, which makes it feel a bit cheap.  I'm sure the designers assumed that lighter was better in today's world of airline weight limits.  Most of the clock is plastic, but the front panels, left and right, are wrapped in a thin sheet of metal veneer.  This adds a look, if not a feel, of quality.It uses a CR2032 battery, which is a large button cell (included, of course).  When you change the battery, you have to reset the clock, including the month, day, and year as well as the hour and minute.  Hopefully, this will not be frequent.  Setting is fairly quick and intuitive.There is a tab on the back that flips out to act as a "table stand."  That's how you prop it up on your bedside table.There is a large, wide, snooze/light button on top.  It will be easy to find in the dark.  The downside is that, while it takes significant force to push it, the button is easy to accidentally press when you're handling the clock -- like when you're setting it.  The sliding cover does not cover the snooze/light button, so you have to be careful to pack the clock so that the button isn't pressed in transit, which would keep the light on and run down the battery.  Taking the battery out is not a good option since, as I said earlier, you have to reset everything if you remove the battery for even a second.The light does an outstanding job of even illumination of the screen, which is apparently backlit.  I've had a number of travel alarms that were lit from one or both sides and extremely hard to read in the dark.  Also, older clock bulbs seem to burn out as a matter of course, even with light use.  I'd like to think that this clock uses an LED with attendant long life and low wattage, but I have no idea if this is the case.One last note:  When you first use the clock, you have to remove the insulating tab in the battery compartment.  I didn't get the cover back on straight  before the first time I went through the setting process.  When I later tried to straighten the cover, the battery lost contact for a millisecond and I had to redo the setting sequence.I would have given the clock five stars if the temp gauge had worked accurately.  The clock will do the job for me, and I recommend it to anyone who needs something lightweight and doesn't need a temperature gauge.Tim

This is a very well-made product.  I did find the Amazon description to be misleading.  It says there is an o-ring where it attaches to the engine.  This is not true.  You have a simple pipe thread where you attach to the engine.  The o-ring is (happily) on the other end where the cap is that you remove to drain the oil.  It's a good system with only one compromise:  the hose stays full of oil that is not used by the engine and is lost every time you drain the engine.  This, I believe, is why manufacturers don't use this approach.  The amount of oil lost is probably under an ounce, so it's no big deal.As you can see from reading other reviews, the real question is whether it is workable in your engine's geometry.  Can you attach it?  If you can, will the hose be long enough?  Will you be able to tuck it out of the way?  I have to wonder about people who blame these problems on the product.  Try to figure this all out BEFORE you buy.I used my Drainzit hose to replace one of the little Briggs and Stratton twist-to-seal kits that came on a 15-year-old riding mower.  The old kit was leaky after 15 years, and it was always a hassle to deal with, partly because of its poor accessibility.  I made up my mind that I was going to replace it if it meant cutting sheet metal to get access.  I expected trouble removing the old B&S one and installing this one.  I avoided cutting metal by using a stubby  wrench (from one of those cheap Harbor Freight sets).  I ground down the shoulders on the open end side to allow it to maneuver.  (Not sure why a low-leverage wrench designed to get into tight spaces would need wide shoulders anyway.)  I wrapped the Drainzit's pipe thread in teflon tape so that I wouldn't need to get it super tight and could ensure a leak-free connection.  It worked.You may be considering the B&S Valve Kit.  There are a couple of advantages for it.  First, you don't have to leave the hose on.  Second, it doesn't waste any oil.  This is the same B&S kit that I said was a hassle.  It is a valve that you twist and pull out to open.  You push in and twist in the other direction to close.  If it is hard to get to, it'll drive you nuts.  As I said, mine leaked eventually, but the little yellow cap that they now provide should reduce or eliminate leakage -- assuming the little cap holds up.  If your oil port is easy to get to, and you don't want a floppy hose to deal with, you should consider the B&S alternative.  The Drainzit will give you a sure seal and be easier to work with in most configurations, but if you need a really long hose, you can buy the B&S and a separate long hose.Bottom line:  The Drainzit product does what it is supposed to do.  Before you buy, you should look carefully at how you will install it, use it, and live with it.

How can a little remote control stun anybody, you ask?  Because, in this day of foreign made, poorly conceived, poorly executed, poorly documented electronic devices, this item stands alone in my experience.  It will control my iPhone, used as a music server, from 30 feet away through two walls.  It is an ideal size.  It has a hidden, but easily accessible, keypad to support certain functions.  It has an off/on switch so you can carry it without worrying about running down the battery (bluetooth demands this).  The setup is straightforward, only because of the superb little instruction brochure.  Once it has been set up, you reconnect it by first turning on BT on your controlled device and then switching on the remote. (Of course, I could choose to leave my iPhone BT on all the time, but that would speed up the depletion of its already short-lived battery.)Speaking of the instructions, all I can say is "Wow."  How can I be "wowed" by instructions, you ask?  Because they are clearer, better written, and better illustrated than any instructions for anything I currently own.  Are you tired of the uncertainty of not knowing what you're going to have to face when you open an instruction brochure?  Are you sick of convoluted explanations and hideous grammar in instruction booklets for just about everything you buy?  Are you sick of typos?  (On more complex devices, are you insulted when you have to buy a book to learn all the features?)  I have $4000 cameras and $75000 cars (new price, I bought used) with manuals that don't come close to this  little product's manual in terms of quality.  The writing is beyond clear and correct, it's actually sophisticated.  They apparently spent the whopping $200 to have a professional editor make it what it is.This is obviously a 5-star review, but could the remote be improved?  I'd like to have the buttons be more easily identifiable by touch.  They already have a rough-smooth contrast that helps tactile recognition, but it's a bit subtle.  That's it.  Otherwise, it's perfect, at least for me.

While this product seems expensive as an add-on to do what an iOS device (iPad, Pod, Phone, etc.) already does, it's practically free when compared to high-end audio investment cost.  Using it as a headphone amp, all you do is plug the Lightning end of your iOS device's cable into the device and the USB end into the iDo.  Then plug your headphones into the iDo and voila.  Other reviewers have already said that this device greatly improves typical iOS-device sound, and it does.  I confess that I'm comparing it to the iPhone 5's audio output, and the iPhone 5's audio is a significant step down in sound quality from earlier iPhones and iPods, probably because it is so small and lightweight.  But there's nothing wrong with the iPhone 5's digital signal, and that's what the iDo uses.  I'd say the iDo will take you 75 percent of the way from iPhone 5 sound to what you'd get from an audiophile rig costing 10 times a much and taking up 20 times as much space.  That's a good deal. If you're an audiophile (audiofool?) or if you happen to have a home theater receiver, you have options that may produce even better sound.The iDo is especially good as a headphone amp, but you can do more with it.  It has RCA line-level jacks on the back that respond to the volume control.  You can connect it to a boom box or set of computer speakers or whatever.  if you're a 'phile, you can input it either to your preamp for switching or directly to power amp(s) if you have separates and don't need the switching.  A more important option is to use the coaxial digital output.  If you're a 'phile who has a separate digital-to-analog converter (DAC), you can do it that way.  If you have a home theater rig, you probably have the ability to connect the digital output to your home theater receiver.  If you have an expensive receiver, its built in DACs are probably better than what's in the iDo.  Whether or not that's true, your home theater receiver is the gateway to your home theater speakers.  No question that this is how 90 percent of digital-output users will do it.  Understand that when you use the coaxial output, you are bypassing the iDo's built-in DAC and analog amplification entirely.  Get a coaxial digital cable if you decide to do this.  If you have an old composite or component video cable, that will do in a pinch.If you have a home theater receiver with a USB input or bluetooth, you may be able to play your cell phone directly through the receiver.  If that's your objective, check those options first.I tried using the digital output going directly into a high-end DAC, and it sounded superb, as you'd expect.  Going this route, I have a true, high-end music server in my iPhone 5 (I have 1000 songs from ripped CDs using Apple lossless compression on my iPhone.)  The message is that it produces a clean digital signal.  If you have any home theater receiver, this is a way to use the iDo, even though, in that mode, all it is probably doing is routing the digital signal to the coax output.  (I'm guessing that there's no processing involved -- there may be.)One technical aside:  the volume control, which affects the line-out as well as the headphone output, is analog instead of digital.  It is digitally controlled, but the actual volume reduction uses analog components.  This is a good thing.  Reducing volume digitally into standard DACs can produce very bad sound.So what am I saying?  The iDo is an outstanding headphone amp.  It can serve as a DAC plus a preamp.  It can produce a coaxial digital signal.  So it can be just an add-on to your iPhone to upgrade the headphone sound, or it can turn your iOS device into an outstanding music server for a home theater or even a high-end audio rig (if the rig has DAC capability).To me it's gratifying to see other reviewers praising a product whose sole function in most applications is sound quality improvement.  It's a sign that in an age of synthetic sound, people still hear differences in quality, and people still care enough to go out of their way to get better sound.  I'm tempted to buy another iDo so I can have one at work and one at home -- actually, I could use two at home.  It's a great product that exceeds expectation.***Update*** If you're primarily interested in using the digital output, check the NuForce website for a cheaper option.

I've only had to actually use Eclipse fluid on a sensor three times.  Other times I've gotten by with blowers and brushes.  But when I've used the fluid and a swab from this kit, what I've seen under a loupe has been very impressive.  The sensor has been perfect as far as I've been able to see.  I've never come close to that level of cleanliness with blowers and brushes, which can get large dust particles but tend to just move around the smaller ones.  A loupe will expose dust that is way too small to affect images, so looking perfect means being perfect in a practical sense.  The fluid will wet the sensor and then dry up in half a second, leaving no residue.I really like the little zipper case. I added some Pec Pads  and a few Zeiss, foil-wrapped, pre-moisened cleaning tissues for lenses cleaning.  I also added an Arctic Butterfly brush laid diagonally in the case along with the stuff that came with it.  When I travel, the only cleaning stuff that can't fit in the case are a Giotto's blower and a SensorKlear loupe.  At home, I use a large SensorKlear loupe and carry a small one when I travel.  The magic in the loupes is in the lighting, which makes dust stand out like over-sharpening in Photoshop!The reason for the review title is that I lost my last kit (with the Arctic Butterfly in it).  I made absolutely sure I couldn't find my original, and then bought another.  It is small, lightweight insurance that I depend on.  The only thing I'd change would be the color of the case to make it harder to lose!Happy shooting,Tim

I read reviews on this and similar items, and this one easily scored the highest; the others all had complaints, even including the simple, overpriced plug converters.  Now I know why this one gets good ratings.  I'm using it on a Nortel IP phone at work that has a separate socket for a headset.  This device has an active amplifier circuit for the microphone, powered through the socket so that it needs no batteries.  People on the other end say I'm crystal clear when I'm whispering.  The Nortel standard handset gets the opposite comments:  "Can you speak louder?  I can barely hear you."  The receiver is excellent as well:  everything sounds clear and natural on my end.  I was hoping for something hands-free that would perform as well as the stock handset.  What I got performs 10 times better.  Highly, highly, highly recommended!

The Arctic Butterfly has a brush suitable for cleaning delicate optics with conducting bristles to help remove statically charged debris.  The brush can be spun using a battery-powered motor to remove the debris from the bristles.  (You never spin the brush against the object you are cleaning.) Spinning helps eliminate some problems with brush contamination and speeds the cleaning process.  This particular kit contains four different brushes:  an APS-sized sensor brush (about a half-inch wide and about the size of the standard Arctic Butterfly brush); a sensor brush that is about 3/4 in wide; a sensor brush almost an inch wide, and a mirror brush about an inch wide exactly matching the size of an APS-C camera's mirror.  The APS brush is supposed to be stored on the motor.  There is one small plastic adaptor for adapting each brush to the motor (not sure why that was necessary).I've used an Arctic Butterfly brush many times before on both APS-C sensors and on a full-frame sensor.  It is very convenient to be able to run the brush over the sensor a couple of times, hold it away from the camera and spin it, and then run it over the sensor again.  You may wisely be asking whether you need all these different-sized brushes just for sensors.  I don't really see the need, even if you have different sized sensors as I do.  It is nice to have a separate brush for the mirror, and that was what made me buy.  I don't like to let a sensor brush touch anything but a sensor.  I've used the same brush on APS-C and full-frame sensors with no problem.  Only the APS-C brush in this kit is small enough for an APS-C sensor.  The larger brushes are definitely too large for an APS-C sensor.  If you want to have multiple brushes for spares and are worried about the spares being too big, don't be.  You could easily trim off the outside bristles to get any of them to an optimum size.  As I explain below, the one thing you don't want is a brush that's too big.  BTW, the mirror brush appears to have the same bristles as the sensor brushes.I use a sensor-cleaning loupe whenever I clean a sensor because it makes all dust visible.  It will show dust that is much too small to appear in a picture.When I have a sensor problem, I'll use a blower first.  If that doesn't work, I'll use a brush.  Normally, if debris hasn't been left on too long, a brush will get it.  Only in severe cases do I resort to cleaning fluid, although cleaning fluid makes a sensor look cleaner under a loupe than any brush.I do want to offer a word of caution.  You must be extremely careful not to let a sensor brush touch anything but a sensor.  I once let an Arctic Butterfly brush touch the inside of my camera at a point near the sensor.  It apparently picked up some grease, because it suddenly started smearing my sensor.  I successfully used Photographic Solutions Eclipse fluid to clean both the brush and the sensor, but it wasn't a pleasant experience.  This is precisely why you must not try to use the larger brushes on an APS-C sensor without trimming them first.  You have probably read the review from the guy who claimed a brush was making small scratches on his sensor.  My guess is that he got some grease on it like I did, and what he saw were grease tracks.  I saw a review of another Arctic Butterfly brush that said the reviewer's brush suddenly started smearing his sensor.  That doesn't happen spontaneously.  The grease doesn't just materialize on the brush.  And I personally don't think it's possible for these bristles to actually scratch a sensor.  That would be like saying you scratched glass with a paint brush.  If there's a hazard associated with these brushes, though, I believe brush contamination with something like grease is the hazard.The kit comes with a hard-plastic case and a lightweight zipper case.  I will use the latter and add to it some swabs, Pec Pads, and Zeiss lens-cleaning pads (which I would never use on a sensor, but I have used successfully on lenses and coated filters).  The kit in this form is ideal for me.  I do pack the blower separately.I'm a believer in the Arctic Butterfly brushes.  They do what they're supposed to and they do it well.  Coupled with a (Giotto's) blower, they allow me to avoid cleaning fluid 99 percent of the time.  Bottom line:  This is a good kit for the money.  I'd get it again.Update:  I have encountered a problem.  This kit comes with a hard case and a soft case, which are both extremely nice.  Both cases came with an extremely strong smell of mildew/mold.  The worst was the soft case.  I've tried everything under the sun to clean the soft case because, as I said in my original review, I had plans for that case.  The case is padded, and the padding is not accessible.  I think the padding is the problem is since I've cleaned everything else.  I e-mailed the manufacturer and received no response.  I'd have returned it for a replacement if it were sold by Amazon, but I didn't want to waste time with a third-party vendor on a matter this small.  Also I thought, given that he is a small vendor, his entire stock may be contaminated anyway.  I'm not taking away a star because I doubt you're buying the product for the case.

I bought this unit to replace an older one by Omron (see below) that was reading incorrectly.  This unit agrees with my physician's measurements when made within a minute of each other.  Its measurements are generally repeatable to within a couple of percent when made a few minutes apart.  Pulse-rate measurements have about 2 percent variation over periods of minutes.  It is critically important to follow the directions to the letter, at least for me.  Blood pressure fluctuates with exercise, eating, drinking alcohol, and time of day.  If you are cold when you take measurements, perhaps because you've taken your shirt off or you're in you underwear, your blood pressure may be pushed up.  I have to sit still and relax for about 5 minutes if I want consistent results.  I have to be careful to position my body properly (according to the instructions) and relax my arm with the cuff in place for about 30 seconds.  If I sit down and start taking measurements immediately, even if I've just gotten up in the morning, my readings will taper off from an initially higher value.  This is not the fault of the monitor, it's just ME.  You may be different.  Remember that when a physician or nurse takes your blood pressure, you've usually been sitting in a holding room for awhile, which allows your blood pressure to settle down.  For me it would be a joke to try to compare the results of measurements taken at home with measurements taken in a doctor's office.  I get the feeling that some reviewers expect that.  After working with it extensively, I'm convinced that this monitor is doing its job exactly as it's supposed to.I had an Omron HEM-712C monitor that was about 6 years old. The Omron unit, which had been stored for almost all of the six years in its original box in a climate-controlled environment, was not producing reliable results.  The diastolic measurements were more than 10 percent low.  I bought the Panasonic EW 3122S because it was from a different manufacturer and had the best reviews of options on Amazon.  I've been extremely pleased with the results.The box and the Amazon listing incorrectly state that an AC adaptor can be purchased separately.  Panasonic no longer makes an adapter, and the accompanying material clearly says not to substitute another adaptor.  The device still has a jack on the side for an AC adaptor, probably because is costs less to keep installing the jacks than to redo the plastic mold for the housing.  The monitor uses 4 AA batteries in series, and the formerly available power supply (EW31225) was six volts DC.  Pictures of the old supply indicate that it was a fairly large supply, meaning it had a fairly high current rating, and a Radio Shack wall-wart substitution won't do the job.  So far, I've made 75 measurements with one set of alkaline AAs, and they are going strong.  For this reason, I didn't deduct a star.

I read the earlier reviews before buying or installing this cartridge.  When I opened it, I did all the standard shaking motions, rotating it back and forth, etc., even though there were no written instructions.  I pulled out the orange tape.  I lifted the shield and pulled out the piece of paper.  I also removed the often-discussed orange tab.  I decided to remove it because the OEM cartridge that I was replacing didn't have a tab.  I then gave the cartridge a few more shakes, installed it, and turned on the printer.  The printer did its standard, getting-ready, humming noise for longer than I expected.  Then it fell silent and the printer lights eventually started blinking in the proper pattern.  Using the printer utility on a Mac, I printed the standard demo page.  Voila:  the print was letter-perfect, side-to-side and top-to-bottom on the very first try.  The print was just as black and as sharp as with the OEM cartridge.The biggest single problem with the P1100w is the cost of toner expended per page.  Problem solved!!.

We have four of these, all of which were bought at Target, so there was no risk of receiving a less-than-perfect-condition item, as happened to one reviewer.  We've taken three of the bags on a total of eight flight segments and on and off a cruise ship.  (Cruise lines tend to be even worse than airports and airlines when it comes to treatment of luggage.)  We've also dragged them a long way, including a quarter mile to a water taxi in Venice.  The three bags still look absolutely like new.  The only mishap has been loss of a zipper tab, which disappeared between luggage pick-up on a ship and arriving at home.  My guess is that a glancing blow on a conveyor knocked it off.  The luggage has a 10 year warranty, so I expect to get a replacement tab and reattach it myself.  (Warranties may not be as good as they sound when you consider the problem of shipment.  If you bought from Amazon, you'd at least have a box.)The bags roll and swivel well.  Spinners, as you probably know, will swivel and roll freely while standing upright.  Unlike some spinners, these bags will roll backward while tilted forward, which can be handy when going on and off elevators where there's not enough room to turn around.  This is what the ad copy means when it says "Push, pull, or turn in any direction with effortless mobility."  When on a flat, smooth surface, I can slip my Tumi roll-aboard over the American Tourister's handle and roll the AT upright.  This vastly reduces the burden on long hauls.  The bag did just fine carrying the extra weight, which probably exceeded a total of 75 pounds.The name of the game now in air travel is to make full use of your 50-pound allowance for checked bags.  I've weighed all four of the AT 29s empty, and they come in within a tenth of a pound of 11.5 pounds.  That's about half the weight of some of our older luggage, and it's a big deal, given the 50 pound limits.  The expansion feature will allow you to get the weight up to 50 pounds, even when packing only clothing.  It's obvious that these bags were sized to reach a total weight of 50 pounds, and with heavier (denser) items, you can exceed 50 pounds without using the expansion volume.  Today's savvy traveler who is pushed against the weight limit will put his heavy (high-density) stuff in carry-on bags, which currently have limits on dimensions but not on weight.  Under such conditions, many will use a roll-aboard  and a back pack (or in my wife's case, a large pocketbook) along with a single checked bag.  On a full plane, you won't be allowed to put two carry-ons in the overhead, so one will have to go under the seat.  If the backpack is fairly small, it can fit under the seat without totally constricting leg movement on long flights.  If you use this trick to handle your heavy (dense) items, you'll likely be able to make full use of the expansion feature without going over 50 pounds.  A disadvantage of the expansion feature is that your clothes will be compressed when the bags are stacked.  The expansion goes outside of the basic frame.  I prefer to keep the expansion volume zipped down when possible.So far I'm extremely pleased with this luggage.  If I have problems later, I'll update this review.***Update*** I've now had four of these for another year.  They've been overseas again and on another cruise ship as well as several CONUS trips.  I wouldn't trade them for anything out there.PS:  If you're concerned about weight, you MUST buy one of the little portable luggage scales.  If we lost ours, we'd be in big trouble.

I've read the reviews of people who say the scale won't produce repeatable results.  I just repeated the weighing of an empty suitcase 8 times and every time I got 11.6 pounds.  I found that results are not that repeatable unless you use the following procedure:  (1) switch on the scale; (2) press the left button with the hook hanging free; (3) move the scale so that the hook is under the suitcase top handle; (4) lift up very gradually until the suitcase is off the floor; (5) wait until the number settles out; (6) note the reading; (7) SWITCH THE SCALE BACK OFF and repeat.  If you don't follow this procedure, measurements may vary by plus or minus about 0.3 pounds around a mean value.  The whole procedure takes under 15 seconds if you're really slow.Now let's be real here.  Repeatability doesn't prove accuracy.  A repeatable scale may be repeatably wrong.I bought this scale to ensure that my bags are under the airlines' 50 pound weight limit.  I've noted that airlines will normally let a bag through if it is within two pounds of 50, so the scale doesn't have to be all that accurate.  In addition, I'd bet the airlines' scales aren't good to better than half a pound, especially considering the beating they take.  My rule of thumb is to stay at or below a reading of 49.2 pounds, just to be safe.  So far, I've run 14 bags through that were just below 50 pounds and I've had no problems.I couldn't live without this thing now.  When my family travels they like to live on the edge of overweight.  And then they like to buy stuff and bring it home.  I often end up having them switch the high-density items to carry-ons.  We end up switching things around multiple times to get all checked bags under 50.  Before we got this scale, we actually had to switch items on the floor of the airport when we were over the limit.  We were relying on a bathroom scale.  Now we've solved the problem.  It simply wouldn't be possible without this scale.  If you're trying to stay under the airline 50-pound limit, I highly recommend this product.

These same tags in different colors have a 4.5 average on three reviews.  One of the the previous reviews on the present listing said the tags "slide open without trying" so the reviewer just tossed them.  What the reviewer is referring to is the fact that the tags slide open to expose a complete address form on the back of the name block that is always visible through the little window.  I have two sets of these tags, and mine don't slide open easily at all.  You have to grip them firmly and pull fairly hard.  If they do slide open, you can just slide them back again; nothing is lost.The other of the two reviews that gave one star (the only two on this listing when I'm writing this) said his broke the first time he used it.  I just ran three of them on 4 flight segments and mine are just fine, thank you.  I'm not saying that it's impossible for them to break, especially considering how our luggage is handled.  But these tags are made of a heavy, non-brittle, PVC-like material that would not break when I just jumped up and down on them.  It would probably take a hammer.I'm about to order four more.Update:  I've now run four of them on 4 more flight segments and through one cruise ship.  Cruise lines are harder on luggage than airlines.  Still no problems.  If I do have problems in the future, I'll report them.2nd Update:  I've now run six of them on many more flight segments and another cruise, and still no problems.

I had trouble getting MapSource to see my nuvi 2555 on two Windows 7 computers.  I was finally successful on one, but never on the other.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the software comes with no useful map anyway.  I contacted Garmin, who told me to download their free BaseCamp software.  BaseCamp turned out to completely meet my needs.  It has a choice of settings for automotive, motorcycling, walking, hiking, and others.  You use BaseCamp with your GPS device connected, and it uses the maps right off of the device without uploading.Be sure you are using a UPS 2.0 or better port, or it will be unbearably slow.  It is retrieving map data for your large computer screen, which is beyond what the nuvi or other device was designed to support. For that reason, even with USB 2.0, it's not super fast when updating screens or computing complex routes. Basecamp allows you to define and store waypoints, routes and other data and exchange with your device.  When you first plug in the device, expect the software to take a minute to see it.  Also, BaseCamp may take several minutes to process the maps the first time.  After that first time, it should only take about 20 seconds to be ready to go.  It is supposed to support the exchange of maps, but I've not gotten it to upload from the device, and I don't have anything to download.BaseCamp isn't perfect, and it takes a little getting used to, but  Garmin has a series of videos on their site that show how to use it.  You might want to just look at the videos before you bother with download and installation. I urge you to give it a look before you spring for the product under review.  While BaseCamp has already met my needs, I'm continuing to discover useful features.BaseCamp is Windows-only.

First of all, the instructions that come with the battery say to charge it before using.  I suggest you follow the instructions, even if it will power your computer immediately.  Given that this battery is 9-cell, and my original equipment battery is 6-cell, I expected to get about 50 percent more time out of this one, and, so far, I have.  I have run it down to about 25% of full life, and recharged it twice with perfect performance.  If I have trouble down the road, I'll come back and amend this review.  If you don't see an amendment here, assume it is still going strong.  My original review date is 29 May 2012.The battery is close to 50 percent heavier than the OEM battery.  Also, it extends downward so that it is not flush with the bottom of the computer.  This causes it to tilt the computer sightly forward toward the user.  This is a good thing from the standpoint of ventilation.  I know people who prop up the backs of their computers just to achieve this effect.  It is a bad thing if you need it to be flat on both sides to slip in to a briefcase or whatever.The seller actually contacted me to makes sure I was satisfied.  That, also, is reassuring.I'm comfortable enough with this battery that I'm about to take it on a trans-atlantic flight.  This purchase has turned out very well for me.  I hope you have a similar experience!Best,TimP.S.  I've returned from my two-week trip, where I made regular use of the battery.  Zero problems.

The Duo replaced a processor in my system that retailed for $4000 and won The Perfect Vision's video product of the year award.  The Duo equaled the performance of that (Optoma) processor in terms of enhanced video performance.  I'm using it on an Optoma HD81 projector that has no built-in processing.  The Duo produced a huge gain in picture sharpness that is dramatic on a 12-foot screen. That level of projection magnifies flaws mercilessly.Of all the video features, the one I like most is the Detail Enhancement (DE).  I've done a lot of work with sharpening (even read a whole book on the subject) in still photography.  In that medium, what goes on is edge enhancement, which sharpens the transition between light and dark areas (by a Gaussian de-convolution, if you speak that language).  The iScan has that capability as well, but the DE is the really surprising capability to me.  I think it may be some kind of frame-to-frame correlation thing.  Anyway, it makes pictures really pop off the screen.  I'll run DE at 80 to 90 percent and edge sharpening at about 20 percent.  If I overdo edge sharpening on my system, I get visible artifacts.  On my 12-foot screen the picture improvement can be spectacular on some material.  It makes everything better.  I haven't found a lot of need for noise reduction, but remember that any sharpening will bring out noise.  I run noise reduction fairly low.You can spend a lot more, but I don't think you'll do much better in picture quality unless you're planning to invest in a professional calibration.  If you want to see what the competition is, go to the B&H Photo website.  You'll quickly conclude that there's no competition in the iScan Duo's price bracket.The Duo has one feature that has made a huge difference for me personally.  It has the capability to split out the audio signal and output it separately, including an audio coax jack, an optical audio jack, and an HDMI jack.  If you want the high-end surround formats, you must use the HDMI audio out jack.  My old processor did not have this feature.  When I used it (or the Duo) downstream of my audio preamp-processor (which behaves like a receiver), I had very serious problems with format transitions that I won't go into.  The Duo allows me to get the audio pre-pro out of the video signal path entirely.  While the Duo is not as slick (and has an ugly display), it has solved my problem, which was a showstopper for watching TV.The Duo will fully support anamorphic lens use, although it is incapable of automatic recognition or triggering a sled mount as my previous processor would.  On the Duo you can set an image for an anamorphic lens by simply switching to the 4:3 letterbox mode.  That mode will spread a 16:9 letterbox image to fully fill the frame with no loss of content.  You can also use the vertical stretch capability as another alternative, but 4:3 letterbox is the perfect solution.While it does offer a nice array of color adjustments, it does not have the flexibility of my previous processor.  It is more than good enough for me in that regard.If you want to do any sophisticated scaling (such as anamorphic lens support), expect to spend some time reading and rereading the manual.  Be sure to notice that the manual has some additions at the end to cover multiple firmware upgrades.  DVDO needs to fold those into the document and not just leave them to be discovered at the end after significant frustration.The manual and menus use some non-intuitive language to describe certain features.  Expect to have to take some notes.  An example is "Active (Aspect Ratio)."  This refers to the aspect ratio of the incoming signal.  It is called "active" because it indicates the amount of the incoming frame that is active as opposed to blacked out as bars above and below or on the sides.  All the manual says is "This is aspect ratio of content or movie."Another example of potential confusion:  Turn off Auto AR when you want to work with the Picture and Active AR menus.  That critical tip is not provided in the descriptions of those menus.The front panel digital display is not as attractive as even a cheap receiver, and it only stays on for a short time.  Of course, once you're set up, you'll want it off anyway.I'm going to report one ugly problem that I had, but let me say up front that it should not affect you at all.  I found that putting HDMI switching ahead of the Duo caused the audio output circuits of the Duo to fail.  This happened on two separate Duo units.  Amazon covered me.  They were going to pull it from their shelves, but I told them the problem would probably never affect another of their customers.  I also said I'd write this review and warn buyers.  Message:  if you're going to use the Duo, expect to do your switching with it.I should also report that the technical assistance person that I spoke to at DVDO was outstanding.  He was knowledgeable and courteous, and, equally importantly, he was accessible.One thing you have to understand about putting any kind of device in the HDMI path is that format changes, source changes, etc. will not transition as quickly or cleanly.  HDMI has to redo all the HD Copy Protection (HDCP) handshaking when it thinks something has changed, and adding devices in series can create havoc.  It will happen when you change TV channels and the video format changes (e.g., 720p to 1080i).  If you keep your installation simple, the iScan Duo will work well.The current generation of flat-panel TVs already offers vastly improved processing over previous generations.  For this reason, standalone processors may be a dying breed.  If you need one though, as I definitely do, the Duo is an excellent choice.  I don't give five stars lightly, especially after having problems as I did.  In all fairness, though, this is a five-star product.  I hope it works out for you.Tim

The sides and bottom of this case are heavily padded so that the exterior width approaches 11cm at the widest point.  It is not perfectly round, having one flat side to allow it to fit against your body or a backpack without constant rolling.  The padding in the top is somewhat thinner, and I may use the extra top space that I have to tuck in a bean bag (the ultimate lightweight tripod).  The padding only adds about 1 cm to the height, so that the external dimensions are about 16x11cm.  The  exterior cladding looks like ballistic nylon, but it is not nearly as coarse as that material usually is.  It has a vertical strap running up the back that will allow you to attach it snugly to a belt.  The strap can be released and reattached at the bottom reliably and securely with velcro.  This will allow you to loop it through your belt, camera bag, backpack, or whatever.  It has double zippers so that they can come together in front and two nylon tab-loops on either end of the zipper opening to grip when closing or opening.While I've owned may Lowepro products over the years, this is my first lens case from them.  I typically use Zing pouches for lenses that didn't come with cases.  The Zings are less bulky, simply because they have far less padding.  I wanted something more sturdy and substantial for this lens, and this case absolutely fills the bill.  The padding adds bulk, but you can't have it both ways.  I will use a Zing when I'm pressed for space, but I'll treat this case like one of the manufacturers' cases on the high-end lenses.  The padding, I should add, adds no significant weight.  Lowepro obviously made weight a priority.While it is certainly not cheap, the quality of the case exceeded my expectation.  It equals the quality of the lens manufacturers' cases at a half to a third of the cost.  If I were going to change anything about these cases, it would be to have closer spaced sizing choices.  I would happily trade this one for one that was a couple of cm shorter.  I highly recommend the case.  As Lowepro likes to proclaim, they've been making excellent products for photographers for many years.  This product is no exception.

These pens write as smoothly as a $400 fountain pen.  In some ways they write better, because fountain pens often have a slight delay before the ink flows.  Notice in my title, I said "WRITES like a fountain pen."  These pens are not pretty, and they feel anything but expensive in your hand.  That said, I like the thick grip; I also like the fact that you can write with much less pressure than with a ballpoint.  I've been retraining my hand to hold the pens more loosely and use very slight pressure.  My hand writing has improved (which isn't saying much).The Sharpie Grip Stick pens -- the ones with the chrome caps -- write exactly the same as these to me.  Those are a much better choice for carrying in pocket or purse, and they are much better looking.  These are best for sitting in a drawer or in a mug on your desk.  You can grab them and use them much quicker and with just one hand:  it takes two hands to remove a cap.I think Sharpie should make a high-end model that accepts refills.  I'd pay at least $15 more each.  A pen that writes with this superb quality deserves to look the part!

Short version:This model is the sweet-spot for homeowners who want long-term reliability and near top performance but do not need to operate with hot water, which doubles or triples the price.  As far as DPW4240 performance goes, I could never go back to one of the lesser washers.  Performance just doesn't compare.  Things get pristine-clean much faster.  Also, I'm not sure more pressure or water throughput would make sense for a homeowner's use.  A downside to so much pressure is that it will blow the paint off of surfaces.  You can deal with this by selecting a nozzle with a wider fan, holding the wand farther from the surface, and/or throttling down the motor.  The build quality on the unit is excellent.  Like ALL gas PWs, this one requires serious maintenance.  I'll describe that later if you want to stick around.  I'll summarize in this short version by saying that I love the washer.  It continues to be worth the price and more.Long version:This is my third year with the DPW4240.  My previous unit was a 3000 psi, 2.7 gpm washer.  Before that, I had one of the larger electric models.  The DPW4240 is a much more serious unit than the lower-powered variety.  It has 40 percent higher max pressure, has a lot more water throughput (4 gpm), and has a 50 foot hose instead of the usual 25 footer.  I can feel the power difference just holding the wand, since the "thrust" force is about 80 percent higher.  Everything about this unit is heavier duty, including the wheels and the frame as well as the motor, pump, hose, and wand.  The only problem I've had has been a leaky valve on a tire.
