(The tires come with tubes installed.)Handling the wand and hose on this unit can be like wrestling an anaconda.  If you're doing something easy like cleaning a deck floor without repositioning the hose, you can literally relax and lean on it.  If you're trying to reposition the wand hose while holding the trigger pulled, expect it to be challenging.  If you weigh under 110 pounds and don't have good upper-body strength, this may not be for you.There are two ways to destroy your pump that are quicker than failing to do maintenance.  The first is to run it without the water source turned on.  The pump must never run without water in the chamber.  The second is to leave the engine running for more than two minutes without pulling the trigger on the wand.  In this second case, the water in the pump heats up.  As a rule, I don't stop the flow for as much as a minute without pulling the trigger for several seconds to run cool water into the pump.When you are ready to start the motor, first verify that the water is on by pulling the trigger on the wand or surface cleaner and verifying a steady flow.  If it doesn't start after two pulls, pull the trigger to release the pressure build-up in the hose.  (All PWs that I've tried require this.)  Like any PW, this one can be harder to pull-start when the engine is hot.  If you encounter this problem, find someone to hold the wand and keep the trigger pulled while you pull the starter rope.  This fully solves the problem and allows the engine to spin more freely and start more easily.  The person must not be a child, because the sudden turn-on of the "thrust" force can make a small person lose his or her balance.  My guess is that manufacturers never tell you of this trick because of safety concerns.  NEVER tie the trigger in the on position on any PW, ever.  When you attach a nozzle to the wand, push the brass collar forward firmly until it clicks.  Otherwise you can shoot it off at seriously high velocity.Before starting, always check the pump oil level.  You can see it in the little plastic window.  Make sure the gas valve is on, water is on, and engine switch (ignition) is on.Here's my prescription for cold starting:  (1) Turn on the gas valve; set the choke to full; set the throttle for about one-third; and turn the ignition switch on.  (2) Pull the trigger on the wand to verify that water is on and flows through the unit without interruption from air-gaps.  (3) Give the rope a pull. (4) Lower the choke to one-half (center position) and pull again.  (4)If the motor has not started, pull the trigger to release pressure; leave the choke at one-half; and try again.  If, after five tries, it hasn't started, go back and give it one or two more pulls at full choke.  If it still won't start, get someone to hold the trigger down as I described above.  I've never failed to get it started.Now for a warm start, which can be trickier:  (1) Be sure the wand is attached to the hose; the wand hose is attached to the washer; the water is on; and the ignition switch is on. (2)Relieve pressure by pulling the trigger.  (3) Set throttle at half and try to start with choke off.  (4) If it doesn't start, continue pulling, advancing the choke a little more each time, always pulling the trigger in between starting attempts to reduce pressure.  (5) Get someone to hold the trigger if necessary.  As before, when someone holds the trigger, it is much easier to pull, and the engine just starts easier.  Warm starts are all about getting the choke right.  If you've fully warmed up the engine and only had it off for a few minutes, it should start on the first pull with the choke off (as long as you've remembered to turn on the ignition switch).  Even after it has run out of gas and had more put in, it normally starts back up on the first pull.Don't drag the garden hose around by just moving the washer.  It puts strain on the hose connection and it can break.When you are finished, if you've been using a cleaning chemical, be sure to run some clear water through the chemical hose to flush out the chemical injection system.One reason that homeowners' gas pressure washers tend not to last is that the homeowners don't maintain them.  In addition to changing motor oil, which you're probably used to with your lawn mower, you must change pump oil.  Pump oil is easier to change than engine oil, because it's so easy to get to.  The pump oil change interval is every 300 hours or 3 months, whichever comes first.  The manuals also have the gall to tell you to adjust the valves on the engine.  The cheaper 3000 psi washers also require this, and I seriously doubt that many owners do it.  (How many owners have a feeler gauge lying around the house?)  If you store the washer in an area that drops significantly below freezing, you're supposed to take steps to protect the pump as well; see the later paragraph on winterizing.  If this is your first washer, or if you haven't done the full maintenance in the past, please read the rest of this review before you buy.  The good news is that the pump oil is easier and less-messy to change than the motor oil.  You can find the pump oil at your local Lowes or Home Depot or at Amazon.  The synthetic Briggs and Stratton pump oil is better, but it costs double.  If you're going to use the pressure washer less than 50 hours every three months, I wouldn't use the synthetic (even though I use nothing but synthetic in my cars).  I'll briefly describe how to adjust the valves at the end of this review.Now, here's how to adjust the valves.  You'll need a 14mm wrench and a 10mm wrench or a 10mm socket with ratchet (or, best of all, an inch-pound torque wrench as I explain later).  Use a 14mm offset box-end if you have it; otherwise, you can get by with an open-end 14mm.  You'll need a feeler gauge, preferably the offset type (that has a bend on each feeler).  These are available from Autozone or Amazon.  (1) Disconnect the spark plug and remove the cylinder head cover.  It is the silver colored cover with OHV embossed on it.  You just remove the center bolt.  Try not to drop the rubber gasket on the floor.  Go ahead and peel the gasket off if it stuck to the engine.  It's easy to put it back on.  (2) Pull on the starter rope to set the piston to the top of the compression stroke.  As you pull the rope, you'll see the valves move.  When they stop moving with the valves up and the rope gets harder to pull, you're in the compression stroke.  If they start to move again, you've gone too far. You want to get close to the end of the compression stroke, which is where the valves start to move again.  Expect to have to experiment. (This is why you want the spark plug disconnected.)  (3) Now for the adjustment.  There are two nuts on top of each rocker arm.  The top nut (10mm), which may be called a locknut or a jam nut, acts to lock the lower nut (14mm) in place.  The lower nut's position determines the valve clearance. The exhaust (left) valve clearance must be adjusted to 0.20mm; the intake (right) to 0.15mm.  To adjust a valve, loosen the top nut several turns; then loosen the bottom nut a couple of turns.  You should then be able to get the feeler into the gap between the rocker arm and the valve.  Next, hand-tighten the bottom nut firmly, pressing the rocker arm onto the feeler gauge.  If you have an offset gauge, it will be easier to manipulate to be sure that it is not tilted as you tighten down.  When it is secure, it should be hard to move the gauge, but it should not be stuck tight.  Now, look carefully at the rotational position of the lower nut -- you don't want that to change as you tighten the top nut to lock it down.  You'll know if it moves, because you won't be able to pull out the feeler!  Use the 14mm wrench to hold the bottom nut in place.  Finger tighten the top nut on the bottom one.  Then take the 10mm wrench, ratchet or torque wrench, and tighten the (top) locknut down to secure the bottom nut.  If the bottom nut turns, you'll have to back up and readjust it.  This is why you need to play close attention to the rotational position of the bottom nut.  Finally, extract the feeler.  Repeat for the other valve. (4) Replace the gasket carefully.  It must seat firmly on the engine.  Then, when you put the cover on, be sure the fit is snug all around.  You don't want the gasket or the cover out of position. (5) Don't forget to reconnect the spark plug, and if the little hose came loose from the valve cover, stick it back in.It's nice to have an inch-pound (i.e., small) torque wrench for setting the locknut down on the bottom nut.  The manual calls for 7 foot pounds, which is 84 inch pounds and is not much torque.  A big torque wrench won't measure that low.  I picked up a decent inch-pound wrench on Amazon: 1/4" Drive CLICK Micrometer TORQUE WRENCH 20-200 Inch pound.  It's under $20 and works fine.  It doesn't have a distinct click, but you can see and feel the joint bend when it reaches the set torque. The torque wrench functions as a 1/4 inch drive ratchet, so you'll need a 10mm socket.  Store the wrench with torque set for 0 inch pounds.The first time you do the valves, it may take awhile to get the bottom nut to stay put while you tighten the top nut.  With a little practice, you can do the whole exercise in five minutes.  Of course, you only need to do this adjustment once a season.  If the words in the above instructions are totally foreign to you, you may want to take the PW to a small engine shop and have them do everything for you.  If you do, please go to a shop with a known, good reputation.  They all talk a good game, but I had one shop set the valves on the wrong stroke and then refuse to take the blame when the engine had no power!  I redid it properly and the power was fine.  That was when I started doing it all myself.As I mentioned previously, a pressure washer stored at sub-freezing temperatures requires protection.  There are several ways to do this, but the easiest is to use a winterizing compound.  Two of the ones out there are Dewalt DP80 and DeVilbiss Pressure Washer Pump Winterizer.  Both are in pressurized canisters with fittings that attach to the PW.  Note that these compounds are explosively volatile and must be handled with extreme care.  DP80 contains both propane and butane!  Read all warnings provided.  Here are the steps you should follow:  (1) Disconnect the high-pressure hose as well as the water hose. (2) Drain water out of hoses.  (3) Be sure ignition switch is off (allows turning over of the engine).  (4) Note that DP80 is potentially explosive containing propane and butane.  (5) Pull the starter rope a couple of times to drain some of the water.  (6)  Attach the winterizer canister to the pump where you would attach the water hose.  (7) Fill until some winterizer comes out of the high-pressure water port (where you attach the wand hose).  Turn over the engine again to distribute the winterizer.  The whole procedure takes a couple of minutes after the first time.Some manuals recommend using the winterizer anytime you are not going to use the pump for over 30 days.  The benefit is lubrication.  If you cannot find one of these winterizers, you can use RV antifreeze.  To do this, you need a 3-foot segment of garden hose.  The idea is that you attach the hose to the pump; hold the hose up; and pour the antifreeze into the hose.  Next, while holding the hose up (and with the spark plug disconnected) pull the starter rope slowly until antifreeze appears at the high pressure outlet.  Be sure to clean up any spilled antifreeze.  Pets tend to be attracted to it, and it causes kidney failure.I always use fuel stabilizer in all my small engines.  If I'm going to store one over a winter, I'll use double stabilizer.  For storage, I'll also use ethanol-free gas.I know all this service business can sound overwhelming.  Essentially all gas-powered pressure washers require these things if you want them to last.  You may be wondering if PWs are more trouble than they are worth.  Once you've accumulated the things you need, and you've done it once, it will no longer seem like a big deal.  If you are not going to do the servicing yourself, maybe you should call a shop and ask their price before you invest in a PW.  Other maintenance includes the air filter, sediment cup, fuel filter, and tank.  The manual states the service intervals for all these things, but unless you're using your washer heavily, you're likely to find that the air cleaner, fuel filter, and tank are fine and don't need servicing even yearly.  Just be sure to check them at prescribed intervals.  Remember, these reviews are supposed to tell you the things that you don't normally know before you buy.  Now you know.  Don't shoot the messenger.You may want to consider a turbo nozzle.  I'll let you do your own research on those.  Remember you'll need one that will handle 4200 psi.  DeWalt makes the one that I use.At some time you may want to consider a NorthStar Pressure Washer Surface Cleaner - 20in.  It is a perfect match to the DPW4240.  I've had my surface cleaner about 5 years.  It was good with my smaller washer, but it's fantastic with the DPW4240.I have one final recommendation.  There is a product out there called Mean Green, which beats any other cleaning chemical I've tried.  There is really no comparison.  The problem with ordering through Amazon is that it is heavy and shipping costs are prohibitive.  The best sources are the Dollar General stores, who often have promotion prices.  Don't dilute it.  Put you chemical tube right in the Mean Green jug.  The DPW4240 dilutes it to 1 part in 10, which is dilute enough.  Spray it on, leave it for several minutes and then rinse.Good luck and all the best,Tim

I'm not going to repeat the litany of features on this camera.  You know it has a Leica certified (if not Leica-built) lens.  You probably know that Leica and Zeiss make the best optics in the world.  You know it offers manual control when you need it.  I'm going to tell you my personal experience with it.I bought my zs6 immediately before going on vacation last summer (2011).  I picked the zs6 based on a careful review of the current crop of market offerings for point-and-shoots.  I also took along a full-frame DSLR and an APS-C DSLR, both current models. Both DSLRs were equipped with Zeiss zooms and other high-end zooms and primes.  I'm a very serious amateur photographer.  Since I mostly use my DSLRs around home, that trip was when I really used the zs6.  A minute ago, I was going back over the  1000-or-so pictures that I took on that trip.  I was blowing the images up to greater than 19x13 and comparing.  What I saw was this:  the little zs6 did an outstanding job.  I had lots of images worth printing on my 13x19 printer.  The resolution was sharp, and the colors were rich and vibrant.  I do a lot of tinkering in Photoshop CS5; I even use plug-ins for noise reduction, so I'm obviously picky.  The shots with the zs6 were more than good enough to print as-is.  I could easily pass them off as coming from a DSLR.  No I'm not going to say that I'm going to sell my other cameras, but I will say this:  If you're a serious photographer and you want no-apologies performance from a PnS that you can carry in your pocket, look no further.Update:  A year later, I'm still getting stellar performance.  I just carried the camera all over the Eastern Mediterranean along with a DSLR.  Once again, the little Panasonic came through.  Sharp images, excellent color, effective image stabilization, and never a problem.  This is a huge accomplishment, given the camera's size and wide zoom range.  I really appreciate the build quality too -- like a Swiss watch.  Lately, I've been tempted to buy either a Sony RX100 or a Lumix DMC-LX7 (the Sony will have better pixel resolution, but the Lumix will have MUCH better low-light capability due to lens as well as sensor differences).  Even though I'm generally a Sony person (I gave up on Nikon a long time ago), this little ZS6 may persuade me to stay with Panasonic in the point-and-shoot domain.  There is a healthy trend in point-and-shoots, which I attribute to the ever-improving cell phone cameras making low-end PnS offerings obsolete.Tim Naff

I bought this lens as a factory refurb at a Sony store.  Before buying, I tested it extensively against my Sony 16-105.  I made a series of identical shots, on a tripod, in camera RAW on an A580, going back and forth between the two lenses with the camera on full manual.  I took the camera body back to my rented condo (in Destin FL), and compared on my computer, working strictly in RAW (avoiding any sharpening by the camera or by my software and avoiding jpeg artifacts).  I zoomed in to identical magnification at identical original focal lengths at identical f-numbers.I honestly didn't want it to be better than my beloved 16-105, just because I didn't want to spend the money, and I'd rather have the wider zoom range on hand when needed.  The bad news for me was that it out-performed the 16-105 in sharpness and in color.  The improvement wasn't stunning, but it was there when you looked for it.  Did I have to look hard to see it?  Actually, I did have to look very closely to see it, but it was always there.  Please understand that I know and understand what constitutes good optical performance.  I have the Zeiss 24-70, the G70-300, and the 50 F4, as well as the legendary Minolta 17-35.  (In my film days I shot Hassleblad and Nikon as well as testing Leica-M.)One reviewer said the vignetting was a problem.  I can see slight darkening in the corners on my A580, but I wouldn't notice if I weren't looking for it.  The same reviewer said he could see a slim B+W 62mm filter.  I have a slim B+W XS-PRO nano 62mm, and I see no evidence of the filter if I screw the filter in all the way without tightening.One reviewer on Amazon said the build quality was poor, and I've read that complaint from others on the web.  I'd rate the build quality as no better than the 16-105, but not nearly as good as the 24-70, which is in a class by itself anyway.  This lens is far, far, far better than the A580 kit lens in build quality, which is the worst I've ever encountered, although the kit lens optics are quite respectable.  Zeiss put the money in the optics on this lens.  Did Zeiss actually manufacture the lens, or did Sony (or some third party) build it to Zeiss specs?  I have no idea.  You can bet Zeiss wouldn't let it go out with their logo if it weren't to their specs.I bought the lens after doing the test, and I'll tell you why.  I was thinking that I'd get an A77 when they came out.  The A77's high-pixel-density sensor makes demands on optics.  I didn't want to pass up the opportunity to be better prepared for the A77 while I could get the lens at a bargain price.Is it worth the money that you'd have to pay?  Compared to the 16-105, I'd have to say it's a wash.  You give up some zoom range, and in return you get a bit better optical performance and a bit more aperture at 80mm.  Some have said, "What is Zeiss coming to?"  I say that Zeiss is giving you exactly what you pay for.  This is a very low price for a Zeiss lens.Is this the right lens for you?  Should you opt for the 16-105 or maybe the Sony 18-250?  The prices are all about the same.  I have all three lenses.  They have similar vignetting characteristics.  The 18-250 has more barrel distortion owing to its extreme zoom range, but that's correctable with software.  The Sony 18-250, while not having the sharpness or chromatic excellence of this lens, sets a new standard super-zoom optical quality.  If I were only going to have one lens for anything other than the A77 or A67, I'd probably want the 16-105 as a good compromise between optical quality and versatility.  If I were going for the A66/77, I'd get the Zeiss, both for the sharpness and for the slightly wider aperture.  (The A66/77 translucent mirror costs about a half-stop worth of light, but DxO says the sensor surprisingly seems to lose nothing significant in low-light performance.)I don't think you'll go wrong with this lens or one of the Sony alternatives.  I didn't give five stars, because of the build quality, but the build quality is more than good enough.  Good luck with your decision!Tim Naff

The build quality of this device looks great.  The wood knobs are attractive.  It almost looks too good for an office cube wall.  The design is good in all respects but one.  You get two brackets, each of which allows adjustment, so that the adjustment ranges of the two brackets overlap.  All good so far.  The problem with my sample is that the adjustment slips if you put anything with any weight on it.  There is a plastic, strain-loaded mechanism on top that is supposed to hold the adjustment in place.  On mine, it is far too weak.  I couldn't hang a couple of lightweight umbreallas and a light-weight jacket on it without it sliding apart and falling on the floor.  No way it would hold the weight of a winter coat.  The only way I could secure it was to wrap a wire around it to hold down the little black button that you're supposed to lift up when you adjust it.  It no longer looks cool, and it's a lot to pay for a very defective product.  Maybe my sample is just a bad one.  You now know everything I know.  Good luck!**Update**  I just upgraded this review from one star to two.  As I said before, the problem was with the adjustment mechanism.  What I finally did was adjust it to the width of my cube and glue it permanently for that width.  Problem solved.  If you are only going to use it at one width, there is a solution to the loose mechanism.

Parallels lets you run Windows apps right alongside your Mac apps.  You can swap data back and forth, hassle-free.  I found the program to be stable and reliable running OS X Lion as the Primary OS with Win7 inside as the Guest OS on a virtual machine (VM). I have not found significant problems with slow performance, but read on.There are several ways to set things up.  You can choose your Guest OS from a selection including Windows and Linux.  You can run your Guest OS out of a VM based in a Boot Camp partition, or simply out of a pure VM.  Once set up, you can run your VM in several modes.  These include full-screen (covering your Primary Mac OS X desktop and making it temporirily inaccessible), in a window on your Mac OS desktop, or fully integrated in Coherence mode with your Guest OS apps running in their own frames, just as they would on a normal Windows machine or Mac.  In the latter case, your Windows apps have the look, feel, and accessibility of Mac apps (without the task bar, of course).  These modes are changeable on the fly, without any rebooting of anything.Regardless of how you choose to run your configuration, you should be aware of some things that can cost money.  First, you must have the Guest installation software.  For example,if you want to run Win7 as your Guest OS as I did, you'll have to buy Win7.  For x64, the cheapest option is the Home Premium downloadable version.  There is a comparable x32 version.  The package says it's supposed to be shipped with a new machine, but I had no problem installing.  If you install it in a Boot Camp partition, you'll have to register it twice. You may have to register by phone the second time, but don't worry, phone registration will work, even if you have to register twice.  Just tell Microsoft its only on one computer.  You may want to buy a virus and spyware scanner for your Windows OS, since Windows is always more vulnerable than a Mac.  Finally, and this is subtle but important, you'll need to take a hard look at your hardware resources.  When you set up Parallels, you will be prompted to specify how much system RAM the Guest OS will be allowed to use.  Only you know how much you can allocate.  If you have 4 GB of RAM on your machine, you might want to specify 1.5 or so.  I have 12 GB (RAM is cheap), and I specified 4 GB.  Also, there is the question of hard-drive space if you use a Boot Camp partition.  You should be able to figure that one out for yourself; just don't forget to think it through carefully before you start, because changing is a bit of a hassle (which has nothing to do with Parallels).  There is no free lunch here, if you want to make one computer into two, you may have to beef it up.  If you create a situation where either your Primary or your Guest is starved for resources, performance will obviously suffer.  I bought my extra RAM from crucial.com, and I wasn't disappointed.  You may also want to check out Kingston.Here's what happens with your RAM usage.  Say you allocate 4 GB of RAM for your Guest OS.  When you boot the OS, enough RAM will be "wired" to the Guest to allow the Guest to join the party, but it will probably start by using less than 1 GB.  Then, if you progressively open more and more memory-users in the Guest OS, you will progressively "wire" more and more RAM for the Guest, making it unavailable to the Primary OS.  The Guest will not "wire" more than you originally allocated.  If you close the memory-users, the RAM is not "unwired"; it remains dedicated to the Guest OS, even though the Guest may not use it again.  Everything starts over when you reboot.  It is easy to watch all this unfold using the Activity Monitor app in OS X Utilities.When nothing is going on on the VM, there is no tax on the processor cores.  Win7 probably doesn't run quite as fast in Parallels as in a dedicated Boot Camp partition, but I haven't made measurements to prove it.  When a Win program like Acrobat reads files from a Mac-formatted drive, it probably reads them a bit more slowly than from a native Windows format due to the translation layer.  I am running an i5 processor.  I run some memory-hog, CPU-intensive applications such as video rendering packages, so I pay attention to these things.  If I'm doing something really intense in Win7, I may run dedicated out of the Boot Camp partition, bypassing Parallels altogether.  In the near future, I may also increase my RAM to 16 GB, even though the last 4 GB-worth of upgrade will cost as much as the first 8.  Unless you're doing something similarly intense, you can probably just stay with 4 GB total.My personal configuration illustrates the adaptability of Parallels. My i5 iMac has a 250 GB solid-state drive (SSD) as the boot drive plus a 1 TB hard-disk drive (HDD).  I put Win7 in a 200GB Boot Camp partition on the HDD to conserve the limited SDD space and simultandously give Win7 room to breathe.  Parallels, itself, must go on the boot drive, so it is on the SDD, but configured this way, it doesn't suck up space from the space-limited, but lightning quick, SDD.  With this arrangement, I can always choose to run in Win7 dedicated mode using Boot Camp with OS X turned off and Parallels bypassed completely.  Both OSs have access to a Mac-formatted 3 TB Firewire-800 external drive.  (Too bad there are no Thunderbolt peripherals yet.)  I can create a Word document in the Mac version of Word, place it on the external drive, and open it in Word for Windows from the same, Mac-formatted drive.  All of this just works.  It's a testament to the flexibility that Parllels makes possible.  Parallels will afford you the same flexibility.One suggestion to the people at Parallels is that they come up with a cleaner way to switch modes.  It's imminently doable, but there's no switch or dial located in one place.  Also, what gives with the check box at shut-down that says reopen Windows when you log back in?  It doesn't reopen Windows when I log back in after a shut-down.I don't care what the books say or what the ads say; file sharing and printer sharing between Macs and PCs is hit or miss when working over a network through anything less than a dedicated server.  (I actually got an Apple Care "Genius" to admit that.)  It is particularly true when a PC tries to directly access something belonging to a Mac.  Macs, with their layers of extra security, don't share anything well, unless it's with another Mac.  The parallels solution comes as close as you can get today to resolving those issues, and, compared to the alternatives, the solution has been elegant for me.In summary, let's face it:  it's tough to make the Win and Mac OSs play nicely together.  Parallels has them playing in the same sandbox.  They aren't fighting over toys or throwing sand.  They're holding hands and smiling.  This is one of those rare instances of sophisticated third-party software that really works without problems.  As one who has to deal with the vagaries (vulgarities?) of software development on a daily basis, I'm impressed.Tim Naff

This review was originally about Mac issues, but see the update at the end if you're a PC person.  I **Update:  I finally reached a knowledgeable person at HP, who informed me that they don't have a WiFi driver for Lion yet (29 Aug 2011).**When installing this printer on a Mac, everything is not automatic as it is on a PC, which requires no CD.  The Mac instructions say to use the CD or download the latest installation file.  My installation attempted to use the current (Aug 27, 2011) installation package downloaded from HP.  It was for OS X, and not specifically for Lion.  Online installation instructions differ from the quick-start guide (for Mac) that came with the printer. The quick-start guide states that, when installing from the CD, you will be prompted as to whether you want to use WiFi.  (Installation also requires that you temporarily connect to the computer with USB.)  Running the downloaded package, there is no prompt.  The printer automatically installs as a USB device and shows up as an active printer. If you want to use a USB cable there is no issue.One reason for choosing the printer was that it had WiFi.  I found a procedure on the HP site for installing on the Mac.  The procedure failed.  I called HP and they gave me the Apple Care number!  **As I said above, I called again and reached a more knowledgeable person, who said there is no Lion WiFi driver yet.  He said to go to HP.com and sign up for e-mail notification of driver updates.  Based on the competance of the guy I spoke to, I'm raising my rating from two to three stars.The printer works fine in USB mode.  WiFi is the problem.I have used cheap HP B&W laser printers before.  They tend to be quick and reliable, and they are relatively reasonable on toner cost.  My complaint is HPs unwillingness to keep the installation software and drivers current.  I have a 4-year-old model that has been rock solid.  HP does not even have a Lion driver for it, and they have no intention of ever providing one.  Bottom line:  if you're a Mac user who likes to keep up with the latest OS, your HP printer may have a limited lifetime due to HP policy.  I'm sure that HP will eventually provide what is necessary for Lion WiFi installation.  But the next printer model change may spell the end of Mac support for the discontinued model.  This is not, BTW, the case for PC drivers, which are kept current much longer.  Don't expect a "no customer left behind" policy from HP.**Update**  I now have two of these and have them installed on Win7, Vista, and XP machines as well as Mac Lion (still via USB).  The printers are all working well.  I have lately run into problems with HP not keeping drivers current for Win7.  They have a work-around:  Run driver software in Vista SP2 compatibility mode.  When you do that, you get in trouble connecting via LAN to printers shared from other computers, even when doing PC to PC.  The  bottom line is this:  HP makes the most reliable, long-lasting printer hardware around, but it doesn't matter because they don't keep the software current.  You may be out of luck when the next OS rolls around.

If you've never used a computer before, this book should be perfect for you.  If you've never used a Mac before, it will be very good.  If you've used early Mac operating systems, but not OS X, it will still be quite good.  If you already know earlier versions of OS X very well, you won't find a lot here to help you.  There is no section that summarizes changes from earlier versions.  There is no consistent identification of OS or app features that are new with Lion.  This book is generally about OS X, and it is not an in-depth treatment.  If you want in-depth, get the Portable Genius book (which was not out for Lion when I did this review).  Most of the book's space is devoted to the apps included with the OS.  There are some exceptions, such as the page on Mission Control, which is new to Lion.  There is also a very nice treatment of file sharing and printer sharing. On the other hand, there's a whole page on how to save a document!So why in the world did I give it four stars?  Even though I've been working with computers, including software development, since the days when a single computer filled a small room, I'm relatively new to Macs.  And this book does do a creditable job of an overview of the OS and the apps.  Yes, it's very "Dick and Jane."  You have to try not to be offended when it tells you things that any near-computer-illiterate would know.  You have to scan each page looking for nuggets.  The nuggets are there ... they really are.  They are easy to find, because a huge amount of effort has gone into creating a good visual presentation. If you are not familiar with an app, you can go through the appropriate section of the book in just a few seconds and save yourself some trial and error.In summary, the book is well organized and designed to make information easy to find and to absorb.  If you're computer literate enough to be reading this review, I can't imagine how you could find anything in the book that would be too difficult for you.  It is a simple book, but that is partly because the author does a good job of simplifying.  The book falls right in line with Apple's own philosophy of simplicity.  Even so, this is not necessarily a book for the simple.All the best,Tim

Jay Winik has written a very good, intense,  readable  and  poignant book about the year 1944. The main part of it focuses on the Holocaust and the failure of FDR and his administration to respond to this horrible vrome perpetrated by the Nazi hordes. Did Roosevelt know about the Holocaust? Yes, he did. Did he do anything about it? Very little. Another question related to this aspect is about the failure of the Allies to bomb Auschwitz and the other extermination-cum-concetration camps. The reasons for this controversial decision not to bomb them  vary. And this is the accusation Mr Winik pins on the shoulder of Roosevelt.One also must remember that the State Department was riddled with Antisemites and Breckenridge Long, Mentioned in the book,  was just one of them. Perhaps the problem lay with Roosevelt's character and policies of a juggler, as he preferred to call himself. The establishment of the WRBdid very little to alleviate the plight of those unfortunate victims who were trying to find shelter.Of course the book tells about many other events which were extremely fateful for the 1939-1945 period. Operation Overlord, the Battle of the Bulge and the liberation of Paris  are among those discussed here. In addtion, there is a very detailed descrition about FDR's health issues- issues which in many ways explain why he acted the way he did in his decision-making process.This book reads like a suspense first rate thriller, and, although there is nothing original in it, I awarded it five stars for the style and its masterful storytelling.

If  I have to nominate one book as the book of the year 2015, this is going to be my choice. It is different from the other  thousands of books that have been written so far about WW2, because it examines in great depth how the German people reacted to the war in its various stages. The war was far from being popular in Germany when it broke out.On the other hand , there were millions who readily embraced Hitler and his policies. There are many questions which are raised in this book, like: why did the German people continue to fight after 1943 , when almost all the Nazi leadership thought the war was lost?  How did the  beliefs, hopes and dreams of the German manifest themselves throughout the war?This the author does by incorporating many untapped so far sources , most of them belonging to people who wrote diaries, commentaries, letters, notes, tec. They were soldiers, teachers, housewives, cabinet-makers, bank clerks, Jews, Protestants and many more.What stands out in this brilliant masterpiece is also the way the churches reacted to the Nazi regime and the various points of view which  were represented by the many clerics. It is a compelling and superb book which will show you some points that you never thought of about WW2.This book is a must for everyone !!!

This is a comprehensive one-volume history of FDR . Alonzo Hamby has succeeded in telling his readers- in twenty-six chapters- about the strong and weak points of FDR. This he has managed to do after a serious effort invested in researching this book, showing especailly FDR's monumental achievements in his foreign policy by demonstrating how he accomplished them.  Roosevelt, according to Professor Hamby, has generated intense emotions."Millions of Americans worshipped him; millions of others could quite literally not bear to speak his name". However, as an American aristocrat born into priviledge, he learned the habit of command from his father and he had also inherited a sense of destiny to lead and strive for greta goals, first as a socially conscious  reformer, then as a world statesman. He displayed courage and determination, whether in coping with the handicap of polio, facing the challenges of the Depression, or dealing with the terrible urgencies of global war. Hamby shows in the final part of this volume how FDR managed to cope qith all the hardships he faced during the last months of WW2 and why he ought to be considered perhaps the greatest American President in our modern times.

The main idea in this new book is that  Russian counterintelligence proved so successful that in many ways and times it surprised theiir American counterpart, the CIA. This was especially relevant in the 1960s -1970s. The weak side of Russian intelligence has been throughout the years the technological one. Human intelligence had to make up for this and for communications intelligence.The eleven chapters which are to be found here are arranged chronoligically, starting with the Cheka and ending with the demise of the Soviet Union. One of the best chapters discusses the extent to which Stalin's terroe crippled the abilities of Russian intelligence . The result was in the total failure to graps the Nazi threat. One terrible result of it was the loss of 27 million Russians.Then the history moves into the Cold War era, when Western intelligence crippled Soviet secret communications, but not for long, since  the Cambridge Five made up for this. It was Khrushchev's denunciation of Stalin which shifted the emphasis towards counterlintelligence, while military intelligence and cryptography hastened to catch up and reduce the growing Anglos-American advantage in orbital satellites  and high-technology interception of ground communications. Image intelligence was of much importance because Khrushchev's vaunted superioirity in strategic missiles was a bluff.There are many examples in the following chapters showing  the modus operandi of the many known and also unknown agents that we sent to the West.  Yuri Drozdov was one of them. He ran many illegals from the S Directorate  and was also successful in penetrating the West German intelligence .Another agent was Yuri Totrov, who served in many countries . He was extremely successful in running counterintelligence operations. The result was that in 1980, his directorate unmasked 168 CIA  officers and 77 agents in the Soviet Union. At Langley, the joke was that Totrov was "the shadow head of personnel at CIA".This book is another good and important addition to the history of intelligence and the role it played in the history of the twentieth century, particularly during the Cold War, where many pieces of the puzzle concerning the shadow wars still remain behind closed archives.

This superbly researched book, based  on new documents and 100 interviews, is about one of the Cambridge Five spies who were in the service of Stalin. Though I cannot agree with the conclusion of the author, I do nevertheless recommend  this book from the bottom of my heart because it is, so far, the best on Guy Burgess. Mr Lownie has invested more than 20 years researching it and the result is astonishing. He shows to what extent the English society was totally degenerate during the 1930-1950 period. The graphic descriptions of Burgess'  male conquests , combined with his bedroom activities, will make you- as it made me- sick, yet this was the reality under which Burgess was operating then. The whole English establishment was extremely naive regarding Russia and the result was that people like Burgess could spy almost everywhere and on everyone. Nobody had suspected that he and his fellows from Cmbridge could actually have been in the service of Comrade Stalin.Burgess was the most important, complex and fascinating of "The Cambridge Spies" all brilliant men recruited in the 1930s to betray their country to Russia. The mystery still remains: why did he agree to work for a foreign power, of which he knew very little, as a student, and continue to serve it untill his death some thirty years later? Why did he leave behind those whom he loved, including his mother, to whom he was devoted, for a lonely exile in Russia? Mr Lownie brings out the many and conflicting characteristics of this man who was full of paradoxes. Add the fact that Burgess was a figure that  could not have been more British with his Eton and Cambridge education, hiis many memberships of London clubs, expensive clothes, love of British literature, and his final wish to be buried in Britain.Another excellent part of this book is about Burgess in Moscow, where he spent the rest of his 62 years after running away from England. This is a very big contribution to the role spies had before and  during the Cold War and should be read by buffs and academics alike.

An endless number of books have been written about Henry Kissinger's foreign policy. Greg Grandin's excellent book proves again and again to what extent Kissinger should be tried as a war criminal for committing the most odious crimes during the period when he served both as the national anvisor and the State Secretary of the Nixon administration.After offering the reader a general overview of Kissinger's theories about history and statecraft, the book centers on Kissinger's crimes. The most notorious one was the decision to bomb Cambodia-an act which can count as one of the most brutal military operations ever conducted in US history. According to one study, the USA dropped 790000 cluster bombs on Vietnam and Cmabodia and between 1969-1973 around 500000 tons of bombs fell on Cambodia alone. Add this to another country, Laos, which was more stunningly hit by US bombers. Laos turned out to be the most heavily bombed country in history-courtesy of Nixon andHenry Kissinger. Defoliation and the use of Agent Orange caused more significant damage. This is not the end of the story. As many as 30 % of the bombs dropped by the USA did not detonate and today, some 80 million unexploded  cluster bombs are hidden "below a thin layer of soild and packed with ball bearings".The justification for these crimes was that the bombings were meant  to destroy the sanctuaries which gave shelter to the supporters of North Vietnam-an argument which has no real foundation.Then, Grandin book gives a second catalogue of crimes committed and sanctioned by Kissinger. On the menu there were the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.To quote again from the book, "what is certain is that individually each of Kissinger's Middle East initiatives-banking on despots, inflating the shah, providing massive amounts of aid to security forces that tortured and terrorized citizens, pumping up the US defense industry with petrodollars, which in turn spurred a Middle East arms race financed by high oil prices, emboldening Pakistan's intelligence service, nurturing Islamist fundamentalism, playing Iran and the Kurds off Iraq" and many more things hust show to what extent Kissinger has been responsible  to create a Middle East into "a knot that even Alexander's sword can't cut".Intrigue,secrecy and lies were the daily basis upon which Kissinger forged his foreign policy, supporting the most corrupt dictatorships in South America.One of the results of this perverted policy was the birth of the Khmer Rouge which was a result of the inferno that the American policy did much to create. Kissinger mocked the principle of sovereignty. According to Kissinger, Barack Obama's drone strikes are a carbon copy of his policies.This book should be in everyone's library and should be carefully read and reread. It  serves as a reminder of the fact that lunatics  and war criminals have not disappearded from history and are still with us. Kissinger is one of them.

Gordon Corera's new book is about computers and spying. It all started at the beginning of WW1 and since then, the computer ahs been engaged in the world of the  shadows game. The USA and Britain led the revolution in this field, but there were other secret services, such as the STASI which were suspicious of the new device and the result was in a 100-kilometer archive in Est Germany, which had details on most East Germans.According to Markus Wollf, computers could be hacked easily.The book has some interesting episodes in the history of cyber-espionage and many technical details about the way computers play the Great Game. All in all, it is an easy journalistic read.

In this exceptional short but very important book, Stefan Ihrig has highlighted a neglegted aspect, namely the influence Ataturk had on the Nazis and Hitler. In six brilliantly and deeply researched chapters, the author shows to what extent the German far right of Weimar and Hitler have been attracted by the deeds and policies of Kemal Ataturk. Turkey was, in addition to Italy, a model which was to be emulated  in various fields such as authoritarian rule, secular modernization, and the political utility of genocide. In Hitler's eyes, the right way for Germany to rise from its ashes after WW1 was a la Turca. It was Ataturk who defied the Western powers to seize control of the government, and he modeled the Munich putsch on Ataturk's rebellion in Ankara. For the Nazis, such as Goebbels and others, Ataturk was the "star in the darkness". Nazi Germany had a lot to learn from the way the Turks had dealt with the various minorities, especially from the way they tried to solve the Armenian problem, which would be the basic platform upon which Hitler and his other bunch of criminals would implement the Final Solution of the Jews.Thsi is a very gripping book and will not be surpassed for many years to come.

This is a very interesting book on a very exciting subject, namely: how the Norwegians succeeded to dupe the Nazis and smuggle out Norway's gold to England and later to the USA and Canada. The book has some flaws and they have to do with  the poor style of writing and the lack of maps. However, it is well researched andis, all in all, a reasonable read.

In what seems to be one of the best-ever written biographies of President Nixon, Evan Thomas wanted to understand who the real Nixon was. In addition, as Mr Thomas writes, the question he kept asking was "whether Nixon could see the true Nixon".  Nixon's strenghts were his weaknesses, and vice versa. The drive that propelled him also crippled him. The underdog's sensitivity that made him farsighted also blinded him. He wanted to show that he was hard because he felt soft. He learned how to be popular because he felt rejected. He was the lonely everyman to the end.In this fascinating and gripping biography, the author peels away all the layers of this complex man who eventually would become the 37th President of the USA, showing the so many contradictions of his personality. To his merit one should mention the detente with the USSR, the establishment of diplomatic relations with China and the ending ot the Vietnam War. Watergate was Nixon's own graveyard as a result of his hubris.This is a very insightful history and biography of a man who always showed optimism, written in a very dynamic style. You will enjoy each and every page of this book, which is based on original research. Kudos, Mr Thomas!

According to Dr Munro price, the fall of Napoleon started during the brief but intense years of 1813-1814 .As he notes right at the very beginning of the book, Waterloo overshadowed these previous years, however, 1814 was the year when Napoleon was deprived of hs throne and his legitimacy. Napoleon's fate was decided in a number of battles and the most famous ones were at Bautzen,Dresden, Leipzig and Laon .Why the French Emperor refused to compromise and accept his opponent's peace terms is the key is sues discussed in the book. Was it arrogance? Was it obstinacy? Was it his hubris?In trying to answer these questions, the author used many untapped sources, like the papers of Caulaincourt, Napoleon's foreign minister and many new unpublished letters of Matternich.Other sources are stil awaiting to be discovered, most of whom are in private hands.The book comes in fourteen chapters and each one shows a different chronoligical aspect of those afore-mentioned years.The best chapter is, in my view, the one describing The Battle of Nations which drove Napoleon's armies back to the Rhine. The next year,1814, forced Napoleon to abdicate and to be exiled to Elba, although after some time-for one hundred days-he regained his throne , but this was a doomed adventure which sealed his fate.There are many detailed maps here showing the many and various military moves during the battles, thus enabling the reader to better grasp the events mentioned before. There are also abundant photos and plates and a long bibliographical list.Although Dr Price mentions that public opinion and the voices of the masses were one of his main aims  to be told about in his book, this does not unfortunately happen. What we get mostly is a history of vox populi through the great statesmen of those years, Metternich and Talleyrand.This is an important book which attempts to also understand the complex personality of Napoleon and also tries to analyze his motives, character and the reasons for his failure. Napoleon finished his life in utter isolation and tedium and he became prone to depression compounded by many health issues. On 2 May 1821 he slipped into semi-consciousnees and died two days later. He was 51.

Paul Ham's new book is a gem among the so many books published on WW1. This war killed, wounded and maimed 37 million people and it plunged the world into the bloodiest conflict mankind has witnessed so far.The book has four sections. The first one  is called "The Tyranny of the Past' and deals with the historical events which dominated European politics up to the beginning of the 20th century.The second part, called "Wilful Blindness and Blinkered Vision" touches Schlieffen's plan and the problem of the minorities in the Balkans.In my view, the last two parts named consecutiverly "In the Salons of Power" and "On the Ground -1914" are the best ones. Here, Mr Ham is giving the reader a panoramic view of the things and affairs which happened on the eve of the war. Contrary to what Professor Clark has written, the leaders of their respective countries "were not sleepwalkers into war", but they chose war deliberately. This was the year when the world ended for millions of men, women and children. As Mr Ham writes, "It was the end of certainty. It was the end of many soldiers's faith in the propaganda of the holy triumvirate of God, King and Country, of lyrical paeans to heroism and self-sacrifice, and all the shibboleths of tired old regimes...which they  and their families would soon tear down as monstrous lies. Many families were with Kipling, who wrote, on the death of his son in 1916: 'If any question why we died/Tell them because our fathers lied".This was the year when ancient regimes and monarchies that had ruled Europe started their  slide into oblivion.The war Europe's autocracies waged to preserve their regimes in the end destroyed them all. Revolution and reform swepf Germany, Russia and Austro-Hungary.As to the question of responsibility, Mr Ham makes no bones about the culpability of Germany which pushed Autro-Hungary to begin this horrible conflict. The famous assassination  committed by Gavrilo Princip was the excuse and Ferdinand's death just triggered the July crisis that hastened the outbreak of the war. It accelerated forces that were already in motion, which would have culminated in war in any case-unless the men in power behaved differently, i.e. sought to mediate and understand one another, and tried the diplomatic arts of peace-keeping. The leaders were wide awake, sentient decision-makers who knew exactly waht was happening and were aware of the repercussions of their actions. Some went willingly to war and some (France, Britain) accepted it with complacent resignation.This although the fact that European leaders later claimed that war was inevitable, ordained by God or Darwin or other forces. Every major European nation had a share of responsibility for the war. Thus, the Great War was an  avoidable, unnecessary exercise in collective stupidity and callousness, launched by profoundly flawed and unintelligent men, most of whom were neither fit nor trained but bred into rule, and who saw the world as a Darwinian jungle in which Teuton, Slav and their Latin and Anglo-Saxon allies were predestined to bash each other's brains out until the fittest won.What make this book outstanding is the fact that it is highly readable, bringing out the voices of the common people, and this to a great extent. It also shows the many angles and voices  of almost every significant event during 1914, and it includes many new sources as well as older ones, creating a new synthesis about the conflict. It also includes nine very detailed maps to make it easier to the reader to follow events on the various 1914 fronts and also has a detailed bibliographical list. The forte of this wonderful book is the simple yet rich and analytical language it was written and I definitely recommend it.

This book proves nothing. After reading it, I am more than convinced about the fact that after death there is nothing.The author seems to have made use of the fact that he is a respected neurosurgeon, although he himself has a black sheet on his personal file .Those reviewers who previously wrote about this point were right and there is no use reiterating their words.But the issue is not Eben's credentials but his credibility, which can be dismissed in a few seconds.A certain chemical is released into the body during the condition which was Eben's disease and it is the explanation for his hallucinatory dreams. The sad fact is that we who are mortals are still looking for some consolation afetr the death of our beloved ones, and this is not new. Humans have sought to delude themselves since the very beginning of history in this respect and Eben is not different.  He has just written another book under the cloak of being a scientist .It would suffice to read the antidote on this written by Professor Richard Dawkins in order to understand to what extent a neurosurgeon is trying to fool innocent readers into making them believe in nonsense. Please save you hard earned money for serious and intelligent books.

Jan Swafford's biography is a masterpiece/ He writes in a panoramic style about everything which concerned Beethoven, one of the greatest titans of music. The physical and mental suffering caused by his deafness-probably as a result of some lead poisoning-would mount a sustained assault on Beethoven's sense of discipline and duty, his gigantic ambition. Nevertheless, Beethoven was destined both for triumph and anguish. This genius would undergo many hard times in his life, yet his solitude  and art would be his best remedies, according to Professor Swafford.This extremely long biography inludes many details and is packed with some original insights  on almost every page. The first three quarters are much more dynamically written and my only reservation about this monumental  oeuvre is that sometimes the author dwells a bit too much on Beethoven's relations with his brothers. As one writer penned, Beethoven "wanted to appear as a new man in each work, even at the risk of making an occasional blunder, or of sometimes being scarcely understood by even a few people. He did not understand people and for approximately the last fifteen years not even their words, and as he did not understand them, neither did they understand him, except in his musical notes".Indeed, Beethoven  had suffered over his years from deafness the most horrible affliction for any musician), colitis,  rheumatism, typhus, skin disorders, abcesses, a variety of infections, inflammatory degeneration of the arteries, jaundice and at the end chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis of the liver.He was, in the eyes of Grillparzer,"the greatest of all".This compulsory book shows  Beethoven's genius and his many flawed sides. It is a most comprehensive biography , written in a lively style, and will be unsurpassed for many years. Bravissimo, Mr. Swafford!

In contrast  to Peter Watson's previous books- and I must admit I really liked most of them tremendously -this volume can be described  as a total  and big bore. It looks as if Mr. Watson has accumulated a number of pertinent authors and summed up their ideas, without having anything new to say about this important and controversial subject. Save your hard-earned money for a better author.

The Nazi  ideology of  "Geomedizin"-that illness was as irrefutable and inevitable result of culture- had a significance for the Jews and other peoples in Eastern Europe. The louse, carrier of typhus, was a symbol of the Jew :a filthy, parasitic, blood-sucking disease element which had penetrated the German nation long ago. If so, according to Julius Streicher, the infamous editor of 'Der Sturmer', the Jew as a bacillus and a plague is not a human being but rather an enemy, a criminal and a disease carrier, thus he must be eliminated.In addtion, Hitler and his bunch of criminals were afraid that typhus might be a serious hindrance which could stay in the way of achieving their dream of mastering Europe. Because the disease plagued the Nazi troops in Eastern Europe, the Nazis were desperately looking for a solution.For this they turned toRudolf Weigl, the Polish scientist who had a world reputation thanks to the fact that it was he who succeeded in creating a vaccine which was effective against the disease.In February 1940, no less a figure than Nikita Khrushchev visited Weigl at his laboratory, offering him  a job at the Soviet Academy of Medicine in Moscow. Weigl declined.After the departure of the Russians from Lwow in 1941, the city where Weigl was working in, the city  became a "Hobbeian theater, every man for himself under a ruthless occupant, the Nazis.Typhus was rampant there, and Weigl even considered leaving the city, but eventually decided to stay.It is estimated that at least 3000 people were working for his institute, which became a tool of deceiving the Nazis and a shelter for many victims of the Nazis. The tens of millions of lice used in the vaccine during the war descended from a cross between lice gathered from the clothing of Russians in Austrian POW camps during WW1, and an Ethiopian variety that Weigl had obtained in Addis Ababa. Wegl employed doomed scientists,writers, doctors and others and thus saved their lives. In addition, he and his workers shipped ton of a weakened serum to the Wehrmacht.Among those saved was another scientist,  the Jewish immunologist Ludwick Fleck, who was sent to Buchenwald. Fleck was forced to create  and re-create a typhus vaccine  under the direction of Erwin Ding, who was called "a Dummkopf who earned a dissertation only on the basis of his services for the party". Being so, Fleck and his colleagues produced two types of the vaccine: one that had no value and was perfectly harmless, and went to the front; and a second type, in very small quantities, that was efficatious and was used in special cases for the comrades who worked at Buchenwald.All this continued until March 1945.Weigl died in 1957 of a heart attack, while Fleck immigrated to Israel.The book is based on many new and untapped documents as well as many interviews with some relevant persons and is a good read,original and well written, although somehow  in a dry language. All in all, I recommend it. very much.

Operation "Valuable Fiend" was conceived at the end of the forties in the previous century. Its purpose was to overthrow the Communists from power in Albania. By doing so, it would signify the first open revolt behind the Iron Curtain and would encourage other anti-Communist elements in the Soviet bloc, would knock out Kremlin's sense of security and show the Soviets that the West could match in kind their tactics for supporting guerrillas and subversive activities in their area of influence. It would also save the situation in Greece by cutting off Albania as one of the remaining  two sources of support for the Communist guerrillas, the other source, Bulgaria, would be intimidated and cutting off the flow of men and supplies through their borders for fear of risking a similar fate.Mr. Lulushi has written a splendidly researched book on one of the less famous episodes of the  CIA's Cold War covert actions. He comes to remedy Nicholas Bethell's book "Betrayed" on the same subject, by examining previously untapped sources, dismissing almost totally Kim Philby's role in the whole affair.Who were the key players in this operation? Where did they come from and how did their background influence their choices and actions durind the operation? What happened to them afterward? What did the agency learn -or not learn- from this failure?These are only some points discussed widely in this book, which incorporates new material as well as interviews with sons and daughters of some key figures in this operation, which was the first one of its kind in the history of the CIA.Unfortunately for the West, the whole operation was one of total failure for many reasons, as stated in the book. The CIA and  MI6 did not accomplish the goals they set, because the Sigurimi, the Secret Albanian  Police,and the KGB turned the tables on them and used and killed or captured  agents for propaganda purposes for years to come.. The Albanians who took part in the affair suffered terrible losses. Dozens perished, and several more who were captured spent the rest of their lives in Communist prisons or hard labour camps. The regime uprooted their families and persecuted hem for decades, generation after generation.Operation Valuable Fiend never developed beyond the reconnaissance and intelligence-gathering stage.The result of this experiment showed it was extremely hard to achieve the goal of overthrowing a Communist regime. Rollling back the Iron Curtain was too hard. Other operations, such as those in Guatemala and Iran were far more successful, but had eventually turned out to be preludes to disasters, since Guatemala sank into a civil war, while the Shah of Iran was run out of power in 1979.The Albanian affair ended in 1954, when the CIA virtually abandoned all infiltration operations in Albania and dismissed the handful of Albanian agents still on its rolls in Greece.The book, which has eighteen chapters, each one devoted to another sub-topic, includes maps and many hitherto unpublished photos. Highly recommended!

This is one of the best volumes written about the Great War. It concerns the diplomatic efforts invested by the various policy makers during the crisis. This is ( only ) diplomatic history at its best, written by a master historian, who looks and examines many issues from a new perspective, especially the German points of view.  Germany is the  main culprit , although others are also criticized for being responsible for the outbreak of the war. Although this is not an easy read , the book is definitely highly recommended.

The main idea behind this book is simple: religion was the driving force behind WW1. This view is extremely wrong and it distorts the real motives which were responsible for the unleashing of the war. Mr Jenkins ignores all the various aspects such as the diplomatic entanglements, the imperialistic factors, the clashes between the various ideologies and many more things and offers the reader a minimal view , supported by a limited number of clergymen and what they thought  about the war. True, there were religious manifestations and characteristics which took place during 1914-1918. But to claim that the war was a religious crusade, as the subtitle suggests, is a gross distortion of facts.

During the Cold War, the CIA was engaged in relentless global warfare with the Kremlin. The agency  used a host of front organizations and phony foundations, spent many millions of dollars to fund concert tours, art exhibitions, magazines, academic research, student activities and book publishing. All theses were weapons in the covert action against the Soviet Union masterminded by George Kennan, who was the intellectual author behind this. One estimate says that some 10 million books and periodicals were distributed by the CIA in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.  "Doctor Zhivago"  was one of those books which was printed and distributed clandestinely in the main  Russian cities.This book, which is just one episode in the colossal ideological battle between the two superpowers, is excellent and is very original. The authors have put in a tremendous effort in researching its topic, using many untapped archives and interviews. It reads like a fast  best-selling political thriller.  This is a fascinating account of the propaganda machines the USA used against the Eastern Bloc, showing Pasternak's  and his friends' courage and it shows to what extent the battle for the minds of the readers in the East  was conducted. It is also a detailed story about the cultural and intellectual background of the thirties to the fifties in the USSR.This  battle over the publication of "Doctor Zhivago" was one of the first efforts by the CIA to leverage books as instruments of political warfare. It was Khrushchev himself who admitted in the end that the Russians "caused much harm to the Soviet Union "and added that he was "truly sorry for the way he behaved toward Pasternak".There were additional writers who followed Pasternak's way, among them Solzhenitsyn and Brodsky.This book is highly recommended.

It was exactly this day  almost one hundred years ago when all hell broke loose and the gates of Armageddon opened. The First World War started and the world would not be the same. Empires disappeared, a new world order was established, 9 million people died, 30 million were injured or maimed and  this war, which was supposed to end all wars, was just the prelude to another more devastating and disatrous tragedy, namely that of WW2.Enter Gordon Martel's brilliant study which examines that fateful month, July 1914, in which the principal players of the tragedy were responsible for the unleashing of it.The author claims that his purpose in writing the book was to provide the reader with the story of "how Europe got from A to B; how it moved from the assassination of the heir to the throne of Austria-Hungary on the 28th of June, 1914,to the declaration of war by five of the Great Powers of Europe at the beginning of August." It is a book of how it happened.This study is divided into four main parts, starting with a long introduction on European politics at the end of the nineteenth century and the beginning of the twentieth. It then commences with the killing of Franz Ferdinand and the reaction to it and then moves on describing the fateful days in July and August 1914. The last part gives the reader on overview of the historiography on the question of who was to be blamed for the outbreak of the war.Mr. Martel is quite honest when he writes that to this day there are many unsolved questions regarding the Great War, but also makes it clear that a combination of hubris, chance and circumstance caused it.The author gives a very detailed description of how the descent into the abyss of war  came about, by providing a very good background of the principal players involved. He also shows to what extent the war might have been avoided every day, and this he does by writing about the every minute-to-minute decisions which were taken then.. He examines the dilpomatic , military and political records  as well as the process of the decision makers, among them Tsar Nicholas 2, the Emperor Franz Joseph, Sir Edward Grey and many other famous  personalities .This book is brilliant because it is written in the style of a first- rate thriller and is researched in depth . It also includes a good bibliographical list and many photos and is highly recommended for those who would like to know the essentials  of World War One.

This book shows to what extent Stalin went in order to incriminate those whom he considered subversive elements and obstacles on the road  of  achieving his goals of total mastery of Eastern Europe.It suggests that Noel Field, who was working in the State Department, may have been a double spy working simultaneously for his American and Soviets masters. It shows to what extent  Stalin went in order to conduct purge trials and the relationship between Allen Dulles and Field.This is an extremely well researched and original book, packed with new information on every of its pages, offering new insights about the minds of those who took part in the Great Game of the Cold War. Highly reccomended.

If you would like to try and read a boring book which repeats its thesis a number of times, read this book. It adds nothing to the understanding of the Cold War and the very use of the term anti-fascism is fuzzy and misleading. One gets  the feeling that even the author himself was trying very hard to build a theory around which to substantiate his claims but failed to do so. There are other superb books on postwar Europe.In this respect, one can only mention the books by the late Tony Judt.  This present volume does not even contain one iota of originality and is a long bore-all this because of the terrible editing of it as well.

This biography is one of the best ones about a great doctor in ancient times. Galen was a polymath and  mastered many fields. The book describes in great detail not only Galen's life, but also the times in which he lived. The Roman Empire comes alive in Professor's Mattern's book .This multi-dimentional doctor was definitely unique in those times and the modern reader will be baffled by Galen's healing methods. True, it was Vesalius who demolished many of Galen's theories, nevertheless Galen has made a huge contribution to the development of medicine by the very fact that he conductued an endless number of dissections and vivisections, demonstrating again and again the way the anatomy of monkeys was similar to that of human beings. In a way, he was the precursor of Darwin.This is an excellent book, superbly researched (although it has some  weak spots and  a good editor might have improved them) and is much enjoyable.

This book is extremely boring and its pivot revolves around one topic endlessly: the difference between  Kennedy's religious beliefs versus those liberal ideas to which he allegedly opposed. The style of writing is such a bore that my only advise to you would be to save your hard-earned money for another book. Why the publishers agreed to even read Ira Stoll's manuscript remains a total mystery.

Sometimes you may have to wait quite a  long time in order to read  such a masterful book like Professor's Schrad gripping book. It is about the way in which vodka and other spirits have influenced the long, rich and arduous history of Russia.His main thesis is that since the days of the Vladimir  the Great of Kiev, alcohol has been used to make the Russians happy. The traditional drinks of Russia were naturally fermented beers, ales, meads and kvas. The imposition of the more potent artificial, distilled spirits came only with the imposition of the modern autocratic state, which used vodka to siphon off society's wealth into the treasury, making this drink the central pillar of Russian autocratic statecraft. Vodka, corruption and autocracy have been intertwined  in Russia ever since.Its secondary thesis is that, in a way, Russian rules conducted a kind of controlled schizophrenic policy vis-av-vis vodka: on the oned hand there were those who encouraged the masses to drink(Stalin being one of them) and on the other hand there were those who were against it(Lenin who was really paranoic about it, and Gorbachev). The reason: vodka was a powerful tool to control the masses and also served as a principal source of income for the state.What is great about this book is the vivid style of writing, demonstrating again that only some people belonging to the academia can also write not only for their peers but also for the history buff as well. The author demonstrates that since its inception, Russia was drenched in alcohol. This fact created the tragic consequences for the Russian society. It hastened the demise of the Soviet Union itself and caused what Professor Schrad calls "the literal demodernization of a twentieth century country".Just to give you an example: after Gorbachev announced a crackdown on the sales or production of vodka, which claimed the lives of tens of millions (mind you, this is no mistake), the most hard of drinkers turned to alcohol surrogates; from mouthwash, eau-de-cologne and perfumed to gasoline, cockroach poison, brake fluid, medical adhesives and even shoe polish on a slice of bread.Another example: "Soldiers in the Soviet Army would offer their last piece of bread to their comrades in order to get vodka and they drank everything just as during the Civil War: aftershave lotions, medicines and liquids containing poisons".Alcoholism runs like a red thread throughout Dostoyevsky's novel "Crime and Punishment" and Marmeladov is only the first noteworthy drunkard. Tolstoy suggested that it was alcohol that clouded Raskolnikov's judgment and led to his inhuman axe murders. The pervasive drunkenness of the Russian soldiers contributed to the military defeat of Russia in the Crimean War during the nineteenth century. Forty-four percent of all military deaths were attributable to alcohol. One can conclude that the chief contributory cause of the Bolshevik Revolution was the prohibition in 1914 of the sale of spiritous liquors.As stated by its author, this book does not pretend to say that vodka was/is everything in Russian history, thus it it not a monocausal explanation of Russian history and culture, but "vodka politics means a lot and it is an alternative lens through which Russia's complex politics and development is seen".By using newly dicovered documents hitherto classified and by integrating them with an in-depth examination of secondary sources, by incorporating studies from many fields such as sociology, political science, literature, memories and various diaries, anthropology, letters  as well as demographic studies, Professor Schrad has managed to write a book of twenty-four chapters (overpacked with many details and anecdotes in addition to excellent analyses) which is both a masterpiece and will definitely become a classic of its kind. This book is more than highly recommended for anyone who would like to enjoy reading about an original idea, examined almost microscopically, leaving no stone unturned . And in addition, it is also a great read!

Had George Orwell read this book, he would have changed a lot in his famous novel. The book is made up of three long essys and each focuses on another aspect  in connection with the brutal and totalitarian Ceausescu regime.The first chapter is about the Securitate and its "conspirativity', that is :the comparmentalization or secrecy of its practices. Here Professor Verdely describes in great detail what the twenty-four kilometers of Securitate files contain and the characterization of these files.The second chapter  discusses one main question; what did the secrecy  for the Securitate mean? Here the author uses a term previously used by Hannah Arendt -a term which defined the secret police as a secret society. By using anthropological terms, Ms. Verdely gives the reader a very broad description of the consequences of secrecy for socialism's legitimation.The last chapter is about the field work of officers and informers of the Securitate.The author herself was subject to surveillance during her many years she had spent in Romania. She was regarded or suspected as a spy working for the CIA and she had the good luck of examining her own files culled from those newly openedarchives.A word of caution merits to be written here: this is not an easy read and the reader is asked for a lot of patience for this book. There are many details and many analyses as well  as the use of  many terms taken from anthropology. Second, the author has done a great job in describing almost microscopically the daily routine and the modus operandi of the Securitate men and informers. Just to whet your appetite here are some statistics. There were 525000 Securitate workers for a country which had 23 million people. This meant one Securist for every 42 citizens. Compare this with the Stasi. They had 271000 workers for a population of 17 million. This meant one Stasi worker for every 62 citizens. Romania was well endowed with informers.This exceptional  and well researched book, which has also many photostats, is more than highly recommended not only for its contents but also for a better understanding of what a security state can mean for the present.

One can doubt it very much whether Israel's fate will not be like Sparta of ancient times. Due to the fact that some writers like Ari Shavit are still living under the preposterous illusion that Israel will be able to cope with some many enemies, let be beg to differ. History proves that in the long run even the mightiest empires have vanished under and because of the war crimes perpetretated continually by their regimes. The suppression of others' rights- in this case the way Israel totally ignores the international law concerning the occupied territories-only strenghtens my view that in the end Israel will become a bitter memory and a relic of the past.

The fact that Henry Kissinger has conducted a foreign policy which caused the deaths of many millions of innocent lives is no secret. This book , however, demonstrates once again that Kissinger ought to be tried  as a war criminal for another less known crime, namely the genocide of more than three million innocent Bengali Hindus who were sacrificed on the alter of the USA-Pakistan relations with the intention of winking  and signaling at China.
