The many crimes perpetrated by the famous duo Nixon-Kissinger are so many that one really doubts if all of them will ever be made public. Read this impressive book written by a professional historian and judge for yourself to what extent Kissinger and his master have gone crazy. Highly recommended.

John Judis has writtten a very good book about the beginnings of the Zionist movement and its influence on world leaders and Jews alike.The first half of the book is about the history of the Zionist movement and the second is about Truman's decisions on the establishment of Israel.It shows the complicated way the many advisors of Truman and the Zionists have gone in order to influence Old Harry to support the establishment of Israel.What was supposed to become a solution to the Jewish problem in the world turned out to be not only a tragedy for the Jews but it has also become a Palestinian tragedy due to the changing and brutal policies perpetrated by the followers  of those descendants of Jabotinsky (a big admirer of Mussolini, mind you) and the religious fanatical parties. These things were never on the agenda of the Fathers of Zionism.Israel is to be blamed for the fact that in contravention to the UN resolutions and interantional law, it sent people to colonize the occupied territories of 1967. This is forbidden according to any international law. Israel's Jews have gained a world of their own, but at the expense of another people. The Palestinians have paid dearly for this and have become a displaced people.Today Israel has become a state which curtails and limits the rights of the Palestinians- those Palestinians whose very existence was  ignored and despised by Golda Meir already in 1969. The Palestinians have no political rigths today and are subject to arbitrary arrest and imprisonment and even torture by Israel's military, and "the continual harassment from the Jewish settlers. That's not the outcome that many of the early Zionists envisaged", concludes Mr. Judis, who has written a very interesting , brilliant and stimulating book about the paradoxes of the Arab-Israeli conflict, using known and new sources in this myth- breaking and highly recommended book.

If there is one book you should read about the many crimes in which the Vatican was involved during the Second World War, Deschner's book is the right choice. Although written many years ago, it was recently updated and is still very relevant and important today.The author, mind you, is a Catholic who does not  hide his disgust of the Catholic Church and is courageous enough to slam incessantly against the Vatican and Pope Pius 12. The reason is extremely simple: the Catholic Church has not done anything to try and stop Hitler  and other mass murderers from executing their devilish plans and extermination programs. No one is spared in this book, not even those  so-called "resistance" priests or bishops in Germany who knew about the horrible crimes perpetrated in Russia and against the Jews  during the Holocaust or in Croatia but all they did was to keep silent. This well researched and documented book can only be called a mini-masterpiece and it is highly recommended.

The extermination of  one of the largest Jewish communities in Europe was that of Hungary. Dry statistics figures show that all in all, 570000 of Hungary's 825000 Jews fell victim in the Holocaust, 437000 of them in the course of less than two months in the spring of 1944.Winston Churchill wrote that thet persecution of Jews in Hungary and their expulsion is "probably the greatest and most horrible crime ever committed in the history of the world.`Enter Raoul Wallenberg. He grew up in a wealthy banking family and his father died of cancer before he even saw his son. Raoul was raised by his mother, but the main figure who was responsible for his upbringing was his paternal grandfather, Gustav Wallenberg. According to Professor Jangfeldt, Gustav adviced his grandson to carry out the duty "of those who have the talent to carry out the great tasks to rise above their contemporaries". Thus Raoul was sent to study architecture at the University of Michigan. After graduating, Raoul took some jobs both in South Africa and in Palestine- to be precise: in Haifa, and after some months he chose to work for a Hungarian Jew who had an import-export business in Stockholm. The name of Raoul's boss was Kolman Lauer and he would be the turning point in Raoul's life, since Lauer, backed by the Americans, was engaged in an effort to save the Hungarian Jews.Raoul arrived in Budapest in July 1944. after being appointed secretary to the delegation and representative of the War Refugee Board. From this point onwards, Raoul would implement his granfather's wish. He worked incessantly in order to save as many Jews as possible by doing several things.  He issued provisional passports called "protective passports ("Schutzpass)" to Jews who had some connection to Sweden. He found thirty-two safe houses where Jews would be housed. He provided food for the Ghetto inhabitants and also began a Swedish hospital in his private flat. Ten specialist doctors worked full-time in the hospitala nd it opened on 2 December, after only five days' preparation. He managed to save the lives of some 8000 Jews in addition to housing tens of thousands of them in those abobe-mentioned safe houses.These are just a few examples taken from this fascinating and extremely well and deeply- researched new biography by Professor Jangfeldt.However, the last one hundred pages of this important volume are much more interesting, since they deal with Raoul's arrest and fate. Why he was arrested remains an enigma. It is here where the original part of the book starts, because there are many new sources which were discovered by the author on this point. The warrant for Raoul's arrest was signed by Deputy Defence Commisar Bulganin and addressed to Marshal Malinovsky with a copy to the head of SMERSH, Victor Abakumov. It said that Raoul " shall be arrested and brought to Moscow" . This happened in January 1945. According to the author, Raoul's possessions contained documents pertaining to the activities of the Swedish delegation in Budapest; his plans for the reconstruction of Hungary after the war; photographs of atrocities committed by the Nazis and the Arrow Cross party. "We also know that he had with him money in various currencies as well as gold and valuables". The Soviets knew about those valuables through a spy in Wallenberg's intimate circle and there is no record of what happened to them and the gold. In all probability, they were stolen by soldiers and officers on the spot.Raoul was sent to the Lubianka prison and the given profession on the arrest card was "diplomatic overseer or observer". Raoul arrived here from another prison, Lefortovo. He shared his cell with the German Gustav Richter, also known as Romania's Eichmann-with the difference that Richter's plan was never implemented. It was Richter who, in 1955, supplied information about the three weeks in which he shared his cell with Wallenberg, who was accused of being a spy in favour of the Germans.The author includes some new photostats of testimonies given by other citizens who saw Wallenberg. The fact that some papers found proved that Wallenberg had connections with various Nazi officials-Kurt Becher and Himmler-worked against him. The Soviets kept Wallenberg in jail for two and a half years without being interrogated more than five times. According to Jangfeldt, Wallenberg was suspected of collaboration with the American and British intelligence sservices-a suspicion which fueled Stalin's paranoia.Raoul died as a result of a heart  attack on 17 July 1947. This  official report is also raising some questions because there are some testimonies written by some Russian officers and  found by the author which deny that Raoul was suffering from a heart condition.The last part of the book asks why the Swedish authorities did  very little for their citizen and maybe there were some economic factors or interests which were responsible for this behaviour. As he concludes, Professor Jangfeldt writes that "much greater resources could no doubt have been mobilized, considering the Wallenberg family's position and influence".This book, which is based on original research, includes tens of never-before-published new photos and is a must for all those who would like to know more about one of the most intelligent and noble persons who was ever alive and has justly deserved the title of" one of the righteous"  during those horrible days in the annals of humanity. Highly recommended.

Operation Paperclip is about the connection between Nazi scientists and American government secrets. Under this program, more than a thousand of Nazi scientists were brought to America  immediately after the end of World War Two. Those scientists helped develop rockets, the NASA program, chemical and biological weapons, aviation and space medicine and many other weapons of mass destruction.They came to America at the behest of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Some officials believed that by endorsing the Paperclip program they were accepting the lesser of two evils-that if America didn't recruit theses men, the Soviet Communists would.The book comes in five parts and each part is about another chronoligical era . Most men that were brought to America were accused of war crimes. Most of them were found guilty of war crimes by the various post-war trials at Nuremberg. Yet the USA wanted them on American soil to work for the American people despite their horrible past.Opposition to Operation Paperclip gained momentum with America's scientific elite and  many scientists were outraged when the details of the secret project came out. Albert Einstein was the most esteemed figure to publicly denouce this operation and wrote directly to President Truman on behalf of his FAS colleagues:"We hold these individuals to be potentially dangerous...Their former eminence as Nazi Party members and supporters raises the issue of their fitness to become American citizens and hold key positions in American industrial, scientific and educational institutions".Another famous scientists, Hans Bethe, who fled the Nazis, asked: "Do we want science at any price?"Among the various and many scientists and their respective projects they were working on, Ms. Jacobsen mentions Dr. Walter Schreiber who was the surgeon general of the Third Reich and developed  intravenous lethal phenol injections. He was finally exposed by an ex-concentration camp victim and as a result had to leave the USA. Another criminal, Kurt Blome, was Hitler's biological weapons maker, while Kurt Debus was a V-weapons engineer who oversaw mobile rocket launches at Peenemunde. An ardent Nazi, he wore the SS uniform to work and became the first director of NASA's JFK Space Center in Florida. Hubertus Strughold was in charge of the aviation research in the Reich Ministry and despite his war crimes was hired by the Americans only to become America's father of Space Medicine.These and many more criminal scientists people the pages of this fascinating  and fast-paced written book. In it, Ms. Jacobsen has incorporated a wealth of post-war interrogation reports, army intelligence security dossiers, Army intelligence armaments reports, declassified memos, diaries and journals. She also used-for the first time-materials supplied to her by the descendants of some Nazi scientists. She definitely shows to what extent the CIA agency had been involved with these monsters and the various ways those Nazis trained and supplied vital information to the CIA. The various and notorious  interrogation techniques and other programs and projects had their beginnings in a camp near Franfurt called Camp King. It was there where Operation Bluebird experiments involving LSD and other drugs started.The army's herbicidal warfare program during the Vietnam War, inwhich 11.4 million gallons of Agent Orange were sprayed over more than 24 percent of South Vietnam was the brainchild of Fritz Hoffmann, another Nazi war criminal. On his deathbed, Hoffmann, according his daughter, was quiet and said nothing about it. Unfortunately, many details about additional projects initiated by the Nazi scientists who were flown into the USA are still classified.For anyone interested in the  history of the postwar period and for those who would like to know to what extent the USA became involved with the Nazi past, this long book is "a must".

This book is one of the best written ones on the subject of Napoleon. It describes in great detail the many battles of the Emperor, with particular emphasis on the bitter fate of the French soldiers in Spain and in Russia, where almost  more than half a million  French soldiers died there.It also takes a deep look into the private life of Napoleon, his loves, his health, his problems with his brothers and with his wives  and also has many quotes, quips and speeches by him.Was he a dictator or a liberator? This depends on the reader's choice, although the author is inclined to show him as a cruel and oppressive leader. The controversy over this point will probably go on in the future.Mr. Dwyer has written a marvellouly researched book, incorporating new evidence about the battles in Russia. It is intended for the academic and the lay reader alike.  My only criticism has to do with the horribly produced  drawings and pictures-many by the famous David- and in the future the publishers should be much nore serious about  this point.All in all, this book is a treat and definitely much recommended!

The many illegal acts committed in the past by the FBI have been known for many years, but never before has a book been able to describe in such great detail the enormity of these crimes, courtesy of the late Edgar Hoover. The American people have been blessed to have in their ranks some individuals who will always care about their personal freedom as well as the freedom and rights of the others. This book should be mandatory reading for each and every citizen who is concerned about the infringements of rights perpetrated by any goverment. it is a must for every intelligent person who wants to read a masterpiece!

Common wisdom claims that the Cuban Missile Crisis(CMC)  was the most dangerous event in the annals of humanity. To quote Dean Rusk's words, it was so  "...because the two superpowers were at each other's jugular veins and it was not easy to see a way out. With fumbling on iether side, this could have resulted in nuclear war".Enter Mr. Pardoe's magnificent book which demonstrates that the contingency plans and the likely scenarios could have been much worse than previously omagined. I believe this is the first book to discuss in such great detail the military preparations for the upcoming conflict. Although limited by a ferocious policy of declassification, the author has managed to tell the reader for the first time about Operation Scabbards. This included a number of frightening possibilities devised by the supreme commanders of the USA army concerning the various ways to fight in Cuba.Had this war happened, one of the biggest losers would be the countries of Europe. There would be no winners in the event of a full nuclear exchange and both superpowers would have been crippled to the point where they may have never recovered.Worse yet, the Cubans and the Soviets both had plans to fight on after the battle for Cuba was lost, waging a guerrilla war. The US occupation of Cuba was not a one ot three month effort; it was destined to drag on potentially for years with a long string of casualties.The book discusses in great detail to what extent the US commanders were naive and knew very little about the real situation in Cuba. Ditto for the CIA, save its head, John McCone, who was perhaps the only one who deduced correctly what the Soviets's intentions were.Many materials which could have expanded the panoramic views represented here were lost or weren't properly archived. This presents any researcher with many problems, since the picture of the CMC is still far from being complete. Many questions still remain open or unclear, although the CMC has been analyzed microscopically so far.Thus Mr Pardoe's archival request for information from the Cuban authorities were politely ignored.The book contains extremely detailed tables concerning the USA army units and their order of combat  as well as many relevant maps, although some of them are not printed clearly. In addition, the author has interviewed many persons who were part of this ongoing crisis, among them marines, sailors, soldiers, officers and analysts. It also has  a chronological list of photographic missions over Cuba and many new photos, hitherto classified. For history buffs and professionals, this is a much highly recommended book!

This book puts the emphasis on Beethoven the man and not his compositions. Mr. Suchet writes about what Beethoven ate, drank, smoked and many other things which show that the genius also had human attributes. He also writes about some episodes which were unnoticed by other biographers. Did you know - for example -that once the great Beethoven was a kitchen aide?Mr Suchet points out the weaknesses and the positive as well as the negative characteristics of his subject. The main parts deal with Beethoven's  life and deeds in Vienna and its suburbs. It is here where he got  achieved his fame and it is here where he composed, directed, took walks ( mainly by himself), ate, quarreled  and died. The main thesis behind this volume is that one can better understand and definitely enjoy Beethoven's music only after knowing even trivial facts about the man. Beethoven was extremely complicated and complex. He would sometimes leash out at people without any regrets for having done so. In his famous and great pieces and small he was the only composer who wrote for anyone and thus became perhaps the greatest of them all.Highly recommended for those who would like to know not only about his music, but also about the man behind the composer.

This book is well researched and gives the reader a panoramic view about one of the most tragic and least understood episodes in the history of WW2. The AK's arranged Warsaw uprising and the destruction of Warsaw stand in the focus here.The author who is living in Poland had access to her father-in-law's vast archive about the events which transpired in the summer of 1944 and she writes about the immense scale of beastly brutality perpetrated by the Nazi hordes against the Polish nation. The tragedy of Poland has been already told many timeds, yet this book is a very good microhistory about the fate of those living in the hellish conditions in Warsaw during August, when the uprising was a total failure and, as a result, the Nazis simply decided to erase the city. This was a unique decision and no other city suffered the same fate during the war.  The decision to do it was taken under the auspices of Hitler and Himmler, and Ms. Richie is extremely good when describing the whole background of this tragic event, which claimed the lives of at least 200000 Poles.But why not award this book five stars? There are some things which could have been incorporated here but are missing. First, there is a lack of relevant maps. Even those that are to be found here are simple and do not give the lay reader the information so much needed when reading  about microevents.Second, the fate of the AK's leadership is almost non-existent during this long book and all we get is a good introduction the the topic.All in all, this is a book I would recommend to those who know something (or nothing)  about this tragedy and would like to expand their horizons.

Leo Damrosch has written an outstanding book on one of the greatest writers in English literature. Swift was a man of many contradictions and his life was full of complex relationships. The author has incorporated new things which were discovered about Swift during the last thirty years and he offers his readers a very lucidly written book which is divided according to many topics which do not come in partilcular chronological order.He starts with Swift's early and tragic life and commences with his first attempts to write various treaties and poems.The author claims that so far the authority on the writer was Irvin Ehrenpreis's monumental biography, which fills two thousand pages by the time the third volume came out, yet there were new aspects of Swift's life and writings that emerged in the last decades. Damrosch also criticizes his predecessor for relying much on Freudian interpretations of personality, which can distort Swift's relationships in general.Damrosch is excellent when he provides the reader with the various backrounds of each new person who entered Swift's life. In fact, sometimes the reader is confronted with many details, which sometimes might be a hindrance  during the reading of the text, but ,all in all, this biography exaust each and every angle of Swift's life, carrer, his friendships and his enemies, his relationship with Sir William Temple, where Swift established a relationship of more than twenty-seven years with Stella, the woman who was thought to be Temple's daughter and perhaps the woman who many thought got married to Swift.Thus one of the greatest enigmas of Swift's life.We also get a fascinating description and history of London in the eighteenth century, to quote, "Street life was aggressive. Carts and wagons were dangerous, herds of livestock pushed past pedestrians, and since there were no sidewalks, it was impossible to avoid the traffic and the dirt". There was a good deal of crime and Swift was captivated by the human comedy in the streets, but was  also disgusted by the London stink. There he wrote two anti-pastorals and there are many descriptions of London's political life which served as the basis for Swift's satirical writings and poems.There are just twenty pages which are devoted to Gulliver's Travels" and, in my opinion, this is a pity because this book is central in Swift's writings and in general. The last years of Swift's life are  detailed as well and the doctors who conducted the autopsy of Swift found the reason for the disease Swift was suffering from.This oustanding volume is extremely well and deeply researched and documented. It also contains tens of facsimiles and photos . It is highly recommended to those who want to know not only about Swift and the times he lived in, but also to those who want to enjoy a very stimulating biography, which is fast-paced and highly enjoyable.

Let me start this time from the end. If Mr. Farmelo would have clarified his main thesis, I would have given this volume five stars. Unfortunately, this did not happen and it is a pity, because the efforts and amount of research invested in this book are worth praising.Churchill was deeply influenced by H G Wells in his views on science as Mr. Farmelo makes it clear from the very beginning. Then there are so many chapters devoted not only to Churchill bit also to his friend and main advisor in scientific  matters, Frederick Lindemann. The Prof , as Churchill called him, was despised by many of his colleagues and was an anti-Semite, although he had done much  to rescue and bring to England Jewish scientists who were trying to escape from the ferocious regime of Hitler. Isaiah Berlin even remarked that he would have liked to kill Lindemann. The Prof knew at some point that he would never be able to compete with other physicists such as Einstein and Rutherford.Mr. Farmelo makes it clear that Churchill's total dependence on Lindemann was a hindrance rather than a blessing when coming to decide matters about the best way to work on the A-bomb. The bureaucratic process which this subject gave birth too was long, endless and arduous and Churchill is regarded as the main culprit for not  obtaining the bomb for England in 1941, when Roosevelt made his famous offer to Churchill. It was much later when both countries decided to co-operate in this matter but the US had the upper hand.In fact, this book is a dual biography of both Churchill and Lindemann, with a lot of relevant information about the other and many physicists involved in the project whose final station was at  Los Alamos. The second part of this good book explains in detail what Churchill's stand  vis-a-vis Stalin and Communism after WW2 was. Mr. Farmelo is in the know about the many efforts of Stalin to get information about the bomb from his many spies who were sent or worked for him. One of them was Klaus Fuchs and there are many details about him and his betrayal.To sum up, Mr Farmelo does not clarify his thesis and one has to infer what exactly the main thesis is in this important  and engrossing book.

This book is another example of how an academic does not write history but a mishmash of gossip and anecdotes. In addition, the menu also includes many details about her family and friends. Now the question that should be asked is this: has someone at Harper book been so distracted that he/she labeled this book under "history"? Why wasn't this book labeled "gossip and friends"?Had I the possibility, I would have given this book 0 stars, but Amazon does not allow one to do so.Stay away from this book (or piece of cheap redundant gossip).

In the annals of humanity, there were many hideous crimes committed against various gropus or peoples. The Black Holocaust stands out in its uniqueness because it was extremely long and took almost 450 years to terminate it. In addition, not only were the Blacks marked to die, they also had to serve as production beasts for the White man before being exterminated. In fact, most Blacks who were enslaved were subjects to humiliation, torture,beatings, rape and economic exploitation by their masters.This magnificent volume by Professors Gates and Yacovone is a gem because of many reasons, but particularly because it gives the reader  a glimpse into the lives of those unfortunate slaves who later on were released form their horrible ordeal, not before enduring those various afflictions mentioned before.There are nine chapters, chronologically starting im 1500 and ending with the election of Barack Obama. In other words, this book takes the reader on a journey where he-or she-is transported to Africa, Europe, the Carribean, South America and the United States.The journey to freedom was far from being smooth and had many bends, like  the ones found in a river. These bends -one should say:too many of them-included rebellions, hardships, slave trades in which most slaves were regarded a piece of property, escape routes,redemption, thousands of lynchings at the beginning of the twentieth century, discrimination, the Harlem Renaissance and finally the ultimate destination-the White House.Superbly illustrated, this volume is also well researched  and  is surely to become a classic of its kind. Its subtext, in my opinion, is that if you stand up for your own rights, you will finally achieve them, no matter what. The quest for freedom, so much desired by those tens of millions of Backs, was gained in the end.  Highly recommended!

This book is one of the best books which appeared during 2013. It is written like an elegant thriller and tells the story of two famous public figures in American contemporary history. It is the story and history  of the Dulles brothers, one a masterspy and the other a foreign secretary. It is also, as the writer mentions, the story of America, of its myopia and hubris. The two brothers wanted the world to go  their way, thus they had invested all their efforts in doing anything legal or illegal in order to achieve this. Allen has conducted numerous covert actions, and was the head of the CIA, which made sure to remove all the obstacles in favour of the United States. Foster has done the same.  The fault with both of them was that they saw the world in Manichean terms only-perhaps a result of their rigorous religious upbringing. There were only two kinds of people or nations in the worlds: the bad ones and the good ones.  In the end, both started to lose their grip on reality, and the humiliation of Allen, who was dismissed from his post by Kennedy, was bigger.This book should be mandatory reading for anyone who likes a good history book, which is extremely well researched and brilliantly written. If I could give it more than five stars I would ,but Amazon does not permit it!

This slim volume is a gem and includes a lot of insights which  could only be written by a master historian, He gives the reader a brief overview about Mozart's life, dismissing some famous myths about the composer. He does not discuss in depth  almost anything , however he has a vey good (and long) chapter on Mozart's operas.Some years ago, I attended a lecture on music. The professor who delivered it told us that Bach wrote heavenly music; Beethoven wrote music for the people; Mozart just wrote music. His words will remain with me forever.This book should be read not only by Mozart fans but also by anyone who wants to understand more about the humane part of a genius' life and his optimistic outlook on life.

I concur with one of the critics here who had previously mentioned the fact that this book needed a serious editor. Instead of reading an interesting story about a fascinating and dynamic part of American history, we get a book  in which things repeat themselves in an endless number of the same pattern. The writing style is awkward, boring and repetitive and one gets the impression that the book was written for those who have a very big problem with understanding reading comprehension. What could be stated precisely and concisely in some pages is unnecessarily told in tens and sometimes hundreds of redundant pages, missing the whole point. This is not how history should be written. I do believe that had this book been shortened by at least  sixty percent, the final product would have been very good indeed, Instead, we get a heavy volume of things which remind one of a dog chasing its tail in order to catch it-all in vain! There are much better books on Theodore Roosevelt and suffice it to mention the works of Edmund Morris. Spare you money! And, mind you, isn't the author Goodwin the one who has been implicated in plagiarizing while writing about the Kennedys? Methinks the answer is in the affirmative.

Let me start with a confession. I was born in Romania and from time to time  I happen to read books about Romanian history and Communism. My speciality concerns the Cold War and whenever a new book  about it is available, I try to read it.This book,  by Tomek Jankowski , is  different. It is a book about Eastern Europe and has many short chapters on almost every facet of  Eastern European history. But this is not another book just about dry facts. It will be enjoyed by many readers who have almost no knowledge about this topic. Even those of you who know much about that part of the world, will find an endless number of gems among its pages.The writing is dynamic, up-to-date, with many new and unusual aspects  and it includes many trivia windows which inhabit its pages.It starts with a journey starting in 500 BC and ends in 2009. The roots of the modern world are to be found in Eastern Europe and an awful lot of peoples, technologies, trade goods and languages that came to make up modern-day Western Europe probably flowed through Eastern Europe first.Rich with pictures. diagrams, figures, jokes, aphorisms , poems, maps and even recipes, you will enjoy a very quick and conciseintellectual journey  in one of the most beautiful yet complicated parts  of the world. This book can serve both as a superb introduction to the topic or as a new a refreshed , stimulating and non- conventional look at Eastern Europe , written by  someone who is a master in his field. Highly recommended!

Intelligence has played a significant part in the history of the Cold War. Spies, as the author mentions, did not change the political balance between the superpowers, but they were responsible, to a great extent, for letting the other side know of the opponent's intentions.This volume, being  supplementary to the first volume which is a history of espionage in America between  the nation's birth to the Cold War, is superb and contains a lot of well known cases in which American citizens betrayed their country.  The author displays not only a very good command of each case, but also analyzes in depth many cases  of espionage which happened during the last sixty years. The main reason for spying was money. As Mr. Sulick writes,"American disbelief in espionage reached its heights in the decades preceding World War Two". The Soviets invested a lot of efforts  to extract vital information about each facet of America, thus they were willing to pay huge amounts of money to anyone who would deliver the merchandise. The years between 1945-1970 were justly called "the Golden Age" of espionage, since the Soviets' network included spies from all walks of life, from inside and outside the government, from the highest levels to low-ranking clerks.Elizabeth Bentley, The Rosenbergs, Harry Dexter White, Theodore Hall, the Venona Project, Aldrich Ames, Ronald Pelton, John Walker and Robert Hanssen, as well as other less famous spies people the pages of this book.Mr. Sulick discusses in great detail the motivations of those spies, the access and the secrets they betrayed, their exposure and the punishment given to each of them and the damage they caused to the national security of the USA. One major conclusion of the author is that the Americans were extremely naive about the possibility-or rather the impossibility-of American citizens spying against their own country.It was not all about money, and some spies had other motives, such as ego, romance, thrills and revenge.The book is divided into six parts, and in my view the best ones are the  last two which discuss panoramically the last vestiges of Cold War espionage and the spy business of the twenty-first century, where a lot of emphasis is put on the Chinese efforts to gain secrets from the USA.The author also makes it clear that the counterintelligence services of the USA almost totally ignored the possibility of China getting involved in the Great Game. This can be due to the fact that the efforts to make it hard on spies to gather classified information were mainly devoted and focused on the Soviet Union and the Eastern block countries. For millenia, Sun Tzu's emphasis on the importance of espionage "has been a pillar of Chinese military and political strategy. His advice about using spies everywhere would be applied relentlessly in the United States in the last quarter of the twentieth century. During that period, Chinese intelligence flooded the United States with students, scientists, businessmen, and emigres from all walks of life to harvest America's political, economic and scientific secrets." One of these spies was Larry Wu-tai Chin's espionage for the Chinese regime and it lasted longer than any known American spy. Another case was that of Katrina Leung who was exposed as a double agent working for both the FBI and the Chinese.At the beginning of the twenty-first century, the Chinese pursued operations to infiltrate young Americans into positions of access.They were recruited on Chinese campuses.In 2010, six out of seven cases of economic espionage involved China; estimated of losses in these cases touched the stunning figure of one billion dollars.These days  there are 140 foreign intelligence services which spy against the United States and, according to the White House officials, economic espionages cost US companies an estimated 100 billion dollars a years in lost sales.Cyberspying is in vogue these days, while spy hunters now confront a far broader spectrum of threat from hostile states and groups, including numerous threats from terrorist organizations. Hacktivism is mainly used  to manipulate data for political purposes or economic ones. It is expected that in the future, the number of cyberespionage attacks will grow and become increasingly sophisticated. These attacks could be launched by terrorists to destroy vital infrastructure systems, including the banking industry, telecommunications, electrical grids, and air traffic control.This book, written by a former CIA couterintelligence chief, is a treat, extremely well researched  and profusely documented and reads like a first rate spy novel. Highly recommended!

Among so many books published  so far about the Kennedy presidency, this one merits to be called the best of them all.It is divided into three parts, and the best one is the third, which discusses the impact of the Kennedy legacy on the other presidents.The first two thirds are about the Kennedy administration and the second one is a dissection about the assassination and the various theories connected to it. Mr Sabato spares no one and  offers his intepretation of the events which happened on the day of the assassination and afterwards.This book, which is superbly researched, is a real gem and reads like a fast-paced thriller, full of surprises on each and every page of it. More than highly recommended!

This is the main thesis of this book. Kennedy was quite disappointed in his court advisors and in many cases he thought that their advice would imperil not only the USA but the whole world.The main culprits were those of the military,among them the notorious Curtis LeMay.Mr. Dallek's previous book on Kennedy was much better than this one, which seems to be a summing up of the main sources and literature on Kennedy -both primary and secondary.Nevertheless, the book will do and has its good points as well.

This book is an example as to how to write a serious and in-depth work based on extensive research encompassing almost all the possible angles of the most famous assassination of the twentieth century. Mr. Waldron is extremely careful and meticulous about every detal and does not spare his criticism towards many figures both in the CIA and the FBI regarding the whole affair.I will not repeat what previous reviewrs have already written. The whole murderous episode is far from being resolved, because, as the author points out, there are still one million files pertaining to the case and waiting to be opened at some point in this decade.This book is brilliantly written and it does not matter if you agree or disagree with its thesis. What matters is the wonderful , dynamic and rapid style of writing and the efforts invested in researching this tour de force book.

Many people , specialists and history buffs alike, claim that  World War One changed the course of modern and comtemporary history. It  is considered the first modern technological war and when it ended, at least four empires disappeared from the world.Many problems which concern the world today have their origins in this war and its aftermath.Margaret Macmillan has written a brilliant book about the background of this horrible conflict which claimed the lives of more than nine million soldiers. This immensly readable book  is  not only a synthesis of things which have been published before, but is also a very broad and deep analysis of various aspects of the events that led to this tragedy.True, Professor Macmillan does not offer any verdict as to who was to be blamed  for the war. She asks many questions, offers many solutions and lets the reader decide for himself  who the real culprit is, but her tendency is to support the Fischer Thesis, or in other words, she more than once hints about Germany's culpability.This is one of the best book that were ever written about WW1 and it is more than highly recommended!

This book is another important addition to what was called in the past "the missing dimension" of Cold War history, namely the history of intelligence during the  that era. Mr. Bagley has written a book about one of the most famous-perhaps the most famous -spymasters who ran espionage operations  for his Kremlin masters. This was Sergey Kondrashev, who was the handler of another famous British spy, George Blake. In fact, this slim volume is about the revelations dictated to Bagley by the Russian superspy, and since he could not write about his past in Putin's Russia, he had to find another way of doing so. Some years ago, Kondrashev died and now Mr. Bagley could publish his adversary's memoirs without any hindrance.Kondrashev headed two of the most important KGB stations abroad, in London and Vienna, and he was chief of the KGB'S German-Austrian Department, overseeing its penetrations of the West German government and other clandestine actions in that area of prime Soviet concern.He also commended the secret intelligence operations of Soviet border troops along their vast frontiers in northern Europe, Central Asia, China and the northern Pacific.His forces contributed to Moscow's effortd to desatbilize China. Small units would clandestinely enter western Chinese territory to plant tower-like transmitters to broadcast calls for autonomy from Beijing's rule. He also adds some surprising information regarding the Nosenko case and I will not spoil it for you. There are some revelations about the fate Hitler's body and his part in this affair.Another important chapter reveals how and to what extent the Soviets conducted disinformation operations aimed against the West.If you want to understand how the great game was played out in different countries and locations during the Cold War, this book is a "must". It also helps clarify some more controversial issues about various angles in the annals of the Cold War history, starting with the revelations of an American traitor who helped ignite the Korean war.This book proves again and again to what extent the importance of intelligence was in those times and no serious historian writing about the Cold War would ignore this dimension. Highly recommended for history professionals and espionage buffs alike.

Ian Buruma has written a short volume about the year 1945, in which he describes the end and the beginning on a new period in conteporary history. The most vicious and brutal war in the annals of humanity has changed everything and Professor Buruma is excellent when describing whatever happened to the common people immediately after the end of this horrible conflict, which took the lives of tens of millions of soldiers and civilians alike. The chapters are organized thematically and in the background there is the personal history of the author's father who was sent to Berlin during the war.It would be a waste of time to describe again the contents of each chapter, since previous critics have already done so before.I would say that the conclusion of the author is not original and he is extremely careful  and honest to point this out, and the things that matters most is  his optimism about the future of Europe, in particular. This is mandatory reading for any intelligent man or woman who cares about the human race. More than highly recommended !

This is another excellent book written by a very talented and erudite writer whose books have so far managed to attract many readers and admirers.This volume is about the brutish and hellish conditions under which miliions were to be found during 1914 in Europe. To be sure, Mr. Hastings does not doubt at all who was to be blamed for the start of the hostilities and by this is he much credit, again, to the Fischer thesis. In other words, the blame goes to Germany and he proves it again and again, dismissing all the other revisionist historians who tried to rebuke this claim. I must say that he is very convincing in presenting these arguments.Sir Hastings also does a superb job in trying to convey the day-by-day ordeal and battles that soldiers and civilians alike had to undergo, and he offers the reader a very broad picture of everythings that happened on the front, be it the Western or Eastern one. This he does in a very simple language,which does not include a lot of military jargon and terms-a rare thing for a military historian.He also analyzes the outcome of the first 5 months of the war, and is extremely critical of the BEF.Highly recommended.

This book is a strong indictment against the many abuses  of the law the CIA and other American intelligence units have perpetrated in the last 40 years.It has ten chapters and it starts with the famous "Family Jewels" which were revealed in the 1970s, leading to the establishment of the well-known Church Committee.What is new here is the scope and breath of the excellent analysis offered by Mr. John Prados, a senior fellow at the NS Archive in Washington. Not only does he describe in great detail what those jewels were about, but he also adds new dimensions to them. This is not only a book about the Year of Intelligence. It demonstrates,step by step, to what extent those people who were in charge of intelligence gathering and dissemination were involved in illegal actions. These actions, which among others, included domestic operations aimed at American citizens, are still in the making these very days.The book is also about the spooks who conducted those illegalities, the efforts to uncover them, the politicos who ordered them or attempted to stymie them and serves as a kind of warning. In particular, Mr. Prados makes it clear that suppression of the truth will only backfire at those who try to hide it, in the same way it acted against them in the past. He attacks mainly the American Presidents who knew or pretended not to know about illegal actions which were undertaken by the CIA. How the Presidents tried to prevent, limit, curtail or outflank investigations is revealed here in great depth.The author makes a distinction between "Family Jewels"-the famous documents revealed to the public in the 1970s and the Family Jewels of today, meaning the controversial actions or operations currently in use these days. He identifies a certain pattern of spy activities which tended or tend to replicate each time. Among those mentioned, one can find political surveillance, eavesdropping, harsh interrogation, assassinations (today targeted ones with the help of drones) and many other things spanning from the days of the Cold War to these very days.The main thesis of the book is that efforts to evade accountability will not be successful.Another aspect is that once projects which are illegally initiated will be extremely hard to shut down. Thus NSA's program called "Minaret" whose purpose was to tap or listen to phone calls of American citizens in the seventies continued for more than a year after a court decision rendered it plainly illegal. The follow-up is today in the "Enhanced Interrogation" techniques against various suspects, or, if you will, the famous "Terrorist Surveillance Program". As Mr. Prados writes, "Presidents and their staff are some of the most dangerous violators of secrecy, because they know what the public does not". Or, to put it otherwise, "the White House plays the same games as does the CIA".The final chapter offers a schematic attempt to remedy this flawed situation and, in addition, is an attack on the classified documents declassification methods used today, which are not appropriate anymore.This immensely readable and well-researched book is more than highly recommended.

There is almost nothing positive one can say about this book. The reason I gave it 2 stars is because of the efforts invested in it, particularly in trying to write an interesting narrative.On the other hand, there are many problems with this biography. As one of the previous readers has already remarked, Berg cannot make up his mind as to whether Wilson was a positive or negative president. Soetimes he portrays him as benevolent, sometimes Wilson is a negative politician or president.In addition, there are many statements written which cannot be supported by any evidence. For example, Mr. Berg claims that the Black Death was taking its toll for some 400 years. This is a figment of his imagination, since in the best case one can speak of some 100-120 years of non-stop death cases as a result of that horrible plague. Another example has to do with a statement allegedly uttered by Churchill, claiming the the USA should not have interfered with other countries' business or affairs, which again cannot be proved by any reliable source.Add the fact that the footnotes are arranged in a terrible manner and they, in the majority of cases, do not correspond to the written text. Some other  essential sources which should have been mentioned because they are a sine qua non in writing about Wilson are totally disregarded. This is a pity and I can only recommend another, older biography, which  is still very good, that of John Milton Cooper.In short, don't waste you time and money on this volume!

They say that when the cannons roar, the muses fall silent. But in the following case, the muses weren't silent at all, on the contrary, they were more than active."Shadows of Combat" is a very original book and is an extension of the authors' previous excellent book called "In Our Duffel Bags".Mr. Geschke and Mr. Toto have this time undertaken a very interesting  and, one must say, original project: to offer a poetic version of their wartime experiences-one which took place and spanned over three continents. The style of writing is far from being conventional and does not conform to any specific rules of poetry writing. Since poems are a personal matter, so are feelings, emotions, thoughts and the reader will find them all here. As young officers sent to Fort Benning, Georgia, these two maintained a laudatory friendship since then.The book is nicely organized with short, precise and concise introductions and complemented by relevant photos for each segment, starting with their period when they were training as officers and proceeding with chapters about  their service in Germany, Panama and Vietnam. Some poems are full of irony, some evoke sad memories, some contain connotations of despair and others serve as a kind of protest against many domestic issues connected in particular to the Vietnam War-a thing which mattered tremendously to both authors/poets. You may like or dislike their poems, yet you will never remain indifferent. Each one of these pieces encapsulates another kind of experience written, I believe, from the very bottom of their hearts.This book has another advantage over others. One should remember that many readers were born after the times described here, therefore they will gain a lot of insights and a hands-on experience about the various episodes in the lives of these two courageous fellows and their comrades, whose mission was to serve their country, no matter what.I personally liked the poems written about Germany, named "Spandau" and "The Wall".In the second half of the book there are poems about the harrowing experience as well as about those horrible times when both men were in Vietnam. Many poems in this section will hammer at you directly. Reading and rereading them will cause you to undergo various emotions. You will laugh, you will cry, you will feel anger or joy, you will be sharing helicopter flights or be a witness  to nature's wrath or beauty. And suddenly, without any previous warning, you will be tranported home, where"...no one cared!Only our families cared. Only our fellow veterans knew and cared.Our plights were sealed. No welcome home.No thanks for our service".Yet out of these desperate moments, you will also find hope and optimism, as demonstrated by Mr. Geschke's son, Scott, who urged his father to relive those times and spread his and Toto's truth for us all. Thus the end of a deep, touching and everlasting journey.Reading this short but poignant volume will definitely whet your appetite for some more poetry from those times, and I beseech both poets/ex-warriors for a follow-up. Chapeau, gentlemen!

I have decided to give this book 5 stars because it is  nicely  and copiously illustrated and, in addition, it is easy to read. It is far from being an academic tome, and it contains many short stories about the history of seafaring and famous sailors. You will meet some of the most famous names in the 3000-year history of the oceans as well as famous explorers who discovered new continents and worlds. Many episodes described were unknown to me.It also has a lot of info about new inventions related to all kinds of sea vessels. Take the ride and you won't be disappointed at all.

Unfortunately, this book suffers from a very major flaw: it is extremely boring. In spite of the author's well known fame and authority, the style of writing is an extrmely dry one.It does not matter whether you are famous, well known and excel as an academic. What really matters-when writing a book-is to keep the reader's interest, and here the author gets almost no points in his favour. Keep your hard-earned money for another author, who will, perhaps, know how to write about this aspect in the history of intelligence in a more interesting  and captivating way.

It's September 21, 1927. He is in his bedroom. A woman has just left. A disordered bed. An overturned scent bottle. A little gold box in which few traces of cocaine remain. A cold supper laid out on the table. D'Annunzio hasn't yet touched the food, but the woman ate some of it during the night. Now, alone, he eats ravenously. The fig and the prosciuto each remind him of the intimate parts of the woman he shared last night.This is just one almost complete entry which appears in this fascinating new book on one of the most colourful characters in modern history.Who was D'Annunzio? He was a poet, a seducer, a womanizer, a pilot, a writer, a playwright, a rebel, a leader of proto-fascists and of mutineers. He worshipped Napoleon. He admired Carlyle who would confirm the poet's veneration for great men and reinforce his conviction that it was not economic forces, as the socialists maintained, but the action of superb individuals that shaped history. Born in 1863, he wrote many novels and poems amd spent some time in Paris at the beginning of the twentieth century. These were the times when poets still had a say and were admired. James Joyce called him "the only European writer after Flaubert to carry the novel into new territory". He was also a journalist and yearned for public adoration. He was a notoriours womanizer who took care to document even the tiniest intimate moments of his sexual acts. His sexual appetite was insatiable. He enjoyed drugs and mysticism. And airplanes. And fast cars, courtesy of Fiat. The masses loved him. He was a demagogue and a kind of a Duce; at least this is how he referred to himself many years before the people and history made the acquaintance with the name of Mussolini.Then, in September 1919, he marched into what he called "The city of Holocaust, Fiume. This episode forms the second part of the book. A city "with a staccato history and mongrel population" sited at the northern part of the Adriatic, which has been one of the Austro-Hungarian Empire's two great Adriatic ports. At the end of WW1 it was occupied by Allied forces, but D'Annunzio thought it should belong to the Italians. He commanded over 200 ex-soldiers in the city until the Italian navy bombed him out. Afetr he left in 1921, over 200 people were killed and about one thousand were wounded in clashes between fascists and socialists. After this episode he would lead a lonely life, still enjoying sex with an  endless number of women. This was the man who considered death of the so many young soldiers not only dulce and decorum but also sublime.The many notebooks he left, his huge correspondence and literary output make it easy on his biographer, since he, and in this case Ms. Hughes, can render D'Annunzio's thoughts, tastes, emotions and physical sensations. As for the style  of writing this book, let me quote the author's words verbatim:" I have made nothing up, but I have freely made use of techniques commoner in fiction writing than in biography. I have not always observed chronological order; the beginning is seldom the best place to start. I have alternated legato narrative with staccato glimpses of the man and fragments of his thoughts".Because he was a public figure for over half a century, the author has been able to draw on dozens of others' records to show the  of him outside as well. In short, the book has many viewpoints about D'Annunzio.This is a splendid biography; in addition, is is also an excellent cultural histoy of Europe between 1880-1930. It shows to what extent other writers and philosophers have influenced D'Annunzio. Among those there were Nietzsche, Rolland, Dostoyevsky, Flaubert and Proust. Written in a very unique and special style, in-depth  and superbly researched, this very long biography containing over 700 pages of written text, will be unsurpassed for many years to come.

I  must confess that at the beginning I thought that I would give this book 5 stars. It is well written and the style is extremely elegant. Add the fact that there is not even one boring moment during its 362 pages of text.But.. Here come the "But".The problem with the book is at the end of end, ot to be more precise: with the last chapter, called "After Dallas". There, on page 353, Mr. Clarke remarks that:"What might have been" is speculation, but what Kennedy intended to do is not".To follow this line of thought and to develop it, one is supposed to supply evidence for such a statement. However, there is nothing which could satisfy the professional historian, since in the best case, this book takes a U-turn and becomes a counterfactual history.To discuss what Kennedy intended to do, one must have proof for it. Here Mr. Clarke produces some statements uttered by some presidential aides and other figures, but all in all, he sounds extremely unconvincing.On the very contrary, there is evidence that Kennedy has never given up the plan to get rid of Castro, and the best proof for this is the "Mongoose Plan", which was the brainchild of his brother, Bobby, and there is not even today one iota  of evidence in the archives to refute this claim. The Presidential Recordings of those times augment this view.I therefore rest my case. One can say that, in the best case, this book is a hagiography of Kennedy and nothing else. Or, it had to carry another subtitle called: "An  intellectual exercise in counterfactual history".

This book is far from being original. The book is a pastiche of well written and well known short summaries of various travelers to America. In a book like this, some chapters are more interesting, some are more boring. It is also meant for the average reader who does not have the faintest idea about this aspect in the history of America.

Most of us think of Victorian England in terms of conformity, imperialism and industrialisation, but this view is extremely limited. In the last years, historians have succeeded in demonstrating that Victorianism was not monolithic at all. It also included undercurrents such as feminism, anti-imperialism, occultism. environmentalism and other "isms". Thus the stable world of Victorian England was seething with many and varied ideas and ideals.In this fascinating and almost thriller-like written book, Professor Bloom presents a great number of some very unusual, peculiar men and women who did not conform to the rules of the masses and whose norms were different from those of the majority. Some of them are known; some of them are not. Some were considered insane, some were dispatched to asylums, some became gurus for a while, and others had utopian dreams and schemes. Among those you wil find here Arthur Conan Doyle, H. G. Wells, Richard Dadd and other madmen, Arthur Machen, Annie Besant, Charles Braudlaugh, Dan Chatterton, Aleister Crowley, John Hargrave and many others.Generally speaking, this is the history of how personal alienation and social revolution went(or didn't go) together during the nineteenth and the beginning of the twentieth centuries. The people mentioned above wanted to shake the foundations of the stable Victorian world order, and the culmination of this was to be found in World War One, when modernism was progressing rapidly, tearing down all the conformities of the previous century.As Professor Bloom writes, Queen Victoria "saw much, did nothing and said nothing, choosing, when convenient, to interfere in matters of lifestyle or of state, and to record her impressions in private journals'. To some, the old woman ruled for too long, causing England to freeze. However, even before her death, there were those who wanted a change. they rebelled against almost everything, and secularism was the religion of the intellectual mid-Victorians. Everything would be settled from now on by science and scientific methods, but there were those who despised science.Many have lost faith not only in God, but also in society itself, therefore they had to find other solutions to solve this problem. These included new diets, occultism, new utopian settlements, vegetarianism, nudism, while others looked to the East, to the Arab world or Hinduism to release them from the bourgeois desire and delusion. The city of God was to be replaced by the city of humanity.Darwinism solved nothing. Victoria's reign was haunted by rebels and revolutionaries. These are discussed in 19 chapters, each devoted to another aspect or angle. They include spiritualists, theosophists under the leadership of Madame Blavatsky, false Messiahs such as Joanna Southcott, socialists, the Fabian Society and its followers, anachists (some of them from Latvia) and emigres who came to England from Russia and other countries of the Continent, imperial adventurers, communists and many more. The old world order had to be blown into pieces, sometimes by violent means, sometimes by various pamphlets or writings. The revolutionary voices of the margins spoke against the center, a center seemingly so powerful as to be unshakeable.To quote, "the Victorian and Edwardian periods saw the fermentation of ideas regarding the state of the self and the meaning of the state that had far-reaching consequences; whether they came from Oscar Wilde's invention of celebrity or T.E. Lawrence work for Arab nationalism, from Crowley's Temple of Thelema or from forgotten anarchists whose incendiary methods punctured the century, the age was dedicated to an ideology of the realisation of the future which would be realised in deed and thought as the only future".In this nightmarish England, one could find escape or comfort in the inner world of the imagination, the world of self-consciousness, and Thomas De Quincey was to embody this trend. It was he who made the use of drugs respectable. Victorian morality was essentially based on personal and social restraint and a personality determined by restricion and guilt. If such restricions were breached, they might lead to indulgence and vulgarity. Having broken with society, the ego has nowhere to go except inward into a solipsistic and ever-neurotic search for the values beyond good and evil.People also wanted to return to a simpler life and reinvent themselves in natural surroundings, therefore John Ruskin's call to the workers to return to a healthy life of toil. Ruskin founded communities, workshops and workers' education schemes, but most failed.This book shows to what extent those outcasts had an influence on Victorian England, capturing the unrest bubbling under the surface the a strait-laced society. It is extremely well written and my only criticism is this: it lacks footnotes and some photos, although it contains a satisfactory bibliography. But all in all, this book is brilliant!

This book is just excellent and extremely well- researched and balanced, offering its reader the opportunity to see the other, most unpleasant  and racist side of Churchill who was, in the eyes of his comtemporaries and in the eyes of Truman and Eisenhower, an anachronism of Victorian England. Churchill sustained two blunders: Gallipoli and Singapore. Though obstinate, he could not come to terms with the fact that already in the forties, his empire was disintegrating, and this process has gained additional momentum particularly after the end of WW2.The adjectives used by him to describe various colonial leaders were notorious, even horrendous.One is not even allowed to use them in this review. Almost everyone of those politicians was prone to be attacked by him, especially Ghandi. The Bengal famine could also be attributed to Churchill, although Mr. James does not say so specifically.Enter the second part of the book which deals with the special Anglo-American relationship. Here Mr. James offers a splendid analysis and his conclusion is that there were almost no smooth waters running between the two countries when coming to deal with the problem of freedom and imperialism. On the contrary, Roosevelt has always abhorred  the idea of British colonialism and made no bones about it.Each and every page of this book is a jewel and it is more than highly recommenced!

These days only a handful men and women who are professional historians can interest and stimulate. The reasons vary, but I believe the main one is still the adage: Publish Or Perish.Thus most historians rush to publish books-histories or monographs-that are meant to be read by only some of their colleagues, in the hope of gaining some more kudos and perhaps earn some more points in order to advance at their respective departments.However, here comes Professor Fleming and proves that in spite of being a very erudite man  and one who is a famous Professor, he can also write for the masses a most enjoyable and readable book without any specific academic jargon.Indeed, this book is a gem and its purpose is to show that alonside the Enlightenment there was a Counter-Enlightenment, which contained many facets and elements. If one were to sum up the purpose of the anti-Enlightenment activists, one could easily say that those alchemists ,conmen, occultists and wizards wanted to attain a complete knowledge of everything.The book has many chapters about Contortionists, Kabbala, esoteric texts, weird persons, charlatans, writers, impostors, seances-you name it. You will meet many unknown figures and some very famous ones along the way.You will be in England, Germany, France and Italy and also in Egypt.Read this book and will get an insight into the mentality of some of the masses during the 17th to the early 19th century. This book is a treasure to be preserved for years.

Many books have already been written on almost every angle and aspect of the Roosevelt administration. This book takes a look at the Roosevelt years from the perspective of five men who went on fact-finding missions to Europe. Their assignment was to find out about various things, especially  those connected to England and its leadership. Roosevelt did not trust the State Department and thus had the opportunity to bypass it by sending these men to various countries.Although the book is an interesting read, it suffers from two very serious flaws. The first: it is only a collection of semi-detached biographies. The second: it leaves the reader to ponder about one question, which is as follows: so what? This volume is like an incomplete symphony and one is left wondering about the reason why it was written at all.In short, not my cup of tea.

General Pacepa must be praised for being a very courageous man. In his capacity as chief of the Securitate, he had demolished the security sevices of an entire country, which was ruled by th  barbarous monster Nicolae Ceausescu. Now, with this new book, he demolishes some other myths perpetrated by the nefarious KGB with the aid of its main tool, namely that of disinformation.The book has several sections dealing with various instances in history. One myth which this book destroys has to do with Pope Pius 12. So far, many people were-and are still- convinced that the Pope has remained silent during the Holocaust and did nothing to help the Jews who were massacred by the Nazi hordes. This is a myth which was well concocted by the Russians who did everything they could in order to besmirch the Catholic Church and its clergymen. In fact, the truth is that the Pope has done more than enough in order to help the Jews and Pacepa offers a very good explanation as to how this disinformation propaganda against the Pope's image came into being.Another interesting chapter has to do with the Kennedy murder. Kennedy was murdered by Lee Oswald, obeying an order from the Kremlin. No other evidence has been produced so far to counter this evidence. But there are still those who have pleasure in perpetuating the myth that the CIA and even  other US high officials have been reponsible for the assassination.Another part discusses in detail the anti-Semitic propaganda sown by the Kremlin and the Putin regime as well as the modus operandi against Islam and to what extent Russian propaganda is used against the Obama presidency.This is an excellent book, written in conjunction with Professor Richlak, and is packed with information nuggets on each page. This is mandatory reading for those who want to know and mainly understand how monstrous regimes produce propaganda campaigns whose aim is to falsify the truth.

Let me start the review by quoting a sentence which is to be found in the epilogue: " The purpose of this book has been to strip away the posthumous glamour and to bring alive the true genius of Disraeli".Indeed, the purpose of both authors has been achieved and they have done a very good job. The introduction is followed by eleven chapters, each dealing with another aspect of Disraeli. The book is written in chronological order and is a pleasure to read, due to the fact that the language is very vivid and the authors not only inform but also entertain their readers.Who was Disraeli? What is the reason that his personality is still fascinating others? In what way was he special? All these points are discussed in detail, although the volume is very short.Disraeli was a very complicated man. He was full of paradoxes and his deeds and personality still evoke a lot of controversies, in spite of the fact that previous authors had already written and covered any possible angle of his long life.Disraeli's main purpose in life was to become famous. Politics was the best and shortest way for him. But this was not enough. He was also seeking for constant excitement and, as the authors point out, this "could not be achieved in the solicitors' office where his father had secured him a place at the start of his career". Nor was it enough to enter the literary profession. Almost all his life in debt, Disraeli's name was soon known to everyone. He was a great womanizer who courted mainly married  and older women, perhaps due to the fact that his mother mother did not bestow upon him sufficient love. He finally decided to marry a woman twelve years older than him. Her name was Mary Anne and Disraeli remarked that she was more like a mistress than a wife. She would later die of stomach cancer and Disraeli never married again.He had many friends but also many enemies, the main one being Gladstone who was called by him "the Arch-Enemy. His other bitter rival was Robert Peel.On the other hand, Disraeli became the darling of Queen Victoria, because he very well knew how to flatter her.We are informed that there are eighty-eight quotations by him in the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations, compared to only fifty by Churchill.He was the first Jewish  Prime Minister and it was he who established the foundations of the Conservative Pary. Although baptized, he had never forgotten his Jewish  roots and was extremely proud of this fact.He presided over many social reforms and scored a famous triumph at the Congress of Berlin in 1878, thus enhancing British prestige. Disraeli despised the liberals and the middle-class values. As a matter of fact, he was far from being progressive and wanted to revive but improve the old ways of doing things.Both authors bemoan the fact that a figure like Disraeli is missing from today's politics. They mention the fact that he used his imagination tp make politics interesting. The public was fascinated with his speeches in the Commons. As Lord Curzon put it later on, Disraeli "was like a conjuror on a platform whose audience with open mouths awaited the next trick". And this is precisely  the problem the authors identify with today's politicians.The authors dispel many myths surrounding Disraeli, such as the phrase "One Nation" which, they claim, was never used by him. In fact, much of the book is devoted to the mythology of Disraeli and the reasons it has been growing over the years after his death. We therefore have two lives of him, the real one and the mythological one.The book, which is a fresh look at one of the greatest British Prime Ministers , is extremely well-researched and also a great pleasure to read.

This is perhaps the best book that has ever been written on the Vietnam war, documenting the most hideous crimes perpetrated by the USA army against innocent civilians. It is just enough to give one example from the hundreds listed in this brilliant book. The son of General Patton, who was part of the US army, kept on his desk a skull and many other body parts of Vietnamese civilians who were brutally murdered by the American troops. Like father, like son, for his father was the one who in 1943 slapped the face of some soldiers who suffered from battle fatigue.This book will make you sick but at last we have an almost complete picture of what had really happened in Vietnam. But one should not only blame the army. One should consider Johnson, Nixon, Mcnamara and especially Kissinger as war criminals, since there is no difference between them and the Nazis who faced the judges  at Nuremberg. Mr. Turse should get at least 2 Pulitzers for this book. More than highly recommended!

The name of Dr. Clemens Benda does not say much to many people. Benda emigrated from Germany during Hitler's rise to power in the 1930s and would become one of the most respected doctors in the United States. However, this respected physician was in fact a monster who was responsible for injecting radiation into children's bodies in order to see its effect on the very young. These experiments were conducted at the MIT with the help of other facilities and in this respect he was not alone. Some children aged between one and eleven years old, who were found at various institutions, were given other lethal doses of radioactive iodine, while this time the project was being coordinated by researchers from Harvard Medical School and the Boston University School of Medicine. Some of these miserable children suffered from Down syndrome and other forms of mental retardation. All this happened during the forties when the Cold War was played out between the major powers. One of the sponsors of these experiments was the CIA. One of its physicians informed a class of recruits in the 1960,"Our guiding light is not the Hippocratic Oath but the victory of freedom". It was clear that the USA had fallen behind the Soviets with regard to its chemical warfare capability and the immediate need to come up to speed in preparation for some future enemy attack. It was also equally clear that research scientists "could not fulfill this mission by animal experiments alone. Human test subjects would be needed; fortunately, most experienced reserchears already knew where to look for volunteers". Nearly seven dozen institutions took CIA money 'many of them for the purpose of plying American citizens with hallucinogenic cocktails and more".One American neurologist, Walter Freeman, would become a leading figure and a specialist in carrying out lobotomies on children.  He was a disciple of Egas Moniz, a Portuguese physician who proselytized the attributes of lobotomy in the fight against a variety of psychological disorders. Freeman once performed lobotomies on 25 women in one day. Ergo, if lobotomies could produce improvements in adults with serious mental problems, it could do the same for children. Hundreds of lobotomies were performed on a vast array of patients including "11 individuals whose schizophrenia developed before the age of ten".Other feebleminded children or idiots placed in American orphanages were also subject to various and hideous experiments-all conducted in the name of scientific progress. This was the extension of the eugenic movement ideology which ran wild during the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th.This book demonstrates the huge hypocrisy of the American scientific establishment. On the one hand, it criticized heavily the atrocious deeds committed by the Nazis, as has been shown by the Nazi trials after the war. On the other hand, the same critics perpetrated almost the same crimes, but this time their motivation was the Cold War ideology.Some doctors wanted to conduct clinical trials and were motivated by noble causes, but others were motivated by greed and fame. By behaving in this way, they forgot or gave up their Hippocratic Oath and routinely trafficked in children to operationalize some bit of medical research. The guinea pigs were poor children who were given tests to see how vaccines worked; in what way radioactive foods had an influence on the body, and  some were even injected with LSD. Others were subjected to lobotomies and electric shock treatments.If you thought that at the beginning of the 21st century things like the ones described before stopped, you are wrong. As the authors point out, American institutions have been replaced by China, India, Tunisia and Nigeria as sites for Phase One drug studies. Drug firms now travel to "places where regulation is virtually nonexistent, the FDA  does not reach, and the mistakes can end up in pauper's graves".To tell the truth, this book will make you sick. It becomes a burden on the reader and it shows to what extent the most noble and respected scientists and doctors became monsters. This book is about science gone absolutely mad and the authors have written an excellent book documenting for many years the horrible deeds committed in the name of scientific progress. This book can also serve as a severe warning of how a respected community of men and women can go mad when nobody controls them. It is about moral amnesia and ethical paralysis of those in the medical and psychological reaerch professions who became totally perverted. Highly recommended!

I am terrified that I'll be attacked by sharks. Living in the Midwest may not expose me to many opportunities for shark attacks, but the occasional sharknado is bound to happen. Fortunately, this shark repellent has come along to alleviate my fears. I continued to use this product for months completely shark free and was content with its use. Then, a few weeks ago my wife took me to the aquarium, and what did I see? A bunch of freaking sharks! What if a tornado hits that aquarium? Will I be able to protect myself from the flying death? I'm not so convinced, so I give this product a three stars.

I was very impressed with this writer. Worked great, burns DVD and Blueray quickly and efficiently. Was able to install a new operating system and run live disks without a problem. I wanted to be able to burn some bluerays for backup and it allowed me to do that, so no complaints here.
