I like the chain my wallet to my pants, so I wanted a nice chain so I didn't have to settle for the limited number of wallets that come with a preexisting chain. It has worked fairly well for me. The clip is sturdy and the chain is sufficiently long enough to comfortably use my wallet while it is attached to my pant loop.The clip did bend out of shape for a while, and I have to bend it back into place. However, ever since that has happened it has worked fine, so I don't have too much to complain about.

The product looks like the image. I purchased it to attach to a lab coat, since I work in a frog lab and thought it would be cute. It's nice, shiny, and solid looking patch. However, as far as an iron on attachment, I spent a large amount of time ironing it on as carefully as possible to make sure it attached to my pocket strongly.In the end, it looked good... for about 24 hours. Then the patch started coming off. Not after x amount of washes, or wearing it for days on end, or doing any kind of strenuous activity with it. No, this broke down after a single day of light use. I'll of course sew the badge on instead. However, as an iron -on badge it's basically useless. The adhesive clearly doesn't work well. For a patch this expensive I'd expect a little bit better.

I purchased the original banana slicer in order to cut my banana up and found that I was unable to get through the peel. I ended up returning it and purchasing this one. I figured two banana slicers would double the slicing power, however I suffered mixed results. I looked online and found out I needed a Hutzler Banana Peeler 621q to use in tandem with the slicer 571b. I wish they would just package them together. It's how they rope you in, first you buy the slicer only to realize you need the peeler. I'm currently saving up for the Hutzler Banana Masticator 821h. The banana is not going to chew itself, is it?

I got this cover shortly after purchasing my samsung galaxy tab 3 and wanting to protect my tablet. I'd prefer to get something nicer, but I really haven't found anything that fits my tastes within my price range yet. I can say the product works. It holds the tablet and protects it. It allows you to stand the tablet up as well, however, it does not do a good job the this. All it gives is a small cloth crevice for the tablet to sit on, and it's not deep or sturdy enough to keep the tablet upright while doing anything above light tapping on the screen. Don't expect to be able to type on the tablet with this case holding it up.The case falls apart pretty quickly as well. The case still works, and although the plastic ring that holds the back to the fold over part together ripped apart, I was able to put it back together and it hasn't ripped apart again. The edges where the case folds is cracked from age. Furthermore, there are several chunks on every edge where the green has worn away to the plasticy black underneath. This is only with about 4 months of wear and tear here. So this doesn't really hold up too well.Surprisingly, the black strap that allows you to close the case totally has held up. I would have expected that to stretch out to uselessness or rip very quickly, and so far its held, so that is nice. Two other issues with it, first, it covers up the Infrared port, so if you like to use it as a remote when your in bed and lazy, you'll have to pull it out of the case. Secondly, if you really drop your tablet while the strap isn't on, it's about a 50/50 whether the tablet jumps out of the case and goes teetering off. So it will protect normal wear and tear, and if you remember to close your case when you walk around it's fine, but during use when it's open, the case can potentially not protect the tablet at all.Anyway, with all that, I think 3 stars is fair. It's cheap and it's still the case I am using. Short of the otterbox, which doesn't make a 10.1 tab3 for some reason, Its good enough.

This is the second massage table I've ever purchased and I honestly have no real complaints. It is stable and light enough for my needs. My wife and I simply use it at home to pamper each other and it has worked fine for that. We weigh in the 300 lbs range and haven't come into any problems as long as we are careful getting on.The previous similarly priced ($100 shipped) massage table I purchased didn't have the arms and consisted of a metal bottom. In some ways I like the wood legs better than the metal. The "height" adjustment knobs on each leg isn't easy to adjust, but it seems slightly easier than my previous massage table. The arms on the sides fit with cheap wooden dowels as well, one of which is difficult to slide in because it's blocked by the handles that allow you to pick up the table when it's folded, but once again that is a minor thing.Finally, there is a bit of chemical smell that I get from it. I haven't made a major attempt to completely clean the table with something to counteract the smell, so I can't say how badly it prevails, however, it is less overpowering than many other cheap products I've purchased before.All in all, it's a nice, professional looking table. It serves the purpose I keep it for and that's really all I can hope for from it for the price spent.

With kids I had two requirements for getting a TV stand. First, it had to be flush with the floor so I wouldn't have to dig out all of the stuff my kids drop there. Second, I wanted glass/plastic across the front so I could use remote controls but keep my devices in relative safety from my kids. The Tv stand met these criteria perfectly.I should have read the finer print a little closer, as it ended up being a bit smaller than I had expected. I suppose it's my fault for mistaking this with it's larger cousin that is frequently sold at Walmart. However, at the price they sell it for, I was a little disappointed. It's really quite small and not worth more than $100. Still, it does what I wanted it to. The cinnamon cherry color comes off as close to black. Except in a very light home it will probably appear very dark in color.There is assembly required. I was able to assemble it fairly easily. Oddly, the way it's assembled only makes it flush with the ground on 3 of the four sides. In the back, it has no piece, so the entire tv stand rests on only 3 sides. It was not a big deal, but still a little strange. Furthermore, the stand I received turned out to have other issues. One of the edges was unfinished. It is not noticeable when fully assembled unless you open the glass doors, but it is still a mistake and I am certain not a result of something I did wrong in assembly.Other than that, the TV stand seems to work fine for a TV stand. I would probably not have boughten this if given a second chance, but I can make due and it is OK.

It's benefits, bigger than average letters and bright yellow coloring is very apparent. It clearly meets both of these needs, which is the primary purpose of this keyboard. It has the clickity clacky keys rather than the soft kind, so don't expect typing to be "quiet". For some reason, they decided to make the delete key much smaller in exchange for a slightly larger enter key, which seems counter intuitive to the point of the ez eyes portion of the keyboard.One of the reasons I went for the keyboard was the claim to being spill resistant. This was a complete hoax. As a matter of fact, this broke down more easily than previous keyboards. A single spill, not directly on the keyboard, completely decimated it. A completely false claim. It also lacks the finger divots at F and J for guidance when performing "proper" typing, another thing that I'd expect from a keyboard designed to make keyboarding easier.Other than that, it works like any other keyboard. If it fits the aesthetics of your home or if you have bad eyes and need it, this can be a functional keyboard for you, but it's claims are a little exaggerated. It's like every other cheap keyboard except it has yellow keys and bigger bold letters. It loses a star for the spill resistance claim, and it loses a star for the delete key being smaller.

I recently started playing Bully Scholarship edition on the xbox 360 and found the game to be an enjoyable experience. I did not have the pleasure of having played the original so I cannot compare it to that. I have however played GTA4, GTA3 through San Andreas, and many other open boxes like it, so I can compare it to those.Graphics: The graphics are not top notch, but I have no real complaint here. They are adequate and don't detract from the game experience. I can tell that things are what they are, there are no creepy disfigured heads like you might see in a bethesda game, so it is good enough for me.Gameplay: The gameplay is very similar to what you might face in San Andreas. The "scope" of the game has certainly been peeled back substantially. The only vehicles that you can use are bicycles, skateboards, and mopeds. The handling isn't great, but you won't be thrown off at every turn with half of your life gone like the GTAs. The university combines with several little towns to make the map you can travel around on, and in Traditional GTA fashion, the map gets unlocked 1/3 at a time as you play. They add emoticons allowing you to interact with people in your environment. This is quite nice, allowing you to grab and bully people, harass them, approve, or threaten them. It's reminiscent of the Fable series in that respect and does very well.Story: This is a major faltering for me. The story is essentially about a troubled boy sent off to a "boarding school" of sorts while his mom goes on a honeymoon with his new step dad. He possesses a lot of angst as a result of his rough upbringing. Through the help of a boy named gary, he ends up getting involved in clique wars. All of this is interesting and fine. What isn't is the cohesion in this story. Hint, it has none. Pretty much every mission in the game involves you being called to someones office, an event that happens completely off camera with no beepers/cellphones/text messages to tell you why you are going to this spot and starting this mission, or they occur as a result of you randomly walking by and getting pulled into something.In GTA games, it's usually a natural progression of things. Missions you do for this guy causes you to meet the next guy who in turn introduces you to the next guy. And when a friend you haven't quested for in a while wants to meet up, they send you a text, beep, ect... and say something. In this game, you just wonder to each other checkpoints, often based on time. All and all, the complete lack of cohesion really hurts and otherwise great story.Timing: This is a major gripe with the game, the day/night cycles. The first thing that is frustrating is that many many missions are timed based, so you can seriously be stuck for 4-5 hours (game time) waiting for a mission to repop up so you can do it. During the day you are required to attend classes, doing so prompts great bonuses and not doing so gets people searching for you for being truant. Then, you have a few hours and then you are up passed curfew and violating that. But wait, there is more. Assuming you are fine having to constantly dodge the teachers and cops, you will simply pass out unconscious if you stay up any later than 2ish. Prompting you to have to race back to a bed less you collapse in the street. Which is fine if sleeping in a bed saved the game as it should, but it doesn't. So to recap, about 3/4 of the day you are "breaking the rules" and will be chased down by anyone who sees you, and you pretty much HAVE to go to the bed every night for no reason other than cause you have to. The ONLY way to save is by logging it in a book near the bed, so no autosaves after missions.Glitches: I don't really care about visual glitches, and so far my game has never frozen completely, but even now, on the newest xbox system, on a hard drive installed version of the game, with all of the patches they have done over the years, the game still has significant slow down issues. This is especially frustrating during the dozens of minigames the game offers, I've had it happen during rhythm based games and completely lost as a result.Minigames: Loads and loads of them. It's one of the main things that GTA4 lost and I am glad this place kept. There are tons and tons of minigames, from "mowing the grass" to arcade games to dodge ball. They are all simplistic and I can't say any of them are as time consuming or engaging as Blitzball from FFX, but they are all mildly amusing and I don't think I was sick of any of them by the time the game was over.Other Annoyances: The other annoyances is that most of the other weapons you can get don't really do much. You'll be finding yourself always using the slingshot with it's infinite ammo, as the eggs are limited, the itching powder and stink bombs are practically useless, the firecrackers can occasionally help on a surprise, but once an enemy is running after you it is basically pointless, you will never get enough distance from them to really make use of it. So all and all the many options you can wield only come to play when filling specific mission criteria. Another annoyance is the shear number of people that run up to you demanding that you "help" them. A few is fine, but it's almost as annoying as the cellphone from GTA4, and you'll quickly find yourself ignoring them and their constant pleas for help, especially with a day so limited in time, where doing what they ask means missing out on your class/mission.The final "annoyance" comes down to the lack of replayability. In the GTAs, it used to be fun going crazy and ending up with 6 stars while you outrun/avoid swat trucks, tanks, and the army; or trying to make crazy leaps, or jumping out of an airplay and going sky diving. You get none of that here. You are just a single guy with fists, and if you warrant stars you either run and hide or face the consequences. Very little options in the ways of mayham here, and very little worth doing other than to acquire the 100% achievements.Overall: So overall it's a good game. It gets 3 stars for the complaints I have with it, but it still has a good story, fun gameplay, and some unique things. The social aspects and the capacity to bully people is really fun, and a feature I wish they'd add to GTA. The story and play is very unique and with the number of minigames it has it is well worth a try. I would definitely consider it if you can get it for cheap, but I wouldn't spend more than $10 on it at this point.

I had purchased Xcom UFO Defense many years ago back when it was first released. In fact, it was one of the first video games I had ever beat. I continued playing with Terror in the Deep and even tried Interceptor during it's time. These games are strategy games. You are an elite group of soldiers battling back an unknown alien enemy that threatens earth and every government. Using government funding, you purchase supplies, build a base, shoot down ufos, land at the sites and mop up any survivors, then take their technology, research it, and build better weapons to rinse and repeat.Every level is a little different. The ufo crash sites are randomly generated and you function via turn based combat, using statistics to make your shots and cover to block theirs. The game is a clever mixture of inventory management, turn based strategy, with a little bit of base building thrown in. Some of you may  have heard about Xcom Enemy Unknown, essentially a remake/reboot of the original, and while I am excited to see that coming, it will be hard to beat the original.Anyway, this is a great game package and easily one of my favorites. The graphics are incredibly dated, so do not expect pretty sprites (think preNES), but for all 5 games this is a great package.The download process is performed through steam. I only mention this because of several one star reviews I noticed. Steam is an online gaming management program offered (and required) through valve... and is "the" way most people buy games these days. Complaining about it's existence is kind of like complaining how you have to rent games through netflix or redbox because all of the blockbusters are disappearing. Sure you CAN complain about it, but it isn't going to change anything. This game CANNOT be played on any modern computer without some significant skill using DOSBOX and modded installation files. Steam, and other sites like it, are pretty much one of the few ways to play this game now a days (plus the hard copy of these games run $100+).So a great game if you can get passed the fact that it uses the modern convention of steam and is an old old dated game. However, certain games; FF6, Civilization 2, Super Mario Brothers 3; seem to survive the tests of time and I definitely see these as being part of those games. I of course speak mostly about UFO Defense and Terror of the Deep... the other three games never really did it for me, but they are extra gravy for those who love this IP and still worth the price of admission.I also should add I was able to pick it up for $2.99 during a sale, and you can purchase it for $14.99 regularly at most places. If you absolutely hate steam, I'd recommend heading over to gamer's gate to get it, since it uses a "less unified" system to download your games. I actually already own the game and deliberately repurchased it so that I had it on steam with the rest of my games, but that's all just down to personal preference.

My wife purchased this apron in for the Kitchen because she occasionally works with things messy enough to require it and thought it would be fun to have. As it turns out, it's a pretty decent Apron. It's made out of a good strong material, rather than something cheap and flimsy. The print is as depicted, so if you like the print I see no reason you shouldn't like the apron. Its a good size, so if you are a plus size woman it should fit fine as well. It's length reaches roughly the knees of a 5'4'' woman. So if you like the design and need an apron, go for it.

I had an old N64 for that we decided we wanted to get up and running for my son. We thought it would be a good way to get him to use a system a little simpler than the xbox 360 to move his way up. We previously found he didn't like the Wii... and we sold it besides. So the N64 is what we got.The cord I received was broken. The audio played, but the video would not. Since the system hadn't been up in running in years, we weren't sure if it was the system or the cord. Instead of sending a replacement, as I expected, they wanted to send us a refund, which seemed more effort than it was worth for a $2 refund. So in the end I ended up buying one from someone else on ebay.The cord works as expected for an N64... presuming you get a working one. It is a cheaply made cord and probably a bit shorter (only 3 feet), as most cords were back in the day, so take that into account. If ours had arrived working, I probably would have given it four stars. The other star is taken off simply because it is composite, short, and cheaply made, but if you have an N64... this is what you need to get it working.As a side note, you can plug a composite cable into a component. Simply plug the yellow prong into the components green and it "usually" works. So if that's a concern of yours, it can be done with most TVs, even if you don't have enough composite inputs.

My father needs reading glasses these days and typically purchases them in bulk at the dollar store, tossing a pair away whenever he breaks it. That has always worked for him, but I decided it would be nice to get him a better pair, especially since he seems to be using them more often than he used to.There isn't too much to say about the Magnivision Hyperflexx. One of the ideal things about it is that it comes at the strength of 2.25, which turned out to be my father's newest prescription. 2.25 is a harder to find number at your typical department store kiosk, where 2.00 and 2.50 seem to be the only numbers available. My father had to settle for a 2.00 because he couldn't find the 2.25, so first off it was nice to be able to find a set that was his prescription.The lens are a thin plastic; unobtrusive and nice looking. They are not too large as to look ridiculous and are actually a tad smaller than I would have thought from the picture. However, they do seem to match up to the picture pretty well in appearance.The final thing to mention would be the frames themselves. By Hyperflexx, I am sure most people are thinking in the back of their heads that it is a frame with memory metal like the flexon brand where you can wrap them around your finger and have them snap back into place. These are a cheap knock off and I doubt they are really memory metal despite the claim. Now, I wasn't going to put the frames to the test and risk breaking my father's birthday present, but I did play with it slightly. The frames do have a certain degree of "give". You can bend them a bit and they will retain their shape, but bend too much and you will bend the metal. So they seem to be made more from a "pliable" metal more than a "memory" metal. Still, they are the best available if you are not interested in buying a $100 pair of reading glasses with full price frames, and could probably survive you accidentally sitting on them (which I believe is how my dad loses most of his reading glasses).So to sum it up, they are a cheap knock off of the flexon brand that flex to an extent. They come in prescription sizes not easily found in a store and of a better quality than most. A great purchase for someone who needs reading glasses and doesn't want to break the bank, but still want something a little better than your kiosk variety glasses at your local walgreens.

You'll find numerous reviews talking about how this product was manufactured many years ago, and the rechargeable batteries that make it up have since expired. I trust this is true as I had trouble finding a pink remote at the time that I wanted one, so they seem to be out of make. The price at $4.99 which is $5 less than most of the other batteries reflects the potential that it may not work.In the end, I decided to chance it both because I didn't have too much to spend, and had a pink remote without a matching rechargeable battery. I suppose I ended up lucky, as the battery charges fine and holds a charge for as long as I'd expect. Is it worst than one I purchased brand new from a store? Maybe, but if there has been any discrepancy I haven't noticed it yet.It is the normal microsoft xbox battery still in the original packaging and it costs me half of what any other color would cost me. I have no regrets purchasing this product, but I do acknowledge that had I been one of the unlucky ones that uncovered a dud I might not feel that way. In the end, you will have to decide if the risk is worth it. If you are wrong, you can always return it for a refund or keep replacing it until you do get one that works, but you need to decide if the trouble is worth the potential savings/color.

This is made out of a very lightweight wood designed pretty much to be torn apart. It accomplishes it's job pretty well.It can be very messy with the destruction left behind, but I suppose you can expect that from a toy designed to be destroy.Here's the warning I provide. Depending on the destructiveness of your bird, or rather, how much your bird likes to chew, this toy might not last much more than a day. So if you know your bird is a light chewer, then this might be a nice toys to rebuy whenever the last one is gone. But if your bird is a heavy chewer, $8 is a lot to pay for something you might need to replace weekly. I'd recommend you find a new more affordable chewing device.I like the product, it's definitely 5 stars, but just be wary of the cost if you have a bird you know will tear it up quickly.

I have a Debryan Parakeet and wanted to give her a way to eat that utilizes her foraging instinct. The foraging sphere looked like it would accomplish this.Like many bird toys, the forage sphere feels pretty homemade. In order to open it to put food in it, you have generic nuts that you unscrew, then pull the entire metal bar out to pull apart the plastic. I can't say it's the most innovative or effective system. You have pull out the entire sphere, pull it completely apart, then put it back together every time you need to do a food fill.The holes themselves are pretty large, and there is a fairly limited selection of items that would be a good fit. We found millet sticks do not work well, as it gets pushed up and becomes out of the birds reach. We found that most of the seed based foods we give her would simply fall right through the cracks. I think that most fruits and vegetables would be a pain, particularly as I expect the moisture from said vegetables would rust the metal component over time.As a result the best food I have found to effectively use the sphere are nuts. Peanuts work great, but most kind of nuts (still in the shells) seem to work well for this system.The Kabobbed food in the picture is a suggestion and I suppose you could spear something to put up there, but you run into two issues. First, you have the loop on one side and the bell on another, so spearing any food would require you to remove the bell. Second you still have the concern that the fruits you could spear would rust the metal over time.For my bird, she typically uses the system by hanging from the ceiling and munching on it from above with her head wrapped around the ball. The issue is, since the entire assembly is put together by a bolt that you are expected to rebolt and unbolt every time you want to add food, it can vary easily unscrew. More than once my bird has sent the toy plunging to the bottom of her cage.So does my bird like it? I suppose it's an innovative way to give her nuts. I would probably buy it again if I had to, but it does have it's faults. It feels (and looks) very handmade. The drillhole the metal bar goes through has microcracks coming from it like it was a poor job. The whole thing is assembled by universal nuts and bolts. But it is still a decent system. I give it 3 stars, because it's decent at what it does, and because I didn't expect that much from it. The bird seems to like it (or at least the nuts in it) and it gives her something to do during the day when she is in the mood.

The following item is a Gender Prediction Test, and I was naturally interested in taking a closer look at it. Some people argue that is it 100% correct 50% of the time, declaring that it randomly picks a specific sex, and that it is always right with half the people who buy it. This is not how the test works at all.In reality, the test is a scientific analysis of a wive's tale. The wive's tale is this, A person with acidic urine theoretically is more likely to carry a girl, where as a more alkaline or basic urine would mean you are carrying a boy. This test just boils down to a significantly overpriced set of litmus paper, which you can buy here at amazon for $2 or so.Urine is typically considered a 7.0 in pH, ranging from slightly basic to slightly acidic, where seven is roughly the same as water. If your strip reads in the 8 or 9 range, the wive's tale suggests it should be a boy. If it reads 6 range, the wife's tale should suggest it's a girl. If you are REALLY on top of things, you can take the readings BEFORE you get pregnant to establish a baseline, and then see whether it is higher or lower when you actually get pregnant.However, in the end, I must point out that this IS a wive's tale, and nothing more than a fancy way of practicing the dozens of other inaccurate ways to predict if it's a boy or girl from peeing on baking soda to heartbeat speed to where it sits in the uterus. The only accurate way to tell the sex of a baby is by ultrasound, and even that's not 100%, the error spawning from that pesky human element.So save yourself $20 and buy the $2 litmus paper if you are looking to have a little fun "trying" to predict the gender of the baby, but if the color coding and plastic casing are enough to motivate you to spend the extra money, you are welcome to it.I'd recommend for the most accurate readings to restrain yourself to a very bland diet a day or two before trying the test, don't want a glass of orange juice or a spicy chipotle potentially effecting the pH of your urine and giving your test a "false" result.Good luck with the Pregnancy! The ultrasound says mine is a girl, and 75% of the wive's tales pointed to girl, so you never know.

If you don't feel like reading what I wrote, I put the pro's and con's at the end of this review. I have recently been eating healthier and one of the many changes was to give up soda and sugary drinks and dedicate myself to the art of tea. As much fun as it is to constantly brew tea with the coffee machine, I really wanted something that did it a better job producing ice tea, and after much looking I found it here.There is a rather limited number of ice tea makers at the consumer level, I've tried just about all of them. My parents are big tea drinkers and have had a pitcher of tea always made since I was born. One of the main things I was looking for was a "universal" tea brewer. In other words, one that does not require the pitcher to function. I found that with this ice tea maker, which offers a drip function that you can be used with any pitcher you want.So far, this is a great tea maker and I love it for most of it's properties. The pitcher has measuring aids on the side, and a screw on top that functions as both the brewing top and serving top. This tea maker consists of three cups with handles that fit together within it's main compartment. The first cup handles "loose tea", which is absolutely perfect as I recently switched to loose tea (as it contains more of the health benefits than processed tea bags). Having a compartment specifically designed for it is wonderful.The second compartment contains the area you would put tea bags. Finally, the third compartment underneath those first two contains where you would put a sweetener. The first thing I need to mention is that this is NOT a sweet tea maker. For those of you who don't know, sweet tea is tea with insane amounts of sugar in it. So if you are expecting to dump cups of sugar into this machine and expect it all to trickle down and mix perfectly, it won't happen. In fact, I expect the machine to clog and flood, accounting to half of these one star reviews.This machine is designed to make iced tea, not sweet tea, so while it contains a compartment for sugar, you are only expected to add a couple tablespoons to give it a sugar accent. I personally use honey, and it works splendidly with no clean up after. I imagine if you are creative you could also use berries, mint, or other fruits if you wanted to add a hint of another flavor.All three compartments easily slip out, allowing you to actually clean every part of the filter. The issue with this is if you don't put every piece back perfectly, I can see it becoming a leak disaster. The tea tastes good, the brewing is quick, and this ice tea maker takes up a lot less space than most of the other brands out there.The tea maker isn't perfect though. There are three issues I had with it. The first issue is that when filling the water basin with water, there is no indicator of how full you should fill it or whether it is full. You are required to keep pouring until you see the water rising and pray you don't overflow. There is an indicator on the pitcher which you can use as a guide.The second issue is that this tea maker is designed to brew everything then mix with copious amounts of ice. It's kind of designed to make "instant" ice tea. This means the tea it brews is relatively less strong (relative to the coffee maker). Mind you, the coffee maker tea needs to be diluted down. I don't feel that the tea from the Westbend needs to be diluted down at all... although it gets a little bit of dilution from all of the ice you are expected to add.The third and final issue is that the pitcher top is designed to receive the tea (through holes on the top), but those holes are always there. So when you switch from brewing to serving, you have a pitcher with a lid that has enough holes that it might as well not be covered at all. I know a normal pitcher doesn't exactly make a airtight seal, but I still like the comfort that hair, dust, bugs, and "fridge smell" are at least being blocked a little by a pitcher, and this gives none of that comfort.So I give this a 4 star review because I think it's the best ice tea maker I have bought to date, but it still has a few issues, enough to knock the ice tea maker down a star.Pros:-Takes up less space than most teamakers.-Can use any pitcher you can fit under it to brew.-Has a unique compartment for adding sweeteners/flavor enhancers.-Can disassemble entire brewing compartment for cleaning.-Includes a loose tea basket-Makes tea immediately, no need to dilute or mix with water(presuming you have the amount of ice it asks for)Cons:-Brews a weaker tea than it could.-Has no indicator when filling the water basin.-Pitcher top provides insufficient protection to external elements.-Can only put a small amount of sweetener in sweetener tray or it won't absorb.-It can't make sweet tea.

My wife purchased these dryer balls for Christmas and I personally don't know much about the alleged things that dryer balls can do for you. My clothing doesn't really suffer from static cling. I imagine fluffiness is a pretty subjective term and the type of cloths you use, temperature of the water, detergent, and softener all effect the fluffiness of your clothing far before a couple of balls.The reason we purchased these balls is because our dryer isn't the greatest, we tend to load it up with clothing, and occasionally some of that clothing gets knotted up or stuck in other pieces of clothing (sheets, towels, ect...) causing the material to stay wet. The natural agitation of the machine is insufficient for all of the clothing to dry completely some times.In comes these balls, which add greater agitation and help keep clothing knocked apart, as a result the clothing dries faster and more efficiently. For someone who uses autodry with a sensor, this might even save you energy. You might even be able to have shorter dry cycles, which considering that drying is the slowest step of doing laundry, is a definite plus.I give it 5 stars because these are cheap, plastic balls that go in your dryer. I don't know why anyone who expects miraculous changes to their wash and I can't imagine one companies dryer balls functioning better or worse than another (unless it actually causes real damage to the washer, which this one doesn't seem to so far.)So for the capability of dryer balls and a price of only $5, I say it's a 5 star product, as it does exactly what a dryer ball does.

I have a Sony Walkman mp3 player which I love to use. To me, it runs superior to any modern ipod or ipod touch. The one problem with it is the lack of internal Bluetooth.I actually use my mp3 player a lot at work. However, the cords often got caught on things I was working with or on clothing and more than once I suffered my mp3 player crashing to the floor or headphones being ripped out of my ears. My goal was simply to prevent this by happening by purchasing both the Blubridge here and a pair of bluetooth headphones. The bluebridge will plug into anything with the appropriately sized audio jack.The device uses bluetooth. For anyone still questioning what bluetooth is, the easiest way to describe it is the USB of wireless. It's simply wireless connection that tends to be very stable and more importantly uninterrupted by most other signals (like wireless phones). If you have a computer or TV, and are looking for a wireless solution, there are better options out there for you. For a simple mp3 player, this seemed like my best and only option.So how does it function? Well enough. I use it all day at work, and after letting it charge over night, it remains functional for about 6-7 hours of continuous use. It plugs into the mp3 player well and feels sturdy and reliable. It seems to work better when on a stable nonmoving surface (as opposed to your pocket) and will cut out sometimes when in the pocket. It also seems to have trouble functioning outdoors, as sometimes while I am outside it will become unusable. The range doesn't handle corner at all, so if there is a wall between you and it, the signal cuts. Range seems to be roughly 20 feet, give or take.My biggest complaint about the blubridge is that it's design is too simple. You only get one button for on/off and connect. It constantly flashes it's LED light when on, and there is literally no indication of it's battery life is up until a red warning light comes on, only occasionally.On the plus side, it does transmit signal well, and when I am listening to my music or audio books, it is clear and good.So I give the device 3 stars. I might consider 3.5 but I think it just falls short for me. Considering you still need to buy the blutooth headset in order to use this device, it is a bit pricy and simplistic for a $30 item.

This is a cheap affordable grill set for two. I can't say I was overly impressed by the quality of the tools it came with. The bag is quite small and portable when zipped up, great for taking to the park or a grill-out, however zipping it up is pretty awkward as the bag has one zipper to pretty much do the job of two.The brush is standard hair bristles, so once you use them a handful of times that is about it. The rest of the tools are sturdy enough to use, and will probably hold together a couple of years, but if you are a heavy griller you will probably want something else.I am content with it for what it was, a cheap, easily portable grill set so that we have something to work with. It's compact case might make it perfect for campers and light grillers, but anyone serious about grilling should probably avoid it. If it was more expensive or I was bigger into grilling, I might have given it a 3 star, but I am pretty content with it for what I expected at $10, so I give it a 4 star.

The Avenir Velcro seat bag works well for it's intended purpose. It attaches, holds well, and will carry your things. I give a three star simply because it is much much smaller than I expected it to be. The pictures available, at least to me, are very misleading. I expected the bag to be about twice it's actually size, but upon receiving it, realized it is actually very small.At best, the bag will hold particularly small things, like keys, or a cellphone. If you expect it to hold larger things (in my case, I wanted it to be able to hold my bag lunch), I believe it would prove to be insufficient.Just be careful when you are looking at the size, 106 cubic inches is not as large as it sounds. I can't imagine, being as this claims to be the "large" size, how small a small size would be. I knock off two stars because of the size, but not any more because that is partially my responsibility to ensure the item is big enough.Other than that, it feels sturdy and functional, so there is not much else you can say about a bag.

I thought it might prove beneficial for people to read a review from someone who essentially does genotyping(this test) as part of his job.I ordered this test because we purchased a dog from the pound and had no clue what breed she was. The test is a pretty simple one, providing you with two q-tips that allow you to gather DNA from your dogs cheek. You essentially get two chances to acquire decent DNA to send to them, so make sure they count. This is the first point where I felt the instructions could have been better. Contaminating DNA is easy, and many people who complain are most likely contaminating their DNA and then wondering why it's getting false calls.The instructions remind you to not feed your dog 2 hours prior to doing the test, what the instructions DO NOT tell you is that you also shouldn't let your dog chew on anything like a dogbone, lick anyone, or genuinely be allowed to touch anything. Any of these acts could potentially hurt results, and while unlikely, can cause a great deal of these errors. I would personally recommend giving the dog some water, then taking the water away and quarantining the dog for 2-3 hours without anything. Put him in a crate or spare room if you have to, make sure she/he has nothing they can lick, eat, or chew. Then take the dog out, and make sure they don't start licking your hands while you are trying to give the test. It also would be a wise decision to wash your hands thoroughly before using the test, and never let the qtip touch anything but the dogs mouth and the inside of the plastic piece it is placed in.The second thing I wanted to mention is with regards to how genotyping works. Essentially, the "testers" have positive controls which show a spread of bands they picture. They run the DNA through something called PCR in order to search for markers(bands) present in your dog, usually indicated by size. Dirty DNA can lead to bad bands, hard to read bands, and in the long run, bad calls. What many people don't realize is that the test only determines how much a dog is of a certain breed. These means that if the dog turns out to be 25% beagle, this DOES NOT mean one of the grand parents was a 100% beagle. This means that your dog has 25% beagle in him, which could theoretically be possible if you have two half beagles breed. Also note that recessive genes carry through, so even though all the dogs they determined in your lineage are big dogs, this in no way means your dog can't be small or vice versa. So just because 50% of your dog is Great Dane, yet your dog looks like a poodle, doesn't necessarily mean the test failed, as you have 50% of your potentially dominant DNA unaccounted for from any number of breeds. Likewise, a dog could have a parent with 50% beagle and end up with essentially no beagle in them. This is simple genetics. In reality, two dogs, both 50% beagle could theoretically have a dog with no significant beagle DNA, or a dog with 100% beagle DNA(although unlikely as the genes that make up a breed are a little more complex than a punnett square)..This test DOES NOT determine lineage... merely the higher percentages of DNA present in the animal. They might call them "parents" and "grandparents", but that is just a reference for "has X% DNA" and has no baring on what the parentage is. This also means that any breed that makes up less than app. 12.5% of your animal simply doesn't show up. So a true heinz 57 dog with 20 breed of dog in it's genetic makeup would render no result.Furthermore, there is no way to determine what your dogs parents are, unless your dog turns out to be exactly 50% one breed and 50% the other.If you strongly disagree with the results of your test, I'd highly recommend that you call the company or amazon and demand a replacement test. If they refuse to offer one, then file a credit card dispute and get your money back however you can. If you retake the test and receive the same results, it might be about time to start reconsidering how you see your dog. If the results differ, you can always question them on the differing results and get to the source of "which one is right", which might even include a 3rd test. Don't be angry if you need to repeat this test three times (presuming they are willing to provide you free kits twice). All this is doing is confirming the information and reinforcing your data, which is always a plus in science.So that is my two cents on the subject. With respect to my dog, we adopted her under the belief it was a border collie lab mix. However, over the course of a year, it seemed to lose any border collie appearance and my wife wondered if the dog possessed any pitbull in her due to people often believing she is a pitbull. Turns out there was no breeds associated with pitbull in her, at least none over 12.5%. The test is what it is. The report is well done. I would have appreciated more information regarding how the test is done and what genes they are testing for, and in truth, I am tempted to call them and see if they can tell me and maybe even provide me the data from my animals test upon request. I suppose I can forgive them for not including that data, as it would most likely just clutter things and make them confusing to read, although I am curious as to how well their lab keeps a record and would I be able to obtain my dog's data on request.

It's hard to hate on this game when you "should" pretty much know what you are getting into when you pick it up. This is Halo, the original xbox game, with updated graphics, achievements, and a few other perks.Immediately before putting this game in, I spent 7 hours strait playing Halo Reach from start to finish. What I found when I finally put in this game was that I was surprised by how different it was. One needs to realize that this isn't Halo "reimagined" with completely updated graphics like you'd find in Reach. The AI, the level designs, and the flaws from the original Halo are all kept.Some of you will LOVE that they kept the game completely intact instead of tweaking and modding it ala the George Lucas treatment. Others will be disappointed by the incredibly stupid AI, certain abnormally overpowered weapons, poor repetitive level designs that make you feel lost (particularly in the beginning), and a bland environment. While yes, the graphics are "better", they didn't add to the preexisting environments, so when they design a level that is bland because that is all the xbox could handle at the time, upping the graphics didn't resolve these issues. The game is exactly what it was on the xbox, flaws and all.So if your question is "is this game for me?", you will need to look at a few things. If you own Halo CE on the Xbox, you'll need to decide whether a facelift, achievements, 6 "new" Reach Maps are worth a repurchase. If you don't own Halo CE and you like the Halo series yet haven't played 1, then it's a definite buy. I personally found that at $40 price tag, it's a bit steep for anyone who already owns Halo CE, so I pulled off a star for that. At $20 though, I think any potential Halo fan should pick it up.

Before you get excited thinking this is the Dr. Ned Zombie Island DLC fleshed out into a full modern day game, realize that this game suffers from four design flaws that prevents it from being as good as Borderlands.The best way to describe this game is borderlands exclusively with zombies and an emphasis on melee. From the cardboard cutout quest handing NPCs, the quick travel, the "safe" zones, the re popping enemies, to loot grabbing, the fetch missions, to being built around coop, to allowing someone to jump into your game at any time, to the skill tree (1 skill point per level, three trees to put it in), the weapons all leveling up from rusty to devastating and beyond, dying causes a quick repop with some money missing, the enemies all leveling as you do, to the quest selection screen(you can pick up multiple quests at once)...well you get the idea. This game is everything borderlands is, plus it adds the occasional escort quest and has random junk like fallout 3, which you can use for weapon mods or selling for cash.So for anyone who is a fan of Borderlands and the MMORPG style level and item grind, this is a great game right? Well, I haven't mentioned the four things that prevent this game from living up to its' potential.1) No Local Coop: Some may disagree that this matters, but that's only because you happen to not live in a family of gamers. You can system link the game, or play on xbox live, but there is NO splitscreen, which is made more upsetting by the fact that the back of the case suggests splitscreen. The inability to play with my wife is frustrating beyond imagination, especially since "all the bits and pieces" are there to do it. If you base a game around coop, as dead island is (to the point several missions refer to you as several people), then they should actually have included coop, borderlands could handle it, so don't tell me it was a limitation of the hardware/software.2) Rapid Weapon Degradation: Having any weapon degradation in a game where you are killing hundreds of zombies was stupid enough, but they ramped it up in this game. Quite literally, you will be able to kill maybe 5 or 6 zombies per weapon. Some weapons are "disposable" and you will simply drop them. Others will simply stop doing damage, and you need to be careful else you end up surrounded my zombies with a weapon that does no damage.3) Rapid Zombie Repops: Very forgivable, as you'd expect a game like this to have repops. But where borderlands enemies only repopped when you left the area or quit and reloaded, dead island pops enemies at random, even in the same area you are in. The pops are sporadic, sometimes you can clear an area of zombies and come back 45 minutes later to find it still cleared, other times zombies will literally repop while your still in the same area. I remember killing a thug in a building, walking to my nearby car and walking back to find the thug repopped. If they cut the repopping down a bit, it would have made a big difference, especially with the rapid weapon degradation.4) Gameplay: Gameplay is a loaded word, so I will simply say this game is clumsier than other games of it's caliber, maybe this was to add suspense and fear, I don't know. Hits don't always register, which is frustrating for a game based on melee. Guns have very limited ammo, so using them is especially frustrating. Some zombies will latch on to you, forcing you to beat them off, from an indecipherable distance that seems to change from zombie to zombie. All in all, things just don't run as smoothly in this game.So, there is my opinion on dead island. This could have easily been a wonderful game, and certainly set itself up to be, but these four issues make the game fall flat on it's face. They took the general layout from borderlands, but made some choice decisions that prevented it from living up to potential. I didn't have any preconceived notions that this was a Fallout 3 with zombies or anything, so that doesn't effect my score. Still it just isn't as good as it could have been.

On stranger tides follows the continuing story of Jack Sparrow after the end of At World's End. Taking place several years later, after Jack's map lead him to a dead end, he continues the search for the fountain of youth. I could say that the movie was OK, but suffered from several issues that just did not put it on par with any of the previous movies.The first issue was the antagonist, Blackbeard. Although he had a dramatic intro, after that, his character just waned. He was not intimidating, scary, or even particularly piraty. At no point could they decide what supernatural powers to give him, so they toss him a giant hodgepodge of whatever was convenient at the time. As a result, one minute he has the mystical power to control rope, another moment he can shrink ships into bottles, another moment he can resurrect the dead, no, he can make voodoo dolls, wait, he can control the wind? His ship has... a flamethrower? They claim him to be evil, and spend the entire movie declaring how evil he is... but he doesn't perform a single evil act in the entire movie. He kills a mutineer and captures and leaves to die a vicious mermaid who murders people... that's it. Other than that, for a pirate, he was actually a pretty decent guy.This leads to the next problem, they make all the other characters "good" so that Blackbeard seems evil in comparison. Pirates and thieves are suddenly altruistic and noble. Blackbeard's evil deed is being the only character in the movie that actually acted like a pirate, and not even a good one. This comes nowhere near the backstabbing, thieving, and traitorousness of the pirates of the first three movies. Suddenly Jack and Barbossa are best chums, this new girl which people keep saying added "much needed sex appeal" Angelica looks like a Latino stunt double of Swan. Her motivations, once again, despite being allegedly corrupted in evil, are completely altruistic and unpirate like.The final issue is how every scene was done. I swear the directors and writers sat down with the scripts of the first three movies and said, what is your favorite scenes from each movie and how can we shove them all into one? Oh, I loved the scene where the Kraken grabs all those people up. Ok, let's have that scene with magical ropes instead. Oh, I love that scene where will and jack fight on the roof planks in the blacksmith shop. Sounds good, let's do that again with Jack and that Angelica. How about that scene where Davy Jones pulls out the long cannons. Great! We'll make it a flamethrower instead! What about the scene where Jack escapes the soldiers. Sure, but we'll have him escape from the middle of the estate now! What about the turner/swan love interest. Yeah, we can throw some altruistic guy in their so he can sloppily be corrupted by pirates while falling in love with an "unattainable" woman outside his station.So yeah. That was the story. We have the antiheroes who have just turned into heroes, the bad guy that is little worse than any of the good guys, "needed" sex appeal that looks no different than the last 3 movies, except latin now. We have almost scene for scene grabs from the original trilogy, more poorly done and in the case of the relationship, was so out of place it could have just been left out.I give it 3 stars, because it was an OK watch, had it's fun moments with Jack Sparrow, and there was occasionally some witty dialogue or interesting scenes. However, ultimately completely unnecessary and anyone who love the trilogy could completely go without watching this.Edit: I figured I should add that Angelica, the latin girl, played by Penelope Cruz, an established actor, acts like, dresses like, and functions like swan from the second two movies. I am not comparing the actors... but that she was clearly a shoed in replacement for the swan character (scriptwise) and never really developed a personality of her own, I hope that solves the confusion.

This is honestly the first anime I have ever watched where I would have to say there was too much fan service. Now, I don't have anything wrong with fan service normally, but this show had so much of it that it was basically distracting from the show.Which is really a shame too, because the story itself is excellent. It follows the story of a series of woman, all looking to compete in a kind of tournament to elect one of them as the next queen of the nation. Each person has their own reasons for fighting, and although the tournaments only officially start in the final episode, matches can be held in route to knock out potential competition.I was a little confused regarding the mechanics of the matches, since losing a match does not seem to disqualify someone from competing again. In fact, the main character is constantly getting her butt handed to her. It is actually pretty silly, as her character keeps getting beat over and over again but never gives up. It is also a little confusing as to who is participating and why. The main character insisted that she wasn't going to participate numerous times yet kept doing things to show that she was going to participate.Anyway, the story was pretty decent, consisting of a fair amount of fun, including an angel that champions the matches continually doing unangelic things. The fighting is OK and the story tends to flow pretty well with each of the characters stories. The end of this series does not end the show, as it is ongoing battle.The biggest thing that annoyed me was the ridiculous amount of fan service. Every character except one wore exceptionally revealing and impractical clothing. For example, one character wore a snake as her underwear. The only thing covering her lower half of her body was a snake wrapped around her nether regions, and she frequently sent the snake away for errands, leaving her completely naked. Other character wear things things that barely cover their chests, including a demon with a second pair of hands that cover her breasts least she want to squirt acidic breast milk at them (yes, this is the basis of several episodes).And that doesn't even touch on the nudity. EVERY fight scene consists of at least one characters clothing being ripped off. There is not a single fight scene that does not have someone's breast bare by the end of it. It is laughably ridiculous. That is where I feel the show fails. Even when they are trying to do serious scenes, everyone is either naked or wearing clothing that might as well make them naked, so it is so ridiculous that it is unbelievable, making what should be powerful emotional scenes a joke.Had they cut the fan service back a couple clicks, this show is pretty good and has the capacity to be a great anime, but like others have mentioned, the sheer amount of fan service is distracting.

Baka and test follows the story of class F. They go to a unique school where classes are split based on test scores. The best students get all the money and equipment in class A, while the worst students get stuck with nothing in Class F. However, students can earn better supplies and equipment by quite literally battling other classes, using their test scores as their battle points.This anime is absolutely hilarious, filled with tons of visual gags. This is the first anime I have ever watched that I would have no problem watching again and again. I watched one episode twice in a row, and found tons of hilarious things I had completely missed the first time through.The season, in and of itself, is very satisfying. The story starts out strong, sits for most of the mid season, but with good reason, and then ends strongly. You will most likely be satisfied with the ending to. There is another season in progress, but I wonder what will happen to continue the series, which seems to have finished up pretty well.There is not any complete nudity although the anime possesses of some partial nudity. The language is OK as well. The comedy is often very visual with a fair amount of slapstick too. I would highly recommend this anime for anyone who wants a couple of laughs and is OK with some stupid humor.

I purchased the Catch N Release in order to provide my son with more toys to use in the bathtub for his third birthday. He seems to enjoy catching things in nets and I wanted him to be able to do that with this toy. So far it has worked well. The net is small, fat and has no threat of being a chocking hazard for younger babies. The other toys also seem to work well floating on the surface until they can be picked up by the net.I imagine younger children would lack the dexterity to be able to pick up the pieces, as the net hole is barely larger than the pieces it picks up. For my son it seems to work fine. It's a cheap, simple toy and I give it it's due for what it is. It should hold up and is unlikely to break under normal circumstances.

I purchased this watch because I was in need of a good watch that I knew would hold up to abuse. Most of my watches tend to break within months, so I was hoping for a watch that would last for a few years.This G-Shock atomic watch met my demands.The display is clear and easy to read. It offers a night light, atomic settings, alarm, stop watch, and timer. All of the things you'd expect from a digital watch. It feels sturdy and the band feels like it will hold up well. I have had it for about 3 months now and it has shown no evidence of cracking or breaking like some watches. I have taken it into water at a water park and always wear it when I take my showers and the seals have held perfectly watertight.So why do I give it a poorer rating that I otherwise should? Because of the Solar charge. Most solar watches I have are able to keep a charge and run perfectly fine. The only issues I ever had were when a watch was broken and the nightlight would randomly turn on over and over again, draining the battery. This has none of these problems, but I find it unable to hold a charge.I live in wisconsin, and it has been spring for most of my ownership of the watch, so no exactly sunny days (mostly rainy). Nonetheless, I'd expect a watch to be able to keep a charge. Instead, I find myself needing to charge the watch up by leaving it in an window during the day every 3 to 4 days. So for every 3 days I wear the watch, I have to spend one day letting it charge.This might be a problem unique to only some of the watches, and it may not be something I will face in the summer months or someone else would face in their sunnier location. However, for me, a watch that can't keep it's charge and dies every couple of days is not a great experience, and it has cost this watch 2 stars in my book. Other than that, the watch is a great one and I would recommend it. If you live in southern California, this is a great watch, if you live in Washington... maybe consider another.Update: Having owned this watch for a longer period of time, nothing has really changed. It still is constantly dying every couple of days. It is summer now and that seems to make no difference. On days I am outside it stays working, on days I am inside it drains and dies. Perhaps the battery just needs a larger capacity than casio gave it, but either way, I expect a solar watch to remain charged most of the time, not be constantly dying everyday I don't spend outside.Update 2: I had the battery replaced and ever since the watch has run fine. It will still power down sometime at night under really low lighting, but by the time I check it again the next day the watch is already back on. I wonder if it has some kind of power setting or something. I increased my score a star because it looks like I just got one with a bad battery.

There is really no surprise here. It is exactly as described, a black silicone cover specific for Sony Walkmans. It covers all of the buttons and even came with a screen cover that was not advertised when I bought it. The cover has a poor indent where each of the buttons are, but no indicator of what button does which, so if you are not familiar with you device, you may find yourself pressing the wrong button every now and then. You may also have to push harder to get buttons to register than you might have once had to.Other than that, it works as it is. Even though it's not perfect, I give it 5 stars because it is very cheap and I like that it covers the buttons, so that everything is protected.

You can't really say much regarding a firewire cable. This is a 4 pin to 4 pin. My camcorder is a 4 pin and my laptop also contained a 4 pin, so it made sense to get this, over the 4 pin to 6 pin you might get if you had a desktop.It is very cheap, much better than the $15 cable you would find at Best Buy, and works for my needs.On the offchance you are just wondering what a firewire does, it's simply a cable, somewhat like USB, used manly for video streaming and external hard drives. So if you have a camcorder, you'll need one of these, particularly sense most camcorders don't come with one like they should.

As far as relaxing ambient light goes, this Himalayan salt lamp is the best. The picture doesn't really do it justice for the lamp's beauty.The lamp has an adjustable dimmer switch which influences the orange glow that the lamp emmits. Don't expect the lamp to be able to light a room, but if you are just looking for a night light, a romantic backlight, a relaxing light during a massage or romantic dinner, Or something to calm your nerves after a long day, then this would work very well.Allegedly, the lamp's salt, when heated by the lamp (although it never gets particularly hot on the outside rocks), is suppose to have an ionic effect, removing the "bad" free radicals from the air and allowing for cleaner breathing and the removal of allergy problems.I would honestly believe this to be a placebo effect, as my wife still is suffering from allergy problems even though we have run the lamp nonstop for a week. Then again, I have a full fledged air filter that hasn't faired any better at providing her relief this spring.Regardless of whether the ionic effect is a wivestale or a real effect of this lamp, it is still a recommended purchase for anyone looking for something to produce a calming ambient light. Definitely a great addition to any massage parlor, and my wife wants a second one for upstairs.

I purchased two of these stuffed lambs for Easter baskets. They worked well for my 3 yo son and 2 yo nephew. The song plays fine, and the lambs are sufficiently well built and cuddly.The lamb's music is controlled by a key that is easily usuable by a toddler. The one odd thing is that the key allows you to unscrew it. So if you turn it the wrong way, you'll have to turn it back before it starts cranking.There is not much to say other than that. This is a music box in the form of a stuffed animal, NOT  a stuffed animal with music. So this isn't meant to be played with by a baby or to be someone's carry around toy. It is better suited for being sat up on a shelf and played to help a baby to sleep, or played with your toddler to expose him to the song.I dropped the rating a star because of the oddity of the key being able to be unscrewed, which can be frustrating when you have to screw it 5 or six turns before it starts winding up. Other than that, treating it more like a music box for kids and less like a stuffed animal would be the key to making sure this is the product for you.

I purchased the case when the paint on my mp3 player began scrapping off a bit. I thought that using this would keep my mp3 player from getting as beat up as my previous one had before it died.So far it has worked well at protecting my mp3 player, which looks as good as the day I put the cover on for all the areas the polyurethane wrap covers. The area it covers is the back of the mp3 player and the edges. The speakers, including the holes in the back of the player, are not covered, along with the screen and the buttons. A screen protector comes with this set to cover the screen, really only leaving the buttons uncovered and speakers uncovered. The case is well built though, allowing easy access to all of the ports and buttons. The only button covered is the volume button, and while changing it sometimes requires a little more work than it did, it is acceptable. The case doesn't offer any protection for the transfer port, so if you wanted to keep it from getting clogged with dust, you'd need to look for something else.The clip that attaches to it is very subpar. It falls off or clips off with incredible ease, and I gave up on it fairly quickly. It is difficult to maneuver the clip where you want it without it popping off the mp3 player, so it is not too effective.The misleading part comes from the color. The blue color of the case is faint, very faint, so after putting it on your mp3 at best it will have a slight bluish tinge. Mostly youll just have that check board pattern on the back of your player with clear squares and bluish snow squares.  So the picture is nothing like what your mp3 will look like with it on.In the end, I give it a 4. Despite it's shortcomings, it works and it is very cheap, if it was more expensive, I might be more disappointed, but at a couple of bucks, it's as good as I would expect.

Prior to purchasing this product I was very familiar with the Sony walkman line, having owned an 8 gb for the last 4 years. It broke so I searched for a replacement and eventually found this nextgeneration device. The color wasn't particularly important to me so I went with this model, which was cheaper at the time. I found the device to be more than adequate for my purposes, which is listening to music and audiobooks.The sound has been of high quality, new features that did not exist on my previous model include external speakers and fm radio. The external speakers are not particularly loud, so it isn't something you can really use instead of, say, a car radio. The radio also seems to work well. As others have mentioned, their are issues with it's sorting and making playlists, which don't really effect me, so I won't rate it negatively due to these flaws. It would be nice if more forms of media were supported, particularly in the video category, but regrettably that doesn't seem to be the case. I still love the ease of syncing files with windows media player, and not having to sync or maintain your entire library on a computer like iTunes forces you to.The one complaint that I have seems to be the quality of the device. My previous one lasted for many years, and while it did get beat up, it took quite some time for it. With this one, specifically the paint job seems defunct. I don't know if I specifically got a defunct one or if all of the RED onces have this problem, but it feels like the paint job was missing the protective gloss layer. Within days of owning the product the paint on the back of the mp3 player began rubbing off. I purchased a case to delay the speed of this, but in the month I have had it, the buttons (the only non covered part of the player) red color has already started rubbing off as well. I have treated my device well, but it already shows wear and tear as if I had been using it for many months in a matter of  weeks.So it's a good device, and I like everything about the hardware behind the device nd the software in the device, but I would have expected it to hold up a little better with regards to the paint. For that I drop it a star. Other than that it is solid and I'd recommend it, you might want to avoid the red color though.Edit: The device eventually unexpectedly broke down. Sony wanted $30 to do an exchange on it, which is honestly a lot more than I would have expected for something supposedly under warranty. I'd probably drop the rating a star, but I feel I was responsible for it breaking. I grabbed it once when I had a wet hand, then it started acting up, I let it dry out and it started working fine, then 3 weeks later it suddenly died and would not start.As far as the issue I mention, the "new" paint job on this refurbished one seems to be holding up a little better. The paint is already rubbing off again, but to a smaller degree around the high wear areas and over a longer period of time (several weeks versus several days). So just about everything I said about the device stands, I DO like the device, just don't grab it when you hand is wet, it doesn't quite have the waterproofness of say, an ipod touch (for obvious reasons), not saying that ipod touches are waterproof, just that they are more water resistant than this.

When you keep in mind the relative price of this dog kennel compared to others, you have to respect the value of this product.This is a simple dog kennel for traveling with a dog. Whether you go on a road trip with the dog, or something bigger, this is a great kennel for the purpose. The size of dog this is designed for is large, which cover border collies, labs, retrievers, and other dogs along this size. It offers plenty of room for my dog, who is still in his puppy stages, but has plenty of room to grow.The remington comes in three basic parts. I was able to figure out assembly pretty quickly without instructions. You simple put the top and bottom together with the door fitting into it's respective holes. You then use a plastic clip to lock the kennel together along the sides. On the up side, you can probably dissasemble the kennel if there is ever a need, on the downside, the assembly is with plain plastic clips that could probably break easily if you assemble it wrong.If someone fell on it or some other accident I could see it breaking... but other than that it is a pretty stable kennel that will hold a dog. As an added plus, it comes with a food bin if you need to provide food or water on the go.The only complaint I have for it is that I found no means of attaching the handles that came with it in an actually useful way (on the top). The kennel is big and bulky and don't expect to be able to lug it around by it's handles. I honestly am not even sure why they provided handles.Other than that, which I can live with for something it's size, it meets my needs. It is the cheapest kennel I have been able to find, and it is well built enough that I don't mine the cost. Most other kennels will run you over $100-200 easily. I was able to get mine for $60. So with that kind of deal, who could complain?

I can really only say it is about as good as Awakening, but not Origins. I have beaten the game now, although I wrote this review after 8 hours of play, I still agree with just about everything I wrote. So the game hasn't picked up or "gotten better". I have dropped the score to 3 stars.Story: This is the first failure in my book. The story seems to lack cohesion. Where the first story was steady and true, you had a purpose and followed that purpose, and each of your companions were met in turn, this story is just a mess. You meander around picking up quest after quest and companion after companion, who follow you for no particular reason whatsoever other than "I owe you one" . For example, one of them becomes a captain of the guard, but still remains your companion, as if that even makes sense, like she/he could make week long expositions while having a steady job.Gameplay: For the most part, the gameplay remains relatively unchanged. The commands, giving commands, and the abilities all feel and run the same. It's faster pace, with you swinging you sword or casting spells wickedly fast, but other than that, it is surprisingly familiar. The enemies are weaker, but they throw more of them at you at once. This leads to another one of my problems with it. They have your enemies hidden until you run into them. You can't scout out and see your enemies ahead of you; Instead, they simply pop up in front of you. You then proceed to fight waves and waves of enemies that magical appear all around you. They literally jump from the sky and land, as if every attack was a carefully planned execution from the rooftops.Menu and levels: The new menu is mostly a slicker less gritty version of the old one. It isn't better or worst. The "level up" options are almost the same, except that you can now see more clearly how each change of your stats effects you. Rather than having all the ability placed on one page, they are now scattered by section and "gridded" so that in order to learn some abilities you need to learn others. In the end, it is just a fancy and less efficient way to display the same thing with the same abilities. I preferred to be able to read my options and see all criteria on one page, so in my opinion, this is less enjoyable. The new dialogue wheel, taken from the concepts of Mass Effect, is something I hate greatly. More often than not, the few word summary they give you does not accurately represent what your character says, so you end up saying things you didn't intend to, and there is no way to predict when and how much the text deviates from the words spoken.Maps are reused shamelessly. Not only do you need to repeatedly go through the same areas over and over again (at least once per act), but they also reuse the same maps as different areas. You end up with a large elaborate map for a mansion or cave, then each different mansions or cave with certain doors passable and other doors locked, thus allowing you to travel through a unique path... but you are really just repeating the same map over and over again, but might be going through it backwards, or having these two doors blocked instead of these two. This hits the score the hardest of anything in my mind. They shameless reuse the same maps over and over again for different environments. Origin did do this, but not nearly to this extent. Within 8 hours of play, I had repeated a single map 3 times for 3 different areas. That is very inexcusable.Other Changes from origins: Other changes include the dog now being a "summon" rather than a character that actual takes up a form slot(I believe this is an addon), which I prefer. You can no longer speak to your companions except in their own "location", so no having conversations when you are out and about, even in a city. The companions no longer have traditional armor, but wear an unique upgradable single armor piece, you are the only one that needs all the pieces of armor. Also crafting, including runes and herbs, is now done at shops unique to that purpose rather than by individuals...Overall: So all in all, the game hasn't impressed me so far. The lackluster introduction of each of the companions is put together so sloppily that it is discouraging at best. The story has no real direction. Nonetheless, the game is still fun, offers a faster past version of the combat system you may have learned to love, and there are some things they have gotten right. It's still a game worth looking at, but you might consider waiting for a price drop.I know it sounds pretty bleak from my diagnosis of the game, but everything else about the game is classic Dragon Age, and if you like that, and can dismiss every thing I mentioned as not a problem or inconsequential, then you know this is the game for you.

We have arrived to the final part of the Desire Me books. If you haven't read the first two stories, you will need to pick up them before proceeding to the final installment. Like the previous story we are picking up where we left off, and there is vital information that is require for this story. Cause we learn a great deal about Nick's past and how it fuels his need for vengeance. We get see Amelia and Nick marry in Desire Me Always. However, will Nick's need to for vengeance cause strife in this newlywed couple.The first couple of chapters is Nick and Amelia enjoying their honeymoon, but Nick needs to satisfy his hunger to get revenge on the vicar. Killing two birds with one stone. However, we have Shauley making a nuisance in Nick's plan. You will remember him as the guy who kidnapped Amelia and from Nick's past.Overall, the Desire Me stories need to be read in order, to get the full benefit of Nick and Amelia's story. As a whole it's a pretty good read where you see two people who overcome the past to find love. Nick never envisioned himself being married, but when Amelia entered his life that all changed. She changed him for the better, but it wasn't an easy process. She stuck by his side through thick and thing. I have to say that ending is a sweet conclusion for this couple and leaves you with a smile to see them overcome all their obstacles. So, if you don't mind going through dark times to find a happy ending, you might consider reading the Desire Me books.Copy provided by Avon via Edelweiss.

Can I scream on how much I love this series? Seriously, it just seems to get better and better. I mean Edge of Danger is AWESOME! Loved the last book, and I didn't know how Katie would top after Levi's story, but she managed.Edge of Danger is a heart pounding non-stop action story, that has you holding your breath at times. To say the least it's one hell of a page turner. Anyway, we meet Tucker Pankov who happens to be an undercover DEA agent. You think he's new character, but we actually have met him in Shattered Duty as Grisha. As Grisha he's one scary dude.
