My parents were French Jews during this period - and fled shortly before this terrible incident when the French police and politicians cooperated with the Nazis to "round up" most of the Jews in Paris for eventual deportation to the death camps. So this important movie had special resonance for me.An astounding film in many ways. What makes it so interesting is that it does present the French people in all their guises - those who protested the round ups, the doctors and nurses who tried to deal with the medical needs of people being crowded into the Paris Velodrome, the children who could not comprehend the cruelty around them, the suicides of Jews who knew what the end result was, the apathy of Marshall Petain who gradually bent to the Nazi demands, the antagonism of the anti-semites who were delighted by the elimination of Jews from Paris, a priest who wears the badge of the yellow Jewish star.In the way the movie approached the events, I felt dark, deep, terrible horror. And yet there are radiant moments of heroism displayed in the film.More than one-third of the Jews who were supposed to be sent away by the French and Germans to death escaped with the help of other French men and women who protected them. This is the story of the children, mothers, and others who did not escape. Harrowing, yes...but necessary.Possibly the most compelling scene is the rampant, wild chaos in the Paris Velodrome as the troubled Jews try to figure out what is happening to them as they are being denied water to drink. Just about all the events in this film are true. (Don't miss the extras and also watch "Sarah's Key", a fictional story about this seminal event in French 20th century history).The New Republic called this one of the best films of the year.  A DVD that works in Region 1 can be purchased from Amazon Canada.

That's a line that Isaac  (Woody Allen) whispers to Mary (Diane Keaton) in the NYC planetarium as they walk between the planets and the stars on the screen.  Such an existential moment.  Alas, it seems to be the one thing that Woody Allen can articulate but not adopt - really deeply - in his soul.  We know him from his wisecracks about God, death, movies, intellectuals, sex...but what this film is about is nostalgia - what we remember of what we think we love.The film begins with Woody Allen exclaiming how much he loves THE CITY.  Yes, I think that is true. One theme is whether he knows how to love  something entirely different - another human being.  His characters always seem to be reaching for that goal - just out of his reach. From my experience, loving another requires unqualified unselfishness, full acceptance of the other, compassion, and a sparkle of wisdom.  Would his character offer his kidney to his wife or best friend?  One senses no.So many reviewers have praised the glorious black and white cinematography. They are right on the money. Gordon Willis did the photography for Woody Allen - and he is justly known for also doing "The Godfather."  The opening sequence may be one of the most sensational I have ever seen on the silver screen....nostalgic shots of Manhattan against the background of George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue.  The opening concludes in a burst of light from fireworks over the city.  Orgasmic. (Gordon Willis also shot "Stardust Memories" for Woody Allen, one of those films that doesn't get much mention these days)It is striking to me that Woody Allen's character does not ever smile. He offers a smirk, yes, but not a smile.  That's an interesting observation about a comedian, about "this" comedian.  Perhaps at this time in his life, he was going through his immature mid life crisis.  That occurs when a man believes he is losing his virility, ponders growing old, and foolishly thinks he can resurrect his life by dating a young, pretty girl.  It is a risque move - as a director - to put your true flaws right into a picture, but there it is, for all to see.  A 42 year old man having an affair with a 17 year old high school student!Mariel Hemingway - the 17 year old - is a revelation.  Of all the characters, she (Tracy) speaks simply from the heart.  The others go about lamenting their relationships, criticizing themselves or their lover, but none of them really seem to be loving anyone. Other than one scene (in a horse carriage in Central Park) when Isaac says that Tracy is "God's answer to Job", Isaac generally does not respect Tracy as an equal. In public, he makes disparaging comments about her. And he is always warning her she is too young for him and the relationship has to self-destruct. So when Tracy finally leaves Isaac, he suddenly realizes he may indeed have lost the one love of his life. At the end of the movie, he begs her to stay.  But the deed is done; she will travel away to London.  Isaac - or Woody Allen - lost the one person in the film who really could love him back, if he had chosen to love her first.Unlike other films which are tied to their moment, the truths in this film will remain valid 10 or 100 years from now. And that's one reason it is a masterpiece. This is not Woody Allen's funniest film, but it may indeed be his best.

Background history - Give applause to Franklin Delano Roosevelt who started the WPA during the Great Depression to help real Americans earn money and keep their dignity.  All of us know about the bridges and Post Offices and roads. Amazing - nine million people received money from the U.S. Government and they paid us back with over a million projects.  Jobs were handed out even to unemployed newspaper reporters, novelists, and poets. They were paid to support national patriotism and give birth to a national identity.  One assignment - travel the American heartland, towns, and ports and document the way Americans feast - talk about the food at the harvest fairs, political and community fundraisers, square dances, or religious revivals.Washington D.C. did not want recipes, it wanted stories. This book is about those stories. These colorful accounts are important historical material. After all, "politics and barbeques go so naturally together because it takes the same amount of time to cook the meat as it does to stroke the voters."Some gems: A group of African American women argue about a fund raiser where the participants plan to serve pig feet: A woman resists:  "Who wants ole pig feet? They give you indigestion. The last time the pig feet were cold and half done."Or a huge salmon barbecue where the salmon is "dunked in a big tub of water with lots of brown sugar. After about half an hour the fish is removed and placed in the barbecue pit and covered with ferns and grass."  Sounds wonderfully tasty.Or a religious revival where the master of ceremonies shouts to the crowd:  "Who danced before the Lord until his clothes fell off?  [The crowd replies] -  "David!"  Later they will feast on "fried fish and chicken, roasted corn, baked ham, all kinds of long-cooked greens, meat in red-hot sauce, and custard pies."Or an Irish tavern in Olde New York where the innkeeper believed "in the right of the male to peace and ease while enjoying his standard delicacies of ale and onions..."The book takes us back to a time when large gatherings of people celebrated food - events that helped create communities and neighborhoods and churches.I did not live during those days in the 1930's and 1940's. And no, I don't eat squirrel stew.Still I believe something terribly important is at risk in our culture.  I see too many young people spend lots of time looking down at their smart phones rather than making new friends across a long table groaning with good eats for all to share.A last thought - "It's worth it to see so many folks eat their part of wholesome vittals."

Oh, what a fairy-tale this romance unfolds.  A student in a private boarding school in a castle by the lake investigates whether an old mansion is haunted, and discovers a beautiful young women imprisoned in the house.  They both fall in love, and he vows to protect her.The charm of the movie is based on the haunting folk-songs the man sings that reverberate through the woods, the fact that the young man has a magical relationship to animals where they trust him implicitly, and the undying love he has for this young mysterious woman, across the lake.We never know whether it is a vision, a dream, or reality, but the other students eventually come to believe that the young man's love for "Marianne" is their love also.  The movie captures that other worldly quality of romance and true love that is all too quickly being forgotten.in this machine driven age.It is a lovely film - lovely to look at - lovely to listen to.

If there is going to be a serious book on the history of photography, then it probably would have to be based on the "George Eastman House Collection", the most comprehensive in the world.  Unlike the history of Western art, there are actually very few books on the history of photography.I think of this volume as a textbook...factual, somewhat dry. Most of the illustrations are in black and white. The emphasis is on the early history of photographic arts.The book begins with early Greek experiments on light, then discusses the very first photograph by Joseph Niepce in 1827 of rooftops from his window. This volume is illustrated with hundreds of photos,  - some of the highlightsA still life with skull - in color no less - (reminds one of Frankenstein) (1850)A soulful daguerrotype of a young girl - John Baptiste Sabatier Blot (1852)The main facade of an Aztec ruin in Chichen-Itza in the jungles  (1860)A human mummy encased in volcanic rock from Pompeii  (1880)Southwestern vistas of rock and Native American dwellings in Canyon de Chelle (1873)A moonlight view of Yosemite Park  (1874)One of the Lincoln Conspirators Just Before his Execution (Rebel with a Cause)  (1865)A moving image of a man pole-vaulting  (1890)An albumin print of an old man - in the style of Rembrandt  - Julia Margaret Cameron (1865)The bridge of Sighs in Venice  (1864)A stirring photograph of the Moon from a telescope  (1865)A railroad wreck with its passenger car in a river  (1900)Half Dome of Yosemite in snow  - Ansel Adams  (1927)Pepper No. 30  almost like an erotic nude - Edward Weston (1930)Gargoyle of Chrysler Building - Margaret Bourke-White  (1930)Martha Graham in dance - Edward Steichen  (1931)Migrant Worker Mother  - Dorothea Lange  (1936)The Flag of Soviet Victory over Berlin - Yevgeny Khaldei (1945)Identification of a Gestapo Informer Before a Tribunal - Henri Cartier-Bresson  (1945)Army Troops See Atomic Blast  (1951)To ponder these images - as art and as truth - stirs the capacity for wonder. (Taschen Publishers also does a lovely book on Alfred Stieglitz)

Everyone knows about the Sistine Chapel...but this gorgeous illustrated book shows the depth of the collections - not just Renaissance art - but Greek vases, ethnic art brought by missionaries, the book collections of the vast library.  I was astounded by the quality of the photos and the variety of the masterpieces owned by the Church.

If you enjoy those wonderful Ealing comedies - "Kind Hearts and Coronets" or "The Man in the White Suite", then of course, you know Joan Greenwood.  If you don't know those films, listen to her in this wonderful version of "Alice in Wonderland."  Her voice is unique, like a cat's seductive purr.

Yes...I think it is....although obviously the movie will not change the way you view the world.Brigitte Bardot electrifies the screen whenever she appears. It is just NOT POSSIBLE to take your eyes off her.  One reason is that she simply is "that hot." But the director deserves credit too.  Knowing how to dress and undress his stars is talent. Vadim understands what makes a woman sexy - perhaps more than any other director (after all, other than King Solomon, he married more beautiful women, one after another, then anyone else in history).I cannot say enough positives how colorful the film is....the scenery of St. Tropez is breathtaking, and the mixture of colors and lights in the film is restored magnificently by Criterion...with as much care as, let's say,  "Black Narcissus."Like many French directors, an underlying theme is missed opportunities for love.  Perhaps the best choice for Bardot's character was the older man in love with her...but it was not to be.Enjoy the film, just don't expect more than it offers.

Because we are repeating history...As explained by Ken Burns, the terrible near "end of the world" disaster of THE DUST BOWL was the worst man made ecological mistake in American history. This aspect of this chapter of the American Experience was not told to me when I learned American history...and I thank Ken Burns for explaining it so well.  As he documents the facts through archival films, letters, and interviews with survivors, we harmed the land through ignorance.  Men and women wilfully destroyed the necessary wild grasses that evolved over time to hold the soil together in the Great Plains. Without those grasses, the newer soil would no longer hold moisture.  As it turned out, the most shocking scenes in the film are those of black, long walls of new tractors destroying those grasses, upturning the valuable soil.  Forget horror movies....this is real terror. {Not unlike the 1918 influenza pandemic}.  Man's most dangerous enemy...is himself.In the documentary, Ken Burns reminds us that Native Americans of the Great Plains experienced their "end of the world" disaster when we recklessly slaughtered their buffalo herds.  Did we think we could not do this to ourselves? The plague of grasshoppers that ate everything in sight in the Dust Bowl is of equal ferocity to the one predicted by Moses in the Old Testament.In 1956, Life Magazine had a cover which warned of serious global climate change if Americans did not make modifications to wasteful, destructive lifestyles.  That warning to respect the Earth was ignored. Today, the victims of Hurricane Sandy experienced first hand what devastating effects of global warming can do to Americans - miserable droughts. ferocious storms, and unimaginable floods. Will we ever learn?  Ken Burns hopes we do.

For most of the 20th century, Native Americans were demonized..  Perhaps as wrong, modern films such as "Dances with Wolves" have over-sentimentalized them.  This picture fits right in between.  An alcholic manipulative rodeo man takes on an inexperienced young Native American to ride wild broncos in Rodeos...and the young man does spectacularly well. He truly enjoys his relationship with the animals.  I think of the film as an American Indian version of Paul Newman's "The Hustler" , but instead of a pool hall, it is the Rodeo Circuit.All the performances seem believable, and the heart of the movie is the personal quest of the Native American to learn his roots. I think it is criminally underrated and should be seen more often by open minded moviegoers.

Most of the positives of the film have been discussed in other reviews...but one aspect of the movie is likely to be hushed up. By voicing an orgasm, Natasha Richardson sexually arouses all who watch this movie. And she does this fully dressed!  What a lesson in eroticism. [Jane Fonda could do that...in "Klute"]Natasha Richardson fans know her from other films such as "Haven" and "The Handmaids Tale."  Her co-star, Bob Hoskins, is also fantastic.  He offers a humble, understated performance as a photographer of cheap religious images.The scenes of his bungling efforts to photograph the great stories of the New Testament - whether of the LAST SUPPER or ST. FRANCIS OF ASSISI - are hysterically funny.  The apostles, most of whom are drug addicts or skid row bums, are depicted as models of devotion.  One factor that makes the movie so funny is that Jeff Goldblum's character takes his role of playing Jesus so seriously,  he slowly comes to believe that he is the Son of God. Astonishing - with a beard and long hair, he really does look like Jesus!Because the movie does not hold back from poking fun at religion devotion,  it is likely to offend a crowd of fundamentalists.  Notwithstanding, the film examines the "big questions" more deeply than let's say, the better known "Life of Brian." I actually think it is funnier too.This is a unique film, for the reasons stated.  I recommend it to cinephiles looking for an offbeat satire outside the mainstream of Hollywood fare.  Consider the funniest line when Jeff Goldblum dressed in a white robe starts to walk slowly into a lake and sinks.  A skid row drunk wakes up his neighbor - "I just saw someone trying to walk on water."  The other responds:  "It happens. Go back to sleep."

Individuals are so used to "narrative cinema" unfolding a conventional story that something entirely different becomes incomprehensible.  This movie rates with "Grapes of Wrath" in honestly depicting the dignity of those laborers who brought us the commodities that we all take for granted - whether coal, copper, or corn.  But these coal fields are now replaced by a newer world - which although less bleak is also less meaningful. The beginning of the film shows the present...but what forms the heart of the film is the past.There is no dialogue.  Accompanied by a haunting brass score, the film is a sequence of slow motion archival footage of coal miners, their union organizers, and their families.  One scene bleeds into another and another so that time is suspended.  Watching and listening, the film operates as a life experience.  And that experience made me meditate on the true meaning of community - one that lives together, works together, feasts together, and dies together.  Without speech, the film speaks instead to our subconscious. As to the photography, we witness the coal miners descending a shaft to enter a narrow dark hell, we cheer their parades, we sympathize with their union solidarity,  One of the most emotional images is a mass of faces waiting for news of survivors in a mining disaster. The music repeatedly evokes those long forgotten brass bands celebrating the laborers.This is raw cinema ... in an old form - e.g. the silent Soviet film "Earth (1930)" ... or is it new?  Astonishing, brave, brilliant, and profound.

What unfolds is a story of an 11 year old boy in a strict household  - maltreated and unloved - who is emotionally harmed over and over again by his parents.  Knowing that other children are loved, this state of affairs simply cannot go on forever. Eventually, this leads to a suicide attempt which is one of the most shocking, choking moments in cinema. The child actor is totally believable; none of the scenes are forced or sentimental. Truly, this film "Poil De Carotte" is tough to watch, but it is an unforgettable experience.  Only 30 years later have I experienced a terrific child actor in French cinema that equaled this peformance - Patricia Gozzi in "Sundays and Cybele."

I went to the multiplex with no expectations...having been generally disappointed with Hollywood offerings this year.  I was very pleasantly surprised how outstanding this film is.It is among the most spectacular computer generated animations ever created...every time the multi-colored tooth fairy shows up on the screen (or her baby fairies) I smiled.  And that is the point of this movie..it makes you smile. "Wings up, Ladies!" (Yes, this is one of those movies that the BIG SCREEN and HIGH DEFINITION enhance enjoyment).  I believe that the astonishing look of the film has something to do with Guillermo del Toro, executive producer - because he is the man responsible for "Pan's Labyrinth", the film that changed the rules on Computer Animation in movies and made an indelible impression on world wide audiences.A perfect movie for children - with no annoying bathroom humor - a (religious?) battle between good and evil that is not too dark. No one gets killed or wounded because the matter in controversy is the quality of dreams.  My favorite character is Santa Claus - with gang tattoos of "naughty" on one arm and "nice" on the other. Instead of the usual stereotype, he turns out to be Russian or Ukrainian.  We know this from his accent and expressions (When upset, he will say something like "Shostakovich"). And...part of the fun is that Santa uses Abominable Snowmen to make the toys rather than the elves who don't do much work at all. The purpose of the Easter Bunny, the Tooth Fairy, the Sandman, and Santa Claus is to bring hope, cheer, and wonder to children.  Enter  - - - Jack Frost --- who has not taken sides yet. Like so many of us, he is seeking the answer to why he is here on earth... his spiritual journey is the core of the film and his quest will determine the childrens' fate.The characters are adorable, perhaps even the villain (The Bogeyman) was once himself.  The reason he has decided to change happy dreams to frightening ones derives from his loneliness.  He believes dark dreams is a way to achieve recognition....alas, an unhappy characteristic that is a dangerous one in our times.  Our heroes, or shall I say superheroes, won't allow that since their mission as GUARDIANS is to protect the children always.Hey, let's get a real family movie for the kids..not "Bad Santa."  This is a wonderful choice. Friendly warning:  The beginning of the movie is very important so don't miss the first few minutes.

I was browsing in my local independent bookstore and discovered this gem.  It has some of the most impressive photographs of "America the Beautiful" - that I have ever seen.  Mixed in with color photographs - such as  a brilliant one of Monument Valley (or) a time lapse view of the sky over Chaco Canyon that looks like God's eye - are some key black and white photographs - such as  the process of carving Lincoln into Mount Rushmore (or) the building of the Bay Bridge between Oakland and San Francisco.  The selections are comprehensive and impressive.  Highly recommended...don't be put off by the cover.

In "The Seven Year Itch", the bumbling seducer wants to impress Marilyn Monroe with Rachmaninoff.  Probably not the best choice.  I recommend this CD which has all the lovely melodies of Satie or Ravel.  I like to play it while I am having dinner with friends.  And...I do send this CD as a gift to others! Impossible not to enjoy.

What "SkyFall" offers to its audience is Bond, James Bond, as an espionage agent...not as a cardboard character or a flawlessly dressed superhero. Back in the 1950's and 1960's, that's how Bond was imagined by his creator.  Go back to the books - start with Casino Royale or From Russia with Love - and you will see that Bond is a tough, loyal, hard-edged spy.  Daniel Craig brings this kind of Bond back.  Sean Connery was glamorous, Roger Moore was silly, but Daniel Craig acts, moves, and thinks like a spy.And the villain in "SkyFall" was once an important asset of MI6...perhaps a friend of Bond once.  He is the enemy today because he wants revenge. Why? He was cruelly betrayed by Britain and M when it was expedient for him to get captured and tortured.  He was traded for 6 other British agents. See the film "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" to get an idea how governments will and do make these choices at the personal sacrifice of their agents.  When my father was a spy against the Nazis for the French this was a real fear when he operated in enemy territory. Can you really trust your own side, when you live in the shadows?  And so Raoul Silva (Javier Barden) - the new enemy of MI6 - was born by surviving his betrayal. Governments do create their own Frankensteins.Both the flawed psychological, hurt natures of Bond and Silva are explored in this brilliant thriller. As Judi Dench (as M) puts it, orphans make the best spies.Although there are some extraordinary stunts in the film, gone are most of the spy gadgets that helped Bond get out of trouble.  He has to use his brains, not only his courage, to win this showdown.  I love the part when he goes back into time, and drives his "Goldfinger" vehicle again.  The gadget that villian Raoul Silva uses, is one we live with everyday - the computer.  For he is an expert in cybercrime.Now we have reached Bond at 50 - Daniel Craig nails it. Although I must confess that this Bond is someone who doesn't smile or enjoy luxury wines - something I miss from the Sean Connery days.

We have all wanted, at some point in our lives, to be a fly on the wall at a moment of historical significance. The fly - this time - is a servant to Queen Marie Antoinette played magically by Lea Seydoux.  The entire film revolves around "her" point of view.Sidonie Laborde reads books to the Queen and is summoned at all hours of night and day to respond to Marie Antoinette's whims. It is apparent that Sidonie, a naive girl, has a schoolgirl crush on the Queen but is emotionally hurt by the fact that her majesty is in thrall to another beautiful woman, la Duchess de Polignac.  There is a telling scene where Sidonie opens the chamber of la Duchesse when the other is fast asleep and nude, and she examines the woman from almost a clinical perspective - trying to understand where is the charm?  But the love triangle takes second place to the reality of the urgent news that the Bastille Prison has just been stormed by the people of Paris and its jailer mutilated by the mob.  The very existence of the monarchy and the nobles is on the precipice.The plot imagines three days in which the idea of revolution swims in the heads of the nobles and servants of Versailles; they realize that their carefully shut off existence is coming to an end and scramble to figure out a way to survive.  Most act badly...full of self interest...or even disloyalty.  Reluctantly, Sidonie Laborde accepts the request of the Queen to act as a decoy by getting dressed up as the Queen's lover and leaving the palace in a lavish carriage.  The purpose of the order is to allow both Queen and her lover to escape safely.  Some palace servants wisely warn Sidonie to refuse to be a decoy...since they fear their companion is going to be killed within the day. As these servants see it, the harm the royalty inflicts on the people they rule is just a minor nuisance to King and Queen.Impressive highlights of the film are the gorgeous cinematography and costumes. (Yes, opt for Blu-Ray to capture all that wonderful detail).  The director shoots two sides of Versailles - its dark rooms and its splendid chambers.  The rapid disintegration of palace life is tangible and realistic like the discovery of water rats running through the corridors.Most of all, I was moved by Lea Seydoux's underplayed emotional performance as she struggles to grasp the enormity of all these events - intimate and historical.  On balance, I recommend the film as one of the better entries of 2012.

Up to now, you could only see this film on VHS.  Gerard Depardieu plays a straight and very tough cop (Mangin) trying to investigate and capture the members of a Tunisian drug ring. Expect violence since he is more than willing to beat up his subjects. Then suddenly before him he is asked to interrogate a quite beautiful Arab girl-woman (played intensely by a young Sophie Marceau). He tries the same technique.But although this police officer wants to do his job - and truly loathes criminals - he simply cannot control his dark attraction to his new suspect (Noria).  But the game is - who is in control of whom.I have rarely seen desire put on the screen more viscerally - as the police officer has to battle his heart or his head over how far he will become involved with his prey.

When I was very young, my father owned a French LP of "Igor Stravinsky - L'histoire du soldat" which was unquestionably his favorite recording.  So I grew up on this.  Of course, his version has only French narration...and so I have never bought a recording without stunning voices - in French. Those versions include one narrated by Jean Cocteau and Peter Ustinov (and) another recording read by Georges Descrieres.In this version, the fable is voiced in English...but the animation is endlessly intriguing. I have remembered images for years.  Most persons know the story - it is a Faustian tale of a simple Russian soldier who sells his violin to the devil in return for a book that predicts the future. With that book, the man can make untold wealth...but he can never capture true happiness. Although he finds a way to get free of the devil, the dark spirit has just one last chance to capture the man's soul again. Will that opportunity arise?For those willing to be engaged with a cartoon as much as with a live film, I cannot recommend a better movie.  Of course, the music is by one of the twentieth century's greatest composers. Even Walt Disney was fascinated with Igor Stravinsky's music - so he used "The Rite of Spring" as the foundation for one of his famous cartoon sequences in "Fantasia."

There is a short list of films that have actually changed political life - and this is one of them.  (Other films would include "Victim" which changed Britain's view of its criminal persecution of homosexuals - or - "I am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang" which sparked interest in changing the harsh treatment of prisoners)  This is a shocking documentary of the culture of rape in the military and the 5 star brass ignoring it. The film discloses the really large percentages of women (and men) who have been sexually attacked by their fellow soldiers - with nothing being done about it, or even worse - expect it - part of the job.  It is a difficult film to watch, bet on that, yet it is disturbingly powerful.

The first thing you notice when you try to use these things is that the release levers don't work the way you probably think they will. In order to separate the jaws, you first have to twist the handle to loosen the pressure and THEN pull on the little lever to slide the jaw around. You also have to wiggle the thing back and forth a bit to get the angle exactly right or you'll be lucky to move it by more than two teeth on the bar. Once you get a feel for it, you can slide the jaw all the way up and down the bar fairly quickly, but before you get a feel for it, you'll probably get angry once or twice. This mechanism is honestly pretty annoying, but in actual usage, it's typically a one-time annoyance. The tradeoff being that you will absolutely never have that jaw slip and fall to the floor on you when you're using the clamp vertically while you've got glue drying on you.The handles are pretty nice, but honestly, they're not so much better than the Besseys that you should go out of your way to pick them up. If somebody sells them near you, great. If they don't, you're not really missing out on anything especially revolutionary. I definitely wouldn't ever order them from any giant warehouse store that doesn't really know how to pack anything bigger than a Blu-Ray. They're not exactly delicate, but the form factor of the jumbo parallel clamp is so inherently awkward that they're not very likely to survive the kinds of impacts they will be subjected to in transit unless they're really well padded. Amazon will never pay people to pad them well, so forget about that right now.

This is a pretty good edge guide in the sense that it's wide, fully adjustable and built to stand up to some serious usage, but there are a few things that bug me about it.For starters, you're twisting those screws straight down into the rods. Unlike the very nice tightening mechanism on the router base itself, Festool took the opposite approach here and gave you something that's guaranteed to put nicks in your rods, hastening their demise unnecessarily. This is crazy disappointing considering the price.The other issue is the amount of slack in the fine adjustment knob. If you need to switch directions because you overshot your adjustment just a hair, you've got to give it almost a full turn before the threads actually engage and begin moving the guide. Not the end of the world, but again, look at the price tag. Come on, guys.Nevertheless, pairing them up is a truly great way to route narrow stock without a table, keeping with the overall system philosophy of bringing the tool to the work rather than vice-versa. I found the stock fence a little too short and stubby to *really* resist tipping given the weight of the 1400, so I made my own 1.75" tall one out of a scrap of 3/4" acrylic, and it's like a completely different tool. With that much surface area contacting the reference edge it honestly glides better than it does on the rail. Because of that, I still think this is one of those must-buy accessories even if it is disappointing in other regards.

Heat guns are not complicated tools. Unfortunately, most manufacturers use that fact as an excuse to not even try when they design theirs and you invariably wind up with a cheap, flimsy piece of junk that finds its way into the landfill within a year's time. Metabo's are plenty light in the hand, but the build quality gives it a far more substantial feel than the orange things you find at the orange stores, and the fan runs quiet with no serious rattles. This particular model lacks a digital display so you're dialing in your temperature by feel alone (obviously, don't ever stick your hand right in front of the nozzle), but the temp *is* continuously variable rather than being locked into a "low" and a "high" mode. There are no attachments in the box, so if that's something you're hoping for, you'll have to pick them up separately.What's it good for? Melting frayed nylon down without setting yourself on fire, drying out drywall mud so you can move on to sanding and painting the same day, giving that coat of waterborne stain, sanding sealer or grain filler the kick in the pants it needs to set up quicker, heat-shrink tubing the tar out of anything, bending thin pieces of metal and plastic, thawing out pipes, softening glue, starting charcoal briquets without lighter fluid and probably several dozen other things that require high heat without an actual flame.It's a little pricey, but it's built to last. I desperately wish more stores would carry their tools.

It's an expensive vacuum. You can get by without it, and I did for quite a while. Slap a Bosch hose on a regular old shop vac and you're pretty much good to go with most tools you're likely to pick up at a fraction of the cost. Sounds great in theory, but in practice, it tends to wind up costing just as much in the long run.For starters, no shop vac on the market generates as much suction as this thing. Not one. It's really staggering how strong it is, and how quiet it is, too. Don't need all that power? Dial it down and the noise level follows suit. Hook this up to a sander and dust will not be able to escape the vortex. You can sand toxic coatings full of silica in your living room all day long and leave no trace whatsoever.But what it really saves you from is context switches. Say you're making a cut with a homegrown budget solution. You mark the cut, line up the track, make a dry pass with the saw to make sure everything slides the way it needs to, and then... You have to go switch your vac on. Easy enough, but whoops, your shirt snagged the track and scooted it off the line. OK, double back and clamp it this time to make sure. Now switch the vac on and dig in. Halfway through, your hose snags because you inadvertently moved something very slightly while you were digging for the clamps. Now you've got scorch marks at best, blade deflection at worst. Can you salvage your workpiece? Maybe you can, maybe you can't. Not a big deal if it's pine, but if it's something you drove a long way to pay a lot of money for, you're not going to be very happy.A vac that switches itself on automatically sounds like an utterly pointless luxury for incredibly lazy snobs, but it's not about the effort involved in flipping a switch, it's about the distractions doing so can create which interrupt your work, cause you to make stupid mistake after stupid mistake, eventually snowballing into a runaway boulder of frustration that encourages you to rush through everything else to make up for lost time, leading to... Yes... More mistakes. Turning a vacuum on is not hard. Concentrating on 5 different things at once is. Get rid of one of those things, and it's pretty amazing how much more you can get done.Bag and filter changes are effortless. They're not cheap, but for the level of filtration they provide, not completely out of line, either.Things I don't like at all:1. The brake is annoying. You have to lift the thing up off the ground to really engage it because it just doesn't have enough of a toehold on it to keep a boot on.2. The hose is really rigid and not especially durable. For as much as they charge, it should at least be as easy to work with as the Rigid kit I got at Home Depot for 1/8th the price. Sure, it's green and anti-static, but it's kinda lame when one of the most critical components of the system is also the weakest.3. Wheels aren't big enough to travel up or down stairs very easily. You have to pick it up.4. Even the simplest of accessories, like the steel tube handlebar thing that lets you dolly it around without stooping, are optional and obscenely overpriced. I don't mind paying for quality engineering at all, but you cannot tell me it took a PhD to come up with a piece of bent metal.5. The suction adjustment knob rotates so far past the markers in either direction that it's easy to mistake the max setting for the minimum setting from a distance because it really could be pointing at either one depending on how you look at it. A Sharpie can fix this in a jiffy.I would absolutely not bother buying one of these for use with a router, jigsaw or miter saw--you can get along just fine without it in most cases--but for sanders, track saws and domino joiners, you're really doing yourself a huge disservice with that chimeric assortment of duct taped adaptors and extension cords we all know you've got going in there.

I didn't read any instructions anywhere, but upon my first encounter with the product, it was fairly obvious that it wasn't going to behave like most grain fillers as it looks a lot more like the acrylic varnish one would use to seal a canvas painting. I slathered it onto my stained maple parts fairly thickly with a foam brush and let it dry about six hours. After that I hit it with a bit of 220 paper until the brush strokes leveled out and all the glue seams and fine pores were gone. Two coats took care of whatever was left. I dunno about drying for four days--seems a bit excessive as it sands very well for me with far less time, and I live in a cool, humid coastal town. Hand sanding is definitely preferable to electric--the dust gums up every paper known to man under the heat of all the friction, and it's really, really, really easy to sand right through the stain even on the slowest speeds.I think all the complainers are just trying to scrape it flush and it's a little too thin to work that way. Treat it more like a really thick sanding sealer and it delivers in spades.

I like a lot of Festool products, but this is the first one I've ever used that left me completely awestruck. I saw the videos boasting about how the dust extractor's suction would help support the weight of the tool, but I figured "support" meant there'd be just a little bit of assistance involved. When I took the Planex out of the box and put it together, I lost even more of that cautious optimism as it is not a lightweight tool by any means--it's mostly metal and there's a considerable heft to it even without the extension tube added into the mix. I switched it on with the vac on high, approached a damaged, textured wall I didn't care about ruining and the thing sucked itself up against the surface so violently and so firmly that I could barely even move it let alone pull it away. Keeping the extractor dialed down to roughly half power is more than enough to keep the dust out of the air.While professionals who sand massive amounts of drywall in commercial installations on a daily basis should probably invest in the auto-cleaning dust extractor, if you're a homeowner who's just doing a room or four, one of the smaller, cheaper models with the HEPA certification will do just fine. If you happen to be digging into walls that may or may not have lead paint on them, I'd even go so far as to say that you're way better off with the cheaper ones in terms of safety. You don't really even need the fancy locking hose if you don't want to pay for it. The regular hose that comes with the regular dust extractors fits just fine and you have to give it a pretty good tug to pull it loose.Oh yeah, and the paper's like a dollar a sheet. That's less than Home Depot wants for a decent 5" disc.The price tag seems ridiculous, but ask a marginally competent drywall contractor how much they want to do one room and it's not so threatening anymore. Add in the fact that you won't have to evacuate the house, board the pets or spend the next year cleaning dust off of everything you own and I think it's a highly worthwhile investment regardless of whether or not you're a pro. Let the neighbors see you using it and then rent it out to them on weekends.

The blade you get with the TS55 isn't bad at all, but it cannot reliably rip 3/4" maple without bogging down and scorching. Festool recommends their "Panther" blade for this task, and while it will make the cut faster and without burn marks, your edges are going to be so horrendously scarred that you'll have to plane both edges down at least 1/16" to get rid of the roughness, so you have to plan to make all of your cuts 1/8" bigger than they really need to be, wasting more material and more timeI tried this Freud out in a hunk of the very same maple that gave the multi-purpose blade the fits and got *all* of the effortless speed of the Panther with none of the horrifyingly deep marks. To be sure, the edges I was left with needed some smoothing out, but it was nothing a few quick passes with a sanding block couldn't fix.The blade says it's got a 2.5mm kerf, but I cut it on a track with a splinter guard set up for a 2.2mm kerf and I didn't see any plastic come off of anything. Haven't gotten out the calipers to really scrutinize it, but in my anecdotal experience, it's a painless switch out with no need to shell out for another splinter guard for either the saw or the track.It's also cheaper and easier to re-sharpen. The geriatric "green Kool-Aid" purists infesting the FOG forums may sneer at it, but I find the Freuds I've used on several makes and models of different saws to be vastly superior to anything Festool's currently putting out blade-wise.

But if you wanted fast, dirty rip cuts, you probably wouldn't have blown your paycheck on a Festool saw.I didn't expect perfection from anything with this low of a tooth count, but the deep gouges this blade creates in both maple as well as the track's splinterguard are just unforgivable. Whatever time it saved me in making the cuts was negated dozens of times over as I planed the scars out of what is now some expensive scrap material because it ended up nearly 1/8" narrower than it needed to be. I'll hang onto it in case I ever find myself wanting to cut up some thick slabs of bamboo, but it caused far more problems than it solved for me.

If you use the ultra-thick FSG blades and adjust the guides properly, this thing really can keep the blade absolutely perpendicular even in material that is several inches thick. If you don't use the thick FSG blades, your results may vary greatly as it is still, fundamentally, just a jigsaw. Introducing the blade to the material still requires a practiced, steady hand as even the most outlandish of the swappable shoes are pretty conventional in design--not much contact length between the front of the shoe and the blade, so it remains pretty tough to tell when you've got it riding flat by feel alone.By far, the most interesting of the different shoes that can be slapped onto the bottom of the Carvex (not included in the base kit) are the one that can be formed into a V at varying angles and the one that slips onto a Festool guide rail. Unfortunately, using either one of these things means giving up dust collection as there is no way to affix the port to them. Of course, even with the obstructive shroud dropped, the dust collection port isn't as good as it is on many of their other tools, so you might not really care. The other shoe surfaces are kinda tough to feel much difference between them. I just keep the phenolic on and forget about the others most of the time.The strobe lights seem like a silly gimmick, but they really work pretty well at higher speeds and help you see where the teeth are in relation to your cut line. Anything below 3 and the time-stopping effect just isn't there. I'm not sure if it even tries to oscillate the LEDs when it's that slow--they seem to be on pretty steady.The zero clearance inserts are both a gift and a curse. While they keep you from blowing out the top of the workpiece, they also keep you from ejecting the blade. For me, this more-or-less negates the benefits of the tool-free blade ejector, as you still have to get in there with your fingers to pull the little piece of plastic out, and it doesn't exactly glide effortlessly. You *will* touch a hot blade at some point in this process, so gloves or a pair of needle-nose pliers are a must.The circle cutter that comes in the accessory kit is a really cool design, but I have concerns over its durability. Just pulling the tape out a couple of times results in lots of little curly-cues of clear coating scraping off of it at several of the contact points inside. Time will tell how long it holds up.If you need a jigsaw, you'll have a pretty hard time finding anything that beats this, and thankfully, Festool refrained from inventing a proprietary blade design--any T-shank blade will do. If you generally dislike jigsaws, I'm not sure the Carvex is revolutionary enough to change any minds. The improvements Festool's made over the mass-market players' offerings are substantial and noticeable, but I don't think anyone would fault you for saying something about lipstick on pigs.

I hated everything about this line. I'm not entirely sure how anything can be both too stiff to stay wound *and* too soft to last more than 30 seconds, but somehow, Cyclone figured it out. The rigidity itself I could have lived with if it worked at all, but since it didn't, the fact that it insisted on straightening itself out inside the head every time it stopped spinning caused the ends to suck themselves right back inside the cap at least six times in 20 minutes was intolerable. I resolved to just never let the head stop spinning to avoid this problem, but I then found myself having to bump it every three feet or so because so much of the line had been chewed off in the process of actually cutting weeds. I swapped it out with some cheap Black & Decker junk line I had sitting in a drawer just to make sure I hadn't somehow forgotten how to wind a trimmer spool or something, and whattya know, it worked beautifully and I only had to bump the head twice before I was done with the entire yard. This is one of the very few times in my life where I've found whatever's laying on the shelf at Home Depot to be vastly superior to pretty much anything else.

There's a fair bit of hyperbole involved in most of the "game changer" reviews you'll see out there, but it really is a well thought out piece of machinery that excels in situations where pocket screws fail, and I know of no other way to make an absolutely flawless locking Parson's joint in ten minutes or less. If you build enough stuff to even know what it is, then odds are good you stand to benefit from owning one. I like it a lot, but there are some things that really, really annoy me about it as well:1. The calibration process detailed in the manual is simply ridiculous. Rather than bother with any of that trial-and-error nonsense, take a little pocket sized square (Woodpeckers makes a good one) and line up the edges with the markings on the different surfaces. I really think Festool could do something to make this a whole lot easier, or at least put some degree of effort into setting it up correctly before they put it in the box.2. The spring-loaded registration pawls are great when you want them, but unbelievably upsetting when you don't. The XL lets you defeat these things, but the 500 does not. Aside from making it slightly more difficult to keep the tool flush against the surface to be cut, if you happen to have an edge that lands right at the point where that plastic starts to bevel, you're going to get frustrated enough to rip it out of there entirely.3. The fence height stops are of no particular value. Even if you happen to have a piece of stock that is exactly the same height as one of those stops, it's still easier to just let the fence drop until it rests on the surface and lock it down there. I think they added these things just to make people feel important when shooting YouTube tutorials about all the settings.4. You can only adjust the mortise width when the motor's running? Really? Why make it a huge green control begging people to touch it, then?5. It's not that easy to hold steady when plunging. Not impossible by any means, but it takes more practice than you'd expect it to. I've seen people swap out different, larger handles to assist with this, but I haven't tried it myself. A small dab of Silly Putty can supply some much needed friction here without marring anything.6. The power switch will pinch your fingers every time you shut it off. Would a plain old rocker switch really have killed some industrial designer's pride?7. The trim stop and extension bars are a little flimsy for the price. Sure, they're essentially half off in this set, but I wouldn't fault anyone for expecting more metal than plastic in something this pricey.The XL is a significant improvement in most of these areas, but I work small more often than I work large, so being able to use the 4mm cutter most folks seem to not take very seriously is more important to me in the long run.

The unboxing experience is pretty awful--there's no packing material whatsoever so everything scrapes against everything else, all of the stickers on the thing are half peeled off, and the head is only loosely attached so if you make the mistake of checking to make sure the motor works before you charge everything up for actual work, it's going to fly right off.Assembly instructions are not very clear at all, but there's only a few parts and only so many ways they can go on, so no big whoop. The usage instructions on the other hand are horrible and self-contradictory. One page tells you to NEVER use the trimmer with the motor positioned to your left side and then the illustration on the next page shows a dude using the trimmer with the motor on his left side. Great. Just do what any sane person would do and wear a heavy long sleeved shirt when trimming and forget about whatever nonsense the GreenWorks clowns felt like mashing into their keyboards that day.You get about half an hour's worth of trimming out of each battery charge if you keep the thing on high speed, and you should really keep the thing on high speed if you have anything bigger than a whisp of grass ahead of you. Charging it back up from empty takes about an hour and a half, so this is obviously not something professionals with lots of yards to do could ever rely on. Even after running it down on high speed from a full charge, I never found the motor anywhere near too hot to touch, so there's another reason I'm not going to pay attention to anything the manual says about which side I swing it toward.Once it gets going, it's almost as good as gas. The line is still a bit on the light side, but it plowed through some seriously thick clumps of foxtail-y things without a problem. It would probably do even better with a brush cutter blade in it, but there's another area where the manufacturer contradicts themselves all over the place. All their promotional materials show brush cutters being used, but there's a big sticker on the tool itself telling you never to install a brush cutter blade. What?Two things about using the thing actually bug me a lot: the buttons and the main trigger. Turning the power on and changing speeds is done via two small bubble switches, and if you're out in the sun and wearing hearing protection as I'd bet 99.9% of all users will be, it's impossible to know when you've actually pressed one of them because you can't see the LED or hear the little electronic chime. Add a pair of gloves into the mix, and you've got one seriously frustrating experience in store for you.The main trigger just isn't big enough to be used for long periods of time. My hands are pretty small but squeezing the trigger is something you can pretty much only do with your index and middle fingers. Doesn't seem like a big deal at all for the first five minutes, but after 10, you'll really start wishing you could use the rest of your fingers to help out.I have no regrets about purchasing it as I haven't seen anything better without a cord or a gas tank, but having put it through its paces, I'm not convinced the price tag is completely justifiable.

The adjustment wheel is tiny and very difficult to operate, but with this style of clamp you ideally won't be adjusting it very frequently, so that's not too much of an issue. By and large, it does exactly what it claims to and you can pretty much set it and forget it no matter how severe the thickness varies in your workpieces. What's a little annoying is the fact that you have to open the handle really, really far to get the jaws apart. That means you probably can't operate it one-handed unless you're an 8-foot tall basketball player, which is a little bit annoying. Whether that's more annoying than having to adjust the pressure repeatedly is largely dictated by the task at hand, so while I'm not getting rid of my other face clamps just because these came out, I do find them handy enough to justify the expenditure.

I use this on my frameless shower once a month and it keeps it from turning into a hideous nightmare quite nicely. Just scrub a little blob around with a Magic Eraser, rinse and move on. After that I clean up any remaining residue with some regular glass cleaner and a wadded-up newspaper. Yes, that residue is annoying, but I find it less annoying than the grit of Barkeeper's Friend that lingers in the shower pan for weeks.If you've had spots on your glass or mirrors for a long, long time, then the surface is more than likely etched and will require abrasive intervention no goop in a bottle can provide.

My experiences with the standard-issue ratcheting track clamps were not especially positive, but I thought I'd like them a lot better than this goofy thing. Turns out I was dead wrong. If you're cutting down 3/4" sheet goods with a single-piece track, this gizmo works a whole lot better and is much less error-prone to set up. No running back and forth from end to end to see if the track shifted while you were tightening one of the clamps down, and no amount of vibration knocks them loose. It is a little snug in the track, but it's not especially difficult to position, and you usually don't need to move it around a lot once it's on.If you're cutting thinner material, however--like sheets of polycarbonate--it's completely useless. The only thing I've found to really work well there is T-track mounted hold-down clamps on both the track *and* the plastic. That stuff likes to scoot around on you as soon as the teeth start biting into it, leading to jagged edges and kickbacks.

I hate random orbital sanders with a passion. The only reason I ever used one was to polish plastics and finishes with MicroMesh discs because they're just so profoundly underwhelming otherwise. Few of them ever remove enough material to be genuinely useful as sanders, they all suck at flattening, and you can never really get away from the horrible pigtails they leave all over the place. While most of them nowadays come with little dust bags or compartments, about five minutes worth of smoothing out an epoxy repair on a window sill is all it takes to cake them up so badly that they might as well not even be there.The Rotex sanders absolutely obliterate three of these problems and substantially reduce the rest. In Rotex mode, you're going to come very close to the aggression level of a belt sander on a lower speed. Not quite the same, but more than enough power to be dangerous. Thick layers of paint and/or silicone polish infested wood just vanish before your eyes. It is somewhat hard to control when it's up full speed, though, so two hands are pretty much required. It could definitely benefit from an accessory handle/knob on the head somewhere, but it's not too bad off without one.In eccentric/random orbital mode, you're still going to get a surprising level of aggression but the unit is much easier to control on high. You can still get some pigtails now and then, but they are nowhere near as prevalent as they are on Bosch or Makita's, and given the aggression level, you can get rid of them almost as soon as you switch grits. Whether this is due to the travel pattern or the abrasives, I'm not qualified to say; all I know is they're not a problem for me anymore, even in soft pine.Having an edge guard is an absolute godsend. The one in the box is just big enough to keep you from accidentally sawing into adjacent perpendicular boards, but others are available if you need even more clearance. It seems like a small, pointless detail, but I can't count the number of times I've accidentally cut a tiny little notch into something I then had to go back and fill, losing 8 more hours of potential finishing time as that stupid little repair cured.Switching over to the triangle pad is quick and painless and it does a much, much, much better job of sanding out corners than a plain vanilla oscillating multi-tool. It's not the most amazing corner sander you'll ever see in your life, but it is very good, and the convenience more than makes up for any of its shortcomings.Of course, the dust collection is a serious selling point for the remodeler/renovator. Put a good, strong vacuum on the end of this thing and you can sand right over uncovered carpet without fear. I still see a fair amount of dust collecting on the surface as I work with the RO 90, but it's not flying around and coating everything within a 100-ft radius the way it would with even a dumb vibrating sander. A respirator's still the best protection for your respiratory system, but if you're the kind of person who absolutely hates wearing them, you'll be much safer around the Festools than anyone else's so long as your vacuum's got an adequately fine exhaust filter. Noise levels are high enough to warrant hearing protection with extended use but the vibration is quite minimal. You can sand for an hour or so and put it down without feeling like your hands are still going at it.The downside is obviously the diminutive size. The RO 90 is mostly for cabinet/finish work where this is more of an asset than a problem as it ends up being much more versatile than some gigantic beast that wears out your shoulder and doesn't fit anywhere you need it to. It's completely unsuitable for a number of tasks, but if you *really* need to do huge table tops then you're probably much better off with something else--like a nice jointing plane instead of an electric sander.It's profoundly disappointing that Festool decided to raise the price on this thing *and* simultaneously take the abrasive sampler packs out of the box, but my local dealer was sympathetic and willing to throw some in for me. The hard pad is the only other must-have accessory I've seen for it, and it's pretty reasonably priced.

This router has a whole lot going for it, but I don't think it's for everybody. What it absolutely excels at is eliminating most of the guesswork associated with routing for you. There's a very clear center mark on every single face of the base so you can just line that up and go to town without fumbling around dividing a bunch of fractional measurements, and you can dial in depth adjustments with an utterly obscene amount of precision. Nothing in a blue or yellow housing can even come close to competing with Festool on these points, so if these are features you need, it's absolutely worth the cost. It's also got plenty of power to drive all but the heaviest of rabbeting bits, so don't concern yourself with its lack of a horsepower rating. It'll scorch pine on 3 so be careful.But if you don't need any of that because you're either not really into cabinetry or are just going to stick the thing under a table (something I wouldn't advise even trying with this model as it's not made for that at all), I don't think I'd let any of the other features sway me. Dust collection is nice, but come on... It's a router. Nothing is ever going to get it all. The one-wrench bit/collet changer does actually work unlike many others out there, but is it really hundreds of dollars worth of hard to use two wrenches? The plunge action is super smooth, but that's not entirely unheard of at lower price points, and the plunge lock knob is definitely not my favorite thing in the world to deal with. I had no trouble getting used to the unconventional handle at all, but twisting is one of the last motions you want to be performing when plunging down into something expensive, so I can't say I completely understand that design decision at all.Its ability to slide down a rail (if you purchase the optional accessory that makes this possible) is great, but not of as much value as it is with a saw. The one exception would be drilling shelf pin holes with one of their special rails geared toward this purpose. That is really fun to watch and makes me wish I'd gotten the rail with said holes when I bought my saw. The MFS rails (also not included) are so simplistic in concept that their value is easily dismissed, but they really are pretty nice to work with. I really wish they included the edge guide in the box. They give you the rods, but nothing to use them with. Those parts are not that expensive to make and they could really make the package a lot more attractive.As much as this tool is geared toward (and priced for!) hardcore pros, I honestly think it's best suited to beginners. If this had been my first router I know I would have gotten much less frustrated with the concept of routing in general. It's really a great tool, but most people can probably get by with much less.

I think it's perfectly fair to say that this is made primarily for finish carpentry. If you're framing a house or installing cable, then really, what's the point? Get a cheap hammer drill you're never going to worry about and get on with your life. Nobody likes a showoff.I do not, however, think it's fair to say that it's underpowered in any way at all. This thing generates plenty of torque and for much longer than any Makita I've owned in the last 15 years. Try punching several dozen 1" holes into 3/4" MDF with a forstner bit (yes, you *should* be using a router for that--so what?) and you'll need to recharge the Makita battery 2-3 times before you're done. Adding insult to injury, it'll only get worse after your first few dozen charges on the thing. How many batteries will you need to buy before the motor burns out? Probably more than enough to make up the price difference here.And let's be honest, the price is... Considerable. But considering the fact that you get two batteries (with 3-year warranties no less) and four, count 'em, FOUR different chucks in the box, it's really not as bad as it seems at first glance. Buy a good, regular drill and a right angle drill and you're out nearly as much money with two tools to store, and the right angle drill probably won't be cordless. With the Festool, it's all one thing and there's also an "eccentric" chuck for getting to those shelf and cabinet screws that end up landing right against the wall. Again, not a problem for house builders, but a serious problem for house livers and fixers. You're not going to use it all that often, but when you do use it, it's going to save you many hours of frustration and grief.The Centrotec chuck is just not that interesting to me. I understand the engineering benefits of their proprietary little system, but I also don't care. With the possible exception of the super-cool "stubby" brad point bits, the Centrotec accessories are crazy expensive for consumables, not that impressive in terms of selection or performance, and you can't buy replacements when they break or dull down. The quick change adaptors are also all complete trash. Luckily, there is absolutely nothing forcing you to ever use the Centrotec system if you don't want to. Obviously, there's the ratcheting chuck that works exactly like every other drill on the planet that you can always fall back on, and short driver bits fit directly into the nubs at the end of both the right angle and eccentric chucks. If you want to pop a Wera Rapidaptor into the ratcheting or eccentric chucks, it holds firm. No issues. It won't sit securely inside the right angle chuck, though. For that, you'll need to pop the ratcheting chuck on the end, which might cause clearance problems. Again, it's easy enough to slip a short bit straight in there in the case of ultra tight spots.With all of these benefits, plus the fact that you can find videos of people dunking them directly into buckets of water without any evidence of failure (no, I'm not trying it myself) I think it's worth it. I'm not ditching my impact driver any time soon, but it's a darn versatile drill.

This is a tiny, tiny, tiny fan. It's extremely quiet, but it also doesn't move an astounding volume of air. I have three Vornados of varying sizes, and the 133's highest setting is about the equivalent of all of their lowest. If you just want something on your desk or next to your bed to keep a little bit cooler without blowing everything around then this is great for that purpose. If you want to *really* get air circulating throughout a room--even a small one--you should look to one of their larger models first. They're only a little bit more expensive and you can always turn an overpowered fan down. You cannot turn an underpowered one up.

These are much smaller than your average T-track so you're not going to utterly destroy a piece of 3/4" MDF if you route a channel to slide them into and you can also use any cheap 1/4" hex bolt you grab off the shelf at Home Depot instead of special ordering some fancy stuff from Rockler or Woodcraft. Actually, the Kreg tracks won't accept those fancy T-track bolts at all because their heads are too wide to fit. I have no clue in the world what "Amazon Reviewer" got in his or her package, but if you *need* to use actual T-track bolts then look elsewhere.They don't come with mounting screws, but they are pre-drilled.

These work out OK if you're using them upside-down with the flat end going underneath the table through a hole of some sort, but if you're using them to secure a Festool track to a workpiece--especially with the parallel guides--they vibrate loose constantly. Doesn't really matter how tight you clamp them down, by the time you're close to finishing your cut, the track starts to move because one or both of these things has fallen down completely. Now you've just screwed up your cut *and* paid too much for a mediocre clamp. There are better alternatives out there for less money.

I saw this in the brochure that came with my saw. I looked at the price and laughed. I saw them in person once they finally started shipping to dealers. I looked at the price and laughed again. It's a piece of routed MDF on top of a plastic box. Anyone who's buying Festool products could probably make something similar in an afternoon or less, myself included.But I didn't make anything similar. Instead, I kept doing little random projects around the house where I found myself thinking "Man, I could actually use that stupid thing right now." After about the hundredth time thinking that, I ordered one, and I like it. I feel like a complete sucker every time I look at it, but I still like it. It holds a few clamps, marking rulers, pencils and pens and it stacks on top of my saw box. I drag it out for all the tiny little things I don't want to go setup a giant work surface for, and it's honestly great. I wish it were a bit deeper than it is, and I wish there were some way to make it stay stuck to the bottom of my saw's systainer while in transit (those little green latches only latch one side), but such is life.

I've had an original Jawhorse for several years, and while it's always been great, the latches for the legs were always really difficult to release (especially on cold days) and its maximum clamping width was occasionally a hindrance. It's unlikely that you're going to be buying sheets of anything that are too wide to fit in this model's jaws, and the leg latches are much, much, much easier to deal with, gloved hands or no. The overall finish is matte rather than glossy and has enough of a texture on it to help keep the thing from slipping out of your hands when they're greasy, and the third foot is also much wider and padded--both welcome additions. The new, smaller wheels make it much easier to turn when you're pushing/pulling it around on floors, but they still will not help you out if you're traveling down a dirt road or up some stairs.My two biggest gripes are both pretty minor:#1 Clamping a 2 foot sheet is very difficult. Anything smaller or larger is no problem at all, but at exactly two feet, you're right at the upper limit of what the sliding jaw in its default orientation can get a grip on. Slip it off and flip it around, and you'll notice that the jaw itself is longer than 2 feet, so it'll only clamp against itself before it comes anywhere near the edge of your board. You can get it to work, you just have to be really careful sliding the jaw back far enough without taking it off completely.#2 The pedal no longer holds the folded legs securely against the main body. There are little nubs there to keep them put, but you can wiggle past them very easily, which means carrying it by the feet of the main legs is not a practical option.I was debating whether or not there was any point in upgrading given the fact that nobody actively stocks these where you can see them, but I have no regrets at this point. My old one's going in the storage closet.Rockwell's quality control, unfortunately, still leaves a bit to be desired. Mine had some extremely sharp bits of welding slag on the legs that needed to be filed down and repainted, and one of the little clips on the rear foot that are meant to secure it in its folded position was bent completely out of shape at the factory before it ever went in the box. How can I tell? Because the part is severely deformed but the paint on its surface is absolutely perfect. Not worth going through the hassle of a return over by any means, but somebody should have noticed that when they were folding it up to go in the box.

Should these cost this much? Absolutely not. Are there any cheaper alternatives that do exactly what these do? Not right now there aren't. While they're certainly not appropriate for every clamping task, the ones they are appropriate for are normally very difficult to achieve with anything else. However ridiculous they may seem, once they save you a few hours of frustration and/or a trip to the ER, you won't miss that money.I'll be absolutely thrilled when the aftermarket knockoffs finally start hitting the streets for 1/4th as much, but until then, this is cheaper than I could make them for.

I didn't pay any attention to the lead rotation gimmick when I bought a bunch of these, I just grabbed them off the rack at the Japanese stationery store because they were closest to the register and went on about my business. Once I actually looked at the package, I thought I'd made a terrible mistake, but to my surprise, the "engine" actually works pretty darn well for normal writing. It does not take much pressure to actuate at all--which you can verify by watching the little white logo spin around through the circular window in the barrel--but obviously there is some amount of play in the lead as the gears do their magic. You're never going to notice this in the course of actual writing, but if you're looking for a drafting pencil that does not do this, then yeah, you'll probably be happier with something that's sold as a drafting pencil.While it's a little bit disappointing that only the lower part of the barrel is metal, its overall lightness is honestly quite nice for many rendering techniques which heavier pencils can make difficult.The eraser is tiny and useless, but I keep a kneaded eraser close by anyway, so I don't really care. I wish they made the 0.3mm version with the metal knurling, but the plastic ones are pretty good, too.

I've used dozens upon dozens of ratcheting screwdrivers and always felt like they did exactly what I expected them to, but none of them ever really became my go-to driver, and I definitely never shed any tears when they went missing. It's really difficult to articulate what exactly is different about this one, but it works so much better than all the others I've had that it's really surprising.It takes very, very, very little resistance to make the ratchet slip the way it's supposed to, so you almost never have to hold the shaft with your fingers to keep it from undoing your last turn. There's very little play in the bit or in the shaft when it's locked, so it's almost as solid as a regular screwdriver when you need it to be. Not solid enough to make it excel at prying open paint cans or the like, but hey, you're not supposed to use screwdrivers as pry bars, right? Nobody ever does that.The bits are not as super-hardened as they could be, so wear is definitely going to show after a while, but I haven't seen one chip or snap so far. Fiddling with the little bits is definitely a two-handed job, though, so if you're an electrician who's up on ladders all day long and frequently only have one hand to spare, I wouldn't bother changing up your toolbelt layout to accommodate this thing.

If you've been laboring under the notion that a 2D scanner would slow you down, this unit will definitely change your mind. It picks up even the tiniest of Data Matrix and QRCode symbols nearly as fast as you can push the button, and the Bluetooth transmission adds only a barely perceptible latency to the process. It's also really small and really light, so lugging it around your neck all day won't be all that bad of an idea. Its ability to pair with iOS devices right out of the box without masquerading as a keyboard is also leaps and bounds above most of the competition out there. If this is a feature you need, you'd be hard-pressed to do any better than this.But while it's generally an excellent scanner, it's still not quite the big fluffy bed of roses you might hope it to be. The seams on the thing are really large and jarringly sharp. The battery cover especially just seems like it was designed by someone who never actually saw the rest of the unit it was supposed to attach to. In addition to being uncomfortable, this makes it profoundly unsanitary as it traps dirt like nobody's business. What's the point in shelling out the extra cash for the "anti-microbial" version if it's just going to be a filth magnet anyway?The buttons are also a little too hard to press to be particularly ergonomic. Their covered bubble switch design obviously contributes to the units splash resistance, but try hitting that tiny power button with gloves on. Ain't gonna happen.And while it does indeed pair with iOS devices beautifully, the SDK Socket Mobile provides you with for developing applications that talk to it is, sadly, not so beautiful. The code and its accompanying documentation is very clearly written by someone who is neither fluent in English nor Objective-C, and by-and-large it's built in a way that makes it seem as though they're just mashing on buttons until the Xcode project builds before they say "ship it!" If I had to guess by the way the whole thing is architected, I'd say their engineers gave up on learning new things at least 20 years ago, but it *will* work if you're willing to spend the time struggling to decipher all of their incomplete examples loaded with semi-explanatory comments that make no sense and fail to reflect what is actually supposed to be going on in the code.All-in-all, it's a great little unit, but it could be so much better if they only took the time to sweat the details.

These are made to be replaced and replaced often. Even if yours is not damaged, as soon as you change blades, it's no longer accurate because you cut it flush the first time you used the track (if you didn't do that, then you need to read instruction manuals more often). As such, it's applied via a very non-permanent adhesive. If you leave it in a 150 degree truck all day, yes, it's probably going to fall off. The fact that it fell off doesn't have anything to do with the quality of the track or its accuracy, it just means you've failed to understand what it is you're working with. A can of WD-40 could very well explode in such an environment, does that mean it's not suitable for use by professional contractors or does it mean professional contractors should be able to figure out a better way to store it?Application's pretty easy given the ridge that's machined into the track, but there's no need to get it perfectly straight since the first thing you do with it is cut it parallel with the blade. Also, if you happen to switch from a 2.2mm and a 2.5mm kerf blade, you can remove and re-apply it a little further out to get one more use out of it when you go back to the 2.2mm.

It's a staple-bound pocket-sized notebook covered in hipster Futura that's full of plastic paper. As such, it's semi-indestructible and good for scribbling in when you might have wet and/or dirty hands. For me, that's when I'm working on cut lists for various materials in the garage rather than hiking through tundra, but it gets the job done.The paper takes pencil surprisingly well--even light strokes from a .3mm 2B lead are strikingly dark and legible, but erasing is very, very difficult. So difficult I've given up trying. That's the main reason I'm withholding a star.Inks are hit-or-miss since there's zero absorption. Unless you like tons of smudges, I'd avoid them altogether.

No, you're not going to get the brightest possible output for more than 10 minutes or so on a full battery charge, but if you're going to be spelunking for hours on end, you should probably consider carrying something bigger and heavier than a pocket-sized tactical light. For its size and weight, it's an incredible little light. There's plenty of heat dissipating metal, everything is very well machined and the switch feels pretty rugged.I got one to replace a Skilhunt that used an older CREE LED and was more difficult to use as it could only switch modes via head twisting. The Olight supports head twisting as well, but you can also double or triple tap the switch, and this is much easier to perform one-handed.
