You can leave it on low for the vast majority of the times when you just want to see under a cabinet or into a scratchy throat without blinding anyone and then double click it on when the power's out for the whole block. The strobe is genuinely seizure-inducing and not a slow blink as on some others I've tried.My only complaint is that it can't stand on its tail, but that's far from a dealbreaker for me.

This is a great thing to toss in your toolbox for dealing with some of the more frustrating fastener heads you're likely to encounter in the world today. While the handle is all plastic, it's pretty durable and unlikely to crack unless you take a jackhammer to it. The bit storage compartment glides smoothly in and out and is permanently captured inside the handle so it will never tumble out completely.The main thing I don't like about it is the difficulty associated with removing and inserting bits into both the shaft and the carrier. They're pretty easy to pop out of the carrier and really easy to pop into the shaft, but pulling them out of the shaft might require gloves or a pair of pliers depending on how clean/cold your hands are. Popping them back into the carrier is a little more delicate a process than I'd like and I usually resort to using my fingernails to push down on the end, which usually amounts to me stabbing myself under the fingernail.I also wish they'd included a few smaller sizes of tamper-proof torx bits instead of all the spanner bits. While the microscopic ones are most frequently used in consumer electronics where something this big is simply the wrong tool for the job, I've had to take apart some dishwasher inlet valves that needed something much smaller than a T-10. The only place I ever see spanner heads is on trains and busses that were built in the 70s.

Given the prevalence of acrylic tubs and shower pans which silicone absolutely will not adhere to under any circumstances, it is utterly baffling to me that contractors continue to use silicone to seal them. It usually lasts about a week before it starts to let go and let water seep through. If you're lucky, you see it happening. If you're not, the water goes behind your walls where it fosters fungal growth and all of the destruction associated with it.White silicone also yellows terribly within weeks and attracts dirt like a magnet. If you try to scrub it, it usually starts peeling off and the damage can only be repaired by removing ALL of it and re-applying. Since the only chemicals that will reliably dissolve silicone also dissolve most plastics and etch glass, this can take days of tedious labor.Lexel sticks to almost anything, does not attract dirt, resists mildew, stands up to normal scrubbing, and does not yellow at all. That last benefit *can* also be a bit of a downside as it's likely to remain a much brighter white than any of your tile or grout, but for the protection it offers, I don't mind at all. After three months of watching some bumbling contractors struggle to seal a frameless shower by globbing on mountains of GE II that just turned brown and fell off, Lexel saved the day. I now use it on every change-of-plane joint I see sprouting cracks and the only times it fails are the times when I fail to apply it correctly. Luckily, I can just cut out the bad spot with an X-Acto blade and re-seal. The results are absolutely seamless and it makes me very sad inside to know that I can't just go to a store and buy it off the shelf anywhere in California.On the down side, it stinks, it shrinks and it's incredibly difficult to work with. I shall now copy and paste an excerpt of my review of the clear version as all of it applies:1) Tape off the area surrounding the gap you want to seal with your favorite painter's tape. Preferably the delicate kind that pulls up quickly and easily.2) Cut your nozzle to run as fine a bead as you can possibly get away with and spend the extra two dollars on a drip-free caulk gun.3) Coat the end of a rounded tool of your choice (popsicle stick, toothbrush handle, spoon, etc) in wax. Wax is one of the few things on earth that Lexel will not stick to. This may seem unnecessary, but Lexel dries faster than you can shoot it and if it already has a bit of a skin on it by the time your finger hits it, you're just going to tear it all out and make a giant mess of rubbery little pills that look terrible.4) Put some rubber gloves on and get a container full of mineral spirits handy for accidental smears.5) Squeeze and run your bead for a foot or so. Run your tool along the bead at about a 30 degree angle, very lightly encouraging it into the gap you're trying to fill. Wipe off the excess frequently. If you wind up with voids, go back over it and repeat. If it takes you longer than 30 seconds to notice those voids, just let it dry the way it is and come back to it in a few hours.6) Move on to the next section and repeat.7) Remove the tape IMMEDIATELY. If you wind up with little lips where the tape pulled away, re-tool VERY gently to smooth them down. A soapy, wet finger may be best for the final touch.8) Crank the (cold) water on and test your work. If it leaks, wait half an hour and dab some touch ups on. If it doesn't leak, let it cure a day or two before you hit it with hot. Thermal expansion/contraction in anything it's trying to bond to can cause it to fail, leaving you with mystery leaks. This is mostly a problem wherever it touches metal.9) Profit.There's a rhythm to the application process that is nearly impossible to convey in writing, so I strongly recommend practicing on some extra/scrap tiles before going after the real thing in your bathroom or kitchen. Once you get it, you'll never want to use anything else.

These things block out just about anything you're likely to encounter during any construction/remodeling task or pesticide application session yet they aren't so restrictive as to leave you gasping for air if you really have to work in them. I use them for sanding, scraping, stripping, concrete drilling, finish spraying, painting, sealing, rug beating, and litter box changing, and nothing ever gets through. They can be a little bulky for working in extremely tight spaces, but I'd rather deal with that than fiberglass in my lungs.

I think it's completely unforgivable that Bosch doesn't include these things with every single router they sell, especially given the fact that no brick-and-mortar store sells them, forcing you to special order. Nevertheless, it's reasonably priced, fairly foolproof and isn't likely to break in any human lifetime.

While this edition is deserving of kudos for breaking all the basic C nonsense out into its own book, I feel as though the author is falling behind in many regards. I still think this is probably the best whirlwind tour of the OS on the market, but so many of the most important features that Apple adds get glossed over that I have to wonder whether or not Mr. Neuburg has actually used any of them. Storyboards? They get a few mentions, but not much in-depth coverage. UICollectionView? Just a few pages of discussion followed by a brick of sample code that does nothing of any value whatsoever. CoreAnimation? He does at least acknowledge its existence, but you're not going to be able to do too much with it if you don't go elsewhere for help.If you look at any of his actual work, it's fairly clear that Matt Neuburg is not one you'd ever turn to if you want an attractive, well-designed UI, and while that's all well and good, people who've stopped learning rarely make good teachers. Each successive edition feels more and more like he's just going through the motions.

For something that was "published" in 2013, having no mention of Varnish's grace or saint mode settings is somewhat unforgivable, even for an overpriced pamphlet like this. The smattering of examples that are given alternate between being oversimplified and pointlessly convoluted and there is ultimately very little in here that I would ever consider putting into production. I'm not a big fan of the official Varnish documentation, but it's free and it's a lot better than this. Save your money.

Had a few hairline cracks starting in some stucco over a structurally unimportant overhang on my house that weren't big enough to bother spending a lot of time on, so I ran some of this goop over them. While it goes on light gray and is immediately noticeable, once it's dry, it somehow manages to blend in well enough that you don't really see it so much unless you look for it. I had no problems getting it to stick to the painted surface, but smoothing it down is a little difficult given the amount of sand in it. Hardly unexpected since the sand is one of its selling points, but there is a LOT of it.I'm docking it a star just because the stuff won't stop coming out of the tube after you release the pressure, even in a drip-free gun. I know Sashco has the technology to do better in this department because Lexel never drips. I'd really like to see that design carried over into their other product lines.

Getting a regular hose onto a Festool product usually requires some combination of crazy adaptors and duct tape and the end result is usually bulky, binding and prone to slipping off midway through a cut, leaving you inhaling a jet stream of sawdust. Festool obviously sells a perfect solution, but the price tag is more than a little ridiculous.While you'll probably need an adaptor of some kind to stick this on the end of another hose rather than attach it directly to a non-Festool vac, it fits snugly on the tool end without an adaptor and isn't insanely heavy. If you want to use this on a Kapex or other tool that wants a Festool 36mm hose instead of their standard issue 27mm, the replacement end you want is called a "reducing sleeve" and is Festool part number FES-487721. Works absolutely perfectly for a fraction of the cost.

As an edge guide, it's plenty sturdy and very unlikely to break in anyone's lifetime, but the rods are a little short and the accuracy of the adjustments leaves a bit to be desired. As a dust collector, it's brittle acrylic that's VERY likely to break and doesn't really work all that well, but it's better than nothing.I only wanted it as a guide, so I'm perfectly content to pitch the dust collector part in the trash and get on with my life, but it does seem more than a bit overpriced for what you're getting. I wish there was a way to use the ultra cheap little guide they throw in the box with the Colt routers while it sits in the plunge base, but since there's not, there's this instead.

While this is a great marking ruler, it's made out of extremely thin gauge sheet metal and is packaged in a simple cardboard backed blister pack. When Amazon handles these, they get shoved into bubble mailers and those bubble mailers are invariably bent. Your ruler will be bent along with it, thereby robbing it of its accuracy.I don't think it's realistic to expect Incra to use heavier sheet metal for a product such as this, but I do think they could come up with a much better package for such a precision instrument than that of a Kenner Star Wars toy circa 1977.
Yup, 2" vinyl letters.  They stick ok.  No real issues.

Ended up needing to order (3) sets to fully cover (2) 8' wide sliding glass doors.  The ring style grommets at the top prevented me for using the full, advertised width of the curtain.  On an 8' wide window, it left me about a foot & a half short of "fully closed" so I ordered a 3rd set to use 3 panels on each window.  Not what I had planned but it is what it is.Material wise.  These are very nicely made, heavy duty, soft material.  They do block out the light and prevent sunlight heat very well.  We noticed a difference the next day!

Quite a nice sleeve for the money.  I use mine for a WAY different intended use; mine holds a cast iron skillet in the camper.  Keeps the skillet from rattling around the cupboard and prevents oils from leaching onto other items around it.  Perfect fit!

The rod is nice.  WAY, WAY TOO MUCH PACKAGING!!!  The manufacturer could easily cut the price in half if they got rid of, or offered this, in a basic packaging.  Yeah, for a glamour retail atmosphere, the packaging helps to sell the product.  Let's face it ... this is a basic, plain curtain rod!  Installation is easy once you figure out how to disassemble some of the parts (one endcap) and the order to reassemble the three shafts.  Worked fine, looks fine.  Too much packaging & a little overpriced because of it.

Fit a little on the larger side but very happy with it.  Get lots of great comments.  Material is good quality & average thickness for a shirt.  Felt like I got my monies worth.  Bought an XL; 1'm about 6'2 & 215#; fit a little baggy but I'm ok with that.

Makes oil changes far easier.  I just changed the oil in my EU1000i without this & there is oil down inside the plastic casing now that I cannot get to.  Add a little dust from he outdoors & it becomes a quick mess in there.  This will help GREATLY with the next oil change by extending the drain spout out beyond the plastic case.  This does not stay installed on the generator.  It is simply a threaded tube inserted where the dip stick is to aide in pouring out the oil.

Fun glasses.  The assembly methods are "ok" at best.  Super cheap frames with the El Wire CY glued to it.  There is a white haze where they glued it all together so it looks like something you would make at home on the kitchen counter.  The El Wire humms which can be annoying if you are in a quiet place ... I was NOT so it didn't bother me.  Three modes.

Fit a little on the larger side but very happy with it.  Get lots of great comments.  Material is good quality & average thickness for a shirt.  Felt like I got my monies worth.  Bought an XL; 1'm about 6'2 & 215#; fit a little baggy but I'm ok with that.

Fit a little on the larger side but very happy with it.  Get lots of great comments.  Material is good quality & average thickness for a shirt.  Felt like I got my monies worth.  Bought an XL; 1'm about 6'2 & 215#; fit a little baggy but I'm ok with that.

Fit a little on the larger side but very happy with it.  Get lots of great comments.  Material is good quality & average thickness for a shirt.  Felt like I got my monies worth.  Bought an XL; 1'm about 6'2 & 215#; fit a little baggy but I'm ok with that.

Fit a little on the larger side but very happy with it.  Get lots of great comments.  Material is good quality & average thickness for a shirt.  Felt like I got my monies worth.  Bought an XL; 1'm about 6'2 & 215#; fit a little baggy but I'm ok with that.

Great looking, unique design.  Each one is different so it won't look exactly like the one shown in the picture.  Mine looks more "camo" than "wavy".  I like it & get lots of great comments.  Material is average thickness.

Purchased to make gag gifts for the Playa.  Came shipped in a large plastic bag, un-assembled (which is perfect for me).  Found the ideal labels for them & made 90+ little gifts.  The order actually contained a couple extra tubes and a handful of extra caps.  Considering making more before I leave for the Playa next week.

Using these for lite-duty tie down on my camper trailer/text/awning.  These work good for my use.  The only downside is the gate opening on the clips; they have a small opening range so I may need to change out for larger clips or hooks.As for use within their intended marketing purpose, I think these would be great!  One thing to know is that the release latch is located on the ratchet which will, generally, be mounted at the highest point (ceiling).  To release, you will need a ladder to reach the release mechanism.  The installed clips on the hanger should fit a normal eye bolt installed on a light fixture.

Just what I needed for fast, easy install of a custom rail built to mount on top of my camper trailer.  The rail sections are secured together with 1/4-20 bolts to weld nuts inside the rails.  Using these knobs allows me to install/remove the rail without the need of tools.  Ordering another package now for spares!

The perfect item for my intended use:  I just completed a break install on a small home built trailer this weekend using a surge coupler and a 3/4-ton truck axle.  I installed this valve in-line so that, in the event of a failure, I could turn off the brakes between the coupler and the brake drums.  Also allows me to back the trailer without fussing with the 'reverse lockout' handle on the surge coupler.
Works as described.  Holds up well enough.  Great for general purpose sanding.  A finer grit should be used afterwards, prior to application of finish coat.
Works good.  Holds up well enough.  Ideal for heavy removal.  Should follow up with finer grit before painting.

I purchased one to roll some 1" EMT conduit.  First off, the die wasn't the "correct" size for 1" EMT.  It turns out that the dies included are perfect for 3/4", 1-1/4" & 2" EMT.  No problem ... we rolled 32 full sticks of EMT to build (3) 32' diameter shade structures.  Takes a little getting used to the operation to achieve the correct, repeatable bends for this type of job.  there is no form of "gauging" on the unit ... basically, bend it till you get to the right shape.  Over bend?  Bend it back a little by hand or start over.  Construction is "ok".  It is a Chinese import item and has the look and feel to follow a 'cheap import' type tool.  It paid for itself in the 1 use we needed it for.  Any use beyond this 1 project is a bonus.  Square dies for 3/4" square tubing are available separately.
Magnets need to be stronger.  Despite finding the very best location I could, I found that it shifted after a normal drive to work.  It's ok, but could be better.

The fit was a little snugger than expected (even as an XL) and the dexterity was a little less than I had hoped for.  Nice gloves never the less.  With the fingers were a touch longer (maybe 1/8-1/4" longer).
Fit the L5SK3 Skillet just right.  easy to get on/off.  Works well.

I like it but it is TINY!  I figured it was a 1-egg size but not so lucky.  I'm keeping it to use for a sauce pan in the camper trailer.  It was worth the $ as we all got a good laugh at the small size of it here at work.

I will start this off by stating that the product itself seems to be fine ... the big 'negativity' to the review is (once again) the WRONG photo on Amazon site.  The picture shown (as of 7/17/2015) is the 3-gallon version (which only holds 2.5 gallons).  The model you are PURCHASING does not have the little storage pouch shown on the front and is NOT rectangular; it is triangular.  Buyer beware that, once again, Amazon shows one thing & ships the buyer another!

Just what I needed.  I enjoy cooling on my bbq/smoker & this opens up the expanded ability to cook items such as sandwiches, eggs, bacon & pancakes without it all falling thru the grates.  Wish it had a storage case/bag since I store it inside the bbq on the trailer when not in use.  Care/handling/cleaning of this is no different than other cast iron cookware.

Having not been able to find a Jalepeno Corer locally, I turned to Amazon for this fast find!  Works great.  Far better than the peeler I was farced to use prior to this.  Easy to use, lite & effective ... especially on the long, deeper peppers.  Cuts my prep time WAY down using the right tool for the job.  The leading edges are scalloped and the backside of the blade is made similar to a peeler.
Work great.  No issue with fogging yet.  Buying a few more pairs for an upcoming trip to the Playa

The pants are nice, the fit is as expected but the quality of the sewing on the bottons was lacking.  When I opened the package, the top button was hanging by 2 threads, another couple buttons were not too far behind (from falling off).  Oh yeah, these are button fly by the way ... which for these very reasons I am not a fan of.  If they were pressed into the fabric like Levi jeans, I may not have an issue with them but they are sewn on like a shirt!  Now I'm having to pay to take these in to get the buttons sewn on the right way.

The blue is not nearly as pronounced as the picture would let it on to be.  The sport is SUPER light & quite strong.  I would have liked to see the fork teeth to be a little sharper & slightly longer but overall its a nice spork.

I received the hitch a few days ago and finally got up the courage to install it last night.  I've installed a few hitches on a few different vehicles in the past & they are, generally, bolt-n-go type assemblies.  This one requires a little more...The item arrived in a nice, oversized cardboard box secure inside by two wads of foam.  The instructions & hardware were securely taped to the receiver opening on the hitch.  The instructions are a simple, 1-page deal with only a handful of easy to understand steps.  The only step that was slightly unclear was the one pertaining to cutting the plastic skid plate/pan but more on that to come.  Hitch is well built & fairly hefty in weight.  The hardware was of proper size & all parts needed were included; including the pill wire but more on that to come.  The instructions are also available to download but here's a brief overview of what I did & what I can remember of the install:Remove the existing tow hooks under the front of the truck; 2 bolts each & they were firmly secured in there.  Cut opening in slid pan/plate.  I didn't clearly understand what part, or actually what direction, I was supposed to enlarge the plastic pan opening based on the directions since there were no pictures/images/illustrations so I took a little extra time to prop the hitch up to see.  It appears to only affect the two (small) plastic pans; one on left/right & not the main skid pan.  I removed both of those; 2 bolts & 2 screws each.  The plastic is soft & cut with relative ease using a sharp box cutter & tin snips.  I personally opened it up about 1" towards the front of the truck & about 1" towards the motor side of the opening.  Nut sure what purpose those two smaller pans serve (to the left/right of the main pan) - maybe they can be left off?  Quick re-install of both small plastic pans/guards.  Jacked the hitch up in place while balancing it on a small rolling jack (attempting the 1-person install).  Can be done with 1 person!  Two people would be faster/easier.  Once I got it in the general location, I installed (finger tight) the 4, 12mm bolts/washers.  Easy so far!  Torqued them to spec as noted in the 1-page instructions.  Next step required a drill.  Found a drill that fit the remaining hole thru the hitch.  Takes a 1/2" drill.  I suspect mine was closer to 17/32 or 9/16".  Whatever size it was, it was PERFECT!  Tip that worked for me:  Trying to drill thru the frame (using the hitch as the guide) can be tough, especially upside down in a fairly tight space.  I used my rolling floor jack, supported the butt of the cordless drill on the jack & jacked it up to provide lite pressure while drilling.  PERFECTION!The final step seems to cause the most grief & makes for the lower star ratings (which REALLY has nothing to do with the product itself).  As you can see by my pictures, they include a 'fish wire' that is setup for this intended purpose & appears to be well thought out.  The 'fish wire' attaches to  the coil of the bolt to pull it thru a small opening.  Took me less than 5 minutes to install BOTH bolts & here's what I did:Drill the holes (as noted above)Fish the wire, coil end first, thru the hole I just drilled & stuck my finger thru the access hole in the frame ~8-10" away to pull the coil thru.  This is the access hole that the cartridge bolt & plate will pull thru.Holding on to the loose end of the wire protruding thru the freshly drilled hole, I slide the square washer over the coil end of the fish wire & into the hole in the frame.  Gently screw the bolt to the coil (see pics below) till the bend in the coil touches the tip of the bolt.  Gently pull the loose end of the wire while feeding the bolt into the hole in the frame.  GENTLY pull on the fish wire & wiggle a little as needed till the bolt starts to come thru the hole.Twist the bolt a little till you fell the carriage head engage the plate.  Gently unscrew the fish wire from the bolt while gently applying a little downward pressure to keep the bolt seated.  Install the nut & torque to spec.Repeat on the other side.Total install time was about 1 hour!  Hitch is SECURE.  Sticker notes it is rated for 5000# towing & 9000# straight pull.  Has two large pull rings.  Happy with the install.  Happy I chose this over the other, which based on other reviews notes you have to remove the skid plate/pan.

My set just came in.  They are a little smaller than I had envisioned but big enough to match the feet on the bottom of my BAL stabilizers.  These can be stacked for extra height (and they nest into each other slightly to keep them from slipping apart).  The included strap to hold them together is useful.  Time will tell if these will be robust enough.

These coolers serve a specific purpose/use for me.  I will preference this by saying that, though they are insulated, these are not designed for long-duration cooling during such activities as camping.  These ARE great for single day or overnight uses like camping, hauling cold or hot items to/from parties, etc.  In short ... they lack really cool insulating capabilities like those found in larger coolers.The lid's are not attached & appear to be hollow (no insulation)With that being said ... here's why I like these!  The ability to stack these is GREAT!  When loading for a short trip or smaller, multi-day trips, the ability to stack them in a orderly fashion makes for better space planning.  Color coding - I buy these (and the 25 qt size) in different colors for different uses; cold/frozen stuff (like meats), dry goods (bread, chips, small cereal boxes), canned goods (perfect for canned good items!) and lastly, drinks (sodas, juice boxes, etc).  Some of these items get ice, others don't ... you get that though.  Makes for an organized load, organized camping or event, etc...Speaking on the topic of stacking ... also think home storage.  The ability to keep these stacked uniformly at home is critical to maximizing my storage.  How many times are you left with a bunch of coolers that are all mis-matched & they form a weird, leaning pile in your garage?  Final thoughts on storage ... After use & drying, I make sure & toss in a 'Fridge & Freezer' baking soda box in each cooler & it seems to keep them fresh for the next use.Just ordered 3 more!

Measurements (hole cutout) were ~50mm as they were noted to be.  The overall OD is 60mm.  The opening (pie shaped, textured piece) is secured to the removable cap & is spring loaded so you can rotate it out of the way to form an opening.  My only "issue" is the color .... they SURE do look tan/beige when I got them.  If you are looking for true GREY to match a GREY desktop, these are far from the correct color.  For me, this color is actually BETTER to match the marbled counter-top they go thru.  They are much thinner & lesser quality than the ones I purchased locally but they will work for my intended needs despite using a 2" holesaw to cutout the openings for these (they fit loose in a 2" cutout)
Nice fitting.  Great adjustments for head size & "flip down" tension.  Adjustable darkness control & delay time.
Good, snug fit.  Priced right.  Helped to keep my cables behind the tv as flat to the wall as possible & prevent kinking & bending.
Easy to install.  The right length for my needs at the right price.  Works as it should.  What more could you ask for in an item?

Poor ... Cheap ... Junk.I had bought a "cheap" version of this from my local sporting goods store & had hoped to pick up a few more like it thru Amazon.  The local one I purchased was less money & WAY better built.  It had a bungee 'hem' to help keep it pulled downwards towards the reel & a loop at the top to hand the rod (if needed).This one came in & it is nothing more than about 6' of wire loom wrap.  The end was melted to keep it from unraveling & then folded over on itself to form the rod tip entry hole ("the bell shape").  Nothing to keep the opening that "bell shape".  The rod tip end was held closed by a 1" long piece of heat shrink tubing melted to form a tip.Needless to say, I would NOT order another one of these from Amazon.  I will go look for more locally.

Great for the price.  Ordered the alternating set to ensure I have the right connector needed when I do the TV install.  These help to heep cords from kinking & make for a better, flatter/thinner cord profile against the wall.

Despite being an XL, the size ran a little on the small side.  I'm about 6'2" & 215# and this was "form fitting" in both arm length & chest.  Happy with the purchase never the less.  If you want it to fit over your regular shirt, you might want to consider ordering 1 size larger.  I could do without the "flames" on the arms though ...

Materials, instructions & assembly were all easy & right on the money.  My only complaint was that the kit referenced using 'locking nuts' & the kit did not include enough 'locking nuts' per the instructions (instead, it had regular nuts).  Installation took a little over 1 hour to do.  Finished product looks good & helped with "body roll".

Initial impressions are that this is an attractive piece of hardware, however a couple things I am missing from my 5 year old Iogear keybaord:  1--there's no "STOP" button.  I can play & pause, but that's not quite the same.  2--there's no scroll wheel.  That was the 2nd thing I missed from the Iogear keyboard when scrolling through long lists.  We'll see how "page down" works...  3--the batteries are not replaceable. I know that was in the description, but I'm a little concerned that I have a throwaway keyboard. I had my Iogear keyboard for 5 years and went through maybe 3 sets of AAA batteries. I can always put a new set of batteries in that, versus throwing away the entire keyboard.  I may return this and just order another Iogear keyboard....I do like the backlight, so I'll need to try this out a few days to see if I like the backlight more than the missing functions.Update after a couple days trying out--this keyboard is losing a couple stars because it's not very ergonomic to type on. It's downright uncomfortable for a touch typist, in fact. Key caps are flat, too close together and and completely undifferentiated. I really miss the trackball and super convenient mouse button placement on the IOgear keyboard.  I do like the backlighting on the logitech, but it's a night & day difference using the two keyboards side by side.  The I just printed a return label for this keyboard and ordered another IOgear GKM561R  keyboard. I've heard recent iterations of the IOGear keyboard might have some quality issues, so I have my fingers crossed.
These are the best toothbrushes I've ever used.  Soft and the bristles really do clean well between teeth. My dentist always says my mouth looks great.  :)

Bought this about 4 years ago for use on my home theatre PC. Great feeling keyboard.  The positioning of the trackball, scroll wheel and mouse buttons are intuitive and incredibly useful.  The dedicated multimedia keys work well. Batteries are replaceable and last many months. The only two things I do not like about this keyboard is that the trackball can be a bit finicky when your hands are very dry, and the backslash key is in the incorrect place. This key is used for mapping/browsing windows network drives. It's just something to get used to.I just purchased a Logitech K830 illuminated keyboard for twice the price because I'm moving some things around and need another keyboard. Logitech got great reviews but I'm probably going to return it to purchase a second ioGear.

Great size for small pills--just what I was looking for.  However, there are two things that are a problem.  First issue - there's no water-tight seal. The reason that is an issue is that a water tight seal not only prevents water from entering, but also keeps the cap on securely. The rubber o-ring provides a bit of resistance to the cap slowly working its way loose.  I do have an easy fix for this because I happen to have a bunch of keyboard o-rings that I bought for my keyboard. These work perfectly. Here's the link--I found the blue ones work best.  Cherry MX Rubber O-Ring Switch Dampeners Blue 40A-R - 0.4mm Reduction (125pcs)Second issue -  I wish the cap and the body were attached together with a small lanyard or chain. This isn't so much an issue as a wish list item because I have not found other products that have this feature. This would be beneficial to prevent dropping one or the other pieces.The size of pills it can contain is slightly bigger than the tiny nitroglycerin pill holder found at most drug stores, so this works better for me.I have tried several other versions of pill holders and found that this one best fits my needs so giving it a pretty good rating.
Used this to wire an in-wall Broan bathroom heater. This is exactly what I wanted so it will never be possible to leave the heater running

This was a great purchase and I'd buy it again.  It rates 5 stars because it's a great heater and fairly quiet, but there are a couple things that it should have. 1--there is no OFF switch.  You can turn down the thermostat to the  point that it will not come on, but there's no actual OFF setting.  In my installation I paired this with a Leviton LTB60-1LZ Decora 1800W timer so that I could hit a single button to turn it on for up to an hour and it will then shut off automatically. 2--when this heater is installed, you can choose to leave it at the full 1500 watts, or disconnect one of the heater element wires so that it runs at half power. I plan to add a small rocker switch to the front so that I can change the heat output easily.In my opinion, the #1 modification was essential, but #2 is just a nice to have that I probably won't use too much.

I fly most every week for work and the airline seats hurt my back because there's little to no lumbar support. I finally found this pillow and provides just enough support so that my back doesn't hurt. It would also work in a car or stationary chair, but for those uses I'd recommend just getting a small regular pillow since there's no need to deflate.The pillow self-inflated in 1-2 minutes. I found that I even needed to let some air out after the plane gained altitude. Inflate to about 50-75% of where you really want it and it should be just about right when you're in the air. It's easy enough to add or remove air either way though, so don't sweat it.The only downside is that this does not pack down to be terribly small, but it still fits in a carry-on easily.  When deflated and rolled up, it is the shape of a cylinder about 3" in diameter and about 5" tall.

I can definitely tell when I'm taking this. This testosterone booster really works. I've tried others from GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe and most of the versions with Tribulus do have an effect. This is pretty pronounced.
Great travel size. Amlactin is my go-to choice for dry skin body cream.
Great specs, form factor and build quality. I expect to buy a few more of these.
